title: Lana Del Rey: All 97 Songs Ranked
content:
25. â€œThe Other Womanâ€ (Ultraviolence, 2014)
First recorded by Sarah Vaughan, but made iconic by Nina Simone, both singers delivered â€œThe Other Womanâ€ with a certain distance. They sang as an impartial observer, or perhaps the wife, telling a sad morality play of a beautiful, loveless mistress. But Lana steps into the other womanâ€™s shoes, embracing the beauty of the melody, the lushness of her lounge jazz arrangement. Thereâ€™s zero separation between herself and the character sheâ€™s playing. Her voice quivers as she sings the closing lines -- â€œAnd as the years go by/ The other woman will spend her life alooooneâ€ -- as if theyâ€™re the last notes sheâ€™ll ever sing.
This is the same downtrodden figure of â€œRide,â€ â€œUltraviolence,â€ â€œShades of Cool,â€ who devotes herself to older men whoâ€™ll never really love her back. Sheâ€™s so trapped by two ideals, young and beautiful, that thereâ€™s nothing else to her. On Ultraviolence, love is the ultimate drug, true believers are addicts, and Lana Del Rey is their prophet. â€œThe Other Womanâ€ isnâ€™t just the final track on the album; it essentially exorcises Lanaâ€™s mistress character for good. Sheâ€™d never sing about herself in the same way again.
24. â€œYayoâ€ (Paradise, 2012)
On Paradise, â€œYayoâ€ feels distant, drenched in reverb, as Lana warbles over piano like a lounge singer. But the original acoustic guitar-led version, the most significant track on 2010â€™s Lana Del Ray a.k.a. Lizzy Grant, is so intimate that itâ€™s almost too sad to listen to. â€œYayoâ€ paints a stark portrait of a toxic submissive relationship: â€œI need you like a baby when I hold you/ Like a druggie, like I told you.â€ Her situation feels completely hopeless, but she persists with the charade: â€œLet me put on a show for you, daddy...â€ As the song ends, it feels like a beautiful death rattle. In either version, â€œYayoâ€ could be the most tragic song Lanaâ€™s ever written.
23. â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ (Born to Die, 2012)
â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ isnâ€™t the most grand or moving song on Born to Die, but it is the most accessible. Lanaâ€™s lyrics are fueled by desire, but unlike many of her early songs, thereâ€™s no literal sense of tragedy: â€œGot my bad baby by my heavenly side/ I know if I go, I'll die happy tonight!â€ The phrase â€œsummertime sadnessâ€ is seasonal -- it suggests a fever, a temporary affliction, a young love that knows itâ€™s fleeting. Glamorous, romantic, but not overwhelmingly sad, the music video was a perfect realization of early Instagram culture -- think girls in flower crowns at music festivals, shot through nostalgic, analog-style camera filters.
Initially Born to Dieâ€™s fourth single, it wasnâ€™t until 2013 that the Cedric Gervais remix made Lana the unlikeliest of mainstream pop stars. His version is hardly subtle, though itâ€™s not as hammer-blunt as much of pop or EDM at the time. Even in a different sonic landscape, over electro-house synths and 4/4 kick drums, Lanaâ€™s distinct vocals donâ€™t lose their personality. Though Gervaisâ€™ version was a bigger crossover hit at the time, it ultimately feels like it exists in an alternate universe -- Lana hadnâ€™t heard the remix until it was on the radio, and has never shown any affection for it in interviews. The original remains the definitive version. Itâ€™s far more representative of Lanaâ€™s musical sensibilities, and in one of the first signs of her reach within popular culture, even inspired a Bangerz-era Miley Cyrus cover.

title: Miley Cyrus, Ariana Grande y Lana del Rey revelan el primer adelanto de su nueva colaboraciÃ³n
content:
Miley Cyrus, Ariana Grande y Lana del Rey revelan el primer adelanto de su nuevo tema | Fuente: ComposiciÃ³n
Lana del Rey, Ariana Grande y Miley Cyrus conforman el sorprendente trÃ­o que pondrÃ¡ mÃºsica a las nuevas aventuras de la saga cinematogrÃ¡fica "Los Ãngeles de Charlie" a partir de este viernes, cuando vea la luz su tema "Don't call me angel".
AsÃ­ lo ha anticipado, Miley Cyrus a travÃ©s de su perfil oficial en Twitter, en el que ha colgado un brevÃ­simo extracto del videoclip que acompaÃ±arÃ¡ esta canciÃ³n, con las tres intÃ©rpretes vestidas de negro y luciendo unas alas.
SerÃ¡ el 15 de noviembre cuando se estrene en salas la nueva versiÃ³n de "Los Ãngeles de Charlie", con Kristen Stewart, Naomi Scott y Ella Balinksi en los papeles principales bajo la direcciÃ³n de Elizabeth Banks.
Toman el relevo asÃ­ a Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore y Lucy Liu, protagonistas en el aÃ±o 2000 de la anterior encarnaciÃ³n cinematogrÃ¡fica de estos personajes, que en realidad nacieron en televisiÃ³n en los aÃ±os 70.
#DontCallMeAngel official music videoğŸ‘¼ğŸ¼ Sep 13 Charlieâ€™s Angels Ariana Grande Lana Del Rey Publicada por Miley Cyrus en Martes, 10 de septiembre de 2019
Entonces las encargadas de poner mÃºsica a la pelÃ­cula fue otro trÃ­o, Destiny's Child, con el tema "Independent Women Pt. 1" y Beyonce, Michelle Williams y Kelly Rowland como integrantes de la formaciÃ³n.
Lana del Rey estÃ¡ de actualidad tras publicar hace solo unas semanas su aplaudido Ãºltimo disco de estudio, "Norman Fucking Rockwell".
Cyrus, por su parte, lanzÃ³ en mayo el EP "She Is Coming" y, tras su reciente y sonado divorcio del actor Liam Hemsworth, volviÃ³ a sorprender con el descarnado tema "Slide Away".
Ariana Grande, que ha ejercido de productora ejecutiva de la banda sonora de "Los Ã¡ngeles de Charlie" junto a Savan Kotecha, Ilya y Max Martin, lanzÃ³ en agosto su Ãºltimo tema inÃ©dito, "Boyfriend", y recibiÃ³ tres Video Music Awards de la cadena MTV por su Ãºltimo Ã¡lbum de estudio, "Thank U, Next" (2019). title: Sechstes Studioalbum von Lana Del Rey: â€You fucked me so good that I almost said 'I love you'â€œ
content:
Dass diese Frau den Mechanismus durchschaut hat, macht sie von Anfang an gefÃ¤hrlich. "Goddamn, man-child", flucht sie, "You fucked me so good that I almost said 'I love you'."
Mit diesen vergifteten Worten beginnt Lana Del Reys sechstes Studioalbum "Norman Fucking Rockwell!", und was man zum Auftakt hÃ¶rt sind die lÃ¤ssig wiegenden Akkorde einer klassischen Klavierballade, wÃ¤hrend die SÃ¤ngerin resigniert von ihrem Liebhaber berichtet, einem in ihren Augen kindischen Poeten, der sein Versagen wie alle MÃ¤nner mit dem Versagen anderer erklÃ¤rt. "Du bist bloÃŸ ein Mann durch und durch", singt sie, "den Kopf in den HÃ¤nden vergraben, ... die Wand vollquatschend, wenn die Party sich gelangweilt abgewandt hat..." Der einzige Grund, warum sie selbst noch bei ihm ist: "You colour me blue."
So einfach liegen die Dinge in Lana Del Reys Universum auch wieder nicht, dass sie nicht Zuflucht suchte in rÃ¤tselhaften Bildern wie diesem. Was ist gemeint mit dieser BlÃ¤ue? Ist es nur Synonym fÃ¼r eine melancholische Stimmung? Oder der Bluterguss, der als Zeichen hÃ¤uslicher Gewalt zurÃ¼ckbleibt? Was es auch sein mag, es fesselt die Protagonistin an ihren "sich selbst verachtenden Dichter".
Und so taucht man ein in eine komplizierte Welt aus in Hassliebe erstarrten Beziehungen, unerfÃ¼llbaren Erwartungen und amerikanischen Versprechen. Wo die Frau sich MÃ¤nnern an den Hals wirft, um ihre Traurigkeit in bindungslosen Ekstasen zu erschÃ¶pfen. Denn an ihre "DÃ¼sternis und Tiefe", wie Del Rey es einmal ausdrÃ¼ckt, reicht ohnehin kein LiebesglÃ¼ck heran.
Del Rey inszeniert sich als ZuckerpÃ¼ppchen mit ondulierten Haaren
Diese Tonlage war nicht zu erwarten, als die gebÃ¼rtige New Yorkerin 2011 mit einem Song Ã¼ber die Fixierung von Jungs auf Videospiele erstmals Furore machte. Ihr DebÃ¼talbum "Born To Die" besaÃŸ den sinisteren Charme eines Teenager-Dramas, bei dem hinter jeder Unbedarftheit eine Katastrophe lauert. Del Rey inszenierte sich als ZuckerpÃ¼ppchen mit ondulierten Haaren und in buntem Bikini. Ihre Songs waren bevÃ¶lkert von bÃ¶sen Jungs, die irgendwelchen Hollywoodfilmen entstiegen schienen und das sogar selbst zu glauben meinten. Das war so bewusst oberflÃ¤chlich angelegt, dass die folgenden Alben nur wie Variationen desselben schalen Als-ob-GefÃ¼hls wirkten.
Gewinnerin. Lana Del Rey (l.) auf dem Cover des preisgekrÃ¶nten Albums. Foto: Polydor
Nicht wenige Kritikerinnen warfen Del Rey Mitte der 10er Jahre vor, sich hinter Fassaden und kÃ¼nstlichen Figuren zu verstecken, ohne deren Lesart zu brechen.
Diesem Prinzip bleibt sie treu. Aber erstmals in ihrer Karriere, die sie mit dem ungeheuer produktiven AusstoÃŸ von sechs Alben in neun Jahren zu einem der einflussreichsten Popstars des Jahrzehnts hat werden lassen, entfaltet ihre Musik subversive Energie. Nicht nur, dass sie stilistisch an keinen derzeit herrschenden Trend mehr angebunden ist. Aus ihren filigranen, kunstvoll entschleunigten ErzÃ¤hlungen spricht eine Selbstachtung, die deutlich an Robustheit gewonnen hat.
Das fÃ¼hrt dazu, dass Songs wie "Venice Bitch" sich sensibel den "beautiful losers" nÃ¤hern und die Ausweglosigkeit ihrer Lage schildern, wÃ¤hrend es in "Fuck You I Love You" heiÃŸt: "Maybe the way that I am living is killing me / But one day I woke up like 'Maybe I'll do it differently'." Eines Tages, sagt sie sich, werde ich wieder aufwachen und wissen, dass es jetzt genug ist - mit diesem Kerl, mit dem Alkohol, mit Ausreden.
In einem langen Essay im "Guardian" Ã¼ber die weiblichen Idole des vergangenen Jahrzehnts betrachtet Laura Snapes die 34-jÃ¤hrige Lana Del Rey als eine Figur des Ãœbergangs. Ihr "purer weiblicher Blick" habe den Weg fÃ¼r die trotzigen Stars geebnet, die auf sie folgen und sich wie Rihanna, Janelle MonÃ¡e oder Solange energisch gegen Rollenerwartungen wehren sollten. Das hat dazu gefÃ¼hrt, dass sich in ihrer Welt mitunter gar keine Helden und Heldinnen mehr finden, auÃŸer ihnen selbst.
TatsÃ¤chlich hat Lana Del Rey sich nie von ihrer Obsession fÃ¼r amerikanische Archetypen gelÃ¶st. Sie schwimmt in den Bildern, die die USA fortgesetzt von sich selbst produzieren, wie in einem gechlorten Pool. Ihre Nachfolgerinnen stehen am Rand dieses Bassins, wÃ¤hrend sie Bahnen durchs Blau zieht, voller Hingabe an den Heroismus, den es bedeutet, sich als Amerikanerin zu fÃ¼hlen.
Produzent arbeitete zuvor mit Taylor Swift und Lorde zusammen
Mit Produzent Jack Antonoff holte sich Lana Del Rey 2017 einen Mann an ihre Seite, der mit seinen 35 Jahren nur unwesentlich Ã¤lter als sie ist zuvor Taylor Swift, St. Vincent und Lorde betreut hatte. Auch fÃ¼r Del Rey fand er genau die richtige Mischung aus IntimitÃ¤t, GrandiositÃ¤t und experimentellen FreirÃ¤umen. Obwohl die Klavierballade das dominierende Element darstellt, Ã¶ffnen sich die Arrangements immer wieder Classic-Rock-Reminiszenzen, pathetischen Pop-Hymnen und minimalistischen Beats. Und so sollte das Album Monate nach seinem Erscheinen Ende August 2019 in Jahresbestenlisten auftauchen und in manchen ganz oben stehen.
Mehr zum Thema Lana Del Reys Album â€Lust For Lifeâ€œ Das Ende der Tranigkeit
In "How To Disappear" spielt Del Rey den Wunsch nach AuflÃ¶sung durch, indem sie sich unter der gleiÃŸenden kalifornischen Sonne an die Seite eines Muskelprotzes platziert, der seinen KÃ¶rper an stÃ¤hlernen GerÃ¤tschaften trainiert. Sie, die Frau, bricht in TrÃ¤nen aus, weil das Leben so hart sei. Und er, der mit den Narben frÃ¼herer SchlÃ¤gereien im Gesicht gezeichnet ist, hat den Vorzug, eine Bierdose aufzureiÃŸen und "einfach nur da zu sein". Nichts geht mehr voran. So stellt sich Lana Del Rey das Verschwinden vor.

title: Soundcheck Award 2019: Frauen dominieren die Longlist
content:
Der Trend der vergangenen Jahre setzt sich auch 2019 fort: Abermals haben es vor allem Frauen in die Endrunde des Soundcheck Award geschafft. So sind diesmal Solange mit â€When I Get Homeâ€œ, Aldous Harding mit â€Designerâ€œ, Lana Del Rey mit â€Norman Fucking Rockwell!â€œ sowie die von SÃ¤ngerin und Songwriterin Adrienne Lenker angefÃ¼hrte Band Big Thief mit â€Two Handsâ€œ nominiert.
Der von Tagesspiegel und Radio eins vergebene Preis fÃ¼r das â€Beste Albumâ€œ wird zum elften Mal vergeben. Unter den bisherigen PreistrÃ¤gerinnen und PreistrÃ¤gern sind Neil Young, James Blake, Bilderbuch und Kate Tempest. Im vergangenen Jahr gewann Anna Clavi mit ihrem Album "Hunter".
Mehr zum Thema Soundcheck-Award-Verleihung Anna Calvi fÃ¼r "Hunter" ausgezeichnet
In die engere Auswahl kamen all jene Alben, die 2019 jeweils von den vier Teilnehmern des â€musikalischen Quartettsâ€œ als Hit bewertet worden waren. Die von Andreas MÃ¼ller und Torsten GroÃŸ moderierte Diskussionsrunde stellt freitags aktuelle PlattenverÃ¶ffentlichungen vor (21 bis 23 Uhr, Radio eins). In diesem Jahr umfasste die Longlist 21 Titel. Daraus wÃ¤hlte eine 50-kÃ¶pfige Expertenrunde die vier Kandidaten, aus denen nun eine Jury von Tagesspiegel und Radio eins den Gewinner ermittelt.

title: Lana del Rey anuncia disco para septiembre y se defiende de las crÃ­ticas por "glamourizar el abuso"
content:
Lana del Rey anuncia que lanzarÃ¡ nuevo disco en septiembre. | Fuente: EFE
Lana del Rey anunciÃ³ que el prÃ³ximo 5 de septiembre lanzarÃ¡ nuevo disco de estudio "Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass", en un mensaje en sus redes sociales que ha provocado mÃ¡s reacciones al defenderse contra quienes la acusan de "glamourizar el abuso".
â€œDoja Cat, Ariana (Grande), Camila (Cabello), Cardi B, Kehlani, Nicki Minaj y BeyoncÃ© han tenido nÃºmeros 1 cantando sobre ser sexy, andar desnudas, follar, engaÃ±ar...", seÃ±ala la artista "harta" de las crÃ­ticas de "escritoras e intÃ©rpretes alternativas".
En su defensa, afirma: "Lo que soy es una persona glamourosa que canta sobre realidades que estÃ¡n muy presentes y constituyen relaciones emocionalmente abusivas".
Lana del Rey rechaza que se la pueda considerar como una "no feminista" y reclama un espacio dentro del feminismo "para mujeres que son y actÃºan como yo, la clase de mujer que dice 'no' pero ante la que los hombres escuchan 'sÃ­', que es vapuleada sin piedad por ser autÃ©ntica y delicada, a la que le quita su propia historia y voz mujeres mÃ¡s fuertes u hombres que odian a las mujeres".
"He sido honesta y optimista acerca de las relaciones complicadas que he mantenido. Y asÃ­ es como es para muchas mujeres. Esa fue desgraciadamente mi experiencia hasta el momento en el que esos discos se hicieron", concluye en su largo discurso, en el que anuncia que esas mismas canciones aparecerÃ¡n en sus prÃ³ximos discos de poesÃ­a y tambiÃ©n en su citado nuevo Ã¡lbum.
Como ya habÃ­a anticipado, se tratarÃ¡ de un disco de "spoken word" (mÃ¡s recitado que cantado) y tomarÃ¡ el relevo de "Norman Fucking Rockwell" (2019), su sexto Ã¡lbum de estudio. Con este material, Lana del Rey se colÃ³ en las listas de los mejores discos del aÃ±o pasado y llegÃ³ a estar nominada al Grammy. En sus temas viajÃ³ del tormento sentimental a la esperanza siendo uno de los mÃ¡s populares "Fuck It I Love You".
En febrero pasado, fue noticia al verse obligada a cancelar su gira por Europa a causa de una enfermedad por la que habÃ­a "perdido completamente" la voz y ante la que deberÃ¡ retirarse temporalmente de los escenarios. (EFE)

title: Pop & Lyrik : Lana Del Rey, die ewige TrÃ¤umerin
content:
AuÃŸer Donald Trump glaubt niemand mehr an Amerika als Lana Del Rey. An ein Land, das weniger als politische Verwaltung besteht, sondern als Fiktion existiert, in Geschichten, die man sich darÃ¼ber erzÃ¤hlt. Und wie die Geschichten mÃ¼ssen auch die ErzÃ¤hler in keiner wirklichen Welt leben.
â€Ich habe mich als Elisabeth Grant vorgestellt und niemand hat auch nur mit der Wimper gezucktâ€œ, spricht Lana Del Rey im siebenminÃ¼tigen â€Sport Cruiserâ€œ, dem lÃ¤ngsten Text von â€Violet Bent Backwards over the Grassâ€œ, der gerade erschienenen Spoken-Word-Version ihres gleichnamigen Gedichtbands. Darin erzÃ¤hlt sie von Flug- und Segelstunden, und sie sinniert darÃ¼ber, wie sich kÃ¼nstlerische und fliegerische oder nautische Kontrolle zueinander verhalten und was das mit Elizabeth Grant, wie sie getauft ist, und Lana Del Rey, ihrem KÃ¼nstler-Ich, zu tun hat. â€Niemand sagte: â€šSie sind nicht KapitÃ¤n eines Schiffes oder Herrin der LÃ¼fteâ€˜ â€¦ FÃ¼r einen kurzen Moment habe ich mich mehr als ich selbst gefÃ¼hlt als je zuvor.â€œ Aber Elizabeth Grant scheitert schon daran, die Richtung des Windes zu spÃ¼ren. â€KapitÃ¤ne sind nicht wie Dichter. Sie suchen nicht nach Metaphern zwischen Himmel und Meer. Und als ich das dachte, wurde mir klar â€“ darum schreibe ich.â€œ
Dass Lana Del Rey ihre Texte als Gedichte verÃ¶ffentlicht, ist nicht wirklich Ã¼berraschend. Seit ihr nach etwas harmlosen FolkanfÃ¤ngen als Lizzie Grant als Lana Del Rey der Durchbruch mit melancholischen Streicherpanoramen und HipHop-Beats gelang, tauchte sie immer konsequenter in die Pop-Kultur der 50er- und 60er-Jahre des letzten Jahrhunderts ab, spielte sehnsÃ¼chtig mit Bildern zwischen Femme Fatale und MÃ¤dchen unter bÃ¶sen Jungs mit Mustangs und Gitarren. Die Texte spickte sie kunstvoll mit Anspielungen aus Literatur, Film, Musik auf eine Idee von Amerika zwischen altem Hollywood und dem All-American-Kitsch des Malers Norman Rockwell, nach dem sie vergangenes Jahr ihr letztes Album benannt hat. DarÃ¼ber wurde sie, so das Onlinemagazin â€Pitchforkâ€œ Ã¼ber das letzte Album, zu â€einer der grÃ¶ÃŸten Singer- Songwriterinnen der USAâ€œ. Mittlerweile gehÃ¶rt sie auch zu den erfolgreichsten, mit rund 20 Millionen verkauften Alben und milliardenfachen YouTube-Clicks.
Lana Del Rey verweist auf popkulturelle Ikonen
Immer mal umstritten ist dabei nicht zuletzt das seltsam nostalgische Frauenbild ihrer Musik, das sie als eine Art alternativen Feminismus verteidigt, der Platz â€fÃ¼r die zerbrechlichere und weichere Weiblichkeitâ€œ lasse. In einer Nussschale bekommt man dieses Weltbild hier im dialogischen â€Tessa DiPietroâ€œ. Del Rey schwÃ¤rmt Ã¼ber einen Live-Mitschnitt des Doors-SÃ¤ngers Jim Morrison von 1968, zweifellos ein â€bad boyâ€œ der Rockgeschichte: â€Das blaue Licht gab ihm eine Art Heiligenschein â€¦ definitiv wie ein Gott auf der BÃ¼hne.â€œ Worauf das GegenÃ¼ber, ihre HomÃ¶opathin, meint: â€Jim starb mit 27 â€“ such dir eine bessere Referenz zum Himmel.â€œ Und seine Texte seien Quatsch.
Verweise auf popkulturelle Ikonen gibt es, wie auf den Alben auch, hier hÃ¤ufig. Bob Dylan, Georgia Oâ€™Keefe, Sylvia Plath tauchen auf, als Projektionen und Hintergrund. ZÃ¤rtliche LiebesstÃ¼cke gibt es, in denen sie â€“ oft vergebens, scheint es â€“ auf die Balance zwischen der â€festen VertikalitÃ¤t der MÃ¤nnlichkeitâ€œ und einem Partner hofft, der â€meine Weite bezeugen kannâ€œ. Manchmal klingen die Texte etwas beflissen poetisch hergerichtet, manchmal hadert â€“ offenbar â€“ Lizzie Grant ein bisschen wehleidig mit den Folgen von Lanas Ruhm. Aber im Ganzen erkennt man einen prÃ¤zisen Blick und â€“ deshalb ist die HÃ¶rversion besser als das Buch â€“ ein feines Ohr fÃ¼r Rhythmus und Fluss der bis zur Prosa frei geformten Gedichte. Ihr GroÃŸpop-Produzent Jack Antonoff legt darunter Ã¼berraschend zurÃ¼ckhaltende AtmosphÃ¤ren aus Keyboards, Gitarre, Streichern.
Neben â€Sport Cruiserâ€œ ist das zentrale StÃ¼ck eine gut fÃ¼nfminÃ¼tige rhapsodische Anrufung von Los Angeles als wankelmÃ¼tige Mutter zu Beginn. Sie zeigt noch deutlicher als der Rest den Einfluss des Beat-Dichters Allen Ginsberg, der in den FÃ¼nfzigern wiederum Walt Whitmans Americana in die New Yorker Jazz-Moderne transponiert hat. â€Nicht ganz die Stadt, die niemals schlÃ¤ft/ aber auch nicht ganz wach/ Aber ganz sicher die Stadt, die trÃ¤umt/ wenn du mit TrÃ¤umen AlbtrÃ¤ume meinstâ€œ, ruft Del Rey und ringt um ihren Platz in der Stadt zwischen Glamour, Neon, Waldbrand und sozialer KÃ¤lte. Zum Ende des Albums und Buchs tauchen die Motive dieses Gedichts noch einmal auf, als Notruf fÃ¼r die amerikanische Kultur. â€Das Paradies ist ein zerbrechliches/ und es scheint nur schlimmer zu werdenâ€œ, spricht sie und stellt ihre Vision gegen die des â€megalomanen PrÃ¤sidentenâ€œ.
Mit dem teilt sie immerhin die Sehnsucht nach vergangener mythischer GrÃ¶ÃŸe, auch wenn ihre Pop-GÃ¶tter natÃ¼rlich nicht Indianer tÃ¶ten, sondern Filme und Musik schaffen. â€Ich bin eine TrÃ¤umerinâ€œ, spricht Del Rey. â€Meine TrÃ¤ume fÃ¼r das Land waren groÃŸ â€“ nicht fÃ¼r das, was es tun sollte, sondern dafÃ¼r, wie es sich anfÃ¼hlen kÃ¶nnte.â€œ Gesungen, muss man sagen, hÃ¶rt sich das aber doch besser an.
â€Violet Bent Backwards over the Grassâ€œ von Lana Del Rey ist als Buch (Simon & Schuster) und als Musikalbum (Universal Music) erschienen.

title: Lana Del Rey talks screaming, being an underdog, and new album in Jack Antonoff interview
content:
Lana Del Rey goes deep with her super-producer buddy Jack Antonoff.
After sharing an update from a video shoot last week, Lana Del Rey has offered more details on her new album, Chemtrails Over The Country Club, as part of a cover story for Interview magazine.
Chemtrails was originally due last Friday - that didn't happen but LDR says the album is "incredibly close" to being finished.
The chat is conducted by close collaborator Jack Antonoff, who has produced the new record after doing last year's Norman F**king Rockwell and Del Rey's spoken word album Violet Bent Over Backwards In The Grass.
As you'd image, it's a very friendly conversation, with LDR offering insights into individual tracks, as well as touching on clubbing with folk legend Joan Baez, mental health, and her last romance.
There's a lot to unpack, so it's definitely worth diving into the full interview here, but here's some highlights.
She wants a song where she "screams [her] head off"
Right now, Lana says, the album is sounding "really, really good, but I don't know if it's perfect, and that really bothers me." She notes that her poetry and personal life have distracted her this year.
She's considering adding "one more defining song", titled 'Dealer', where "I'm just screaming my head off," she explains. â€œPeople donâ€™t know what it sounds like when I yell. And I do yell.â€
'White Dress/Waitress' sounds like a highlight
She calls it a "defining moment" for the album, and reveals the track was recorded at Jim Henson's studio while "being watched by a giant Kermit."
"I loved that," she says. "What I like about the song is that for all of its weirdness, when you get to the end of it, you understand exactly what itâ€™s about."
"I hate when I hear a song that has a great melody, but I have no idea what theyâ€™re talking about. In the grunge movement, a lot of the lyrics were super abstract, but the melodies and the tonality were such a vibe that you felt like you knew exactly what the singer was thinking. Nowadays, you get a beautiful melody but you donâ€™t really know what the person is talking about, or if itâ€™s even important to them."
The title track is about her siblings and girlfriends
Listening back to Chemtrails Over The Country Club reminds Lana of her "stunning girlfriends [and] my beautiful siblings."
"'Chemtrails...' is the title track because it mentions them all and it mentions wanting so much to be normal and realizing that when you have an overactive, eccentric mind, a record like Chemtrails is just what youâ€™re going to get."
Mid Year Report: triple j's 20 most anticipated moments in music Here's our list of upcoming releases and musical events that'll help carry you through the rest of the garbage fire of a year it's been.
"I've been really stressed about this album"
Norman F**king Rockwell was arguably Lana's most critically adored record, and she began working on the follow-up almost immediately, even though she wasn't entirely clear of the direction.
"From the top, we knew what Norman was. But with Chemtrails, it was like, 'Is this new folk? Oh, god, are we going country?' Now that itâ€™s done I feel really good about it."
She calls it a very "Midwestern-sounding" record, and it doesn't look much to her past but "more like where I'm going," she explains. "It makes me anxious listening to it, because I know itâ€™s going to be a hard road to get to where I want to be, to do what I want to do."
She still views herself as an underdog
â€œIâ€™m not the kind of artist whoâ€™s ever going to get justified,â€ Del Rey tells Antonoff at one point. â€œI will die an underdog and thatâ€™s cool with me.â€
That sounds a bit rich coming from a hugely popular decade-defining artist with multiple chart-toppers and awards to her name, but it comes as part of a spiel about how Lana "was always right" about the darker sides of relationships.
â€œI subscribe to the idea that whatâ€™s going on in the macrocosm, whether it be in the presidency or a virus that keeps us isolated, is a reflection of whatâ€™s going on in the individual home and inside bedrooms and what people intimately talk about,â€ she said.
Later, she notes: â€œIâ€™m not saying itâ€™s more relevant than ever, but my concern for myself, the country, the world â€” I knew we werenâ€™t prepared for something like this, mentally.â€
It's the closest the interview comes to addressing the controversial Instagram post that saw Lana getting dragged earlier this year.
Challenging times are good for culture
Towards the end of the chat, Del Rey and Antonoff begin waxing about the current state of the world and offer up some optimistic thoughts about how 2020's global issues can positively shape the future.
"If we can get this right culturally, we can open up a few decades of the greatest music and the greatest dance and the greatest theater and the greatest human interaction," Antonoff says.
"Thereâ€™s no way weâ€™re going to get it wrong. Weâ€™re really on the right path," Del Rey responds. "The #MeToo movement was not just a passing movement. Black Lives Matter, no way in hell thatâ€™s going away. People talking out about mental health, thereâ€™s no way theyâ€™re not going to seek even more genetic testing to find out what theyâ€™re predisposed to."
"All the scariness and worriedness and disappointment at the same time is like being in a big rocket that is shooting us into a new emotional place, and weâ€™re going to come out of it and be like, 'I donâ€™t want to go shopping. I need to go talk to somebody about something."

title: Lana Del Rey: Die Leute drehen durch!
content: Die 35-jÃ¤hrige SÃ¤ngerin ist davon Ã¼berzeugt, dass man derzeit - ausgelÃ¶st durch die globale Pandemie - tiefer in sich selbst schauen mÃ¼sse, wÃ¤hrend man im Lockdown isoliert sei. Da es keine alltÃ¤glichen Ablenkungen gibt, wÃ¼rden die Menschen verzweifelter denn je werden, so Lana. Im 'Interview'-Magazin erklÃ¤rt die Musikerin ihre Theorie: "Ich glaube, dass es seit einiger Zeit eine existentielle Panik gibt, aber die Menschen haben sie sich nicht bewusst gemacht, da sie so beschÃ¤ftigt damit waren, sich Schuhe zu kaufen. Und Schuhe sind toll. Ich liebe Schuhe. Aber jetzt, da man nicht shoppen gehen kann, musst du dir deinen Partner genau ansehen und dich fragen 'Ich lebe seit zwanzig Jahren mit dir, aber kenne ich dich wirklich?' Dir fÃ¤llt auf, dass du dir nie erlaubt hast, deine OberflÃ¤che anzukratzen, denn wenn du tiefer gehen wÃ¼rdest, kÃ¶nntest du einen kleinen Zusammenbruch erleiden, einfach so, und kein Reden wÃ¼rde dagegen helfen."

title: Lana Del Rey: 'Les gens paniquent car ils ne peuvent pas faire de shopping'
content:
Selon Lana Del Rey, le coronavirus a crÃ©Ã© un vide existentiel chez les gens car ils ne peuvent plus se distraire en "achetant des chaussures".
La chanteuse s'est confiÃ©e Ã  Jack Antonoff Ã  ce sujet, expliquant que le confinement a provoquÃ© une crise de nerfs parmi les gens qui utilisaient initialement le shopping comme faÃ§on d'oublier leurs problÃ¨mes.
Elle a dÃ©clarÃ©: "Je pense qu'il y a une certaine panique existentielle depuis dÃ©jÃ  longtemps mais les gens n'y ont pas prÃªtÃ© attention car ils Ã©taient trop occupÃ©s Ã  acheter des chaussures. Et c'est mignon, les chaussures. J'adore Ã§a. Mais maintenant qu'on ne peut plus faire du shopping, il faut regarder son partenaire et se dire 'Je vis avec toi depuis 20 ans, mais est-ce que je te connais vraiment?'. Les gens rÃ©alisent qu'ils n'ont en fait qu'une notion minime de qui ils sont car s'ils essayaient d'aller plus loin, ils auraient une mini crise de nerfs sans raison, et ils ne pourraient pas expliquer pourquoi."
Aux yeux de l'artiste, la panique est inÃ©vitable pour tout Ãªtre humain, mais elle avoue Ãªtre consciente que les gens la critiqueront pour ces propos.
"Ã‡a fait partie de notre composition gÃ©nÃ©tique", a-t-elle poursuivi, "Certaines personnes sont simplement du genre Ã  paniquer. Je pense que beaucoup de gens sont comme Ã§a."
Lena a aussi admis que d'aprÃ¨s elle, le virus est une "rÃ©flexion" de ce qui se passe Ã  l'intÃ©rieur de nous.
Elle a continuÃ©: "Je souscris Ã  l'idÃ©e que ce qui se passe dans le macrocosme, que ce soit le prÃ©sident ou un virus qui nous force Ã  nous isoler, est une rÃ©flexion de ce qui se passe chez nous, dans nos chambres, une rÃ©flexion de ce dont les gens parlent."

title: Lana Del Rey Tells Jack Antonoff How She Got Joan Baez to Perform 'Diamonds & Rust' With Her
content:
Lana Del Rey chatted with her famed songwriter Jack Antonoff about her upcoming album Chemtrails over the Country Club for the cover of Interview Magazine Tuesday (Sept. 8).
With almost nine hours left of her road trip from Oklahoma to California, Del Rey answered Antonoff's questions about her year-long journey between releasing Norman F---ing Rockwell!, her sixth studio album which peaked at No. 3 on the Billboard 200, to wrapping up Chemtrails. But as she took a trip down memory lane, Antonoff inquired about how she brought Joan Baez with her onstage for a special duet of Baez's hit "Diamonds and Rust" last October.
"On the last tour, we went to Berkeley and I really wanted to do 'Diamonds and Rust' with Joan, and she was kind enough to accommodate me. Nobody necessarily wants to show up to do a giant show for 15,000 kids at Berkeley, but she told me that if I'd drive out 80 miles from Berkeley, then we could practice at her kitchen table, and if it was good, she would do it," the 35-year-old singer-songwriter recalled. So thatâ€™s what I did. She corrected me on all my harmonies, and by the end, it was great."
But the real kicker was what happened after their scream-worthy performance. "Then we went out clubbing to this Afro-Caribbean two-step place and danced all night. She f---ing outlasted me," she said.
As the "Doin' Time" singer ties the loose ends of her current project that'll be released at an unknown date this month, she discussed two of the defining tracks, "White Dress/Waitress" and "Chemtrails over the Country Club." She started the first while playing the piano at The Muppets creator Jim Henson's studio, where Antonoff noted they were "being watched over by a giant Kermit."
"What I like about that song is that for all of its weirdness, when you get to the end of it, you understand exactly what it's about. I hate when I hear a song that has a great melody, but I have no idea what theyâ€™re talking about," Del Rey said of "White Dress/Waitress." "In the grunge movement, a lot of the lyrics were super abstract, but the melodies and the tonality were such a vibe that you felt like you knew exactly what the singer was thinking. Nowadays, you get a beautiful melody but you donâ€™t really know what the person is talking about, or if itâ€™s even important to them."
And the latter titular track doesn't signal where she's been before, but where she's headed and who's been by her side along the way, from her girlfriends to her siblings to her dogs, cats and chickens. "'Chemtrails' is the title track because it mentions them all and it mentions wanting so much to be normal and realizing that when you have an overactive, eccentric mind, a record like Chemtrails is just what youâ€™re going to get."
Del Rey plans to drop the single "Let Me Love You Like a Woman" ahead of the album, which she teased in an Instagram video last Tuesday (Sept. 1) that she filmed on the set of the "Chemtrails over the Country Club" music video. She'll also release her debut poetry book Violet Bent Backwards over the Grass on Sept. 29.
Read the rest of Del Rey and Antonoff's Interview cover story conversation here.

title: Lana Del Rey Talks With Jack Antonoff About Imminent Album, Pandemic
content:
Lana Del Rey has not given up being an Angeleno, but she talks about living a different kind of life in frequent stays in Oklahoma in a new cover story for Interview magazine. The singer also goes deep into the subject of mental health issues during a pandemic â€” hers, and the worldâ€™s â€” as she chats with Jack Antonoff, the producer of her forthcoming album, â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ which additionally comes up for lengthy discussion in the new Q&A.
As is Interview magazineâ€™s custom, the star is interviewed by a friend â€” in this case, Antonoff, who also collaborated with her on 2019â€™s â€œNorman Fâ€”ing Rockwellâ€ â€” who probes in mutually agreeable areas but leaves other burning questions alone. (For now, the biggest burning question among fans is: When is â€œChemtrailsâ€ coming out? The introduction to the story says â€œthis month,â€ but a Sept. 4 date that was previously on the books for the album release has already come and gone. Del Reyâ€™s label, Interscope, has said it has no firm date as of now.)
Itâ€™s not clear when the interview was conducted, but it did find Del Rey and Antonoff at a moment when work on the album was not yet completed. And it finds the producer catching the singer on the phone as she road-trips through the American Southwest. â€œIâ€™m on the I-40 with 8 hours and 50 minutes left to get back to L.A. Itâ€™s been a long drive back from Oklahoma,â€ she tells Antonoff. Later, she says, â€œSometimes Iâ€™ll go into a gas station on Route 66, mask on, glasses on, yada, yada, and the teller will be like, â€˜Oh my gosh, youâ€™re that singer!â€™ And Iâ€™m like, â€˜What the hell? How did you even recognize me?'â€
Why Oklahoma? Del Rey isnâ€™t asked and doesnâ€™t say, but she has previously been known to be dating Tulsa police offer and â€œLive PDâ€ star Sean Larkin (even though, in a Larkin interview in the New York Times in March, he described the then-current state of their relationship as â€œjust friendsâ€). Whatever the reason for her current visits, Del Rey says, â€œIâ€™m driving back from there and I didnâ€™t want to leave.â€
Antonoff wonders â€œif weâ€™re going to be making records in Tucson or Tulsa next year,â€ and Del Rey answers, â€œItâ€™s funny, the record was Midwestern-sounding before I even went to the Midwest. Whatâ€™s interesting about having a true muse â€” and it sounds kind of ridiculous â€” is that youâ€™re at the whim of it. When Iâ€™m singing about Arkansas, even Iâ€™m wondering why. The one way I would describe the Midwest, Oklahoma in particular, is that itâ€™s not cooked or oversaturated, and thereâ€™s still space to catch that white lightning.â€
As for that new album, Del Rey says â€œweâ€™re incredibly closeâ€ to finishing it â€” at whatever point the interview might have been conducted â€” despite â€œhow much Iâ€™ve been distracted by poetry this year.â€ (Del Rey recently released her first book and audiobook of poetry, â€œViolet Bent Backwards Over the Grass.â€) â€œIâ€™ve been really stressed about this album,â€ she admits, almost in contrast to Antonoff saying the making of it felt looser. â€œFrom the top, we knew what â€˜Normanâ€™ >was. But with â€˜Chemtrails,â€™ it was like, â€˜Is this new folk? Oh, god, are we going country?â€™ Now that itâ€™s done I feel really good about it, and I think a defining moment for this album will be â€˜White Dress/Waitress.'â€
Thatâ€™s one of three specific songs she mentions â€” another being â€œDealer,â€ an outlier whose fate was still TBD as of the interview. â€œThe one thing that makes me upset is that if I hadnâ€™t been so distracted with my personal life and my poetry, I couldâ€™ve broken it down in a more delicate, precise way,â€ she says. â€œI guess the way I couldâ€™ve done that is just by adding one more defining song to it. Right now itâ€™s really, really good, but I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s perfect, and that really bothers me. I think I need to add that song, â€˜Dealer,â€™ where Iâ€™m just screaming my head off. People donâ€™t know what it sounds like when I yell. And I do yell.â€
And yet, at other points in the interview, Del Rey comes down on the side of anti-shouting as she emphasizes her love of melody. â€œThe one thing that I know that I can do regardless of where Iâ€™m at in my process is make a beautiful melody,â€ she tells Antonoff. â€ I donâ€™t really care if you mush an amazing life story into an alternative record. If the melodies donâ€™t stun me, I kind of donâ€™t care. I think itâ€™s interesting if youâ€™re yelling and shouting and talking about where youâ€™re going and what itâ€™s been like, but to me thatâ€™s not a record. Thatâ€™s a therapy session. â€¦ Itâ€™s a diary you should read for Audible or something.â€
As she did in a controversial series of Instagram posts during the summer â€” a subject that goes unremarked upon in the interview â€” Del Rey speaks about her own fragility, as a real thing and not an image construct, and she also refers to panic attacks.
â€œEvery ex I have, every girlfriend I have, every family member I have, even the ones I donâ€™t speak to â€” they know the ins and outs of why I sometimes catch sheer panic out,â€ she says. â€œIâ€™ll say, â€˜Today was a bad day and itâ€™s because of you, and I donâ€™t even know you anymore.â€™ I donâ€™t necessarily think thereâ€™s much value in doing that â€”i tâ€™s just whatâ€™s true. I donâ€™t ever feel bad for saying to someone, â€˜Iâ€™m having a panic attack because of what youâ€™ve done.â€™ Thatâ€™s black-belt life, like 3.0. Whatâ€™s insane is that the pandemic has brought up all of these mental health crises and domestic crises that were always there, that I always sang about, that people had so much to say about in terms of, â€˜Sheâ€™s just feigning emotional fragility.â€™ And itâ€™s like, â€˜Well, not really. Youâ€™re feigning emotional togetherness despite the fact that youâ€™re a wack-job Monday through Friday.â€â€
Del Rey takes some comfort in the general populaceâ€™s awareness of its own anxiety possibly having caught up with hers during the pandemic. â€œI donâ€™t feel like Iâ€™m doing okay. I just know now that I was always right,â€ she says. â€œI think thereâ€™s been existential panic for a long time, but people havenâ€™t been paying attention to it because theyâ€™ve been too busy buying shoes. And shoes are cute. I love shoes. But now that you canâ€™t go shopping, you have to look at your partner and be like, â€˜Iâ€™ve lived with you for 20 years, but do I even know you?â€™ â€¦ I got a lot of sâ€” for not only talking about it, but talking about lots of other things for a super long time. I donâ€™t feel justified in it, because Iâ€™m not the kind of artist whoâ€™s ever going to get justified. I will die an underdog and thatâ€™s cool with me. But I was right to ask, â€˜Why are we here? Where did we come from? What are we doing?â€™ â€¦ I also think itâ€™s a really good thing that weâ€™ve gotten to this point where we have to bump up against ourselves, because itâ€™s not going to be the same when the Beverly Center reopens.â€
Del Rey also recounts for Antonoff the experience of having Joan Baez agree to sing the â€™70s hit â€œDiamonds and Rustâ€ on a tour date last year. That involved a small bit of compulsory road-tripping. â€œNobody necessarily wants to show up to do a giant show for 15,000 kids at Berkeley, but she told me that if Iâ€™d drive out 80 miles from Berkeley, then we could practice at her kitchen table, and if it was good, she would do it,â€ Del Rey recalls. â€œShe corrected me on all my harmonies, and by the end, it was great. Then we went out clubbing to this Afro-Caribbean two-step place and danced all night. She fâ€”ing outlasted me.â€

title: Interview Magazine
content:
â€œNot the kind of artist whoâ€™s ever going to get justified,â€ she says. Photo: Xavier Collin/Picturegroup/Shutterstock
Lana Del Rey has two No. 1 albums and six Grammy nominations to her name, regularly works with some of the biggest names in music, and made what many considered to be some of the best music of 2019. Yet here the singer-songwriter-poet is on the cover of Interview magazine, talking with partner-in-crime Jack Antonoff, calling herself â€œan underdog.â€ â€œIâ€™m not the kind of artist whoâ€™s ever going to get justified,â€ Del Rey told Antonoff. â€œI will die an underdog and thatâ€™s cool with me.â€ The comments came as part of a longer rambling about how Del Rey â€œwas always rightâ€ about, well, everything. â€œI subscribe to the idea that whatâ€™s going on in the macrocosm, whether it be in the presidency or a virus that keeps us isolated, is a reflection of whatâ€™s going on in the individual home and inside bedrooms and what people intimately talk about,â€ she said. Later, she added, â€œIâ€™m not saying itâ€™s more relevant than ever, but my concern for myself, the country, the world â€” I knew we werenâ€™t prepared for something like this, mentally.â€ It wouldnâ€™t be the first time we called her a prophet.
Elsewhere, she and Antonoff didnâ€™t shed much light on new album Chemtrails Over the Country Club, which was supposed to be out September 5. Describing the sound, Del Rey said, â€œIt was like, â€˜Is this new folk? Oh, god, are we going country?â€™â€ As for tracks, she said she thought â€œWhite Dress/Waitress,â€ which Del Rey and Antonoff recorded at Jim Hensonâ€™s studio, would be â€œa defining moment.â€ Another song, â€œDealer,â€ which may or may not have been added to the track list, features Del Rey â€œjust screaming my head off.â€ â€œPeople donâ€™t know what it sounds like when I yell,â€ she said. â€œAnd I do yell.â€ And the title track is about her â€œstunning girlfriendsâ€ and â€œbeautiful siblings,â€ who inspired a lot of the album. The album as a whole sounds like the Midwest, added Del Rey, a self-proclaimed Angeleno. â€œItâ€™s not cooked or oversaturated, and thereâ€™s still space to catch that white lightning,â€ she said of Oklahoma, debatably part of the Midwest. No word on what brought her back there, though.

title: Miley Cyrus propone l'idea di un gruppo con Billie Eilish e Lana Del Rey
content:
Miley Cyrus sta vivendo un momento particolarmente intenso ed Ã¨ definitivamente tornata sul palcoscenico musicale dopo un periodo di stop. La popstar Ã¨ tornare a fare parlare di sÃ© col singolo â€œMidnight Skyâ€ uscito ad agosto ed eseguito durante gli MTV Music Awards con una performance unica nel suo genere. Pochi giorni fa si Ã¨ poi divertita durante il programma â€œLive Loungeâ€ di BBC Radio 1, eseguendo la cover di â€œMy Futureâ€, lâ€™ultimo singolo di Billie Eilish.
Lâ€™artista statunitense sta lavorando al suo settimo album e sembra molto interessata a collaborazioni con altri cantanti. Lâ€™interprete della hit â€œWrecking Ballâ€ ha parlato a lungo di un possibile featuring con Dua Lipa, tanto che le due ragazze hanno anche pubblicato una foto che le ritrae insieme in uno studio di registrazione. Sempre durante la sua ospitata a BBC Radio 1, la 27enne ha lanciato lâ€™idea di formare un super gruppo con Billie Eilish e Lana Del Rey. Unâ€™idea ambiziosa e che sembra avere delle fondamenta, anche se non sarÃ  semplice metterla in atto in un futuro molto vicino.
MILEY CYRUS E Lâ€™IDEA DEL SUPER GRUPPO
Miley Cyrus ha espresso la sua opinione su questa ipotesi proprio quando ha eseguito a suo modo â€œMy Futureâ€, modificando anche una parte del testo e prodigandosi in una linguaccia proprio sul finire della sua performance. La cantautrice ha dichiarato: â€œLana Del Rey Ã¨ stata la prima cover che abbia mai fatto al Live Lounge e ora sto facendo Billie Eilish. Qualcuno una volta ha detto che io, Billie e Lana dovremmo fondare una band chiamata Billie Rey Cyrus. Secondo me Ã¨ una buona ideaâ€.
LE ULTIME NOTIZIE SU CYRUS, EILISH E DEL REY
Miley Cyrus ha recentemente confessato di avere abbandonato la dieta vegana dopo sei anni perchÃ© ha dovuto introdurre del pesce nelle sue abitudini alimentari, dato che il suo cervello â€œnon stava piÃ¹ funzionando a dovereâ€. La bionda di Nasvhille Ã¨ apparsa in grande forma agli MTV Awards e il suo ultimo singolo sta riscuotendo un buon successo.
Billie Eilish ha interpretato la colonna sonora di â€œ007 No Time to Dieâ€, il 25esimo capitolo della saga di James Bond che uscirÃ  nelle sale italiane in pieno autunno. Lo scorso 30 luglio ha pubblicato il suo ultimo singolo â€œMy Futureâ€ e il successo Ã¨ stato travolgente, la 18enne si Ã¨ esibita anche durante la convention democratica.
Lana Del Rey uscirÃ  in autunno col suo nuovo album intitolato â€œChemtrails over the Country Clubâ€, lanciato dal singolo â€œLet Me Love You Like A Womanâ€. A marzo 2021 pubblicherÃ  il suo secondo libro, dal titolo â€œBehind the Iron Gates â€“ Insights from the Institutionâ€. La 35enne statunitense ha giÃ  collaborato con Miley Cyrus in â€œDonâ€™t Call Me Angelâ€, parte della colonna sonora del film â€œCharlieâ€™s Angelâ€.

title: Lana Del Rey, pubblicato il video del nuovo singolo "Let Me Love You Like A Woman"
content: I fan attendevano dal primo settembre lâ€™arrivo di una nuova canzone di Lana Del Rey (FOTO). La stessa artista aveva annunciato che avrebbe pubblicato un brano intitolato â€œLet Me Love You Like a Womanâ€ e il 16 ottobre ha mantenuto la promessa. "Let Me Love You Like a Woman" Ã¨ la prima canzone del prossimo album di Lana Del Rey â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€. La stessa artista aveva preannunciato lâ€™arrivo del suo nuovo progetto discografico per il 5 settembre, ma ad oggi non si conosce ancora la data di uscita. Dall'uscita di â€œNorman Fucking Rockwell!â€ album che ha fatto conoscere il talento di Lana Del Rey in tutto il mondo e che le ha permesso di conquistare la sua prima candidatura nella categoria di album dell'anno nell'ambito dei Grammy Awards 2020, la cantante ha dato vita a numerose collaborazioni. Ha partecipato con Miley Cyrus e Ariana Grande alla colonna sonora di Charlie's Angels "Don't Call Me Angel" e tra i tanti progetti ha pubblicato le cover di "For Free" di Joni Mitchell , "Don't Think Twice" di Bob Dylan (insieme a Joan Baez), â€œI'll Follow You Into the Dark" dei Death Cub For the Cutie e â€œI'll Be Home for Christmasâ€ (con Kacey Musgraves). A luglio ha invece pubblicato la versione audiolibro della sua nuova raccolta di poesie â€œViolet Bent Backwards Over the Grassâ€.

title: Fans Choose Lana Del Rey's 'Let Me Love You Like a Woman' As This Week's Favorite New Music
content:
Lana Del Rey's "Let Me Love You Like a Woman" has topped this week's new music poll.
Music fans voted in a poll published Friday (Oct. 16) on Billboard, choosing the 35-year-old singer's classic romantic ballad as their favorite new music release of the past week.
"Let Me Love You Like a Woman," Del Rey's first single from her upcoming album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, brought in 72 percent of the vote this week. It beat out new music by Justin Bieber and Benny Blanco ("Lonely"), Demi Lovato ("Commander in Chief"), G-Eazy featuring Blackbear ("Hate the Way") and others.

title: Lana Del Rey Unveils 'Let Me Love You Like a Womanâ€™
content:
Lana Del Rey is finally giving the first taste of her upcoming album Chemtrails Over the Country Club.
The singer released the project's first single, "Let Me Love You Like a Woman," on Friday (Oct. 16). The drop comes just a day after Del Rey announced the song alongside a vintage-inspired black-and-white cover art.

title: First Stream: New Music From Justin Bieber & Benny Blanco, Lana Del Rey and More
content:
Justin Bieberâ€™s 2020 output has generally leaned toward the optimistic: on his album Changes and recent single â€œHoly,â€ the superstar sings about the comfort of marriage and finding peace after battling demons. On the affecting â€œLonely,â€ however, he revisits those subjects that once bedeviled him, somberly looking back on the moments of his career in which â€œeverybody saw me sick / And it felt like no one gave a s--t,â€ as a piano line steadies his ache. Super-producer Benny Blanco has worked with Bieber multiple times before, most notably on the acoustic-pop hit â€œLove Yourself,â€ and for this reunion, theyâ€™ve also corralled Finneas to co-produce these particular shades of gray. Listen on Amazon Music
Listen on Apple Music
Listen on Pandora
Listen on Spotify
Listen on TIDAL
Listen on YouTube Music
The Song That Will Sound Great While Driving Down a Highway:
Lana Del Rey, "Let Me Love You Like a Woman"Â
Lana Del Reyâ€™s first new song since her brilliant 2019 album Norman F--king Rockwell represents the sound of comfort: trying to convince her romantic partner to drive away from Los Angeles with her and forge a simpler life, Del Rey is offering an existence of care and devotion, in exchange to be talked to â€œin poems and songs.â€ â€œLet Me Love You Like a Womanâ€ is classically romantic but always understated, as Del Rey operates over piano and slide guitar provided by frequent collaborator Jack Antonoff and delivers a vocal take thatâ€™s confident in its power to hypnotize. Del Rey has become similarly unflappable as a songwriter, and her latest is a fully realized continuation of a remarkable creative run. Listen on Amazon Music
Listen on Apple Music
Listen on Pandora
Listen on Spotify
Listen on TIDAL
Listen on YouTube Music The Remix That Youâ€™ll Want To Play Very Loudly In Your Car:
Sada Baby feat. Nicki Minaj, "Whole Lotta ChoppasÂ (Remix)â€
Nicki Minaj has hopped on a countless number of songs as a guest artist, but never before has she announced her arrival on a track by exclaiming, â€œNine months motherf--king pregnant, like what!â€ This remix to Detroit rap savant Sada Babyâ€™s slowly-going-viral hit â€œWhole Lotta Choppasâ€ has been blessed with an extended cameo from Minaj, recording just before she became a new mom and dropping references to the Black Lives Matter movement, vaping and Milwaukee Bucks star Giannis Antetokounmpo in a matter of seconds. Sada Baby wisely cedes the first half of the new version to his guest, then comes in, unfurls his own top-notch wordplay and reminds us of the originalâ€™s magic. Listen on Amazon Music
Listen on Apple Music
Listen on Pandora
Listen on Spotify
Listen on TIDAL
Listen on YouTube Music The Song Thatâ€™s More Effective Than Lots of Cable News:
Demi Lovato, "Commander in Chief"Â
Aside from the obvious risk of alienating fans with different political views, releasing a song titled â€œCommander in Chiefâ€ that decries a president who may very well be voted out of office in less than a month, is a move that could be precarious when it comes to the shelf life of that song. Fortunately for us, Demi Lovato doesnâ€™t care about such trivial matters, and has dropped a beautifully scathing ballad at a moment when the pop world needed her sense of urgency. â€œWonâ€™t give up, stand our ground / Weâ€™ll be in the streets while youâ€™re bunkering down,â€ she sings, crafting a message for the moment as well as a song that will endure as one of her most undeniable vocal takes to date. Listen on Amazon Music

Listen on YouTube Music The Album That Checks In With a Hip-Hop Great:
T.I., The L.I.B.R.A.
Any rap fan who was around in the second half of the 2000s knows to never discount the magnetism of T.I., who can nod to a front-to-back classic full-length like 2006â€™s King or a hits-packed mega-seller like 2008â€™s Paper Trail. New album The L.I.B.R.A. (an acronym for â€œThe Legend Is Back Running Atlantaâ€) posits Tip as the still-dynamic king of the south who has no problem sharing the stage with the next generation of ATL titans, as Lil Baby, Young Thug and 21 Savage are among the guest-packed lineup. T.I. is convincing on these flashier collaborations, but the highlight here is â€œHow I Feel,â€ a reflection on protesting, police brutality and growing up Black that features Killer Mike and Eric Bellinger. Listen on YouTube Music The Song That Takes Aims At The Liars and the Dirty, Dirty Cheats:
Lauv & Conan Gray, "Fake"Â
Back in March -- a month that feels like it occurred several years ago! -- Lauv and Conan Gray both released their respective debut albums, How Iâ€™m Feeling and Kid Krow, and those full-lengths have endured as two of the more accomplished pop showcases of 2020. Now, the singer-songwriters have intertwined their rise with â€œFake,â€ an anthem against everything two-faced, with a shout-along chorus and some charming lyrical details -- Lauv is sick of all the social media sanitizing, while Gray could go without the drunk dialing thatâ€™s brushed off the following morning. â€œFakeâ€ represents a pairing that makes sense on paper and is even more compelling in practice. The Album To Show Your â€™90s-Loving Older Sister:
Beabadoobee, Fake It Flowers
For those who only know British-Filipino singer-songwriter Beabadoobee from Powfuâ€™s viral hit â€œDeath Bed (Coffee For Your Head),â€ which sampled her track â€œCoffee,â€ get ready to learn a lot more with Fake It Flowers, one of the most exciting pop-rock debuts of 2020. Beabadoobee spends the album synthesizing a myriad of genres -- indie-pop, grunge, even a little emo -- as well as harkening back to â€˜90s alternative music queens like Liz Phair and PJ Harvey. Although Beabadoobee wears her influences proudly, her perspective is fresh and vibrant on Fake It Flowers, on radio-ready flare-ups like â€œWorth Itâ€ and on chugging, gloriously noisy ballads like â€œSorry.â€ Listen on Amazon Music

G-Eazy feat. Blackbear, "Hate the Way"Â
After leading hits like â€œNo Limitâ€ and â€œHim & Iâ€ back in 2017, G-Eazy has taken some artistic detours in recent years, most notably on this yearâ€™s alternative-leaning album Everythingâ€™s Strange Here. With â€œHate the Way,â€ a new collaboration with Blackbear, the rapper has refocused his aim back toward top 40, deploying an ultra-catchy hook and spinning a tale of an imperfect romance that he just canâ€™t quit. Blackbear makes for a capable sidekick while leading the chorus, but the sound of G-Eazy, cozy in the lane that made him a star, should excite fans for whatever comes next. Listen on Amazon Music

Paris Hilton, "I Blame You"Â
Fourteen years after dropping the still-potent â€œStars Are Blind,â€ Paris Hilton has a few more tricks up her finely tailored sleeve: the veteran DJ has released a new single thatâ€™s ripe for the dance floor, whenever those reopen. â€œI Blame You,â€ a collaboration with the producer LODATO, finds Hilton delivering breathy vocals and making room for an animated beat drop that powers a straightforward hook. Hilton has spent the past decade developing an impressive live resumÃ©, and â€œI Blame Youâ€ makes for a fun check-in with a seasoned star -- and, yes, another excuse to fire up â€œStars Are Blindâ€ on our preferred streaming service. content:

approfondimento

Sulle note del suo inedito "South Dakota", alle Audition (Cosa Ã¨ successo nella prima puntata di Audizioni: IL VIDEO), il ventunenne livornese porta a casa quattro sÃ¬ e i complimenti non scontati dei giudici. Emma davanti ai suoi occhi vede una "bellissima persona con una bellissima storia da raccontare. E con una battaglia che tu hai giÃ  vinto ma che potresti combattere per altri". La voce di Amami si riferisce al vissuto del concorrente che ammette la sua passata difficoltÃ  nel mostrarsi agli altri per ciÃ² che Ã¨: â€œprima di trasferirmi in Inghilterra avevo paura di far vedere chi sono veramente, ma qui mi sono reso conto di chi voglio essere. Non possiamo essere influenzati dal giudizio degli altri". Mika lo guarda con ammirazione, â€œla cosa che mi ha colpito Ã¨ questa voce che Ã¨ cosÃ¬ grande che ti dÃ  l'impressione di abbracciarti". I giudizi sono unanimi anche questa volta, nel corso della seconda parte di Bootcamp, Blue Phelix passa il turno con Video Games di Lana del Rey, una delle sue canzoni preferite. Da dietro le quinte arrivano i commenti di Alessandro Cattelan e i giudici non coinvolti nella scelta, Manuel, a cui Francesco ricorda Prince (nel look), non apprezza la scelta del pezzo, nÃ©, a suo dire, la terribile versione, â€œma lui Ã¨ comunque bravissimoâ€.
Lo switch con enrico
Emma, compiaciuta per lâ€™esibizione, chiarisce subito che il palco di X Factor Ã¨ molto pericoloso, â€œma tu sei piÃ¹ pericoloso di quel palco, il tuo talento Ã¨ evidente, devo darti una sedia e fare uno switchâ€. La tensione sale, Ã¨ ad Enrico che tocca abbandonare la gara. Cattelan dissente e anche gli altri giurati non sono dâ€™accordo sullâ€™eliminazione del concorrente. Ma i giochi son fatti, Emma si congratula con la sua squadra e chiede da parte di ognuno il massimo impegno. Raggiunti i suoi compagni di viaggio nel backstage non nasconde il dispiacere di aver mandato a casa diverse persone, â€œÃ¨ dura dire di noâ€.

title: Poesie: Die unterwÃ¼rfige SexualitÃ¤t der Lana del Rey
content:

title: Lana Del Rey: Shitstorm wegen falscher Corona-Schutzmaske
content:
Bei Stars schaut man doppelt genau hin. Wenn ihnen Verfehlungen passieren, dauerts nicht lange und es tobt ein Shitstorm. Aktuell erlebt Popstar Lana Del Rey einen solchen â€“ wegen einer gelÃ¶cherten Maske.
Instagram 1/7 Popstar Lana Del Rey trÃ¤gt eine gelÃ¶cherte Glitzermaske.
Instagram 2/7 So las der Popstar bei der Lesung in Los Angeles aus seinem Gedichtband vor.
Instagram 3/7 Von Abstand keine Spur: Lana Del Rey posiert mit einem Fan Wange an Wange.
6/7
JEAN-GUY PYTHON 7/7 Im Juli 2019 trat Lana Del Rey am PalÃ©o Festival in Nyon VD auf.
Klar, es sieht gut aus. Ãœber dem Gesicht von Popstar Lana Del Rey (35, Â«Video GamesÂ») glitzert eine Netzmaske. Geheimnisvoll schimmert ihr Mund durch all die vielen LÃ¶cher hindurch. Ein schÃ¶nes Sujet fÃ¼r ein Hochglanzmagazin, fÃ¼r das sie posiert haben soll.
Doch auch im realen Leben zieht sie diese nutzlose Maske Ã¼ber. So hielt die Singer-Songwriterin in Los Angeles eine Lesung. Im Buchladen Barnes & Noble stellte sie vor wenigen Tagen ihren neuen Gedichtband Â«Violet Bent Backwards Over the GrassÂ» vor, sinngemÃ¤ss heisst der Titel auf Deutsch: Â«Veilchen biegen sich Ã¼ber das Gras.Â» Das Video befindet sich auf Del Reys Instagram-Seite, der mehr als 17 Millionen Fans folgen. Doch statt Likes auf die Maske mit der Masche folgte ein Sturm der EntrÃ¼stung. Â«Unverantwortlich, wie du das Leben deiner Fans riskierstÂ» â€“ Â«Was hast du dir dabei nur gedacht?Â» â€“ Â«Hast du noch nicht gemerkt, dass wir uns inmitten einer Pandemie befinden?Â» oder Â«Ich bin entsetzt, wie ignorant du bist!Â» sind nur ein paar der Reaktionen.
Del Rey, die bÃ¼rgerlich Elizabeth Woolridge Grant heisst, weiss um die Corona-Schutzregelung in Los Angeles. Da muss bei jedem Personenkontakt ausserhalb des eigenen Haushalts ein Mund-Nase-Schutz getragen werden. DarÃ¼ber sah die KÃ¶nigin der dramatisch-geheimnisvollen Balladen jedoch hinweg. Mit ihren Fans posierte die US-Amerikanerin fÃ¼r Selfies, von Abstandsregelung keine Spur.
Wange an Wange posiert sie mit ihren Fans
Ihre Schwester Caroline Grant (32) versuchte umgehend zu beschwichtigen. Â«Lana ist negativ auf Covid-19 getestet worden und sie hielt einen Abstand von 1,8 Metern zu ihren FansÂ», sagte sie auf Anfrage des Nachrichtensenders BBC. Die Bilder jedoch zeigen etwas ganz anderes: Wange an Wange lÃ¤sst sich Lana Del Rey mit Fans ablichten.

title: Grammys' Spoken Word Race Could See Lana Del Rey, Colin Jost Face Off
content:
Ronan Farrow has a Pulitzer, is a Grammy nomination in his future? Farrow is eligible in the spoken word category for â€œCatch and Kill,â€ chronicling how he broke the Harvey Weinstein story. The book is a winner, but his comical narration, complete with Bond-villainesque impersonations of everyone from Eastern European seductresses to Ukrainian henchmen, is not. He wouldâ€™ve been a long shot anyway: The category has historically rewarded the likes of Michelle Obama, Betty White, and Jimmy Carter, and this yearâ€™s contenders arenâ€™t lacking for notable voices.
VIOLET BENT BACKWARDS OVER THE GRASS (Lana Del Rey)
The singer-songwriterâ€™s first spoken word album, set to music by frequent collaborator Jack Antonoff (Taylor Swift, Lorde), accompanies an upcoming book of poetry. Her meditations encompass everything from global warming to vaping and have been described as â€œsometimes clichÃ©d, often rambling and consistently solipsisticâ€ â€” all of which seems very on-brand. It also could give Del Rey a shot at her first Grammy after six previous nominations.
A VERY PUNCHABLE FACE (Colin Jost)
As the title suggests, the â€œSNLâ€ head writer and Mr. ScarJo cops to how off-putting his generic handsomeness can be in this frequently hilarious and occasionally moving memoir that recounts his rise to the top of the late-night heap. Jost has the kind of bonafides that Grammy voters love: Fellow â€œSNLâ€ vets like Tina Fey and Amy Poehler are past nominees and satirists like Carol Burnett and Carrie Fisher were winners.
YEAR OF THE MONKEY (Patti Smith)
The third memoir from the so-called punk poet laureate is a dreamy travelogue that recounts how she spent 2016: jetting from Lisbon to Rockaway Beach, bidding goodbye to longtime friends like Sam Shepard, hitchhiking, sifting through polaroids, and being generally horrified by the outcome of the presidential election. Smith has been nominated for four Grammys (including twice in the spoken word category), but is shockingly Grammy-less.
THE CHIFFON TRENCHES (Andre Leon Talley)
The former Vogue editor-at-large provides a passport to the glory days of onetime publishing Camelot, Conde Nast, read in the dishy cadence of a beloved dinner guest. Talleyâ€™s expense account-fuelled memories of Fashion Weeks past â€” with the occasional South of France jaunt with the Karl Lagerfelds of the world â€” are the main attraction, but its heft is in dissecting how racism shapes the world of haute couture.
TOO MUCH AND NEVER ENOUGH (Mary L. Trump)
Want a Grammy winner thatâ€™s certain to inspire a Twitter meltdown? Cue: Mary L. Trumpâ€™s tell-all about her uncle, the leader of the free world, and her familyâ€™s unique brand of psychosis. A trained psychologist, Trump reads her own medical assessment. Spoiler alert: the Donald is a preening sociopath. Her damning assessment is presented in cool, clear, clinical tones that makes it all the more devastating, and could garner votes for what it says as much as how she says it.

title: Lana Del Rey, please wear one of these face masks instead
content:
Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
With the coronavirus pandemic nowhere near finished, prioritizing fashion over function when it comes to your face mask just isnâ€™t worth it.
But thatâ€™s exactly what Lana Del Rey did during her surprise meet-and-greet at Barnes & Noble at The Grove in LA on Friday, sporting an embellished fishnet mask that offered zero protection against COVID-19 â€” and prompting an outpouring of concern from her fans.
â€œI love you sis but please wear a real mask,â€ one person begged the 35-year-old singer on Instagram, while another commented, â€œGirl weâ€™re in the middle of a pandemic.â€
â€œMaâ€™am that is the exact mask u told us not to wear,â€ another fan pointed out â€” referencing Del Reyâ€™s September Interview cover, for which she posed in a near-identical mesh style along with the line, â€œPlease wear a mask. (Just not, you know, this one.)â€
Other fans insisted that the superstarâ€™s face covering featured an invisible plastic lining for added protection, although the Dolls Kill â€œPure Finer Thingsâ€ mask ($12) she appeared to be wearing includes no such barrier.
The good news? Del Rey neednâ€™t sacrifice her obsession with pretty, sparkly PPE to stay safe; there are plenty of delicate embellished options on the market that offer the same glamorous look without compromising on coronavirus protection.
Below, a handful of eye-catching options to help take the Grammy nominee from â€œBorn to Dieâ€ to double-ply.
These faux rhinestone mesh face masks look a lot like Del Reyâ€™s â€” but crucially, theyâ€™re lined with a cotton-based inner layer thatâ€™s both stretchy and water-repellent, making them a smarter choice.
$24 for two
This similar style is also comprised of a stone-studded fishnet layer over a more protective textile.
$15
The combination of rose gold sequins, metallic mesh and a cotton lining make this pretty number a smart pick.
$9.95
A favorite of stars like Busy Philipps, Sadoughiâ€™s gorgeous face coverings come adorned with pearls, stars and lighter-than-air lace.
$40 for three
Jennifer Lopez has been living in this bridal designerâ€™s sequined masks, but we think the pretty â€œProvocateurâ€ â€” which features Chantilly lace, eyelash trim and, best of all, three layers of protection â€” might be more Del Reyâ€™s style.
If youâ€™re looking for something seriously bedazzled, this swimwear brandâ€™s sparkling offerings are just the ticket. Bonus: You can wear them into the pool or ocean! (A bonus for those who, like Del Rey, enjoy getting high by the beach.)
$90
Florals, sequins and bows? â€œShades of coolâ€ doesnâ€™t even begin to describe this one.
$60

title: Lana Del Rey arranges fan meet-and-greet
content:
In the midst of a pandemic, singer Lana Del Rey arranged a fan meet-and-greet and welcomed the audience in an utterly futile face mask.
Lana Del Rey, the 35-year-old singer-songwriter, come to sight after she appeared wearing a personalized mesh face mask that was anticipated to be vinyl during her meet-and-greet with her followers.
The mask created a labyrinth for her audience as it became difficult to understand if it contains a see-through material for the ones conscious of trends.
However, her video in which she was wearing the customized mesh face mask after receiving more than 1.8 million views made her fans concerned about her mask choice.
One of her fans while expressing disappointment over the selection of mask added, â€œLana please wear a real mask Iâ€™m begging you to be safe.â€

title: Lana Del Rey Wears Mesh Mask to Poetry Book Signing
content:
Lana Del Rey. Photo: Courtesy of @lanadelrey/Instagram
This pandemic has had the uncanny ability to show peopleâ€™s true colors, from presidents to pop stars. Take this weekend as a prime example â€” not just for that main story, but for Lana Del Rey greeting fans at a surprise book-signing while wearing a mesh mask. The singer-songwriter took to the Barnes & Noble at the Grove in Los Angeles to promote her poetry book Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, which came out last week. Del Rey posted photos and videos of herself wearing the mask â€” which, as if us non-scientists at Vulture need to point out, is ineffective against COVID-19 in nearly every way â€” on Instagram, where fans promptly criticized her. â€œYOU MAKE IT SO HARD TO STAN PLEASEE WEAR A PROPER MASK,â€ @jake_troiano wrote. â€œMISS GIRL NOT THE MASK YOU ARE SO HARD TO STAN,â€ @apricotttz added.
The mask recalled the one she wore on the cover of Interview, where she claimed she was â€œan underdogâ€ and gave updates on her as-yet-unreleased album Chemtrails Over the Country Club. Del Reyâ€™s sister, Caroline â€œChuckâ€ Grant, told fans that Del Rey â€œtested negativeâ€ and stayed â€œmore than six feet away,â€ despite the fact that she posed for photos for fans â€” and, you know, breathed on and touched all those books. Del Rey later posted another video to Instagram of her reading the poem â€œNever to Heavenâ€ while wearing a cloth mask. Sure, hope is a dangerous thing for a woman like her to have, but not as much as the novel coronavirus.

title: Maske in Netz-Optik Was hat Lana Del Rey da nicht verstanden?

Der Mund-Nasen-Schutz wird in Corona-Zeiten zum alltÃ¤glichen Accessoire. Doch egal, wie individuell und abgefahren er auch aussehen mag - in erster Linie soll er doch dazu dienen, die Virusverbreitung zu verringern. Lana Del Rey scheint das nicht so ganz einzuleuchten.
Lana Del Rey hat am Wochenende in einem Buchladen in Los Angeles ihren neuen Gedichtband "Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass" vorgestellt und daraus vorgelesen. Bei dem Treffen mit ihren Fans trug die SÃ¤ngerin einen netzartigen Glitzer-Mundschutz, wie auf Instagram in einem Backstage-Video zu sehen ist, das Del Rey selbst verÃ¶ffentlicht hat.
In dem Clip schwirren Stylisten um die SÃ¤ngerin. Die 35-JÃ¤hrige zeigt wÃ¤hrenddessen auf ihre BÃ¼cher vor ihr auf dem Tisch und kÃ¼ndigt an, diese fÃ¼r die Fans zu signieren.
Nach der VerÃ¶ffentlichung des Videos und einigen weiteren Bildern, die Fans wÃ¤hrend der Signierstunde gemacht und auf Twitter verÃ¶ffentlicht hatten, brach eine Welle der Kritik auf Del Rey herein. "Was ist das fÃ¼r eine Maske?", fragt sich nicht nur ein Instagram-Follower in den Kommentaren zu dem Clip. Die SÃ¤ngerin sei "unverantwortlich" und gefÃ¤hrde in der Corona-Pandemie sich und andere, kritisieren zahlreiche Follower.
Keine Reaktion von Del Rey
Der Zeitung "The Independent" zufolge erklÃ¤rte Caroline Grant, die Schwester der SÃ¤ngerin, Del Rey sei negativ auf das Coronavirus getestet worden und habe mehr als 1,5 Meter Abstand zu den Fans gehalten. Ein Twitter-Bild, das offenbar ebenfalls bei dem Event entstand, zeigt die SÃ¤ngerin jedoch Gesicht an Gesicht mit einem Fan.
Die netzartige Maske erinnerte an Del Reys Cover fÃ¼r das Magazin "Interview", fÃ¼r das sie einen Ã¤hnlichen Mundschutz trug. Del Rey selbst reagierte auf den Shitstorm zunÃ¤chst nicht. Sie postete lediglich einen neuen Clip, in dem sie - diesmal mit geschlossener Maske in Leo-Optik - ein weiteres Gedicht vortrÃ¤gt.

title: Lana Del Rey receives backlash after wearing mesh face mask during fan meet and greet
content:
The fans of American singer-songwriter Lana Del Rey are upset over the artist's decision to wear a mesh face mask to a fan meet and greet. According to E!News, the 35-year-old singer made a spontaneous stop at the Barnes & Noble at shopping complex The Grove in Los Angeles to promote her new poetry book 'Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass'.
In a series of Instagram photos and videos, Lana is wearing a mesh face mask that provides no protection from the spread of the coronavirus. However, her team, who can be seen in the background of the videos, do seem to be wearing the proper face coverings. Fans called the 'Cinnamon Girl' singer out in the comments section, with many asking her to apologise for her choice of mask.
"Please address the mask situation," one comment, which received over 18,000 likes, read. "it's absolutely embarrassing" "I'm trying so hard to love you but please wear a real mask," added another fan.
Others pointed out that doing a meet and greet was not "responsible" in the first place, and made worse by the fact that Lana did not seem to be taking the proper precautions to protect her fans, and herself, from the coronavirus. E!News reported that Lana previously wore a similar mask on the cover of Interview magazine. (ANI)

title: Lana Del Rey criticised for wearing mesh face mask to meet fans
content:
Lana Del Rey has been criticised for wearing a mesh face mask as she greeted fans at a recent signing.
The Born to Die singer made an appearance at Barnes and Noble in California, Los Angeles on Saturday, October 3, where she performed a few excerpts from her new poetry book Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass. While there, she wore a glittery, fishnet style face covering that she had previously used during a cover shoot for Interview magazine.
After posting a video of herself getting ready for the event on Instagram, Del Rey's followers took to the comments section to slam her choice of personal protection.
@lanadelrey Instagram
Related: Spice Girl Victoria Beckham didn't want the nickname 'Posh'
"YOU MAKE IT SO HARD TO STAN PLEASE WEAR A PROPER MASK," one wrote, as another said: "Ma'am that is the exact mask you told us not to wear."
"You're setting yourself up at this point, we can't defend you," a third posted, alongside two broken heart emojis.
"Lana please wear a real mask I'm begging you to be safe," another said, as a fifth said: "Girl that's not a mask. You make good music but poor decisions."
This content is imported from Twitter. You may be able to find the same content in another format, or you may be able to find more information, at their web site.

According to BBC News, Del Rey's sister, Caroline 'Chuck' Grant, who live-streamed the reading on social media, assured that the singer had "tested negative" and kept six feet away from people at all times. The publication also revealed that Del Rey, herself, declined to comment.
Later, pop culture Twitter account @Popcrave shared images of the musician posing next to fans for selfies.

title: Lana Del Rey criticised for wearing mesh face mask
content:
Singer Lana Del Rey has been strongly criticised by fans and defended by her sister after she turned up for a book signing in LA wearing a mesh face mask which appeared to offer little of no defence against Covid-19.
The Born to Die singer, whose real name is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, appeared at the Barnes and Nobel store at the Grove outdoor mall in Los Angeles on Saturday, BBC News reports.
Lana Del Rey meets with fans at surprise book signing event for her collection of poetry, #VBBOTG, in LA. ğŸ“š pic.twitter.com/t2H7hYAvhz â€” Pop Crave (@PopCrave) October 3, 2020
Del Rey was at the event to read from and sign copies of her new poetry book Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, and posted pictures of herself on Instagram in the glitter-studded mask, which looked like it contravened guidelines set down by the CDC in the US.
"I love you sis but please wear a real mask, it's gives a bad message," one Instagram user commented on Del Rey's video from the book event.
"Lana I'm begging you wear a real mask," another fan wrote.
Another one of her Instagram followers said, "please address the mask situation... it's absolutely embarrassing,"
However, Del Rey's sister, Caroline "Chuck" Grant, who live-streamed the book reading on Instagram, said Del Rey had "tested negative,", adding that her sister was maintaining a six-foot distance from fans.
The following day, the singer was commended by fans after she was seen wearing a cloth mask.

title: Lana Del Rey wears 'ineffective' crystal mesh face mask to meet and greet
content:
ES Insider Newsletter The hottest luxury and A List news Enter your email address Continue Please enter an email address Email address is invalid Fill out this field Email address is invalid You already have an account. Please log in Register with your social account or click here to log in I would like to receive updates on cool openings and celebrity lifestyle news every week, by email Update newsletter preferences
Singer Lana Del Rey has stirred controversy with her new choice of mask: a mesh crystal design she wore to a meet and greet over the weekend.
In pictures and videos she shared from a recent book signing, the see through mask appeared to offer little protection leading fans to criticise the star.
Del Rey made an appearance at a Los Angeles Barnes & Noble bookshop to promote her new poetry collection Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass.
Coronavirus guidelines in Los Angeles ask people to wear a face mask when out in public.
While Del Rey was technically wearing a face mask, many took issue with the open mesh she had chosen.
She wore a similar style for a photoshoot with Interview Magazine and appears to also have a black version, which is described as 'Lanaâ€™s Own' in the photo credits.
Some compared the mask to mesh on supermarket fruit and others said she â€œ[makes] it so hard to stanâ€ her in the comments.
Others pleaded with her to wear an appropriate mask.
One fan in attendance at the signing claimed the event was â€œshut down shortly after it startedâ€ by the health department. When asked by other fans if her mask was â€œfully meshâ€ they said it was â€œineffective but cute.â€
Evening Standard Insider has reached out for comment.
Her mask is similar to a rhinestone one worn by Paris Hilton to dinner in Los Angeles this July. Her mask was met with a similar response.
Following the backlash, Del Reyâ€™s sister said via The Independent that the singer had â€œtested negativeâ€ and was â€œmore than six feet awayâ€ from fans at her signing.
Other pictures show Del Rey taking pictures with fans, while she also shared a video of fans following her as she left the venue in a car, many of them side by side as they attempted to take pictures of the departing star.
Del Rey has not responded to the backlash, though yesterday she posted a video of herself wearing a different mask - this time a full coverage leopard-print design. In the video, she read one of her poems for her followers.
Many of her fans piled into her comments to discuss her new mask, which she took off at the end of the video before turning off her camera. One of most liked comments on the video read: â€œFinally a better mask.â€
