title: Lana Del Rey slammed after she wears mesh face mask to poetry book signing event
content:
Get all the very latest news in Ireland straight to your email every single day Sign up! Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Invalid Email
Singer-songwriter Lana Del Rey has been slammed for wearing a mesh face mask at a fan book signing event.
The Venice B***h singer, 35, real name Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, donned a sparkly fishnet face mask for the event at Barnes & Noble in Los Angeles on Friday.
Lana was promoting her new poetry book Violet Bent Backwards Over The Grass at the fan meet-and-greet event.
The glamorous star, whose blonde locks were swept back for the event, sat in a cordoned off area to read excerpts of her poetry.
The singer later appeared to pose for photos for fans whilst wearing the glamorous face mask which clearly had holes in the front.
She previously donned a similar one for the cover of Interview magazine in September.
Lana's younger sister and photographer Caroline 'Chuck' Grant recorded the event on Instagram with a live feed, but the comments on the footage from fans were quick to complain about her sister's face mask during the Covid-19 pandemic.
(Image: yourgirlchuck/Instagram)
One person commented: ""LANA WEARING A MESH MASK TO AN EVENT FOR HER POETRY WTF So irresponsible."
Meanwhile, a different follower wrote: "Why is she at an event with a bunch of people wearing a mesh mask??? I love Lana but this is incredibly irresponsible."
Finally, one Lana fan commented: "Lana is a grown woman and we shouldn't tell her what to do BUT wearing #that mask is dangerous for her and for others...It's very irresponsible."
(Image: yourgirlchuck/Instagram) (Image: yourgirlchuck/Instagram)
However, Chuck was quick to jump to her sister's defence, noting that she kept her distance from fans and had tested negative for Covid-19 prior to the event.
Chuck penned: "She's more than six feet away and she tested negative, so chill."
Elsewhere, another fan argued that the mask had a clear secondary layer beneath the mesh.
They penned: "Guys, the mask has a translucent layer underneath the mesh. Calm down."
(Image: yourgirlchuck/Instagram)
Finally, mirroring Chuck's words, another fan account on Twitter noted: "Lana Del Rey's sister Chuck confirms that Lana was more than 6ft away from other people at the event (a few fans sadly broke the social distancing rule as she was leaving) and she is also tested NEGATIVE for COVID-19!".
Mirror Online has reached out to representatives of Lana Del Rey for comment, while she has yet to comment publicly on the matter.
Lana's book of poetry, Violet Bent Backwards Over The Grass, was released on hardback on September 29, 2020.
(Image: Getty Images)
Fans of the singer are currently awaiting the release of her seventh studio album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club.
The album, originally titled White Hot Forever, was due for release in September but has now been pushed back.
Lana released her previous album Norman F***ing Rockwell last year.

title: Lana Del Rey sparked backlash from fans as she appeared to wear a mesh face mask at a public book signing in LA
content:
Lana Del Rey hosted a book signing on Friday at a Barnes & Noble store in LA for her poetry book, "Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass."
The singer-songwriter posted an Instagram video on Friday that showed her wearing a face mask made of a mesh-like fabric.
Del Rey then appeared to wear the same mask at the event, and her fans took to social media to express concern because her nose and mouth looked exposed.
The CDC recommends face masks that have two or more layers of washable, breathable fabric, and that completely cover the nose and mouth.
Fans of Lana Del Rey are calling out the musician for appearing to wear a face mask that seemed to lean more toward fashion than function while hosting a public book signing event.
The singer-songwriter, whose full name is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, released a poetry book, "Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass," in July. On Friday, Del Rey announced in an Instagram video that she would host an "impromptu" book signing event at a Barnes & Noble store that day at The Grove, a shopping center in Los Angeles.
Advertisement
A post shared by Lana Del Rey (@lanadelrey) Oct 2, 2020 at 3:35pm PDT
Impromptu signing A post shared by Lana Del Rey (@lanadelrey) on Oct 2, 2020 at 6:40pm PDT Oct 2, 2020 at 6:40pm PDT
In her video announcing the details of the event, Del Rey wore a metallic, beige face mask made in a mesh style.Another Instagram post that Del Rey shared on Friday shows her arriving at the book signing wearing the same mesh-like mask.
Fans of Del Rey left comments on her Instagram posts about her face covering, with some begging her to wear a "real mask." Other fans seemed to defend Del Rey's mask, pointing out that the star may have been wearing a clear layer of fabric under the accessory.
Advertisement
"I love you sis but please wear a real mask, it gives a bad message," one user commented on Del Rey's Instagram video
"Love you love you love you so much but please wear a mask under that one, take care," another user wrote on Instagram in response to the singer's video.
Advertisement
One Instagram user wrote: "please address the mask situation... it's absolutely embarrassing.""Guys, the mask has a translucent layer underneath the mesh. Calm down," another user added via Del Rey's Instagram post
Del Rey has not made any public social-media posts addressing the face covering that she wore on Friday. Representatives for Del Rey did not immediately respond to Insider's request for comment.
The CDC recommends that face masks have at least two layers of washable, breathable fabric and completely cover the nose and mouth
While it's possible that Del Rey wore a layer of fabric under her mesh-like mask, fans expressed concern because the mask appeared â€” from her videos on Instagram â€” to leave her nose and mouth exposed due to the tiny holes of the design.
Advertisement
This defeats the purpose of masks, according to guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for wearing a mask to help curb the spread of COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
"Masks are recommended as a simple barrier to help prevent respiratory droplets from traveling into the air and onto other people when the person wearing the mask coughs, sneezes, talks, or raises their voice," reads the CDC's guidelines on its website.
The CDC's recommendation for face masks is based on research about the role respiratory droplets play in spreading the novel coronavirus, and the CDC cites clinical and laboratory evidence that shows the proper wearing of face masks "reduce the spray of droplets when worn over the nose and mouth."
Advertisement
When selecting a face mask, the CDC recommends masks that have at least two layers of washable, breathable fabric , that completely cover the nose and mouth, and that fit snugly without gaping.Some types of face masks are currently discouraged by the CDC for everyday use â€” including those made of fabric that's not breathable, coverings with exhalation vents or valves, and masks intended for healthcare workers, like N95 respirators.

title: Lana del Rey maakt fans boos met visnetmondkapje
content:
Lana del Rey droeg vrijdag tijdens een meet and greet in boekhandel Barnes & Noble in Los Angeles braaf een mondkapje, maar wel eentje die niet zoveel nut had. De 35-jarige zangeres droeg er namelijk een van visnet. En dat maakte fans nogal boos.
Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, zoals de zangeres echt heet, droeg een zilveren mondkapje met gaatjes. In de winkel organiseerde ze voor fans een signeersessie voor haar nieuwe boek Violet Bent Backwards Over The Grass.
Lana zat in een afgesloten stukje van de winkel, maar later verschenen een voor een foto's op sociale media waarop ze met fans in contact was. Daarbij hield de zangeres weinig afstand. In Los Angeles luidt het dringende advies om een mondkapje te dragen als je in contact bent met andere huishoudens. De fans reageren verontwaardigd en noemen de actie onverantwoordelijk.

title: Un mÃ©dico, sobre la polÃ©mica mascarilla de Lana del Rey: "No hay que ser un virus inteligente para atravesar una malla"
content:
El pasado 3 de octubre, la cantante Lana del Rey fue objetivo directo de las crÃ­ticas al acudir a una firma de libros con una mascarilla de malla.
El uso de mascarillas es obligatorio en las calles de Los Ãngeles. AdemÃ¡s, las autoridades han recomendado a la poblaciÃ³n que, cuando interactÃºen con personas externas a su nÃºcleo de convivencia, aunque no estÃ©n en la calle, tambiÃ©n las utilicen.
Tras las numerosas crÃ­ticas que la cantante ha recibido, el doctor Peter Chin-Hong, mÃ©dico de la Universidad de California en San Francisco, intervino explicando que la mascarilla de Lana del Rey es ineficaz.
"No estoy muy seguro de que evite la propagaciÃ³n de Covid-19. Parece interesante, pero no hay que ser un virus inteligente para atravesar una malla", explicÃ³ el mÃ©dico a Billboard. "Puedo dibujar una mÃ¡scara en mi cara con un marcador mÃ¡gico y tendrÃ­a la misma eficacia que una mÃ¡scara de malla", cita.
Chin-Hong animÃ³ a los fans a no dejar en evidencia a Lana por el uso de su peculiar 'accesorio', puesto que, al hacerlo, solo podrÃ­an crear una respuesta defensiva por parte de la cantante.
Por otro lado, durante la promociÃ³n de su nuevo libro, Violet Bent Backwards Over The Grass, Lana aprovechÃ³ para confirmar dos posibles fechas de lanzamiento de su prÃ³ximo Ã¡lbum, Chemtrails over the Country Club, que podrÃ­a ver la luz el 10 de diciembre, aunque el vinilo tendrÃ¡ que esperar al 7 de enero.

title: Lana Del Rey faces criticism from fans over mesh face mask
content:
Lana Del Rey hosted a book signing on Friday at a Barnes & Noble store in LA for her poetry book, "Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass."
The singer-songwriter posted an Instagram video on Friday that showed her wearing a face mask made of a mesh-like fabric.
Del Rey then appeared to wear the same mask at the event, and her fans took to social media to express concern because her nose and mouth looked exposed.
The CDC recommends face masks that have two or more layers of washable, breathable fabric, and that completely cover the nose and mouth.
Visit Insider's homepage for more stories.
Fans of Lana Del Rey are calling out the musician for appearing to wear a face mask that seemed to lean more toward fashion than function while hosting a public book signing event.
The singer-songwriter, whose full name is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, released a poetry book, "Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass," in July. On Friday, Del Rey announced in an Instagram video that she would host an "impromptu" book signing event at a Barnes & Noble store that day at The Grove, a shopping center in Los Angeles.
In her video announcing the details of the event, Del Rey wore a metallic, beige face mask made in a mesh style.
A post shared by Lana Del Rey (@lanadelrey) Oct 2, 2020 at 3:35pm PDT
Another Instagram post that Del Rey shared on Friday shows her arriving at the book signing wearing the same mesh-like mask.
Impromptu signing A post shared by Lana Del Rey (@lanadelrey) on Oct 2, 2020 at 6:40pm PDT Oct 2, 2020 at 6:40pm PDT
Fans of Del Rey left comments on her Instagram posts about her face covering, with some begging her to wear a "real mask." Other fans seemed to defend Del Rey's mask, pointing out that the star may have been wearing a clear layer of fabric under the accessory.
"I love you sis but please wear a real mask, it gives a bad message," one user commented on Del Rey's Instagram video.
"Love you love you love you so much but please wear a mask under that one, take care," another user wrote on Instagram in response to the singer's video.
One Instagram user wrote: "please address the mask situation... it's absolutely embarrassing."
"Guys, the mask has a translucent layer underneath the mesh. Calm down," another user added via Del Rey's Instagram post.
Del Rey has not made any public social-media posts addressing the face covering that she wore on Friday. Representatives for Del Rey did not immediately respond to Insider's request for comment.
The CDC recommends that face masks have at least two layers of washable, breathable fabric and completely cover the nose and mouth
While it's possible that Del Rey wore a layer of fabric under her mesh-like mask, fans expressed concern because the mask appeared â€” from her videos on Instagram â€” to leave her nose and mouth exposed due to the tiny holes of the design.
This defeats the purpose of masks, according to guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for wearing a mask to help curb the spread of COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus.
"Masks are recommended as a simple barrier to help prevent respiratory droplets from traveling into the air and onto other people when the person wearing the mask coughs, sneezes, talks, or raises their voice," reads the CDC's guidelines on its website.
The CDC's recommendation for face masks is based on research about the role respiratory droplets play in spreading the novel coronavirus, and the CDC cites clinical and laboratory evidence that shows the proper wearing of face masks "reduce the spray of droplets when worn over the nose and mouth."
When selecting a face mask, the CDC recommends masks that have at least two layers of washable, breathable fabric, that completely cover the nose and mouth, and that fit snugly without gaping.
Some types of face masks are currently discouraged by the CDC for everyday use â€” including those made of fabric that's not breathable, coverings with exhalation vents or valves, and masks intended for healthcare workers, like N95 respirators.

title: Lana Del Rey wears mesh face mask to LA book signing
content:
Lana Del Rey has stoked controversy by appearing at a book signing in Los Angeles wearing a particularly redundant accessory: a face mask made of white, glittery mesh.
Lana Del Rey hosted an event at a Barnes & Noble bookstore in LA to commemorate the launch of her new poetry collection, â€œViolet Bent Backwards Over the Grassâ€.
The singer-songwriter posted a video of herself wearing the mesh face mask, leading fans to question why she would wear a mask that is essentially non-functional.
View this post on Instagram A post shared by Lana Del Rey (@lanadelrey) on Oct 2, 2020 at 3:35pm PDT
Advertisement
Lana Del Ray, real name Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, later shared a photo of herself to her social media arriving at the â€œimpromptu signingâ€ wearing the same mesh mask.
â€œLana sweetie what is this mask,â€ asked one fan commenting on Instagram. Others begged her to wear a â€œrealâ€ mask and said that they â€œcanâ€™t defend [her]â€ anymore when she exhibits this kind of behaviour.
â€œLana I love u, but ur [sic] just asking to be dragged at this point,â€ another fan implored.
The World Health Organisation has recommended that people wear â€œnon-medical masksâ€ in situations where social distancing is difficult, such as in shops. Presumably, however, by â€œnon-medicalâ€ they did not mean â€˜full of huge, gaping holes and hence completely useless for the purpose of stemming the spread of COVID-19.â€™
At time of reporting, Lana Del Rey has not made any public comment on the matter.
More than 200,000 people in the US have died after contracting COVID-19, 16,000 of which died in California.
74% of the deaths in California have been in people aged 65 or older while almost half (48%) were recorded among the Latino population, according to The LA Times.
Advertisement
The US Central Disease Control (CDC) recommends that masks worn by people have at least two layers of washable, breathable fabric that completely cover the nose and mouth.

title: Lana Del Rey did a very bad job of wearing a mask while meeting fans
content:
Lana Del Rey did a no good, very bad job of wearing a mask at an event last weekend. The singer participated in a meet and greet event with fans on October 3 and was photographed wearing a mesh mask. In the case of most things, itâ€™s the thought that counts, but not when it comes to COVID-19. When it comes to global pandemics, â€œa double layer of breathable material properly covering the nose and mouthâ€ is what actually counts.
On Saturday, Del Rey appeared at the Grove location of Barnes & Noble in Los Angeles to perform a reading from her new poetry book, Violet Bent Backwards over the Grass. The Born to Die singer shared photographs and videos from the event, as did many fans, with all the images showing Del Rey in what appears to be a mesh mask. Maybe there is a super-strong, super-thin translucent layer of fabric underneath the mesh, but itâ€™s highly unlikely and still not good enough.
NOT LANA DEL RAY WEARING A MESH MASK AT A MEET & GREET pic.twitter.com/3Qcyg5ZDEk â€” tea sesh ğŸƒ (@TeaSeshYT) October 3, 2020
Del Reyâ€™s sister Chuck Grant livestreamed the reading and meet-and-greet on Instagram and told fans the musician had recently tested negative for covid. Grant also told viewers that her sister was remaining six feet away from fans. Many photos show that Del Rey, in fact, did not remain six feet away from fans and unless she and everyone in attendance were tested as they were walking into the bookstore, a negative result really doesnâ€™t matter as she could have contracted the virus anytime after her test was administered.
Del Rey previously wore what looks like the same mask during a photo shoot with Interview magazine, where she does appear to be physically distancing from the photographer. Before the book event, Del Rey shared a video of herself along with her crew backstage. In the clip, everyone in Del Reyâ€™s entourage can be seen wearing proper masks while the singer is wearing her mesh mask.
View this post on Instagram A post shared by Lana Del Rey (@lanadelrey) on Oct 2, 2020 at 3:35pm PDT
In a second video, Del Rey performs a reading for her book and waves goodbye to dozens of fans who have surrounded her car. Thankfully, everyone appears to be in masks that have been deemed appropriate for reducing the spread of coronavirus, which is still very much a thing regardless of what type of mask a person wears.
View this post on Instagram Impromptu signing A post shared by Lana Del Rey (@lanadelrey) on Oct 2, 2020 at 6:40pm PDT
Even with the mask providing virtually no protection for Del Rey or those around her, the singer still removed it for part of her reading. She also told fans that her next album, which she titled Chemtrails Over the Country Club, will be released either in December or January. Letâ€™s hope the preorder includes a branded full-coverage cloth mask for Del Ray and her fans.
RELATED: Fashion-forward masks to stay safe and stylish
Many fans commented on Del Reyâ€™s posts following the October 3 event and asked the singer to apologize for her useless mask. â€œPlease address the mask situationâ€¦ itâ€™s absolutely embarrassing,â€ wrote a fan. â€œIâ€™m trying so hard to love you but please wear a real mask,â€ added another. One fan wrote that the event had to be shut down for safety reasons, writing â€œLanaâ€¦the health department literally had to shut the event down. You literally werenâ€™t wearing a safe mask and there was no social distancing whatsoever. This was not smart. Please donâ€™t do it again. Love you, but please take this virus seriously.â€
Del Rey shared a third video the following day, which shows the singer wearing a cloth mask while performing a reading from her poetry book. Del Rey appears to be alone in her car while doing the reading. Okay, yes, that seems safe.

title: Matt Maeson Calls on Lana Del Rey for New Version of 'Hallucinogenics'
content:
Matt Maeson's "Hallucinogenics" is already the ideal soundtrack for the feeling of losing touch, and now he's added Lana Del Rey to a new rendition of the track released on Friday (Sept. 25).
Del Rey's ethereal vocals fit perfectly into the song's acoustic nature, trading lines with Maeson before they come together for the chorus. "Pushin' past the limit, trippin' on hallucinogenics / My cigarette burnt my finger 'cause I forgot I lit it," they sing in unison.
The original "Hallucinogenics" is featured on Maeson's debut album, Bank on the Funeral.
Listen to the Lana Del Rey version below.

title: Musikkanmeldelse: Nye lÃ¥ter uke 42
content:

Musikkanmeldelse: Nye lÃ¥ter uke 42
Lana del Rey, Demi Lovato, og Turab sitt samarbeid med Ane Brun dukker opp blant lÃ¥tene VG har anmeldt denne fredagen.
Oppdatert i gÃ¥r 21:26
Lana Del Rey - Â«Let Me Love You Like a WomanÂ»
Albumet Â«Chemtrails Over the Country ClubÂ» (for en tittel) skulle egentlig ha vÃ¦rt ute i over en mÃ¥ned nÃ¥. I stedet skylder Del Rey pÃ¥ vinylfabrikken og forskyver alt til neste Ã¥r. Passende for en artist som til de grader illuderer drÃ¸mmen om Hollywood i alt hun gjÃ¸r. FÃ¸rste singel er (selvsagt) en mÃ¸rkmanende, mystisk og seig stilÃ¸velse i forsÃ¸ksvis underkastelse, der refrenget gjentas i det uendelige. Med kun et stillfarent piano, og et nesten ikke-eksisterende arrangement. Likevel bygger lÃ¥ten seg gjenkjennelig opp i intensitet i de tre minuttene den bruker pÃ¥ Ã¥ fÃ¥ jeg-personen i teksten klar til Ã¥ endelig forlate LA. Eller gi opp alt.
Turab og Ane Brun - Â«Nesten HjemmeÂ»
Turab Awan fra Manglerud i Oslo har drevet med musikk siden lenge fÃ¸r han dukket opp pÃ¥ Norske Talenter i 2014. Her har 21-Ã¥ringen fÃ¥tt til et noe overraskende samarbeid med selveste Ane Brun. Hun bidrar med mer stjernestÃ¸v enn virkelig Ã¥ lÃ¸fte lÃ¥ten, for det gjÃ¸r Turab greit alene. Â«Nesten hjemmeÂ» er mer sÃ¸t og fengende lykke fra den syngende rapperen. En oppstemt liten sak som fester seg pÃ¥ hjernen pÃ¥ riktig mÃ¥te. Og nesten blir for gledelig til Ã¥ spilles nÃ¥ som vi er nesten i november.
TIx og Teddy - Â«Ikke hanÂ»
Thomas Alexander Strandskogen var tidligere Thomas i boybandet Suite 16. Som ble stÃ¸rst da de fikk remiksebehandling av russelÃ¥tmaskinen Rykkinnfella. Her har han slÃ¥tt seg sammen med hitlistegrossist (og tidligere russelÃ¥tfabrikk) Tix i en virkelig klinelÃ¥t. Om Ã¥ vÃ¦re ham som forstÃ¥r, og ikke ham som er dum. Teksten er passe enkel og nÃ¸drimete, der skÃ¥rene rimer pÃ¥ tÃ¥rene. Det er greit det. Teddy synger fint, det er passe vuggende, og lett forglemmelig. Tix produserer sÃ¥ det hÃ¸re passe eksklusivt ut. SÃ¥ lar vi den Ã¥penbare han/ham-diskusjonen ligge.
Ben Alexander - Â«SomniÂ»
Dette er fort de som ikke helt husker at de har glemt Massive Attack. Londonbaserte Ben Alexander er egentlig fra vÃ¥re trakter, men jobber med Ã¥ etablere seg som artist der over i den eurpeiske pophovedstaden. Dette samarbeidet med vel sÃ¥ ukjente MÃ¶rmaid pÃ¥ vokal er myk chill med raus romklang. Og en seig, men duvende beat som holdes sammen av en repetitivt pianotone. Ja, det kunne vÃ¦rt introen til en HBO-serie. Det er det altsÃ¥ ikke. I alle fall ikke ennÃ¥.
Demi Lovato - Â«Commander in ChiefÂ»
NÃ¥ er verden sÃ¥ pÃ¥ hodet at popen har blitt politisk. I stedet for Ã¥ lage en sinna Â«American IdiotÂ» for Ã¥ fortelle hvor hÃ¥plÃ¸st hun synes USA er drevet, skaper Lovato en velmenende ballade der blant annet Julia Michaels har bidratt med skrivekunster. Utfordringen er at resultatet peker vel sÃ¥ mye i retning av den parodiske Â«The American DreamÂ»-lÃ¥ten fra filmen Â«Wag the DogÂ». En ganske traust og seigflytende gospelsak som virker oppriktig velment. Samtidig: Det er vel en slags sannsynlighet for at man lettere lytter til teksten i denne hastigheten. Den er god. SpÃ¸rsmÃ¥let er om det vil flytte en eneste velger. Jeg tviler.
Ava Max og Atlantic Holiday - Â«Christmas Without YouÂ»
De fleste av oss kan leve fint med at julemarsipanen er i butikkene, selv om vi fremdeles ikke har passert Halloween. Men 2020 er tydeligvis ogsÃ¥ offisielt sÃ¥ fÃ¸kka at vi allerede har Ã¥rets fÃ¸rste nye julesang. Og for noe forferdelig tÃ¸v. Ava Max (Tix-skrevne Â«Sweet but PsychoÂ») legger vokalen som en greit entusiastisk Mariah Carey-kopi (ja, hun treffer en hinsides hÃ¸y C pÃ¥ slutten). Teksten er ogsÃ¥ en slags skrudd pastisj pÃ¥ Â«All I Want for ChristmasÂ». Produksjonen kommer sÃ¥ rolig inn fra siden at man virkelig skal lete etter julestemningen. Og for Ã¸vrig: Atlantic Holiday er vel heller ikke en artist, men en hotellkjede? Heldigvis er det fremdeles ni uker igjen til jul.
Lauv og Conan Gray - Â«FakeÂ»
Produsent/sanger/lÃ¥tskriver Lauv er den store samarbeidsmonsteret for tiden. PÃ¥ Ã¥rets tolvte (!) singel (da inkluderer vi ikke diverse Tik Tok-samarbeid) har med Conan Grey, som albumdebuterte tidligere i Ã¥r. Refrenget passer perfekt til Ã¥ rope hÃ¸yt i biler, busser, bÃ¥ter, gatelangs og i hissige oppgjÃ¸r. Javisst er den ganske sÃ¥ enkel, men pÃ¥ den gode mÃ¥ten. Â«FakeÂ» er et passe greit hate-anthem med mild gitar og snill beat. Dessuten har den et perfekt aproposlÃ¥t-potensiale. Slik skal man pÃ¥ ingen mÃ¥te underslÃ¥ verdien av.
Verfast - Â«Nok sagt!Â»
Denne trioen kommer fra steder pÃ¥ vestlandet som stemmer hundre prosent med bandnavnet. De har gitt ut noen gode tendenser det siste Ã¥ret, uten at lÃ¥tene har sittet helt. Her treffer de derimot tilnÃ¦rmet perfekt med nydelige vokalharmonier i et vestkyst-aktig (selvsagt) gitarlandskap som kler sognedialekten perfekt. Det Ã¸ses pÃ¥ fine harmonier i et passe vart tempo. Slikt som man mÃ¥ kunne si at svenskene har vÃ¦rt mye bedre til enn oss. (Og det norske bandet som like gjerne heter Sweden). Ikke minst det virkelig lykkelig harmoniserte refrenget her noe man gjerne kan spille om igjen og om igjen.

title: Justin Bieber & Benny Blanco, Lana Del Rey & More: What's Your Favorite New Music Release This Week? Vote!
content:
This week packed an emotional roller coaster of songs about feeling lonely, longing for love and lashing out against the government.
Justin Bieber reunited with benny blanco (who co-wrote "Love Yourself") for "Lonely," a song that somberly revisits the darker twists and turns along Bieber's path to childhood stardom.
Lana Del Rey tries to convince her lover to run away from LA with her in the classic romantic ballad "Let Me Love You Like a Woman." And Demi Lovato urges her listeners to look critically at the current "Commander in Chief" in her latest single that comes one month before the presidential election.

title: People Who Wear Mesh Face Masks Are Losing The COVID-19 Battle On Every Level
content:
Looking for a face mask that skirts the face covering guidelines while simultaneously screaming â€œPick me next!â€ to the coronavirus? Look no further than the mesh mask.
The barely there facial coverings are in the news this week after singer Lana Del Rey wore a bejeweled version to a Barnes & Noble poetry reading and fan meet-and-greet in Los Angeles on Friday. (Naturally, there were plenty of â€œBorn To Dieâ€ quips on Twitter.)
Del Rey, who wore a similarly sparkly, similarly ineffective mask on the cover of Interview magazine last month, was quickly called out by concerned followers on social media. (Photos posted on Instagram and Twitter show the singer in close proximity to some fans while taking selfies.)
â€œGirl thatâ€™s not a mask,â€ read one comment from her more than 17 million Instagram followers. â€œYou make good music but poor decisions.â€
â€œILY BUT WEAR A PROPER MASK,â€ read another upvoted comment.
Other fans of the singer-cum-poet insisted that the mask featured an invisible lining for added protection but as Page Six noted, the Dolls Kill â€œPure Finer Thingsâ€ mask Del Rey appeared to be wearing includes no such barrier.
Whatever the case, Del Rey is hardly the first to flout mask regulations by wearing a questionable face covering. In recent months, everyday, non-Grammy-nominated people have thrown on mesh and crochet masks to protest safety regulations they say are government overreach.
Some have filmed or photographed themselves successfully going into markets and stores, claiming that their demonstrations are proof that mask ordinances are for â€œcompliance,â€ not safety.
While there are Counties requiring masks in public;
NO law requires a specific type or particulate rating of mask.
The general public are making their own masks including open mesh. No fines have been issued while wearing them in public.
This is about compliance, not safety. pic.twitter.com/dZnmHwcTeF â€” Futilz (@futilecauz) July 7, 2020
On Etsy, more than 7,500 search results come up for mesh masks. Many were originally marketed for events like raves but the reviews show that people are buying them to tiptoe around mask ordinances: â€œAwesome product, appeases the mask police while allowing me to breath [sic] and look fancy while doing so lol,â€ a review of a popular bejeweled mesh mask reads.
It goes without saying that these â€œmasksâ€ offer little â€• if any â€• protection against a virus that has killed more than 1 million people worldwide.
â€œRespiratory droplets are tiny and can easily be released through the openings of the mesh,â€ said Kirsten Hokeness, professor and chair of the department of science and technology at Bryant University and an expert in immunology, virology, microbiology and human health and disease. â€œThe CDC recommends masks made of two or more layers covering your face and nose.â€
Hokeness said that hearing about the mesh mask trend is especially hard to swallow after the events of this weekend: The United Statesâ€™ mask-averse president is infected with COVID-19. The virus is now tearing through the West Wing and Capitol and on top of that, we still have to deal with the attention-seeking antics of the â€œpersonal freedomâ€ crowd.
Seven months into the pandemic, Hokeness, like many Americans, is suffering from anti-masker fatigue.
â€œIt is infuriating to continue to see people either try to skirt the mask mandates by not wearing effective masks or not wearing masks at all as we still struggle to get this virus under control in this country,â€ she said.
â€œThe coronavirus outbreak at the White House clearly indicates how quickly this virus can spread to individuals who are not wearing masks and are in close contact,â€ Hokeness said. (Many experts believe that Trumpâ€™s gathering in late September to celebrate the nomination of Judge Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court could be classified as a COVID-19 superspreader event.)
Lana Del Rey wearing a face mask // a random Karen wearing a face mask pic.twitter.com/2qNeoPbBSw â€” LGâ¹Â¹Â¹ ã€„ (@EnigmaticGaga) October 2, 2020
As for people who wear mesh PPE, theyâ€™re losing the COVID-19 battle on every front. First, thereâ€™s the twofold health concerns: They magnify their risk of catching the virus themselves and risk spreading it.
Whatâ€™s more, their political statement has holes it in (literally): Wouldnâ€™t real rebellion mean refusing to conform to the rules and going entirely mask-free?
They may feel as if theyâ€™re â€œowning the libsâ€ with their workaround, but they still have to go through all the minor discomfort of wearing a mask â€• just without any of the actual benefits.
What they do gain is attention, said Shane G. Owens, a psychologist and the assistant director of campus mental health at Farmingdale State College in New York (SUNY).
â€œThis makes sense with celebrities because they live on attention,â€ he said. â€œThe â€˜regular Joe and Janeâ€™ faux-mask-wearers are harder to understand.â€
Still, the psychologist gave some thought to why youâ€™d risk you and your family getting COVID-19 to spite the government.
â€œSome value independence over personal and public health,â€ he said. â€œSome people believe that masks are more dangerous than the disease. Others believe theyâ€™re part of a sinister plot to enslave us.â€
Whatever their beliefs, as the war over mask use wears on, Owens thinks the mask-resistorsâ€™ behavior is sort of like that of children in a family with a lot of conflict.
â€œTheyâ€™re trying desperately to get their parentsâ€™ attention and control the uncontrollable.â€
They may end up attracting the wrong kind of attention, though: If youâ€™re wearing a faux mask to protest government overreach into your life, youâ€™re behaving in a way that begs for more government intrusion into your life, Owens said.
â€œWearing masks that draw more attention to you like these mesh ones is not an effective way to keep the government off your back,â€ he added.
In other words: If you hate the government-mandated mask guidelines, youâ€™re really going to hate government contract tracers incessantly calling you once you test positive for COVID-19.

title: Is Lana Del Rey's Mesh Mask Effective? A Doctor Weighs In... And Cautions Against 'Mask Shaming'
content:
Spotlighting Lana Del Rey's 'Norman F***ing Rockwell' on Billboardâ€™s Grammy Pre-Show
Chin-Hong compared Del Rey to Lady Gaga, who "is still able to be fashionable and have an effective mask"; the Chromatica star sported a number of stylish face coverings at the 2020 MTV Video Music Awards in August, all of which effectively shielded her mouth and nose without sacrificing the eye-catching flair that is characteristically Gaga. "The holes are so big in the mesh that you might as well be wearing nothing," Chin-Hong continued of Del Rey's blingy mask. "I can draw a mask on my face with a magic marker and it would have the same efficiency as a mesh mask." A spokesperson for Del Rey had not responded to requests for comment at press time.
While it appeared that Del Rey wore only the mesh mask during the book signing, her defenders wondered if she might have a clear protective layer under the bling that went undetected in her Instagram pics. Chin-Hong is aware of one FDA-approved option -- the ClearMask -- for those needing to read lips or see others' facial expressions, but "The clear part is just around the mouth, because plastic blocks the virus," he explained, "so you can still breathe through fabric from the nose." It's clear that mesh masks alone don't work in preventing the spread of coronavirus, so what does? "Thereâ€™s a hierarchy of masks," Chin-Hong said. "The Tesla of masks is the N95, then you get the surgical masks that we use in the hospital, then you get the cloth coverings that people wear normally and on the streets, then you have the neck gaiters that you can buy from North Face." While the N95 masks are at the top of the list, the expert said they are not necessary in everyday life, just in medical and high-risk situations. "For most people, wearing a regular cloth mask is good enough," he said.

title: Lana Del Ray criticised for wearing mesh mask to book signing in Los Angeles
content: Musician Lana Del Rey came under fire on social media after wearing a mesh face mask to a book signing

title: Lana Del Rey criticized for wearing mesh mask while meeting fans at book signing
content:
Singer Lana Del Rey attended a book signing in Los Angeles on Saturday, greeting fans while wearing what appeared to be a mesh face mask. The pop star is now receiving criticism online for wearing a mask that does nothing to protect others from potential coronavirus exposure.
The singer, whose real name is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, appeared at the Barnes & Noble store at the Grove outdoor mall in Los Angeles Saturday, BBC News reports. She read passages of her new poetry book "Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass."
Del Rey sported a mesh mask, studded with glitter, that appeared to have holes in it. On Instagram, she posted several videos of the stylish yet ineffective mask. The CDC says people should wear masks with two or more layers of cloth and no exhalation valves or vents.
Get Breaking News Delivered to Your Inbox
"I love you sis but please wear a real mask, it's gives a bad message," one Instagram user commented on Del Rey's video from the book event.
"lana i'm begging you wear a real mask," another Instagarm user wrote.
"please address the mask situation... it's absolutely embarrassing," another commenter wrote on a second post of Del Rey's where she is wearing the mesh mask.
Del Rey's sister, Caroline "Chuck" Grant, live-streamed the book reading on Instagram, and said Del Rey had "tested negative," BBC News reports. She said her sister was remaining six feet away from her fans during the event. However, photos show otherwise.
Lana Del Rey meets with fans at surprise book signing event for her collection of poetry, #VBBOTG, in LA. ğŸ“š pic.twitter.com/t2H7hYAvhz â€” Pop Crave (@PopCrave) October 3, 2020
On Sunday, Del Rey posted a video of herself wearing a cloth mask, and fans commended her.
However, the mask she wore to the public event violated Los Angeles' mask mandate, which is in effect because masks are a proven way to slow the spread of coronavirus. "Everyone is asked to wear a face covering when they are interacting with others who are not members of their household in public and private spaces," the guidance from the LA County Public Health Department reads.
Acceptable masks include bandanas, neck gaiters, homemade face coverings, scarves or tightly woven fabric, such as cotton t-shirts and some types of towels, the health department says.
CBS News has reached out to Barnes & Noble and reps for Lana Del Rey for comment and is awaiting response. CBS News has also reached out to Simon and Schuster, a property of ViacomCBS, which published the book.

title: Lana Del Rey criticised for wearing mesh mask to poetry reading
content:
Fans of Lana Del Rey have criticised her for wearing a glittery mesh mask that did not appear to fully cover her nose and mouth at a surprise poetry reading and book signing event.
The musician read from her new collection, Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, and posed with fans at a Barnes and Noble store in Los Angeles at the weekend, wearing a net facial covering that did not seem to assist in preventing the spread of the coronavirus.
After Del Rey posted images of herself wearing the mask to her Instagram account, fans accused the 35-year-old of being irresponsible and begged her to wear a proper facial covering.
Lana Del Rey meets with fans at surprise book signing event for her collection of poetry, #VBBOTG, in LA. ğŸ“š pic.twitter.com/t2H7hYAvhz â€” Pop Crave (@PopCrave) October 3, 2020
Del Rey has yet to respond to the criticism. The Guardian has contacted representatives for the singer for comment.
Del Reyâ€™s sister, Chuck Grant, claimed that the star had â€œtested negativeâ€ and always remained six feet away from fans. Yet several fans shared photographs from the event depicting them standing next to and touching Del Rey.
Combined with other preventative measures such as hand washing and social distancing, wearing face masks protects against the spread of coronavirus by acting as a barrier between the wearer and other individuals.
At the Los Angeles event, Del Rey told fans that she planned to release her forthcoming album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, in December or the following month. Her last album, Norman Fucking Rockwell!, was named 2019â€™s album of the year by multiple publications, including the Guardian.

content:
Five-time Grammy nominee Lana Del Rey didnâ€™t win any awards for her face-covering at a public reading of her new book.
The â€œYoung and Beautifulâ€ singer wore a mesh face mask that apparently exposed her nose and mouth in violation of local coronavirus guidelines as she got close to attendees.
Del Rey promoted her collection of poetry, â€œViolet Bent Backwards Over Grass,â€ with an appearance Friday at a Barnes & Noble in Los Angeles.
Fans posted photos of themselves well within 6 feet of the performer and even cheek to cheek, prompting backlash from people on social media.
â€œur setting urself up at this point we cant defend you,â€ one wrote on the Instagram Live post.
â€œlana please wear a real mask iâ€™m begging you be safe,â€ a concerned fan wrote.

Some even referenced her 2012 album â€œBorn To Die.â€
Del Reyâ€™s sister Caroline said the singer had â€œtested negativeâ€ and was standing â€œmore than 6 feet awayâ€ from others, the U.K.â€™s Independent reported, but that was not the case.

title: Lana Del Rey slammed for wearing ridiculous mesh face mask to meet fans
content:
Maybe itâ€™s vinyl?
Thatâ€™s at least what some people may be hoping for singer-songwriter Lana Del Rey after the 35-year-old was seen wearing what appeared to be a bedazzled mesh face mask during a recent meet-and-greet with fans.
â€œLivestream,â€ the star wrote in an Instagram video she shared shortly before she attended a book signing on Saturday.
Del Reyâ€™s poetry book, Violet Bent Backwards over the Grass, was originally published on July 28, but the Grammy nominee held a book signing at a Barnes & Noble located at the Los Angeles retail hot spot, The Grove.
â€œI canâ€™t wait to see you guys,â€ Del Rey said while wearing her sparkly mask in the video, which has been viewed by more than 1.8 million people as of Sunday afternoon.
It is not visibly clear whether her mask has a transparent material under the mesh design given the availability of see-through masks for fashion-conscious consumers.
Representatives for Del Rey and Barnes & Noble did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
Followers of Del Rey were highly critical of her face mask choice.
â€œur setting urself up at this point we cant defend you,â€ wrote the postâ€™s top commenter, which received more than 3300 likes.
â€œUhm,â€ another highly-liked user commented.
â€œlana please wear a real mask iâ€™m begging you be safe,â€ a concerned fan added.
Del Reyâ€™s sister, Caroline â€œChuckâ€ Grant, allegedly chimed in that her famous sister â€œtested negativeâ€ and was standing â€œmore than six feet awayâ€ while she attended the signing, according to The Independent.
However, a collection of photos tweeted by celebrity news blog Pop Crave shows the singer stood rather close to some attendees.
Lana Del Rey meets with fans at surprise book signing event for her collection of poetry, #VBBOTG, in LA. ğŸ“š pic.twitter.com/t2H7hYAvhz â€” Pop Crave (@PopCrave) October 3, 2020
Last month, Del Rey was featured on the cover of Interview magazine with another bedazzled mesh-like face mask.
In a tweet that shared the cover on September 6, Interview asked its followers to wear a mask that is not like the one Del Rey is wearing:
We werenâ€™t planning to do our September cover reveal until next week, but the @lanadelrey stans got to it early ğŸ’ Check back Tuesday morning for her interview with @jackantonoff and the rest of the photos from the shoot, photographed by Chuck Grant and styled by Mel Ottenberg. pic.twitter.com/o0eOeAPHds â€” Interview Magazine (@InterviewMag) September 6, 2020
The US has more than 7.4 million confirmed cases of coronavirus, according to the Johns Hopkins COVID-19 Dashboard. California has 829,995 of those cases with 273,699 of those who tested positive hailing from Los Angeles.

Mais les concerts qui, dÃ¨s avril, devaient allumer la mÃ¨che de ce come-back trÃ¨s attendu avec une tournÃ©e dans une dizaine de pays de lâ€™Est et dâ€™Europe centrale, ont fait long feu. Tout comme une premiÃ¨re poignÃ©e de festivals dâ€™Ã©tÃ©.
Alors que la semaine de rÃ©sidence que Woodkid et ses musiciens devaient dÃ©buter prÃ¨s dâ€™Aix-en-Provence (Bouches-du-RhÃ´ne) pour prÃ©parer leur retour scÃ©nique vient dâ€™Ãªtre annulÃ©e, ses bureaux parisiens semblent autant occupÃ©s Ã  gÃ©rer les effets des contraintes sanitaires que la frÃ©nÃ©sie dâ€™une sortie Ã©vÃ©nement.
AprÃ¨s avoir vÃ©cu plusieurs annÃ©es Ã  Brooklyn (New York) dâ€™oÃ¹ il dominait lâ€™East River, lâ€™artiste multimÃ©dia est revenu sâ€™installer en bord de Seine. Porte de la Chapelle pour sa vie privÃ©e, et dans le 10e arrondissement de la capitale pour son atelier. Câ€™est ainsi quâ€™il a baptisÃ© les locaux oÃ¹ se rÃ©partissent les deux pÃ´les principaux de ses activitÃ©s.
Une vaste piÃ¨ce est consacrÃ©e Ã  lâ€™image. Photo, vidÃ©o, animation 3D, effets spÃ©ciauxâ€¦ Les crÃ©ations visuelles restent centrales pour ce fils de professionnels de la Â« crÃ©a Â» publicitaire qui, aprÃ¨s des Ã©tudes dâ€™arts plastiques Ã©pousant graphisme, photographie et animation, avait fini par se rÃ©vÃ©ler comme rÃ©alisateur de spots publicitaires et de clips.
Lâ€™artiste franÃ§ais, Woodkid, dans son Â« atelier Â», le 22 septembre Ã  Paris. MATHIEU RICHER MAMOUSSE POUR Â« M LE MAGAZINE DU MONDE Â»
Plus calfeutrÃ©, le studio dâ€™enregistrement se trouve Ã  lâ€™autre bout des locaux. Bras droit musical de Yoann Lemoine, Tanguy Destable â€“ connu comme musicien et producteur sous le nom de Tepr â€“ sâ€™affaire Ã  rÃ©adapter la setlist de concerts sans arrÃªt reportÃ©s, dont la scÃ©nographie et lâ€™orchestration doivent Ã©voluer au grÃ© des nouvelles jauges.
Il vous reste 66.91% de cet article Ã  lire. La suite est rÃ©servÃ©e aux abonnÃ©s.

title: Lana Del Rey finally responds to mesh face mask controversy
content:
Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window)
In early October, Lana Del Rey was roundly criticized for attending an LA meet-and-greet wearing what appeared to be a bedazzled mesh face mask amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.
At the time, fans begged the 35-year-old musician to â€œwear a real mask,â€ calling her a â€œKarenâ€ and â€œa danger to herself and othersâ€ and pointing out that a sheer face covering does nothing to stop the spread of the coronavirus. We were even inspired to find her some safer, more suitable options.
Now, Del Rey is breaking her silence on the subject â€” and claiming that there was more to her mask than meets the eye.
On Monday, the Michigan Daily tweeted a story about the controversy swirling around the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ singer, and Del Rey herself responded.
â€œGreat article. The mask had plastic on the inside,â€ she wrote. â€œTheyâ€™re commonly sewn in by stylists these days. I donâ€™t generally respond to articles because I donâ€™t care. But there ya go. Same goes for everyoneâ€™s masks in my video. Iâ€™m lucky enough to have a team of people who can do that.â€
A situation with layers, you might say.

title: Lana Del Rey Addresses Mesh Face Mask Backlash
content:
"Mask etiquette has become synonymous with compassion, intelligence and human decency," the article read. "Del Rey's fashion choice feels like a slap in the face for those who have been intimately hurt by COVID-19 and for those who wear their masks without issue. Celebrity status does not exclude Del Rey from responsibility."
Towards the end of piece, the article posed questions about cancel culture and how it might effect Lana and her career.

title: Lana Del Rey says her controversial mesh mask had plastic underneath
content:
Lana Del Rey took to Twitter on Tuesday to respond to a Michigan Daily article that questioned whether or not she deserved the criticism she received for wearing a mesh face mask to a book signing in October.
Del Rey said it was a "great article," and added that her mask had a layer of transparent plastic sewn into it.
She also denied rumors that she glamorizes abusive relationships and voted for Donald Trump in the 2020 presidential election.
And when a fan asked why it took so long for Del Rey to comment on the mesh mask, the musician said she's been busy working on two albums and "happily donating a million dollars throughout the nation."
Visit Insider's homepage for more stories.
Lana Del Rey is responding to the backlash she faced after wearing a controversial face mask last month.
In October, the musician attended a book signing at a Los Angeles Barnes & Noble while wearing a beige mask made from mesh and sparkles. Her skin and mouth were visible underneath, seemingly revealing that there was no protective layer sewn into the face covering.
On Tuesday, however, Del Rey said her mask actually had a layer of plastic under the mesh in response to an article from The Michigan Daily that questioned whether or not Del Rey deserved the harsh criticism she received.
A post shared by Lana Del Rey (@lanadelrey)
In the Michigan Daily piece, writer Madeleine Virginia Gannon argued that while speculation surrounds Del Rey â€” ranging from questions about her music to her political preferences â€” it's unclear whether or not "the 'high courts' of the internet" should have the power to deem celebrities as "problematic."
"Does a mesh mask disqualify her from our love?" Gannon asked of Del Rey's mask choice. "It seems such an insignificant misstep for an idol who the world has cherished for so long. But the pandemic has killed hundreds of thousands of people â€” a number so large, it seems unfathomable."
"Mask etiquette has become synonymous with compassion, intelligence, and human decency," Gannon continued. "Del Rey's fashion choice feels like a slap in the face for those who have been intimately hurt by COVID-19 and for those who wear their masks without issue. Celebrity status does not exclude Del Rey from responsibility."
Del Rey seemingly enjoyed Gannon's writing, calling the piece a "great article" on Twitter. But she also offered some insight into the reality of her face mask.
"The mask had plastic on the inside," Del Rey wrote. "They're commonly sewn in by stylists these days. I don't generally respond to articles because I don't care. But there ya go. Same goes for everyone's masks in my video. I'm lucky enough to have a team of people who can do that."
â€”Lana Del Rey (@LanaDelRey) November 17, 2020
"Again not that I believe it's anyone's business at all â€” but I made it clear who I voted for," the musician went on to say in another tweet. "And I don't glamorize tough relationships. Relationships can just be tough. Period. Every other singer sings about the same damn thing. Always have, Probably always will. Thanks stay tuned."
Representatives for The Michigan Daily and Madeleine Virginia Gannon did not immediately respond to Insider's request for comment.
â€”Lana Del Rey (@LanaDelRey) November 17, 2020
After Del Rey shared the tweets, a fan reached out over Twitter and said: "No hate but took you long enough."
Del Rey then replied: "Bro I'm working on two albums and excitedly and happily donating a million dollars throughout the nation. If I responded to everything I would be ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸."
â€”Lana Del Rey (@LanaDelRey) November 17, 2020
As Insider's Darcy Schild previously reported, it was Del Rey's own fans who previously criticized her choice in face mask, with people writing messages like "Love you love you love you so much but please wear a mask under that one, take care" on Instagram.
"Other fans seemed to defend Del Rey's mask, pointing out that the star may have been wearing a clear layer of fabric under the accessory," Schild wrote.
A post shared by Lana Del Rey (@lanadelrey)
Mesh masks are sold through a variety of retailers and websites, though they're especially popular on marketplace sites like Etsy.
At the time of writing, a search on Etsy for the term "mesh mask" yields more than 10,000 results. Similarly, a search for the term "breathable mask" brings up more than 202,000 products.
Though many of the designs are meant to be worn on top of another mask â€” for both protective and styling purposes â€” some of the face coverings are being purchased by those who are entirely against wearing masks.
"I think these mask requirements are ridiculous, so this is the perfect alternative if you want to be able to breathe!" one Etsy shopper commented on a mesh mask sold by NevaNudeLLC in July. "My daughter was even excited to wear it because of how sparkly and colorful it is."
Cloth masks and other protective equipment is crucial in helping prevent the spread of COVID-19. As Insider's Anna Medaris Miller wrote, "medical masks or cloth face coverings, ideally with three layers, could be a ticket to controlling the coronavirus outbreak â€” if everyone wore them."
Medaris Miller pointed to a recent UK study, which showed that "mandates to wear masks could be enough to contain an outbreak without a lockdown," as well as a case report in which two infected hairstylists wearing masks in Missouri did not transmit the virus while seeing 140 customers (also wearing masks).
While wearing masks helps protect others, Medaris Miller wrote that "a range of new research shows masks protect the wearer, too," citing Dean Blumberg, chief of pediatric infectious diseases at UC Davis Children's Hospital, who said wearing a mask can reduce the risk of infection by 65%.

title: Bruce Springsteen Stars in New Bleachers Song, 'Chinatown'
content:
Bleachers frontman and hit producer Jack Antonoff has always worn his New Jersey affiliation and Bruce Springsteen influence proudly, and today he brings it all home: Bleachers have dropped two new tracks, giving fans a sneak peek of new music a forthcoming album due next year â€” and one of them, â€œChinatown,â€ features none other than Springsteen himself. The release is a throwback to the 7â€ single days, and its B-side is even titled â€œ45.â€ Both tracks are available digitally and on 7â€ â€” and a video for â€œChinatownâ€ directed by Carlotta Kohl is out NOW.
In a mostly lower-case statement that weâ€™re not going to correct, Antonoff says: â€œchinatownâ€ starts in NYC and travels to new jersey. that pull back to the place i am from mixed with terror of falling in love again. having to show your cards to someone and the shock when you see them for yourself. thinking you know yourself and where you are fromâ€¦. having to see yourself through somebody who you want to stayâ€¦ i started to write this song with these ideas ringing in my head. to further understand who you are pushes you to further understand where you are from and what that looks and sounds like. there are pieces in that that are worth carrying forever and pieces worth letting die. â€œchinatownâ€ and â€œ45â€ are both the story of this â€“ â€œchinatownâ€ through someone else, â€œ45â€ through the mirror. as for bruce, its the honor of a lifetime to be joined by him. he is the artist who showed me that the sound of the place i am from has value and that there is a spirit here that needs to be taken all over the world.â€

title: Lana Del Rey Covers 'On Eagle's Wings' Hymn in Honor of Joe Biden's Acceptance Speech
content:
Lana Del Rey took a break from the recording studio to share a cover of the hymn "On Eagle's Wings" after being inspired by President-elect Joe Biden's acceptance speech on Saturday (Nov. 7).
In his emotional address, Biden shared some inspiring words from the 1970s hymn, which was a favorite of his late son Beau Biden, who died from cancer in 2015. Obviously inspired, Del Rey took to Instagram to share her a capella take on the Michael Joncas-penned hymn.
â€œAnd He will raise you up on eagleâ€™s wings/ Bear you on the breath of dawn/ Make you shine like the sun/ And hold you in the palm of His hand,â€ Del Rey beautifully sings in the black-and-white clip.

S'adressant directement Ã  Alex, Lana a dÃ©clarÃ© : "Va. Te. Faire. Voir."
Un message simple mais percutant qui aura probablement pris Alex de court. Ã‡a n'est effectivement pas tous les jours qu'une star vous dit d'aller paÃ®tre sur les rÃ©seaux sociaux.
L'utilisatrice a postÃ© par la suite : "Lana me dit d'aller me faire voir alors que j'ai son nom tatouÃ© sur mon bras. Looool bah ok."
Ce Ã  quoi la chanteuse a rÃ©pondu: "Non, relis ce que tu as Ã©crit, pÃ©t****."
Des propos inattendus de la part de la star qui laissent donc entendre qu'elle n'a pas votÃ© pour l'actuel prÃ©sident des Ã‰tats-Unis mais probablement pour son adversaire Joe Biden.
CÃ´tÃ© boulot, Lana prÃ©pare actuellement son prochain album "Chemtrails Over the Country Club", lequel risque de ne pas sortir avant le printemps prochain. En attendant, la chanteuse a annoncÃ© la sortie d'une compilation de NoÃ« qui regroupera de grands classiques de la chanson.
Par ailleurs, la star a rÃ©cemment repris l'hymne de l'Ã©quipe de football de Liverpool, 'You'll Never Walk Alone' pour un documentaire sur le fameux club. Un morceau a cappella qui en a sÃ©duit plus d'un.

title: Lana Del Rey lanzarÃ¡ un Ã¡lbum de covers para Navidad MÃºsica Twitter NNDC
content:
Un problema de logÃ­stica ha llevado a Lana del Rey a comunicar el aplazamiento a 2021 del que habrÃ­a sido su sÃ©ptimo Ã¡lbum de estudio, â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€, y a anunciar en su lugar un trabajo que solo verÃ¡ la luz en formato digital y que contendrÃ¡ â€œstandardsâ€ americanos y clÃ¡sicos navideÃ±os.
En el repertorio, ha comentado ella misma en Twitter, se incluirÃ¡n â€œcanciones de Patsy Cline y algunas del gÃ©nero â€˜americanoâ€™ que tenÃ­a en el bolsillo con Nikki Laneâ€, ha dicho en referencia a un par de temas que tenÃ­a preparados con la artista que abriÃ³ algunos de los conciertos de su anterior gira y que no llegaron a formar parte de su Ãºltimo Ã¡lbum.
En el listado de este disco navideÃ±o con el que pretende compensar a sus seguidores tambiÃ©n estarÃ¡ su versiÃ³n de â€œYouâ€™ll Never Walk Aloneâ€, incluida a su vez en la banda sonora de un nuevo documental sobre el equipo de fÃºtbol del Liverpool.
SegÃºn ha comentado, el motivo del retraso de â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€ radica en las plantas de prensado de vinilos, que permanecerÃ¡n cerradas hasta principios de marzo, por lo que su llegada a las tiendas no se producirÃ¡ antes de â€œ16 o 17 semanasâ€.
El disco, ha aÃ±adido, se encuentra no obstante â€œterminadoâ€ y, segÃºn sus palabras, tiene un aire â€œfolky y superdiferenteâ€ a su predecesor, el disco â€œNormam Fucking Rockwellâ€ (2019), que fue considerado por la prensa especializada como uno de los mejores a nivel mundial de su aÃ±o de ediciÃ³n.
Hace solo unas semanas dio a conocer el primero de los anticipos de este nuevo Ã¡lbum, â€œLet Me Love You Like a Womanâ€, corte pausado, con cierta resonancia onÃ­rica y mÃ­nima instrumentaciÃ³n, que reposa sobre todo en el piano y en la voz de su intÃ©rprete.
Escrita y producida por Lana Del Rey y Jack Antonoff, fue grabada en Los Ãngeles en Conway Studios y en Nueva York en Electric Lady Studios, presumiblemente como el resto del nuevo trabajo.
Desde el inicio de su carrera en 2012 como Lana del Rey con el exitoso â€œBorn To Dieâ€ (previamente lanzÃ³ el disco â€œLana Del Rayâ€ (2010) bajo su nombre real, Lizzy Grant), la estadounidense se ha mostrado muy activa en tÃ©rminos discogrÃ¡ficos, con la publicaciÃ³n de prÃ¡cticamente un disco cada un aÃ±o o dos aÃ±os.

title: Lana Del Rey covers Liverpool FC anthem for an upcoming documentary
content:
Lana Del Rey covers â€˜Youâ€™ll Never Walk Aloneâ€™ by Rogers & Hammerstein for an upcoming documentary. The true to life film is based on the English soccer team Liverpool FC.
The rhythm from the musical, Carousel, has become the adopted anthem for fans of the Premier League champions.
Lana posted a monochrome clip of her singing the song in the studio with a caption reading, â€œFor the new documentary about Liverpool.â€ Reports have suggested that Lanaâ€™s a cappella version of the song will also appear on an album of standards which she is planning.
The renowned dream pop artist delayed the release of her latest album â€˜Chemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€™ due to logistics issues surrounding the vinyl making process. Her album was scheduled to drop in early September but will now be available in January.

title: Lana Del Rey til fan: "Dra til helvete"
content:
VALG: Lana Del Rey reagerte sterkt da en fan anklaget henne for Ã¥ stemme pÃ¥ Donald Trump. Foto: Arroyo-OConnor / AFF
Lana Del Rey til fan: Â«Dra til helveteÂ»
En fan anklaget Lana Del Rey for Ã¥ stemme pÃ¥ president Donald Trump pÃ¥ Twitter. Det likte ikke sangeren.
NÃ¥ nettopp
Etter hvert som resultatene av valget fortsetter Ã¥ strÃ¸mme inn, har Lana Del Rey bedt en fan om Ã¥ Â«go fuxk yourselfÂ», eller Â«dra til helveteÂ» pÃ¥ Twitter. Dette var etter at fanen anklaget sangeren for Ã¥ stemme pÃ¥ Donald Trump, skriver NME.
I en nÃ¥ slettet Twitter-melding skrev en fan: Â«Jeg bare VET at Elizabeth stemte pÃ¥ Trump. Jeg skulle Ã¸nske jeg kunne sÃ¸ke opp hennes stemmer i et stemmeregistreringerÂ», og henviser da til Lana Del Reys virkelige navn - Elizabeth Grant.
Del Rey fikk pÃ¥ en eller annen mÃ¥te nyss om Twitter-meldingen, og ga et veldig kortfattet svar: Â«Go. Fuxk. Yourself.Â»
Dette skriver ogsÃ¥ Billboard.
Lana Del Rey svarer pÃ¥ en Twitter-melding hvor det stÃ¥r: Â«Jeg bare VET at Elizabeth stemte pÃ¥ Trump. Jeg skulle Ã¸nske jeg kunne sÃ¸ke opp hennes stemmer i et stemmeregistreringer.Â» Foto: Skjermdump
Meldingen har i ettertid blitt slettet.
Men i en egen Twitter-melding, som ogsÃ¥ er slettet, avslÃ¸rte hun som hadde anklaget Del Rey for Ã¥ stemme pÃ¥ Trump at hun faktisk er fan av sangeren, og hun hevder Ã¥ ha navnet hennes tatovert pÃ¥ armen.
Â«Lana sa at jeg skulle dra til helvete selv nÃ¥r jeg har henne tatovert pÃ¥ armen minÂ», skrev brukeren.
Men Del Rey sÃ¥ ogsÃ¥ denne Twitter-meldingen. Igjen reagerte hun sterkt og svarte raskt:
Â«Nah, read what u wrote hoeÂ».
NÃ¥r fanen skriver hun er fan av Lana Del Rey og hevder hun har en tatovering av sangeren, svarer Del Rey: Â«Nah, read what u wrote hoeÂ» pÃ¥ Twitter. Foto: Skjermdump
Samtidig har det vÃ¦rt en noe travel uke for Â«Born To DieÂ»-sangeren. Hun kunngjorde nemlig at utgivelsen av hennes kommende album Â«Chemtrails Over The Country ClubÂ» vil bli forsinket til vÃ¥ren.
Hun ga ut hovedsingelen fra albumet, Â«Let Me Love You Like A WomanÂ», i forrige mÃ¥ned.
LÃ¥ta fikk terningkast fire av VG.

title: Lana Del Rey shuts down claims suggesting she voted for Trump
content:
Lana Del Rey shuts down rumors suggesting that she casted a vote in favor of Trump in the US Presidential Election 2020.
A dedicated Lana fan wrote, â€œI just KNOW Elizabeth voted for Trump, I wish I could look up her voting records. Something doesnâ€™t sit right with me.â€
Responding to the ludicrous claim, Lana commented, â€œGo **** yourself.â€
The fan reacted, â€œLana telling me to go **** myself when I have her tattooed on my arm lmfaoooo alright then.â€
Lana then said, â€œNah read what u wrote.â€
The singer has always been one of Trumpâ€™s very staunch critics.
In 2017, she admitted taking part in a protest where witches united to hex Trump.

title: FÃ£ diz que Lana Del Rey votou em Donald Trump. Cantora reage
content:
Na noite desta terÃ§a-feira, um fÃ£ de Lana Del Rey recorreu ao Twitter para lanÃ§ar o rumor. O internauta disse que a artista tinha votado em Donald Trump nas eleiÃ§Ãµes dos EUA, que decorreram esta terÃ§a-feira.
"Eu sei que a Elizabeth [nome de Lana Del Rey] votou no Trump, gostaria de poder pesquisar os seus registos de votaÃ§Ã£o. Para mim, algo nÃ£o estÃ¡ certo", escreveu.
Perante tais palavras, a cantora mostrou desde logo o seu desagrado com as mesmas e respondeu Ã  letra: "Vai-te f******"
De seguida, o seguidor disse: "A Lana estÃ¡ a dizer-me para eu me f***** quando eu a tatuei no meu braÃ§o... tudo bem entÃ£o".

title: Lana Del Rey Delays Chemtrails, Curses Out Fanâ€™s Trump Tweet
content:
She â€œwonâ€™t not fuck you the fuck up.â€ Photo: Rebecca Sapp/Getty Images for The Recording Academy
We interrupt this election coverage to bring you Lana Del Reyâ€™s problems. The singer was active across social-media platforms last night, broadcasting live from a Dennyâ€™s on Instagram and then hopping over to Twitter around 1 a.m. PT to â€¦ cuss out a fan? It was a tense night for many. Tuesday evening, she started streaming from a Dennyâ€™s outdoor dining tent, discussing election non-results with her rumored boyfriend, Clayton Johnson. During the Live, she had good news and bad news. Bad news: Chemtrails Over the Country Club, her forthcoming album, is delayed a whopping 16 to 17 weeks due to backlogs at vinyl pressing plants, which she claims are not reopening until March 5. So, in the meantime, the good news: Sheâ€™s putting out a digital album of â€œAmerican standards and classicsâ€ in time for Christmas. As a teaser, she reveals Chemtrails is completely finished â€” Jack Antonoff has been freed â€” and itâ€™s â€œfolky, super different from Norman,â€ her most recent album, Norman Fucking Rockwell. Later that night, she posted her a cappella rendition of soccer anthem â€œYouâ€™ll Never Walk Aloneâ€ from a new documentary about Liverpool FC to Twitter, and youâ€™d think that would be the last weâ€™d hear from Lizzie Grant for the night, especially this night. But as soon as she uploaded the cover, she started replying to a conversation between two stans speculating that she voted for Trump.
â€œGo. Fuxk. Yourself,â€ she replied, straight up. The fan was shocked. â€œLana telling me to go fuck myself when I have her tattooed on my arm lmfaoooo alright then,â€ they tweeted, adding, â€œI honestly think Iâ€™m gonna have to [unstan]. Itâ€™s just really hard.â€ But Lana wasnâ€™t even done eviscerating this person. â€œBro. Iâ€™ve been waiting for u to [unstan],â€ she responded to the convo again. â€œDo it.â€ She added, â€œNah read what u wrote hoe,â€ with seemingly no inclination as to why fans might assume she voted for Trump â€¦ all while not actually admitting whom she voted for. When the fan deleted the tweets, Del Rey replied with a screenshot. She also called another fan â€œstupidâ€ for tweeting part of the livestream where Del Rey noted â€œa lot of redâ€ on the map. â€œI know lana is anti trump and my goal wasnâ€™t to call her out or whatever,â€ the fan tweeted afterward. â€œOnce again, Iâ€™m sorry.â€ Many had been questioning Del Reyâ€™s vote, asking her to settle their arguments; she opted to call one a â€œhoeâ€ instead of just logging off â€” a fun and not at all hostile relationship to have with your fans in the lead-up to two album releases! â€œSo, thanks for everything, all your support, and thanks for buying me my meal at Dennyâ€™s and my shit at Home Depot,â€ she ended her Live last night. â€œThanks for that, kids.â€

title: 'Go f--k yourself'
content:
Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
Lana Del Rey told a fan to â€œgo fâ€”k herselfâ€ for suggesting that she cast a ballot for Donald Trump.
On Tuesday night, an ardent fan of the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ singer tweeted (using Reyâ€™s real first name Elizabeth): â€œI just KNOW Elizabeth voted for Trump, I wish I could look up her voting records. Something doesnâ€™t sit right with me.â€
The pop star promptly told the fan to â€œGo. Fâ€”k. Yourself.â€
The fan then wrote, â€œLana telling me to go fâ€”k myself when I have her tattooed on my arm lmfaoooo alright then.â€
Clearly, a tattoo did nothing to mollify Del Reyâ€™s feelings because the 35-year-old singer replied, â€œNah read what u wrote hoe.â€
Del Rey has long been an outspoken critic of President Trump.
In 2017, she admitted taking part in a protest where witches united to hex Trump.

title: Lana Del Rey Snaps At Fan Who Said She Voted For Trump: 'Go F*** Yourself'
content:
Lana Del Rey clapped back at a fan on Twitter who assumed she voted for Donald Trump and not Joe Biden in the election, telling her to "go f*** yourself."
The race for the White House is continuing with no winner in sight as the count carries on into Wednesday.
Vote counting is still ongoing in states where there are close races, including Wisconsin, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Georgia and Nevada. Their electoral college votes are crucial for either candidate to get over the line.
President Trump insisted he is winning the state in the early hours of Wednesday, during a defiant press conference in which he prematurely claimed victory amid ongoing vote counts.
So needless to say, tensions are high and the "Blue Jeans" singer was not impressed when a fan presumed who she voted for in the tight race.
The singer, whose given name is Elizabeth Grant, did not hold back when interacting with a fan on social media today.
The fan initially tweeted: "I just KNOW Elizabeth voted for Trump, I wish I could look up her voting records. Something doesn't sit right with me."
To which Grant replied: "Go. F***. Yourself."
Clearly caught off guard by the blunt response, the fan further tweeted: "Lana telling me to go f*** myself when I have her tattooed on my arm lmfaoooo alright then."
Grant then added: "Nah read what u wrote h**."
Here's screenshots of lana del rey putting yall in your place and not giving a fuck. Queen went for blood pic.twitter.com/9xRZMVk4tV â€” legendary del rey (@nfrstan) November 4, 2020
The "Born to Die" hitmaker has not shied away from speaking her mind about politics in the past.
In 2018 she posted a comment on Kanye West's Instagram page saying: "Trump becoming our president was a loss for the country but your support of him is a loss for the culture."
Further eviscerating the presidential hopefulâ€”who himself failed to get many votes todayâ€”she wrote: "I can only assume you relate to his personality on some level. Delusions of Grandeur, extreme issues with narcissismâ€”none of which would be a talking point if we weren't speaking about the man leading our country.
"If you think it's alright to support someone who believes it's OK to grab a woman by the p**** just because he's famous-then you need an intervention as much as he does-something so many narcissists will never get because there just isn't enough help for the issue. Message sent with concern that will never be addressed." (via Cosmopolitan)
The singer made headlines earlier this year when she shared a lengthy Instagram post lashing out at "female writers and alt singers" and those who have criticized her music.

title: Lana del Rey ruziet met fan over stem op Trump
content:
Lana del Rey heeft het flink aan de stok met een fan op Twitter. De fan beschuldigde de 35-jarige zangeres ervan op Trump te hebben gestemd, waarop Del Rey reageerde met "Go. Fuxk. Yourself.".
Daar stopte de fikse discussie niet. De fan benadrukte groot fan van Del Rey te zijn en plaatste daarbij een foto van een tattoo met de tekst 'Lana'. Nog steeds was Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, zoals de zangeres voluit heet, niet te spreken over de actie en beschouwt de volger dan ook niet als een fan: "Nee, kijk wat je schrijft, hoer."
De fan krabbelt terug en besluit zich maar iets minder bezig te houden met haar idool, tot groot genoegen van Lana zelf. "Daar heb ik op gewacht. Doe het", sluit de zangeres af.

title: Lana Del Rey covers 'You'll Never Walk Alone' for new film
content:
Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Lana Del Rey covers "You'll Never Walk Alone" in a new video on Instagram.
The 35-year-old singer shared her a cappella version of the song Tuesday.
Advertisement
The black and white video shows Del Rey recording the song at a studio. Del Rey used a filter to create an old-time movie effect.
"You'll Never Walk Alone" is a show tune from the 1945 musical Carousel. The song is also sung at soccer clubs around the world, including the Liverpool Football Club. Liverpool band Gerry and the Pacemakers released a cover of the song in 1963.
In the caption, Del Rey said she was recording the song for a new documentary about the Liverpool F.C. soccer team.
"You'll never walk alone- accapella," she wrote. "For the new documentary about Liverpool x @liverpoolfc."
Del Rey is a longtime Liverpool F.C. fan who first attended a home match in 2013.
"I was introduced to Liverpool F.C. by my manager, Ben, whose mood is dependent on the Liverpool results. I love watching Luis Suarez play," she told the team's official website at the time.
Del Rey was to release her seventh studio album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, on Sept. 5 but postponed the release. The album features the single "Let Me Love You Like a Woman," released in October.
Del Rey announced her new album in May while slamming critics who say her lyrics glamorize abuse.
"I've been honest and optimistic about the challenging relationships I've had. News flash! That's just how it is for many women. And that was sadly my experience up until the point that those records were made," she said.

title: Lana Del Rey Shuts Down Fan Who Says She "Voted For Trump"
content:
Twitter
Lana â€” whose real name is Elizabeth Grant â€” responded with three simple words: "Go. Fuxk. Yourself."
When the fan tweeted after the fact, pointing out that she has Lana "tattooed on her arm," Lana replied again: "Nah read what u wrote hoe."
And when the fan said she may have to "unstan" Lana, even though it would be "really hard," Lana replied yet again: "Bro. I've been waiting for u to. Do it."

title: Lana Del Rey Posts Lovely Solo Version of 'You'll Never Walk Alone'
content:
In an Election Night post from a Dennyâ€™s, Lana Del Rey gave an update on her forthcoming album â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€ (itâ€™s delayed), promised a â€œdigital record of American standards and classics for Christmas,â€ and posted a lovely version of the 1945 showtune â€œYouâ€™ll Never Walk Aloneâ€ (which was recorded separately, not at Dennyâ€™s).
The post begins Del Rey and Clay Johnson, her rumored boyfriend, having a middle-school level discussion of the election results thus far and how the electoral college works. She then updates fans on the progress of her latest album â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ which she says has been delayed for â€œ16 to 17 weeksâ€ due to backlogs at vinyl pressing plants, which she says are not reopening until March 5. However, she says the album is finished and is â€œfolky, super different from â€˜Norman,â€™â€ referencing her previous album, last yearâ€™s Grammy-nominated â€œNormal Fâ€”ing Rockwell.â€
However, she said sheâ€™ll be releasing a digital album of â€œAmerican standards and classicsâ€ in time for the holidays, including â€œPatsy Cline songs, some Americana with Nikki Lane Iâ€™ve had in my back pocket,â€ referencing the singer-songwriter who opened her 2019 â€œRockwellâ€ tour and occasionally performed with her.
In 2019, at collaborator Jack Antonoffâ€™s annual Ally Coalition concert, Del Rey performed rough versions of a pair of country songs the two of them had been messing around with, although they did not appear on â€œRockwell.â€
Finally, she mentioned her version of â€œYouâ€™ll Never Walk Alone,â€ from a new documentary about the Liverpool football [soccer] team, which she delivers in a powerful a capella version that shows off her impressive range â€” particularly the high notes â€” in a manner that she rarely does on her own songs.

title: Lana del Rey noemt fan â€™hoerâ€™ na ruzie over stem op Trump
content:
En daar bleef het niet bij. De fan, die twittert onder de twijfelachtige naam holyh00ker, benadrukte groot bewonderaar te zijn van Del Rey. Ze plaatste een foto van een tatoege met de tekst Lana.
Maar steeds is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, zoals de zangeres voluit heet, niet te spreken over de actie. Ze beschouwt de volger dan ook niet als een fan: â€Nee, kijk wat je schrijft, hoer.â€
Holyh00ker krabbelt uiteindelijk terug en besluit zich maar iets minder bezig te houden met haar idool. Dit tot groot genoegen van Lana: â€Daar heb ik op gewacht. Doe hetâ€, sluit de wereldster â€“ die goed is voor 9,6 miljoen volgers â€“ af.

title: Lana del Rey furiously responds to fans who think she voted for Trump
content:
Lana Del Rey really wants you to know she did not vote for Donald Trump.
The singer, whose birth name is Elizabeth Grant, exploded at a fan who suggested she might support the president's re-election.
Del Rey also said "what do you know?" as a Republican analyst reported on the election during an Instagram livestream. She then added "shut the f*** up".
Although the singer's feelings are now very clear, fans can be forgiven for questioning her allegiances.
Del Rey's attitude towards politics has long been ambivalent â€“ and controversial.
She has spoken out against Trump before, saying he makes women feel "less safe", and has even directed her followers to put a hex on him. But she's also sparked various backlashes over the years for claiming to be uninterested in feminism, appearing to criticise women of colour musicians for owning their sexuality, posting uncensored videos of Black Lives Matter protesters and wearing a face mask with holes in it while meeting with fans at a poetry reading.
In short, she doesn't always seem to be on the same wavelength as other liberals and progressives when it comes to politics and social justice.
But one thing Del Rey is consistent on is not holding anything back when a fan irritates her on social media.
Her clapbacks are legendary â€“ if a little harsh.
At least we know in no uncertain terms where Del Rey currently stands.

title: Lana Del Rey sings You'll Never Walk Alone as US election results roll in
content:
The video will start in 8 Cancel
Get all the very latest news in Ireland straight to your email every single day Sign up! Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Invalid Email
Lana Del Rey has surprised her fans by singing a song of hope on the night of the US election.
The Video Games singer, 35, took to her Twitter account to share a video of herself singing You'll Never Walk Alone from the musical Carousel as the results rolled in on Tuesday night, US time.
The song will be better known to UK fans as the anthem of Liverpool F.C. thanks to the 1963 cover by scouse band Gerry and the Pacemakers that is sung at matches.
In the black and white video, Lana belted out the opening lines of the song, singing: "When you walk through a storm, hold your head up high and don't be afraid of the dark.
(Image: Twitter)
"At the end of a storm there's a golden sky, and the sweet silver song of a lark."
The song ends: "Walk on, walk on with hope in your heart.
"And you'll never walk alone. You'll never walk alone."
(Image: Twitter)
Lana's fans loved her cover version of the song, with many pointing out the connection to Liverpool.
One tweeted: "Give her time to sing this song for thousands of fans at Anfield before the match starts. Please @LFC."
"Lana said up the reds," another posted.
(Image: Twitter) (Image: Getty Images)
A third said: "Get her in for the inevitable champions league final in May."
"Who knew Lana is a scouser x," another joked.
Another wrote: "My favourite club and my favourite singer."
