title: Lana Del Rey records stunning a-capella version of You'll Never Walk Alone for Liverpool documentary
content:
Nothing wrong with being a newcomer, so sign up to the Liverpool newsletter Subscribe now Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Invalid Email
A new a-capella version of You'll Never Walk Alone has been recorded for a documentary about Liverpool Football Club by Lana Del Rey.
The Grammy-award nominated American singer-songwriter has produced a version of the iconic track which originated from the 1963 Rodgers & Hammerstein musical â€˜Carouselâ€™ and was covered by Merseybeat band Gerry & The Pacemakers before becoming the Reds' anthem.
The full details of the documentary are yet to be released but Del Rey took to Instagram to reveal her involvement.
Sharing a black and white video clip of the new a-capella version of You'll Never Walk Alone, she wrote: â€œYouâ€™ll never walk alone- acapella. For the new documentary about Liverpool."
The 35-year-old star visited Anfield for a game against Tottenham back in 2013 and said she was a Liverpool and Celtic fan.
She told Liverpoolfc.com at the time: "I was introduced to Liverpool FC by my manager, Ben, whose mood is dependent on the Liverpool results. I love watching Luis Suarez play.
Sign up to our free LFC email newsletter Get all the latest updates after Liverpool's 5-0 win at Atalanta, including Jota analysis, plus breaking news, transfer talk and analysis straight to your inbox every day with our FREE email newsletter. Sign up here - it only takes a few seconds!
"It's actually my second time in Liverpool but my first time at Anfield. The people in Liverpool are so friendly and the stadium's really impressive.
"I've not had the chance to attend a game before but I've watched Liverpool on TV before. It's great to actually come to Anfield.
"Liverpool are my team but I also support Celtic in Scotland, who are my boyfriend Barrie's team."

title: Lana Del Rey Shuts Down Fan Who Accused Her of Voting For Donald Trump
content:
"Choosing this misleading clip out of the entire livestream isn't going to get you more livestreams," Del Rey wrote in response to the implication that she was in support of a Republican win. "Stupid," she added.
Another Twitter user then posted a clip from Del Rey's Nov. 3 Instagram livestream , in which she looks at an election map on her phone and notes, "Thatâ€™s a lot of red."
The user then replied in a since-deleted tweet that she may have to "unstan" Lana, though it would be "really hard." Del Rey fired back: "Bro. I've been waiting for u to. Do it."
The apparent fan, Alex, then responded, "I have her tattooed on my arm," which inspired another sharp retort from the singer: "Nah read what u wrote hoe."
Meanwhile, Del Rey shared a hopeful video about her work with the DigDeep water project on behalf of the Navajo community. "No matter what the results of the election just remember we can each as individuals shine brightly and contribute to our world in our own individual way," she wrote alongside the video documenting the importance of clean water to the Navajo people.
"As Iâ€™ve been lucky enough to be given an advance from Simon and Schuster, Iâ€™m so grateful to be able to spread that money around to foundations that are in need of our help beginning with foundations connected to the Navajo community," continued the singer, who announced in July that a portion of the proceeds and her whole advance from her poetry collection, Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, would go to a variety of Native American projects, including the Navajo Water Project.
"We hope the @digdeepwater project will find relief with the $350,000 that we delivered to them last month. I personally have always believed in personal reparations to give back to the people who have shaped our land. I look forward to updating you on the rest of the donations that we make throughout the year."
The fan's tweets have since been hidden, but you can check out Del Rey's tweets below, and watch her DigDeep video here.

title: Lana Del Rey Pushes Back 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club,' Promises Another Album
content:
Lana Del Rey has good news and bad news for her fans. The bad news is that she's delaying the release of her upcoming album Chemtrails Over the Country Club by 16 weeks.
The good news? She's planning to release a record filled with "American standards and classics for Christmas" to tide them over.
In an Instagram Live on Tuesday (Nov. 3), Del Rey posted up with her friend at a Denny's restaurant while the two kept abreast of any more votes coming in for the 2020 election. And in the thick of the anticipation last night, she dropped her own bombshell announcement.

title: Tracks of the week reviewed: Middle Kids, MaxÃ¯mo Park, Lana Del Rey
content:
Middle Kids
R U 4 Me?
Even before the reign of TUT (These Unprecedented Times) it would have been mighty difficult to resist a song that opens with the line: â€œDaylight / Eat a piece of cake to start the day right.â€ After that initial sugar rush, fresh-faced Aussie pop-mob Middle Kids careen through a nervy, Strokes-esque floorfiller about flailing around in search of emotional connection that still manages to be a sunny delight.
Simone White
Goldfinger
Cineworld is not enough: Daniel Craig might keep ghosting us but an imminent benefit album of Bond covers curated by the Wedding Present is here to plug the double-O gap. Realising that there is no way to out-foghorn Dame Shirley, LA-based chanteuse White wisely opts for a more spectral but still gorgeous reading, with soothing waves of guitar reverb instead of brassy raunch.
MaxÃ¯mo Park
Baby, Sleep
The durable geordie cathart-rockers have a new album due early next year and, judging by the lead-off single, they have lost none of their clattering energy. After gnashing his teeth at the state of the world, singer Paul Smith pulls out a surprisingly sweet and lullaby-ready chorus, suggesting there is at least one thing to look forward to in 2021.
Lana Del Rey
Let Me Love You Like a Woman
Used to be you could approach a new Del Rey track confident it would involve a hypnotic, narcotic incantation of dead idols and kitsch Americana. These days, she has found an even more powerful drug: sincerity. The piano-led Let Me Love You Like a Woman still has that widescreen, cinematic LDR feel, but channels it into a classic three-hankie weepie.
New Found Glory
Scarier Than Jason Voorhees at a Campfire
Putting out a silly slasher-themed single in time for Halloween feels like a zombie no-brainer. But these increasingly creaky Floridean punk-poppers still manage to mess it up. Their cardinal sin? Conspicuously name-checking Friday the 13thâ€™s hockey-masked teen-mangler in the title then utterly failing to mention him in the actual song, a cruel tease of Voorhees.

title: Christina Aguilera on Seth Meyers
content:
She turned â€œThe Christmas Songâ€ into â€œThe Christ(ina)mas Song.â€ Photo: YouTube
â€™Tis the damn season, folks. Late night was particularly festive this week, filled with the utter joy that 2020 â€” the year that simply wouldnâ€™t quit â€” is quickly coming to an end. Smiles, laughs, and most notably, music played a larger role in the late-night sphere than usual this week, with memorable performances and musical guests popping up all over. As such, weâ€™re going to jingle them bells and ring in the holiday season with some music-themed moments from this week in late night. Make a joyful noise!
5. Lana Del Rey Goes Dark on The Tonight Show
The Ghost of Christmas Past is here and her name is Lana Del Rey. The moody singer dropped by The Tonight Show on Monday for her first televised performance in over nine years, since she unforgettably graced the stages of SNL and delivered what some critics have called the worst SNL musical performance of all time. I prefer to think she was just misunderstood â€” like literally, no one could understand the words coming out of her mouth. Now, almost a decade later, the sometimes-problematic singer is back on TV singing her newest single â€œLet Me Love You Like a Womanâ€ with far better results. Clad in black leather and singing in a dimly lit bar, Del Reyâ€™s performance is almost anti-Christmas in nature, but still very good. If you squint, you can see a hint of holiday spirit, as there are a few strands of red Christmas lights adorning the stage. Youâ€™d think Lana would be feeling at least somewhat festive, as it was announced this week that she recently got engaged to her new beau Clayton Johnson, but, hey, maybe this is how she expresses joy. Weâ€™re pretty sure Dionne Warwick would put Del Rey firmly in the â€œspookyâ€ category with Miss William Eye Lash.
4. Laura Benantiâ€™s Musical Melania Gagging on The Late Show
Okay, this clip technically isnâ€™t musical in any way, but Laura Benanti has a Tony Award for playing Gypsy Rose Lee, so she gets grandfathered in because we know the talent is there. Laura Benanti broke out her impeccable Melania Trump impersonation on The Late Show With Stephen Colbert to discuss what we all know to be Melaniaâ€™s absolute favorite holiday, Christmas! Apparently, the Trump administration has been holding mask-less Christmas parties this holiday party, which â€” considering the amount of COVID-19 we know exists within the walls of the White House â€” sounds like a veritable death trap (RIP Herman Cain). When asked if sheâ€™s worried that her guests may get sick, Miss Melania â€œWho gives a fuck about Christmas?â€ Trump responds accordingly: â€œOh, who doesnâ€™t wake up a little sick after a good party, eh?â€ she purrs. â€œBesides, Iâ€™ve always considered nausea to be a side effect of spending an evening with my husband.â€ She proceeds to make a series of gagging noises that are legitimately musical in nature, warranting a spot on this list. Also musically satisfying: Benantiâ€™s pronunciation of Kayleigh McEnanyâ€™s name [Kay-Lay Mac-Air-Nay-Nay], whom she doesnâ€™t want to share a jail cell with. Ahh, imagining any Trump in a jail cell is truly music to mine ears.
3. Amber Ruffin Sings a Ditty Dedicated to â€œThe Worst, Worst Christmas of Our Livesâ€
For many reasons, this Christmas is gearing up to be, well, not so great. Rather than ignore that painfully true fact, Late Night With Seth Meyers decided to lean into it with an original â€™50s style song spiritedly sung by writer Amber Ruffin. Ruffin sings the song with its genuinely catchy refrain â€” â€œItâ€™s the worst, worst Christmas of our lives!â€ â€” wearing a festive golden holiday dress while wandering through the empty studio. When asked why she was out there, Ruffin screams, â€œIâ€™m out here singing directly to the audience we havenâ€™t had in eight months and who knows if weâ€™ll ever see again!!â€ before popping back into a cheery smile. After belting out a satisfying key change on the phrase â€œholiday in denial,â€ Ruffin continues to lament about the sorry state of the holidays this year via this upbeat tune, with lyrics like â€œThis yearâ€™s celebration got a whole lot chiller / I want to see my favorite aunt, but I donâ€™t want to kill her,â€ which struck an emotional chord for me because I too would like to see and not kill my favorite aunt (Hi, Aunt Nanette!). Things are rough out there this holiday season, and Late Night seems to understand that this Christmas, weâ€™re not â€œhanging a shining star upon the highest bough-ing,â€ weâ€™re â€œuntil then weâ€™ll have to muddle through somehow-ing.â€
2. Phoebe Bridgers Goes From Her Bedroom to Carnegie Hall on The Late Late Show
Phoebe Bridgers, self-described queen of horny sad girls, is one of the rare artists who was able to make it on this list with a musical performance on a week not dedicated to music. This week, sheâ€™s back, with a truly stunning performance of her song â€œKyotoâ€ from her album Punisher on The Late Late Show. The Grammy nominee for Best New Artist kicks off the video by singing in a makeshift bedroom before stumbling out of bed and wandering onto the stage of Carnegie Hall, performing the song accompanied by her longtime collaborator Rob Moose. Her appearance on The Late Late Show was holiday-themed in that it gave the gift of introducing the world to a gorgeous, string-laden new arrangement of â€œKyoto,â€ and Bridgers wore pajamas for the performance, which has major â€œChristmas morningâ€ vibes. Also, at the end she revealed that the whole thing was done via the magic of green screens, which is the real Christmas miracle.
1. Christina Aguilera Fully Reinvents â€œThe Christmas Songâ€ on Late Night With Seth Meyers
Vocal acrobat Christina Aguilera dropped by Late Night With Seth Meyers apropos of nothing this week to sing an absolutely wild rendition of â€œThe Christmas Song,â€ and while it wasnâ€™t quite a Fergieâ€™s National Anthem moment, it came pretty damn close. From moment one of the performance Xtina brings the drama, walking down a spiral staircase in a tasteful seasonal plaid pantsuit. Already, we know weâ€™re in for something big, and boy do we get it. She starts the performance off going 60 percent/40 percent re: sticking to the melody versus making it her own, but after finishing one pass at the song, Christina simply decides to go off and sing whatever the hell she wants. In round two, â€œThe Christmas Songâ€ becomes almost unrecognizable and transitions into something that can only be described as â€œThe Christ(ina)mas Song,â€ a smorgasbord of fierce belting and superfluous melismas and riffs. Christinaâ€™s vocal performance encapsulates everything we know and love about Christmas: Itâ€™s over the top, itâ€™s absolutely unnecessary and show-y, and legitimately too much. God bless Christina Aguilera, one of the most talented vocalistas to ever vocalista. Merry Christ(ina)mas to you and yours.

title: The Best Music Books of 2020
content:
In a year filled with things we didnâ€™t want to think about, there were few more indulgent escapes than music books. Thanks to everyone who took the trouble to write and publish them, in a year when record and book stores were closed and, worst of all, music fans were deprived of concerts and will be for at least several months to come â€” a feeling that, as one friend described it today, â€œis like being deprived of an essential nutrient.â€ But like live albums and livestreams, books brought us at least a little closer to the sensations we miss so much. Every â€œbest ofâ€ list is incomplete and it would be impossible to cover every worthy book, especially when some of them so with apologies to the ones we didnâ€™t get to â€” particularly Rob Halford and Dave Mustaine, whose omission here is not a metal snub! â€” in no particular order, here are The Best Music Books of 2020 That We Managed to Procure and Actually Finish Readingâ€¦
(Note: The irony of music writers reviewing books about music is not lost on these music writersâ€¦)
â€œCanâ€™t Slow Down: How 1984 Became Popâ€™s Blockbuster Yearâ€ by Michaelangelo Matos â€” The veteran music writer, New Yorker critic and author of the excellent dance-music tome â€œThe Underground Is Massiveâ€ turns his formidable attention to a year that he quite convincingly argues marked the beginning of the music megastar. As expected, Prince, Madonna, Bruce Springsteen, Tina Turner and, er, Huey Lewis dominate the stage, but Matos delves just as expertly into the burgeoning rap, indie-rock and dance music scenes, as well as country, technology, the business (this was the year affordable CDs first began to appear) and lots more. Itâ€™s an informed and witty although rather completist read â€” to use a period-appropriate metaphor, itâ€™s a bit like digging through every single bin in a record store â€” but thereâ€™s volumes of information and perspectives even for those of us who were there.
â€œMore Myselfâ€ by Alicia Keys â€” Like many memoirs, this unexpectedly engaging tome is most interesting when focused on Keysâ€™ early years in New Yorkâ€™s rough and tumble Hellâ€™s Kitchen neighborhood and the trials of navigating her initial fame, which was challenging even for a young woman raised in New York City in the â€˜80s. Keys is candid and New York tough throughout (fun fact: she first met her husband, producer Swizz Beatz, when she was 14 but didnâ€™t connect with him until many years later), although her humility begins to feel a bit forced as she reaches superstardom â€” but then again, itâ€™s probably pretty hard not to flex when youâ€™re a 15-time Grammy winner describing a private lunch at the White House with Bono and President Obama.
â€œViolet Bent Backwards Over the Grassâ€ by Lana Del Rey â€” The leap from song to text is a tricky one, even for one of the funniest and most clever lyricists working today. Although Del Reyâ€™s self-serious side grabs the wheel for much of her first book of poetry, her wit and dry perspective shine; her Kodachrome-style photos and typewritten fonts (along with vintage shots and artwork by others) bring a visual dimension that helps to compensate for the initial disconnect of experiencing her words without melody.
â€œThey Just Seem a Little Weird: How Kiss, Cheap Trick, Aerosmith, and Starz Remade Rock and Rollâ€ by Doug Brod â€” Whatâ€™s better than a terrific rock biography? Four terrific rock biographies packed into one, with nothing lost in the headbanging whiplash of going back and forth between a quartet of individually and collectively fascinating bands. For anyone who lived through the ascent of flamboyant guitar music in the 1970s or has a residual fondness for these monsters of rock that continued to thrive into the â€™80s and beyond, there could scarcely be a more entertaining read than â€œThey Just Seem a Little Weird,â€ an absorbing first book by former Spin magazine editor Doug Brod. At first it might seem like a conceit to continually be finding the connections between Aerosmith, Cheap Trick and the rather less heralded Starz, but Brod easily makes a case that these groups are united not just in their frequent intersections but in having influenced rock for a lifetime to come. Itâ€™s a music nerdâ€™s biographical delight: less childhood backstories or sordid marital tales, and lots more about which Kiss album really represented shark-jumping or discussion about why Steven Tyler looked down on Gene Simmonsâ€™ rival outfit and Joe Perry didnâ€™t. Thereâ€™s a deep level of reporting by Brod that results in one amusing or trenchant detail after another, as he brings the funny and, more importantly, brings the fondness. (Read Varietyâ€™s excerpt from Brodâ€™s book here.) â€” Chris Willman
â€œTotal F*cking Godhead: The Biography of Chris Cornellâ€ by Corbin Reiff â€” One of the defining rock singers of his generation, the late Chris Cornell rarely got the sort of literary attention bestowed on his Seattle contemporary Kurt Cobain, and Reiffâ€™s exhaustively researched tome does yeomanâ€™s work to fill that void. Tracing Cornellâ€™s life from a quiet, Beatles-worshipping kid through his time as the shirtless demigod frontman of Soundgarden, his divisive second act in supergroup Audioslave, and his sadly truncated tenure as a rock and roll elder statesman, Reiff gives the singer his due as both an artist and a man, and several scenes depicted here â€š Cornellâ€™s sudden discovery of his higher vocal register, his odd couple friendship with Mother Love Bone frontman Andrew Wood, his Forrest Gump-like ability to show up at one watershed moment in musical history after another â€” feel ready-made for screenplay treatment. â€” Andrew Barker
â€œLooking to Get Lost: Adventures in Music & Writingâ€ by Peter Guralnick â€” At 500-plus words, this hefty missive from one of the true masters of this genre plays to all of his strengths: a series of deeply knowledgeable and heartfelt profiles, portraits and perspectives on some of the greatest musicians of the past 75 years, ranging from Ray Charles and Johnny Cash to Howlin Wolf and Eric Clapton. It unfolds like a series of New Yorker articles â€” with Guralnick at the wheel, all you need to do is sit back and enjoy the ride.
â€œDâ€™Angeloâ€™s Voodooâ€ by Faith A. Pennick â€” The high-water mark of the neo-soul movement, Dâ€™Angeloâ€™s sophomore album turned him into a true superstar at the dawn of the current millennium, but it also set a standard that he would struggle for years to live up to â€” a follow-up album would not emerge for 14 years â€” and earned him the sort of fame that he would soon discover he had no interest in maintaining. Pennickâ€™s book for Bloomsburyâ€™s 33 1/3 series tackles the album from a multitude of angles â€” some scholarly, some personal â€” and her chapter-length dissection of the infamous music video for â€œUntitled (How Does It Feel)â€ offers an insightful, all-too-rare exploration of the damage that body-image issues and objectification can wreak on male stars, too. â€” Andrew Barker
â€œSing Backwards and Weepâ€ by Mark Lanegan â€” Out of all the music books released this horrible year, itâ€™s hard to imagine one making a readerâ€™s jaw drop more often than this harrowing memoir from the former Queens of the Stone Age vocalist who, to quote the book blurb, â€œwithin less than a decade would rise to fame as the frontman of the Screaming Trees and then fall from grace as a low-level crack dealer and homeless heroin addict.â€ To hear him tell it, Lanegan was a truly horrible person, a hustler, petty criminal and alcoholic from elementary school on. While the Trees were one of the more feted bands of the era â€” the less familiar will be drawn in by drug-addled cameos from Laneganâ€™s close friends like Kurt Cobain, Layne Staley and others â€” his bad behavior became more aimed at himself. Heâ€™s said that â€œwriting this book was probably the most unpleasant thing Iâ€™ve ever doneâ€ â€” and although thatâ€™s quite a statement considering some of the events in â€œSing Backwards,â€ itâ€™s also hard to look away.
â€œThe Velvet Underground Experienceâ€ by Christian Fevret and Carole Mirabello / â€œMy Week Beats Your Year: Encounters With Lou Reedâ€ by Michael Heath and Pat Thomas â€” The history of the Velvets and Reed is thoroughly trodden ground, and these beautifully rendered collections wisely donâ€™t try to reinvent that wheel. Instead, the VU book is a gorgeous reproduction of the English-language catalog from a 2016 exhibit, filled with rare photos of the band and other ephemeralia, while the Reed tome is a collection of the notoriously cantankerous bardâ€™s most infamous interviews, illustrated with period photos and summarized by the title of one of its closing chapters, â€œâ€˜People Are Really Stupidâ€™: A Lifetime of Pain With Rockâ€™s Mr. Angry.â€™â€
â€œJimmy Page: The Anthologyâ€ by Jimmy Page â€” This lavish tome, which is approximately the size and weight of a tombstone, is essentially a companion to the Led Zeppelin founderâ€™s equally lavish 2010 â€œAutobiography.â€ Heâ€™s dug deep into his vast personal archives and photographed hundreds of items for this follow-up: guitars and stage outfits to memos and diary pages and receipts and loads of other stuff, photographed in pristine detail. While the accompanying text glosses over the less-flattering points of his history (his long heroin addiction and youthful paramours arenâ€™t mentioned), even casual Zeppelin fans will find the photos from this well-curated archive dump dive fascinating.
â€œThere Was a Time: James Brown, the Chitlinâ€™ Circuit and Meâ€ by Alan Leeds â€” Publicist, DJ, tour manager and more, Leeds has had a close-up view of Brown, Prince, Dâ€™Angelo and others. As the title says, this book focuses on his years with Brown, and while there are countless fascinating scenes and anecdotes, the main impression is of what a horrible boss the Hardest Working Man in Show Business was: When Leeds was a DJ, Brown sweet-talked him like a silver-tongued devil â€” but their relationship changed completely the minute Leeds became an employee. Geniuses are often not nice people â€” especially ones who overcame the daunting and degrading obstacles that Brown did â€” and Leeds managed to retain his admiration and respect for the man, even when he was being a total asshole.
â€œTime Between: My Life as a Byrd, Burrito Brother and Beyondâ€ by Chris Hillman â€” Probably due to his unassuming nature, Hillman is one of rockâ€™s overlooked giants of the â€˜60s â€” an original Byrd, a pioneer in merging country and rock with that band and the Flying Burrito Brothers, cowriter of â€œSo You Wanna Be a Rock and Roll Starâ€ and one of the greatest rock bassists in history. To a degree, that unassuming nature â€” or maybe just 50-plus years of hindsight â€” also sometimes makes this book a bit of an anti-â€œBehind the Musicâ€: Whether or not he indulged, you sometimes long for more sex, drugs and rock and roll, or at least a bit more dishing: â€œWait, tell me more about hanging out with the Beatles! What other crazy things did Gram Parsons do? What else do you remember about Altamont?!â€ Still, itâ€™s fascinating to read about his view from slightly out of the spotlight as countless memorable characters drift in and out of his life.
â€œOne Last Song: Conversations on Life, Death and Musicâ€ by Mike Ayers â€” Itâ€™s hard to imagine a more grim musical topic, especially in the year of COVID, than oneâ€™s dying moment. But Ayers got a wide range of musicians â€” from Andre 3000 and Sonny Rollins to Phoebe Bridgers and Wanda Jackson â€” to weigh in on which song would be the one theyâ€™d like to be the last one they hear before they die. Considering the context, itâ€™s an unexpectedly uplifting read.
â€œUtopia Avenueâ€ by David Mitchell â€” Itâ€™s not often that novels cross into authentic music writing, but the latest from the ambitious author of such works as â€œCloud Atlasâ€ and â€œThe Thousand Autumns of Jacob De Zoetâ€ has turned his gaze to a fictional rock band (bearing the bookâ€™s title) in 1960s Swinging London. While Mitchellâ€™s greatest strengths â€” voice and a slightly supernatural plot â€” are very much present here, it does at times feel like itâ€™s trying a bit too hard to launch a BBC or HBO miniseries, with the jolly jocularity of a bandâ€™s â€œchemistryâ€ and fictional hammy cameos from everyone from David Bowie and Syd Barrett to John Lennon and Joni Mitchell. Heâ€™s done his homework and evokes the zeal, excess and language of the era, but while such easter eggs may delight the more casual reader, they often as not induce an eye-roll from snobs like us. Itâ€™s a compelling story if you donâ€™t mind a little extra cheese.
â€œMusic by Max Steiner: The Epic Life of Hollywoodâ€™s Most Influential Composerâ€ by Steven C. Smith â€” A film music career couldnâ€™t get any fuller than Steinerâ€™s three-decade run at the top, and a chronicling of it couldnâ€™t get any better than Smithâ€™s second book. His first, 1991â€™s â€œA Heart at Fireâ€™s Center: The Life and Music of Bernard Herrmann,â€ helped precipitate a huge uptick of interest in that once neglected, now deified film composer. He gives Steiner the same exhaustive biographical treatment here, and differences between the two greats are immediately apparent. While Herrmann could be said to have something close to a signature style with his Hitch films, Steiner was an unparalleled journeyman who could (and did) do anything orchestral, from â€œKing Kong,â€ â€œCasablancaâ€ and â€œGone With the Windâ€ to â€œA Summer Place.â€ Smith makes the case, which maybe should be but isnâ€™t always obvious, that Steinerâ€™s brilliant versatility shouldnâ€™t be held against him. The other big difference? That Steiner was funny as hell, which means this â€œEpic Lifeâ€ is filled with a surprising number of laughsâ€¦ even if Smithâ€™s ultimate intent is to show that, beneath his dishy, jolly surface, Steiner was just as much the tortured artist. You donâ€™t have to be a film score buff â€” although, given Smithâ€™s mastery of describing the composing art, it doesnâ€™t hurt! â€” to become transfixed by this golden-age-of-Hollywood slice of life. (Read Varietyâ€™s interview with Smith here.) â€” Chris Willman

Und genau der soll nun bereits vor Lana auf die Knie gegangen sein â€“ und die "Born To Die"-Interpretin habe den Antrag sogar angenommen!
Wie Us Weekly von einem Insider erfahren haben will, soll sich Lana tatsÃ¤chlich nach nur wenigen Monaten mit Clayton verlobt haben. Angefeuert wurde die GerÃ¼chtekÃ¼che am Montagabend durch einen Auftritt in Jimmy Fallons (46) "Tonight Show": Dort trug Lana einen Ring, den etliche Fans als Verlobungsring deuteten.
Angeblich lernte die 35-JÃ¤hrige ihren vier Jahre jÃ¼ngeren Partner auf einer Dating-App kennen. Seit August folgen sich die beiden auf Instagram. Im November tauchte Lana erstmals auf einem Foto auf Claytons Profil auf â€“ allerdings sind lediglich ihre Beine zu sehen.

title: Lana Del Rey is reportedly engaged to a man she met on a dating app around five months ago
content:
Lana Del Rey appears to be rounding out a controversial year with some exciting news.
While sheâ€™s yet to confirm the news to her followers, the singer has been spotted on several occasions sporting an engagement ring, believed to have been given to her by a man she met on a dating app around August.
The Grammy nominee â€” who tends to keep her love life under wraps â€” has been dating singer Clayton Johnson, 31, with a source confirming to PEOPLE theyâ€™re set to tie the knot.
RELATED: Lana Del Rey hits back over â€˜racismâ€™
Speculation started to mount on Monday when the singer performed her new track Love You Like A Woman on The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon , and eagle-eyed fans spotted a big honking ring on her finger.
A flurry of exclamatory Tweets followed: â€œLana is engaged omgâ€ and â€œYâ€™all see that?â€ next to a close-up photo of the ring.
This wasnâ€™t the first time the rock sparked rumours, however. On November 18, another fan tweeted a photo of Lana wearing the bling, and someone else spotted the rock way back on Halloween, where the duo wore matching The Wizard of Oz costumes.
RELATED: Lana Del Rey slammed for dragging BeyoncÃ©
Lana is caught with a ring on her ring finger AGAIN pic.twitter.com/qK2bJ6jVKK â€” ğšğšğšŠğšğšŠğš— (@streamcocc) December 12, 2020
Meu Deus: Lana Del Rey com amigos celebrando o #Halloween2020 pic.twitter.com/HvB5pf7vUI â€” Lana Del Rey Addiction (@LDRaddic) November 1, 2020
It seems to be a whirlwind romance for the singer, who confirmed sheâ€™d split from her policeman boyfriend Sean Larkin back March. Larkin, 46, also revealed that the two were â€œjust friendsâ€ in a New York Times profile around the same time.
Johnson and Del Rey started following each other on Instagram in August, and since then, fans have spotted her appearing on his social media.
The two seem to have a lot in common given Johnson is also a musician.
Del Reyâ€™s new beau was a vocalist and guitarist of trio The Johnsons, alongside his brothers Chantry and Connor. The trio â€” originally from Modesto, California â€” last released Call Whenever in June 2017 on SoundCloud.
Like many celebs this year, Del Rey has courted controversy with her social media presence and questionable antics amid the pandemic, including wearing a mesh face mask to greet fans at a recent event.
In June, the singer also faced backlash over a video showing looters in the riots following George Floydâ€™s death.
Twitter users accused Del Rey, 34, of sharing a minute-long video of looters to her 16.5 million followers on Instagram, exposing their faces in the up-close-and-personal footage.
But the Del Rey uproar of 2020 originally kicked off in May, when the star took to Instagram to address criticism that her music was â€œglamorizing abuseâ€.
In the message, Del Rey called out a plethora of other artists for making â€œsongs about being sexy, wearing no clothes, f***ing, cheating, etc.â€
Most of the women listed by Del Rey are black, causing followers to accuse her of racial bias in her response.

title: Lana Del Rey fiancÃ©e, ce qu'il faut savoir sur son petit-ami Clayton Johnson
content:
Voici tout ce qu'il faut savoir sur Clayton Johnson, le fiancÃ© de Lana Del Rey.
Il y a quelque temps, Lana Del Rey se faisait mÃ©chamment tacler par les internautes, jugÃ©e d'inconsciente face au Covid-19. AprÃ¨s cette histoire qui a fait un gros bad buzz, aujourd'hui, on parle encore de la chanteuse new-yorkaise mais pour un tout autre sujet. D'aprÃ¨s Us Weekly, Lana Del Rey est dÃ©sormais fiancÃ©e Ã  Clayton Johnson, son nouveau petit-ami... Puisque personne ne savait qu'ils Ã©taient en couple jusqu'ici ! En rÃ©alitÃ©, le fiancÃ© de la chanteuse est un musicien et chanteur, qui a fait ses dÃ©buts dans le groupe The Johnsons, avec ses deux petits frÃ¨res, comme les Jonas Brothers. Il a d'ailleurs fait une apparition dans le clip "Cake by the Ocean" de DNCE, l'ancien groupe de Joe Jonas, en jouant un commentateur sportif.
Outre sa carriÃ¨re de chanteur et musicien, Clayton Johnson est aussi mannequin. Il a participÃ© Ã  des campagnes publicitaires pour les marques Forever 21 et pour une marque de coques de tÃ©lÃ©phone, Incipio. Mais d'ailleurs, oÃ¹ on bien pu se rencontrer le jeune homme de 31 ans et Lana Del Rey ? D'aprÃ¨s People Magazine, les deux tourtereaux auraient fait connaissance sur une application de rencontres... Comme quoi, mÃªme quand on est une cÃ©lÃ©britÃ©, les plateformes et rÃ©seaux sociaux peuvent toujours servir pour trouver l'amour ! Cependant, les amoureux n'ont pas encore postÃ© de photos ensemble, ni mÃªme officialisÃ© leur relation. En mÃªme temps, aprÃ¨s les critiques des stars de la chanson envers Lana Del Rey, qui Ã©tait jugÃ©e raciste, elle se fait plus discrÃ¨te sur la Toile dÃ©sormais.

title: Lana Del Ray is engaged to singer Clayton Johnson: report
content: On â€œThe Tonight Show,â€ Del Rey performed the song â€œLet Me Love You Like a Woman,â€ which she released in October. The single is part of her upcoming album â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ due out next year.

title: â€˜Lana Del Rey verloofd met geliefdeâ€™
content:
Lana Del Rey zou zich volgens Us Weekly verloofd hebben met haar vriend Clayton Johnson, met wie ze bijna een jaar samen is. De 35-jarige zangeres zou de verlovingsgeruchten op gang gebracht hebben nadat ze met een flink glimmende ring optrad tijdens de late night show van de Amerikaanse presentator Jimmy Fallon.
Volgens een bron zou Johnson zijn vriendin onlangs ten huwelijk hebben gevraagd, al wilde Lana's woordvoerder dat nieuws niet bevestigen.
Op sociale media zijn fans er zeker van dat hun idool binnenkort in het huwelijksbootje stapt, nadat ze een foto op Instagram plaatste waarop aan haar linkerhand een ring te zien was. "Hallo?! Hebben jullie die enorme ring aan Lana's vinger ook gezien? Dit kan toch niets anders dan een verlovingsring zijn?", aldus een fan.
Vorige maand werd de zangeres ook al eens gespot met de ring, waardoor volgers zich toen ook al afvroegen of er misschien meer gaande was.

title: Lana Del Rey engaged to boyfriend Clayton Johnson: Report
content:
Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window)
Lanaâ€™s Del-gaged.
Lana Del Rey and boyfriend Clayton Johnson are reportedly engaged after dating for less than a year.
Us Weekly reported Tuesday that Johnson recently put a ring on the â€œYoung and Beautifulâ€ chanteuseâ€™s finger; fans had spotted a ring on her finger during her Monday performance on â€œThe Tonight Show.â€ People magazine echoed the news Tuesday evening as well.
Us reports that the coupleâ€™s social-media flirtation â€” which in 2020 practically counts as being caught going in and out of a hotel together â€” dates back to August, graduating from flirty comments to videos and clips of each other.
Guitarist Johnson is something of an also-ran in the music world, having notched his biggest success via a cover â€” with his brothers â€” of the 2015 Kanye West, Paul McCartney and Rihanna novelty hit â€œFourFiveSeconds.â€ He bounced around in several other bands, modeled and appeared in music videos for DNCE and Paris Hilton. So, an all-around LA renaissance man, really.
Del Rey split from her previous boyfriend, cop Sean Larkin, in March. Page Six has reached out to her team for comment.

content:

Lana Del Rey may have some happy news as the year reaches a close as rumours swirl she has become engaged to a gentleman she met on a dating app.
The 35-year-old chart topping star â€“ whose name is Elizabeth Grant â€“ is said to have fallen head over heels for a fellow musician named Clayton Johnson and allegedly said â€œyesâ€ when he got down on one knee.
Tongues were set wagging that Lana and her 31-year-old beau were planning wedding bells following an appearance by the Born To Die singer on The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon on Monday.
Fans were quick to spot a giant rock on the singerâ€™s wedding finger â€“ while some fans discovered the ring had been on her finger for days while reviewing recent social media posts by the star.
(Image: NBC)
People Magazine has claimed that the singer is indeed engaged.
A report published by the US magazine on Tuesday states: â€œThe Grammy nominee â€” who largely keeps her love life under wraps â€” recently got engaged to singer Clayton Johnson.â€
People also claimed the pair had a very modern way of matching, adding: â€œThe couple met on a dating app.â€
(Image: Clayton Johnson /Instagram)
The outlet failed to reveal which app exactly the singers had matched on.
Twitter was awash with speculation on Monday evening after Lana sang on Jimmy Fallonâ€™s show.
One curious fan wrote: "The ring on her finger? Is she engaged?â€ alongside a pair of eyes emoji.
While another gasped: "Lana is caught with a ring on her ring finger AGAIN," alongside a screngrab from a recent Instagram post by the singer.
(Image: FilmMagic)
Despite being in the spotlight for a decade, Lana has kept her romantic life closely guarded.
It is believed she was engaged in 2014 to then-boyfriend, Scottish singer Barrie-James O'Neill â€“ founder and frontman of a band called Kassidy.
Her current romance is believed to be only months old â€“ after the singer broke up with policeman boyfriend Sean 'Sticks' Larkin last year.

title: Lana Del Rey Engaged to Boyfriend Clayton Johnson
content:
Photo-Illustration: Vulture, Getty Images and YouTube
Leave it to Lana Del Rey to outdo herself after dating a cop. A source confirmed to People that Del Rey is engaged, after she wore a hefty ring during her December 14 return to late night on the Tonight Show. Her new beau? Clayton Johnson, a former singer in a YouTube cover band with his brothers. People added that 25-year-old Del Rey and 31-year-old Johnson met on a dating app, and according to the report, they began following each other on Instagram in August. Johnson has since posted photos with Del Rey to his account, along with appearing in Del Reyâ€™s Election Night Instagram Live from Dennyâ€™s.
Johnson previously had a bit of a music career of his own in pop band the Johnsons with his two brothers, Chantry and Connor. They covered pop songs on their YouTube channel, which racked up nearly 90,000 subscribers, with the earliest video, a cover of Magic!â€™s â€œRude,â€ posted in July 2014. Their most popular video is a cover of Rihanna, Paul McCartney, and Kanye Westâ€™s â€œFourFiveSeconds,â€ which has 1.5 million views. The Johnsons never covered Del Rey herself, but they covered multiple songs by her sisterâ€“inâ€“Jack Antonoff Taylor Swift, for whatever thatâ€™s worth. (And that â€œNew Romanticsâ€ cover is kind of fun, isnâ€™t it?) They also released some music of their own, including the shameless SEO-grab of a song â€œCalvin Kleinsâ€ and â€œScream,â€ produced by former Eve 6 drummer Tony Fagenson. Billboard called the Johnsons â€œseriously catchy pop musicâ€ when the outlet premiered â€œScreamâ€ in 2017, which it called â€œan irresistible jam.â€ We kind of have to agree! Sadly, the Johnsonsâ€™ last song posted to YouTube was their original â€œCall Me Wheneverâ€ in May 2017. But hey, maybe Caleb can add some harmonies on his new fiancÃ©eâ€™s next album?

title: Lana Del Rey, Chicks to Perform at Jack Antonoff's Ally Coalition Show
content:
The annual Ally Coalition Talent Show is one of the best benefits of the year, which has seen stellar performances in the past from Taylor Swift, Lana Del Rey, Kacey Musgraves, Lorde, the (Dixie) Chicks, the National, Carly Rae Jepsen and Antonoff himself.
While this yearâ€™s event will be virtual, the lineup is just as stellar as ever, with Del Rey, the Chicks, Brittany Howard, St. Vincent, Maggie Rogers, Hayley Williams, Sleater-Kinney, Tierra Whack, Clairo and many more (the full lineup appears below). It takes place on Monday, December 21 at 9 p.m. ET exclusively on Twitch.TV/JackAntonoff.
This yearâ€™s event will be free to view with a suggested donation. To RSVP for the show visit Twitch.TV/JackAntonoff. To learn more about Talent Show and to donate to TAC, visit TACâ€™s Talent Show Action Center.
Monies raised throughout the evening will be used to distribute to partner organizations around the country that serve the LGBTQ youth community, including but not exclusively, BreakOUT!, BU Wellness Network, Lost-n-Found Youth, New Alternatives, Oakland LGBTQ Community Center, and the Ruth Ellis Center. These organizations address homelessness and create safe, affirming spaces. 40% of youth experiencing homelessness identify as LGBTQ.
The night will again be curated by founding members Jack Antonoff and Rachel Antonoff, and will feature performances by Big Red Machine, Bleachers, Blu DeTiger, The Chicks, Clairo, Claud, Andrew Dost, Brittany Howard, Lana Del Rey, Muna, Maggie Rogers, Shamir, Sleater-Kinney, Spoon, St. Vincent, Rufus Wainwright, Wallows, Tierra Whack, Hayley Williams, and surprise guests.
Comedians Kalen Allen, Mike Birbiglia, Aidy Bryant, Chris Laker, The Lucas Bros., Jacqueline Novak, Reggie Watts, and Roy Wood Jr., will appear to provide one-minute sets of stand up, and Rachael Ray will share her favorite one minute recipe. The evening will be produced by NAACP & EMMY-nominated Michael Matuza (MBM Entertainment).
â€œThe TAC talent show is the night of the year I look forward to most,â€ notes TAC co-founder Jack Antonoff. â€œObviously we canâ€™t meet in person this year, but the money this show raises is more important than ever, considering how disproportionately marginalized communities have been affected by the pandemic. This show is always about getting my friends together and keeping things really loose, so magic can happen. This year will be no different â€“ lots in store. Play it loud and have a party at home cause this one is gonna be something else.â€
Leading up to the show, fans will also have an opportunity to get a signed guitar from Jack Antonoff by either donating to TAC or by taking action to end conversion therapy. In addition, all fans who donate $10 or more, before or during the show, will be entered to win a pair of Bose headphones. To donate or to take action, please visit TACâ€™s Talent Show Action Center.
â€œOur community continues to encourage and support each other and the causes they care about, and together have raised more than $83 million for charity in 2020,â€ said Brian Rucker, Director of Premium Music Content at Twitch. â€œWe are thrilled to partner with The Ally Coalition to host this yearâ€™s Talent Show on Twitch, which will see some of the biggest names in music and entertainment coming together to raise funds for an amazing and much needed cause â€“ supporting LGBTQ youth organizations across the U.S., with a focus on Black LGBTQ youth.â€

The news comes not long after the Summertime Sadness singer called it quits with her ex-boyfriend
American singer Lana Del Rey is reportedly engaged to her boyfriend Clayton Johnson after less than a year of them dating.
According to a report by Us Weekly, fans spotted a new bling on â€˜thatâ€™ finger of the singer while she performed on The Tonight Show on Monday.
The portal claimed that Rey and Johnson had been engaged in social media PDA since August this year as they dropped flirty comments on each otherâ€™s posts.

title: Lana Del Rey Performs on Tonight Show 9 Years After SNL Bomb
content:
Eye contact! Cheeky smiles galore! Photo: YouTube
In January 2012, Lana Del Rey performed on Saturday Night Live in a set so criticized that many have called it one of the worst SNL performances of all time. Meant to build steam for the release of her debut album, Born to Die, the set instead led her to cancel any further television slots and postpone her tour. Last night, nine years later, the singer re-debuted on American television on Jimmy Fallonâ€™s show, performing the newest single, â€œLet Me Love You Like a Woman,â€ from her forthcoming album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club. Shot in a moody barroom, Del Rey wears dark locks and a leather outfit and is backed by a full band, with the Grammy nominee and Oscar winner TÃ¡ta Vega, Melodye Perry, and Kenna Ramsey as backup singers. Del Rey makes plenty of eye contact and smiles at the camera and is more empowered in her voice and body language than the last time we saw her on TV, when she looked nervous and sang offbeat, flat songs with her arms rarely leaving her sides.
No further details about the new album have been announced since its delay, but we know Del Rey has teamed up with Jack Antonoff again, who produced her previous album, Norman Fucking Rockwell! The singer also released a book of poems earlier this year titled Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, for which Antonoff wrote accompanying music.

title: Lana Del Rey performs 'Let Me Love You Like a Woman' on 'Tonight Show'
content:
Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Lana Del Rey performed "Let Me Love You Like a Woman" during an appearance on The Tonight Show starring Jimmy Fallon.
The 35-year-old singer performed the song during Monday's episode of the NBC late-night show.
Advertisement
Del Rey was joined by a live band and backup singers for the performance at a rustic bar. The Tonight Show official Twitter account said the performance was Del Rey's first U.S. TV appearance in nine years.
Del Rey released "Let Me Love You Like a Woman" in October. The song is the lead single from Del Rey's forthcoming seventh studio album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club.
Del Rey originally planned to release her new album in September but delayed the release due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In May, she addressed critics who say her lyrics are anti-feminist and that she glamorizes abuse.
"Im fed up with female writers and alt singers saying that I glamorize abuse when in reality I'm just a glamorous person singing about the realities of what we are all now seeing are very prevalent emotionally abusive relationships all over the world," Del Rey wrote on Instagram.
"I've been honest and optimistic about the challenging relationships I've had. News flash! That's just how it is for many women. And that was sadly my experience up until the point that those records were made," she said.
Chemtrails Over the Country Club will mark Del Rey's first album since Norman [Expletive] Rockwell, released in August 2019. In November, Del Rey covered the song "You'll Never Walk Alone" for a new documentary.

title: Lana Del Rey Takes the Vintage Route With â€˜Fallonâ€™ Performance: Watch
content:
Lana Del Rey has had creative year, despite the pandemic.
There was the spoken word release Violet Bent Backwards over the Grass, and its accompanying book. Her sixth studio album Chemtrails over the Country Club was announced and was ready to go, but was pushed back to 2021. Blame the health crisis for that.
She also unveiled a new set of â€œAmerican standards and classics,â€ which should arrive ahead of Santa.

title: Spotify: Taylor-Swift-Fan hackt mehrere KÃ¼nstlerseiten
content:

"Beste GrÃ¼ÃŸe an meine KÃ¶nigin Taylor Swift": Ein Hacker hat die Spotify-KÃ¼nstlerprofile von einigen weltberÃ¼hmten SÃ¤ngern gehackt â€“ auch die Accounts von Dua Lipa und Lana Del Rey waren betroffen. Neben GrÃ¼ÃŸen an Taylor Swift erwÃ¤hnte der Hacker auch US-PrÃ¤sident Donald Trump.
Ein Hacker hat sich Medienberichten zufolge Zugang zu den Spotify-Profilen mehrerer bekannter SÃ¤nger verschafft â€“ unter anderem kaperte er die KÃ¼nstlerseiten von Dua Lipa und Lana Del Ray. Dabei hinterlieÃŸ der Unbekannte auch ein paar GruÃŸworte an Popstar Taylor Swift.
Mit dem Tool "Spotify for Artists" kÃ¶nnen Musiker ihre eigene Spotify-Homepage verwalten und neben ihren Songs auch Profilbilder, Kurzbiographien und eigene Playlists verÃ¶ffentlichen. Der Hacker, der sich selbst Daniel genannt habe, habe die Fotos der KÃ¼nstler durch ein Bild von sich selbst, sowie die Biographien durch eigene Passagen ersetzt. AuÃŸerdem soll er die Nutzer aufgerufen haben, ihm auf Snapchat zu folgen und die Worte "Trump 2020" hinzugefÃ¼gt haben.
UngÃ¼nstiger Zeitpunkt fÃ¼r SicherheitslÃ¼cke
FÃ¼r Spotify dÃ¼rfte Daniels Ausflug in die persÃ¶nlichen Profile Ã¤uÃŸerst peinlich sein â€“ gerade erst hatte der Musikanbieter die meistgestreamten Songs des Jahres verÃ¶ffentlicht. Auch ihren persÃ¶nlichen musikalischen JahresrÃ¼ckblick kÃ¶nnen die Nutzer seit Kurzem einsehen.
Der Streamingdienst korrigierte die Ã„nderungen schnell wieder. Auf Twitter finden sich jedoch weiterhin zahlreiche Screenshots der gehackten Profile.

Es sei allerdings noch unklar, wie sich der Hacker Zugriff zu den KÃ¼nstlerprofile verschafft habe. Dua Lipa unter den Spotifys Top-KÃ¼nstlerinnen des Jahres
Laut Spotify gehÃ¶rte die britische SÃ¤ngerin Dua Lipa neben Billie Eilish, Ariana Grande, Taylor Swift und Halsey zu den meistgestreamten KÃ¼nstlerinnen 2020. Der am hÃ¤ufigsten abgespielte Song komme allerdings vom Kanadier The Weeknd â€“ 1,6 Milliarden Mal wurde "Blinding Lights" gestreamt.

title: Lana Del Rey Is Only Speaking for Herself Now
content:
â€œChemtrailsâ€ comes across as gilded as the insular world in which Lana Del Rey resides. Photo: Lanna Del Rey/YouTube
â€œSo I just want to say, nobody gets to tell your story except for you,â€ Lana Del Rey said in a May 2020 Instagram video. â€œEven if that means itâ€™s kind of messy, like this, along the way.â€ The video was one of her multiple long-winded defenses after calling out a largely Black group of pop stars for expressing their sexuality in their music. Her initial comments preceded the announcement of two book projects, including a spoken-word poetry collection Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, and an album, then set for September 2020. In the middle of that defense video, she revealed the title: Chemtrails Over the Country Club.
After a delay (which she attributed to the global slowdown in vinyl production), the album is now set to come out March 19, but it doesnâ€™t feel like much else has changed. Almost immediately after debuting the cover art, featuring a vintage-styled photograph of her and her friends, Del Rey defended herself against alleged criticisms that the group pictured wasnâ€™t racially diverse. â€œYes, there are people of color on this recordâ€™s picture and thatâ€™s all Iâ€™ll say about that,â€ she wrote, going on to name individual friends. The next day, she explained her comments to host Annie Mac when debuting the title track on BBC Radio 1. She also opined on the recent insurrection at the Capitol, saying that President Donald Trump â€œdoesnâ€™t know that heâ€™s inciting a riot â€¦ because heâ€™s got delusions of grandeur.â€ But when the Black-aimed culture publication Complex wrote in a headline, â€œLana Del Rey Doesnâ€™t Believe Donald Trump Purposely Incited Capitol Riot,â€ she singled them out on Twitter. â€œThanks for the cool soundbite taken out of context,â€ she wrote in one tweet. â€œItâ€™s fucked up. You know Iâ€™m real,â€ she added in another. â€œWhoever wrote this is a genuine piece of shit.â€ It was the same defense as before, in a slightly different package: that her critics didnâ€™t understand what she had to say because they just werenâ€™t listening to all of it. (Sheâ€™d also used that logic to lash out at the media before, when she targeted NPR music critic Ann Powers for a review of her 2019 album Norman Fucking Rockwell!)
On â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ the song, Del Rey doesnâ€™t have much profound to say. Itâ€™s one of her classic dreamy love songs, set amid the high-class decadence she frequents with an added layer of suburban duty. The titular chemtrails only color the scene â€” really, thereâ€™s nothing to escape, not the elementary-school obligations or the fine jewelry. â€œWe laugh about nothing as the summer gets cool,â€ Del Rey sings, encapsulating the space the song itself occupies. She sways and lilts through the delicate rhythm, eventually finding her way toward a glitchy bridge that takes over the entire song. Producer Jack Antonoff, who helms the new album, as he did her last, seems to have taken a few notes from his folklore and evermore collaborator Aaron Dessner; the track sounds as crisp as one of the musical â€œsketchesâ€ Dessner contributed to Taylor Swiftâ€™s projects. That makes â€œChemtrailsâ€ more interesting than the middle-of-the-road lead single â€œLet Me Love You Like a Woman,â€ but doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s any more substantive. The way Antonoffâ€™s production swells to take over the rest of the song also recalls previous album Norman Fucking Rockwell!â€™s epic standout â€œVenice Bitch.â€ But while that song built toward its fate, on â€œChemtrails,â€ it just feels like a flourish, as gilded as the world Del Rey inhabits in the lyrics.
NFR! shined the most when it had stakes. When Rolling Stone lauded the songs on that album as â€œepitaphs for the entire country,â€ it wasnâ€™t an overstatement â€” whether remarking on romance or the state of the world, Del Rey finally used the wit and flair she always wielded for something clear, new, and essential. She wasnâ€™t just channeling Bob Dylan and Joni Mitchell, she was challenging herself to meet the standards of the once-in-a-generation songwriting that her heroes set. But even Dylan lost his way, multiple times, throughout his career. Unlike Dylan, though, itâ€™s not just going to take a good comeback album for Del Rey to reclaim her NFR!-era praise. Sheâ€™s going to need to listen to the rest of the generation she once supposedly spoke for â€” otherwise sheâ€™ll just continue speaking for herself.

title: Lana Del Rey On Capitol Riot & Album Controversy
content:
She touches on feeling "wild" in a standout lyric from the first verse of her title track, which got a whimsically wicked music video treatment: "I'm not unhinged or unhappy, I'm just wild."
"If I go to the Brentwood Country Mart barefoot or whatever, Iâ€™m not insane; Iâ€™m connected to the earth. ... I think people are having to re-evaluate what is strange and not strange," she continued. "Like watching the people storm the Capitol, everyone gets to go look at that and figure out what Capitols theyâ€™ve been storming this year in their own freakinâ€™ lives. 'Cause everyoneâ€™s running amok. You know, half the people I know are just jerks. Like I could picture them being like, 'Well, we need a change.' And then other half of the people I know are like watching them with tears in their eyes, in disbelief. And it is sad, it is scary. But it could happen in any country."
Del Rey says she thinks the last four years were necessary in order for there to be change in this country. "The madness of Trump, as bad as it was, it really needed to happen. We really needed a reflection of our worldâ€™s greatest problem, which is not climate change, but sociopathy and narcissism. Especially in America. Itâ€™s going to kill the world. Itâ€™s not capitalism, itâ€™s narcissism. I was surprised we didnâ€™t have a live-television psychopath crazy person as a president a long time ago because thatâ€™s what we see on TV and thatâ€™s what we see on Instagram."
Shortly after posting her album artwork on Instagram on Sunday, Del Rey shot back at haters in a lengthy comment underneath the photo in question. "These are my friends this is my life. We are all a beautiful mix of everything- some more than others which is visible and celebrated in everything I do," she wrote. "In 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without even trying to. My best friends are rappers my boyfriends have been rappers. My dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, Iâ€™m not the one storming the capital, Iâ€™m literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it."
Del Rey noted in her BBC Radio 1 interview that half of the women featured in her Chemtrails cover are people of color, and she felt "uncomfortable" having them dragged into the controversy. "But I spoke to them as well and they were like, 'We donâ€™t care. You should not care. ... Your friends are from all over the place, and youâ€™ve never represented yourself in any other way.'"
Update (Jan. 13): Following the pushback for her comments about Trump, Del Rey posted a series of tweets on Tuesday (Jan. 12) clarifying that her words were not intended as a defense of Trump, who she called, "so significantly impaired that he may not know what he was doing due to his significant lack of empathy and the wider ranging problem is the issue of sociopathy and narcissism in America."
The singer also posted an accompanying 95-second video in which she expanded on what she said was the real message she was trying to convey in the interview.
Listen to LDR's full BBC Radio 1 interview here and see her followup tweets below.

title: Lana Del Rey rewears mesh mask in 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club'
content:
Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
Guess this mesh mask wasnâ€™t born to die.
Months after facing backlash for wearing a bedazzled mash mask to an LA meet-and-greet, Lana Del Rey brought back the controversial style for her new â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€ music video, which was released on Tuesday.
In true Lana Del Rey fashion, the â€™60s-inspired video sees the star driving to the country club decked out in pearl jewelry, completing her look with the now-infamous sheer face covering.
The â€œBlue Jeansâ€ singer, 35, eventually ditches the mask as she and her friends morph into werewolves for the videoâ€™s surprise ending. (Fangs and mesh donâ€™t mix, it seems.)
While Del Rey defended her mask in November, saying that it â€œhad plastic on the inside,â€ fans couldnâ€™t help but react to its return.
â€œLana stands canâ€™t escape the mask,â€ tweeted one, while another asked, â€œwhy is lana del rey doubling down on her stupid mask situation?â€
â€œNot @LanaDelRay wearing her fake face mask as a fashionable accessory in this music video,â€ wrote a third.
While we may never unmask the reasoning behind the styleâ€™s return, Del Rey did model a more obviously effective face covering earlier this week, posting an Instagram selfie in a blue-and-white mask studded with over 1,000 Swarovski crystals by Benveniste Couture.

title: Lana Del Rey, usciti video di Chemtrails Over The Country Club, copertina e tracklist
content:
Ãˆ appena uscito il video in cui la star canta il brano omonimo del disco. E sul suo profilo Instagram sono state anticipate sia la title track sia la cover di questa nuova fatica discografica, in uscita il prossimo marzo
E non solo quelli: anche il videoclip del singolo omonimo tratto dallâ€™album , Chemtrails Over The Country Club appunto, Ã¨ apparso da poche ore su YouTube registrando un vero e proprio boom di visualizzazioni. Oltre due milioni di clic (nel momento in cui stiamo scrivendo questo articolo, le visualizzazioni sono quasi arrivate a due milioni e mezzo) nonostante sia online da una manciata di ore.
La data dâ€™uscita di Chemtrails Over The Country Club , il nuovo disco di Lana Del Rey , si avvicina. CosÃ¬ la cantautrice newyorkese ha deciso di dare un assaggio del suo settimo album in studio a tutti i suoi fan. Anzi: a tutti i suoi follower dato che copertina e tracklist sono state svelate sul profilo di Instagram della cantante.
La data ufficiale in cui il disco dovrebbe uscire Ã¨ il 19 marzo . Per ingannare lâ€™attesa (spasmodica per alcuni fan tra i piÃ¹ accaniti), la cantautrice ha postato su IG tre immagini eloquenti. La prima Ã¨ quella che rivela la copertina : una foto in bianco e nero che ritrae la star in abiti dallo stile anni Trenta attorniata da dieci figure femminili di diversa etÃ  ed etnia . Una scelta guidata dallâ€™ inclusivitÃ  , come la stessa Lana Del Rey ha affermato.
InclusivitÃ  come fil rouge del nuovo disco di Lana Del Rey
approfondimento
Lana Del Rey, prima esibizione live con "Let Me Love You Like A Woman"
Lana Del Rey ha risposto ad alcune accuse che le erano state rivolte commentando con queste parole: "In undici anni di lavoro sono sempre stata molto inclusiva. I miei migliori amici sono rapper, i miei fidanzati sono stati rapper. I miei piÃ¹ cari amici venivano da qualsiasi parte del mondo, quindi prima che facciate nuovi commenti sulla questione WOC/POC, non sono io a prendere d'assalto la capitale, sto letteralmente cambiando il mondo esponendo sul tavolo la mia vita, i miei pensieri e l'amore. Rispettatelo."
Queste parole di sfogo sono presumibilmente in risposta alle critiche che la cantautrice ha ricevuto lo scorso maggio, quando si era paragonata a cantanti come Doja Cat e BeyoncÃ© nel post con cui annunciava su Instagram il nuovo album.
La Del Rey aveva nominato come popostar soltanto artiste non bianche (oltre alle sopracitate, spiccavano i nomi di FKA Twigs, Ariana Grande, Camila Cabello, Cardi B, Kehlani e Nicki Minaj) e gli sgradevoli commenti postati da alcuni utenti lâ€™avevano spinta a giustificarsi. Come? Dicendo che ha semplicemente nominato le sue cantanti preferite. Popstar che, per citare le parole di Lana Del Rey comparse sul suo profilo IG, â€œsono state al numero 1 in classifica con canzoni che parlano di essere sexy, di fare sesso, di tradire ecceteraâ€¦ Questo Ã¨ il motivo per cui le ho citate. Avrei potuto nominare chiunque ma ho scelto le persone che preferiscoâ€.

title: Popkolumne: Neues von Lana Del Rey, Passenger und Celo & Abdi
content:
Von Jakob Biazza
Die Gefahr war natÃ¼rlich immer da. Lana Del Rey, die Grande Dame des von ihr selbst erfundenen Genres Dem-Ãœberdruss-an-der-Welt-mit-Geschmeide-und-Geigen-entkommen-retro-Folk-Soul ist dem Realen womÃ¶glich seit jeher ein klein wenig entrÃ¼ckter als der Durchschnitt. Gerade hat sie im Social-Web fÃ¼r MÃ¤rz ihr neues Album "Chemtrails Over the Country Club" angekÃ¼ndigt - mit einem Foto des Covers. Es zeigt die SÃ¤ngerin mit ihren besten, mitunter opulent behangenen Freundinnen an einem lÃ¤ndlichen Tisch mit karierter Decke, und was soll man sagen: Die Runde sieht so aus, wie es der Titel verspricht, weshalb sich Menschen tatsÃ¤chlich nicht zu blÃ¶d waren, Del Rey vorzuwerfen, ihr soziales Umfeld sei zu wenig divers. So weit so reflexhaft. Und ein wenig verwundert dann doch, mit welcher Energie und Akribie die 35-JÃ¤hrige die VorwÃ¼rfe zu entkrÃ¤ften versucht - unter anderem, indem sie dezidiert Herkunft und Wurzeln der Freundinnen auflistet, um zu zeigen, dass sie sehr wohl "of color" seien: "Meine wunderschÃ¶ne Freundin aus Del Rio Mexico, genau wie meine allerliebste Freundin Alex und meine hinreiÃŸende Freundin Dakota Rain." Dann folgt das wunderbar-verschnupfteste Zitat wenigstens dieses noch recht jungen Pop-Jahres: "Ich bin nicht diejenige, die die Hauptstadt stÃ¼rmt, ich verÃ¤ndere buchstÃ¤blich die Welt, indem ich mein Leben und meine Gedanken und meine Liebe da drauÃŸen auf den Tisch lege, 24/7. Respektiert das." Okay, tun wir.
Detailansicht Ã¶ffnen (Foto: dpa)
Das mit dem besoffenen Clown nimmt man Mike Rosenberg hingegen nicht ganz ab. Da sitzt er also, auf dem Cover von "Songs For The Drunk And Broken Hearted" (Cooking Vinyl/Sony Music), dem neuen Passenger-Album - rotzvoll offenbar, fettige Haare, halb geleerte Schnapsflasche in der Hand, das geschminkte Gesicht ein einziger Sauertopf. BÃ¶ll kÃ¶nnte ihn kaum trauriger erfinden. Aber so richtig passt das nicht. Passenger ist spÃ¤testens seit seinem GroÃŸhit "Let Her Go" auf todtraurig gemeinten, aber dann eben doch eher lebensbejahend ausgefÃ¼hrten Pop-Folk gebucht. Auch auf dem neuen Album klingt er immer noch meistens so, wie diese hÃ¼bschen Gegenlicht-Instagram-Fotos aussehen. Aber hie und da schummelt sich eine zumindest beschwipste Trompete in die Szenerie, torkelt eine kleine Gitarren-Unsauberkeit vorbei, schwankt die Stimme ein bisschen ergriffen. Das Ã¤ndert nicht viel am Gesamtbild, steht Rosenberg aber ganz gut.
Detailansicht Ã¶ffnen (Foto: Dead Oceans)
Kurzer Moment der Irritation, zweiter Blick aufs Cover: Doch, sollte eine MÃ¤nnerstimme sein, die da nach 30 Sekunden Samt-Flausch-Intro feine LichtfÃ¤den in die Welt schickt. Aaron Frazer wird gerade als neuer Falsett-Wunderknabe des Retro-Souls in Stellung gebracht. Man liest allenthalben sogar schon Vergleiche mit Curtis Mayfield, und wie immer, wenn man von Vergleichen mit Curtis Mayfield liest, ist das etwas hochgegriffen. Aber: Was Frazer auf "Introducing..." (Dead Oceans) macht, hat tatsÃ¤chlich einen recht bezaubernden Schmelz. Und dazu phasenweise eine relativ erlesene Coolness. Er ist als Drummer der Band Durand Jones & The Indications so bekannt geworden, wie man das als singender Schlagzeuger einer Retro-Soul-Band eben werden kann. AuÃŸerdem hat Dan Auerbach - Rumpel-Gitarrist bei den Black Keys und unvermeidlicher Produzent fÃ¼r alles, was retro wirken soll, in Wirklichkeit aber dann doch routiniert an Urbanem geschult ist - das Album produziert. Das merkt man ein paar der StÃ¼cke an. Vor allem dem in der HÃ¼fte sehr locker schwingenden, leicht rockig angezeckten "Can't Leave It Alone". Anders gesagt: Sollte das Privatfernsehen irgendwann doch wieder Softpornos ins Freitagabendprogramm nehmen - Aaron Frazer kÃ¶nnte die distinguierteren unter ihnen sicher ganz famos vertonen. Im wirklich allerbesten Sinne.
Detailansicht Ã¶ffnen (Foto: 385ideal/Universal Music)
Kurzer Moment der Irritation, zweiter Blick aufs Cover: Doch, sollten zwei Komiker sein, die da nach 15 Sekunden DunkeldÃ¼ster-StraÃŸen-Synthie-Intro von Drogendeals faseln, von Packs drÃ¼cken, Hashplatten, Unterwelt und Fluchtfahrten. Celo & Abdi sind fÃ¼r Deutsch-Rap schlieÃŸlich ein bisschen das, was Thomas Gottschalk und Mike KrÃ¼ger ("Zwei Nasen tanken Super"!) fÃ¼r den deutschen Witzfilm waren: irgendwie irritierend also, schon auch lustig - und auf ganz eigene Art grandios. "Mietwagentape 2" (385ideal/Universal Music) ist entsprechend eine Art Roadmovie-Gossenpersiflage-Coming-of-Age-Jason-Statham-Action-HÃ¶rspiel. Mit ein paar wirklich sehr manierlichen Beats Ã¼ber die zum Teil grandios verzogen gerappt wird. Anders gesagt: Sollte bald ein Revival von "Cheech und Chong" anstehen, oder eines von "Jay und Silent Bob" (was beides bitte bald der Fall sein sollte) - Celo & Abdi kÃ¶nnten die distinguierteren Folgen sicher ganz famos vertonen. Und auch spielen.

title: Lana del Rey anuncia fecha de lanzamiento de su nuevo disco "Chemtrails Over The Country Club" y se defiende de crÃ­ticas por la portada
content:
Lana del Rey arranca el 2021 con su nuevo disco de estudio. | Fuente: EFE
Lana del Rey ha confirmado que serÃ¡ el 19 de marzo cuando se publique su nuevo disco, "Chemtrails Over The Country Club", del que en paralelo ha anticipado el listado de canciones y el cuidado videoclip del tema que le da nombre.
La artista ha desvelado asimismo la portada del Ã¡lbum, en la que aparece rodeada por sus mejores amigas, segÃºn ha explicado en un mensaje que ha querido anticiparse a una posible polÃ©mica en torno a la falta de diversidad racial mostrada en la misma.
"En 11 aÃ±os de trabajo siempre he sido extremadamente inclusiva sin siquiera intentarlo. Mis mejores amigos son raperos, mis novios lo han sido. Mis amigos mÃ¡s queridos han venido de todas partes, asÃ­ que antes de que vuelvas a hacer comentarios sobre un problema con personas de color o mujeres de color, no soy yo quien asalta la capital. Estoy literalmente cambiando el mundo al poner mi vida, mis pensamientos y mi amor sobre la mesa. RespÃ©talo", ha escrito Lana del Rey.
No es el Ãºnico mensaje en el que la artista ha aludido de alguna manera al reciente asalto al Capitolio en Washington D.C. por partidarios del presidente, Donald Trump, contra el que ha sido muy crÃ­tica.
Â¿QUÃ‰ ESPERAR DEL DISCO?
"Siempre hay confusiÃ³n y agitaciÃ³n y, en medio de ella, siempre hay mÃºsica hermosa tambiÃ©n presentando mi nuevo Ã¡lbum", seÃ±alaba, por ejemplo, en el texto inicial de presentaciÃ³n de su nuevo material, que formarÃ¡ parte de su sÃ©ptimo disco de estudio, grabado como su antecesor en colaboraciÃ³n con Jack Antonoff.
Once serÃ¡n los cortes que incluya. Por este orden: "White Dress", "Chemtrails Over The Country Club", "Tulsa Jesus Freak", "Let Me Love You Like A Woman", "Wild At Heart", "Dark But Just A Game", "Not All Who Wander Are Lost", "Yosemite", "Breaking Up Slowly", "Dance Till We Die" y "For Free".
El Ã¡lbum "Chemtrails Over The Country Club" toma el relevo al aplaudido "Norman Fucking Rockwell" (2019), considerado uno de los mejores de ese aÃ±o. Meses atrÃ¡s, Lana del Rey dio a conocer el primer anticipo, "Let Me Love You Like a Woman", con cierta resonancia onÃ­rica y mÃ­nima instrumentaciÃ³n. (EFE)

title: Lana Del Rey defiende 'Chemtrails': "No soy yo quien asalta la capital'
content:
La cantante Lana del Rey se ha visto envuelta en una polÃ©mica despuÃ©s de contestar airadamente a algunos de sus seguidores de Instagram, que criticaron la portada de su nuevo disco, Chemtrails Over The Country Club, en la que aparece ella con algunas de sus amigas.
"Siempre hay confusiÃ³n y agitaciÃ³n y en medio de ella, siempre hay mÃºsica hermosa tambiÃ©n", era el texto que acompaÃ±aba a la imagen de la portada, en blanco y negro, donde posan una decena de mujeres vestidas elegantemente para la ocasiÃ³n.
Pero algunos comentarios enfadaron a Lana del Rey, que aÃ±adiÃ³ un comentario posterior, defendiÃ©ndose de supuestas crÃ­ticas sobre la mayorÃ­a de personas blancas en la imagen.
"Â¡TambiÃ©n quiero decir que con todo lo que estÃ¡ pasando este aÃ±o! Y no, esto no fue mi intenciÃ³n, estas son mis mejores amigas, ya que lo preguntas hoy", escribiÃ³. "Â¡Y maldita sea! SÃ­, hay gente de color en esta foto del disco y eso es todo lo que dirÃ© al respecto", aÃ±adÃ­a, aunque despuÃ©s se extendiÃ³.
"Mi hermosa amiga Valerie de Del RÃ­o MÃ©xico, mi mÃ¡s querida amiga Alex y mi hermosa amiga Dakota Rain, asÃ­ como mi amada Tatiana. Estas son mis amigas, esta es mi vida", continuÃ³. "Todos somos una hermosa mezcla de todo, algunos mÃ¡s que otros, lo cual es visible y celebrado en todo lo que hago", exponÃ­a.
"En once aÃ±os de trabajo siempre he sido extremadamente inclusiva sin siquiera proponÃ©rmelo", hacÃ­a ver.
"Mis mejores amigos son raperos, mis novios han sido raperos", se defendÃ­a. "Mis amigos mÃ¡s queridos han venido de todas partes, asÃ­ que antes de que vuelvas a hacer comentarios sobre un problema de WOC / POC [Women of color / Person of color], no soy yo quien asalta la capital", atacaba la cantante a quienes la habÃ­an criticado.
"Estoy literalmente cambiando el mundo poniendo mi vida, mis pensamientos y mi amor sobre la mesa 24 horas al dÃ­a, siete dÃ­as a la semana. RespÃ©talo", exigÃ­a.

title: Lana Del Rey defends herself from backlash over lack of diversity on new album cover
content:
Musician Lana Del Rey preemptively defended herself from criticism over her new album cover having a lack of diversity. The 35-year-old Grammy-nominated musician shared the cover of her much-awaited album 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club' on Instagram and defended the cover in the caption.
The monochrome cover of the album features a group of women sitting around a picnic table laughing and smiling. "There's always turmoil and upheaval and in the midst of it- there's always beautiful music too introducing my new album chemtrails over the country club," the musician wrote in the caption.
Del Rey followed up in a lengthy note in the comment section noting that the group is a diverse group of ladies, reported Fox News. "I also want to say that with everything going on this year! And no this was not intended-these are my best friends, since you are asking today. And damn! As it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover yes there are people of color on this records picture and that's all I'll say about that but thank you," she wrote.
The 'Summertime Sadness' singer also acknowledged that the women in the photo are her close friends as she also called out a few of them by their name. "These are my friends this is my life. We are all a beautiful mix of everything- some more than others which is visible and celebrated in everything I do. In 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without even trying to. My best friends are rappers my boyfriends have been rappers. My dearest friends have been from all over the place," Del Rey wrote.
She then ended the note by calling out the critics who incited her to defend herself and also mentioned those who stormed the Capitol building in Washington D.C. earlier last week. "So before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, I'm not the one storming the capital [sic], I'm literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it," Del Rey wrote.
The musician had previously faced backlash when she shared a video of herself in a mesh face mask that could not protect people against the coronavirus. (ANI)
(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)
