title: Lana Del Rey Reveals Chemtrails Over the Country Club Cover
content:
Photo: NBC/NBCU Photo Bank via Getty Images
On Sunday, Lana Del Rey dropped the cover art and track list for her highly anticipated upcoming album Chemtrails Over the Country Club, which will include songs like â€œTulsa Jesus Freakâ€ and â€œNot All Who Wander Are Lost,â€ as well as the EPâ€™s previously revealed single, â€œLet Me Love You Like a Woman,â€ which premiered this past fall. In an interesting nod to the plot of Christopher Nolanâ€™s Tenet, the singer also penned an Instagram comment in which she attempts to reverse the flow of the internetâ€™s entropy and defend Chemtrailsâ€™ cover art against any and all future criticisms that could be leveled at it, including, seemingly, that her inclusion of women of color could be seen as an attempt to counteract her bad press from this spring. In fact, Del Rey goes wide enough to conclude with the lines: â€œIâ€™m not the one storming the capital, Iâ€™m literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it.â€ Phew!
â€œI also want to say that with everything going on this year! And no this was not intended-these are my best friends, since you are asking today. And damn!,â€ the singer wrote in the since-deleted comment, captured here by Stereogum. â€œAs it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover, yes, there are people of color on this recordâ€™s picture and thatâ€™s all Iâ€™ll say about that. But thank you. My beautiful friend Valerie from Del Rio Mexico, my dearest friend Alex and my gorgeous friend Dakota Rain as well as my sweetheart Tatiana. These are my friends, this is my life. We are all a beautiful mix of everything - some more than others, which is visible and celebrated in everything I do.â€
â€œIn 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without trying to,â€ continued Del Rey. â€œMy best friends are rappers, my boyfriends have been rappers. My dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, Iâ€™m not the one storming the capital, Iâ€™m literally changing the world, my putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it.â€
Back in May, the singer defended herself against criticism that her comments comparing her perceived reception to that of female artists of color like BeyoncÃ©, Doja Cat, and fka twigs came across as tone-deaf and racially insensitive. â€œThe fact that they want to turn my post, my advocacy for fragility into a race war,â€ Del Rey said in a subsequent video attempting to clarify her statement. â€œItâ€™s really bad. Itâ€™s actually really bad.â€
Update, January 11, 6 p.m.: Lana Del Rey is now defending her defense of her new album cover for Chemtrails Over the Country Club. Speaking to BBC Radio 1â€™s Annie Mac for the premiere of the title track, she addressed alleged criticisms of the cover photo regarding inclusivity. â€œMy girlfriends come from all over the world, they have children from all different types of people,â€ she explained. â€œAnd Iâ€™m mentioning all this, like, to people who are listening because people really wanted even more people of color on my album cover. Which you know is, to a point, a photo just is what it is.â€ Del Rey further claimed that â€œactually half the people in this photo are people of color.â€ She also said the so-called controversy â€” which seems to have been started and fanned only by herâ€” made her think â€œback to all my songs and videos and starting with more of a hip-hop sound.â€ She went on, â€œI just feel like if thatâ€™s really what people are gonna say, I have an answer for them, which is that if you look closer, you will see people of color. Itâ€™s a black-and-white image, so zoom in, you know. Itâ€™s just weird, you know?â€ Do we, Lana?
Elsewhere in her conversation with Mac, Del Rey spoke about the pandemic (â€œI always wondered, with 8 billion people in the world, [why] this did not happen soonerâ€) and the riot at the Capitol (â€œWatching the people storm the Capitol, everyone gets to go look at that and figure out what Capitols theyâ€™ve been storming this year in their own freakinâ€™ livesâ€).

title: Lana Del Rey â€˜Chemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€™
content:
Lana Del Rey is squarely in release mode once again, as evidenced by a new, unprompted Instagram rant about her diverse friend group and the rappers sheâ€™s dated, in defense of her Chemtrails Over the Country Club album cover. Well, we hope youâ€™ve digested that controversy (hell, hope youâ€™ve digested the last one!), because sheâ€™s now released the title track from her upcoming album. Written with and produced by her partner-in-crime Jack Antonoff once again, â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€ continues the sparse, moody stylings of lead single â€œLet Me Love You Like a Woman.â€ Itâ€™s yet another of her songs of decadence, with lyrics about jewelry, sports cars, horoscopes, and indeed, chemtrails and country clubs, before distorted guitars and strings eventually swallow the song. The video premiered on January 11 at 2:10 p.m. ET, or 11:10 a.m. in Del Reyâ€™s beloved California. (The jury is still out on whether all the 1s are a chemtrail-esque conspiracy.) It features Del Rey living her retro fantasy while wearing that cursed mesh mask before she and her girls are swept up in a tornado and, uh, turned into demonic werewolves? It also involves fish and lemons and a fancy car, but here we are, still stuck on the werewolves.
Del Rey previously told Antonoff, in an Interview cover story, that the song would be about her â€œstunning girlfriendsâ€ and â€œbeautiful siblingsâ€ â€” whom she coincidentally put on the album cover. â€œIt mentions wanting so much to be normal and realizing that when you have an overactive, eccentric mind, a record like Chemtrails is just what youâ€™re going to get,â€ she continued. Speaking of the record, Chemtrails Over the Country Club is now set to come out March 19, according to its Apple Music listing. Del Rey already released the track list with the album cover, confirming Chemtrails would also include previously teased songs like â€œTulsa Jesus Freakâ€ and â€œWhite Dress.â€

title: Lana Del Rey unveils, defends 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club' album cover
content:
Jan. 11 (UPI) -- Lana Del Rey is giving a glimpse of her Chemtrails Over the Country Club album cover.
The 35-year-old singer shared the cover art Sunday on Instagram, writing, "There's always turmoil and upheaval and in the midst of it- there's always beautiful music too."
Advertisement
The cover shows a group of women smiling and laughing as they sit together around a table. Shortly after unveiling the cover, Del Rey defended the photo in the comments.
"I also want to say that with everything going on this year! And no this was not intended-these are my best friends, since you are asking today. And damn! As it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover yes there are people of color on this records cover and that's all I'll say about that but thank you," she wrote.
Del Rey named some of her friends who appear in the photo and said her group is "a beautiful mix of everything."
"In 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without even trying to. My best friends are rappers my boyfriends have been rappers," she said. "My dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, I'm not the one storming the capital, I'm literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it."
Advertisement
Del Rey also shared a tracklist for the album. Chemtrails Over the Country Club will include 11 songs, including the title track, "Chemtrails Over the Country Club."
Del Rey will release Chemtrails Over the Country Club on April 16. The album was originally scheduled for release in September but was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
In December, Del Rey said she fractured her arm while ice skating and will be wearing a cast in her next music video.
Del Rey previously defended herself from critics who say her lyrics are anti-feminist and that she glamorizes abuse.
Chemtrails Over the Country Club will mark Del Rey's first album since Norman [Expletive] Rockwell, released in August 2019.

title: "Yes There Are People of Color on This", Lana Del Rey defends new album cover
content:
American singer and songwriter Lana Del Rey shared the cover art of her upcoming album and followed that up by posting a message before users could "make comments again about a WOC/POC issue." According to E! News, the 'Summertime Sadness' singer took to her Instagram on Sunday (local time) and shared with everyone the artwork for her latest upcoming album 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club'. She captioned the post as, "There's always turmoil and upheaval and in the midst of it -- there's always beautiful music too, introducing my new album chemtrails over the country club."
The cover image showed the star and a group of women gathered around an outdoor table. Shortly afterwards Lana added a comment to seemingly defend the shot from potential criticism. The 35-year-old Grammy-nominated star said, "I also want to say that with everything going on this year!"
She continued, "And no this was not intended-these are my best friends, since you are asking today. And damn! As it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover yes there are people of color on this records picture and that's all I'll say about that but thank you." She went on to name a few of the women who appear on the cover with her, calling the group a "beautiful mix of everything."
Sharing that she has "always been extremely inclusive without even trying to," Lana continued by writing, "My best friends are rappers my boyfriends have been rappers. My dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, I'm not the one storming the capital, I'm literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it." As per E! News, it is still unclear as to what exactly spurred this comment from Lana. (ANI)

title: Lana del Rey: Singer faces backlash over â€˜extremely tone-deafâ€™ comments about new album
content:
After a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol building last week, a lot of people have been chiming in with their thoughts about the riots â€“ but Lana Del Rey contributed her own stance in maybe the strangest way.
The â€˜Summertime Sadnessâ€™ singer unveiled the tracklist and cover art for her upcoming album, Chemtrails over the Country Club on Instgram. And in apparent attempt to shut down any discourse before it even began, she elaborated on the inclusion of women of colour in the cover art.
â€œAs it happens when it comes to my amazing friends, yes there are people of colour on this recordâ€™s picture and thatâ€™s all Iâ€™ll say about that but thank you,â€ she wrote on a now-deleted Instagram comment, before she says more about it.
Del Rey continues by saying that her best friends are rappers in a bizarre defence of herself.
To top it all off, she invokes the Capitol riot: â€œBefore you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, Iâ€™m not the one storming the Capitol, Iâ€™m literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24/7.â€
After the announcement, fans took to Twitter to share their disappointment over Del Reyâ€™s latest fumble, as well as her use of the â€œmy friends are Blackâ€ excuse to ignore her privilege.
The singer has face a fair share of controversy.

title: Lana Del Rey Criticized On Twitter For Album Cover Defence
content:
Lana Del Rey released the album cover and tracklisting for her seventh album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club on Sunday, before launching into a lengthy Instagram comment which saw her defending herself from accusations of racism, and which many have criticized for being tone deaf.
The cover of Lana's album, which she posted on her Twitter, features a black and white image of the singer and a group of women around a table. Some of her fans, however, were quick to criticize this image. One, for example, tweeted, "Lana cover is giving me racist 1950s vibes," while another wrote, "lana posted a cover that looks like a women for trump gathering."
lana posted a cover that looks like a women for trump gathering, commented under it about how shes not racist because she has rapper friends, then posted a fleet where shes wearing that stupid mesh mask, ALL in a half hour i cant defend this woman ill just listen to the music pic.twitter.com/oPD6vWRbYj â€” m (@lovveless) January 10, 2021
chemtrails over the country club - lana del rey (2021) pic.twitter.com/XP6oIn7wX8 â€” marco (@mrcoantro) January 10, 2021
But anyway stream Cotcc by lana del rey pic.twitter.com/BhNTWT99wy â€” Lana Del Rey is my Religion (@MeangirlRulz) January 11, 2021
Seeming to respond against comments like these, the singer, whose given name is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, took to Instagram.
In a now-deleted post, the "Born to Die" hitmaker wrote: "As it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover yes there are people of color on this records picture and that's all I'll say about that."
However, this was not all she said about that. She continued: "In 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without even trying to. My best friends are rappers my boyfriends have been rappers."
For many, this comment read as tone deaf, with Lana giving a new spin on the "I have black friends" defense that white people have given to defend themselves about accusations of racism in the past.
How do I balance my love for lana del rey discography but also read this disaster pic.twitter.com/5d30Wg6REy â€” paige renee (@paigerenee26) January 11, 2021
Reacting to this, one fan tweeted: "#LanaDelRey i love you but please you are confusing the heck out of people talking about certain topics AT THE WRONG TIME. it had nothing to do with race. and to use a black stereotype 'rappers' in replace of the black ppl you've dated and been friends with is SO TONE DEAF. #lana"
Another Twitter user posted a reaction featuring a picture from the movie Get Out, about a white woman who lures her Black boyfriend to her parent's house so they can steal his body, with the caption, "Lana del Rey and her rapper boyfriends."
Lana del Rey and her rapper boyfriends pic.twitter.com/eRfcJ1rkk4 â€” camille (@itsscamillelove) January 10, 2021
Another Twitter user, meanwhile, compared her to Miya Ponsetto, a 22-year-old woman who recently appeared on CBS This Morning to defend herself after being arrested for confronting a Black teen in a hotel and accusing him of stealing her phone.
Lana Del Rey trying to write an Instagram caption pic.twitter.com/kuFbeNwNNq â€” Charlie (@midn1ghtmover) January 11, 2021
Del Rey finished her comment by writing: "My dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, I'm not the one storming the capital [sic], I'm literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it."
One Twitter user summed up the situation by writing, "if you ever feel useless, just remember that lana del rey has a publicist."
This latest Instagram post comes after a year in which the singer received criticism online for another controversial statement on race.
In May 2020, she defended herself against accusations that her songs glamorized abuse with a post in which she called out a number of women of color artists for their lyrical content, writing, "Now that Doja Cat, Ariana, Camila, Cardi B, Kehlani and Nicki Minaj and BeyoncÃ© have had number ones with songs about being sexy, wearing no clothes, f******, cheating, etcâ€”can I please go back to singing about being embodied, feeling beautiful by being in love even if the relationship is not perfect, or dancing for moneyâ€”or whatever I wantâ€”without being crucified or saying that I'm glamorizing abuse?"
tag yourself in lana del reyâ€™s new album cover, iâ€™m the iphone that nobody remembered to take out of the shot even though itâ€™s right next to the title pic.twitter.com/1wEtmXAy8w â€” Sarah McGonagall (@gothspiderbitch) January 10, 2021
The album cover of Chemtrails Over the Country Club also features a reference to the last time Lana Del Rey received the ire of Twitter. In the bottom left hand of the image, an iPhone can be seen next to Lana's mesh face mask, which many criticized her for wearing.

title: Lana Del Rey Defends Album Cover: "There Are People of Color on This"
content:
Watch : Lana Del Rey & Sean Larkin Split After 6 Months of Dating
Lana Del Rey is reflecting on her recent album-cover reveal.
The singer took to Instagram on Sunday, Jan. 10 and shared the artwork for her much-anticipated forthcoming album Chemtrails Over the Country Club.
"There's always turmoil and upheaval and in the midst of it- there's always beautiful music too," she captioned the post. "introducing my new album chemtrails over the country club."
Shortly after revealing the cover image that shows the star and a group of women gathered around an outdoor table, Lana added a comment to seemingly defend the shot from potential criticism.
"I also want to say that with everything going on this year!" the 35-year-old Grammy-nominated performer wrote. "And no this was not intended-these are my best friends, since you are asking today. And damn! As it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover yes there are people of color on this records picture and that's all I'll say about that but thank you."
She went on to name a few of the women who appear on the cover with her, calling the group a "beautiful mix of everything."

title: Star slammed for bizarre US riot post
content:
Lana Del Rey has again angered social media users while defending herself against past criticism of racial insensitivity, claiming she's "literally changing the world" with her music, and telling fans she's "dated rappers" in the past.
The singer, 35, unveiled the cover and tracklist for her upcoming album, Chemtrails Over The Country Club, on Sunday, adding in a since-deleted comment that she has an "extremely inclusive" approach to diversity in reference the women of colour included in the images.
Deflecting past accusations of racism, she went on to tell followers that her "best friends and past boyfriends have been rappers", adding in reference to last week's riots that she's "not the one storming the capital (sic)".
RELATED: Lana Del Rey engaged after five months
Del Rey's statement read: "As it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover yes there are people of colour on this records (sic) picture and that's all I'll say about that but thank you.
"My beautiful friend Valerie from Del Rio Mexico, my dearest friend Alex and my gorgeous friend Dakota Rain as well as my sweetheart Tatiana. these are my friends this is my life. We are all a beautiful mix of everything - some more than others which is visible and celebrated in everything I do.
"In 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without even trying to. My best friends are rappers my boyfriends have been rappers," the singer added.
"My dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, I'm not the one storming the capital (sic), I'm literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it."
RELATED: Lana Del Rey slammed for ridiculous face mask
A number of fans took issue with her words.
Some pointed out that she was seemingly associating rappers with people of colour, while others ripped into her for using the Capitol riots to promote her new music.
Others mocked her "changing the world" claim.
RELATED: Lana Del Rey slammed for dragging BeyoncÃ©
if you ever feel useless, just remember that lana del rey has a publicist pic.twitter.com/3WPM2SW3Qu â€” vinh (@thickianagrande) January 10, 2021
live footage of lana del rey changing the world: pic.twitter.com/MzyhqZBaZG â€” hen (@iloveulanaa) January 10, 2021
â€œIâ€™ve had rapper boyfriendsâ€ is the new â€œI have a black friend...Iâ€™m not racistâ€ yo did Lana Del Rey just- ğŸ’€ â€” Fay (@epicfaylure) January 10, 2021
Lana del rey couldve literally released the album silently but she had to remind us that sheâ€™s changing the world one rapper boyfriend at a timeğŸ–ğŸ¾ğŸ˜Œ â€” joannaâ€™s struggle tweets (@dumbdotcomm) January 11, 2021
Lana Del Rey really used the failed coup to promote her album..... pic.twitter.com/QtjPLWvafH â€” kate bush's husband (@airbagged) January 10, 2021
"So before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, Iâ€™m not the one storming the capital, Iâ€™m literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven."
Sigh.
It's 2021 and Lana Del Rey is still a nightmare for her publicist. â€” Ernest Owens (@MrErnestOwens) January 11, 2021
The songstress had a controversial 2020, having been forced to issue two apologies in disputes involving fellow female artists.
Back in May, Del Rey named R&B singer Kehlani and other artists while attacking critics who said her music was "glamorizing abuse" while Cardi B, Nicki Minaj, and others wrote hits "about being sexy, wearing no clothes, f***ing, cheating, etc".
After commenters called her out for naming mostly women of colour, Del Rey remained unapologetic, saying the artists were her "favorite f***ing people".
In a follow-up post, she told fans that "making it about race says so much more about you than it does about me".
Just a few weeks later, after posting videos of looters during the Black Lives Matter protests in footage that revealed demonstrators' faces, she was called out by the very artists she had named previously.
Calling for her to remove the footage, Kehlani accused her of "(endangering) the lives of Black people" by disclosing identities.
Del Rey eventually took the posts down.
Originally published as Star slammed for bizarre US riot post

Back in May, Del Rey named R&B singer Kehlani and other artists while attacking critics who said her music was â€œglamorizing abuseâ€ while Cardi B, Nicki Minaj, and others wrote hits â€œabout being sexy, wearing no clothes, f***ing, cheating, etcâ€.
After commenters called her out for naming mostly women of colour, Del Rey remained unapologetic, saying the artists were her â€œfavorite f***ing peopleâ€.
In a follow-up post, she told fans that â€œmaking it about race says so much more about you than it does about meâ€.
Just a few weeks later, after posting videos of looters during the Black Lives Matter protests in footage that revealed demonstratorsâ€™ faces, she was called out by the very artists she had named previously.
Calling for her to remove the footage, Kehlani accused her of â€œ(endangering) the lives of Black peopleâ€ by disclosing identities.
Del Rey eventually took the posts down.

title: Lana Del Rey Indulges in Whimsically Wicked Transformation in 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club' Video
content:
Lana Del Rey finally unveiled the music video for "Chemtrails Over the Country Club" from her upcoming seventh album of the same name on Monday (Jan. 11). The title track is also available on streaming services.
The vintage '60s-style flick features Del Rey in her "little red sports car" driving to the country club to cool off by the pool with her pristine, pearl-wearing posse. She and her friends occasionally sport her infamous shimmering mesh mask that Del Rey previously received flack for wearing. But their perfect summer day gets an unexpected twist when a twister Ã  la The Wizard of Oz swoops in and snatches the singer in her red convertible.
Looks like she's not at the country club anymore, but Del Rey reunites with her gal pals as they transform into a pack of werewolves in the middle of the night, howling at the moon after setting her car ablaze.

title: Lana Del Rey Talks Capitol Riot & Album Controversy
content:
She touches on feeling "wild" in a standout lyric from the first verse of her title track, which got a whimsically wicked music video treatment: "I'm not unhinged or unhappy, I'm just wild."
"If I got to the Brentwood Country Mart barefoot or whatever, Iâ€™m not insane; Iâ€™m connected to the earth. ... I think people are having to re-evaluate what is strange and not strange," she continued. "Like watching the people storm the Capitol, everyone gets to go look at that and figure out what Capitols theyâ€™ve been storming this year in their own freakinâ€™ lives. 'Cause everyoneâ€™s running amok. You know, half the people I know are just jerks. Like I could picture them being like, 'Well, we need a change.' And then other half of the people I know are like watching them with tears in their eyes, in disbelief. And it is sad, it is scary. But it could happen in any country."
Del Rey says she thinks the last four years were necessary in order for there to be change in this country. "The madness of Trump, as bad as it was, it really needed to happen. We really needed a reflection of our worldâ€™s greatest problem, which is not climate change, but sociopathy and narcissism. Especially in America. Itâ€™s going to kill the world. Itâ€™s not capitalism, itâ€™s narcissism. I was surprised we didnâ€™t have a live-television psychopath crazy person as a president a long time ago because thatâ€™s what we see on TV and thatâ€™s what we see on Instagram."
Shortly after posting her album artwork on Instagram on Sunday, Del Rey shot back at haters in a lengthy comment underneath the photo in question. "These are my friends this is my life. We are all a beautiful mix of everything- some more than others which is visible and celebrated in everything I do," she wrote. "In 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without even trying to. My best friends are rappers my boyfriends have been rappers. My dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, Iâ€™m not the one storming the capital, Iâ€™m literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it."
Del Rey noted in her BBC Radio 1 interview that half of the women featured in her Chemtrails cover are people of color, and she felt "uncomfortable" having them dragged into the controversy. "But I spoke to them as well and they were like, 'We donâ€™t care. You should not care. ... Your friends are from all over the place, and youâ€™ve never represented yourself in any other way.'"
Listen to LDR's full BBC Radio 1 interview here.

title: Lana Del Rey Shares Album Art, Hit With Backlash For "Extremely Inclusive" Comments
content:
Lana Del Rey shared the official artwork and tracklist for her upcoming album, Chemtrails Over The Country Club, Sunday, but she is being criticized for comments she made regarding the cover art.
Rebecca Sapp / Getty Images
The since-deleted comments speak on the women of color shown in the album art and her "extremely inclusive" approach to diversity:
My beautiful friend Valerie from Del Rio Mexico, my dearest friend Alex and my gorgeous friend Dakota Rain as well as my sweetheart Tatiana. these are my friends this is my life. We are all a beautiful mix of everything- some more than others which is visible and celebrated in everything I do.
In 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without even trying to. My best friends are rappers my boyfriends have been rappers. My dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, I'm not the one storming the capital, I'm literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it.
"Comes off angry also, she equated rappers to black people which was ......racist," one user tweeted in response to the comments.
It's possible these comments could have flown under the radar, but Del Rey has a history of making controversial statements regarding other artists music industry.
[Via]

title: Lana Del Rey clarifies cover art concept of forthcoming album
content:
Vocal powerhouse Lana Del Rey jumped in to clear the air about the cover of her upcoming album Chemtrails Over the Country Club.
The singer had taken to Instagram to share the cover in an exciting post.
"Thereâ€™s always turmoil and upheaval and in the midst of it- thereâ€™s always beautiful music too introducing my new album chemtrails over the country club," the caption read.
The cover shows the star with a group of women gathered around a table at an outdoor setting, smiling joyously.
Following the post, the Grammy-nominated performer jumped in the comments to add more context regarding the inclusion of people of colour, though it is unclear what triggered it.
"I also want to say that with everything going on this year! And no this was not intended-these are my best friends, since you are asking today. And damn! As it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover yes there are people of color on this records picture and that's all I'll say about that but thank you," she wrote.
She went on to name a few of the women and share their ethnicity while she called the group a "beautiful mix of everything".

title: Musique: Lana Del Rey, Arlo Parks, essentielles en 2021
content:
La chanteuse amÃ©ricaine Lana Del Rey en concert Ã  Benicassim, en juillet 2020 en Espagne
PublicitÃ© Lire la suite
Paris (AFP)
Personne ne sait quand reprendront les concerts, mais les albums qui rythmeront 2021 se profilent dÃ©jÃ , entre Lana Del Rey, Django Django, Arlo Parks, La Femme, Eddy de Pretto sans oublier le ticket Liminanas-Laurent Garnier.
Pas encore connue du grand public, Arlo Parks, promesse de la neo-soul, a dÃ©jÃ  des fans illustres telles Billie Eilish et Michelle Obama. Et son visage a sÃ©duit le rÃ©alisateur Gus Van Sant pour une campagne de publicitÃ©. Le premier album de la Londonienne (aux racines entre France, Tchad et Niger), "Collapsed in sunbeams", arrive le 29 janvier et les singles "Green eyes" ou "Caroline" permettent de se faire une idÃ©e.
Autre nouvelle venue, la FranÃ§aise Lala &ce lÃ¢chera le mÃªme jour "Everything tasteful", un des disques les plus attendus dans un rap/r'n'b entre lascif et percutant. CÃ´tÃ© valeur sÃ»re, il faut citer Texas. "Oui un nouvel album arrive", a lancÃ© Ã  l'AFP la chanteuse-leader Sharleen Spiteri, en dÃ©cembre lors de la sortie du single-Ã©claireur "Hi".
"Chemtrails over the country", nouvel album de la diva Lana Del Rey, successeur annoncÃ© de son meilleur opus "Norman fucking Rockwell!" (2019) --"Violet bent backwards over the grass" paru en 2020 n'Ã©tant qu'un recueil de poÃ¨mes mis en musique-- se montre enfin aprÃ¨s maints reports. Dans un teaser de moins de 30 secondes sur ses rÃ©seaux sociaux, la star promet un nouveau single le 11 janvier. C'est dÃ©jÃ  plus que Drake, dont le "Certified lover boy" se fait toujours dÃ©sirer.
- Britanniques bruyants -
Autre retour, celui de Django Django, avec "Glowing in the dark" --soit "Brillant dans le noir", album-promesse d'espoir dans une pÃ©riode sombre-- annoncÃ© le 12 fÃ©vrier.
Le morceau-titre des Britanniques a dÃ©jÃ  Ã©tÃ© livrÃ© et bÃ©nÃ©ficie d'un remix-appel Ã  la danse des turbulents Hot Chip.
D'autres disques en provenance du Royaume-Uni doivent faire du bruit. Notamment celui de Squid, collectif remuant de Brighton qui a mis en transe tous les festivals dÃ©fricheurs avant le Covid-19. L'objet tant convoitÃ© doit atterrir au printemps. Et dans la collection des sales gosses, on attend les saillies des Viagra Boys ("Welfare jazz", ce vendredi).
Dans le rayon franÃ§ais, le surdouÃ© Arman MÃ©liÃ¨s sera le guide de son "Laurel Canyon" (le 26 fÃ©vrier) tandis que GaÃ«tan Roussel questionnera raison et sentiments avec "Est-ce que tu sais?", le 19 mars.
L'ancien leader de Louise Attaque a donnÃ© le ton avec deux singles, dont notamment "On ne meurt pas (en une seule fois)" avec un clip au casting fou, entre grands noms du sport comme Bixente Lizarazu, Alain Prost, Marie-JosÃ© PÃ©rec ou encore Christine Arron.
- "Histoire vaccinÃ©e" -
Les nouvelles plumes repointent Ã©galement le bout de leur nez. Eddy de Pretto annonce une tournÃ©e XXL pour l'automne 2021 --"Mes amours, nous repartons pour une seconde histoire ! Celle-ci sera vaccinÃ©e", Ã©crit-il sur ses rÃ©seaux-- et sort ce mercredi un nouveau single, "Bateaux-mouches" Ã  teneur auto-biographique. Ce qui prÃ©figure sans doute un deuxiÃ¨me album cette annÃ©e, aprÃ¨s l'encensÃ© "Cure" (2018).
Les dandys dÃ©cadents de Feu! Chatterton, de La Femme, ainsi que ceux de Magenta (prolongement du groupe Fauve) sont aussi dans les starting-blocks.
Enfin, chez les savants fous, deux projets font saliver. Le duo Ã©lectro Cabadzi prÃ©voit "Burrhus" (le 5 fÃ©vrier), rÃ©fÃ©rence Ã  Burrhus Frederic Skinner, spÃ©cialiste de la psychologie du comportement dans les annÃ©es 1950-60.
Cabadzi, qui avait prÃ©cÃ©demment mis en musique des rÃ©pliques de films de Bertrand Blier, Ã©voquera cette fois "l'addiction aux rÃ©seaux sociaux, dangereuse car induite par l'ergonomie des applis", comme l'avait exposÃ© Ã  l'AFP, Lulu, moitiÃ© du binÃ´me.
Et les Liminanas agrandissent encore leur collection de collaborations (aprÃ¨s Etienne Daho ou Peter Hook, ex-Joy Division et ex-New Order) en s'attelant cette fois au patron de l'Ã©lectro Laurent Garnier.

title: Azealia Banks Viciously Body Shames Lana Del Rey On Instagram
content:
Azealia Banks held nothing back while going at Lana Del Rey on Instagram, Monday. The New York native asked fans whether they thought gravy poured out of Del Rey's arm after the Norman Fucking Rockwell! singer was seen in a cast.
Ilya S. Savenok / Getty Images
"She is a brick," Banks sings in an Instagram story posted, Monday. "Lana you looking like that fucking hamburger. You need to stay out of that 7-Eleven. Stop shoving that cheeseburger down your throat."
"Do you think gravy poured out when Lana Del Rey broke her arm?" the 29-year-old wrote alongside a picture of Del Rey in a cast.
Del Rey first revealed she had broken her arm while skating earlier this week.
When you see my second video for this album, donâ€™t think that the fact Iâ€™m wearing a cast is symbolic for anything other than thinking I was still a pro figure skater. I wiped out on my beautiful skates before the video even began after a long day of figure eights and jumps in the twilight of the dezert. Anyways my fracture isnâ€™t that bad kind of goes with my new bucket hat. Thanks to my beautiful family for my gifts.
Banks and Del Rey previously went at each other on social media, earlier this year, after Del Rey called out Nicki Minaj, Doja Cat, Cardi B and others, stirring up a major controversy.
[Via]

De quoi l'encourager Ã  les rassurer sur son compte Instagram, et comme l'a repÃ©rÃ© le magazine amÃ©ricain People, ce dimanche 27 dÃ©cembre. L'interprÃ¨te de Blue Jeans a rÃ©vÃ©lÃ© avoir souffert d'une mauvaise chute alors qu'elle faisait du patin Ã  glace. "Je pensais que j'Ã©tais une patineuse artistique professionnelle", a-t-elle Ã©crit en lÃ©gende de sa publication relayÃ©e sur le rÃ©seau social. La chute est survenue alors qu'elle tournait le clip d'un titre issu de son album Chemtrails Over the Country Club, qui sortira dans les bacs le 11 janvier 2021.
Dans la foulÃ©e, Lana Del Rey a rassurÃ© ses fans. "De toute faÃ§on, ma fracture n'est pas si grave et elle va bien avec mon nouveau chapeau", a-t-elle poursuivi, toujours en lÃ©gende de sa publication Instagram. Et de poursuivre, cette fois en s'adressant Ã  ses proches : "merci Ã  ma belle famille pour mes cadeaux." Ainsi, l'artiste de 35 ans s'est rÃ©vÃ©lÃ©e assise profitant de ses cadeaux de NoÃ«l, son bras dans une attÃ¨le. Ses admirateurs se sont, Ã  leur tour, saisis de sa publication pour lui souhaiter de belles fÃªtes mais surtout une paisible convalescence.
Lana Del Rey : un mariage en 2021
Et si sa famille Ã©tait prÃ©sente Ã  ses cÃ´tÃ©s pour le rÃ©veillon, il n'en fut pas de mÃªme pour son bien-aimÃ©, Clayton Johnson, ce dernier ayant cÃ©lÃ©brÃ© NoÃ«l au cÃ´tÃ© de ses propres proches en Californie. Une absence dont Lana Del Rey ne lui tiendra certainement pas rigueur car, au mois de dÃ©cembre 2020, alors qu'elle Ã©tait de passage sur le plateau de l'Ã©mission The Tonight Show de Jimmy Fallon, Elizabeth Grant de son vrai nom a dÃ©voilÃ© un somptueux bijou : une bague de fianÃ§ailles. Vivant une idylle sans accrocs depuis le mois d'aoÃ»t, les tourtereaux ont, en effet, dÃ©cidÃ© de franchir le cap du mariage.

title: Lana Del Rey schockiert ihre Fans: Die SÃ¤ngerin hatte einen Unfall!
content:
SÃ¤ngerin Lana Del Ray hat sich beim Eislaufen ihren Arm gebrochen. Sie hatte fÃ¼r ihr ein neues Video ihres Albums "Chemtrails Over The Country Club" gedreht.
Los Angeles - Schock fÃ¼r die Fans der SÃ¤ngerin Lana Del Rey ("Summertime Sadness")! Die 35-JÃ¤hrige hat sich beim Eislaufen ihren Arm gebrochen.
SÃ¤ngerin Lana Del Rey (35) hat sich beim Eislaufen ihren Arm gebrochen! Auf Instagram zeigt sie ein Bild der Bandage (r). Â© Instagram/Bildmontage/lanadelray
Huch, wie konnte das nur passieren? Auf ihrem Instagram-Account zeigt sich der brÃ¼nette Star mit der auÃŸergewÃ¶hnlichen Stimme mit bandagierten Arm. Dabei sitzt sie vor einigen Alben und lÃ¤chelt leicht in die Kamera.
Lana hat sich doch tatsÃ¤chlich beim Videodreh fÃ¼r ihr neues Album "Chemtrails Over The Country Club" den Arm gebrochen. Die 35-JÃ¤hrige erklÃ¤rt, sie habe gedacht, dass sie nach wie vor ein richtiger Profi beim Eislauf wÃ¤re. Anscheinend eine Fehlannahme.
"Ich bin auf meinen schÃ¶nen Schlittschuhen umgekippt, bevor das Video Ã¼berhaupt angefangen hat", schreibt sie. MÃ¼ssen sich die Fans denn nun etwa groÃŸe Sorgen machen?
Die "Cinnamon Girl"-SÃ¤ngerin gibt zugleich Entwarnung. "Meine Fraktur ist nicht so schlimm, passt irgendwie zu meinem neuen Eimer-Hut." Besagten Hut trÃ¤gt die sonst so auf zarten Kleidungsstil fokussierten Dame auf ihrem Kopf.
Die Fans senden ihr viele GenesungswÃ¼nsche. Andere witzeln, dass es bestimmt eine LÃ¼ge sei, dass sich Lana beim Eislauf den Arm gebrochen habe. "Wir wissen doch alle, dass das passiert ist, weil du die gesamte Musikindustrie auf deinen Armen trÃ¤gst!"
Die SÃ¤ngerin bringt bereits jetzt ihre AnhÃ¤nger zum Ausrasten. Auf YouTube teaserte sie kÃ¼rzlich ihr neues Album, welches im Januar 2021 erscheinen wird, kurz an. Der nur 20 Sekunden lange Clip hat bereits mehr als 500.000 Aufrufe erhalten.

title: Skate-Unfall: Lana Del Rey hat sich den Arm gebrochen
content:
Lana Del Rey (35) gibt offenbar 110 Prozent, wenn es um ihre Musikvideos geht. Die SÃ¤ngerin arbeitete in den vergangenen Monaten hart an ihrem neuen Album "Chemtrails Over the Country Club" â€“ Anfang des kommenden Jahres soll es dann endlich soweit sein. Offenbar war Lana in den dazugehÃ¶rigen Musikvideos mit vollem KÃ¶rpereinsatz dabei â€“ und brach sich beim Dreh den Arm!
Auf Instagram berichtet die "Video Games"-Interpretin von ihrem unglÃ¼cklichen Unfall und verrÃ¤t dabei zeitgleich einige Details in Bezug auf den zweiten Clip ihres neuen Albums: Anscheinend wird Lana in diesem mit einem Gips zu sehen sein. Das habe allerdings keinerlei symbolischen Hintergrund â€“ die Musikerin sei einfach hingefallen, als sie skatete. "Ich habe meine wunderschÃ¶nen Skater zerstÃ¶rt, bevor das Video Ã¼berhaupt nach einem langen Tag aus Achten und SprÃ¼ngen bei DÃ¤mmerung in der WÃ¼ste begann", erzÃ¤hlt die 35-JÃ¤hrige.
Dennoch geht es ihr wohl gut â€“ immerhin nahm Lana die UmstÃ¤nde weitestgehend mit Humor: "Wie auch immer, die Fraktur ist halb so wild, irgendwie passt sie gut zu meinem neuen Hut", gibt die SchÃ¶nheit im Netz Entwarnung.

title: Lana Del Rey says she fractured arm while ice skating
content:
Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Lana Del Rey has announced on Instagram that she fractured her left arm while ice skating and told fans not to think deeply into her wearing a cast in her next music video.
"When you see my second video for this album, don' think the fact I'm wearing a cast is symbolic for anything other than thinking I was still a pro figure skater," Del Rey said on Sunday alongside a photo of herself wearing an arm sling.
Advertisement
"I wiped out on my beautiful skates before the video even began after a long day of figure eights and jumps in the twilight of the dezert. Anyways my fracture isn't that bad kind of goes with my new bucket hat. Thanks to my beautiful family for my gifts," she continued alongside photos of herself going through a collection of vinyls and Norman Rockwell magazine covers.
Del Rey is referring to the next music video for her upcoming album Chemtrails Over the Country Club, which is set for release on Jan. 11. The singer previously released "Let Me Love You Like a Woman" from the project.
The 35-year-old delayed the release of Chemtrails Over the Country Club from September due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The singer last released the album Norman [Expletive] Rockwell in August 2019.

title: Lana Del Rey Reveals Broken Arm & Says She Will Be Wearing A Cast In Music Videos
content:
Lana Del Rey revealed on Instagram, Sunday, that she broke her arm skating and that the cast worn in her upcoming music video is not meant as a symbolic gesture.
Ethan Miller / Getty Images
Del Rey explained the incident alongside a picture of her arm in a cast:
When you see my second video for this album, donâ€™t think that the fact Iâ€™m wearing a cast is symbolic for anything other than thinking I was still a pro figure skater. I wiped out on my beautiful skates before the video even began after a long day of figure eights and jumps in the twilight of the dezert. Anyways my fracture isnâ€™t that bad kind of goes with my new bucket hat. Thanks to my beautiful family for my gifts.
Del Rey mentions that the video will be her second from her upcoming album Chemtrails Over The Country Club. She already released the first video which is for her single â€œLet Me Love You Like A Woman."
Chemtrails Over The Country Club will be Del Rey's first album after making headlines earlier this year for calling out Nicki Minaj, Doja Cat, Cardi B, and more stirring up a major controversy.

title: Lana del Rey canta Silent Night per celebrare il Natale. VIDEO
content:
Il grande classico natalizio Ã¨ stato reinterpretato dalla cantautrice ospite di un evento in onda su Twitch Condividi:
In attesa di conoscere il nuovo album â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€, Lana Del Rey (FOTO) si Ã¨ esibita in un particolare evento proponendo come augurio ai suoi fan la tradizionale â€œSilent Nightâ€. Una suggestiva performance in streaming che ha stregato il pubblico presente sulla piattaforma Twitch, dove si Ã¨ tenuta la lunga maratona che ha riunito numerosi artisti. Oltre al classico del Natale â€œSilent Nightâ€, scelto per augurare buone feste, Lana Del Rey ha interpretato anche Il suo ultimo singolo â€œLet Me Love You Like A Womanâ€. Una performance molto intima e davvero sentita che ha subito fatto il giro del web e dei social.
Lâ€™esibizione in uno show su Twitch Lana del Rey Ã¨ stata ospite di Jack Antonoff, sua sorella Rachel e la Ally Coalition per il loro settimo talent show annuale, trasmesso gratuitamente in streaming su Twitch e che ha permesso di effettuare donazioni a sostegno dei giovani LGBTQ senza casa. Hayley Williams ha scelto di interpretare â€œTeardropâ€ dei Massive Attack, St. Vincent ha invece cantato "Martha My Dear" dei Beatles. Lo spettacolo ha visto anche le apparizioni dei Chicks, Big Red Machine, Blu DeTiger, Clairo, Claud, Andrew Dost, Brittany Howard, Shamir, Muna, Maggie Rogers, Spoon, Rufus Wainwright, Wallows e Tierra Whack. Presenti anche i comici Reggie Watts, Mike Birbiglia, Aidy Bryant, Chris Laker, Jacqueline Novak e Roy Wood Jr. con dei mini set. "La pandemia Ã¨ stata dura per tutti, ma le comunitÃ  che stiamo supportando qui sono state colpite in modo sproporzionato", ha scritto Antonoff su Instagram quando ha annunciato l'evento. Solo pochi giorni fa Lana Del Rey aveva presentato dal vivo il nuovo singolo â€œLet Me Love You Like A Womanâ€. Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, questo il nome allâ€™anagrafe, Ã¨ stata protagonista allâ€™interno del programma The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon. Pubblicato il 16 ottobre 2020, il brano Ã¨ stato eseguito per la prima volta dal vivo solo due mesi dopo.

Die jÃ¤hrliche Â«Talent ShowÂ» der Organisation Â«The Ally CoalitionÂ», bei der bekannte Musiker fÃ¼r den guten Zweck singen, wurde wegen der Corona-Pandemie in diesem Jahr als Livestream gezeigt. FÃ¼r ihren Auftritt setzte sich Lana Del Rey vor den Weihnachtsbaum in ihrem Wohnzimmer.
Paramore-Frontfrau Hayley Williams (31) schaltete sich fÃ¼r ihr Cover von Â«TeardropÂ» (Massive Attack) in Bademantel und mit Handtuchturban dazu.

Der SÃ¤nger steuerte solo eine Version des Songs Â«This Is Me TryingÂ» bei, den er mit und fÃ¼r Taylor Swift geschrieben und produziert hat. SpÃ¤ter trat er dann noch zusammen mit seiner Indie-Band Bleachers auf.
Â«Die Pandemie hat alle hart getroffenÂ», schrieb Antonoff auf Instagram, Â«aber die Gemeinschaften, die wir hier unterstÃ¼tzen, sind Ã¼berproportional betroffen.Â» Mit dem Benefizkonzert hatte er nach eigenen Angaben schon vor der Ausstrahlung am Montag (Ortszeit) rund 250.000 Dollar sammeln kÃ¶nnen.

title: Nye lÃ¥ter uke 2 - se terningkast
content:
BIL: Mannen med hornene og bÃ¸tta er fremdeles mye bedre enn hodeplagget skulle tilsi. Foto: MAJOR
Nye lÃ¥ter uke 2 â€“ se terningkast
Emilie Nicolas, Lana del Rey, BjÃ¸rn Torske og Ringnes-Ronny er blant lÃ¥tslipperne denne uken.
Publisert: NÃ¥ nettopp
Ringnes-Ronny â€“ Â«10 000 MilÂ»
Maskefjeset som ikke skal spille pÃ¥ Sandnes Kulturhus med det fÃ¸rste fortsetter Ã¥ lure ut stÃ¸dig elektronisk pop. Kvaliteten er fremdeles varierende. Forrige uke var det den noe dottete Â«MonsterÂ». Denne uken leverer han derimot en varm og fengende hyllest til ensomheten ved lange bilturer, ikledd et virkelig solid M83 og Chromatics-aktig arrangement. Kan fÃ¥ selv den mest innbitte bussentusiast til Ã¥ angre pÃ¥ at man ikke har lappen.
Lana del Rey â€“ Â«Chemtrails over the Country ClubÂ»
LÃ¥ttittelen, som ogsÃ¥ er tittelen pÃ¥ Lana del Rey sitt kommende album, er sÃ¥ perfekt at det er omtrent umulig Ã¥ toppe den. Â«ChemtrailsÂ» er da heller ikke et spesielt overraskende eller imponerende Lana del Rey-Ã¸yeblikk. Snarere et litt stillestÃ¥ende sÃ¥dan. Det skrider sakte fremover pÃ¥ et vis som ikke stÃ¥r tilbake for noe av det hun har gjort tidligere. Men sÃ¥, i stedet for et voldsomt hÃ¸ydepunkt, fisler hele lÃ¥ten ut iâ€¦ ingenting. Akkurat som tittelens konspirasjonstÃ¥ke.
SHEVIL: BrÃ¥kete kvartett lager monstrÃ¸st solid hardcore. Foto: JÃ˜RN VEBERG
Shevil -Â« Monsters on TVÂ»
Denne solide Oslo-kvartetten har ikke gitt ut mye de siste seks Ã¥rene. Her er de plutselig tilbake med en lÃ¥t som garantert ikke handler om Â«MaskoramaÂ», men som lover veldig godt for det kommende albumet. Folk som synes vokal skal synges, ikke ropes, har lite Ã¥ hente her. Selv om de tar feil. SÃ¥ god melodiÃ¸s hardcore kan det aldri bli for mye av. Ikke norske band som tar navnet sitt fra en Melvins-lÃ¥t heller.
Foo Fighters â€“ Â«Waiting on a WarÂ»
Verdens greieste band markerer verdens greieste vokalist sin 52-Ã¥rsdag med en oppstemt ballade. Egentlig hÃ¸res det ut som ett svakt restespor fra svenske Soundtrack of our Lives, om de hadde vÃ¦rt fast inventar pÃ¥ gitarpub. Vente pÃ¥ krig er jo ogsÃ¥ noe Ã¥ synge om disse dager, men her handler det altsÃ¥ ikke om Ã¥ vÃ¦re klar for kamp, men frykten for at det skal bli krig. Til tross for det veldig jovialt blide melodibildet. TempoÃ¸kningen i slutten, som til forveksling kan hÃ¸res ut som Nirvanas Â«Territorial PissingsÂ» er ikke sÃ¥ ille.
BjÃ¸rn Torske â€“ Bommelom
En av Bergens og nasjonens mest banebrytende elektronikaartister fÃ¸lger opp det nydelige albumet Â«ByenÂ»(2018) med en rytmisk EP om noe de fleste gjÃ¸r hver dag. Det syv minutter lange signatursporet kan ved fÃ¸rste lytt hÃ¸res ut som en trommemaskintest. Det er i stedet et tydelig og fengende nikk tilbake til den rytmiske 2001-utgivelsen Â«TrÃ¸bbelÂ» (2001). Ã…rets mest barnslige lÃ¥ttittel? Garantert.

title: Lana Del Rey defends Trump comments as she brands him a 'narcissist psychopath'
content:
Get all the very latest news in Ireland straight to your email every single day Sign up! Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Invalid Email
Lana Del Rey has defended her comments about US president Donald Trump.
The musician, 35, said her comments about the riots at the Capitol building led by looters were "taken out of context" as she defended her stance.
Lana appeared on BBC Radio 1 to chat to Annie Mac about her latest album release before touching on the current situation in her home country.
Lana's comments instantly blew up on social media after outlets assumed she meant Trump "didn't know he was inciting" the violent insurrection in Washington DC, and that his divisive presidency "needed to happen" to America.
"The madness of Trump, as bad as it was, it really needed to happen," she told Annie Mac live on air. "We really needed a reflection of our worldâ€™s greatest problem, which is not climate change, but sociopathy and narcissism."
(Image: lanadelrey/Instagram)
"It's not capitalism, it's narcissism," she added. "I was surprised we didn't have a live-television psychopath crazy person as a president a long time ago because that's what we see on TV and that's what we see on Instagram."
During the chat, Lana labelled the riot, which resulted in the deaths of five people, as "disassociated rage".
And after being slammed on social media for her comments, Lana has defiantly returned to social media to set the record straight about her thoughts.
"What I was describing w the BBC was that Trump is so significantly impaired that he may not know what he was doing due to his significant lack of empathy and the wider ranging problem is the issue of sociopathy and narcissism in America," she told fans.
(Image: AFP via Getty Images)
In a follow-up tweet, she said: "Iâ€™ll say it again I donâ€™t appreciate the larger magazines taking my well-intentioned and believe it or not liberal comments out of context. Itâ€™s actually what I sing about quite often. Itâ€™s what Iâ€™ve been condemned for saying. You can listen to the entire interview."
After sending the tweets, Lana returned to Instagram to share a lengthy video of herself in her bedroom as she cleared up any confusion surrounding her comments.
"I really donâ€™t appreciate being painted as some white Republican whoâ€™s always been given everything and supports the incite of the Capitol riot," she explained. "I grew up struggling, working my a** off, we had nothing, period."
(Image: @LanaDelRey/Twitter) (Image: @LanaDelRey/Twitter)
She went on: "I personally donâ€™t get it. I just think sometimes because of the way I look, itâ€™s easy to paint this picture, but man, did I struggle to become the genuine singer-songwriter I am."
Lana went on to hit out at the naysayers, and explained why she feels it's important to fight back against her critics.
"People do not last a long time in my workplaceâ€¦itâ€™s fun to tear people down, but it really discourages them from moving onto their next project," she said.
(Image: FilmMagic)
"This is my story, Iâ€™m telling itâ€¦Iâ€™m the wrong person to come for when it comes to not being inclusive or liberal. Not that I ever focused on either one. I always just focused on the music, but if people want to make it political, Iâ€™m down, but listen to the entirety of the 40-minute interview.
"Soâ€¦I donâ€™t want to have to focus on this, but it is what it is. Iâ€™d love to get the point one day where we just talk about the music, but until that day, I want you to know my story."
Captioning the lengthy video on Instagram, Lana wrote: "Talk about it. Get it out of your system. And then GFYS."

title: Lana Del Rey Calls Out Media Outlets For Their Coverage Of Her Trump Comments
content:
After remarks made during an interview went viral, Lana Del Rey is clarifying her stance on America's current political unrest. The award-winning singer recently sat down with BBC Radio 1 to chat about her Chemtrails Over The Country Club project, and during the discussion, she was asked about the insurrection at Capitol Hill last Wednesday (January 6). She spoke at length about the topic, but one snippet captured the attention of the masses and soon became the focal point of the interview.
Erik Voake / Stringer / Getty Images
"The madness of Trumpâ€”as bad as it was, it really needed to happen," said the singer. "We really needed a reflection of our worldâ€™s greatest problem, which is not climate change but sociopathy and narcissism. Especially in America. Itâ€™s going to kill the world. Itâ€™s not capitalism, itâ€™s narcissism." Elsewhere she added, "You know, he doesnâ€™t know that heâ€™s inciting a riot and I believe that" because of his ego and "delusions of grandeur."
Soon, multiple media outlets picked up the quote, and Lana was criticized for her remarks, but after seeing Complex's coverage, she specifically took issue with the outlet because of their reported longstanding relationship. "OK complex not that our 10 year relationship matters I guess Thanks for the cool soundbite taken out of context," Lana tweeted. "I said that the bigger problem is Sociopathy-so whether he meant to incite a riot is less important than the larger issue in America at hand -the problem of sociopathy."
She added that she voted for Biden and continued to defend her full "liberal" statement. She called out major media outlets who also reported on the story. You can check out Lana's tweets, as well as a video of her explaining her remarks, below.
View this post on Instagram A post shared by Lana Del Rey (@lanadelrey)
[via]

title: Lana Del Rey sparks racism criticism after bizarre statement about new album
content:
Lana Del Rey has unleashed the name and cover artwork for her new album - and angered people online for the bizarre statement that accompanied it.
The 35-year-old â€˜Born to Dieâ€™ singer announced her new album would be called Chemtrails Over The Country Club - then appeared to pre-empt any criticism that she was indulging in â€œtokenismâ€ by including â€œwomen of colourâ€ on the album cover.
In a somewhat jumbled message on Twitter, Del Rey said the women on the cover of the album were all friends who were a â€œbeautiful mix of everything.â€
â€œIn 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without even trying to,â€ she said.
â€œMy best friends are rappers, my boyfriends have been rappers.
Chevron Right Icon â€˜My best friends are rappers, my boyfriends have been rappers.â€™
â€œMy dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, Iâ€™m not the one storming the capital.
â€œIâ€™m literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24-seven.
â€œRespect it.â€
While some fans mocked the idea that del Rey was â€œchanging the worldâ€ with her album, others took issue with the â€œmy best friends are rappers, my boyfriends have been rappersâ€ comment.
â€œShe was talking about people accusing her of being racist and in defence, she said that her best friends are rappers/ her boyfriends have been rappers, insinuating that 1. being a rapper = being POC and 2. dating/being friends with a POC makes you not racist,â€ one person wrote.
Lana Del Rey. Credit: AP
â€œLana Del Rey couldâ€™ve literally released the album silently but she had to remind us that sheâ€™s changing the world one rapper boyfriend at a time,â€ another said.
â€œI feel bad for her ... I know her intentions arenâ€™t bad, but MESS,â€ wrote another.
In 2020, critics attacked del Rey for writing songs with lyrics that were â€œglamourising abuse.â€
Del Reyâ€™s response was to name artists including Cardi B and Nicki Minaj as artists who wrote songs about â€œbeing sexy, wearing no clothes, f***ing, cheating, etcâ€.
When she was called out for citing black artists, del Rey said the artists she named were her â€œfavourite f***ing peopleâ€, telling fans: â€œmaking it about race says so much more about you than it does about meâ€.

title: Chemtrails over the Country Club: Lana Del Rey draws controversy after pre-emptively defending album artwork
content:
Lana Del Rey has received backlash online â€” for pre-empting backlash.
The songstress released the artwork for her highly anticipated upcoming album, Chemtrails over the Country Club, this morning.
But rather than leaving it there, the 35-year-old posted a lengthy passage pre-empting any backlash about her using people of colour in her album artwork â€” but her avoidance strategy has still landed her in hot water.
The 35-year-oldâ€™s album cover sees her and a group of friends in a 1950s scene, clad in pearls and enjoying a picnic.
In a stand alone comment, that reads like she is responding to a critic accusing her of tokenism, Del Rey attempts to jump ahead of any backlash by clarifying that the people of colour in the photo are her friends.
But now fans and industry critics are accusing her of using the â€˜some of my friends are blackâ€™ defence after she wrote that â€œwe are all a beautiful mix of everything â€” some more than othersâ€.
â€œIn 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without even trying to,â€ she insisted.
â€œMy best friends are rappers, my boyfriends have been rappers. My dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, Iâ€™m not the one storming the capital.
â€œIâ€™m literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24-seven. Respect it.â€
But Del Rey ended up trending on social media this afternoon anyway, with fans saying that her attempt at being â€œwokeâ€ was actually just â€œtone-deafâ€.
â€œShe was talking about people accusing her of being racist and in defence she said that her best friends are rappers/ her boyfriends have been rappers, insinuating that 1. being a rapper = being POC and 2. dating/being friends with a POC makes you not racist,â€ one user commented.

title: Star slammed for bizarre US riot post
content:
Lana Del Rey has again angered social media users while defending herself against past criticism of racial insensitivity, claiming she's "literally changing the world" with her music, and telling fans she's "dated rappers" in the past.
The singer, 35, unveiled the cover and tracklist for her upcoming album, Chemtrails Over The Country Club, on Sunday, adding in a since-deleted comment that she has an "extremely inclusive" approach to diversity in reference the women of colour included in the images.
Deflecting past accusations of racism, she went on to tell followers that her "best friends and past boyfriends have been rappers", adding in reference to last week's riots that she's "not the one storming the capital (sic)".
RELATED: Lana Del Rey engaged after five months
Del Rey's statement read: "As it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover yes there are people of colour on this records (sic) picture and that's all I'll say about that but thank you.
"My beautiful friend Valerie from Del Rio Mexico, my dearest friend Alex and my gorgeous friend Dakota Rain as well as my sweetheart Tatiana. these are my friends this is my life. We are all a beautiful mix of everything - some more than others which is visible and celebrated in everything I do.
"In 11 years working I have always been extremely inclusive without even trying to. My best friends are rappers my boyfriends have been rappers," the singer added.
"My dearest friends have been from all over the place, so before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, I'm not the one storming the capital (sic), I'm literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven. Respect it."
RELATED: Lana Del Rey slammed for ridiculous face mask
A number of fans took issue with her words.
Some pointed out that she was seemingly associating rappers with people of colour, while others ripped into her for using the Capitol riots to promote her new music.
Others mocked her "changing the world" claim.
RELATED: Lana Del Rey slammed for dragging BeyoncÃ©

â€œIâ€™ve had rapper boyfriendsâ€ is the new â€œI have a black friend...Iâ€™m not racistâ€ yo did Lana Del Rey just- ğŸ’€ â€” Fay (@epicfaylure) January 10, 2021
Lana del rey couldve literally released the album silently but she had to remind us that sheâ€™s changing the world one rapper boyfriend at a timeğŸ–ğŸ¾ğŸ˜Œ â€” joannaâ€™s struggle tweets (@dumbdotcomm) January 11, 2021
Lana Del Rey really used the failed coup to promote her album..... pic.twitter.com/QtjPLWvafH â€” kate bush's husband (@airbagged) January 10, 2021
"So before you make comments again about a WOC/POC issue, Iâ€™m not the one storming the capital, Iâ€™m literally changing the world by putting my life and thoughts and love out there on the table 24 seven."
Sigh.
It's 2021 and Lana Del Rey is still a nightmare for her publicist. â€” Ernest Owens (@MrErnestOwens) January 11, 2021
The songstress had a controversial 2020, having been forced to issue two apologies in disputes involving fellow female artists.
Back in May, Del Rey named R&B singer Kehlani and other artists while attacking critics who said her music was "glamorizing abuse" while Cardi B, Nicki Minaj, and others wrote hits "about being sexy, wearing no clothes, f***ing, cheating, etc".
After commenters called her out for naming mostly women of colour, Del Rey remained unapologetic, saying the artists were her "favorite f***ing people".
In a follow-up post, she told fans that "making it about race says so much more about you than it does about me".
Just a few weeks later, after posting videos of looters during the Black Lives Matter protests in footage that revealed demonstrators' faces, she was called out by the very artists she had named previously.
Calling for her to remove the footage, Kehlani accused her of "(endangering) the lives of Black people" by disclosing identities.
Del Rey eventually took the posts down.
Originally published as Star slammed for bizarre US riot post

title: Unmissable Music for an Uncertain Year
content:
An artist or label considering releasing music in 2020 had to make some calculations: How important would live promotion be to this recordâ€™s success? Would the music still be timely if it sat on the shelf for six months or more? Would the artist have the financial means to put a completed album on hold? How difficult would it be to record the music in an age of social distancing? The answers to these and other questions led to one of the stranger release years in memory, light on big names and heavy on collections of live and unreleased material culled from the archives. The first half of 2021 will most likely be a continuation of 2020â€™s patchwork. Touring as we knew it before the pandemic wonâ€™t be back anytime soon. But even at this early date there are a number of potentially important records from artists who find themselves at a crucial junctureâ€”trying to maintain momentum after a breakthrough, returning after years away, struggling to take their music to a new place. Hereâ€™s a look at 10 tracks from such albums, most of which should come out this yearâ€”some have release dates, some are tentative, and one hasnâ€™t been announced.
Torch singer Lana Del Rey first mentioned â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ the follow-up to her 2019 LP â€œNorman Fâ€”ing Rockwell,â€ back in May, and it was at one point scheduled for release this past fall. But Ms. Del Rey pushed it back, and it seems likely to come out in the first half of 2021. The advance single â€œLet Me Love You Like a Womanâ€ was produced and co-written by Ms. Del Reyâ€™s frequent creative partner Jack Antonoff, and with its spare piano part it pretty much picks up where her last record left off.
We expected a sixth studio album from Torontoâ€™s Drake in 2020, but the rapper and singer born Aubrey Graham instead put out â€œDark Lane Demo Tapes,â€ a mishmash of old tracks and previously unreleased material. The long awaited LP, â€œCertified Lover Boy,â€ is coming later this month, and our first taste of music from it came in the form of â€œLaugh Now Cry Later,â€ featuring Chicago rapper Lil Durk. The song is loose and breezy and breaks no new ground for Drake, but his effortless melodic style is intact.
Dave Grohlâ€™s Foo Fighters last released a full-length record in 2017. The groupâ€™s 10th studio album, â€œMedicine at Midnight,â€ is coming Feb. 5. The most recent advance single, â€œNo Son of Mine,â€ dropped last week, and it found the band in a familiar hard-rocking zone, but â€œShame Shameâ€ from November is more interesting: Moody and subtle with R&B inflections, it finds Mr. Grohl exploring the upper end of his vocal range to intriguing effect.
The past year was a great one for the younger generation of rock songwriters, particularly women. Both Phoebe Bridgers and Waxahatchee had creative breakthroughs, and they made two of 2020â€™s best records. Julien Baker is a member of the indie supergroup Boygeniusâ€”with Ms. Bridgers and Lucy Dacusâ€”and she has a solo album, â€œLittle Oblivions,â€ coming Feb. 26. Ms. Bakerâ€™s music is explosive, with screamed choruses about emotional torment, but her new song â€œFaith Healerâ€ sees her smoothing out rough edges while keeping her trademark intensity.

content:

La chanteuse affiche un joli plÃ¢tre sur les photos quâ€™elle a postÃ©es sur les rÃ©seaux sociaux.
Â«Ma fracture nâ€™est pas si grave que Ã§aÂ», a rassurÃ© Lana Del Rey Getty Images
Lana Del Rey a Ã©tÃ© repÃ©rÃ©e en Californie portant une Ã©charpe gris clair et un plÃ¢tre noir. La star a dÃ©clarÃ© Ã  ses fans, sur les rÃ©seaux sociaux, quâ€™elle sâ€™Ã©tait blessÃ©e en patinant.
La chanteuse a publiÃ© une galerie de photos comprenant un de ses portraits et une sÃ©lection de ses cadeaux de NoÃ«l, et a Ã©crit un commentaire humoristique: Â«Quand vous verrez ma deuxiÃ¨me vidÃ©o pour cet album, ne pensez pas que le fait que je porte un plÃ¢tre est symbolique pour une autre raison que je suis toujours une patineuse artistique professionnelle. Jâ€™ai fait disparaÃ®tre mes beaux patins avant mÃªme que la vidÃ©o ne commence, aprÃ¨s une longue journÃ©e de huit et de sauts dans le crÃ©puscule du dezert (sic). De toute faÃ§on, ma fracture nâ€™est pas si grave que Ã§a, elle va avec mon nouveau bob. Merci Ã  ma belle-famille pour les cadeaux.Â»
Des vinyles en cadeau
Parmi ces cadeaux, on dÃ©couvre des disques vinyles, dont Diamonds & Rust, de Joan Baez, ainsi quâ€™une grande bague rose et un livre dâ€™art de Norman Rockwell â€“ qui a servi dâ€™inspiration pour le titre de son dernier album musical, Â«Norman F**king RockwellÂ»!
Lana Del Rey a Ã©galement publiÃ© une photo de son nouveau fiancÃ©, Clayton Johnson, qui les montre se frottant le front lâ€™un contre lâ€™autre alors que chacun porte un masque Ã  motifs.

title: Lanzamientos musicales 2021: Drake, Foo Fighters y Lana del Rey alistan sus nuevos discos
content:
Drake, Foo Fighters y Lana del Rey prometen lanzamientos para el 2021. | Fuente: ComposiciÃ³n (Instagram / AFP)
La incertidumbre discogrÃ¡fica que marcÃ³ 2020, con retrasos perpetuos y Ã¡lbumes sorpresa, se mantendrÃ¡ en 2021; con pocos lanzamientos cerrados, cabe posar la vista en Drake y Lana del Rey y las esperanzas en BeyoncÃ©, Adele, RosalÃ­a, Arcade Fire, Billie Eilish y The Cure, ademÃ¡s de reformular esta pregunta: Â¿serÃ¡ el aÃ±o de Rihanna?
El calendario a estas alturas no puede ser mÃ¡s escueto. En enero apenas habrÃ¡ grandes lanzamientos (destacar el dÃ­a 15 al dÃºo de electrÃ³nica punk Sleaford Mods, con "Spare Ribs") y habrÃ¡ que esperar al 5 de febrero para desenvolver "Medicine At Midnight", esperado regreso de Foo Fighters, mÃ¡s experimentales a tenor de lo escuchado en el primer anticipo, "Shame Shame".
Febrero traerÃ¡ algÃºn otro trabajo reseÃ±able, como "As The Love Continues" de Mogwai, el dÃ­a 19, y ya el 26 tanto "Detroit Stories" de Alice Cooper, como "That's Life" de Willie Nelson, el Ã¡lbum de versiones de Frank Sinatra grabado por el veterano country man.
"Endless Arcade" de Teenage Fanclub llegarÃ¡ el 5 de marzo y unos dÃ­as despuÃ©s, el 19, el Ã¡lbum que recopila todos los duetos de Sting. En abril, el dÃ­a 16, serÃ¡ el turno de una de las bandas jÃ³venes que han logrado agitar el mundo del rock, Greta Van Fleet, con "The Battle At Garden's Gate".
A partir de aquÃ­, el Ã¡mbito de la mÃºsica internacional se vuelve escurridizo. Entre los lanzamientos mÃ¡s seguros estÃ¡n "Certified Lover Boy", de Drake, que deberÃ­a ver la luz en algÃºn momento del mes de enero, segÃºn anunciÃ³ Ã©l mismo hace unas semanas.
Igualmente cercano estÃ¡ lo nuevo de Lana del Rey ("Chemtrails Over The Country Club"), que se espera para marzo por los retrasos en las plantas de prensado de vinilo. En Ã©l ha vuelto a colaborar con el productor Jack Antonoff, como en "Normam Fucking Rockwell" (2019).
Otro disco que postergÃ³ la pandemia fue "Black Diamond" de Janet Jackson, su primer trabajo en mÃ¡s de un lustro, del que dio su primera noticia oficial hace ya casi un aÃ±o, y quien podrÃ­a tener trabajo inÃ©dito antes del verano serÃ¡ Jennifer Lopez, segÃºn confirmÃ³ Sony Music.
EL ROCK CALIENTA MOTORES
ï»¿Otro Ã¡lbum del que se lleva hablando desde hace tiempo y que parece estar en la lÃ­nea de salida es lo nuevo de The Cure. Robert Smith, quien ademÃ¡s ha estado trabajando en un disco en solitario, confirmÃ³ a la BBC en septiembre que el primer material inÃ©dito de la banda desde 2008 estÃ¡ listo y que serÃ¡ "el mÃ¡s triste".
Algo mÃ¡s se harÃ¡ esperar el sexto Ã¡lbum de Arcade Fire. Con Rick Rubin como productor y "una versiÃ³n mÃ¡s extrema" de lo hecho hasta el momento, en el podcast de Broken Record comentaron que tras el parÃ³n en la grabaciÃ³n a causa del estallido de la pandemia, se esperaba reemprender el trabajo en Texas (EE.UU.) en estas semanas.
Las expectativas en torno a Red Hot Chili Peppers son mÃ¡s difusas. Unas fotos publicadas en verano por Flea, el bajista, mostraron a toda la banda en el estudio y en octubre el guitarrista John Frusciante, de vuelta tras su salida en 2008, confirmÃ³ en Australia que estaban inmersos en la composiciÃ³n de material nuevo.
A LA ESPERA DE OTROS GRANDES DEL HIP HOP
ï»¿En el mundo del hip hop, uno de los mÃ¡s esperados es Travis Scott, quien el pasado octubre avanzÃ³ a travÃ©s de su Instagram que su cuarto Ã¡lbum de estudio llevarÃ¡ por tÃ­tulo "Utopia".
Con el Ã©xito desde hace unos meses del tema "WAP" junto a Megan The Stallion, Cardi B supo calentar el ambiente para el que serÃ¡ el sucesor del celebrado "Invasion of Privacy" (2018). De momento se desconoce hasta su tÃ­tulo.
Se sigue igualmente a la espera de una continuaciÃ³n del premiado "DAMN" (2017), de Kendrick Lamar, quien ratificÃ³ recientemente que en efecto estÃ¡ a la bÃºsqueda de un "nuevo sonido", pero que es un proceso que le lleva mucho tiempo.
MUJERES AL PODER
ï»¿BeyoncÃ© no estuvo parada durante la pandemia, segÃºn revelaba la versiÃ³n estadounidense de Hola. SegÃºn esta, la estadounidense estÃ¡ trabajando en un nuevo "show virtual" y en cÃ³mo mostrar su "nueva mÃºsica", que ya se habrÃ­a empezado a escribir y grabar con artistas como Dua Lipa y The Shindellas como referentes.
Tras reaparecer en las Ãºltimas semanas, estÃ¡ confirmado que Adele se encuentra en el estudio grabando la deseada continuaciÃ³n de "25" (2015). Uno de sus colaboradores, el percusionista de Pearl Jam, Matt Chamberlein, confirmaba en estos dÃ­as que su regreso suena "emotivo y poderoso" y que estÃ¡ mÃ¡s cerca de lo que ella misma da a entender.
TambiÃ©n se estÃ¡ gestando ya lo nuevo de Billie Eilish. Tal y como ella confirmÃ³ hace unos dÃ­as en una entrevista durante el iHeartRadio Jingle Ball 2020, estÃ¡ "al 50 por ciento" y versarÃ¡ sobre todo acerca de sus pensamientos y experiencias personales.
Como ella, Lorde se llevÃ³ grandes elogios por su Ãºltimo trabajo, "Melodrama" (2017). En una reciente publicaciÃ³n en Instagram, la neozelandesa animÃ³ a sus seguidores a votar en las elecciones del paÃ­s. "Y a cambio yo les darÃ© algo el aÃ±o que viene", prometiÃ³.
Anni Clark, mÃ¡s conocida como St. Vincent, tambiÃ©n confirmÃ³ que el sucesor de "MASSEDUCTION" estÃ¡ "listo y cargado". En una charla con Mojo, comentÃ³ ademÃ¡s que se ha inspirado sobre todo en los discos de principios de los aÃ±os 70 de Stevie Wonder y en la mÃºsica de Sly & The Family Stone.
Por Ãºltimo, Rihanna. No hay novedades respecto a la continuaciÃ³n de "ANTI" (2016). Fue en 2018 cuando la barbadense confirmÃ³ que habrÃ­a nuevo disco, probablemente un trabajo doble integrado por un disco mÃ¡s pop y, eso seguro, uno mÃ¡s experimental a partir de sus raÃ­ces caribeÃ±as. Demasiado ocupada como empresaria, declarÃ³ a Interview su intenciÃ³n de volcarse en el verano de 2019 en su nuevo Ã¡lbum. Pero este sigue sin llegar...
Â¿Y EN ESPAÃ‘OL?
ï»¿Cuando el pasado mes de noviembre se cumplieron dos aÃ±os de "El Mal Querer", RosalÃ­a se dejÃ³ ver en el estudio y lo confirmÃ³ en el Ãºltimo nÃºmero de Vogue USA, del que fue portada. "Necesitaba estas horas trabajando solo en mi mÃºsica", dijo la catalana sobre el nuevo disco, que se prevÃ© que salga en 2021, como la prometida colaboraciÃ³n con Billie Eilish.
Su compaÃ±Ã­a, Sony Music, anticipÃ³ que se espera material nuevo de Enrique Iglesias para antes del verano. En el Ã¡mbito latino, habrÃ¡ novedades asimismo de Manuel Turizo en febrero y de Camilo y de Nicky Jam en marzo.
Jorge Drexler, por su parte, adelantÃ³ a Efe que ya habÃ­a comenzado a trabajar en un nuevo Ã¡lbum de estudio y que lo habÃ­a hecho desde una perspectiva diferente, al incorporar otras miradas a su proceso compositivo, por ejemplo la de C. Tangana.
Tras el bombazo de algunos de sus Ãºltimos sencillos, especialmente "TÃº me dejaste de querer", se espera con ganas precisamente el siguiente Ã¡lbum de este artista madrileÃ±o, que verÃ¡ la luz en febrero, segÃºn confirmÃ³ Sony Music.
Aunque sin fecha, tambiÃ©n estÃ¡ atado el que serÃ¡ el quinto disco de estudio de Leiva tras "Nuclear" (2019). El artista revelÃ³ a EFE que contarÃ¡ con dos productores: por un lado Carlos Raya, su colaborador habitual en estas labores desde hace aÃ±os; y por otro el mÃºsico AdÃ¡n Jodorowsky, mÃ¡s conocido como Adanowsky y por ser hijo del polifacÃ©tico artista chileno Alejandro Jodorowsky.
Menos seguro es el retorno de Alejandro Sanz, pero el cantante y compositor madrileÃ±o confirmÃ³ a EFE que aprovechÃ³ el confinamiento para registrar nuevas canciones de cara a un nuevo Ã¡lbum que podrÃ­a ver la luz en 2021.
(Con informaciÃ³n de EFE)

title: Lana Del Rey : l'histoire derriÃ¨re sa fracture du bras
content:
Lana Del Rey porte actuellement un plÃ¢tre au bras suite Ã  un accident de patinage. Sur ses rÃ©seaux sociaux, l'interprÃ¨te de "Video Games" a expliquÃ© comment cet incident est survenu avec humour.
Accompagnant son message de photos montrant ses cadeaux de NoÃ«l, la star a Ã©crit : "Quand vous verrez ma deuxiÃ¨me vidÃ©o pour cet album, ne pensez pas que le fait que je porte un plÃ¢tre est symbolique pour une autre raison que je suis toujours une patineuse artistique professionnelle. J'ai fait disparaÃ®tre mes beaux patins avant mÃªme que la vidÃ©o ne commence, aprÃ¨s une longue journÃ©e de huit et de sauts dans le crÃ©puscule du dezert. De toute faÃ§on, ma fracture n'est pas si grave que Ã§a, elle va avec mon nouveau bob. Merci Ã  ma belle-famille pour les cadeaux."
RÃ©cemment, Lana a fait parler d'elle en rÃ©pondant Ã  une fan qui l'accusait d'avoir votÃ© pour Donald Trump lors des Ã©lections prÃ©sidentielles de novembre.
La chanteuse de "Born To Die" a effectivement rÃ©pondu de maniÃ¨re trÃ¨s directe Ã  une fan qui doutait de ses opinions politiques. L'utilisatrice Twitter, prÃ©nommÃ©e Alex, a Ã©crit : "Je SAIS qu'Elizabeth (le vrai prÃ©nom de la chanteuse, ndlr) a votÃ© pour Trump. J'aimerais pouvoir regarder ses relevÃ©s de votes. Je n'ai pas un bon pressentiment."
ExtrÃªmement mÃ©contente de se voir associÃ©e Ã  Donald Trump, la star n'a pas mÃ¢chÃ© ses mots dans sa rÃ©ponse.
S'adressant directement Ã  Alex, Lana a dÃ©clarÃ© : "Va. Te. Faire. Voir."
Un message simple mais percutant qui aura probablement pris Alex de court. Ã‡a n'est effectivement pas tous les jours qu'une star vous dit d'aller paÃ®tre sur les rÃ©seaux sociaux. L'utilisatrice a postÃ© par la suite : "Lana me dit d'aller me faire voir alors que j'ai son nom tatouÃ© sur mon bras. Looool bah ok." Ce Ã  quoi la chanteuse a rÃ©pondu: "Non, relis ce que tu as Ã©crit, pÃ©t****."
Des propos inattendus de la part de la star qui laissent donc entendre qu'elle n'a pas votÃ© pour Donald Trump mais probablement pour son adversaire Joe Biden.

title: Lana Del Rey mostra braÃ§o fraturado e conta que se acidentou enquanto patinava: 'NÃ£o foi tÃ£o ruim assim'
content:
Na foto de comemoraÃ§Ã£o de Natal que a cantora Lana Del Rey postou, um detalhe chamou a atenÃ§Ã£o. Ela estava com o braÃ§o engessado e usando uma tipoia. Ela contou que se acidentou enquanto patinava no gelo e que "minha fratura nÃ£o foi tÃ£o ruim assim" e que o gesso "combina com o novo chapÃ©u", que ganhou de presente de Natal da famÃ­lia.
Lana Del Rey mostra braÃ§o fraturado e conta que se acidentou enquanto patinava: 'NÃ£o foi tÃ£o ruim assim' Foto: ReproduÃ§Ã£o
"Quando vocÃªs virem o meu segundo clipe do prÃ³ximo Ã¡lbum, nÃ£o achem que o fato de eu estar com o braÃ§o engessado Ã© simbÃ³lico de alguma coisa. Acontece que uma parte de mim ainda acha que eu sou uma patinadora profissional", brincou na legenda.
No mesmo carrossel de fotos em que aparecia com o braÃ§o machucado, ela compartilhou os momentos natalinos em famÃ­lia, os presentes que ganhou, como discos de Joan Baez, 5 e Diamonds & Rust.
