title: Lana Del Rey fratura braÃ§o apÃ³s cair durante patinaÃ§Ã£o
content:
Acidente aconteceu na vÃ©spera de gravar novo clipe (Foto: DivulgaÃ§Ã£o)
No Ãºltimo domingo, 27, Lana Del Rey anunciou nas redes sociais que sofreu um acidente enquanto patinava no gelo. A artista fraturou o braÃ§o, que agora estÃ¡ engessado. Em postagem, a cantora brincou falando que o fato ocorreu depois de um dia inteiro "fazendo rodopios e saltos no crepÃºsculo do deserto".
O acidente aconteceu exatamente um dia antes do comeÃ§o das filmagens do prÃ³ximo clipe da cantora. Por isso, Lana explicou que provavelmente irÃ¡ aparecer â€œengessadaâ€ no vÃ­deo. "Quando vocÃªs virem o meu segundo clipe do prÃ³ximo Ã¡lbum, nÃ£o achem que o fato de eu estar com o braÃ§o engessado Ã© simbÃ³lico de alguma coisa. Acontece que uma parte de mim ainda acha que eu sou uma patinadora profissional", disse.
Apesar do transtorno, a cantora finalizou ressaltando seu bom humor diante da situaÃ§Ã£o. "Minha fratura nÃ£o Ã© tÃ£o ruim, no entanto: o gesso combina com o meu novo chapÃ©u. Obrigada Ã  minha famÃ­lia linda pelos presentes de Natal".

title: Lana Del Rey Announces 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club' Video Release Date
content:
Everyone, stay calm. The Chemtrails Over the Country Club era is finally upon us.
After months of pushing back release dates, Lana Del Rey announced on Tuesday (Dec. 22) that the music video for her upcoming album's title track, plus an album pre-order will be available on Jan. 11, 2021.
In a 25-minute teaser, the singer is seen in a number of luxurious outfits, giving a taste of what the lush new album cycle will look like.

title: How to watch the 7th annual Ally Coalition Talent Show live: Stream the virtual benefit concert from anywhere
content:
This year's Ally Coalition Annual Talent Show is going virtual for a live benefit concert featuring performances by some of the biggest names in music. The Ally Coalition is dedicated to bettering the lives of LGBTQ youth, supporting homeless LGBTQ youth, and advocating for equality which is why it's no surprise that major acts like Lana Del Rey, Maggie Rogers, or Hayley Williams will be lending their time and a special performance to the benefit. While the show itself is free to watch, you can donate during the event or right now by texting the letters TAC to the number 833-535-0584. You can also donate to The Ally Coalition via PayPal.
Along with Lana Del Rey, Maggie Rogers, and Paramore frontwoman Hayley Williams, the 7th Annual Talent Show will feature performances by Big Red Machine, Bleachers, Blu Detiger, The Chicks, Clairo, Claud, Andrew Dost, Brittany Howard, MUNA, Shamir, Sleater-Kinney, Spoon, St. Vincent, Rufus Wainwright, Wallows, and Tierra Whack. The show will feature more than just musical guests though; there will also be one-minute standup sessions with Kalen Allen, Mike Birbiglia, Aidy Bryant, Chris Laker, The Lucas Bros, Jacqueline Novak, Reggie Watts, and Roy Wood Jr. as well as a one-minute meal tutorial with Rachael Ray.

title: Marilyn Manson sparks furious backlash after â€˜leaked textsâ€™ show him â€˜body-shamingâ€™ Lana Del Rey
content:
Singer Marilyn Manson has been at the centre of controversy as allegations against him from several women, including former partners, have been made.
American actor Evan Rachel Wood made the first allegations in a statement last week. She alleges Manson, whose real name is Brian Warner, had groomed her from a teenager and â€œhorrifically abusedâ€ her during the pairâ€™s three-year relationship. Once Woodâ€™s shocking claims became public, more women came forward with their own statements about the singer.
Publicist Annie Abrams has recently spoken about alleged torture suffered at the hands of Manson. She has also revealed texts in which Manson allegedly body-shamed singer Lana del Rey.
In the screenshots posted on Abramsâ€™ Instagram account, she shared the alleged text exchange with the caption:
â€œ#marilynmanson trash talking/body shaming @lanadelrey and asking me to find a mug shot of Ashley Walters (how cute is this @illmagore ) MM: you mess with my life, I mess with yours. That was the deal, no? Rot in hell.â€
The messages seem to show Manson sending a picture of Lana del Rey followed by the words "no comment". When asked who the image was of, Manson appears to call the singer "Lasagna Del Ray" in a cheap jibe.
He then adds: "Not body shaming. Or whatever. But that pic is fucking crazy.â€
On Twitter, users were disgusted and encouraged those who laughed to take a look at themselves.
Back in 2014, leaked video footage appeared to depict Lana Del Rey being sexually assaulted. Initial reports suggested that the disturbing scenes were made for a Manson music video, but the singerâ€™s representative has denounced these as false, saying â€œit must be a fan video splicing up old Manson video footage with someone elseâ€™s Lana Del Rey footage.â€
Manson later spoke out about the clip, explaining that he did want to make a video with Del Rey but the collaboration proved difficult to organise.

title: Lana Del Rey's 1st Album Was Inspired by This 1990s Movie
content:
Lana Del Reyâ€™s music includes a number of references to movies, however, one movie, in particular, had a profound impact on her work. One classic movie was a major influence on her album Born to Die. Hereâ€™s a look at what Del Rey had to say about it.
Lana Del Rey | Chelsea Lauren/WireImage
Lana Del Rey: a musician for movie fanatics
A lot of Del Reyâ€™s work includes classic movie references. For example, the lyrics to â€œBody Electricâ€ reference Gentlemen Prefer Blondes, the video for â€œRideâ€ quotes A Streetcar Named Desire, and John Wayne and Marilyn Monroe are portrayed in her short film Tropico. Movies mean a lot to Del Rey. According to Vulture, Del Rey revealed in 2012 she wanted to break into the movie industry and enjoys screenwriting. In fact, she hoped to leave music behind to make movies.
However, her love for movies extends beyond writing. During an interview with the Los Angeles Times, Del Rey revealed she has a particular fondness for film scores. Specifically, she said she enjoys Nino Rotaâ€™s work on The Godfather and Giorgio Moroderâ€™s work for the remake of Cat People. She also singled out the soundtrack of a classic 1990s film, citing Thomas Newmanâ€™s score for American Beauty as one of her favorites. â€œI remember the first time I saw the film, the score is the first thing you hear,â€ she recalled. â€œI loved it.â€
The score for American Beauty
RELATED: Lana Del Rey Once Said a Rapper Changed Her Life, He Said Heâ€™d Hit Her
What inspired Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜Born to Dieâ€™
Del Rey doesnâ€™t simply enjoy the soundtrack of American Beauty. She draws inspiration from it. â€œI started working [on Born to Die] with this kid from London, Justin Parker; he sort of wrote a lot of the chords on the record. And then I was looking for a producer to tie everything together, sonically, and Emile [Haynie] was perfect, because, musically, weâ€™re on the same path,â€ she told MTV News. â€œWe love mixing the light and the dark together, and I was in love with his beats â€¦ he understood what I meant when I was talking about wanting a mix of a sound similar to Thomas Newmanâ€™s American Beauty score, mixed with a [Bruce] Springsteen, summertime sadness feel. And everything came togetherâ€¦ Sonically, I always knew exactly what I wanted.â€
The connection between American Beauty and Born to Die makes sense. American Beauty is a dark, sexual movie and Del Reyâ€™s music is often dark and sexual. In addition, the sonic textures of the album resemble Newmanâ€™s score. While Del Reyâ€™s tends to reference older pop culture, the 1990s still play an important role in Born to Die thanks to the influence of American Beauty.
The song â€œBorn to Dieâ€
RELATED: The Story Behind the Controversial Title of Lana Del Reyâ€™s New Album
How the world reacted to â€˜Born to Dieâ€™
So did drawing inspiration from American Beauty work for Del Rey? Born to Die peaked at No. 2 on the Billboard 200 in 2012. The album stayed on the chart for a total of 379 weeks. Clearly, the album was a massive commercial success â€” and it wouldnâ€™t be the same without American Beauty.

title: Lana Del Rey, il nuovo singolo Ã¨ White Dress
content:
Due immagini su Instagram annunciano lâ€™uscita del nuovo singolo della cantautrice, terzo estratto dellâ€™album in arrivo il 19 marzo Condividi:
Lana Del Rey (FOTO) ha annunciato lâ€™uscita di un nuovo singolo condividendo due immagini sulla sua pagina Instagram. Il brano Ã¨ â€œWhite Dressâ€, prima traccia del nuovo album â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€ in arrivo il mese prossimo. Si tratta del terzo singolo estratto dal progetto discografico dopo â€œLet Me Love You Like a Womanâ€ e la titletrack. In particolare lâ€™uscita di questâ€™ultimo brano era stato accompagnato da una serie di interviste che avevano attirato lâ€™attenzione dei media. Lana Del Rey non aveva usato mezze parole per parlare di Donald Trump definendo lâ€™ex presidente degli Stati Uniti â€œun riflesso del piÃ¹ grande problema del nostro mondo, che non Ã¨ il cambiamento climatico, ma la sociopatia e il narcisismoâ€. Parole forti che avevano fatto il giro del web.
Il singolo â€œWhite Dressâ€ e il nuovo album In merito al nuovo singolo â€œWhite Dressâ€, Lana Del Rey ha scelto invece di pubblicare due foto su Instagram. Nel primo scatto Ã¨ immortalata una donna che sta pattinando e indossa un vestito bianco. Ad accompagnare lâ€™immagine ci sono le parole "Mi ha fatto sentire ... mi ha fatto sentire come un Dio" scritte in rosa. La seconda immagine mostra la stessa donna con ali d'angelo bianche e il titolo "White Dressâ€. La data di uscita di â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€ Ã¨ stata posticipata piÃ¹ volte ed ora Ã¨ prevista per il 19 marzo. Questa la tracklist del disco: White Dress Chemtrails Over The Country Club Tulsa Jesus Freak Let Me Love You Like A Woman Wild At Heart Dark But Just A Game Not All Who Wander Are Lost Yosemite Breaking Up Slowly Dance Till We Die For Free Lâ€™album â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€ si chiude con la traccia â€œFor Freeâ€, cover di Joni Mitchell

title: The Weeknd Once Admitted All His Music Is About Lana Del Rey
content:
In some ways, The Weeknd is operating in a class of his own. The singer took the music industry by storm in the mid-2010s. And yet, in addition to The Weekndâ€™s dating life, he has formed a few key collaborative relationships with other artists. In particular, The Weeknd and Lana Del Rey have worked together a few times. And The Weeknd once admitted just how important Del Rey is to his music.
Lana Del Rey performs on stage at Rogers Arena in Vancouver | Andrew Chin/Getty Images
The Weeknd worked with Lana Del Rey several times
On the surface, The Weeknd and Del Rey might seem like very different artists. After all, The Weekndâ€™s music hip hop and soul sound feels more in line with someone like Ariana Grande. Meanwhile, Del Reyâ€™s career lives much more in line with rock-infused pop. However, the two artists are much more similar than the genres of their music might reveal.
For instance, The Weeknd and Del Rey both often capture a dream-like quality in their songs. In addition, their lyrical content dips into dark territory, such as their preoccupation with drug references. So it makes sense they would work well together. And so they have. Beginning with The Weekndâ€™s 2015 single â€œPrisoner,â€ theyâ€™ve worked together on five songs.
RELATED: The Weekndâ€™s Mother Was Disappointed In Him As a Teenager; â€˜She Looked at Me Like She Had Failedâ€™
The Weeknd said the singer is very important to his music
Although the Grammy Awards have yet to bestow a trophy to Del Rey, her work certainly makes a huge impact on The Weeknd. In fact, the â€œBlinding Lightsâ€ singer once revealed just how vital she is to his own music. In a 2015 interview with Pitchfork, The Weeknd explained the interconnected nature of Del Reyâ€™s music and his own.
â€œMe and Lana have been friends for a long time. Iâ€™ve inspired her. Sheâ€™s inspired me. I feel like weâ€™ve always been talking to each other through our music. She is the girl in my music, and I am the guy in her music. Itâ€™s just this ghostly collaboration that feels the most natural on the whole [Beauty Behind the Madness] album. Even the whole monologue intro on â€œLonely Starâ€ from [my 2011 mixtape] Thursday â€” I just realized now that thatâ€™s Lana. Thatâ€™s Lanaâ€™s voice. I mean, itâ€™s my voice pitched up, but itâ€™s her. Itâ€™s who she is. She was definitely the first feature that I wanted to bring on this album.â€
The Weeknd and Del Rey are more than just collaborators, it seems. The pairâ€™s music â€” according to The Weeknd â€” is spiritually linked. Perhaps this revelation puts into context not only the collaborations between these two but their respective catalogs as well.
RELATED: The Weeknd Shares the Critical Role Jim Carrey Played in His Career
Are The Weeknd and Lana Del Rey dating?
Considering the personal nature of their bond, curious fans might wonder whether The Weeknd and Del Rey are dating. In fact, so far itâ€™s never been confirmed whether the pair have ever been romantically linked. But The Weeknd is definitely no stranger to high-profile relationships.
For years, the singer has been in an on-again/off-again relationship with model Bella Hadid. Heâ€™s also been romantically linked to Selena Gomez somewhere in the midst of it all. However, thereâ€™s no confirmation who â€” if anyone â€” The Weeknd is currently dating.

title: Start Walkinâ€™ 1965-1976
content:
Nancy Sinatra was both blessed and burdened with that last name. When she launched a pop career in the early 1960s, the Sinatra name immediately distinguished her from so many other promising young singers, and it meant she had a trusted adviser who could provide wise counsel (such as always own your masters). On the other hand, she was always Frankâ€™s daughter in the public eye, always Nancy with the laughing face. She covered his songs, signed with his label (Reprise Records), and even made movies for his production company. It was her father who set up a meeting between her and Lee Hazlewood, who until then was best known for working with guitarist Duane Eddy in the 1950s. Both men have long been viewed as motivating figures in her career, barely behind the scenes, and it appears to be an ongoing struggle: â€œI canâ€™t seem to get out of this trap,â€ she told The Believer in 2014. â€œIâ€™m either Frankâ€™s daughter or the person who sang with Lee Hazlewood. Thatâ€™s OK; I donâ€™t begrudge the men in my life. They helped me tremendously.â€
In many ways, her career and legacy have been defined by getting out of the shadows of these famous men and fighting to get her proper due as an artist. Sinatra has enjoyed few major reissues. There have been many greatest-hits collections, but few that do more than scratch the surface or offer any kind of broad overarching vision. In fact, the most substantial retrospective, 2011â€™s Cherry Smiles: The Rare Singles, was released on her own Boots label. That paucity of compilations makes Start Walkinâ€™ a necessary addition to her catalog and immediately the best place for a newcomer to jump into her catalog. While most compilations cover a relatively brief period in the late 1960s when she was enjoying a steady stream of hits and even filming television specials, this one extends that range well into the 1970s, concluding with her retirement in 1976. These 23 tracks cover a lot of ground musically and critically, tracing her massive hits in the mid 1960s and following her as she weathers professional upheavals and changing pop trends.
Start Walkinâ€™ does not, however, include Sinatraâ€™s very first singles, when she was a teenager trying to find her voice. She calls it her â€œNancy Nice Ladyâ€ period, when she worked with Annette Funicelloâ€™s producer and presented a squeaky-clean image. Even Sinatra doesnâ€™t think very highly of those songs, and Start Walkinâ€™ locates her first sessions with Hazlewood in 1965 as the true start of her career. But that older material provides an interesting point against which to measure her transformation: She dyed her hair blonde, performed on TV in go-go boots and miniskirts straight from Mary Quantâ€™s store in London. Always aware of the importance of visuals (her 1961 single â€œCufflinks and a Tie Clipâ€ was one of the first seven-inch singles packaged in a full-color sleeve), she projected power and sophistication from the stage and from the TV screen, along with a sexual confidence and emotional maturity that made her a stand-in for an entirely new generation of American women in the mid-â€™60s. Those boots suggested a whole army behind her.
Those qualities extended to the music and then some. Hazlewood goaded her in a more sexual direction, often describing what he wanted in vulgar terms (in a 1968 interview with Cosmopolitan, Sinatra says he asked her to sing â€œlike a 13- or 14-year-old girl who goes out with 40-year-old menâ€). But Sinatraâ€™s songs never sound vulgar. Like the first generation of rockâ€™nâ€™rollers a decade earlier, Sinatra has a blast with innuendo rather than stating her desires outright. She teases the possibilities in her infamous cover of Cherâ€™s â€œBang Bang,â€ as though she knows that you know what sheâ€™s really singing about. That song was neither a single nor a hit at the time, but half a century later, itâ€™s one of Sinatraâ€™s most popular and enduring tunes largely because there are so many different layers in her performance: She foregrounds the poignancy in the lyricsâ€”the sting of betrayal, the weight of regretâ€”to match Billy Strangeâ€™s noir guitar licks. Similarly, she revels in the breezy ambiguity of â€œSugar Town,â€ which may or may not be about turning on and tuning out. â€œIâ€™m gonna lay right down here in the grass, and pretty soon all my troubles will pass,â€ she sings, her voice skipping along to the melody, but the song is less about the wink and more about the calm she finds looking up at the sky.
As Start Walkinâ€™ progresses through her career, the songs grow more florid and more idiosyncratic, incorporating folk rock, country, chamber pop, and a kind of theatrical pastoral psychedelia. Until he abruptly moved to Sweden (allegedly without telling Sinatra) and later after heâ€™d returned to the States, Hazlewood served as her primary songwriter, and this compilation suggests that it was her versatility that allowed him to embrace his own mannerisms as a lyricist, producer, and pop conceptualist. The jump cuts on â€œSome Velvet Morningâ€ are fairly well-known, but can still knock a listener off balance, while â€œArkansas Coal (Suite)â€ is more cinematic and certainly more ambitious, as Sinatra sings in the voice of a woman whose life is made and then broken by the coal mines. More generally, her voice seems to invite oddball arrangement ideas, such as the backwards guitar solo on â€œSandâ€ or the solo kickdrum on â€œLightningâ€™s Girl,â€ which rumbles like an idling motorcycle. Itâ€™s fun listening to her navigate these unexpected flourishes, as though she is responding to the music and the music to her.
One of the best moments on Start Walkinâ€™â€”and certainly one Iâ€™ve returned to repeatedlyâ€”is a small, tossed-off line on â€œFridayâ€™s Child.â€ The song, a hit in 1967, is about an individual abandoned by society, an outcast born with no blessings, only burdens. It seems to suggest some allegory, but Hazlewoodâ€™s lyrics can be vague. Still, Sinatra invests the song with the weight of experience and empathy, culminating in the line, â€œFridayâ€™s childâ€¦ whom theyâ€™ll forget to bury!â€ She spits the line, almost choking on her disgust. Itâ€™s the rare moment when Sinatraâ€™s composure threatens to crack. But it never does, at least not on Start Walkinâ€™, not even when she bursts into sobs at the end of her melodramatic reading of Dolly Partonâ€™s â€œDown from Dover.â€
Itâ€™s unfortunate that this retrospective concludes with â€œ(Lâ€™Ã©tÃ© Indien) Indian Summer,â€ from 1976. Hazlewood takes lead, reciting in his stentorian baritone verses about an old lover and a beach and the moon, and Sinatra is reduced to singing wordlessly in the backgroundâ€”window dressing for his reminiscence. True, this was her final single before she retired to raise her daughters, but Start Walkinâ€™ plays loose enough with the tracklist chronology. It has the perhaps unintended effect of leaving her career open-ended, as though she still hasnâ€™t escaped the shadow of the men in her life. Everything up to that point proves otherwise.
Buy: Rough Trade
(Pitchfork earns a commission from purchases made through affiliate links on our site.)

title: Marilyn Manson Body-Shames Lana Del Rey, Allegedly Calls Her "Lasagna Del Ray"
content:
Marilyn Manson has been battling violent abuse allegations for most of the new month, already being exposed as an apparently insatiable bully. Based on some leaked text messages of the rocker between him and an Instagram user known as Annie Abrams (initially confused for a True Blood actress, view her IG post on that below), he was a part of the fat-shaming mob that poked fun of songstress Lana Del Rey after she was captured by the paparazzi's camera.
The "Summertime Sadness" crooner appeared to have gained a bit of weight during the COVID-19 quarantine, promoting many people, including Manson, to make fun of her build. Manson allegedly sent a photo of Del Rey to Abrams before commenting on her appearance, prefacing his statements with "Not body shaming. Or whatever," before continuing, "But that pic is f**king crazy. It's like Vince Neil bad."
The metal singer continued his attack on Del Rey, dubbing the songstress "Lasagna Del Ray" to further ridicule her for her weight gain. He then explained his personal relationship with the Grammy-nominated artist, explaining, "I know her. And my good friend was dating her and hilariously enough I did a photo shoot that they used her hair extensions dyed black and I had an octopus on my head." He went on to claim in the messages, "She is really complicated. I'll leave it at that."
As mentioned briefly before, Manson is currently facing allegations of abuse from his ex-fiancee Evan Rachel Wood, who outed the disgraced singer for "grooming" and "horrifically" abusing her for years. Since then, numerous women have come forward with their own allegations against the singer.
Manson has denied the allegations in an Instagram post, writing, "Obviously, my art and my life have long been magnets for controversy, but these recent claims about me are horrible distortions of reality. My intimate relationships have always been entirely consensual with like-minded partners. Regardless of how - and why - others are now choosing to misrepresent the past, that is the truth."
[via]

title: Lana Del Rey's FiancÃ© Clayton Johnson Shares Rare Photo of the Couple
content:
Watch : Lana Del Rey - 2020 Grammy Awards Glambot
Lana Del Rey and Clayton Johnson are packing on the social media PDA.
On Feb. 4, Clayton, who appeared to be celebrating his birthday, posted a picture of the singers sharing a smooch and captioned it, "Happy birthday to me." While this isn't the first time the two have posted about the other on social media, it is the first time they've shared a PDA pic directly to their feeds versus stories.
Of course, the pair had already reached a major milestone in their relationship. Back in December, sources told Us Weekly and People that Clayton proposed to Lana. And while the two haven't publicly commented on the reports, there have been several signs of an engagement.
For starters, eagle-eyed fans noticed the Grammy-nominated artist was wearing a diamond ring on that finger during her performance on the Dec. 14 episode of The Tonight Show. In fact, followers got another peek at the rock in Clayton's recent photo.

title: Fallece Sandie Crisp, protagonista del video viral Obedece a la morsa
content:
El 29 de enero se confirmÃ³ la muerte de la actriz trans Sandie Crisp, a los 61 aÃ±os de edad. SegÃºn la informaciÃ³n difundida por TMZ, la partida de la artista se produjo el Ãºltimo miÃ©rcoles por causas que no han sido reveladas.
Famosa en la cultura underground americana, Sandie Crisp adquiriÃ³ notoriedad mundial con el perturbador video Obedece a la morsa, que se hizo viral en Internet durante el 2007.
No obstante, el mencionado clip en realidad es un extracto de la pelÃ­cula The goddess bunny (La diosa coneja) de 1998, cinta que fue concebida y dirigida por Nick Bougas como una biografÃ­a de Sandie Crisp, con pasajes de su trabajo en la escena subterrÃ¡nea de Los Ãngeles, ademÃ¡s de las dificultades que significÃ³ vivir con poliomielitis y ser VIH positivo.
A pesar de ello, y antes de la fama adquirida por Obedece a la morsa, la actriz trans fue invitada a participar del video musical para The dope showâ€ (1998) de Marilyn Manson.
TambiÃ©n aparece en â€œFallen Leavesâ€ (2006) de Billy Talent y â€œPuppet Masterâ€ de Cypress Hill, de 1997.
La noticia de su muerte fue lamentada por la cantante Lana del Rey a travÃ©s de su cuenta de Instagram, donde ademÃ¡s de compartir fotografÃ­as de Sandie Crisp, escribiÃ³:
â€œSignificaste todo para mi hermana y Hunter, y por eso significaste mucho para mÃ­. Gracias por traer tanta alegrÃ­a a sus vidasâ€.

title: Musik von Spielbergs Tochter: Buzzy Lee hat Melancholie im Blut
content:
Buzzy Lee heiÃŸt eigentlich Sasha Spielberg und ist die Tochter von Hollywood-Regissseur Steven Spielberg. Vor allem aber macht sie wunderschÃ¶ne traurige Musik.
Der Nachname Spielberg kann einem sicherlich nicht nur in Hollywood viele TÃ¼ren Ã¶ffnen. Vor allem dann, wenn man tatsÃ¤chlich mit Regie-Ikone Steven Spielberg verwandt ist. So wie Sasha Rebecca Spielberg, seine Tochter. Doch statt diesen Umstand zu nutzen, verÃ¶ffentlicht die 30-JÃ¤hrige bereits seit Jahren Musik unter diversen Pseudonymen. Derzeit fokussiert sie sich auf ihr Alter Ego Buzzy Lee und bringt nach einer EP in 2018 mit "Spoiled Love" nun das erste Album heraus, das in Zusammenarbeit mit dem New Yorker Musiker Nicolas Jaar entstand.
Darauf prÃ¤sentiert sie sich in intimen Songs mit zarter Stimme als introvertiertes, zerbrechliches Wesen mit dunklen Flecken auf der Seele. Nicht selten wird Buzzy Lee - womÃ¶glich aufgrund der Nostalgie, die in ihrer Musik mitschwingt - mit Kollegin Lana Del Rey verglichen. ntv.de hat mit ihr darÃ¼ber gesprochen, warum dieser Vergleich auch fÃ¼r sie selbst hinkt, wie es ist, eine Spielberg zu sein und warum sie der Musik der Schauspielerei gegenÃ¼ber immer den Vorzug geben wÃ¼rde.
ntv.de: Buzzy Lee ist nicht dein erstes Musikprojekt. Du hast zuvor unter dem Namen Wardell bereits Musik mit deinem Bruder Theo gemacht. Warum jetzt dieses Soloprojekt?
Buzzy Lee: Wir haben 2010 als Brother/Sister angefangen, ehe wir uns zu Wardell umbenannt haben. Das lief also eine ganze Weile. Unsere letzte Platte erschien 2019. Wir haben immer zusammen Songs geschrieben und sind gemeinsam auf Tour gegangen. Wir haben als Bruder und Schwester eine wirklich besondere Verbindung. Ich hatte aber so viele eigenen Songs, die Theo nicht fÃ¼r Wardell haben wollte. Ich aber wollte sie unbedingt verÃ¶ffentlichen und das ist der Grund, warum es nun Buzzy Lee gibt. Ich bin dann auch mit nur einer weiteren Person getourt, das war schon was Besonderes fÃ¼r mich. Seitdem kann ich mir es kaum noch vorstellen, wieder mit sechs Leuten unterwegs zu sein. Und deswegen habe ich Buzzy jetzt in den Fokus gestellt.
Gibt es eine Geschichte hinter dem Pseudonym?
Ich finde zum einen, dass es einfach gut klingt. Zum anderen ist Lee der Name meiner GroÃŸmutter, die mich sehr beeinflusst hat. Und Buzzy war ihr Spitzname, also habe ich das beides einfach kombiniert. Namen sind schon eine seltsame Sache ...
Du musst es wissen, deiner ist immerhin Spielberg ... WÃ¤re der nicht auch eine Option gewesen?
Es ist tatsÃ¤chlich ein ziemlich groÃŸer Nachname und ich wollte nicht, dass er am Ende die Musik Ã¼berstrahlt. Deswegen haben wir immer unter anderen Namen verÃ¶ffentlicht. AuÃŸerdem gibt es einen Youtube-Star namens Sasha Spielberg mit Millionen von Followern. Das ist der eigentliche Grund, warum ich mich dagegen entschieden habe. (lacht)
Buzzy Lee ist zudem schon etwas griffiger als Sasha Rebecca Spielberg ... und passt irgendwie auch besser zu der doch sehr melancholischen und intimen Musik, die du machst. "Spoiled Love" ist das Album einer Trennung, richtig?
Ja, tatsÃ¤chlich. Ich habe mich von meinem Freund getrennt. Aber meine Songs sind auch so immer melancholisch. Ich sitze ja allein am Piano, da kommt nicht so viel FrÃ¶hlichkeit auf. (lacht) Ich fÃ¼hle mich einfach melancholisch, wenn ich allein bin.
Ich habe in verschiedenen Artikel Ã¼ber dich gelesen, dass man dich gern mit Lana Del Rey vergleicht. Ich persÃ¶nlich empfinde das nicht so. Wie geht es dir damit?
GrundsÃ¤tzlich ist der Vergleich erstmal okay. Ich finde sie wirklich fantastisch. Viele meiner Freunde sind groÃŸe Fans von ihr. Sie ist cool und talentiert, aber ich habe den Vergleich auch nie verstanden. Selbst unter meinen Instagram-Fotos schreiben Leute, ich wÃ¤re "so Lana" - eine jÃ¼dische Lana mit dunklen Haaren dann wohl am ehesten. (lacht) Vergleiche in der Musik sind sowieso interessant. Immer knÃ¼pfen wir eine Verbindung zu etwas, an das uns das GehÃ¶rte erinnert, und vergleichen, um es zu verstehen. Aber ich freue mich, dass dich meine Musik nicht an Lana erinnert. (lacht)
Die Songs waren bereits vor Ausbruch der Pandemie fertig, sodass du die Chance hattest, gemeinsam mit Nicolas Jaar zu reisen, um es aufzunehmen.
ANZEIGE Spoiled Love 9,74 â‚¬ Jetzt kaufen
Ich habe die ersten Songs bereits 2017 geschrieben, und 2019 haben wir mit den Aufnahmen begonnen, in einem Studio in Norditalien. Das lag daran, dass Nicolas bereits dort war und ich ihm einfach gefolgt bin. Das Studio dort war unglaublich. Zu der Zeit habe ich auÃŸerdem einen Franzosen gedatet, da war es einfach gut, in Europa zu sein. (lacht).
Stand das VerÃ¶ffentlichungsdatum im Januar 2021 seinerzeit schon fest oder habt ihr diesbezÃ¼glich eure PlÃ¤ne angepasst? Auf Tour gehen kannst du damit ja auch jetzt erstmal nicht.
Es sollte tatsÃ¤chlich deutlich frÃ¼her erscheinen, aber dann kam Corona. Und selbstverstÃ¤ndlich wollte ich damit auch auf Tour gehen. Wir haben das Release immer weiter verschoben. Aber jetzt muss es einfach raus.
Wie geht es dir persÃ¶nlich mit der Situation? Gerade Kalifornien, wo du lebst, ist ja schwer von Corona betroffen.
NatÃ¼rlich ist es schlimm, Menschen nicht treffen zu kÃ¶nnen und dass alles geschlossen ist, gerade fÃ¼r Leute, die sowieso schon von Ã„ngsten geplagt werden. Aber zu Beginn habe ich es noch positiv gesehen, dass eine hÃ¶here Macht uns dazu zwingt, mal eine Pause einzulegen. Man muss nichts tun, das man nicht tun will. Aber nach und nach Ã¤nderte sich das. Ich dachte irgendwann: 'Verdammt, ich will nach Ibiza reisen!' (lacht) Ich habe stattdessen sehr viel Reality-TV geschaut, aber davon hatte ich dann auch irgendwann genug.
Du hast in der Vergangenheit auch schon als Schauspielerin gearbeitet. Wenn du dich entscheiden mÃ¼sstest, wÃ¼rdest du der Musik den Vorzug geben?
Zu 100 Prozent. Ich wollte frÃ¼her unbedingt Schauspielerin werden. Als ich dann etwa 19 Jahre alt war, hat sich das dann mehr in Richtung Musik entwickelt, weil sie mich viel mehr berÃ¼hrt als die Schauspielerei. Heute schauspielere ich nur noch fÃ¼r Projekte von Freunden.
Aber hat dich dein Vater nie vor einen Job im Filmbusiness gewarnt?
Er hat sehr viel Wert darauf gelegt, dass wir alle zur Schule gegangen sind, gute Noten hatten und das College besuchten, um einen guten Abschluss zu machen. Ansonsten hat er uns immer bei allem unterstÃ¼tzt. Da hatte ich GlÃ¼ck.
Ist der Name Spielberg ein TÃ¼rÃ¶ffner oder bereitet dir das auch schon mal Probleme, weil du womÃ¶glich hÃ¤ufiger im Mittelpunkt stehst, als einem lieb ist?
Ich versuche zu vermeiden, meinen Namen Ã¼berhaupt zu sagen. Wenn ich aber beispielsweise wegen eines Rezepts in der Apotheke stehe, hinter mir eine Schlange, und mich die Angestellte dann nach dem Namen fragt, flÃ¼stere ich ihn. NatÃ¼rlich kommt dann: "Was?" und ich sage ihn ein bisschen lauter. Bis sie ihn dann richtig laut wiederholt. Das ist mir schon sehr unangenehm. (lacht) Ich bin nÃ¤mlich ziemlich schÃ¼chtern. Aber in Sachen Musik hÃ¤tte mir der Name sicher nicht geholfen, er hÃ¤tte eher vom Inhalt abgelenkt.
Welche Hoffnung hast du fÃ¼r dieses Jahr? Denkst du, noch auf Tour gehen zu kÃ¶nnen mit "Spoiled Love"? Und stÃ¼nden dann auch Europa und Deutschland auf dem Plan?
Europa auf jeden Fall, ich liebe es so sehr. Ich wÃ¼rde gern Ã¼berall hin und hoffe, dass es klappt, bin aber nicht sehr optimistisch. Ansonsten fange ich diesen Monat schon mit den Aufnahmen zu meinem nÃ¤chsten Album an und schreibe auch weiterhin Musik. Und dann zÃ¤hle ich die Tage, bis es wieder auf die BÃ¼hne geht.
Warst du schon mal in Deutschland?
Ja, etwa vor sechs Jahren, da war ich in Berlin und fand es toll. Dort ist eine so verrÃ¼ckte Szene und ein ganz besonderes Nachtleben ...
Normalerweise ...
Normalerweise ...
Es ist gut mÃ¶glich, dass die kleinen, intimen Clubs, in denen auch du auftreten wÃ¼rdest, nach der Pandemie nicht mehr existieren. Dann mÃ¼sstest du womÃ¶glich ins Stadion ausweichen ...
Ja, das stelle ich mir toll vor. Ich auf der BÃ¼hne eines Stadions am Klavier und im Publikum zehn Leute, die mir zujubeln. (lacht)
Mit Buzzy Lee sprach Nicole Ankelmann
Das Album "Spoiled Love" ist ab dem 29. Januar erhÃ¤ltlich.

title: Lana Del Rey Once Said a Rapper Changed Her Life, He Said He'd Hit Her
content:
Lana Del Rey cited lots of different artists as influences, however, not all of them have been kind to her. One of them fantasized about hitting her in his music. Hereâ€™s the story â€” and how Del Reyâ€™s friend Azealia Banks reacted to these violent lyrics.
Lana Del Rey | Chelsea Lauren/WireImage
The artist who changed Lana Del Reyâ€™s life
According to Rolling Stone, Del Reyâ€™s influences are eclectic. They include everyone from Nancy Sinatra to The Eagles to Walt Whitman. One of her more contemporary influences in Eminem. â€œHe really changed my life because I didnâ€™t know music could be intelligent,â€ Del Rey said. â€œHe was talking about his own life and he wasnâ€™t just rhyming over music for rhymeâ€™s sakeâ€¦ That made me think I could talk about the way things were instead of just making stupid music.â€ While Del Rey makes music in a different genre than Eminem, she incorporated elements of hip-hop production into albums like Born to Die and Honeymoon.
What Eminem said about Lana Del Rey in a song
This did not prevent Eminem mentioning Del Rey in one of his songs in a way thatâ€™s less than flattering. He released a freestyle where he rapped â€œPlay nice? B*tch Iâ€™ll punch Lana Del Rey right in the face twice, like Ray Rice in broad daylight in the plain sight of the elevator surveillance/â€™Til her head is banging on the railing, then celebrate with the Ravens.â€ This lyric referred to the time Rice, a member of the Baltimore Ravens, assaulted his then-fiance Janay.
â€œYoung and Beautifulâ€
RELATED: The Saga of the Lana Del Rey/Lorde Beef
This lyric is not without precedent in Eminemâ€™s discography. Heâ€™s rapped about committing violence numerous times and insulted celebrities ranging from the Backstreet Boys to Lindsay Lohan to Britney Spears. In a similar vein, Del Rey released a song called â€œUltraviolenceâ€ which is about a victim of domestic violence.
How Azealia Banks reacted to this
According to The Music, Del Reyâ€™s then-friend Azealia Banks called Eminem out for his lyrics. She tweeted â€œBut does Eminem know that I will personally punch him in his mouth?!â€ She added â€œTell him to go back to his trailer park and eat his microwave hotpocket dinnerâ€¦.â€ She also said Eminem was in an incestuous relationship with his sister. This comment was part of Banksâ€™ long history of criticizing public figures.
â€œLoveâ€
RELATED: Did Lana Del Rey Once Write a Rap-Influenced Song About Azealia Banks?
Does Lana Del Rey still like Eminemâ€™s music?
So did this incident sour Del Rey on Eminemâ€™s music? Apparently not. According to HipHop24x7, she once posted a video of herself listening to Eminemâ€™s iconic hit â€œLose Yourself.â€
Which artist is more popular?
This raises an interesting question: Which artist is more popular? Eminem released 22 top 10 singles on the Billboard Hot 100, 5 of which reached No. 1: â€œThe Monster,â€ â€œLose Yourself,â€ â€œLove the Way You Lie,â€ â€œNot Afraid,â€ and â€œCrack a Bottle.â€ On the other hand, Del Rey released only four singles which reached the top 40 of the Billboard Hot 100: â€œDonâ€™t Call Me Angel,â€ â€œSummertime Sadness,â€ â€œWest Coast,â€ and â€œYoung and Beautiful.â€ None of her singles reached No. 1 so far.

title: Lana Del Rey Shares Glowing Selfie Post-Album Release, Says She's 'Happy'
content:
As expected, fans banded together to congratulate the artist on the new album.
"The album is absolutely stunning [heart emoji] you should be so happy and SO PROUD!! Flawless x," penned one Instagram user, earning 399 likes from Lana's following.
"The album is INCREDIBLY BEAUTIFUL! So endlessly proud of u babe," read another message.
"Thank YOU for giving us another masterpiece of beautiful music," said Riccardo Simonetti, leaving a heart emoji.
More than 42,600 people chimed in on the post to praise the album and list their favorite songs on it. Others relished in the singer's happiness, telling her it was well-deserved.
In the seven hours since it has been live, the selfie was liked by over 1.8 million people.

title: Lana Del Rey: Chemtrails Over the Country Club review - bold and beautiful
content:
Lana Del Reyâ€™s latest album begins with the borderline infamous singer-songwriter reminiscing about a time before fame. Sung in a fluttering soprano at the very limit of her range, White Dress pictures the 19-year-old Del Rey in a tight uniform, working as a waitress in the mid-00s and dreaming of what is to come. â€œDown at the Men in Music Business Conference,â€ she confides in a breathless rush, the budding artist finally feels â€œseenâ€.
At the albumâ€™s other end sits a cover of Joni Mitchellâ€™s For Free, in which the grande dame of song pondered, in 1970, how a busker can play â€œreal good, for freeâ€ to so little acclaim, while Mitchell herself is raking it in as a celebrity. Del Reyâ€™s album has more than one arc, but one is a numbers game. On White Dress she is alone; by the end, she is joined by Weyes Blood and singer-songwriter Zella Day, each singing a Joni verse and joining in on period-perfect harmonies, weighing up the contradictions.
Throughout this excellent seventh outing, Del Rey frequently chews over the vexed business of success, her loneliness and her comradeship. She accosts you in various bars, not only telling you her star sign â€“ Cancer â€“ but her moon: Leo. In the middle is perhaps this great albumâ€™s greatest segment. A minor-key folk song that doesnâ€™t bother trying to be anything but, Yosemite dates back to sessions for Del Reyâ€™s 2017 album, Lust for Life, but embodies this albumâ€™s concern with craft. â€œWe did it for fun, we did it for free,â€ she sings of her work, in one of Del Reyâ€™s best vocals to date. On Wild at Heart, she claims not to be a star, nodding obliquely to the death of Princess Diana â€“ â€œthe cameras had flashes, they caused the car crashesâ€ â€“ an impression only reinforced by repeated references to Elton Johnâ€™s Candle in the Wind.
The dead-eyed jadedness of her earlier protagonists has been replaced by something less coy and more direct
Fame is just one concern: Del Rey weighs up the relative merits of change and constancy, of love and loneliness, all with intensely discreet instrumentation provided by returnee producer Jack Antonoff, who worked on Del Reyâ€™s last album, the equally extraordinary Norman Fucking Rockwell!. All these nods are seeded carefully through a suite of songs that also reference one another.
The albumâ€™s title â€“ Chemtrails Over the Country Club â€“ could have been used on many of Del Reyâ€™s previous records, pointing up as it does the contrast between the Americana of white picket fences and the nationâ€™s uneasy dark side, a continued fascination of Lana Del Reyâ€™s work. (â€œChemtrailsâ€ refers to a conspiracy theory that the condensation from aeroplanes is secretly laced with nefarious chemicals.)
But this is a record chockful of beauty and thoughtful autobiography that only a more experienced, more assured songwriter could have made. Although one of its central songs, Dark But Just a Game, dwells on the seamier side of Los Angeles celebrity, the dead-eyed jadedness of Del Reyâ€™s earlier protagonists seems to be behind her, replaced by something less coy and more direct. These are tunes full of pugnacious vulnerability and unapologetic prettiness, littered with Laurel Canyon throwbacks and elegiac, multitracked vocals. Del Rey has come close to conventionality â€“ but on her own terms. Sheâ€™ll still be getting â€œhigh on pink champagneâ€ (a form of MDMA), a barfly equally at home in Calabasas â€“ a celebrity enclave in the LA hills â€“ or tempting a â€œTulsa Jesus freakâ€ back into bed.
Love songs continue to predominate in the work of this inveterate romantic, but throughout Chemtrails, Del Rey alights repeatedly on the mentorship and solidarity of fellow female songwriters. As well as Weyes Blood and Day, singer-songwriter Nikki Lane duets with Del Rey on a plangent country tune, Breaking Up Slowly (apparently, there are more country songs waiting in the wings). That track evokes the long-suffering country singer Tammy Wynette and concludes that, where once Del Reyâ€™s protagonist might have clung, breaking up is â€œthe right thing to doâ€. Moreover, Del Rey is also â€œcovering Joni and dancing with Joan [Baez]â€ while Stevie [Nicks] is â€œcalling on the telephoneâ€. The albumâ€™s cover art finds Del Rey surrounded by her sister and a bevy of female friends, all glamorous and, pointedly, of many skin tones. (Del Rey has come under fire for some ill-judged comments online about the output of women of colour, which she maintains were misunderstood.)
No longer is Del Rey selling a kind of compromised ultra-femininity; she is doing â€œthe Louisiana two-step, high and brightâ€ with her squad. In the video for the title track, her pack all turn into sexy werewolves by night, referencing, perhaps, Clarissa Pinkola EstÃ©sâ€™s Women Who Run With the Wolves and the recent Disney+ Marvel offering WandaVision as much as The Wizard of Oz. Del Rey is at pains to clear up something very important: â€œIâ€™m not unhinged or unhappy,â€ she sings, â€œIâ€™m still so strange and wild.â€

title: Anmedelse: Lana Del Rey - "Chemtrails Over the Country Club"
content:

ALBUM: Lana Del Reys karriereforlÃ¸p har vÃ¦rt av den smÃ¥tt utradisjonelle sorten. Hun ble allerede fÃ¸r det store gjennombruddet med Â«Born To DieÂ» kanonisert inn i offentligheten som en slags mytisk divaskikkelse som ingen helt visste hvor de hadde. Hva som var sant og hvem som gjorde hva ble etter hvert ikke sÃ¥ viktig lenger. Hennes slÃ¸rete og dovne sang med smÃ¥tt nihilistiske undertoner ble et varemerke som bredte om seg.
NÃ¥ pÃ¥ plate nummer seks er hun til en viss grad avmystifisert, uten at det har rokket nevneverdig med moduset hennes som en slags musikalsk femme fatale som kan hugge til uanmeldt. Billedlig, selvsagt, og med et slags positivt fortegn, om det gir mening? Hun er ikke blitt lystigere til sins, lyrisk sett, selv om Â«Lust for LifeÂ» for to plater tilbake kanskje ville ha deg til Ã¥ tro noe annet.
GlamorÃ¸s og skjebnetung
Â«Chemtrails Over the Country ClubÂ» er bekmÃ¸rk nattklubb-pop, glamorÃ¸s og skjebnetung om hverandre. Hvor glitrende paljetter dekker over de mÃ¸rke historiene som ligger i bunn. Instrumenteringen er sober og tilbakeholden fÃ¸r lÃ¥ta fÃ¥r bygge seg opp som et ulmende crescendo som igjen toner ut med at instrumentene skrelles bort. Sangen fremstÃ¥r som et slags postkort fra et liv i likegyldighet.
Â«Wild at HeartÂ» er romantikk og melankoli i skjÃ¸nn forening pÃ¥ en slik mÃ¥te bare Del Ray kan formidle. I hennes historier gÃ¥r nemlig sjeldent bra til slutt, selv om det stormer av fÃ¸lelser i kastene. Melodisk er den prima vare - storslagen og sakral. Â«Dance Till We DieÂ» ligger i den andre enden av det musikalske spekteret - lett jazza med tillÃ¸p til Ã¥ ta av fÃ¸r den raskt lander pÃ¥ matta igjen.
Ingen brÃ¥ bevegelser
Innimellom ytterpunktene gjÃ¸r hun det hun kan best, morderiske nidviser uten brÃ¥ bevegelser eller store kreative krumspring, men like fullt proppet med atmosfÃ¦re, lyrisk finesse og melodiske kvaliteter. I tillegg utfordrer hun det Ã¸vre vokalregisteret hakket mer enn hun har hatt for vane tidligere - det funker fint som krydder. HÃ¸r bare Â«YosemiteÂ» og Â«White DressÂ».
Alt i alt er Â«Chemtrails Over the Country ClubÂ» tre vel anvendte kvarter i selskap med en pop-stjerne som har gjort det pÃ¥ sin mÃ¥te.

title: Lana del Rey presentÃ³ â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€, su Ã¡lbum mÃ¡s personal
content:
â€œCuando era camarera, llevaba un vestido blanco, mira cÃ³mo conseguÃ­ estoâ€, canta Lana del Rey en el tema de apertura de â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€, la colecciÃ³n de canciones mÃ¡s personal de la enigmÃ¡tica artista que, por primera vez, se adentra en la AmÃ©rica profunda.
La continuaciÃ³n del aclamado â€œNorman Fucking Rockwellâ€ se estrena este viernes con un sonido parecido al de su predecesor, aunque con giros al country desde los que la autora repasa su lugar en la mÃºsica entre referencias a iconos como Joni Mitchell y Joan Baez.
â€œHe luchado mucho para ser entendida como una persona y no como una modaâ€, explicaba Del Rey en una entrevista reciente para la portada de Music Week Magazine.
Considerada una de las mejores cronistas musicales de la Ã©poca, Lizzy Grant (su nombre autÃ©ntico) ha ido narrando el devenir de Estados Unidos, su gran musa, con una iconografÃ­a repleta de referencias a la cultura popular.
Su sÃ©ptimo disco llega una dÃ©cada despuÃ©s de que â€œVideo Gamesâ€ sirviera como carta de presentaciÃ³n de una artista que recuperaba el imaginario del siglo XX (el Hollywood clÃ¡sico, Elvis Presley y la promesa del sueÃ±o americano) cuando el paÃ­s se precipitaba a una crisis de identidad que aÃºn no ha superado.
Menciones al Brooklyn de Lou Reed (â€œUltraviolenceâ€), al Art Deco y el neo-noir (â€œHoneymoonâ€), al espÃ­ritu hippie de 1968 (â€œLust for Lifeâ€) y a la decadencia actual de California (â€œNFRâ€) son las piezas con las que construyÃ³ su universo.
Ahora, lejos de ese â€œBorn To Dieâ€ (2012) citado como influencia por artistas de la talla de Taylor Swift y Bruce Springsteen, Del Rey viaja a las zonas rurales del paÃ­s para enumerar los motivos por los que rechazÃ³ la popularidad y apostÃ³ por una carrera de largo recorrido.
AsÃ­ lo expone en â€œWhite Dressâ€, un recuerdo de que con 19 aÃ±os trabajaba de camarera buscando una oportunidad en noches de micrÃ³fono abierto o en â€œconferencias de hombres de la mÃºsicaâ€. El siguiente corte, que da nombre al Ã¡lbum, celebra los momentos cotidianos, â€œlavarme el pelo, lavar la ropa / televisiÃ³n tarde en la noche, solo te quiero a tiâ€, como rechazo total a la vida de celebridad.
Ese recelo continÃºa en â€œLet Me Love You Like a Womanâ€ y â€œWild At Heartâ€, donde Del Rey confiesa que necesitaba abandonar su adorada Los Ãngeles para adentrarse en nuevos territorios.
La compositora ha recorrido ese paÃ­s que tan preocupada le dejÃ³ en su anterior disco por el cambio climÃ¡tico (â€œLos Ãngeles estÃ¡ en llamas), el populismo de Trump (â€Kanye West es rubio y se ha idoâ€) y el narcisismo de las redes sociales (â€œespero que se estÃ© retransmitiendoâ€).
Y de esta manera, las 11 canciones del Ã¡lbum estÃ¡n repletas de citas a Arkansas, Nebraska, Louisiana, el country de Texas y Tennessee, con arreglos entre el rock, el folk y el funky que envuelven la voz de una cantautora que, a bordo de su camioneta, se analiza a ella misma.
â€œLa cosa de estar en la carretera es que hay demasiado tiempo para pensarâ€, dice en â€œNot All Who Wander Are Lostâ€.
Â¿Y quÃ© piensa? Pues que no estÃ¡ tan mal, a pesar de todo. â€œHe estado haciendo versiones de Joni y bailando con Joan. Stevie me llama por telÃ©fonoâ€, razona en â€œDance Till We Dieâ€ como recordatorio de que, mÃ¡s que tener de referencia a Joni Mitchell, Joan Baez y Stevie Nicks, ahora es una mÃ¡s del grupo.
A modo de contraste, la artista cierra la colecciÃ³n con una versiÃ³n de â€œFor Freeâ€, el clÃ¡sico en el que Mitchell celebraba que solÃ­a tocar gratis antes de â€œhacerlo por fortunasâ€.
Del Rey ha contado siempre que su sueÃ±o cuando trabajaba de camarera era rodearse de un cÃ­rculo de mÃºsicos como lo hicieron Bob Dylan, Joan Baez, David Crosby y compaÃ±Ã­a en los aÃ±os 60 y 70. No lo encontrÃ³ asÃ­ que, segÃºn confiesa en â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€, tuvo que imaginarlo.

title: Review: Lana Del Rey shifts gaze in 'Chemtrails' release
content:
Decay and decadence coexist in the world created by Lana Del Rey in â€œChemtrails Over The Country Club.â€
Lana Del Rey, â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€ (Interscope Records and Polydor Records)
Decay and decadence coexist in the world created by Lana Del Rey in â€œChemtrails Over The Country Club.â€
At first listen, her intimate follow-up to critically-acclaimed â€œNorman (Expletive) Rockwellâ€ may seem less urgent. Rather than deconstructing the American myth, Del Rey shifts her gaze inward. But in the quiet, she disassembles a different pain, one felt in the unforgiving glow of the limelight.
Whispering opener â€œWhite Dressâ€ immediately sets â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€ apart from â€œNorman (Expletive) Rockwell,â€ her breathiness almost jarring.
She works with the same producer, Jack Antonoff, whose credits are also seen on Taylor Swiftâ€™s 2020 albums â€œevermoreâ€ and â€œfolklore.â€ There are echoes of Swiftâ€™s production on Del Reyâ€™s new album with songs like the gentle â€œYosemiteâ€ leaning in the folk direction.
Del Rey has perfected the art of creating album capsules. Each record emanates its own aesthetic with songs cross-referencing one another within the album. Del Rey gives cohesion to albums in a way that is unmatched by most other artists.
In â€œDance Till We Die,â€ she sings of Joni Mitchell covers before launching into her own cover of Mitchellâ€™s â€œFor Free.â€ â€œYosemite,â€ too, seems to call to her closing cover. â€œWe did it for fun/ We did it for free,â€ she croons. â€œWe did it for the right reasons.â€
Paralleling the juxtaposition in the title, Del Reyâ€™s seventh album explores the yin and yang of fame, fortune and creativity. On the surface are glittering images: jewels in a country club pool and bars that stay open â€œjust for us.â€ Ringing underneath is a melancholy emptiness perforated by isolation and desire.
Album-standout â€œDark But Just A Gameâ€ encapsulates these feelings. Del Rey paints a picture of someone who sees those who have fallen before her. â€œTheir stories all end tragically,â€ she sings, bringing to mind artists like Judy Garland and Amy Winehouse. â€œThe best ones lost their minds.â€
Other songs create the same illustration. â€œThe cameras have flashes, they cause the car crashes,â€ Del Rey sings in the Americana-tinged â€œWild At Heart,â€ referencing the catastrophic death of Princess Diana.
â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€ has all Del Reyâ€™s staples â€” angelic layered vocals, bridges that bring a second dimension to tracks and tongue-in-cheek lyrics.
Del Rey may not have reached the perfection of â€œNorman (Expletive) Rockwell,â€ but in "Chemtrails Over The Country Club,â€ sheâ€™s offered something different: vulnerability.

title: An uneven portrait of Lana Del Rey's glamorous malaise.
content:
There once was a Glamorous Person, by the name of Lana Del Rey, who only wanted to sing about dark subjects in her glamorous way, without being accused of glamorizing that darkness and thereby betraying feminism and womankind. After all, might not the luster of her appearance and the lushness of her sounds illuminate those shadow traps all the better, in conveying how desire and danger can intertwine? Setting up campâ€”and â€œcampâ€ is the wordâ€”in the Glamorous Person capital of Los Angeles, she carried the torch (song) for a rich, local cultural tradition of tracing the cityâ€™s gleam back to its rough noir sources. Like Raymond Chandler or Warren Zevon before her, the Glamorous Person intimated that beneath the beach sands lie the buried corpses and the contaminated pipes.
Advertisement
Advertisement
Advertisement
However, this Glamorous Person also carried a diamond-studded chip on her shoulder. And for good reason: When she first emerged into the limelight, she was dismissed as a foolâ€™s-gold, phony Glamorous Person who had not earned her glamour. This reaction was a sexist-tinged misreading of the entire idea of glamour, which any good sorcerer knows is a trick by definition. Granted, her sleights of hand may initially not have been undetectably smooth at every turn, but she honed them rapidly, enchanting more and more followers. With her 2019 collection of spells, Norman Fucking Rockwell!, even the most resistant subjects seemed to fall under her sway. The academy of professional magicians nominated her to its highest honors.
Advertisement
Sign up for the Slate Culture newsletter The best of movies, TV, books, music, and more, delivered to your inbox three times a week. We encountered an issue signing you up. Please try again. Please enable javascript to use form. Email address: Send me updates about Slate special offers. By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy and Terms Sign Up Thanks for signing up! You can manage your newsletter subscriptions at any time.
In that very moment of vindication, though, the Glamorous Person seemed to become mesmerized by her glittering grudges of old. First, in September 2019, she laid a curse upon a critic who made the mistake of paying her the wrong compliments, and loosed her social-media minions upon the offender like a pack of baying hounds. In the process, the Glamorous Person denied ever having had a â€œpersona,â€ which seemed not only absurd given that sheâ€™d dubbed herself with the transparently concocted Glamorous Sobriquet â€œLana Del Rey,â€ but also a betrayal of the fundamental larger-than-life-ness of glamour, which discloses its truths through the efficacy of its illusions. (She seemed to be mixing up the idea of persona with a claim of dishonesty.)
Advertisement
Advertisement
Then, last May, in defending her right to sing about sexuality and violence, she claimed critics mistreated her compared to a list of other artists, most of them women of color, as if to imply there was some kind of reverse double-standard. (This was also the message in which she dubbed herself a Glamorous Person.) Many regrettable sequels followed, in interviews and online statements, culminating in her pre-emptive Instagram defense in January of the cover of her new album, Chemtrails over the Country Club, which features the Glamorous Person in the company of many of her nearest and dearest Glamorous Friends. Seeming to fear the group would be judged tokenistic or insufficiently diverse, she resorted to a tired â€œsome-of-my-best-friendsâ€-style declaration, capping it by claiming that with her arts, she was â€œliterally changing the world â€¦ 24 seven,â€ at which itâ€™s hard not to giggle. And thatâ€™s a notorious spell breaker.
Advertisement
Following up an album as acclaimed as Norman Fucking Rockwell! is never easy to begin with, but the series of unfortunate events that Iâ€™ve just recounted really wound up the spring of potential backlash for Del Reyâ€™s new music. Perhaps partially to let that tension dissipate (or because of pandemic-fueled backups at vinyl-pressing plants), Chemtrails Over the Country Club was delayed from September until this month. (In the meanwhile, she released a book of poetry with musical accompaniment, called Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, which Iâ€™d politely call pretty decent, as far as rock-star poetry goes. I quite like the title piece.)
Advertisement
Advertisement
Though there are times itâ€™s unavoidable, I generally try not to take starsâ€™ public statements too seriously. Glamorous People are not always their own best diplomatic envoys, and some, such as their patron saint Andy Warhol, have raised studied vapidity to a kind of art form in itself. However, the critic that Del Rey attacked in 2019 was Ann Powers of NPR, a good friend of mine, and I did worry that this might affect how I heard her new music. On first listen, I found Chemtrails a disappointment relative to NFR, and there was a fugitive satisfaction in the feeling. With repeated plays, though, I came to hear it as pursuing an off-road from the expansive national-imagination portraits Del Rey and her producing partner Jack Antonoff created on that last album, even if Chemtrails remains more uneven. Itâ€™s more private and understated. In places, it pokes around behind the glamour and discloses its shortfalls, without abandoning the Glamorous Person project altogether. What it still leaves under-interrogated is glamourâ€™s implicit whiteness, as in the femme-fatale imagery Del Rey draws upon, in contrast with the jazz, blues, and R&B roots of her musical settings. Thatâ€™s standard fare in American pop, but itâ€™s more conspicuous in Del Reyâ€™s work, because history and nostalgia ride so close to the surface here, even without the recent controversies.
Chemtrails Over the Country Club is framed by its opening and closing tracks, both songs about what someone might lose in becoming glamorous; that is to say, in self-commoditization. The first, â€œWhite Dress,â€ harkens back to a 19-year-old working as a waitress on the night shift, hanging out, drinking in the new rock of the mid-2000s (the White Stripes and Kings of Leon get shoutoutsâ€”as does, for less legible reasons, Sun Ra), and getting her first taste of being â€œseenâ€ as an artist at what she amusingly calls â€œthe Men in Music Business Conference.â€ How directly autobiographical that is, I donâ€™t know, but the poignancy kicks in at the end when she sings, â€œIt made me feel/ Made me feel like a god/ Kinda makes me feel/ Like maybe I was better off.â€ The anecdote may sound thin described on the page, but the ache is in how Del Rey sings most of the song at the almost squeaking tiptop of her falsetto, as if performing as her younger self. At first, itâ€™s over a bare piano, then Antonoff brings in bass and drums that swirl like gathering clouds, until she reaches her sighing conclusion.
Advertisement
Advertisement
Advertisement
The closing song is a cover of Joni Mitchellâ€™s â€œFor Free,â€ from 1970â€™s Ladies of the Canyon, arguably the album where Mitchell began to find her mature voice. The selection is perhaps a little barbed, given that the Powers review that upset Del Rey contrasted her lyrics somewhat unfavorably with Mitchellâ€™s. But it also reinforces the sentiment of â€œWhite Dress,â€ as itâ€™s the song in which Mitchell pays tribute to a clarinetist busker who â€œplayed real good for free,â€ while she realizes that, â€œNow me, I play for fortunes/ And those velvet curtain calls/ Iâ€™ve got a black limousine/ And two gentlemen/ Escorting me to the halls.â€ Itâ€™s Mitchell observing her loss of idealism and autonomy in exchange for glamour.
Advertisement
Advertisement
Many artists cover Mitchell (Mitchellâ€™s web page lists 66 other versions of â€œFor Freeâ€ alone) and most founder on the rocks of her genius, but Del Rey blunts the possible hubris by sharing the song with two other strong singers, Zella Day and Weyes Blood. Yet they each end up doing a â€œJoni accentâ€ (and Antonoffâ€™s arrangement is reverently Mitchell-esque too), a boundary that LDRâ€™s verse manages mostly to slip. Along with the thematic resonance, the song serves as an index to the ambitions of Chemtrails as an album, shifting a few degrees away from the lyrical and musical pastiche approach of NFR toward Mitchellâ€™s famously more â€œconfessionalâ€ singer-songwriter mode.
â€œFor Freeâ€ is presaged by the penultimate track, â€œDance Till We Die,â€ which stakes Del Reyâ€™s own claim to the Laurel Canyon ladiesâ€™ lineage. Thereâ€™s a triplet of namedrops in the opening verse: â€œIâ€™m covering Joni and dancing with Joan/ Stevieâ€™s calling on the telephoneâ€â€”LDR has dueted with Stevie Nicks in the past, and this song centers on a story sheâ€™s told in interviews about going out in San Francisco with a then-septuagenarian Joan Baez â€œto this Afro-Caribbean two-step place and [dancing] all night. She fucking outlasted me.â€ For a dance-themed song, itâ€™s a little drowsy, but comes alive all of a sudden when it hits a bridge aptly set in a Bay Area, 1960s blues-band style, though thatâ€™s sadly brief.
Advertisement
Advertisement
Advertisement
Del Rey wrestles with the contradictions of fame in a few other of these songs, such as â€œWild at Heart,â€ which asks an unnamed interlocutor, â€œWhat would you do if I wouldnâ€™t sing for them no more?â€ (Itâ€™s one of a few songs here that would be better if it didnâ€™t lapse back partially into the pastiche gearâ€”the much-reiterated, David Lynch-referencing title line is dull by comparison to the rest of the lyrics.) And â€œDark But Just a Gameâ€ reflects on a Hollywood party full of people whose stories might well â€œall end tragically,â€ with a nod to Allen Ginsbergâ€™s â€œHowlâ€ in the line, â€œThe best ones lost their minds.â€ Itâ€™s set to one of Del Rey and Antonoffâ€™s best musical structures here, with an â€œAâ€ section in a typically LDR slinky-noir style, but a â€œBâ€ part that breaks out into a bright Beatles- or Elliott Smith-like texture building to her all-cancelling exclamation, â€œDonâ€™t even want whatâ€™s mine/ Much less the fame!â€
Advertisement
Advertisement
But the Joni homage also primed my ear to listen for the Blue emotional notes on the rest of the album, in songs like â€œTulsa Jesus Freak,â€ â€œYosemite,â€ and â€œNot All Who Wander Are Lost,â€ which put geographical wanderlust in tension with a grownup yearning for erotic companionship and loyalty. Del Reyâ€™s fascination by conventional gender roles persists, most wearyingly to me on â€œLet Me Love You Like a Woman,â€ which is like a 1970s Neil Diamond single melting into sticky tarâ€”but sheâ€™s in conversation with a better batch of men here than before. That doesnâ€™t devalue the realism and relevance of her many past bad-boy songs, which sheâ€™s always understood better than her critics did, but to keep growing she needs new scenarios and complications.
Advertisement
That said, maybe my favorite song on the record is one about those old archetypes, but in a new and hilarious register. Itâ€™s a crawling country waltz called â€œBreaking Up Slowly,â€ which lightly references the old Neil Sedaka chestnut â€œBreaking Up is Hard to Doâ€ but as a duet with roots country singer Nikki Lane, itâ€™s recast as a commiserating-gals anthem. Itâ€™s not subtle about its influences: â€œI donâ€™t wanna live with a life of regret,â€ Lane sings on the opening verse. â€œI donâ€™t wanna end up like Tammy Wynette.â€ Then LDRâ€™s verse offers the rejoinder: â€œGeorge got arrested out on the lawn/ We might be breaking up after this song.â€
Advertisement
Advertisement
Del Reyâ€™s comedic flair is much of what her detractors have underestimated about her. (Her apparent humorlessness in online sniping does not help.) Itâ€™s the biggest thing sheâ€™s drawn from her hip-hop influences, but no doubt also part of her attraction to Hollywood dames; Marilyn Monroe, despite her tragic end, was first and foremost a comedienne, an old-fashioned term that Del Rey at her best, gender-as-drag-role double-act deserves. The Glamorous Person is also the giddy and irreverent person, if they understand what the quick-change power of glamour is all about. But of course, being a bombshell can also set off bombshells in oneâ€™s life. Lana Del Rey has juggled these explosive signifiers throughout her career. The restraint of this album, compared to the last, can be sometimes mesmerizing and sometimes soporificâ€”the title track is much better in its video form, which features glamazons transmogrifying into were-beasts and vampires, than it is on the album.
But overall, Chemtrails opens a channel for the actor behind the antics to hint at what all her shifting faces mean, without dispelling the glamour altogether, which only a thick puritan literalist would demand. The only downside is that Del Rey herself sometimes takes on the character of that thick literalist, when she starts typing in her off time. Speaking of which, unless youâ€™re an anti-scientific conspiracy theorist, the term is actually contrails.

title: Review: Lana Del Rey Shifts Gaze in â€˜Chemtrails' Release
content:
Lana Del Rey, â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€ (Interscope Records and Polydor Records)
Decay and decadence coexist in the world created by Lana Del Rey in â€œChemtrails Over The Country Club.â€
Download our mobile app for iOS or Android to get alerts for local breaking news and weather.
At first listen, her intimate follow-up to critically-acclaimed â€œNorman (Expletive) Rockwellâ€ may seem less urgent. Rather than deconstructing the American myth, Del Rey shifts her gaze inward. But in the quiet, she disassembles a different pain, one felt in the unforgiving glow of the limelight.
Whispering opener â€œWhite Dressâ€ immediately sets â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€ apart from â€œNorman (Expletive) Rockwell,â€ her breathiness almost jarring.
She works with the same producer, Jack Antonoff, whose credits are also seen on Taylor Swiftâ€™s 2020 albums â€œevermoreâ€ and â€œfolklore.â€ There are echoes of Swiftâ€™s production on Del Reyâ€™s new album with songs like the gentle â€œYosemiteâ€ leaning in the folk direction.
Del Rey has perfected the art of creating album capsules. Each record emanates its own aesthetic with songs cross-referencing one another within the album. Del Rey gives cohesion to albums in a way that is unmatched by most other artists.
In â€œDance Till We Die,â€ she sings of Joni Mitchell covers before launching into her own cover of Mitchellâ€™s â€œFor Free.â€ â€œYosemite,â€ too, seems to call to her closing cover. â€œWe did it for fun/ We did it for free,â€ she croons. â€œWe did it for the right reasons.â€
Paralleling the juxtaposition in the title, Del Reyâ€™s seventh album explores the yin and yang of fame, fortune and creativity. On the surface are glittering images: jewels in a country club pool and bars that stay open â€œjust for us.â€ Ringing underneath is a melancholy emptiness perforated by isolation and desire.
Album-standout â€œDark But Just A Gameâ€ encapsulates these feelings. Del Rey paints a picture of someone who sees those who have fallen before her. â€œTheir stories all end tragically,â€ she sings, bringing to mind artists like Judy Garland and Amy Winehouse. â€œThe best ones lost their minds.â€
Other songs create the same illustration. â€œThe cameras have flashes, they cause the car crashes,â€ Del Rey sings in the Americana-tinged â€œWild At Heart,â€ referencing the catastrophic death of Princess Diana.
â€œChemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€ has all Del Reyâ€™s staples â€” angelic layered vocals, bridges that bring a second dimension to tracks and tongue-in-cheek lyrics.
Del Rey may not have reached the perfection of â€œNorman (Expletive) Rockwell,â€ but in "Chemtrails Over The Country Club,â€ sheâ€™s offered something different: vulnerability.

title: Lana Del Rey â€˜White Dressâ€™ Music Video: WATCH
content:
Every album cycle, Lana Del Rey picks one or two seemingly recreational activities and chooses to add sultry lyrics and Instagram filters over them. Last time, it was driving on the freeway and surfing for Norman Fucking Rockwell! On Honeymoon, it was swimming. This time, for her new album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, roller-skating was deemed worthy for the Lana treatment: Her latest music video, for â€œWhite Dress,â€ features glamour shots of masked-up models gliding and grabbing takeout. In one shot, Del Rey (or perhaps a model who looks very much like her) glides down an interstate in a white dress; in another, maybe-Lana has a broken arm and skates around a campfire in an empty room. As Vulture critic Craig Jenkins writes, â€œLana gets a little better at being Lana every year.â€ Above, watch the full music video.
Related

"Ce titre, il Ã©voque la sensation que j'ai et que les gens peuvent avoir, celle que parfois, on fait tout comme il faut, mais malgrÃ© tout Ã§a ne fonctionne pas.
