Et c'est quelque chose que j'ai beaucoup ressenti pendant le premier confinement : comment on en est arrivÃ© lÃ  ?", confie l'ancienne moitiÃ© de HER Ã  Linternaute.com.

title: The Curious Case of Lana Del Rey
content:
Lana gets a little better at being Lana every year. Chemtrails Over the Country Club is no exception. Photo: Lana Del Rey/YouTube
As her pop-star peers reinvent themselves every other year, Lana Del Rey focuses on the refinement of her songwriting, sharpening one unique musical idea over time. Where others may express growth by expanding outward, taking bigger risks by dabbling unexpectedly in different genres and mediums, Lana gets a little better at being Lana every year. In a sense, this makes her predictable. You could hazard a guess about what the new album will sound like and what the new video will look like before you ever press â€œplay.â€ Itâ€™s going to serve bleak, Nick Caveâ€“ish chamber music, just sweet enough to render the darkness enticing. Itâ€™s going to be visualized through bleary Americana that almost seems to satirize the real thing, the way the unintentional â€™60s kitsch of Valley of the Dolls is weaponized in the gauche Russ Meyer sorta-remake Beyond the Valley of the Dolls. Itâ€™s going to conjure the nightmarish underside to the American dream; itâ€™s going to show how nostalgia favors the good, how memory fails us, how weird and terrible things always are, and how to rise above it all. What made the journey from Born to Die to here an intriguing one is how Lana Del Rey has whittled uncompromising, jarringly direct music out of the often overwrought melodrama of her earliest songs, leaving a little excess behind at each turn. What remains is the moving melody and emotion that older songs like â€œNational Anthemâ€ used to drown in the thick arrangements and beats that kept her records in contention on pop charts and radio. What she has lost in hit potential, she has recouped in craft; 2019â€™s Norman Fucking Rockwell! was a staggering achievement.
The last albumâ€™s skeleton crew returns for this monthâ€™s latest, Chemtrails Over the Country Club. Again, Rockwell producer Jack Antonoff supplies delicate instrumentation and production, continuing to assist his pop collaborators in finding joy in stillness â€” as he did with Lorde on Melodrama and with Taylor Swift on the back-to-back tearjerkers folklore and evermore â€” while revealing restraint to be a more interesting aspect of his creative tool kit than the signature bluster of Bleachers, fun., and Taylorâ€™s Reputation. Rick Nowels, who co-wrote and co-produced â€œSummertime Sadness,â€ â€œHigh by the Beach,â€ â€œLust for Life,â€ and many more Lana classics, accompanies the singer once more on the sparse, skeletal â€œYosemite.â€ What sets Chemtrails apart from its predecessor is a hint of lightness, the lilt in the drums driving â€œTulsa Jesus Freak,â€ the swelling sweetness of â€œWild at Heart,â€ the burst of harmony in the chorus of â€œDark But Just a Game.â€ Rockwell was, in part, a musing on Golden State horror, haunted by serial killers, deceased rock stars, and â€œbeautiful losers,â€ where our protagonistâ€™s big dream is to escape the bustle of cities, to seek a quiet life with â€œa kid and two cats in the yardâ€ while the getting was still good. That albumâ€™s itch to escape Los Angeles bled into the writing collected last year in Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, Lanaâ€™s first book of poetry and spoken-word album. â€œEverythingâ€™s burnt here / Thereâ€™s no escaping it,â€ she laments in â€œThe Land of 1,000 Fires.â€ In â€œSportsCruiser,â€ sheâ€™s taking flying and sailing lessons to clear her head; in â€œLA Who Am I to Love You?,â€ she tries (and ultimately fails) to make San Francisco work for her instead. On Chemtrails, sheâ€™s exploring America, pining for Oklahoma and Arkansas in â€œTulsa Jesus Freakâ€ and for Nebraska in â€œNot All Who Wander Are Lost.â€ The opener, â€œWhite Dress,â€ details an eventful trip to Florida.
Chemtrails is a subtle scaling back of the already sparse sonics of Rockwell. Where the last album would build from gossamer acoustic melodies to booming beats, and swell to triumphant rock-and-roll climaxes, Chemtrails deals arrangements that still feel hushed with the volume all the way up. The gorgeous multitracked guitars in â€œNot All Who Wander Are Lostâ€ donâ€™t peek out of the mix until the songâ€™s final seconds. The sax-rock breakdown in â€œDance Till We Dieâ€ comes as a shock, like a playback of Joni Mitchellâ€™s stark Blue interrupted with a cut from the lush Court and Spark. (Lanaâ€™s â€œFor Freeâ€ is faithfully delicate, though backing vocals from Weyes Blood and Zella Day help flesh it out.) The albumâ€™s understated drums are almost always live, barring the heartbeat thump in â€œLet Me Love You Like a Woman.â€ â€œTulsa Jesus Freakâ€ plays its hip-hop beat as lightly as a Ka song would. Chemtrails ebbs and flows like post-rock elsewhere, bubbling up slowly and settling into sated silence. This makes it something of a demanding listen. Chemtrails draws you into a different speed, a distended sense of time and sound. These songs are slow but not necessarily long, bare-bones but not quite empty. Without the last albumâ€™s subtle pop flourishes, this one can feel suffocatingly dark, a tougher pill to swallow than Rockwell, though a close reading of the lyrics reveals less despairing stories than the sadness pervading these arrangements would suggest.
These characters are on the mend, changing their lives, and finding love, success, and a sense of community. When the penultimate song, â€œDance Till We Die,â€ arrives, the waitress dreaming of fame in â€œWhite Dressâ€ now calls Stevie Nicks and Joan Baez real-life friends. In â€œYosemite,â€ the most depressing-sounding thing on this album, the singer relishes feeling appreciated and understood. The breakup detailed in â€œBreaking Up Slowlyâ€ is presented as a painful necessity, a stitch in time mitigating greater future emotional distress. The title track celebrates friends and loved ones. â€œWild at Heartâ€ and â€œNot All Who Wander Are Lostâ€ come to terms with the idea that there is no singular life path appropriate for everyone, that itâ€™s okay if being who you are throws other people off. â€œIâ€™m not unhinged or unhappy,â€ Lana sings at one point in the title track, â€œIâ€™m just wild.â€ Whatâ€™s fascinating about this collection of songs is that its perspective switches unexpectedly between autobiographical and story songs. She actually did dance at an Afro-Caribbean two-step joint with Joan. The rejection of fame in â€œDark But Just a Gameâ€ seems like an understanding gleaned from being a celebrity who has caught her fair share of smoke. (Did the Men in Music Business Conference of â€œWhite Dressâ€ really happen?) In â€œBreaking Up Slowly,â€ Lana slides into the perspective of the late country icon Tammy Wynette, who was married to George Jones while the legendary singer-songwriter battled addictions that famously drove him to commandeer the lawn mower and take the highway to a bar after she hid his car keys. The slipperiness of this albumâ€™s point of view, coupled with its unique guest vocalists and closing Joni Mitchell cover, makes it feel like a monument to free, unfettered womanhood.
The steadfast resolve that has sharpened Lanaâ€™s music over time has sometimes made her unpopular off-record, though. The flap in January about how many people of color are featured on the Chemtrails Over the Country Club album art could happen only to a star whose use of classic American iconography has made people itch in the past. Her statement in response to the criticism only made it worse; telling people youâ€™ve dated rappers when your wokeness comes into question doesnâ€™t make any of this go away. Last spring, when she complained that she hadnâ€™t been afforded the same considerations as a songwriter as other stars â€œwith songs about being sexy, wearing no clothes, fucking, cheating, etc.,â€ it was perceived as a slight against her peers, and fans of BeyoncÃ©, FKA Twigs, and others named in the post took umbrage. Lanaâ€™s art is, in many respects, a wry commentary on American whiteness, and that sparks suspicion and distrust in people who donâ€™t see a distance between the singer and what sheâ€™s pushing back at in her songs. The gap between how Lana sees herself and how sheâ€™s seen by others was most profound this January when she suggested that the attack on the Capitol and the terror of the Trump years could force positive change, and some people wondered if she was secretly a supporter, while many more felt the comment was made in poor taste. Her response on Twitter to a Complex post about the incident â€” â€œItâ€™s fucked up. You know Iâ€™m realâ€ â€” was telling.
The lesson of the Capitol attack, of small-business owners revealed as insurrectionists and of horrified neighbors and exes turning in rioters to police, is that maybe nobody really knows anyone. If your aim is to do good, you must live with the fact that not everyone will read your intentions as such. Lashing out at your critics only invites more drama. If you donâ€™t give a shit, donâ€™t give a shit. Itâ€™s frustrating hearing Lana sing about the weight of fame in â€œDance Till We Dieâ€ in the face of avoidable controversy. It could be lighter for her if she adapted a bit and explained herself less. But keeping the same energy is core to the Lana Del Rey experience. The paradox remains alluring.

title: Neues Album ist Bekenntnis-Platte: Lana del Rey Ã¶ffnet ihren Panzer
content:
Das Blau des Himmels kÃ¶nnte kaum blauer sein, das Licht nicht gleiÃŸender. Ein perfektes, sonnendurchflutetes Idyll wie aus einem Cinemascopefilm. Wenn da nur nicht diese unheilvollen Zeichen wÃ¤ren. Das Stocken der Bilder, die in Flammen aufzugehen scheinen, die Kondensstreifen der Flugzeuge, die sich hoch Ã¼ber den Palmen kreuzen.
Im Video zum Titelsong ihres Albums â€Chemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€œ gleitet Lana del Rey im kirschroten Mercedes-Cabrio durch SÃ¼dkalifornien, weit zurÃ¼ckgelehnt, um sich im Fahrtwind abzukÃ¼hlen. SÃ¤uselnd singt sie zu hallenden Pianoakkorden, dass sie nicht unglÃ¼cklich sei, sondern bloÃŸ ein bisschen wild. Und sich auf der Flucht befinde, mit einem sÃ¼ÃŸen Geliebten.
Bis sich die Welt verdunkelt, ein Wirbelsturm aufzieht und das Auto mit sich fortreiÃŸt. Am Ende verwandelt sich die SÃ¤ngerin in einen zÃ¤hnefletschenden Werwolf.
Lana del Rey, mit 24 Millionen verkauften TontrÃ¤gern und unfassbaren vier Milliarden Streams einer der grÃ¶ÃŸten Popstars der Gegenwart, ist auch auf ihrem siebten Studioalbum schwer zu fassen. Den Titel kÃ¶nnte man als ironischen Schlusskommentar zum moralischen Ausverkauf Amerikas in der Trump-Ã„ra verstehen. Chemtrails, das sind die von Flugzeugen erzeugten Kondensstreifen am Himmel, mit denen die Regierung laut VerschwÃ¶rungstheoretikern die BevÃ¶lkerung zu vergiften trachtet.
Und in den Luxusdomizilen der Countryclubs bleiben die MillionÃ¤re und MilliardÃ¤re vor allem in den SÃ¼dstaaten gerne unter sich. Aber kÃ¶nnte der Song nicht auch bloÃŸ eine Postkarte aus der eigenen Vergangenheit sein, Kindheitserinnerung an trÃ¤ge Tage, die sie mit ihrer Schwester am Swimmingpool verbrachte, trÃ¤umend in die wechselnden Wolkenmuster starrend?
[Wenn Sie aktuelle Nachrichten aus Berlin, Deutschland und der Welt live auf Ihr Handy haben wollen, empfehlen wir Ihnen unsere App, die Sie hier fÃ¼r Apple- und Android-GerÃ¤te herunterladen kÃ¶nnen.]
Seit ihr 2011 mit ihrer lasziven Hymne â€Video Gamesâ€œ der Durchbruch gelang, ist Lana del Rey vorgeworfen worden, mehr Kunstprodukt als KÃ¼nstlerin zu sein. Sie wurde als â€KÃ¶nigin des TrÃ¼bsalsâ€œ und lebende MÃ¤nnerfantasie verspottet. Und seit sie sich von einem Interviewer provozieren lieÃŸ und sagte, sie fÃ¤nde Feminismus â€langweiligâ€œ und wÃ¼rde lieber Ã¼ber â€intergalaktische MÃ¶glichkeitenâ€œ sprechen, gilt sie als Anti-Feministin.
Gerade erst hat sie erneut der Behauptung widersprochen, dass ihre Lippen das Ergebnis einer SchÃ¶nheitsoperation seien. Im letzten Jahr lÃ¶ste sie einen Shitstorm aus, nachdem sie auf Instagram gefragt hatte, warum Beyonce, Cardi B und Kehlani fÃ¼r die Darstellung von SexualitÃ¤t in ihrer Musik gefeiert wÃ¼rden, man ihr aber vorwerfe, in Songs wie â€Ultraviolenceâ€œ weibliche UnterwÃ¼rfigkeit zu glorifizieren? Im Feminismus mÃ¼sse es auch â€ Platz fÃ¼r Frauen geben, die wie ich aussehen und sich wie ich verhaltenâ€œ. Rasch versuchte sie die EntrÃ¼stungswogen zu glÃ¤tten und beteuerte, ein Fan der schwarzen Kolleginnen zu sein.
Befreiung von den Vorbildern
Dass sie vergangene GrÃ¶ÃŸe schÃ¤tzt, demonstriert die SÃ¤ngerin, die vor 35 Jahren als Elizabeth Woolridge Grant in New York geboren wurde, bereits mit ihrem KÃ¼nstlernamen. Er kombiniert die Hollywooddiva Lana Turner mit einem Automodell, das lange nicht mehr produziert wird, dem Ford Del Rey.
Ihr Vintage-Pop schwelgt im Erbe von Fifties- und Sixties-Stars wie Doris Day, Bobbie Gentry oder Nancy Sinatra. Die nostalgische Farbstichigkeit ihrer Musik ist geblieben, doch von den Vorbildern hat sie sich lÃ¤ngst befreit.
Angefangen mit dem noch etwas richtungslos wirkenden Album â€Born To Dieâ€œ, das â€Video Gamesâ€œ enthielt, wurde Lana del Reys Songwriting von Platte zu Platte besser. Das letzte, 2019 erschienene Album â€Norman Fucking Rockwell!â€œ, das fein ziselierte Orchesterarrangements mit retrofuturistisch fiependen Synthesizersounds verknÃ¼pfte, war ihr Meisterwerk. Einmal gehÃ¶rt, bekommt man die fast zehnminÃ¼tige Popsymphonie â€Venice Bitchâ€œ nicht mehr aus dem Ohr.
Die Kunst der Inszenierung
AuthentizitÃ¤t von einer PopsÃ¤ngerin zu verlangen, ist ein Widerspruch in sich selbst, schlieÃŸlich liegt im Pop die Kunst gerade in der Inszenierung. Im Fall von Lana del Rey, die aus Zitaten und Huldigungen ein ganz eigenes musikalisches Universum gezimmert hat und bis heute damit beschÃ¤ftigt ist, Zuschreibungen zurÃ¼ckzuweisen, wirkt die Forderung umso absurder. Trotzdem Ã¶ffnet sie auf â€Chemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€œ (auf Polydor/Universal), das an diesem Freitag herauskommt, ihren Panzer und gibt mehr von sich preis denn je.
â€Ich musste mich stÃ¤rker nach innen wendenâ€œ, so hat Lana del Rey gegenÃ¼ber dem britischen Musikmagazin â€Mojoâ€œ ihren Ansatz beschrieben. Fast ist die Platte ein Folkalbum geworden, und von Folksongs wird erwartet, dass sie von echten GefÃ¼hlen, echtem Leben erzÃ¤hlen. Bereits das mit kargen Klavierakkorden einsetzende AuftaktstÃ¼ck â€White Dressâ€œ wirkt bekenntnishaft.
Mit wisperndem Falsett beschwÃ¶rt die SÃ¤ngerin ihre KarriereanfÃ¤nge, als sie eine weiÃŸe Kellnerinnenuniform trug, um mit Nachtschichten die Teilnahme an einer Musikkonferenz in Orlando zu finanzieren. Sie musste sich mÃ¼hsam hocharbeiten, lautet die Botschaft. Mag sein, dass sie damit auch dem Eindruck widersprechen mÃ¶chte, mit einem goldenen LÃ¶ffel geboren zu sein, weil ihre Eltern in der Finanz- und Werbebranche arbeiteten.
â€Dance Til We Dieâ€œ heiÃŸt der SchlÃ¼sselsong des Albums. â€Iâ€™m covering Joni and I'm dancing with Joan / Stevie is calling on the telephoneâ€œ, spricht sie da mehr, als dass sie singt. Eine Ahnengalerie, unterlegt mit PianotÃ¶nen, einer flirrenden E-Gitarre und einem gedÃ¤mpft einsetzenden Softrocksaxofon. Stimmt ja auch alles: Mit Fleetwood-Mac-SÃ¤ngerin Stevie Nicks hat del Rey bereits auf ihrem hippieesken Album â€Lust For Lifeâ€œ gesungen, nun covert sie Joni Mitchells Ballade â€For Freeâ€œ.
Und mit Joan Baez stand sie bei deren Abschiedstournee in Berkeley auf der BÃ¼hne. Seitdem ist die 80-jÃ¤hrige Folkveteranin voll des Lobes fÃ¼r die jÃ¼ngere Kollegin: â€Sie ist eine auÃŸergewÃ¶hnliche Frau, die ihre Karriere in die eigenen HÃ¤nde genommen hat. Und darauf kommt es an.â€œ
Lana del Rey lebt schon lÃ¤nger in Los Angeles, nun verortet sie sich auch musikalisch im Erbe der â€Ladies of the Canyonâ€œ. Gemeint ist der Laurel Canyon, die bergige Wohngegend, in dem Songwriterinnen gegenkulturelles Engagement mit introspektiven Texten verbanden. Unter den elf StÃ¼cken auf â€Chemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€œ, die Lana del Rey wieder mit ihrem Produzenten Jack Antonoff geschrieben hat, findet sich kein neues â€Venice Bitchâ€œ, aber doch einige herausragende Lieder.
Weggehen, um anzukommen
Das schÃ¶nste heiÃŸt â€Let Me Love You Like a Womanâ€œ, vielleicht eine Anspielung auf Carole Kings Klassiker â€(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Womanâ€œ. Mit schlÃ¤frig einsetzender, sich weit hochschraubender, gedoppelt in einem Chor endender Stimme zeigt sich die SÃ¤ngerin verletzlich wie begehrend: â€I donâ€™t care where I go as long as youâ€™re with me.â€œ Egal wohin, ich folge dir. Im Hintergrund wimmert eine Slide-Guitar.
Vom Aufbrechen und vom Weggehen, um anzukommen, einem alten Folk- und Country-Topos, ist Ã¼berhaupt viel die Rede. In der Akustikgitarrenballade â€Wanderlustâ€œ reimt del Rey â€Not all those who wander are lost / Itâ€™s just wanderlust.â€œ
Das StÃ¼ck ist minimalistisch instrumentiert, zwischendurch schnarrt die Produzentenstimme aus der Kontrollkabine. â€Wanderlustâ€œ, ein Lehnwort aus dem Deutschen, steht fÃ¼r Fernweh. Lana del Rey will in Bewegung bleiben. Man lÃ¤sst sich gern von ihr mitnehmen.

title: Lana Del Rey's 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club': Album Review
content:
Even in the world of stan-dom, Lana Del Rey fans can be alarmingly intense. People who are ordinarily calm and composed will suddenly get slightly wild-eyed when her name is mentioned, their voices growing breathy as if channeling her, saying, â€œOh, I love her!â€ and gushing in an almost hypnotized way that seems to carry beyond just her music. Itâ€™s not an uncommon phenomenon â€” Prince and Madonna fans, among many others, can be the same way â€” but it speaks most of all to her formidable skill at self-mythology. No matter who she actually is as a person, Lana Del Rey â€” the persona, the character, the brand â€” is quite a creation.
What does all that have to do with an album review? More than most artists, itâ€™s difficult to separate Del Reyâ€™s music from that persona (not to mention some of her distasteful social-media comments), and maybe weâ€™re not supposed to. But the disadvantage is that the mystique can overshadow the music. And thatâ€™s a shame, because Del Rey is an innovative, prolific artist â€” not to mention one of the most imaginative and hilarious lyricists working today â€” who continually challenges herself while usually knowing just how far she can push her musical boundaries. Each of her albums has a loose musical theme â€” the noir-pop of â€œBorn to Die,â€ the cinematic arrangements of â€œHoneymoon,â€ the â€˜70s SoCal vibe of â€œLust for Lifeâ€ â€” and her two most recent ones, which see her collaborating primarily with Jack Antonoff (Taylor Swift, Lorde, the Chicks, St. Vincent), have a hushed, low-key feel.
With the new â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ that low-key vibe is languid even by Lana standards. It dispenses with most of the orchestrations and lush keyboards of its predecessor, â€œNorman Fucking Rockwell,â€ and keeps the tempos slow and the arrangements much more spare, with long passages accompanied only by guitar or keyboard.
The album starts off strong, leading with the apparently autobiographical â€œWhite Dress,â€ a look back at her early years (â€œJust singing in the street/ Down at the Men in Music Business Conference/ I felt free â€™cause I was only nineteenâ€). Itâ€™s filled with references to Sun Ra, Kings of Leon and the White Stripes, as well as one of her favorite themes â€” summer, in this case seemingly connoting a farewell to youth. It also finds her pushing at the edges of her sound, with the music carrying a vaguely Van Morrison feel while she sings portions of the song at the very top of her range.
The albumâ€™s strongest songs follow â€” the title track and â€œWild at Heartâ€ may have the best melodies, â€œTulsa Jesus Freakâ€ serves up her familiar white-trash-fabulous theme â€” but at around the midway mark it starts getting even more languid, like the wine or the meds are kicking in andâ€¦ mmmâ€¦ canâ€™t we just sit here on the couch for a while longer? (To be fair, it may be the pandemic kicking in.)
However, the slow tempos donâ€™t detract from her always-vivid lyrics: â€œBreaking Up Slowly,â€ a duet with Nikki Lane, mentions tragic country legends Tammy Wynette and George Jones, although itâ€™s not very country-sounding. There are the familiar themes of California and Jesus â€” and where â€œRockwellâ€ had one â€œCandle in the Windâ€ reference, this album has two. And she flexes about some of her recent collaborations on â€œDance Til We Dieâ€: â€œIâ€™m coverinâ€™ Joni [Mitchell] and Iâ€™m dancinâ€™ with Joan [Baez] / Stevie [Nicks] is callinâ€™ on the telephone.â€
On cue, the albumâ€™s closing track is indeed a Joni cover: â€œFor Free,â€ from her generation-defining 1970 album â€œLadies of the Canyon.â€ Itâ€™s a duet with Zella Day and Weyes Blood, the latter of whom does a jaw-droppingly accurate Joni impersonation that ends the song and the album.
Del Rey has released six albums and loads of stray songs in less than nine years â€” and thatâ€™s not even including her two prior, fledgling efforts, and the spoken-word album she and Antonoff dropped last year â€” adding up to around a hundred songs. Keeping things fresh for oneself, let alone for fans, is a constant challenge for any artist, and itâ€™s one that Del Rey rises to with impressive consistency. But self-parody is always just a heartbeat away, and her tendency to work primarily with a familiar pod of collaborators can make things repetitive. â€œChemtrailsâ€ is a progression in some ways but a holding pattern in others â€” weâ€™re most interested to see where she goes next.

title: Nouvelle ode amÃ©ricaine Ã  l'amour tragique â˜…â˜…â˜…Â½
content:
Sans trop sâ€™Ã©loigner de la proposition de son opus prÃ©cÃ©dent, le remarquable Norman Fucking Rockwell !, Lana Del Rey offre avec Chemtrails Over the Country Club un septiÃ¨me album plus intimiste, moins percutant, fort dâ€™un Ã©ventail vocal et thÃ©matique (un peu) plus large.
Marissa GroguhÃ©
La Presse
Sur la piÃ¨ce dâ€™ouverture, White Dress, la voix de Del Rey est dÃ©chirante et se prÃªte magnifiquement Ã  cette chronique mÃ©lancolique des temps rÃ©volus. Elle se rappelle de l'Ã©poque oÃ¹ elle Ã©tait serveuse, de ses dÃ©buts, Â« Ã  19 ans seulement Â», tiraillÃ©e entre la fiertÃ© du chemin parcouru et la tragique nostalgie.
Let Me Love You Like a Woman, de son titre jusquâ€™Ã  chacune de ses paroles, en passant par sa mÃ©lodie que lâ€™on croirait dÃ©jÃ  entendue, est une de ces chansons qui portent la distincte estampille Lana Del Rey. Tout comme la piÃ¨ce titre et quelques autres sur Chemtrails. La Californienne ne rÃ©invente pas sa formule, loin de lÃ . Cela ne donne pas de mauvaises chansons, mais on se demande toutefois combien de piÃ¨ces comme celles-ci la reine de la mÃ©lancolie pourra encore sortir avant lâ€™Ã©cÅ“urement gÃ©nÃ©ral. Peut-Ãªtre aussi quâ€™on ne sâ€™en lassera jamais, il est vrai que personne ne parle de lâ€™amour qui fait souffrir aussi bien que Lana Del Rey.
La plume de lâ€™auteure-compositrice-interprÃ¨te (rÃ©cemment dÃ©crite par Bruce Springsteen comme une des plus belles aux Ã‰tats-Unis) a rarement Ã©tÃ© aussi acÃ©rÃ©e et constante. Del Rey sâ€™est de nouveau accompagnÃ©e de Jack Antonoff (Taylor Swift, Lorde, St. Vincent) pour lâ€™Ã©criture de la plupart des titres, un choix qui nâ€™a jamais dÃ©Ã§u qui que ce soit.
Le poids du succÃ¨s
Plus vocale que jamais, Lana Del Rey est devenue un personnage de plus en plus controversÃ© cette derniÃ¨re annÃ©e. Ses dÃ©clarations sur le racisme, sur Donald Trump et sur ses privilÃ¨ges, tout comme ses choix de masque en pleine pandÃ©mie, lâ€™ont placÃ©e dans la mire de ceux qui ne pardonnent pas les vedettes qui osent Ãªtre imparfaites.
AgacÃ©e par la constante critique (qui la suit depuis ses dÃ©buts) voulant quâ€™elle Â« glamourise lâ€™abus Â», elle a aussi dÃ©fendu ses thÃ©matiques fÃ©tiches (Â« se sentir belle en Ã©tant en amour, mÃªme si la relation nâ€™est pas parfaite Â», notamment) en se comparant maladroitement Ã  dâ€™autres musiciennes.
Lana Del Rey peut Ãªtre la proie de bien des critiques, mais elle se laisse de moins en moins faire, mÃªme si cela ne fait parfois que jeter de lâ€™huile sur le feu. Comme une rÃ©action Ã  tout cela, elle chante ici son envie dâ€™Ã©chapper Ã  cette vie sous les regards inquisiteurs. Â« Donâ€™t even want whatâ€™s mine, much less the fame Â», dit-elle sur lâ€™excellente Dark But Juste a Game, au relief envoÃ»tant. Elle se dit Â« accablÃ©e par le poids de la cÃ©lÃ©britÃ© Â» sur Dance Till We Die, magnifique ballade oÃ¹ elle rend hommage Ã  Joni Mitchell, Joan Baez et Stevie Nicks.
Lana Del Rey excelle dans les rÃ©fÃ©rences Ã  la culture et au paysage amÃ©ricains, ne se prive pas ici, encore une fois, dâ€™en imbiber tout lâ€™album. Câ€™est une conteuse exceptionnelle qui nous fait rÃªver des scÃ¨nes quâ€™elle nous dÃ©crit avec adresse.
Les amies dâ€™abord
Il est toujours autant question de romance mÃ©lodramatique et nostalgique sur Chemtrails, mais Del Rey fait cette fois une petite place Ã  lâ€™amitiÃ© Ã©galement. La pochette de lâ€™album, oÃ¹ la chanteuse se fond dans un groupe tout fÃ©minin et tout sourire, est la premiÃ¨re Ã  le suggÃ©rer : dans le Country Club de Lana Del Rey, on veut se retrouver entre femmes. Parler de ruptures et de relations compliquÃ©es, mais entre femmes.
La chanteuse country Nikki Lane prÃªte sa voix Ã  Breaking Up Slowly. Lâ€™album se conclut sur la reprise dâ€™une chanson de Joni Mitchell. Sur For Free, Del Rey invite les chanteuses Zella Day et Weyes Blood, une addition plaisante qui vient pousser un peu plus loin cette impression que cet album est fait pour et par les femmes (et Jack Antonoff).
Lana Del Rey ne fait que rarement place Ã  des collaborations. Ces invitÃ©es de choix en fin dâ€™album sont des apports judicieux, viennent donner le dernier souffle nÃ©cessaire pour complÃ©ter le 45 minutes dâ€™Ã©coute sans quâ€™on ait eu le temps dâ€™Ãªtre blasÃ©.

title: Du Lana Del Rey tout crachÃ© â˜…â˜…â˜…Â½
content:
Sans trop sâ€™Ã©loigner de la proposition de son opus prÃ©cÃ©dent, le remarquable Norman Fucking Rockwell !, Lana Del Rey offre avec Chemtrails Over the Country Club un septiÃ¨me album plus intimiste, moins percutant, fort dâ€™un Ã©ventail vocal et thÃ©matique (un peu) plus large.
Marissa GroguhÃ©
La Presse
Sur la piÃ¨ce dâ€™ouverture, White Dress, la voix de Del Rey est dÃ©chirante et se prÃªte magnifiquement Ã  cette chronique mÃ©lancolique des instants rÃ©volus. Elle se rappelle le temps oÃ¹ elle Ã©tait serveuse, ses dÃ©buts, Â« Ã  19 ans seulement Â», tiraillÃ©e entre la fiertÃ© du chemin parcouru et la tragique nostalgie.
Let Me Love You Like a Woman, de son titre jusquâ€™Ã  chacune de ses paroles, en passant par sa mÃ©lodie que lâ€™on croirait dÃ©jÃ  entendue, est une de ces chansons qui portent la distincte estampille Lana Del Rey. Tout comme la piÃ¨ce titre et quelques autres sur Chemtrails. La Californienne ne rÃ©invente pas sa formule, loin de lÃ . Cela ne donne pas de mauvaises chansons, mais on se demande toutefois combien de piÃ¨ces comme celles-ci la reine de la mÃ©lancolie pourra encore sortir avant lâ€™Ã©cÅ“urement gÃ©nÃ©ral. Peut-Ãªtre quâ€™on ne sâ€™en lassera jamais, il est vrai que personne ne parle de lâ€™amour qui fait souffrir aussi bien que Lana Del Rey.
La plume de lâ€™auteure-compositrice-interprÃ¨te (rÃ©cemment dÃ©crite par Bruce Springsteen comme une des plus belles aux Ã‰tats-Unis) a rarement Ã©tÃ© aussi acÃ©rÃ©e et constante. Del Rey sâ€™est de nouveau accompagnÃ©e de Jack Antonoff (Taylor Swift, Lorde, St. Vincent) pour lâ€™Ã©criture de la plupart des titres, un choix qui nâ€™a jamais dÃ©Ã§u qui que ce soit.
Le poids du succÃ¨s
Plus vocale que jamais, Lana Del Rey est devenue un personnage de plus en plus controversÃ© cette derniÃ¨re annÃ©e. Ses dÃ©clarations sur le racisme, sur Donald Trump et sur ses privilÃ¨ges, tout comme ses choix de masque en pleine pandÃ©mie, lâ€™ont placÃ©e dans la mire de ceux qui ne pardonnent pas les vedettes qui osent Ãªtre imparfaites.
AgacÃ©e par la constante critique (qui la suit depuis ses dÃ©buts) voulant quâ€™elle Â« glamourise lâ€™abus Â», elle a aussi dÃ©fendu ses thÃ©matiques fÃ©tiches (Â« se sentir belle en Ã©tant en amour, mÃªme si la relation nâ€™est pas parfaite Â», notamment) en se comparant maladroitement Ã  dâ€™autres musiciennes.
Lana Del Rey peut Ãªtre la proie de bien des critiques, mais elle se laisse de moins en moins faire, mÃªme si cela ne fait parfois quâ€™ajouter de lâ€™huile sur le feu. Comme une rÃ©action Ã  tout cela, elle chante ici son envie dâ€™Ã©chapper Ã  cette vie sous les regards inquisiteurs. Â« Donâ€™t even want whatâ€™s mine, much less the fame Â», dit-elle sur lâ€™excellente Dark But Juste a Game, au relief envoÃ»tant. Elle se dit Â« accablÃ©e par le poids de la cÃ©lÃ©britÃ© Â» sur Dance Till We Die, magnifique ballade oÃ¹ elle rend hommage Ã  Joni Mitchell, Joan Baez et Stevie Nicks.
Lana Del Rey excelle dans les rÃ©fÃ©rences Ã  la culture et au paysage amÃ©ricains, ne se prive pas ici, encore une fois, dâ€™en imbiber tout lâ€™album. Câ€™est une conteuse exceptionnelle qui nous fait rÃªver des scÃ¨nes quâ€™elle nous dÃ©crit avec adresse.
Les amies dâ€™abord
Il est toujours autant question de romance mÃ©lodramatique et nostalgique sur Chemtrails, mais Del Rey fait cette fois une petite place Ã  lâ€™amitiÃ© Ã©galement. La pochette de lâ€™album, oÃ¹ la chanteuse se fond dans un groupe tout fÃ©minin et tout sourire, est la premiÃ¨re Ã  le suggÃ©rer : dans le Country Club de Lana Del Rey, on veut se retrouver entre femmes. Parler de ruptures et de relations compliquÃ©es, mais entre femmes.
La chanteuse country Nikki Lane prÃªte sa voix Ã  Breaking Up Slowly. Lâ€™album se conclut sur la reprise dâ€™une chanson de Joni Mitchell. Sur For Free, Del Rey invite les chanteuses Zella Day et Weyes Blood, une addition plaisante qui vient pousser un peu plus loin cette impression que cet album est fait pour et par les femmes (et Jack Antonoff).
Lana Del Rey ne fait que rarement place Ã  des collaborations. Ces invitÃ©es de choix en fin dâ€™album sont des apports judicieux, viennent donner le dernier souffle nÃ©cessaire pour complÃ©ter le 45 minutes dâ€™Ã©coute sans quâ€™on ait eu le temps dâ€™Ãªtre blasÃ©.

title: Lana Del Ray: â€Chemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€œ
content:
Auf dem neuen Album der KÃ¼nstlerin geht es wieder vor allem um sie selbst. Aber warum das zu einem Problem machen?
Von Joachim Hentschel
Vor knapp zwei Wochen stellte der Film-Stuntman Hunter Ray Barker im Nordwesten von Los Angeles ein blaues Kinderplanschbecken vor dem "Los Toros" auf, seinem Lieblings-Mexikaner. FÃ¼llte es mit Kidneybohnen, lieÃŸ sich fÃ¼r 24 Stunden in der Pampe nieder, um Spenden fÃ¼r das coronagefÃ¤hrdete Restaurant zu sammeln. Und bekam nachmittags glamourÃ¶sen Besuch. Die SÃ¤ngerin und Songwriterin Lana Del Rey schaute vorbei, im roten Kapuzenpullover. Sprach ihre SolidaritÃ¤t aus und postete das Foto fÃ¼r ihre mehr als 18 Millionen Instagram-Fans. Unter das heitere Bild schrieb sie: "Don't ask why." Fragt nicht nach dem Grund.
Abgesehen davon, dass sich Lana Del Rey in der Ã–ffentlichkeit sonst von Bohnenzubereitungen aller Art weitgehend fernhÃ¤lt, ist der Nukleus der Geste ganz typisch fÃ¼r sie. Nehmt das Bild, so schÃ¤big es ist, scheint sie hier zu sagen. Nehmt es fÃ¼r seine Aura, seine amerikanische Momentaufnahmenhaftigkeit, aber fragt nicht, was es bedeuten soll. Was ja selbst dann die falsche PrimÃ¤rreaktion wÃ¤re, wenn man bei Julia Stoschek vor einem Monitor mit abgefahrenen Drohnenvideos steht und Ã¼berlegt, ob es hier irgendetwas zu kapieren gibt.
Die SZ-Redaktion hat diesen Artikel mit einem Inhalt von Youtube angereichert Um Ihre Daten zu schÃ¼tzen, wurde er nicht ohne Ihre Zustimmung geladen. Inhalt jetzt laden Ich bin damit einverstanden, dass mir Inhalte von Youtube angezeigt werden. Damit werden personenbezogene Daten an den Betreiber des Portals zur Nutzungsanalyse Ã¼bermittelt. Mehr Informationen und eine WiderrufsmÃ¶glichkeit finden Sie unter sz.de/datenschutz. Dieser externe Inhalt wurde automatisch geladen, weil Sie dem zugestimmt haben. Zustimmung widerrufen und Seite neu laden
Dennoch handle Lana Del Rey am Ende immer nur von sich selbst, sagen ihre Kritiker
Lana Del Rey ist allerdings Entertainerin, schreibt Songs mit viel Text, hat gewaltige Erfolge. Und ihre Pop-Inszenierungen als frÃ¼he Joan Didion und noch frÃ¼here Lauren Bacall sind derart spektakulÃ¤r und cineastisch, dass man kaum drum herumkommt, in ihnen auch immer die Geschichten zu suchen. Den erzÃ¤hlerischen Drive, den man eigentlich erwarten dÃ¼rfen sollte, wenn jemand im kirschroten Mercedes-500-K-Cabrio durchs Video fÃ¤hrt.
Dennoch handle Lana Del Rey am Ende immer nur von sich selbst, sagen ihre Kritiker. Von sich und den alten, wasserdicht nostalgischen, vermeintlich entpolitisierten Bildern, die sie herunterblÃ¤ttere wie in einem stinklangweiligen Vintage-Style-Account auf Pinterest. Dass das freilich eine Frage des Blickwinkels ist, dass Del Rey wohl nie eine Chance hat, als groÃŸe GegenwartskÃ¼nstlerin anerkannt zu werden, solange die Leute immer schon an ihrem Lipgloss abglitschen, ist eine andere Sache.
Detailansicht Ã¶ffnen
Auf "Chemtrails Over The Country Club", ihrem neuen, siebten Studioalbum, singt Lana Del Rey Ã¼brigens in der Tat vor allem von sich selbst. Es ist ihre Hybris-Platte, ihr "Ich knabbere schwer an meinem Ruhm"-Liederzyklus, ihr Abschiedsbrief an die HÃ¤schenphase der Karriere. Wie autobiografisch das im Einzelnen gemeint sein kÃ¶nnte, ist - wie beim neuen Christian-Kracht-Roman - die mit Abstand Ã¶deste Frage, die man ans Kunstwerk stellen kann. Als mittelgroÃŸe, bereits spÃ¤tsommerliche Inszenierung funktioniert "Chemtrails Over The Country Club" jedenfalls so luftabschnÃ¼rend gut, dass man Del Rey sowieso jedes Wort glauben will, das sie ins starke, digital hochaufgelÃ¶st Laurel-Canyon-2021-Echo hineinwispert.
Dass diese Musik durch und durch weiÃŸ ist, ist ja alles andere als verwerflich
Und ja, es wird viel gewispert auf dem "Chemtrails"-Album. Allerdings schon im ersten Song "White Dress" auf so Ã¼beraus unbescheidene, vorlaute Art, dass Lana Del Rey die Stimme buchstÃ¤blich Ã¼berschnappt. Hier erzÃ¤hlt sie, begleitet von einer kleinen Nightclub-Combo, Ã¼ber die BerufsanfÃ¤nge als Kellnerin, die es ins Musikbusiness verschlÃ¤gt und sich dort derart in die Ereignisse verheddert, dass die Zeilen des Songs vor lauter Silben fast zu platzen drohen. 40 Minuten spÃ¤ter, gegen Ende der Platte, wird sie in "Dance Till We Die" am dramaturgischen Scheitelpunkt ankommen, an dem nur noch die Flucht aus dem Alltag des Ruhms mÃ¶glich scheint. Sie tanzt mit Joan Baez, telefoniert mit Stevie Nicks. Covert mit den SÃ¤ngerinnen Zella Day und Weyes Blood, superfrech und superschlÃ¼ssig, das StÃ¼ck "For Free", in dem Joni Mitchell 1970 Ã¼ber entfremdete Arbeit im Kulturgewerbe klagte. Die Musik ist durchweg sparsam, man hÃ¶rt die Fingerkuppen auf den Saiten, die leise knackenden Schlagzeuger-Gelenke. Beziehungsweise das, was die Felsen der Santa Monica Mountains davon zurÃ¼ckhallen lassen.
Zuletzt hat Lana Del Rey versucht, sich in die Diversity-Diskurse einzuschalten, hier doch noch Punkte zu holen, die ihr als ultraweiÃŸer Retro-Style-Ikone bislang verwehrt blieben. Es ging desastrÃ¶s nach hinten los - was allein deshalb schade ist, weil sie "Chemtrails Over The Country Club" auch fÃ¼r sich allein hÃ¤tte sprechen lassen kÃ¶nnen, als, siehe oben, wirklich starke Sisterhood-Platte. Dass diese Musik durch und durch weiÃŸ ist, wie das Kleid der Kellnerin, die Leinwand vor dem Filmstart oder eben die verdammten Kondensstreifen, ist ja alles andere als verwerflich. Solange sie so beweglich, anschlussfÃ¤hig und nachhaltig atemberaubend ist, wie viele es der KÃ¼nstlerin eh nie zugestehen werden.

title: Un nouvel album Ã  la pop envoÃ»tante pour Lana Del Rey
content:
Depuis le triomphe de Â« Born to Die Â» en 2012, les albums de Lana Del Rey sont dÃ©sormais trÃ¨s attendus dans le monde de la musique. Ce vendredi, la collection de lâ€™auteur-compositrice-interprÃ¨te new-yorkaise sâ€™enrichit dâ€™un septiÃ¨me joyau, Â« Chemtrails Over the Country Club Â». Des Â« traÃ®nÃ©es chimiques Â» dans le ciel qui lui ont inspirÃ© onze morceaux Ã  la pop sophistiquÃ©e, quasi Ã©thÃ©rÃ©e, oÃ¹ la superficialitÃ© des choses nâ€™est quâ€™un prÃ©texte Ã  une exploration plus profonde (et plus mÃ©lancolique) de lâ€™Ã¢me humaine.
Une recette qui, en tout cas, sÃ©duit un large public et aussi la critique. En 2019, Â« Norman Fucking Rockwell Â», son sixiÃ¨me album sacrÃ© aux Grammy Awards, sâ€™Ã©tait Ã©coulÃ© Ã  plus de 800 000 exemplaires Ã  travers le monde, portant son total personnel Ã  20 millions de disques vendus.
Ã€ lire sur le sujet Les albums les plus attendus de 2021
Influences folk et fÃ©minines
Dans le suivant, entrecoupÃ© dâ€™un recueil de poÃ©sie en 2020 (Â« Violet Bent Backwards Over The Grass Â») on retrouve Jack Antonoff Ã  la production, gage dâ€™une continuitÃ© artistique bien identifiÃ©e. MalgrÃ© la crise sanitaire et la rarÃ©faction dâ€™Ã©vÃ©nements rÃ©els pour fait connaÃ®tre ses nouveaux titres, Lana Del Rey semble promis Ã  un nouveau succÃ¨s planÃ©taire, tout en affirmant ses influences folk et fÃ©minines (Joan Baez, Joni Mitchell, Stevie Nicks) sans renier un cÃ´tÃ© esthÃ©tique qui se vÃ©rifie dans les clips de ses chansons.
Que de chemin parcouru pour Lizzie Grant (son nom dâ€™origine) en une dÃ©cennie. Ã€ 35 ans, par son travail Ã  la fois exigeant et fÃ©dÃ©rateur, elle sâ€™impose comme une figure incontournable de la scÃ¨ne musicale internationale.
Â« Chemtrails Over the Country Club Â», Lana Del Rey, Polydor/Universal. Disponible sur les principales plateformes musicales.

title: Lana Del Rey se arrisca em novo disco, mas faz falta algum tempero
content:
SÃ£o Paulo
Lana Del Rey abre de maneira surpreendente seu novo disco. A cantora deixa de lado sua tradicional voz ingÃªnua e doce, como se fosse uma menina de 15 anos do interior prestes a debutar, e sussurra.
NÃ£o se trata, contudo, de um cochicho discreto ao pÃ© do ouvido â€”Ã© um canto no limite da respiraÃ§Ã£o, seguro de si e que atravessa diversos matizes no decorrer da primeira faixa, a excelente â€œWhite Dressâ€, para nos contar a histÃ³ria de uma jovem garÃ§onete que trabalha no turno da noite usando um vestido branco e justo.
A mÃºsica Ã© tambÃ©m a melhor de â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€, o sÃ©timo disco â€”sem contar o Ã¡lbum de poesia falada lanÃ§ado em 2020â€” da cantora e compositora americana. SÃ£o cinco minutos de um total de 50 em que ela mais se arrisca.
A cantora Lana Del Rey, que lanÃ§a o disco 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club' - Neil Krug
A performance inicial projeta uma sombra pelas dez faixas seguintes do disco, de forma a fazer o ouvinte procurar por mais do mesmo. Contudo, boa parte de â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€ traz a tradicional lamÃºria entre o monÃ³tono e o sensual da artista, que a tornou admirada ou detestada por uma geraÃ§Ã£o de adultos hoje se encaminhando para a meia idade.
â€œChemtrailsâ€, por exemplo, soa como uma continuaÃ§Ã£o do disco anterior, o indicado ao Grammy â€œNorman Fucking Rockwellâ€ â€“um pop barroco, de ar kitsch e trÃ¡gico a um sÃ³ tempo, habitado pelo clichÃª da mulher Ã  moda antiga, que se veste com luvas de renda e colar de pÃ©rolas e viaja num conversÃ­vel pelo interior dos Estados Unidos, passando por motÃ©is de beira de estrada.
Desde seu primeiro trabalho, em 2012, Del Rey recriou o apelo imagÃ©tico da "road trip" pelos Estados Unidos, e ainda Ã© esse universo que ela habita no disco novo, com ajuda da sonoridade do produtor Jack Antonoff, responsÃ¡vel pela maior parte dos instrumentos.
A fÃ³rmula da dupla, contudo, se repete no miolo do disco, tornando as faixas bastante uniformes entre si, o que pode ser encarado como a assinatura da artista ou como falta de tempero. De todo modo, Antonoff â€”conhecido por seu trabalho com as divas do pop Lorde e Taylor Swfitâ€”, parece extrair a versatilidade possÃ­vel da voz de Del Rey, sem usar efeitos em demasia para a ofuscar.
Outro bom momento do disco Ã© â€œDark But Just a Gameâ€, em que a voz da cantora lembra de passagem Beth Gibbons, do Portishead, e o instrumental tambÃ©m remete ao clima relaxado e viajante do grupo de Bristol. â€œEnquanto o mundo todo estÃ¡ louco/ nÃ³s estamos nos chapando no estacionamento/ Enquanto o mundo todo estÃ¡ louco/ estamos nos beijando no estacionamentoâ€, canta ela.
Na faixa final, os vocais da convidada Weyes Blood quase ofuscam os de Del Rey na bela cover de â€œFor Freeâ€, da icÃ´nica cantora de folk Joni Mitchell, injetando um sopro final num Ã¡lbum com diversas canÃ§Ãµes parecidas. O disco termina com o mesmo assombro do comeÃ§o.

title: Lana Del Rey: Chemtrails Over the Country Club review - A low-key masterpiece
content:
Album:
Chemtrails Over the Country Club Artist:
Lana Del Rey Label:
Interscope Genre:
Pop
For Lana Del Rey a frock can contain multitudes. On Summertime Sadness, from her debut album, Born to Die, a red dress was a passport to freedom, an escape hatch out of the dreariness of reality. The scarlet gown was back on 2014â€™s Cruel World, from Ultraviolence, deployed once again as a metaphor for slipping off the shackles and entering a pop fantasia of her own devising.
A dress also features in her new record â€“ but this time the colour has changed, along with the context. â€œWhen I was a waitress,â€ sings Del Rey in an exhaling coo, â€œwearing a white dress . . .â€
White Dress is one of the most diaristic belters Del Rey has yet written, and it is telling that it is the song with which she chooses to open her seventh long play (LP). Authenticity â€“ if it matters, whether pop stars should covet or run from it â€“ is a subject Del Rey has been required to engage with through her career. And it is the topic she grapples with head-on here, deploying her choice of clothing as a metaphor for the innocence and yearning of her prestardom days.
Sadness, in and out of season, is the recurring theme. White Dress sees Del Rey harking back to her years as a striving artist, paying the bills by working as a waitress
With her first hit, Video Games, in 2011, the popular line on Del Rey was that she was David Lynchâ€™s fever dream brought to life. But the idea that she was selling an artificial version of herself â€“ that the artist, born Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, was â€œplayingâ€ the role of Lana â€“ chafed from the outset with the singer.
She did not always parse the criticism appropriately, it is true. Whether lashing out at journalists â€“ punching down is always a bad look for musicians â€“ or writing stream-of-consciousness Instagram posts evoking BeyoncÃ©, Nicki Minaj and Cardi B (which drew claims of racism), Del Rey sometimes seemed to have a shaky and slightly desperate grip on her own narrative.
But she is winningly assured on Chemtrails Over the Country Club, a project in dialogue with fame, hate and the confusing state of â€œBeing Lanaâ€. That may make it feel like an exercise in navel-gazing â€“ and to a degree it is. Yet itâ€™s also a low-key masterpiece, less performatively incandescent than 2019â€™s Norman F**king Rockwell! but, in its own somnolent way, no less irresistible.
Del Reyâ€™s songwriting has always leaned into minor-key ennui. And that is again the case here as she reunites with the Lorde, Taylor Swift and St Vincent collaborator Jack Antonoff and with Rick Nowels, formerly of New Radicals and a co-writer with Del Rey of Summertime Sadness.
Sadness, in and out of season, is the recurring theme. The aforementioned White Dress sees Del Rey harking back to her years as a striving artist, paying the bills by working as a waitress and staking her future on a music conference in Orlando. â€œI wasnâ€™t famous,â€ Del Rey coos. â€œKinda makes me feel/ Like maybe I was better off.â€
Chemtrails demands complete buy-in from the listener. Itâ€™s self-serious, the pacing never rising beyond creakingly woozy
Elegiac and unfolding in their own good time, the songs that follow live up to Del Reyâ€™s billing of Chemtrails as a â€œcountry folkâ€ album. This, though, is a rhapsody with a lot of blue in its soul: the title track, for instance, finds the artist awash in jewellery, hanging out with the 1 per cent even as she discerns, just over the horizon, an oncoming darkness (â€œMe and my sister just playinâ€™ it cool/ Under the chemtrails over the country clubâ€).
As with all of her work, Chemtrails demands complete buy-in from the listener. Itâ€™s self-serious, the pacing never rising beyond creakingly woozy. And some of the choices donâ€™t quite land. She duels grippingly with the country star Nikki Lane on Breaking Up Slowly.
But on Not All Who Wander Are Lost, Del Rey pinches the chorus from a line of poetry in JRR Tolkienâ€™s Lord of the Rings. (Hereâ€™s hoping the next Dua Lipa record is inspired by David Eddingsâ€™s The Belgariad.)
Yet these are ultimately quirks rather than quibbles and donâ€™t detract from the masterfulness of Del Reyâ€™s vision. Now, more than ever, she stands tall as popâ€™s most singular talent.

title: Lana Del Rey se arrisca em novo disco, mas faz falta algum tempero
content:
Lana Del Rey se arrisca em novo disco, mas faz falta algum tempero
Cantora americana sussurra e inova seu pop barroco em 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club'
Lana Del Rey abre de maneira surpreendente seu novo disco. A cantora deixa de lado sua tradicional voz ingÃªnua e doce, como se fosse uma menina de 15 anos do interior prestes a debutar, e sussurra.
NÃ£o se trata, contudo, de um cochicho discreto ao pÃ© do ouvido -um canto no limite da respiraÃ§Ã£o, seguro de si e que atravessa diversos matizes no decorrer da primeira faixa, a excelente "White Dress", para nos contar a histÃ³ria de uma jovem garÃ§onete que trabalha no turno da noite usando um vestido branco e justo.
A mÃºsica Ã© tambÃ©m a melhor de "Chemtrails Over the Country Club", o sÃ©timo disco -sem contar o Ã¡lbum de poesia falada lanÃ§ado em 2020- da cantora e compositora americana. SÃ£o cinco minutos de um total de 50 em que ela mais se arrisca.
A performance inicial projeta uma sombra pelas dez faixas seguintes do disco, de forma a fazer o ouvinte procurar por mais do mesmo. Contudo, boa parte de "Chemtrails Over the Country Club" traz a tradicional lamÃºria entre o monÃ³tono e o sensual da artista, que a tornou admirada ou detestada por uma geraÃ§Ã£o de adultos hoje se encaminhando para a meia idade.
"Chemtrails", por exemplo, soa como uma continuaÃ§Ã£o do disco anterior, o indicado ao Grammy "Norman Fucking Rockwell" -um pop barroco, de ar kitsch e trÃ¡gico a um sÃ³ tempo, habitado pelo clichÃª da mulher Ã  moda antiga, que se veste com luvas de renda e colar de pÃ©rolas e viaja num conversÃ­vel pelo interior dos Estados Unidos, passando por motÃ©is de beira de estrada.
Desde seu primeiro trabalho, em 2012, Del Rey recriou o apelo imagÃ©tico da "road trip" pelos Estados Unidos, e ainda Ã© esse universo que ela habita no disco novo, com ajuda da sonoridade do produtor Jack Antonoff, responsÃ¡vel pela maior parte dos instrumentos.
A fÃ³rmula da dupla, contudo, se repete no miolo do disco, tornando as faixas bastante uniformes entre si, o que pode ser encarado como a assinatura da artista ou como falta de tempero. De todo modo, Antonoff â€“conhecido por seu trabalho com as divas do pop Lorde e Taylor Swfitâ€“, parece extrair a versatilidade possÃ­vel da voz de Del Rey, sem usar efeitos em demasia para a ofuscar.
Outro bom momento do disco Ã© "Dark But Just a Game", em que a voz da cantora lembra de passagem Beth Gibbons, do Portishead, e o instrumental tambÃ©m remete ao clima relaxado e viajante do grupo de Bristol. "Enquanto o mundo todo estÃ¡ louco/ nÃ³s estamos nos chapando no estacionamento/ Enquanto o mundo todo estÃ¡ louco/ estamos nos beijando no estacionamento", canta ela.
Na faixa final, os vocais da convidada Weyes Blood quase ofuscam os de Del Rey na bela cover de "For Free", da icÃ´nica cantora de folk Joni Mitchell, injetando um sopro final num Ã¡lbum com diversas canÃ§Ãµes parecidas. O disco termina com o mesmo assombro do comeÃ§o.

title: Lana Del Rey - Chemtrails Over the Country Club review: Lanaâ€™s world is a lovely place to visit
content:
Review at a glance
P erhaps the person in charge of money acquisition at Lana Del Reyâ€™s record label has looked at her chart statistics and concluded that she ought to do more collaborations with Ariana Grande and Miley Cyrus. Their 2019 team-up, Donâ€™t Call Me Angel from the Charlieâ€™s Angels soundtrack, was her first proper hit single since a dance remix of her song Summertime Sadness in 2013.
The New Yorker has toyed with big-selling duet partners elsewhere, singing with The Weeknd and rapper ASAP Rocky on her 2017 album Lust for Life, but now her idea of a profitable union is very different. Sheâ€™s pictured on the cover of her seventh album with 10 of her real-life friends. She has always looked and sounded like someone who could ruin your life in a Raymond Chandler novel, and today her fastidious aesthetic seems less connected than ever to the whizzy preoccupations of the livestreaming, TikTok-ing pop world. Her last release was a spoken word recording of her poetry. She opens Dance Til We Die with the lines: â€œIâ€™m covering Joni and Iâ€™m dancing with Joan/Stevieâ€™s calling on the telephone.â€ Thatâ€™s Mitchell, Baez and Wonder to you.
The guest stars here are three less well-known female singer-songwriters: outlaw country singer Nikki Lane gets top billing on Breaking Up Slowly, while Zella Day and Weyes Blood join in on the aforementioned Joni cover. Itâ€™s a languid, sincere version of For Free, from the Ladies of the Canyon album.
Del Rey sounds like multiple ladies herself. She experiments in various ways with that vampish voice, adding a delicate sheen of Auto-Tune at the end of Tulsa Jesus Freak and forming a whole chorus of herself on Wild at Heart â€“ a rare bit of â€œbigâ€ music. She sounds distant and crackly on part of Yosemite, as though singing into a Jazz Age microphone. Strangest of all is White Dress, the opener, which she has said was mostly ad-libbed while co-writer and producer Jack Antonoff noodled at the piano. She sings about listening to The White Stripes and Kings of Leon, sounding harsh and breathless as she tries to cram the unlikely words â€œMiami Music Business Conferenceâ€ into one short line.
A lot of this album sounds improvised, loosely held together, and more introverted than its grand, dazzling predecessor, Norman F***ing Rockwell! Like its creator, itâ€™s off in a world of its own, free of commercial obligations and revelling in that autonomy. Itâ€™s a lovely place to visit.

title: Chemtrails Over the Country Club
content:
On the morning of January 11th, as she ate a popsicle for breakfast with a newly broken arm, Lana Del Rey tumbled into nearly 40 somersaulting minutes of free-associative responses to questions from BBC Radio 1 presenter Annie Mac. On live radio, the pop star parkoured from thoughts on Trumpâ€™s presidency to going to the farmerâ€™s market barefoot to how sheâ€™d characterize at least half of her friends as jerks. Finally, her frisson found a foothold in the psychology behind the insurrection at the U.S. Capitol that had taken place six days earlier. Partway through clarifying how she felt Trumpâ€™s â€œsociopathyâ€ may have unintentionally inspired the deadly siege, she cleared her throat to show her conviction. â€œI actually think this is the most important thing Iâ€™ll say in this interview,â€ she underscored. â€œFor people who stormed the Capitol, itâ€™s dissociated rage. They want to wild out somewhere! Itâ€™s like, we donâ€™t know how to find the ways to be wild in our worldâ€¦.and at the same time, the world is so wild.â€
In or out of context, this is an entirely fair analysis. With rare exception, the strange tradition of having celebrities act like talking heads on matters of national politics or domestic terrorism is both a largely pointless and joyless spectacle. But Lanaâ€™s monologue about the neuroses plaguing the United States was genuinely fascinatingâ€”for two reasons.
The first is that, for the past decade, Lana has been an exceptional hunter-gatherer of white American arcana. In 2011, she emerged as an aesthetic howitzer, exploding a broad but deeply personal index of iconography into her own nation of death-driven kitsch. It was Xanadu, built from a blissful, degenerate, high-femme sort of jingoism. Geographiesâ€”the Hollywood sign, the tri-state, California writ largeâ€”became mythological playgrounds for her to languor around and smoke Parliaments on. Marilyn Monroe, men in training yards, cherry pies, a Pleasantville middle-class, Coachella, violence-as-romance and romance-as-violence: she offered us a canon of heritage markers recast in â€™10s-era drama and became the rare sort of talent that was able to congeal past and present into seductively conceptual cinema. With time and refinement, Lana Del Rey had mushroomed into what we called the next best American songwriterâ€”emphasis on American.
The second reason was more obvious. The original purpose of the BBC interview was to promote her newly released single titled â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ and the album that shares its name. Whether meant to be tongue-in-cheek, a joke, or not one at all, the titleâ€™s flawless alignment with the mood and mien of that momentâ€”the conspiracy-mindedness, the radiant gloom, the fragility, and the suggestion of the type of person associated with the words â€œcountry clubâ€â€”was an act of poetry. It was remarkable to hear the bard of white American malaise suggest which delusion was gripping the nation.
Two months later, Miss Americaâ€™s latest text has emerged, and Chemtrails Over the Country Club is definitely both wild and incredibly American, the twin tenets of her empire. In 2017, Lana told Pitchfork that the American flag was no longer going to be a part of her live performances for fear of indicating national pride during the Trump era, but there was still one billowing on the cover of 2019â€™s Norman Fucking Rockwell!, and there may as well be one on the front of Chemtrails as well. (There actually is a flag hidden on the back.) She canâ€™t help it: No muse speaks louder to Lana than the promised land, where cities are metaphors, its dead are its gods, and she, its glamorous Orpheus.
Like most labeled among the â€œgreatestâ€ of their realm, Lana Del Rey is focused on conquest. Here I mean that literally, in terms of acreage: Where her previous albums were rooted mostly on the coasts, her sixth record reaches prominently toward the center of the nation, warmed by the yeasty heat of the heartland. She goes to Arkansas and Nebraska and Oklahoma, narrates life as a waitress, lauds Jesus erotically, and affects a little twang. It is her most rangy albumâ€”her folksiest, her singer-songwriter-iestâ€”and takes us physically further and deeper into her crystal vision of the country. If Norman Fucking Rockwell! was broadly interpreted as her â€œobituary for America,â€ this one might be her purest paean to it.
Depending on your mileage with her mythos, there are a few different entry points into Chemtrails. Likely because this is an album with a jumble of at least a few former-outtakes and entirely new cuts, Chemtrails is generous inasmuch as each song seems to work like a point on a timeline, correlating toward a version of Lana from periods past or present. Despite how often her body of work seems to loop back on itself into one slowly-growing MÃ¶bius of intertextâ€”Bob Dylan lyrics, Elton John lyrics, countless mentions of California, jewels, the price of fame, roses, thornsâ€”placing these tracks along her continuum is rewarding.
For those who found solace in Norman Fucking Rockwellâ€™s sincerityâ€”that quality that made her less of a fabulist and more of a protagonistâ€”â€œWild at Heartâ€ represents the Lana myth at its most hard-boiled. The song begins on Sunset Boulevard. The melody is as if â€œHow to Disappearâ€ and â€œLove Songâ€â€”two of NFRâ€™s most plaintive balladsâ€”were put into a blender. The references are Lynchian, but only at a slant: There is nothing of Laura Dern and Nicolas Cageâ€™s skull-crushing vim from the auteurâ€™s movie by the same name, but the soapy storyline does smack of the filmâ€™s strangely glib tenderness. There is a lot of cigarette smoking, peripatetic wandering, and firm declarations of being seductively fucked-up. â€œIf you love me, you love me,â€ she assures, â€œbecause Iâ€™m wild at heart.â€ Welcome back to Lanaland.
What Proust did for scent, Lana does for American spaces. She wanders through cities, breathes in the air just to get a sense of it, then drifts on. She travels east from L.A. to â€œYosemite.â€ The opener â€œWhite Dressâ€ introduces some adult alternative radio digestibility into the sound, a little bit of Jewel in the sparse drumming and the uniquely squeezed, head-voice heroics that weâ€™ve not heard from her before. But sheâ€™s in Orlando then, a city of transience, sticky heat, and languishing in her desire to be anywhere else. Texas is buried inside â€œBreaking Up Slowly,â€ a torchy piece sung in an outlaw tenor. It calls upon the dissolution of the greatest twosome known to countryâ€”Tammy Wynette and George Jonesâ€”as a thematic fulcrum, but what she does more plainly in her duet with Nikki Lane is suggest countryâ€™s token lawlessnessâ€”the freedom of not knowing what to do or where to go next.
Her reverence for Wynette makes a lot of sense. Lana kept one of Wynetteâ€™s albums in the studio with her as she recorded her album (â€œI always have Tammy with me,â€ she said), likely as both spiritual and lyrical guidance. Itâ€™s almost too on-the-nose: Wynetteâ€™s biggest hit, â€œStand By Your Man,â€ is a ballad that celebrates a particularly outmoded strain of womanly steadfastness in the face of difficult loveâ€”a sorrowful get-it-together mantra that seems more like a rationalization than a reminder. Lanaâ€™s â€œLet Me Love You Like a Womanâ€ is its psychic twinâ€”not country in sound but in aura, a tribute to the now-taboo thrills of traditional submission.
It should be less surprising that there is so much God in this. For someone with so much worship for the nation under it, her relationship to God has been complicated. (â€œMe and God we donâ€™t get along,â€ she sang in â€œGods and Monsters.â€). But Lana has done a lot of reckoning with higher powers as of late: â€œIt made me feel like a God,â€ goes the moonglow refrain of â€œWhite Dress;â€ thereâ€™s a lot of â€œcontemplating Godâ€ in â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ and â€œTulsa Jesus Freakâ€ is a full-on ultra-glam evangelical spectacle, lifted to heaven on the prosthetic wings of AutoTune.
The holiest spirit here, however, is her own. When she goes full Lana and gives in to her proclivity for near-embarrassing, entirely seductive, overwrought American beauty, it sounds divine. â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€ is a ballad drawn directly from the Lana Del Rey vein, all honey sun, moneyed smiles, the pleasure of living lavishly. The video shows Lana in a diamantÃ© mesh mask, looking a little like Hedy Lamarr in low fidelity, glancing sweetly from the driverâ€™s seat of a mid-century Mercedes-Benz Cabriolet. Chemtrails dart overhead in crosshatch as Lana stares up with widened eyes. Whether or not she actually believes in covert geoengineering is entirely irrelevant: itâ€™s the idea behind them sheâ€™s in love with. Like so many who find themselves alienated and disillusioned, she erects dreamworlds to inhabit, writes narratives that provide substance to a life that threatens to spiral without them. â€œIâ€™m not unhinged or unhappy,â€ she declares. â€œIâ€™m just wild.â€
Her reassurances come with reasonâ€”few artists in recent memory have summoned more concern. Recall how intensely critics offered outsized meditations on the authenticity of her persona when she emerged in 2011 with Born to Dieâ€”they just didnâ€™t believe what they saw. Her image as a volatile WASP cosplaying as a bourgeois-boheme obsessed with American kitschâ€”reviews practically demanded an apology for her image, or at least some crumb of irony, to match our cynicism. Who was more detached, us or her? Morally or aesthetically, it felt unrealâ€”so she doubled-down, showing us how real and earnest she was. After Norman Fucking Rockwell, pop culture took her more seriously. And so she wrote a manifesto about her womanhood, which proposed a few clumsily-worded questions and asked for space and credit among choice women of color. She later tried to assure usâ€”with some belligerenceâ€”that she has given people of color plenty of room at her table. Small infernos ensued.
These are not isolated wildfires. Lana has been chronically drawn to the combustible. Thematically, lyrically, and in reality, her voice has always been incendiary. The groundswell after the BBC interviewâ€”the post-interview, welly-eyed â€œfuck youâ€ directed at media magazines and her detractorsâ€”I can think of no artist of her caliber who has drawn a more direct line between the self-abnegation of her pop persona and the person before us. There is no rule in place here, but when the artistâ€™s being starts eclipsing their art, it becomes, for better or worse, part of their art too.
Lana the artist and Lana the woman have been extraordinarily compelling as of late. Not because itâ€™s in any way satisfying to see such a singular talent gesture so blatantly toward her own fragility and fearâ€”off her albums, at leastâ€”but because she consistently manages to reflect back a very particular portrait of the country she holds so close. Chemtrailsâ€™ vision may be roaming, but the artistâ€™s remains impressively narrow. To paraphrase Lana, it is definitely difficult to articulate oneâ€™s wildness, especially for those so inherently wild at heart. What is lucid, though, is that Lana Del Reyâ€™s inheritance has always been truly Americanâ€”and everything weâ€™ve seen in recent memory confirms how disarmingly, specifically American sheâ€™s become.
Buy: Rough Trade
(Pitchfork earns a commission from purchases made through affiliate links on our site.)
