title: Justin Bieber Tops Album Chart, Finally Knocking Off Morgan Wallen
content:
For Justin Bieber, itâ€™s â€œLonelyâ€ at the top, or at least the album that contains that recent hit song bowing at No. 1. â€œJusticeâ€ debuted on top of the Rolling Stone album chart â€” the first time in 11 weeks that the No. 1 position hasnâ€™t belonged to wayward country star Morgan Wallen and his until-now indomitable â€œDangerous: The Double Album.â€
Bieber also took command of the song chart, with the fourth single to be released from the new album, â€œPeaches,â€ debuting at No. 1.
Wallen had two spots to fall this week, as Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€ slipped in ahead of him at No 2, too.
Given the consistency of Wallenâ€™s January release, though, it would not be surprising to see it move back up to the top in weeks to come and go for setting some non-consecutive-week records.
â€œJusticeâ€ bowed with 146,000 album units. Song streams for Bieberâ€™s album added up to a strong 138.4 million. Full-copy album sales were OK, at 29,300. Interest in buying the individual songs as downloads was strong, with 40,600 track sales.
Del Reyâ€™s â€œChemtrailsâ€ had a good enough debut that it would have toppled Wallen, too, in any other recent week. Its album units figure in its first week out was 98,000. Where Del Rey really excelled was in full album sales; the album sold 53,000 copies, more than double what Bieberâ€™s album did in sales. But fans were so eager to buy the whole album that individual track sales were minimal, at 4,000. Song streams for the album weighed in at 19.6 million.
Pushed down to third place, Wallenâ€™s album clocked in with 62,600 album units. Its actual sales are on the wane, with seemingly everyone who wants to buy it having done so; album sales for the week were just 3,200 and song sales landed at 9,300. But in the streaming realm, â€œDangerousâ€ continues to be just a monster, racking up 73.6 million this week â€” more than three times the streams of the overall No. 2, Del Rey.
Rounding out the album top 10 were Pop Smoke at No. 4 followed by the Weeknd, Dua Lipa, Lil Durk, Taylor Swift (â€œFolkloreâ€), Pooh Shiesty and Lil Baby.
On the Rolling Stone songs chart, â€œPeaches,â€ a good-timey Bieber track featuring Daniel Caesar and Giveon, premiered at No. 1 with 26.8 million song streams. The only other debuting song among the top 10 was also a new Bieber track, â€œAs I Am,â€ featuring Khalid, in at No. 10 with 12.7 million song streams. Bieber actually has three songs in the upper ranks, though, as a previously released holdover, â€œHold On,â€ sits at No. 6.
Cardi Bâ€™s former chart-topper â€œUpâ€ landed at No. 2 for the week with 16.9 million streams.
Moving up: â€œLeave the Door Openâ€ by Silk Sonic, aka Bruno Mars and Anderson .Paak, shoving the door wide open at No. 3 with 14.6 million streams in its third week.
Olivia Rodrigoâ€™s â€œDrivers Licenseâ€ is finally starting to show its age, getting edged out of the top 10 for the first time since it debuted three months ago to land at No. 11.
Other tunes in the top 10 include two by Drake at Nos. 4-5, followed by Dua Lipaâ€™s â€œLevitatingâ€ at No. 7, Masked Wolf at No. 8 and Lil Tjay and 6LACK at No. 9.
See the entire songs chart here. For the album chart, click here.

title: Lana Del Rey Debuts at No. 1 on Top Album Sales Chart
content:
Plus: Justin Bieber, Loretta Lynn, Jon Batiste, Paul Stanley and Benny the Butcher & Harry Fraud bow in top 10.
Lana Del Rey rules Billboardâ€™s Top Album Sales chart, as her new studio album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, debuts at No. 1 on the list dated April 3. Itâ€™s her third chart-topper on the list, following 2017â€™s Lust for Life and 2014â€™s Ultraviolence.
Chemtrails was released March 19 via Polydor/Interscope and starts with 58,000 copies sold in the U.S. in the week ending March 25, according to MRC Data. With Chemtrailsâ€™ arrival, Lana Del Rey scores the third-largest sales week for an album released in 2021, and the largest sales week for an album released by a female artist this year. Only the debut frames of Morgan Wallenâ€™s Dangerous: The Double Album (74,000) and Foo Fightersâ€™ Medicine at Midnight (64,000) were larger.
Billboardâ€™s Top Album Sales chart ranks the top-selling albums of the week based only on traditional album sales. The chartâ€™s history dates back to May 25, 1991, the first week Billboard began tabulating charts with electronically monitored piece count information from SoundScan, now MRC Data. Pure album sales were the measurement solely utilized by the Billboard 200 albums chart through the list dated Dec. 6, 2014, after which that chart switched to a methodology that blends album sales with track equivalent album units and streaming equivalent album units. The new April 3-dated Top Album Sales chart (where Chemtrails debuts to No. 1) will be posted in full on Billboard's website on March 30. For all chart news, follow @billboard and @billboardcharts on both Twitter and Instagram.

title: Lana Del Rey Earns Fifth U.K. No. 1 With â€˜Chemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€™
content:
Lana Del Rey flies high on the U.K. albums chart with Chemtrails Over The Country Club (Polydor), which gives the U.S. singer her fifth No. 1.
Chemtrails bows at the summit with 40,000 chart sales, according to the OCC, a sum that includes a whopping 16,700 sales on vinyl. Thatâ€™s enough to give Del Rey the fastest-selling vinyl of the century for a female act.
With her latest No. 1 on the Official U.K. Albums Chart, Del Rey ties Celine Dion for the fifth most No. 1 albums by a female solo artist in the U.K. Only Madonna, Kylie Minogue, Barbra Streisand and Taylor Swift have landed more.

title: Lana Del Rey lanÃ§a novo Ã¡lbum impressionante
content:
Lana Del Rey (Foto: Neil Krug)
Onde algumas superestrelas se reinventam a cada era, Lana Del Rey prefere refinar seu som e expandir silenciosamente sua personalidade enigmÃ¡tica e infinitamente fascinante.
Co-produzido por Jack Antonoff, que tambÃ©m trabalhou com o cantor de 35 anos em Norman Fucking Rockwell! de 2019, Chemtrails Over the Country Club Ã© outro exercÃ­cio de precisÃ£o e moderaÃ§Ã£o. Os momentos mais fortes do Ã¡lbum - como um quase rap espetado em Dance Till We Die - parecem fragmentos de luz perfurando as Ã¡rvores em uma agradÃ¡vel tarde de verÃ£o. Mas isso nÃ£o significa que o sÃ©timo Ã¡lbum de estÃºdio de Del Rey seja simplesmente â€œmais do mesmoâ€.
Capa do Ã¡lbum Chemtrails Over The Country Club (Foto: DivulgaÃ§Ã£o)
Aqui estÃ£o sete maneiras pelas quais Chemtrails Over The Country Club de Lana Del Rey enriquece seu jÃ¡ formidÃ¡vel legado musical.
1. Del Rey continua a construir seu prÃ³prio mito
Um fÃ£ hardcore de Del Rey provavelmente poderia escrever uma tese apenas na faixa de abertura White Dress. Aqui, ela relembra seus dias despreocupados prÃ©-fama como uma garÃ§onete que se sentia "vista" por seu homem. Enquanto ela confere o nome das bandas de rock Kings of Leon e The White Stripes - e algo chamado "Men in Music Business Conference" - Del Rey cria um clima Ã­ntimo e melancÃ³lico que ela mantÃ©m pelos prÃ³ximos 45 minutos ao longo do Ã¡lbum. A linha final da mÃºsica Ã© especialmente reveladora e apresenta um dos temas recorrentes do Chemtrails Over The Country Club: quando Del Rey canta, "meio que me faz sentir que talvez eu estivesse melhor", ela parece estar sugerindo que a fama tambÃ©m nÃ£o esteve gratificante para ela.
2. Ela definitivamente tem fama em mente
Del Rey nos diz exatamente o que ela pensa da fama em Dark But Just a Game quando canta, "estÃ¡ escuro, mas Ã© apenas um jogo - entÃ£o toque como uma sinfonia". Wild at Heart - uma canÃ§Ã£o que divide o tÃ­tulo com um filme de David Lynch de 1990, um toque muito Del Rey - realmente se inclina para a sombra. Quando ela canta "as cÃ¢meras tÃªm flashes, elas causam os acidentes de carro", Ã© difÃ­cil nÃ£o imaginar a falecida princesa Diana, um Ã­cone cujo nome Del Rey conferiu em seu poema Patent Leather Do-Over.
3. Encontra novos giros no ritmo normal e lÃ¢nguido de Del Rey
Agora, os fÃ£s dela sabem que nÃ£o devem esperar cortes agitados - para isso, vocÃª precisarÃ¡ revisitar os remixes de 2013 prontos para clubes de Cedric Gervais de Summertime Sadness e Young & Beautiful. Como todos os Ã¡lbuns desde Ultraviolence de 2014, Chemtrails Over The Country Club Ã© uma peÃ§a de humor, mas isso nÃ£o significa que falte luz e sombra. Breaking Up Slowly Ã© uma balada com salpicos country, Dance Till We Die apresenta algumas trompas jazzÃ­sticas e Wild At Heart tem vocais overdubbed impressionantes que farÃ£o seus braÃ§os se arrepiarem.
Consistentemente melÃ³dico e meticulosamente produzido, este Ã© um Ã¡lbum que revela floreios sutis e detalhes ocultos a cada toque.
Lana no clipe Chemtrails Over The Country Club (Foto: Cortesia )
4. Ela nos lembra que ela ainda Ã© uma romÃ¢ntica incurÃ¡vel
NÃ£o seria um Ã¡lbum de Lana Del Rey sem pelo menos um interesse amoroso nÃ£o confiÃ¡vel, mas sedutor. Ele aparece em Not All Who Wander Are Lost, puxando cadeiras e abrindo portas para Del Rey como um verdadeiro cavalheiro. Isso nÃ£o significa, no entanto, que ela se sinta totalmente convencida por ele. "O que acontece com homens como vocÃª Ã© que vocÃª tem muito a dizer", ela canta, "mas vocÃª vai ficar?"
5. Ela tambÃ©m nos lembra que Ã© uma das grandes compositoras americanas
â€œEu venho de uma cidade pequena, e vocÃª? SÃ³ menciono isso porque estou pronto para deixar LAâ€, Del Rey canta em Let Me Love You Like a Woman. Nessa mÃºsica, ela estÃ¡ presa entre as luzes brilhantes do sonho americano e suas raÃ­zes mais discretas. Embora ela tenha nascido em Manhattan, sua famÃ­lia mudou-se para Lake Placid, uma pequena cidade no interior do estado de Nova York, quando ela tinha um ano.
Em outro lugar, Tulsa Jesus Freak combina sexo e religiÃ£o de uma forma que lembra o CinturÃ£o BÃ­blico conservador dos Estados Unidos. "DevÃ­amos voltar para o Arkansas", canta Del Rey, "trocar este corpo por aquela lata de gim."
Cena do clipe Chemtrails Over The Country Club (Foto: Cortesia )
6. As letras sÃ£o salpicadas de referÃªncias nostÃ¡lgicas da cultura pop
Tulsa Jesus Freak e Yosemite pegaram emprestadas as imagens da Candle in the Wind de Elton John, enquanto Del Rey pisca para Prince em Let Me Love You Like a Woman, quando canta: "Podemos nos perder na chuva roxa." Mais tarde, a cantora country Nikki Lane colabora no adorÃ¡vel Breaking Up Slowly e entrega este dÃ­stico nÃ­tido: "NÃ£o quero viver uma vida de arrependimento / NÃ£o quero terminar como Tammy Wynette."
7. E termina com uma capa de Joni Mitchell
Depois de cantar na penÃºltima faixa Dance Till We Die que ela estÃ¡ "fazendo um cover de Joni", Del Rey faz exatamente isso, recrutando os cantores indie Weyes Blood e Zella Day para uma interpretaÃ§Ã£o sincera da faixa de 1970 de Joni Mitchell For Free. Ã‰ fÃ¡cil ver como hÃ¡ um destaque do Ã¡lbum Ladies Of The Canyon, que pode ressoar com Del Rey. Ã‰ uma mÃºsica na qual Mitchell pondera a diferenÃ§a entre ela mesma - uma estrela cantando suas canÃ§Ãµes "para fortunas" e "chamadas de cortina de veludo" - e uma humilde musicista de rua que ela vÃª tocando "muito bem" por nenhum dinheiro.
NÃ£o pela primeira vez neste Ã¡lbum, Del Rey parece estar se perguntando se ela estava â€œmelhorâ€ antes de se tornar famosa.
Chemtrails Over The Country Club de Lana Del Rey jÃ¡ estÃ¡ disponÃ­vel nas plataformas digitais

title: Lana Del Rey: Albumtitel schon geplant

Ich habe auch einen alternativen Titel, den ich mag, der 18 Monate meines Lebens zusammenfasst.â€œ FÃ¼r welchen sie sich entscheiden wird, werden die Fans aber wohl noch nicht sofort erfahren.
Die 35-JÃ¤hrige hat auch erklÃ¤rt, dass sie sich nicht darauf konzentriere, riesige â€šHitâ€˜-Singles zu schreiben, sondern interessante Projekte schaffen wolle. Sie fÃ¼gte hinzu: â€Es ist nicht so, dass ich keinen Hit haben will. Es ist nur so, dass meine Reise, ohne es direkt zu planen, eher zu einem langfristigen Spiel geworden ist.â€œ

title: Lana Del Rey feels nostalgic for 2004 in the stunning 'White Dress'
content:
A stark but beautiful reflection on what was a much simpler time for the artist
Every day we highlight great new music added to the Double J playlist.
New to Double J? Here's how you can tune in, no matter where you are.
Lana Del Rey's new album Chemtrails Over The Country Club opens with 'White Dress', a gentle piano ballad that see the singer reflect on a simpler world. A world where she was a 19-year-old waitress obsessed with The White Stripes and Kings Of Leon.
Skip YouTube Video FireFox NVDA users - To access the following content, press 'M' to enter the iFrame.
Of course, it's not as breezy as all that might make it sound. There's a conflict here, as Lana considers whether she left behind a better life when she pursued the dream of stardom.
"What I like about that song is that for all of its weirdness, when you get to the end of it, you understand exactly what itâ€™s about," she told collaborator Jack Antonoff in Interview Magazine last year.
"I hate when I hear a song that has a great melody, but I have no idea what theyâ€™re talking about."
Fame can be a burden. Fame like Del Rey's, which has been complex since the very start and isn't getting any simpler, must feel particularly encumbering.
For all the justified criticism she gets for some of her public comments, this song proves she is able to express herself in song pretty incredibly.
Also, the vocal hook in the chorus is simply stunning.
Chemtrails Over The Country Club is out now.
Check out Double J's Best New Music playlists on Spotify and Apple Music for more great new tunes.

title: Noah Cyrus Signs With TaP Music for Management
content:
"We have been fans from afar for a long time," Millet tells Billboard. "We were finally introduced, had an initial meeting over Zoom and then when Wendy and Mookie met Noah in person it all clicked and moved fast."
Adds Cyrus: "Immediately upon meeting Mookie and Wendy, I knew TaP would be my new home. Iâ€™m thrilled to be joining a roster with such strong female artists who are empowered to achieve massive success on their own terms.â€
Earlier this month, Cyrus, 21, attended the Grammys as a best new artist nominee. Last year, she released her well-received, more stripped-down EP, The End of Everything, on RECORDS/Columbia. She's currently working on a six-track project with collaborator PJ Harding as well as her upcoming debut full-length.

title: Lana Del Reyâ€™s 10-Year War With the Culture
content:
2020 was a treacherous year for celebrities online, who had to navigate a complex set of unwritten rules about the proper tone to strike on social media that bedeviled even the savviest among them. So of course Del Rey wasted no time stepping in it. In May, she announced her new album with an Instagram post: â€œNow that Doja Cat, Ariana [Grande], Camila [Cabello], Cardi B, Kehlani, Nicki Minaj, and BeyoncÃ© have had number ones with songs about being sexy, wearing no clothes, fucking, cheating, etc. â€” can I please go back to singing about being embodied, feeling beautiful by being in love even if the relationship is not perfect, or dancing for money â€¦ without being crucified or saying that Iâ€™m glamorizing abuse? â€¦ Iâ€™m not not a feminist, but there has to be a place in feminism for women who look and act like me.â€ The other artistsâ€™ fans united against her, pointing out that sheâ€™d mostly targeted women of color. Del Reyâ€™s own fans pleaded for her to delete the post. A more calculating star might have known it was time to go away for a while. But it was 2020 â€” who was capable of logging off? Instead, she dug in her heels. â€œThe fact that they want to turn â€¦ my advocacy for fragility into a race war â€” itâ€™s really bad,â€ she said in a follow-up video. Her timing was impeccable: That same week, the Amy Cooper scandal turned white womenâ€™s â€œfragilityâ€ into a punch line.
Photo: Lana Del Rey/Instagram An Instagram message to her fans.
Del Rey tried to get back on the right side of history, but once again she was playing with imagery whose meaning had slipped out of her grasp. When she Instagrammed L.A. protests against police brutality, she drew criticism for posting videos of looting. When she did a book signing wearing a mesh mask, she was accused of putting lives at risk. (She claimed it had protective plastic underneath.) Eventually she entered a state of twitchy paranoia familiar to listeners of Taylor Swiftâ€™s Reputation. After posting the art for her upcoming album, Del Rey appended a defense against accusations of tokenism that had yet to be made: â€œAs it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover, yes, there are people of color on this recordâ€™s picture.â€ She added, â€œMy best friends are rappers, my boyfriends have been rappers.â€
She was not entirely wrong to be so anxious. The following day, Del Rey proposed to an interviewer that Trump was so addled before the January 6 insurrection that â€œhe doesnâ€™t know that heâ€™s inciting a riotâ€ â€” and was immediately accused of downplaying the violence. Unhappy with the way her comments were circulated online, she personally responded to seemingly every single tweet about it, taking particular umbrage with Complex. â€œItâ€™s fucked up. You know Iâ€™m real,â€ she tweeted at the website, whose audience has primarily been people of color. Shortly after Chemtrailsâ€™ release in March, she sarcastically reposted a months-old Harperâ€™s Bazaar think piece: â€œJust want to say thank you again for the kind articles like this one and for reminding me that my career was built on cultural appropriation and glamorizing domestic abuse.â€ Then she announced she would soon be releasing yet another album: Rock Candy Sweet, out June 1.
Thus, the negative feedback loop rolls on. Every stilted and tone-deaf public statement brings less charity from the blogosphere, which only makes her skin even thinner. There are two ways the relationship can go from here: If the albums hold up, Del Reyâ€™s artistry could push away the memory of a few bad posts. If itâ€™s not, we all may be better served muting her for a while.

title: Le romantisme Ã©purÃ© de la chanteuse Lana Del Rey
content:
La chanteuse Lana Del Rey, en juillet 2020, Ã  Los Angeles. NEIL KRUG
LÃ¨vres rouges pulpeuses en Ã©vidence, faux cils et eye-liner pour la touche gothique, gilet Ã  carreaux grunge et attelle Ã  la main gauche pour le soupÃ§on de dÃ©rision, Lana Del Rey pose en Â« une Â» du nouveau numÃ©ro du magazine britannique Mojo. Un nouveau gage de crÃ©dibilitÃ© pour la diva pop californienne de 35 ans, ce mensuel rock Ã©tant plutÃ´t habituÃ© aux couvertures posthumes sur Bowie, Cohen et Lennon ou des lÃ©gendes vivantes sexagÃ©naires. Dans lâ€™entretien, le seul accordÃ© Ã  la presse, la chanteuse confie que les nombreuses interviews donnÃ©es lors des quatre premiÃ¨res annÃ©es de sa cÃ©lÃ©britÃ© lâ€™ont littÃ©ralement Â« cramÃ©e Â».
Il faut dire que la critique, divisÃ©e, nâ€™a pas toujours Ã©tÃ© tendre avec Elizabeth Woolridge Grant (son vrai nom Ã  lâ€™Ã©tat civil) depuis le raz-de-marÃ©e provoquÃ© par son tube Video Games en 2012. Lana Del Rey affirme dans Mojo sâ€™Ãªtre souvent sentie humiliÃ©e par des questions lourdes de sous-entendus hautains, lorsque les journalistes la soupÃ§onnaient dâ€™Ãªtre une starlette fabriquÃ©e par les maisons de disques â€“ ce qui est faux.
Lire le portrait (en septembre 2019) : Le rÃªve amÃ©ricain selon Lana Del Rey
Sept albums plus tard, elle a prouvÃ© que son talent nâ€™Ã©tait pas Ã©phÃ©mÃ¨re. DisciplinÃ©e crÃ©ativement, discrÃ¨te sur sa vie privÃ©e, Lana Del Rey enregistre des albums Ã  cadence annuelle, une prolificitÃ© qui lui permet de sâ€™autoriser quelques Ã©carts artistiques sans trop de consÃ©quences. AprÃ¨s un passage Ã  vide entre 2015 et 2018, son sixiÃ¨me opus, Norman Fucking Rockwell (2019) a Ã©tÃ© encensÃ© et aurÃ©olÃ© du Grammy du meilleur album. Depuis a Ã©tÃ© a publiÃ©, en septembre 2020, un disque Ã  part, Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, recueil de ses poÃ©sies mis en musique. Un privilÃ¨ge rare dans un environnement mainstream dominÃ© par les musiques urbaines.
Compositions dÃ©pouillÃ©es
Chemtrails Over the Country Club, septiÃ¨me album, prolonge cette phase crÃ©ative sans souffler sur les braises du succÃ¨s du prÃ©cÃ©dent. Les onze chansons ont Ã©tÃ© produites et coÃ©crites avec Jack Antonoff, dÃ©couvert par Taylor Swift et partenaire de jeu depuis Norman Fucking Rockwell. En quarante minutes, le disque est le plus court de Lana Del Rey, volontÃ© dâ€™Ã©lagage que lâ€™on retrouve dans des compositions relativement dÃ©pouillÃ©es. Â« Nous avons retirÃ© des choses, encore et encore, jusquâ€™Ã  trouver lâ€™essence de Chemtrails Over the Country Club Â», a commentÃ© Jack Antonoff sur Instagram. Lâ€™enregistrement a Ã©tÃ© trÃ¨s spontanÃ© lors de sessions confinÃ©es au studio new-yorkais Electric Lady : Â« Des prises principalement en direct, alors que les choses venaient juste dâ€™Ãªtre Ã©crites. Des chansons comme White Dress et Not All Who Wander Are Lost reflÃ¨tent ces premiers moments oÃ¹ mots et musique prennent ensemble subitement forme. Â»

title: Lana Del Rey no conduce coches elÃ©ctricos
content:
Nadie ejemplifica mejor que Lana Del Rey la escisiÃ³n vivida en el seno de la generaciÃ³n millennial en el Ãºltimo par de aÃ±os. Analizada hasta el Ãºltimo detalle en infinidad de artÃ­culos, ensayos y tuits, se convirtiÃ³ tal vez en la generaciÃ³n mÃ¡s monitorizada de la historia. Obviamente, como ese control era ejercido mayormente por miembros de generaciones anteriores, se convirtieron tambiÃ©n en la menos comprensible. Pero los analistas, y tambiÃ©n ese segmento de la poblaciÃ³n que transita por la vida con complejo de audiencia, se cansaron de ellos.
Dedicaron todas sus energÃ­as a los que venÃ­an detrÃ¡s. Una parte de los millennials se erigieron en portavoces de la generaciÃ³n Z, al menos, en los medios â€”prensa, Twitter, Instagramâ€” en los que estos no tenÃ­an presencia ni ganas de tenerla. Otra se aferrÃ³ a la nostalgia prematura, aquello que decÃ­an los expertos que los definÃ­a. Lana Del Rey es de estos Ãºltimos. Como buena millennial, pasÃ³ casi una dÃ©cada siendo observada, puesta en duda, elevada a la categorÃ­a de Ãºnica y sin precedentes y tambiÃ©n a la de redundante, egocÃ©ntrica y algo pedante. Hasta 2019, cuando lanzÃ³ Norman Fucking Rockwell!, cada triunfo de la estadounidense cargaba la misma cantidad de Ã©xito que de fracaso. Aquel disco lo cambiÃ³ todo. Porque era espectacular, pero tambiÃ©n porque lo que ella significaba â€”en tanto a ella misma y en tanto a su generaciÃ³nâ€” ya importaba menos. Dos aÃ±os despuÃ©s, aparece Chemtrails Over The Country Club, un Ã¡lbum que Lana Del Rey anunciÃ³ prÃ¡cticamente el mismo dÃ­a que lanzÃ³ el anterior. ParecÃ­a que quisiera aprovechar que entonces prensa y pÃºblico parecÃ­an alineados con lo que ella proponÃ­a y no tanto ya con lo que ellos proponÃ­an para ella. Pero ese disco se hizo tan grande y tan influyente que la californiana dejÃ³ de tener prisa. Por eso tal vez este Ã¡lbum caminÃ³ tan despacio.
Chemtrails Over The Country Club mantiene algunas de las constantes de Norman Fucking Rockwell!, pero es mucho mÃ¡s tÃ­mido, una caracterÃ­stica que jamÃ¡s creÃ­amos que podrÃ­amos asociar a su autora. El disco arranca con la estupenda â€˜White Dressâ€™, que narra su experiencia como camarera en una convenciÃ³n de la industria del disco. No puede evitar recordar lo fÃ¡cil que era todo cuando simplemente podÃ­as ir por la vida escuchando a The White Stripes. El tema es una maravilla nerviosa en la que las palabras se caen unas encima de las otras, mientras ella trata de ordenarlas con pavorosa tranquilidad. Es tremendamente gratificante escuchar cÃ³mo el corte se embarulla. Algo similar sucede en â€˜Dark but Just a Gameâ€™, tal vez la canciÃ³n mÃ¡s cercana a Norman Fucking Rockwell!, en la que se juega mÃ¡s.
El resto del disco apuesta por una aproximaciÃ³n mÃ¡s de perfil bajo. Hay que buscar mÃ¡s los detalles que en las anteriores entregas. Cuando los encuentras, eso sÃ­, son tremendamente bellos. Desde la cadencia perfectamente armada del tema titular hasta esa batalla entre ella y Jack Antonoff que es â€˜Tulsa Jesus Freakâ€™, pasando por la forma en que la pareja de artista y productor parecen reparar a medio camino en que â€˜Wild at Heartâ€™ es un corte que ya han grabado y empiezan a retorcerlo hasta convertirlo en algo soberbio y hasta novedoso, o la versiÃ³n del â€˜For Freeâ€™ de Joni Mitchell que, con la colaboraciÃ³n de Weyes Blood y Zella Day, cierra el disco y que sirve para desenmascarar todos los trucos del Ã¡lbum y hasta de la toda la carrera de la californiana. Como Lana Del Rey es una prestidigitadora sin pudor, desenmarscararla le sienta mejor a ella que a quien cree desenmascararla.
Portada de 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club', de Lana Del Rey. AP
Toda la iconografÃ­a asociada a la estadounidense ha tenido siempre mucho que ver con una idea de EE UU que ya casi no existe y que apenas ella parece echar de menos. Su visiÃ³n tiene cero sintonÃ­a con los tiempos que corren, porque sus ciudades no son cosmopolitas y liberales o convulsas y apocalÃ­pticas, sino bellas, trÃ¡gicas y ensimismadas. Sus personajes pertenecen a cierto concepto de Ã©lite blanca que ya no se celebra ni en las revistas de moda y sus inquietudes producen imÃ¡genes preciosas que nada tienen que ver con casi nada que pueda sucederle a nadie. Un coche descapotable es un coche que te pueden robar, no uno en el que lo peor que te puede pasar es que te despeines.
En ese universo que ha creado, a pesar de ser un mundo que tiene los dÃ­as contados, Lana del Rey estÃ¡ cÃ³moda porque sabe gestionar la melancolÃ­a como nadie, aportando una pizca de rencor y otra de humor. Sus personajes no toman cÃ³cteles de narcÃ³ticos, sino que se toman los narcÃ³ticos como si fueran cÃ³cteles. El problema llega cuando Lana abandona la comodidad de su visiÃ³n californiana de la tragedia en Cinemascope y se adentra en el interior de EE UU. Temas como â€˜Yosemiteâ€™ y â€˜Not All Who Wander Are Lostâ€™ son ejercicios folk soporÃ­feros, vacÃ­os de valor y con un discurso que no termina de funcionar. Como todo en Lana Del Rey, depende de lo cÃ³moda que se encuentre ella en su decepciÃ³n y su ensoÃ±aciÃ³n. Llevarla hasta un sitio en el que tiene que cerrar los ojos para ver algo resulta un fracaso tremendo. Lo Ãºnico bueno que se atisba en este camino emprendido por la artista hacia lo rural es que, cuando escriba sobre su retorno a casa, con el rÃ­mel corrido, la factura del motel sin pagar, la maleta con la mitad de las cosas que contenÃ­a cuando saliÃ³ de casa y el coche sin apenas gasolina (Lana no conduce elÃ©ctricos), los resultados pueden ser espectaculares.
Puedes seguir a BABELIA en Facebook y Twitter, o apuntarte aquÃ­ para recibir nuestra newsletter semanal.

title: â€Chemtrailsâ€œ: Eine philologische LektÃ¼re von Lana del Rey
content: â€Die beste Maske, die wir tragen, ist unser eigenes Gesichtâ€œ, schrieb Nietzsche einmal. Eine Dialektik der kÃ¼nstlerischen Maske liegt darin, dass gerade sie die Mitteilung jener verletzlichen, weichen Zonen ermÃ¶glicht, die wir Normal-Maskierten berechtigterweise so Ã¤ngstlich verbergen. Was wÃ¤re es auch anderes als Schamlosigkeit? PrivatsphÃ¤re hat ihren Sinn. Lassen wir also Elizabeth Grant, von der wir so wenig wissen, beiseite, und lauschen wir Lana Del Rey, wie sie auf ihrem neuen, sechsten Studioalbum erscheint.

title: With her sixth album Chemtrails Over the Country Club, Lana Del Rey takes a road trip into the past
content:
Like much of Lana Del Rey's music, #Chemtrails often bends backward to grasp at an elusive and irretrievable prelapsarian state
On her sixth major-label album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, Lana Del Rey wants to get away from it all.
After her great, California-centric 2019 epic Norman _____ Rockwell! maybe sheâ€™s just craving a change of scenery: â€œIâ€™m ready to leave LA and I want you to come,â€ she announces on the new albumâ€™s wanderlustful first single, 'Let Me Love You Like a Woman.' Other Chemtrails songs name-check stops on an American road trip, from Yosemite National Park to Lincoln, Nebraska, to Tulsa, Oklahoma. But on some of the recordâ€™s most stirring moments, Del Rey seems to desire an even greater spiritual sense of oblivion: â€œIâ€™m in the wind, Iâ€™m in the water, nobodyâ€™s son, nobodyâ€™s daughter,â€ she sings on the haunting title track, sounding blissfully untethered. During the albumâ€™s opening number, 'White Dress,' she pirouettes across the upper edge of her vocal register, her airy falsetto evaporating into the space around her like a fleeting, soon-to-be-illegible piece of skywriting.
One of the albumâ€™s several stunners, 'White Dress' is a melancholic, piano-driven tone poem that conjures the emotional intensity of Cat Power and reimagines a â€œsimpler timeâ€ when the narrator was a 19-year-old night-shift server in â€” of all the places in Norman Rockwellâ€™s America â€” Orlando, Florida. But she felt happy, capable: â€œWhen I was a server, wearing a white dress, like look how I do it, look how I got this.â€ The tempo is unhurried, and the song saves some of its most affecting revelations â€” â€œit kind of makes me feel like maybe I was better offâ€ â€” for its unsettling final moments.
From the moment she emerged with the semi-anachronistic torch song 'Video Games' in 2011, Del Rey has always branded herself an old soul. Like much of her music, Chemtrails often bends backward to grasp at an elusive and irretrievable prelapsarian state. (As she put it on one of her best songs, 2019â€™s unofficial anthem 'The Greatest,' â€œnobody warns you before the fall.â€) Sometimes the past she glorifies is mass-cultural (the muted, subtly auto-tuned 'Tulsa Jesus Freak' mines a Manson-family aesthetic similar to Quentin Tarantinoâ€™s Once Upon a Time â€¦ in Hollywood), but just as often on this record it is sharply personal, yearning for a lost time when making music was a carefree hobby and not Del Reyâ€™s job. Throughout, Chemtrails finds her meditating on the value of her art, wondering if itâ€™s too late to get back to the garden.
Fame is the albumâ€™s recurring boogeyman, most explicitly on the languidly guitar-driven 'Dark but Just a Game,' which Del Rey has said takes its name from something her producer Jack Antonoff said to her while they were musing about the tragic fates of so many stars. (Chemtrails reunites Del Rey with Antonoff, who coproduced Norman with her and once again gives her billowing voice the appropriate amount of compositional elbow room.) â€œThe cameras have flashes, they cause the car crashes,â€ she sings on the gently surging 'Wild at Heart' â€” another highlight. On two other occasions she references 'Candle in the Wind,' that mass-cult elegy that Elton John barely needed to rework to fit the fates of both Marilyn Monroe and Princess Diana.
Easy as it can be to forget, though, the particular slab of blue over the country club is hardly the entire sky. This finite perspective makes Chemtrails more of a minor offering than Norman _____ Rockwell!, which took big swings and often connected, capturing something that had been difficult to articulate about her generationâ€™s larger sense of malaise. Perhaps to avoid repeating herself, Chemtrails finds Del Rey scaling back, seeking more insular insight.
When all of its virtues are working in tandem â€” rich melodies, compositional surprises, only-Lana-would-say-it turns of phrase â€” Del Reyâ€™s music casts an engrossing spell. But in the moments when its tempos and timbres grow a bit repetitive, as they did on her sleepy 2015 album Honeymoon and do for a several-song stretch in the middle of this album, its limitations come into focus. 'Not All Who Wander Are Lost' builds a chorus around bumper-sticker wisdom, while vague lyrics like â€œlet me love you like a woman, let me hold you like a babyâ€ lack the specificity of her better songs.
At best, Del Reyâ€™s hyper-referential music convincingly recreates the particular feeling of encountering art in a postmodern age, when the past is so cluttered with worthwhile cultural artefacts that everything new reminds one, at least a little bit, of something old. But as she dances on that fine line between evoking and signifying, Del Rey sometimes risks outsourcing her profundity to things other artists have said more vividly before.
Such is the gamble of ending an album with a Joni Mitchell cover â€” though here thatâ€™s a risk Del Rey pulls off. On a gorgeous, reverent and harmony-enlivened rendition of 'For Free,' she is joined by the musicians Zella Day and Natalie Mering (who records as Weyes Blood), and in Mitchellâ€™s lines finds echoes with many of the questions sheâ€™s been pondering about the relative value of art and the distortions of fame. The song comes from Mitchellâ€™s 1970 LP Ladies of the Canyon, but if Chemtrails has a kindred spirit in Mitchellâ€™s discography, itâ€™s 1972â€™s For the Roses, her own â€œleaving Los Angelesâ€ album, which Mitchell composed in the solitude of her stone cottage on the Sunshine Coast of British Columbia.
By the end of Chemtrails, though, Del Rey has found solace not in solitude but solidarity, specifically with other women. The album regains momentum on its final trio of songs, which are suddenly populated with other female voices and names. (In addition to Day and Mering on 'For Free,' Del Rey is joined by the country artist Nikki Lane on a song Lane wrote, 'Breaking Up Slowly.') The cathartic 'Dancing Til We Die' finds her doing a late-night Louisiana two-step with an imagined clique of her musical heroes, some of whom (Stevie Nicks, Joan Baez) Del Rey has already toured or collaborated with. â€œGod, it feels good not to be alone,â€ she exhales, shortly before the faint, lonely sound of a horn drifts into the mix, as if from another bar down the road. Momentarily, it leaves its mark in the blue, and then just as quickly itâ€™s gone.
Lindsay Zoladz c. 2021 The New York Times Company

title: Chemtrails Over The Country Club shows us the real Lana Del Rey
content:
Dialling back the drama, the album serves as a love letter to the past, but one that feels more genuine to Lana herself.
In the ten years since Lana Del Rey first introduced us to her world of â€˜Video Gamesâ€™, sheâ€™s perfected tragic Hollywood romanticism. A greyscale chase of an American Dream, driven by a love of vintage glamour and beautiful melancholia.
From Born to Die to Ultraviolence, then Lust For Life into her acclaimed Norman F*cking Rockwell! chapter, the intrigue surrounding Lana Del Rey and her next steps has always remained enticing.
Enter: Chemtrails Over The Country Club.
Lana Del Rey has always been at her best when writing about the subject she knows most intimately: herself. These tracks were laden with the self-indulgence fans have come to expect from Lana, but with a sense of reinvention threaded throughout both.
Chemtrailsâ€¦ swaps SoCal confidence and braggadocio for folkier hues and ballads built against sparse, minimal arrangement. Working with Jack Antonoff and Rick Nowels on production, Lana opts to put a more emotional perspective front and centre the whole way through - a perspective that seems more connected to her actual self, than any other character adopted previously.
Skip YouTube Video FireFox NVDA users - To access the following content, press 'M' to enter the iFrame.
â€˜White Dressâ€™, with its references to Kings of Leon and The White Stripes, is the type of song that invites Lana fans to look on at moments where she began that transition from youth into adulthood.
â€œWhen I was a waitress / Wearing a tight dress / Handling the heat
I wasnâ€™t famous / Just listening to / Kings of Leon to the beat
Like look at how / I got this / Look how I / Got thisâ€
Itâ€™s a strong start to the record, bolstered by â€˜Chemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€™ and â€˜Wild At Heartâ€™, both offering up some of the albumâ€™s most melodic moments. Itâ€™s made evident that Chemtrailsâ€¦ is more about the small town experiences, the formative moments that can form character.
Gone is Lanaâ€™s focus on the sun-kissed West Coast. Instead, sheâ€˜s powered by the spirits of Joan Baez and Joni Mitchell, drawing inspiration from the American Midwest.
Stylistically, Chemtrailsâ€¦ doesnâ€™t veer too much away from understated balladry, but when it does, it provides moments of sharpness and renewed clarity. â€˜Dark But Just A Gameâ€™ is a great switch up; seductive in its slow burn guitars and tambourine.
Skip YouTube Video FireFox NVDA users - To access the following content, press 'M' to enter the iFrame.
Lana meditates on fame, and her disillusionment with it, rather wishing for people to stay the same.
â€œItâ€™s dark / But just a game
So play it / Like a symphony
You know / Our loveâ€™s the same
Theyâ€™ll both go down / In infamyâ€
Itâ€™s a central idea we hear again on â€˜Yosemiteâ€™, with Lana singing about change in seasons and relationships with a wryness that feels quite personal. Itâ€™s the sort of music you listen to and could easily associate with the cinematic sounds of her previous work. Here, Lanaâ€™s voice is simply accompanied by acoustic guitar, minimal percussion and delicate production. And it works way better.
The second half of Chemtrailsâ€¦, though it does have â€˜Yosemiteâ€™ and â€˜Dance Till We Dieâ€™, does become same-y. â€˜Not All Who Wander Are Lostâ€™ and â€˜Breaking Up Slowlyâ€™, though not placed together on the tracklist, feel like they bleed into one another.
Closing the album with a cover of Joni Mitchellâ€™s 1970 classic â€˜For Freeâ€™, Lana recruits the talents of both Zella Day and Weyes Blood to flesh it out. And it has to be said, Weyes Bloodâ€™s Joni-isms on this track are scarily accurate. Itâ€™s a surprising moment of contrast, but one Iâ€™m glad exists.
Skip YouTube Video FireFox NVDA users - To access the following content, press 'M' to enter the iFrame.
Chemtrails Over The Country Club is easily one of the most delicate Lana Del Rey efforts to date. Her songwriting feels more introspective than wide-eyed and wandering. The lyricism rolls off the tongue as if her diary entries have been taken from the page direct to record.
Is it her most inspired collection of material? No.
Is it any less magnetic? Definitely not.
And itâ€™s this paradoxical element of Lana Del Reyâ€™s artistry that makes her a compelling figure, whether you want to wade into her world or not.
Just days after the albumâ€™s release, Lana announced another album - Rock Sweet Candy - is on the way in June. The way Lana has promoted its release so far makes it seem like a direct commentary on the backlash she received following distasteful doubled down responses to allegations of cultural appropriation.
You listen to an album like Chemtrailsâ€¦ then read Lanaâ€™s social media post about â€˜wanting revengeâ€™ - the two are baffling to put together. But maybe weâ€™re not supposed to.
Lanaâ€™s brilliance as a songwriter has always stemmed from the way she creates a universe all her own on record, so who knows what is coming next.

title: Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜Chemtrailsâ€™ Is Flying to No. 1 In U.K.
content:
Lana Del Rey is cruising to a fifth No. 1 on the U.K. Albums Chart with Chemtrails Over The Country Club (Polydor).
At the halfway point in the chart week, the U.S. singer and songwriterâ€™s latest LP is outselling the rest of the Top 10 combined, the OCC reports.
Chemtrails is the best-seller in physical and digital formats so far this cycle. Its midweek tally of 34,000 combined sales eclipses the entire first-week effort of her previous three albums, and the collection is on track for Del Reyâ€™s best release week since 2014â€™s Ultraviolence.

title: â€˜Chemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€™ by Lana Del Rey Review: Tainted by Expectation
content:
In 2011, singer Lana Del Rey released â€œVideo Games,â€ a single that introduced her to the wider public but was not her debut. Sheâ€™d already issued a digital EP as Lizzy Grant in 2008 and a full-length album introducing her new moniker in 2010 (albeit with a different spelling than she now uses), â€œ Lana Del Ray A.K.A. Lizzy Grant.â€ But these releases, when she was still tethered to her birth name, were heard by almost no one and have been written out of her canon. From â€œVideo Gamesâ€ forward, she wrote about star-crossed lovers moving through scenes dense with references to film and music history and sang her songs in a whispered croon that radiated glamour. This shadowy mode became synonymous with her stage name and her music, which sold and streamed in big numbers, and carried her to widespread fame.
On her 2019 record â€œNorman Fâ€”ing Rockwell!â€ she shared her tales of existential romance at the edge of the apocalypse, and they attained an extra layer of meaning because of who was singing them. While her songs unfold like little movies and can carry psychological insight, they also touch on what itâ€™s like to be Lana Del Rey. â€œNFR!â€ topped many criticsâ€™ lists in 2019 and was a clear breakthrough for the singer, so following it was inevitably going to be tricky. Her seventh studio album, â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ out now, sounds similar to its predecessor on a casual listen and features a few new wrinkles, but itâ€™s missing the detail that makes her best work so remarkable.
Musically, â€œChemtrailsâ€ extends the sound of â€œNFR!â€ Once again, she mostly works with songwriter and producer Jack Antonoff, who co-writes and co-produces almost all of the materialâ€” Rick Nowels, her creative partner on earlier work, writes and produces one track. As in 2019, the tempos are slow and the arrangements are minimalist, led by piano or acoustic guitar.
The most appealing twists here are her experiments with vocals. Sheâ€™s become a more resourceful singer over the years, and on many of these tracks she uses the upper end of her range in novel ways, conveying new vulnerability. The opener, â€œWhite Dress,â€ finds her in this mode. Itâ€™s one of her best songs to date, looking back at her life at age 19â€”sheâ€™s 35 nowâ€”when she was waiting tables and living in the moment with no hint of what was to come. Sheâ€™s always had an ear for lyrical specificity, and here she name-checks two emerging rock bands from that timeâ€”â€œListening to White Stripes when they were white-hotâ€ and â€œI wasnâ€™t famous, just listening to Kings of Leonâ€â€”and positions herself as a dreamer who had a lot to learn about navigating the music business but had the tenacity to succeed.
The higher voice that carries through â€œWhite Dressâ€ pops up regularly on â€œChemtrails,â€ and weâ€™ve never heard her sound quite like this before. On â€œNFR!â€ she often sounded dryly amused and sometimes even bored by the parade of men in her life, and her offhand put-downs added moments of levity. Here, singing with a more fragile tone, she sounds like someone for whom a potentially doomed affair represents a real risk.
A handful of recurring images and motifs suggest a loose concept. Both â€œTulsa Jesus Freak,â€ which indulges Ms. Del Reyâ€™s fascination with love and lust among the down-and-out, and â€œYosemite,â€ about a romantic pair who seal themselves off from the world and become obsessed with each other, contain the phrase â€œNo more candle in the wind,â€ which is nearly identical to a line from her 2018 epic â€œMarinerâ€™s Apartment Complex.â€ The use of the line is quintessential Lana Del Rey, taking an overexposed element from pop cultureâ€”in this case, Elton Johnâ€™s 1973 tribute to Marilyn Monroe, later reworked to honor Princess Dianaâ€”and situating it effectively into her own cinematic universe. It also places her in the lineage of these icons.
Unfortunately, such odd asides and weird lyrical turns are in relatively short supply on this outing. Aside from the title track, a comparatively weak number about suburban ennui that feels informed by streaming TV dramas such as â€œBig Little Lies,â€ the songs are mostly minor scenes about intense infatuation with few surprises. â€œWild at Heartâ€ and â€œDark but Just a Gameâ€ are reasonably moody and tuneful but lyrically indistinct, which is not something you can say about most of her work.
The penultimate track, â€œDance Till We Die,â€ opens with a line about Ms. Del Rey interacting with her idols: â€œIâ€™m coverinâ€™ Joni and Iâ€™m dancinâ€™ with Joan / Stevie is callinâ€™ on the telephoneâ€â€”that would be Joni Mitchell, Joan Baez and Stevie Nicksâ€”but it doesnâ€™t build upon that memorable kickoff. The song serves mostly to set up the closing number, a cover of â€œFor Freeâ€ from Ms. Mitchellâ€™s 1970 LP â€œLadies of the Canyonâ€ that features singers Zella Day and Natalie Mering, who records as Weyes Blood.
Had it closed her previous release, â€œFor Freeâ€ would have been a bold claim that the younger singer deserved to be mentioned in the same breath as one of her heroes. But here the gesture doesnâ€™t feel earned, and the folky melody sounds almost medieval and hence out of place next to those crafted with Mr. Antonoff and Mr. Nowels. Ms. Del Rey set a high bar last time and â€œChemtrailsâ€ canâ€™t reach itâ€”though the music here is strong and her voice has grown richer, the uncharacteristically vague lyrics fail to transport you to Ms. Del Reyâ€™s usually immersive worlds.
â€”Mr. Richardson is the Journalâ€™s rock and pop music critic. Follow him on Twitter @MarkRichardson.

title: Lana Del Rey vient de sortir Chemtrails Over The Country Club son nouvel album, elle annonce dÃ©jÃ  le prochain
content:
Lana Del Rey vient tout juste de sortir son nouvel album Chemtrails Over The Country Club qu'elle annonce dÃ©jÃ  le prochain. On vous en dit plus !
Justin Bieber a dÃ©voilÃ© vendredi son nouvel album Justice, dont nous vous avons fait la critique, mais ce n'est pas le seul ! Lana Del Rey est elle aussi de retour avec Chemtrails Over The Country Club. Ce septiÃ¨me opus comporte onze morceaux de pop Ã©purÃ©e. On y retrouve des mÃ©lodies douces et enivrantes typiques de l'univers de la chanteuse. Dans cet album, Lana Del Rey Ã©voque la difficultÃ© en tant que femme de se faire une place dans le milieu de la musique mais Ã©galement de maniÃ¨re gÃ©nÃ©rale. L'artiste avait dÃ©jÃ  dÃ©voilÃ© plusieurs clips dont celui de "Chemtrails Over The Country Club" et "White Dress", offrant un avant-goÃ»t Ã  ses fans.
Mais si Lana Del Rey ravit tout le monde avec ce nouvel album, elle surprend en annonÃ§ant dÃ©jÃ  la sortie de son prochain ! Et c'est sur Instagram que la chanteuse a dÃ©voilÃ© l'information. Samedi, l'artiste a publiÃ© une photo avec en lÃ©gende : "ROCK CANDY SWEET le 1er juin". Un projet qui lui tient Ã  coeur puisque Lana Del Rey a indiquÃ© dans ses stories que cet opus contiendrait ses rÃ©ponses face aux "accusations dâ€™appropriation culturelle et de glamourisation des violences domestiques" qui l'ont visÃ©es rÃ©cemment. On a hÃ¢te de dÃ©couvrir tout cela ! En attendant, dÃ©tendez-vous en Ã©coutant notre playlist des nouveautÃ©s de la semaine avec Justin Bieber, Jul et Naps, SCH...

title: Lana Del Rey, annunciata l'uscita di un nuovo album su Instagram
content:
A pochi giorni dallâ€™uscita del suo â€œ Chemtrails over the Country Club â€, Lana Del Rey ha annunciato un nuovo album di inediti previsto per lâ€™1 giugno 2021. Il titolo rivelato sui suoi canali social Ã¨ â€œ Rock Candy Sweet â€ e si tratterebbe di un nuovo disco di inediti. Lâ€™annuncio di â€œRock Candy Sweetâ€ Ã¨ stato decisamente sobrio, con una foto che ritrae un primo piano dellâ€™artista e il nome del disco. Nessun singolo, nessuna cover e nessuna notizia di qualsiasi genere su questo nuovo album, ad eccezione della data dâ€™uscita. Probabilmente nelle prossime settimane se ne saprÃ  di piÃ¹ ma al momento lâ€™uscita di questo nuovo album Ã¨ tanto misteriosa quanto inaspettata.
Lâ€™uscita di â€œChemtrails over the Country Clubâ€ era prevista inizialmente per lo scorso anno. Lâ€™emergenza sanitaria ( LO SPECIALE - GLI AGGIORNAMENTI - LA MAPPA ) ancora in corso ha perÃ² costretto Lana Del Rey a rivedere i suoi piani e a posticipare il disco a marzo 2021. Ovviamente la stessa sorte Ã¨ toccata al tour e ai concerti di presentazione di questo album che sono stati riprogrammati a data da destinarsi, quando la situazione sarÃ  meno complicata. Tra i singoli estratti daâ€œChemtrails over the Country Clubâ€ troviamo â€œ Let Me Love You like a Woman â€, che ha visto la luce sulle piattaforme digitali a ottobre 2020. Il singolo omonimo rilasciato a gennaio di questâ€™anno e â€œ White Dress â€ che ha accompagnato lâ€™uscita dellâ€™album lo scorso 19 marzo. Nel frattempo Lana Del Rey ha pubblicato la sua prima raccolta di poesie â€œ Violet Bent Backwards over the Grass â€ ed Ã¨ in attesa di pubblicare la seconda parte dellâ€™opera â€œ Behind the Iron Gates â€“ Insights from the Institution â€, prevista per il 2021. La cantante aveva annunciato anche lâ€™uscita un disco di cover country ma, lâ€™annuncio di â€œRock Candy Sweetâ€ sembra aver stravolto i programmi dellâ€™artista che ha preferito â€œripiegareâ€ su un nuovo disco di inediti.
Le critiche dietro a â€œChemtrails over the Country Clubâ€
approfondimento
Lana Del Rey, il post prima dell'uscita del nuovo album
A poche ore dalla pubblicazione della copertina di â€œChemtrails over the Country Clubâ€, molte riviste di settore lâ€™hanno etichettata come una delle piÃ¹ brutte cover di sempre. Inoltre lâ€™artista Ã¨ stata accusata di aver â€œcopertoâ€ le differenze tra le donne di colore e le donne bianche con lâ€™uso del bianco e nero. Lana Del Rey ha risposto dicendo di essere sempre stata una persona attenta allâ€™inclusione, nella vita come nella musica. Ha poi aggiunto che la foto voleva immortalare un momento di convivialitÃ  tra amiche, a prescindere dalle differenze e dal colore della pelle.
In un post sui social lâ€™artista ha scritto: â€œFate uno zoom, aguzzate bene lo sguardo: quelle sono le mie amiche nella vita reale e ce ne sono di tutti i colori. Vengono da ogni parte del mondo e hanno figli con persone di tutte le razze. Del resto nessuno di noi puÃ² dirsi di unâ€™unica razza. Ho tanti problemi ma tra questi non câ€™Ã¨ il razzismoâ€. Con queste parole Lana Del Rey ha messo a tacere la polemica, sottolineando il fatto che la foto voleva intendere lâ€™esatto contrario di ciÃ² che si Ã¨ detto.

A beleza da mÃºsica de Lana pÃ´de aparecer inteira, sem manhas, solta do peso da mitologia que ela prÃ³pria criou, sem armadilhas.

title: Neues Album von Lana Del Rey - Eine echt starke Sisterhood-Platte
content:
Neues Album von Lana Del Rey â€“ Eine echt starke Sisterhood-Platte Auf Â«Chemtrails Over The Country ClubÂ» geht es mal wieder vor allem um die KÃ¼nstlerin selbst. Na und? Joachim Hentschel
Vor knapp zwei Wochen stellte der Film-Stuntman Hunter Ray Barker in Los Angeles ein blaues Kinderplanschbecken vor dem Â«Los TorosÂ» auf, seinem Lieblings-Mexikaner. FÃ¼llte es mit Kidneybohnen, liess sich fÃ¼r 24 Stunden in der Pampe nieder, um Spenden fÃ¼r das coronagefÃ¤hrdete Restaurant zu sammeln.
Und bekam nachmittags glamourÃ¶sen Besuch. Die SÃ¤ngerin und Songwriterin Lana Del Rey schaute vorbei, im roten Kapuzenpullover. Sprach ihre SolidaritÃ¤t aus und postete das Foto fÃ¼r ihre mehr als 18 Millionen Instagram-Fans. Unter das heitere Bild schrieb sie: Â«Don't ask why.Â» Fragt nicht nach dem Grund.
Abgesehen davon, dass sich Lana Del Rey in der Ã–ffentlichkeit sonst von Bohnenzubereitungen aller Art weitgehend fernhÃ¤lt, ist der Nukleus der Geste ganz typisch fÃ¼r sie. Nehmt das Bild, so schÃ¤big es ist, scheint sie hier zu sagen. Nehmt es fÃ¼r seine Aura, seine amerikanische Momentaufnahmenhaftigkeit, aber fragt nicht, was es bedeuten soll.
Lana Del Rey ist allerdings Entertainerin, schreibt Songs mit viel Text, hat gewaltige Erfolge. Und ihre Pop-Inszenierungen als frÃ¼he Joan Didion und noch frÃ¼here Lauren Bacall sind derart spektakulÃ¤r und cineastisch, dass man kaum drum herumkommt, in ihnen auch immer die Geschichten zu suchen. Den erzÃ¤hlerischen Drive, den man eigentlich erwarten dÃ¼rfen sollte, wenn jemand im kirschroten Mercedes-500-K-Cabrio durchs Video fÃ¤hrt.
Zuletzt hat Lana Del Rey versucht, sich in die Diversity-Diskurse einzuschalten.
Dennoch handle Lana Del Rey am Ende immer nur von sich selbst, sagen ihre Kritiker. Von sich und den alten, wasserdicht nostalgischen, vermeintlich entpolitisierten Bildern, die sie herunterblÃ¤ttere wie in einem Vintage-Style-Account auf Pinterest. Dass das freilich eine Frage des Blickwinkels ist, dass Del Rey wohl nie eine Chance hat, als grosse GegenwartskÃ¼nstlerin anerkannt zu werden, solange die Leute immer schon an ihrem Lipgloss abglitschen, ist eine andere Sache.
Auf Â«Chemtrails Over The Country ClubÂ», ihrem neuen, siebten Studioalbum, singt Lana Del Rey in der Tat vor allem von sich selbst. Es ist ihre Hybris-Platte, ihr Â«Ich knabbere schwer an meinem RuhmÂ»-Liederzyklus, ihr Abschiedsbrief an die HÃ¤schenphase der Karriere. Wie autobiografisch das im Einzelnen gemeint sein kÃ¶nnte, ist die mit Abstand Ã¶deste Frage, die man ans Kunstwerk stellen kann.
Es wird viel gewispert
Als mittelgrosse, bereits spÃ¤tsommerliche Inszenierung funktioniert Â«Chemtrails Over The Country ClubÂ» jedenfalls so luftabschnÃ¼rend gut, dass man Del Rey sowieso jedes Wort glauben will, das sie ins starke, digital hochaufgelÃ¶ste Laurel-Canyon-2021-Echo hineinwispert.
Amerikanisch durch und durch: Das Cover zum Album Â«Chemtrails Over the Country ClubÂ». Foto: Keystone
Und ja, es wird viel gewispert auf dem Â«ChemtrailsÂ»-Album. Allerdings schon im ersten Song Â«White DressÂ» auf so Ã¼beraus unbescheidene, vorlaute Art, dass Lana Del Rey die Stimme buchstÃ¤blich Ã¼berschnappt. Hier erzÃ¤hlt sie, begleitet von einer kleinen Nightclub-Combo, Ã¼ber die BerufsanfÃ¤nge als Kellnerin, die es ins Musikbusiness verschlÃ¤gt und sich dort derart in die Ereignisse verheddert, dass die Zeilen des Songs vor lauter Silben fast zu platzen drohen.
Die Schattenseiten des Ruhms
40 Minuten spÃ¤ter, gegen Ende der Platte, wird sie in Â«Dance Till We DieÂ» am dramaturgischen Scheitelpunkt ankommen, an dem nur noch die Flucht aus dem Alltag des Ruhms mÃ¶glich erscheint. Sie tanzt mit Joan Baez, telefoniert mit Stevie Nicks. Covert mit den SÃ¤ngerinnen Zella Day und Weyes Blood, superfrech und superschlÃ¼ssig, das StÃ¼ck Â«For FreeÂ», in dem Joni Mitchell 1970 Ã¼ber entfremdete Arbeit im Kulturgewerbe klagte. Die Musik ist durchweg sparsam, man hÃ¶rt die Fingerkuppen auf den Saiten, die leise knackenden Schlagzeuger-Gelenke. Beziehungsweise das, was die Felsen der Santa Monica Mountains davon zurÃ¼ckhallen lassen.
Zuletzt hat Lana Del Rey versucht, sich in die Diversity-Diskurse einzuschalten, hier doch noch Punkte zu holen, die ihr als ultraweisser Retro-Style-Ikone bislang verwehrt blieben. Es ging desastrÃ¶s nach hinten los â€“ was allein deshalb schade ist, weil sie Â«Chemtrails Over The Country ClubÂ» auch fÃ¼r sich allein hÃ¤tte sprechen lassen kÃ¶nnen, als, siehe oben, wirklich starke Sisterhood-Platte. Dass diese Musik durch und durch weiss ist, wie das Kleid der Kellnerin, die Leinwand vor dem Filmstart oder eben die verdammten Kondensstreifen, ist ja alles andere als verwerflich. Solange sie so beweglich, anschlussfÃ¤hig und nachhaltig atemberaubend ist, wie viele es der KÃ¼nstlerin eh nie zugestehen werden.

title: Lana del Rey hint op nog een nieuw album
content:
Lana del Rey lijkt binnenkort weer met een nieuw album te komen, zo blijkt op Instagram. Vrijdag bracht de Amerikaanse zangeres haar meest recente plaat Chemtrails Over The Country Club uit.
De zangeres deelt een foto op haar Instagram met de tekst "ROCK CANDY SWEET, 1 juni". In de reacties gaan fans er gelijk vanuit dat het om een nieuw album gaat en reageren daarom enthousiast.
Eigenlijk zou Chemtrails Over The Country Club vorig jaar al uitkomen, maar de plaat liep meerdere keren vertraging op. Door de coronacrisis en door enkele aanpassingen van Del Rey kwam de plaat op 19 maart uit.

title: Lana Del Rey's new album Chemtrails Over the Country Club has all her staples, and ample vulnerability
content:
Paralleling the juxtaposition in the title, Del Reyâ€™s seventh album explores the yin and yang of fame, fortune and creativity.
Decay and decadence coexist in the world created by Lana Del Rey in Chemtrails Over The Country Club.
At first listen, her intimate follow-up to critically-acclaimed Norman (Expletive) Rockwell may seem less urgent. Rather than deconstructing the American myth, Del Rey shifts her gaze inward. But in the quiet, she disassembles a different pain, one felt in the unforgiving glow of the limelight.
Whispering opener 'White Dress' immediately sets Chemtrails Over The Country Club apart from Norman (Expletive) Rockwell, her breathiness almost jarring.
She works with the same producer, Jack Antonoff, whose credits are also seen on Taylor Swiftâ€™s 2020 albums evermore and folklore. There are echoes of Swiftâ€™s production on Del Reyâ€™s new album with songs like the gentle 'Yosemite' leaning in the folk direction.
Del Rey has perfected the art of creating album capsules. Each record emanates its own aesthetic with songs cross-referencing one another within the album. Del Rey gives cohesion to albums in a way that is unmatched by most other artists.
In 'Dance Till We Die', she sings of Joni Mitchell covers before launching into her own cover of Mitchellâ€™s 'For Free'. 'Yosemite', too, seems to call to her closing cover. â€œWe did it for fun/ We did it for free,â€ she croons. â€œWe did it for the right reasons.â€
Paralleling the juxtaposition in the title, Del Reyâ€™s seventh album explores the yin and yang of fame, fortune and creativity. On the surface are glittering images: jewels in a country club pool and bars that stay open "just for us". Ringing underneath is a melancholy emptiness perforated by isolation and desire.
Album-standout 'Dark But Just A Game' encapsulates these feelings. Del Rey paints a picture of someone who sees those who have fallen before her. â€œTheir stories all end tragically,â€ she sings, bringing to mind artists like Judy Garland and Amy Winehouse. â€œThe best ones lost their minds.â€
Other songs create the same illustration. â€œThe cameras have flashes, they cause the car crashes,â€ Del Rey sings in the Americana-tinged 'Wild At Heart', referencing the catastrophic death of Princess Diana.
Chemtrails Over The Country Club has all Del Reyâ€™s staples â€” angelic layered vocals, bridges that bring a second dimension to tracks and tongue-in-cheek lyrics.
Del Rey may not have reached the perfection of Norman (Expletive) Rockwell, but in Chemtrails Over The Country Club, sheâ€™s offered something different: vulnerability.

title: What Is Lana Del Rey's Real Name and Why Did She Change It?
content:
The â€œLittle White Dressâ€ musical pop star sensation Lana Del Rey is like many other celebrity performers that have changed their names. Most actors and musicians choose a new pseudonym early on in their careers, so fans can connect to their stage persona right from the start.
When the melancholy singer selected a new name midstream, fans and critics alike were unimpressed. Projects released under Del Reyâ€™s birth name seemed to disappear from the internet overnight, and her original surname was suddenly erased from social media.
Everyone seemed to question the emerging artistâ€™s motives. Fans felt deceived, wondering if the sultry performerâ€™s management team was behind her new edgy look, sound, and overall performance style.
Who is Lana Del Rey?
Lana Del Rey | David Crotty/Patrick McMullan via Getty Images
RELATED: 8 Things Lana Del Rey Is Very Sad About
Del Rey was born Elizabeth Woolridge Grant in 1986. The New York native moved to the big city at the age of 18, not intending to pursue a musical career.
Vogue reported the â€œLust for Lifeâ€ singer was studying metaphysics at Fordham University when she started performing in local nightclubs as Lizzy Grant and Sparkle Rope Jump Queen.
It wasnâ€™t until 2011, when she released the single â€œVideo Games,â€ that her career took off, and she signed a deal with Interscope Records. A decade later, the singer-songwriter has seven studio albums under her belt, four extended EPs, and 37 singles.
According to Billboard, Del Rey has had 13 Hot 100 Songs and has been on the Artist 100 Chart for 79 weeks. In 2019, she collaborated with Ariana Grande and Miley Cyrus on the hit single, â€œDonâ€™t Call Me Angel.â€
Del Rey has received six Grammy nominations, her most recent in 2019 for Album of the Year for Norman F***ing Rockwell.
Does Lizzy Grant still exist?
Rolling Stone Germany-
Photos of me working on set with my sister while Iâ€™m not working on music. Hard work brings me so much happiness. Especially when itâ€™s for her@rollingstoneDE pic.twitter.com/VKGh9UQfXN â€” Lana Del Rey (@LanaDelRey) March 24, 2021
RELATED: The Story Behind the Controversial Title of Lana Del Reyâ€™s New Album
In the summer of 2009, Lizzy Grant took the stage at a small New York venue. The shy young performer failed to impress audiences with her dime-a-dozen appearance and vocal abilities. She released an album that went nowhere.
Several years later, the determined artist reemerged under the stage name of Lana Del Rey. She released her first self-titled album in 2010, which was met with great success. Her critically-acclaim second album Born to Die launched her career, but with it came huge controversy.
The well-received single â€œVideo Gamesâ€ became a viral sensation on YouTube, racking up more than 20 million views. The quiet young Grant seemed to have suddenly transformed into a performer capable of selling out venues.
Despite her newfound success, Guardian reported critics began to question if â€œthe transformation from Grant to Del Rey had been planned all along.â€ They explained that Grant, who appeared to be a struggling artist that appeared out of nowhere, was actually the daughter of a millionaire who paid a management team to create her Del Rey image.
Suddenly, fans began to question how organic the sultry songstress was and wondered how much influence her label had in marketing her persona to the masses. When Del Rey appeared on Saturday Night Live, fans, critics, and even other celebrities weighed in on the terrible performance with actor Juliette Lewis saying, â€œWatching this â€˜singerâ€™ on SNL is like watching a 12-year-old in their bedroom when theyâ€™re pretending to sing and perform.â€
Del Rey explains the simple reason behind her name change
RELATED: Lana Del Reyâ€™s Beautiful Tragedy Is Winning Over Critics
The â€œLet Me Love You Like a Womanâ€ singer became known for her trademark look, which Vogue described in 2011 as â€œbouffant hair, doll-like lashes teamed with blinging gold chains and vintage T-shirts.â€ At the time, the fashion magazine said, â€œThe singer knows exactly how she wants to be seen â€“ her chosen stage name another way of reflecting her musical identity.â€
In an interview with Vogue, the controversial performer explained, â€œI wanted a name I could shape the music towards. I was going to Miami quite a lot at the time, speaking a lot of Spanish with my friends from Cuba â€“ Lana Del Rey reminded us of the glamour of the seaside. It sounded gorgeous coming off the tip of the tongue.â€

title: Why Lana Del Rey Refuses to Sing a Line From Her Controversial Song 'Ultraviolence'
content:
Lana Del Rey is one of the hardest working singer-songwriters in the business. Her catchy songs about her struggles to find love and happiness have garnered a devoted following that resonates with her lyrical prowess. However, some see her songs about the toll that toxic relationships not as an artist baring her soul but as a poisonous way to keep rampant problems in society from ever moving forward.
Lana Del Rey | David Crotty/Patrick McMullan via Getty Images
Lana Del Rey has been accused of glorifying abuse
RELATED: Here Are Four Singers Inspired by JFKâ€™s Life Story
Del Rey is no stranger to criticisms about her lyrics. Known for her deeply personal odes about love, hate, and everything in between. As Title Magazine noted, her verses about toxic relationships, however, some believe her words, even if they mean well, can trigger negative memories for victims of abuse, both physical and mental.
From â€œVideo Games,â€ where the singer treated an emotionally unavailable man as a quirk to recent songs likes â€œUltraviolence,â€ Del Reyâ€™s penchant for realistic lyrics has been as much a part of her legacy as her music over the past decade. However, it doesnâ€™t mean that sheâ€™s unaware of the dangers behind her storytelling.
Lana Del Rey on â€˜Ultraviolenceâ€™
RELATED: Billie Eilish Wants You to Stop Comparing Her to Lana Del Rey
Del Rey has some awareness of the way her words can paint a picture that she doesnâ€™t want the world to see. When asked about the line that stated that a hit from a former partner felt â€œlike a kiss,â€ Del Rey believes she went too far. As such, when she performs in front of a live audience, the songwriter told Pitchfork that she now skips the line out of respect for those who may feel triggered.
â€œI donâ€™t like [the line]. I donâ€™t. I donâ€™t sing it. I sing â€œUltraviolenceâ€ but I donâ€™t sing that line anymore. Having someone be aggressive in a relationship was the only relationship I knew. Iâ€™m not going to say that that [lyric] was 100 percent true, but I do feel comfortable saying what I was used to was a difficult, tumultuous relationship, and it wasnâ€™t because of me. It didnâ€™t come from my end.â€
Del Rey has been quick to self-critique for most of her career. Itâ€™s part of the appeal for such a wide-ranging audience around the world. Just because Del Rey understands it, however, does not mean that these criticisms are wrong.
Lana Del Reyâ€™s dynamic artistry
Criticisms such as Isabella Castilloâ€™s piece at State Press about Del Reyâ€™s lyrical content have followed her from day one. However, while she acknowledges the regrets that some of her more graphic lyrics bring her, she also sees her music as a reflection of real-life experiences. As she grows older, so do her experiences and music.
â€œIâ€™m trying to do a new thing. I never wrote better when I had a lot of turmoil going on. Born to Die was already done before any of the s**** hit the fan. When things are good, the music is better. Iâ€™m trying to change from the way I thought things were gonna be to what I feel like they could be, which is maybe just brighter,â€ she told the publication.
Del Rey has millions of devoted fans across the world. The flip-side of that coin, however, is the fact that her music, however personal it may be, can trigger people who do not know the context. Personal songs about love and abuse are as old as music itself. In years past, it was standard for these songs to not only do well but also dominate the charts.
However, the tide has shifted when it comes to violence against women, and songs like â€œUltraviolenceâ€ now seem antiquated just a few years after its release. Del Rey owns this, and while many will take issue with her style, the fact that she acknowledges these issues is why she has such a stranglehold

title: Why stars should think twice before calling out their critics
content:
In 2018, while working as a freelance writer, I travelled three hours outside of London on a train, and then a coach, to review a music festival. I camped in the cold and the rain, waking up at 8am each morning to make sure I didnâ€™t miss anything. When I got home, I filed what I thought was a generous review. I did not expect the organiser and the founder of the festival to find me on Twitter to tell me that I clearly hadnâ€™t attended, or that my three-star review was full of lies. They were hurt that I hadnâ€™t given it five stars. I was hurt that my hard work â€“ complete with blood blisters, swollen glands and glitter that took two weeks to wash out of my hair â€“ was now seen as a declaration of war.
As an editor and sometime critic specialising in pop culture, differing perceptions are par for the course. I find it skull-crushingly boring to see the same TV show or album receive near-identical reviews across the board, or read identikit reviews of the same film. I inhale peopleâ€™s opinions â€“ the good and the bad, the funny and the touching, the flippant and the problematic â€“ and exhale them. I donâ€™t internalise them. I donâ€™t agree with a lot of what I read, but I take something from it: someone elseâ€™s views. I go to certain people because I know, nine times out of 10, we think very, very differently (hereâ€™s looking at you, Camilla Long). Reviews can serve as a guide but they are also an artform in their own right. They entertain, inform and challenge readers. The writer AO Scott described criticism in his 2016 book Better Living Through Criticism as â€œartâ€™s late-born twinâ€.
It was a second strange experience, then, to wake up in a foreign country at the end of 2019, on a parental-death-imposed holiday where work was as good as a million miles away, to find that a Twitter â€œstormâ€ had started around one of my opinions. At that point in time, my existence was a comforting combination of workaholism, panic attacks and grief. My writing â€“ which had started by blogging online and then writing for the likes of NME in my teens â€“ never took itself too seriously. It came from that place where love, deference, humour and actual journalism coagulate. Yet, the creator of a major BBC crime drama â€“ yes, that one â€“ had taken it another way. Reflecting on a (very) short piece online, he described me as snide, and talentless, and said I shouldnâ€™t be doing my job. Never mind that this was the dance that we had both essentially entered into by doing our jobs â€“ him to create art that was to be judged, me to write and judge said art â€“ I was wrong. I was a horrible person.
I am not one for Twitter beef â€“ and also couldnâ€™t face paying another Â£200 for data â€“ so I left it. I thought that was it, until the same person resurfaced a year and a half later, just before the new series of that crime drama, wanting me to know, in a national magazine, that I was a â€œcuntâ€ and a â€œpiece of shitâ€. The words rose off the page like some kind of twisted Magic Eye picture. Yes, this was about me; I was the bad guy.
Culture writing is place for fans to engage with the things they love; a place for differing opinions
As journalism has become ever more dominated by celebrity, public figures have also become more willing to engage with criticism of their work, pushing when they donâ€™t agree with something. When the singer Lizzo was underwhelmed by a 2019 album review by Pitchforkâ€™s Rawiya Kameir, she wrote in a now-deleted Tweet that â€œPEOPLE WHO â€˜REVIEWâ€™ ALBUMS AND DONâ€™T MAKE MUSIC THEMSELVES SHOULD BE UNEMPLOYED.â€ Her reaction is, on one hand, understandable: who wants to be criticised? And yet it fundamentally misunderstands what culture writing and criticism is. It is not there to take pot shots at Lizzo, or anyone else: itâ€™s a place for fans to engage with forms that they love; to be excited and disappointed; a place for differing opinions.
In this case, Kameir deftly situated the album in the canon of overly slick empowerment pop, and conceded that it â€œperforms an important social functionâ€. She considered it, explained it, and treated it seriously, like the art that it is. She wrote that Lizzo is talented; she looked for the positives. However, it was seen as something more devious, more calculating. The stereotype of a critic as cruel, immoral and even underqualified (perhaps best encapsulated on film by the restaurant critic Anton Ego in Ratatouille), rather than someone trying to contextualise, parse, and make sense of what they see, is a pervasive one.
Lana Del Rey, who requested that the critic Ann Powers no longer be her fan. Photograph: Mat Hayward/Getty Images
When the Buzzfeed writer Anne Helen Petersen wrote in great detail about how the career of now-disgraced film star Armie Hammer had been stuck in second gear for a decade, Hammer called her â€œbitter AFâ€. In the same year, Lana Del Rey took umbrage with the music critic Ann Powers of NPR for saying she was embodying â€œa personaâ€ (who doesnâ€™t?), and that her lyrics were â€œuncookedâ€. Those were, of course, just Powersâ€™s words. But to Del Rey, they had struck a nerve. She told Powers not to call herself a fan of hers ever again. In all of these cases, by shouting about them, the person with the actual power â€“ the artist, the celebrity â€“ ironically brings more attention to the criticâ€™s views (see: the Streisand effect).
Of course, there are times when criticism tips into something more controversial. A review of Dolly Aldertonâ€™s book Ghosts went viral online in 2020. There wasnâ€™t that sense of the reviewer having engaged with something before offering up a short, sharp, maybe flippant take. Rather it seemed over the top; the book, said the Irish Times writer Barry Pierce, brought him â€œnothing but pain and disappointmentâ€. The editor-in-chief of Empire magazine, Terri White described it as â€œtaking great delight in destroying for effectâ€. While I do not believe it shouldnâ€™t have been published â€“ as I said, I do not agree with probably 99.9% of what I read â€“ I donâ€™t know that it was the most informative kind of review. If criticism is an art, then this was a bad example.
Likewise, when Carey Mulligan clashed with the film industry magazine Variety over a review describing her get-up in the film Promising Young Woman as â€œbad dragâ€ and adding that â€œeven her long blonde hair seems a put-onâ€. Should it have been published? I think you know my answer. But does Mulliganâ€™s appearance have anything to do with the review? Probably not enough to warrant inclusion. Yet, it all comes back, I think, to the question of intent. â€œIâ€™m a 60-year-old gay man. I donâ€™t actually go around dwelling on the comparative hotnesses of young actresses, let alone writing about that,â€ said its author, Dennis Harvey. I donâ€™t think Harvey should have been talking about Mulliganâ€™s appearance because, honestly, why? But that potential to say something that someone wonâ€™t like is inextricably baked into being a critic. Many writers I know donâ€™t read the comments below their pieces for the same reason.
Carey Mulligan, who responded to Dennis Harveyâ€™s comments, saying: â€˜Itâ€™s important that criticism is constructiveâ€™ Photograph: AP
If we donâ€™t give our true opinions, what kind of job are we doing? A colleague recently told me about one of the first reviews they had written, and the publicist who phoned them in a strop to get a star rating changed, assuming that the editor â€“ whom they had worked with several times before, and would happily go for a pint with â€“ would give in (they didnâ€™t). I would happily enter into a dialogue with most people about my work â€“ and have done, many times â€“ but, really, who is going to do that on a public forum, especially when they are being told theyâ€™re trash?
Alison Herman, writing in The Ringer in 2019, described the present moment as â€œa time when the public is disconcertingly unaware of the function of a vital civic institution like a free press, a misunderstanding thatâ€™s frequently exploited for political gain. Fashion bloggers and music critics are not investigative journalists, nor are pop stars and comedians fear-mongering leaders. But theyâ€™re channeling a deeply troubling trend in how the public exaggerates media membersâ€™ power, just as that power â€“ such as it is â€“ has never been less secureâ€. As well as being insecure, criticism is still predominantly dominated by people of the same race, social class, gender and sexuality. Being different in any â€“ or several â€“ of those ways, does not usually a thick-skinned critic make. Your impostor syndrome has, of course, told you that youâ€™re not good enough long before anyone else could get in there.
I left the festival feeling depleted, and â€“ when the tweets arrived â€“ confused about whether a handful of drinks tokens were really supposed to have secured a glowing review. I drained my blisters and got far, far away from Twitter. Unlike the founder â€“ and the famous writer of an acclaimed crime drama â€“ I knew it was best not to take criticism to heart.

title: Lana Del Rey reveals new album, â€˜Blue Banisters,â€™ due July 4
content: In Varietyâ€™s review of â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ deputy music editor Jem Aswad wrote: â€œKeeping things fresh for oneself, let alone for fans, is a constant challenge for any artist, and itâ€™s one that Del Rey rises to with impressive consistency. But self-parody is always just a heartbeat away, and her tendency to work primarily with a familiar pod of collaborators can make things repetitive. â€œChemtrailsâ€ is a progression in some ways but a holding pattern in others -- weâ€™re most interested to see where she goes next.â€

title: Lana Del Rey has announced a new album but fans are already mocking the artwork
content:
Lana Del Rey has made a surprise announcement today that her eighth studio album, Blue Banisters will be released later this year on July 4.
The news comes as a surprise to fans because Del Rey recently dropped an album Chemtrails over the Country Club in March this year.
Although her fans are excited about receiving two LPs from the Grammy Award nominee within a few months of each other, many were unimpressed with the artwork for the new album and made their feelings clear on social media.
The album artwork for Blue Banisters features a portrait of Del Rey with white borders in each corner and quote marks on either side of the image and the title is at the bottom in a blue distinctive font, with swirls.
As Del Rey is known for her iconic imagery that accompanies her albums, her fans criticised the latest artwork - with some saying that it looked like Del Rey edited the image herself on her phone.
Read more:
A petition has even been created in protest and already has over 1,300 signatures. Itâ€™s titled: â€œBAN LANA FROM PICSART,â€ Picsart is a mobile photo editing app.
Here are some of the fans reactions.
Some even made edits of their own to mock the artwork.
Others used their creative talents to completely redesign the album cover.
But there were some that appreciated Del Reyâ€™s lack of production in regards to her album cover.
We will have to wait until 4th July to see if the actual music lives up to the fanâ€™s expectations.

title: Lana Del Rey Announces Another New Album, Blue Bannisters
content:
Photo: WireImage
Lana Del Rey has seemingly revealed the title of her upcoming album, Blue Bannisters, which will drop on July 4, according to her Twitter and Instagram. Lana had previously announced a new record called Rock Candy Sweet, slated for a June 1 release, a day after her seventh studio album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, dropped. Itâ€™s unclear if Rock Candy Sweet was a different working title of Lanaâ€™s upcoming album, or if itâ€™s the first single off of Blue Bannisters, or if itâ€™s another album entirely. The singer shared the announcement of Blue Bannisters alongside the same grainy selfie she used for the Rock Candy Sweet announcement, albeit with a different filter. Itâ€™s all incoherent and mysterious and thus very much in line with the Del Rey ethos.
