title: Barrie-James' 'Riverside,' Feat. Lana Del Rey: Video Premiere
content:
Thatâ€™s certainly true with â€œRiverside,â€ a somber piano ballad featuring former girlfriend Lana Del Rey. The song, as subdued as it is musically, offers an upbeat message of support lyrically, as Del Rey sings, â€œIâ€™m up a creek and youâ€™re my paddle.â€ Similar to the three Barrie-James tracks that appear on Del Reyâ€™s new album, Blue Banisters, â€œRiversideâ€ was recorded nearly a decade ago, in 2012, and closes out the set. Barrie-James felt it complemented the other songs on the project. â€œThis album needed a song that stood out from the others, and â€˜Riverside,â€™ because of its moody piano sullen sound, made it really stand out,â€ he tells Billboard. Barrie-James wrote the song in Glasgow in 2012 -- or channeled it. â€œI wanted to write a piano line that made me weep and the universe gifted me this song,â€ he says. He and Del Rey recorded it at Los Angelesâ€™ Nightbird Studios in 2012 when they were dating. Leaked versions of the demo have circulated on YouTube since 2015, but the official video of the revamped song premieres below.
For its inclusion on Strange Desire, â€œI wanted to add pedal steel strings and some guitar to make 'Riverside' hit harder. The bulk of this album was recorded live on either the 12-string acoustic or the six-string guitar, so I felt â€˜Riversideâ€™ being a piano duet song fit nicely as the closer and Lanaâ€™s vocals on it really make it work.â€ The album also features â€œCountry 33,â€ a duet with Vacancy Records labelmate Ashley Campbell, daughter of the late Glen Campbell, that recalls classic country duets of the late '60s and early '70s between Nancy Sinatra and Lee Hazelwood or Johnny Cash and June Carter Cash -- an era before Oâ€™Neill was born. Barrie-James and Del Rey previously covered the Sinatra/Hazelwood 1967 hit â€œSummer Wine.â€

title: Lana Del Rey Sets New Record for Most No. 1 Alternative Albums
content:
Lana Del Rey has set a new record today as the artist with the most No. 1 albums on Billboardâ€™s Alternative Albums chart, Billboard reports. Her new album Blue Banisters is her sixth to achieve that chart position. It also breaks her out of a previous three-way tie with Foo Fighters and Coldplay, who have both had five career No. 1 albums on the chart. Blue Banisters is Lanaâ€™s second album to achieve that top spot this year after her March release Chemtrails Over the Country Club.
Read Pitchforkâ€™s feature â€œLife, Liberty, and the Pursuit of Happiness: A Conversation With Lana Del Rey.â€

title: Lana Del Rey Sets Record for Most Alternative Albums No. 1s
content:
'Blue Banisters' launches as her sixth leader.
Lana Del Rey claims the record for the most No. 1s in the history of Billboard's Alternative Albums chart all to herself, as Blue Banisters debuts atop the survey dated Nov. 6, marking her sixth leader.
The set, released Oct. 22, starts with 33,000 equivalent album units earned in the Oct. 22-28 tracking week, according to MRC Data.
With six rulers, Del Rey breaks out of a three-way tie with Coldplay and Foo Fighters for the most No. 1s ever on Alternative Albums, which began in 2007.

title: Stevie Nicks Said Singing on This Lana Del Rey Song 'Changed Me Forever'
content:
Stevie Nicks provided guest vocals on one of Lana Del Reyâ€™s songs. During an interview, Nicks revealed why the song changed her forever. Notably, Del Rey said she had a strong reaction to the song as well.
Stevie Nicks | Richard McCaffrey/Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images
What Lana Del Rey thought of Stevie Nicks after working with the Fleetwood Mac singer on a song
Del Reyâ€™s albums donâ€™t feature too many collaborations. Despite this, her album Lust for Life features an all-star cast of guest stars. Nicks, The Weeknd, Playboi Carti, Sean Ono Lennon, and ASAP Rocky all appear on songs from the eclectic album. The album blends old and new styles just as the guest list includes musicians from different generations.
During an interview with KROQ, Del Rey talked about Nicks. The â€œBorn to Dieâ€ singer said Nicks kept up to date on all the new music. Del Rey also said Nicks lived up to her reputation and brought a new dimension to the song they worked on together.
RELATED: Stevie Nicks Didnâ€™t Want to Record This Song That Became a Hit for Tom Petty
What Stevie Nicks thought of the song
The song in question was called â€œBeautiful People, Beautiful Problems.â€ Itâ€™s a slow piano ballad that couldâ€™ve just as easily worked as an album track on a Fleetwood Mac album or one of Nicksâ€™ solo albums. During an interview with V Magazine, Nicks and Del Rey discussed â€œBeautiful People, Beautiful Problems.â€ Nicks had many kind things to say about Del Rey.
â€œYou have a beautiful voice and Iâ€™ve already learned things to add to how I sing from you,â€ Nicks said. â€œWorking on your song has changed me forever because Iâ€™ve learned from you. We are witchy sisters and thatâ€™s it. Thatâ€™s where â€˜Beautiful People, Beautiful Problemsâ€™ comes from, because we are trying to ride above all the problems and have hope in everything else, but itâ€™s still a world filled with problems no matter how hard we try to change it.â€
RELATED: Stevie Nicks Was Told She Couldnâ€™t Perform This Song Because It Was a â€˜Manâ€™s Songâ€™
Del Rey revealed her reaction to â€œBeautiful People, Beautiful Problems.â€ â€œIâ€™m so proud of the song that we did, â€˜Beautiful People, Beautiful Problems,'â€ she said. â€œI just love your performance on it. The people reading probably donâ€™t know that you know my longtime producer Rick Nowels from high school, basically.â€
The way the world reacted to Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜Beautiful People, Beautiful Problemsâ€™
Del Rey never released â€œBeautiful People, Beautiful Problemsâ€ as a single. It never charted on the Billboard Hot 100. On the other hand, Lust for Life was a massive hit. It peaked at No. 1 on the Billboard 200, staying on the chart for 22 weeks.
RELATED: Stevie Nicks Didnâ€™t Tell Lindsey Buckingham Who Fleetwood Macâ€™s â€˜Landslideâ€™ Was About Until Years Later
The Official Charts Company reports â€œBeautiful People, Beautiful Problemsâ€ did not chart in the United Kingdom either. title: Termina noivado de Lana Del Rey
content:
Foto: ReproduÃ§Ã£o/Instagram/lanadelpictures
Lana Del Rey estÃ¡ solteira novamente, segundo informou o jornal inglÃªs Sunday Mirror. A cantora ficou noiva em dezembro passado do namorado, o guitarrista Clayton Johnson, meses depois de se conhecerem por meio de um aplicativo de namoro.
Mas, agora eles decidiram seguir caminhos separados devido Ã s pressÃµes da pandemia do coronavÃ­rus, de acordo com fontes.
â€œEla estÃ¡ trabalhando no novo Ã¡lbum. Com o lockdown ela teve suas lutas e infelizmente eles seguiram caminhos separadosâ€, disse um informante Ã  publicaÃ§Ã£o.
Clayton compartilhou uma foto deles juntos no Instagram em fevereiro, mas a imagem agora foi removida de sua conta.
DEIXANDO AS REDES SOCIAIS
Em setembro a cantora decidiu desativar suas contas nas redes sociais, e explicou sua decisÃ£o:
â€œOi pessoal, eu sÃ³ queria que vocÃªs soubessem que amanhÃ£ iremos desativar nossas contas de mÃ­dia social, minhas contas de mÃ­dia social. Isso Ã© simplesmente porque tenho tantos interesses e outros trabalhos que faÃ§o que exigem privacidade e transparÃªnciaâ€, avisou.
Lana garantiu aos fÃ£s que continuarÃ¡ trabalhando em seus Ã¡lbuns de mÃºsica, poesia e palavra falada, mas tambÃ©m â€˜farÃ¡ alguns empreendimentos diferentesâ€™.
Veja+: Lana Del Rey fica de fora do Lollapalooza 2022
Ela acrescentou: â€œAinda estou muito presente e amo o que faÃ§o. Estou absolutamente aqui pela mÃºsica.â€, garantiu.
A cantora de â€˜Born to Dieâ€™ ofereceu a seus fÃ£s um â€˜sincero agradecimentoâ€™ por todo o apoio ao longo dos anos, mas admitiu que estÃ¡ ansiosa para trabalhar em outras coisas fora dos holofotes.
â€œPor enquanto, acho que vou apenas manter meu cÃ­rculo um pouco mais prÃ³ximo e continuar a desenvolver algumas outras habilidades e interesses.â€
LANA DEL REY SE DEFENDE
Lana Del Rey usou seu perfil no Instagram para anunciar seu novo Ã¡lbum, intitulado White Hot Forever. O disco estÃ¡ previsto para ser lanÃ§ado no dia 5 de setembro deste ano. Para dar a notÃ­cia aos fÃ£s, ela fez um textÃ£o para os haters, rebatendo crÃ­ticas que vinha recebendo sobre estar â€˜romantizandoâ€™ relacionamentos abusivos em suas canÃ§Ãµes e poemas.
â€œUma pergunta para a cultura: agora que Doja Cat, Ariana, Camila Cabello, Cardi B, Kehlani, Nicki Minaj e BeyoncÃ© chegaram ao topo das paradas cantando sobre ser sexy, ficar sem roupa, transar, trair, etc â€” serÃ¡ que eu posso voltar a cantar sobre apreciar o prÃ³prio corpo, se sentir linda por estar apaixonada, mesmo que seja um relacionamento imperfeito, danÃ§ar por dinheiro, ou o que quer que seja, sem ser crucificada e acusada de glamorizar abuso?â€, comeÃ§ou ela.
â€œEu estou cansada de escritoras mulheres e cantoras alternativas dizendo que eu glamourizo o abuso, quando na realidade eu sou apenas uma pessoa glamourosa que canta sobre as realidades de relacionamentos abusivos que vemos por toda a parte do mundoâ€, continuou.
â€œCom todos os tÃ³picos que mulheres finalmente tÃªm permissÃ£o de explorar, eu sÃ³ quero dizer que nesses 10 anos eu acho patÃ©tico que pessoas dizem que por causa do meu lirismo mÃ­nimo, detalhando meus papeis Ã s vezes submissos ou passivos nas relaÃ§Ãµes, eu estaria fazendo com que as mulheres retrocedessem 100 anos. Vou deixar claro, eu nÃ£o sou uma feminista, mas precisa haver espaÃ§o no feminismo para pessoas que parecem e agem como eu â€“ o tipo de mulher que fala nÃ£o e os homens escutam sim â€“ o tipo de mulher que Ã© abusada sem piedade por ser autÃªntica e delicada. O tipo de mulher que tem sua histÃ³ria e voz silenciada por mulheres mais fortes, ou por homens que odeiam mulheresâ€, afirmou.
â€œEu tenho sido otimista e honesta sobre as relaÃ§Ãµes desafiadores que eu tive. Mas olha sÃ³! Ã‰ como Ã© para muitas outras mulheres. E infelizmente foi minha experiÃªncia atÃ© essas mÃºsicas serem feitas. E foram 10 longos anos de comentÃ¡rios negativos sobre isso, atÃ© recentemente eu aprender muito com isso. Mas eu acredito que realmente tenho aberto caminho para mulheres pararem de â€˜colocar um sorriso no rostoâ€™ e serem capazes de falar sobre o que quiserem em suas mÃºsicas, diferente de mim, que sÃ³ por expressar notas de tristeza em minhas primeiras duas mÃºsicas, fui colocada como se estivesse histÃ©rica em 1920â€, finalizou.
Depois, informou sobre seus prÃ³ximos projetos nos quais estÃ¡ trabalhando: dois livros de poesia e seu novo Ã¡lbum.

title: Lana del Rey ha roto con su prometido, Clayton Johnson, a quien conociÃ³ en una 'app' de citas
content:
No se ha sabido hasta ahora porque la discreciÃ³n con la que ha llevado su vida privada ha sido encomiable, asÃ­ como que cuando ha sido noticia ha sido por su mÃºsica, dado que este aÃ±o ya ha sacado dos Ã¡lbumes. Pero lo cierto es que Lana del Rey ha vivido este aÃ±o un triste episodio: ha cortado con Clayton Johnson, el hombre que conociÃ³ por una aplicaciÃ³n para citas y que llegÃ³ a ser su prometido.
El pasado diciembre, en 2020, apenas unos meses despuÃ©s de que Lana rompiese con su anterior novio, Sean Larkin, el policÃ­a influencer y de que ambos se conociesen a travÃ©s de una app, la autora de Ã©xitos como Summertime Sadness, Norman fucking Rockewell o Young and Beautiful y el tambiÃ©n mÃºsico Johnson se comprometÃ­an y ella enseÃ±aba y presumÃ­a orgullosa de su anillo.
Pero ahora parece que ese amor ha durado mÃ¡s bien poco. Por un lado, Lana del Rey se ha quitado todas sus redes sociales en septiembre, lo que impide un seguimiento mÃ¡s o menos notable de su vida privada, asegurando que la razÃ³n era que querÃ­a centrarse en "diferentes proyectos", como el disco que acaba de salir a la luz, Blue Banisters, el segundo este aÃ±o tras el lanzamiento en marzo de Chemtrails over the Country Club.
Por otro lado, Clayton, de 32 aÃ±os, cuatro menos que la artista, ha borrado la Ãºnica fotografÃ­a de ellos dos juntos que habÃ­a en su Instagram y que publicÃ³ en febrero. Esta noticia solo la sabÃ­a su cÃ­rculo mÃ¡s cercano, razÃ³n por la cual no ha trascendido hasta ahora.
Una fuente del diario britÃ¡nico The Mirror ha explicado que las razones de esta separaciÃ³n han sido, sobre todo, las tensiones generadas durante los meses mÃ¡s duros de la pandemia, problemas que se han visto agravados por la necesidad de Lana de centrarse en su carrera musical y anteponer sus nuevos desafÃ­os al amor por Clayton.
"Ella ha estado este tiempo trabajando en el nuevo Ã¡lbum. Con el confinamiento ya tuvieron sus problemas y, lamentablemente, han decidido tomar caminos separados", ha explicado el informante, asÃ­ como que Clayton tambiÃ©n ha decidido alejarse de las redes sociales durante el duelo por la ruptura, sobre todo porque en su Ãºltimo disco, Lana del Rey hace referencia a su apetencia por tener novio y no por ese hombre que ahora mismo solo puede mirarla "en sus sueÃ±os".

title: Drake, Lana Del Rey & Elton John in Billboard 200 Top 10
content:
Plus, Lana Del Rey and Elton John debut in the top 10.
Drake's Certified Lover Boy returns to No. 1 on the Billboard 200 albums chart (dated Nov. 6) for a fifth nonconsecutive week on top, as the set rebounds from No. 2. It earned 74,000 equivalent album units (down 10%) in the U.S. in the week ending Oct. 28, according to MRC Data.
Plus, Lana Del Rey's Blue Banisters debuts at No. 8 on the Billboard 200, marking her eighth top 10 album, and Elton John's The Lockdown Sessions launches at No. 10, starting as his 21st top 10 and granting him a span of over 50 years of appearing in the chart's top tier.
The Billboard 200 chart ranks the most popular albums of the week in the U.S. based on multi-metric consumption as measured in equivalent album units. Units comprise album sales, track equivalent albums (TEA) and streaming equivalent albums (SEA). Each unit equals one album sale, or 10 individual tracks sold from an album, or 3,750 ad-supported or 1,250 paid/subscription on-demand official audio and video streams generated by songs from an album. The new, Nov. 6, 2021-dated chart (on which Certified returns to No. 1) will post in full on billboard.com Nov. 2. For all chart news, follow @billboard and @billboardcharts on both Twitter and Instagram.

title: Obongjayar, Jlin, Lana Del Rey, and More: This Weekâ€™s Pitchfork Selects Playlist
content:
The staff of Pitchfork listens to a lot of new music. A lot of it. On any given day our writers, editors, and contributors go through an imposing number of new releases, giving recommendations to each other and discovering new favorites along the way. Each Monday, with our Pitchfork Selects playlist, weâ€™re sharing what our writers are playing obsessively and highlighting some of the Pitchfork staffâ€™s favorite new music. The playlist is a grab-bag of tracks: Its only guiding principle is that these are the songs youâ€™d gladly send to a friend.
This weekâ€™s Pitchfork Selects playlist features Obongjayar, Jlin, Lana Del Rey, Fiyahdred, and more. Listen below and follow our playlists on Apple Music and Spotify. (Pitchfork earns a commission from purchases made through affiliate links on our site.)

content:

Som vanlig handler det om trÃ¸blete kjÃ¦rlighet, partnerproblemer og en ellers, tilsynelatende, uutholdelig grÃ¥ hverdag. Ikke overraskende forsterket av bÃ¥ten vi alle har befunnet oss i det siste halvannet Ã¥ret.
Â«Grenadine quarantine, I like you a lotIt's L.A., "Hey" on Zoom, Target parking lot / And if this is the end, I want a boyfriend / Someone to eat ice cream with and watch television / Or walk home from the mall with 'Cause what I really meant is when I'm being honest / I'm tired of this shitÂ»
Selv om hun synger om relaterbare problemstilling, er hun sitt sedvanlig distanserte selv, om enn noe mindre glamorÃ¸s i uttrykket.
Sparsommelig instrumentering
OppfÃ¸lgeren til Â«Chemtrails Over the Country ClubÂ» er mer sparsommelig arrangementsmessig. Hun er stort sett mer eller mindre alene med flygelet. Den tidvis prangende instrumenteringen fra tidligere glimrer med sitt fravÃ¦r her.

BÃ¥de Â«Text BookÂ», Â«Black Bathing SuiteÂ» og tittelkuttet, Â«Blue BanistersÂ» er alle gÃ¥tefulle, mÃ¸rkromantiske stykker som lÃ¸ser seg opp som en brusende dispril i et vannglass, og siver ut i Ã¥rene dine med sin sedative kraft. Akkompagnert av tekstlinjer som er klare i talen, men som du aldri vet helt hva du skal lese inn i.
MÃ¸rk humor
Denne dualiteten mellom gravalvor og potensiell mÃ¸rk humor er noe av det som gjÃ¸r henne uhÃ¥ndgripelig og fascinerende. I tillegg har hun sitt helt sÃ¦regne tonesprÃ¥k som gir henne en unikhet som gjÃ¸r at hun ikke slutter Ã¥ begeistre. HÃ¸r bare avsluttende, Â«Sweet CarolinaÂ».

Lâ€™esthÃ©tique Lana Del Rey se rapporte dâ€™abord et avant tout Ã  sa musique. Blue Banisters sonne comme un ramassis de toutes les chansons que Lana Del Rey a Ã©crites au cours des derniÃ¨res annÃ©es et qui ont Ã©tÃ© Ã©cartÃ©es de peu des albums quâ€™elle a fait paraÃ®tre. Et quel magnifique ramassis ! Il nâ€™y a aucune unitÃ©, aucune rÃ©elle cohÃ©rence, sur ce disque. Pourtant, la plupart des piÃ¨ces, individuellement, parviennent Ã  franchement nous convaincre.
On trouve sur Blue Banisters du Lana Del Rey de toutes les Ã©poques. Les ballades au piano ne manquent pas, les refrains mÃ©lancoliques et la touche cinÃ©matographique non plus. Mais Ã  lâ€™Ã©coute des paroles, on sent une envie dâ€™Ãªtre plus ancrÃ©e dans ce qui lâ€™entoure et non plus seulement dans ce que lâ€™amour lui fait subir. La mention de Black Lives Matter sur la gÃ©niale Textbook semble quelque peu forcÃ©e, mais on accorde quelques points pour lâ€™effort.
0:00 0:00 Couper le son
Ce huitiÃ¨me album de Lana Del Rey en 10 ans amÃ¨ne surtout un cÃ´tÃ© autobiographique qui semble plus authentique que jamais. Câ€™est peut-Ãªtre pour cela que les genres se mÃ©langent, parce quâ€™on nous raconte des Ã©poques et que la musique Ã©volue au fil du rÃ©cit. La plume de Lana Del Rey fait de nouveau des ravages.

title: Albumanmeldelse Lana del Rey - "Blue banisters": Steinway to heaven
content:
SUR OG ALENE: Lana del Rey synger ikke om maling som tÃ¸rker. Bare nesten
Albumanmeldelse Lana del Rey â€“ Â«Blue banistersÂ»: Steinway to heaven
Lana del Rey er bare seg selv, hjemme ved klaveret.
Av Tor Martin BÃ¸e
Publisert: For mindre enn 20 minutter siden
Lana del Rey sitt Ã¥ttende album er en skuffelse. I alle fall pÃ¥ papiret. Her er ikke en eneste smart lÃ¥ttittel.
Albumnavnet i seg selv er noe sÃ¥ hverdagslig som malte gjerdestolper, eller hva man nÃ¥ skal oversette banisters med. Coveret er Lana, et malt gjerde og to schÃ¤fere.
Bak den hverdagslige tittelen skjuler det seg noe sÃ¥ ordinÃ¦rt som et klaverdrevet album om Ã¥ vÃ¦re hjemme.
Slik vi alle har vÃ¦rt. Og for fÃ¸rste gang kan man faktisk kjenne seg igjen i Lana del Rey: Glamouren er borte. Hverdagsstillheten har tatt over.
For eksempel pÃ¥ Â«Black Bathing SuitÂ», en seig, drÃ¸mmende (en pleonasme i denne sammenhengen, ja visst) Lana del Rey-lÃ¥t. Med dumsmarte tekstlinjer som Â«If this is the end, I want a boyfriendÂ».
Slikt bare Lana del Rey kan lire av seg og samtidig fremstÃ¥ smart og nonchalant. Samtidig som hun bÃ¥de parafraserer sin egen Â«National AnthemÂ» og sluttsekvensen til Â«Rocky Horror Picture ShowÂ».
Â«DealerÂ» er den eneste stedet som koker over av bÃ¥de utagerende aggresjon og indre irritasjon. I et passe lugnt Sergei Gainsbourg-arrangement. Flere lÃ¥ter holder sÃ¥ mye tilbake at man virkelig skal nÃ¦rlytte for Ã¥ sette pris pÃ¥ nyansene.
Slik blir Â«Blue BanistersÂ» en utgivelse for de som virkelig lytter. Superfansen som kanskje lurer pÃ¥ hvordan hun egentlig har hatt det i pandemien. Som likevel ikke vil finne et eneste seriÃ¸st svar her. Men det finnes her. Godt gjemt.
En sentral del er at Â«Blue BanistersÂ» er samtids-Lana. En annen del er at det muligens er pÃ¥ tide Ã¥ anerkjenne Lana del Rey som en seriÃ¸st produktiv artist, som ikke alltid treffer virkelig blink, sÃ¥ som med Â«Norman Fucking RockwellÂ». Men som heller ikke skaper noe virkelig hÃ¥plÃ¸st.
Hadde man hadde slÃ¥tt sammen marsutgivelsen Â«Chemtrails Over the Country ClubÂ» med denne, hadde man fÃ¥tt en fantastisk oppfÃ¸lger til karrierehÃ¸ydepunktet. PÃ¥ samme vis som Taylor Swift toppet hjemmesitterÃ¥ret 2020 med Ã¥ gi ut to album som gikk i en helt ny retning.
I stedet mÃ¥ vi ta til takke med den Joni Mitchell-klingende Â«Sweet CarolinaÂ», med tekstlinjer som hos de fleste andre hadde fremstÃ¥tt som en parodi: Â«You name your babe Lilac Heaven/ After your iPhone 11Â».
Det er pÃ¥ ingen mÃ¥te genialt.
Men det er hundre prosent Lana del Rey.

title: Lana Del Rey Is Gentle But Defiant on 'Blue Banisters': Album Review
content:
Arriving a mere seven months after â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ all signs pointed to Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€œBlue Banistersâ€ being a companion piece. Proximity, it turns out, is all they have in common. While â€œChemtrailsâ€ found Del Rey channeling singer-songwriters of yesteryear with dreamy Laurel Canyon musings, her latest is imbued with an urgency to reclaim her own narrative, anchoring it in the here and now. She does this by piecing together a musical autobiography that documents family ties, friendships, love affairs, her connection with Los Angeles and even the interpretation of her art.
Del Rey made her intentions clear from the outset. â€œIâ€™m writing my own story,â€ she tweeted, while first teasing â€œBlue Banistersâ€ in April. â€œAnd no one can tell it but me.â€ Her need to set the record straight stems from a spate of negative articles that attacked everything from her brand of feminism to her choice in face masks. Feeling the need to explain herself has resulted in a transparency that makes the album an outlier in Del Reyâ€™s discography. She has always been an expert world-builder, but never has one of them felt as lived-in and true.
â€œText Book,â€ the album opener, addresses two recurring themes in Del Reyâ€™s work: her absent father and resulting daddy issues. Only this isnâ€™t a simple exercise in self-therapy. The artist actively joins the dots, showing the causal relationship between the two as well as her inability to undo that emotional programming. For someone accused of wallowing in misery (she addresses that accusation directly on the aptly titled â€œBeautifulâ€), â€œText Bookâ€ offers hope â€” however faint â€” that something healthier is, in fact, possible. The song is also notable for its very modern setting. â€œThere we were, screaminâ€™ â€˜Black Lives Matterâ€™ in the crowd,â€ she sings in the chorus, the first of many references carbon-dating the album to 2020-21.
The most notable example is perhaps â€œBlack Bathing Suit,â€ a sprawling, five-minute master class in self-analysis and observation. On it, Del Rey mentions quarantine, Zoom and Target parking lots in the same verse before alluding to lockdown weight gain. â€œThe only thing that still fits me is this black bathing suit,â€ she memorably quips on the pre-chorus. â€œBlack Bathing Suitâ€ is also notable for its dizzying production, which reflects an ambition and willingness to experiment sonically â€” the song closes with a literal growl that would make Samuel T. Herring proud â€” not seen since 2015â€™s vastly underrated â€œHoneymoon.â€
â€œViolets for Rosesâ€ is another time capsule of pandemic life. â€œThe girls are runninâ€™ â€™round in summer dresses, with their masks off and it makes me so happy,â€ Del Rey begins the track. â€œLarchmont Village smells like lilies of the valley.â€ The setting is idyllic, but the relationship presented is quite the opposite. However, instead of succumbing to the allure of self-destruction, â€œViolets For Rosesâ€ is about peeling yourself away from a toxic situation â€” making it another rebuttal of the claim that she glamorizes darkness and despair.
She continues with that theme on the â€œMr. Brightsideâ€-referencing â€œThunderâ€ by presenting a cratering love affair that morphs into a cautionary tale. â€œIf hello just means goodbye then, baby, better walk away,â€ she advises. Perhaps the most evolved and philosophical rumination on love is the Mike Dean-produced â€œWildflower Wildfire.â€ Built on wisdom born from mistakes, the song captures the realization that love can be nurtured but never guaranteed. Itâ€™s hopeful in a world-weary kind of way. These are no longer the musings of an ingenue, but rather a grown woman who understands that happiness is fleeting.
While the references are timely, the themes are timeless. The achingly lovely title track is an ode to female friendship, while â€œArcadiaâ€ unravels Del Reyâ€™s borderline-spiritual affinity with Los Angeles. She not only feels inspired by the City of Angels, but also sees herself reflected in the jagged geography and accumulation of lost souls looking for something. Itâ€™s Del Reyâ€™s poetic way of repudiating the statement that she has hidden behind a persona. The singer-songwriter might not be a Cali girl by birth, but its influence upon her is genuine and profound.
The albumâ€™s scrapbook-like approach is underlined by the inclusion of a handful of tracks recorded in 2013 with ex-boyfriend Barrie James Oâ€™Neill. Originally intended for â€œUltraviolence,â€ the songs â€œIf You Lie Down With Meâ€ and â€œNectar of the Godsâ€ have found their perfect home on â€œBlue Banisters.â€ Instead of describing her personal history, Del Rey literally shares a piece of it. The experience is something akin to reading old love letters: intimate and deeply affecting. â€œCherry Blossom,â€ another unearthed demo, this time co-written by long-time collaborator Rick Nowels, is a lilting lullaby that segues perfectly into the moving album-closer.
Co-written with her sister and father, â€œSweet Carolinaâ€ finds Del Rey singing to an unborn child â€” complete with references to crypto currency and an iPhone 11. Itâ€™s the kind of lyrical potluck that is quintessentially her own. â€œBlue Banistersâ€ might lack the majesty of â€œNorman Fucking Rockwellâ€ or the commercial sheen of â€œBorn To Die,â€ but it offers a rare glimpse of an artist securing her legacy, one song at a time.

content:

Schwere Klavierakkorde, dann sÃ¤uselt Lana Del Rey: â€My body is a map of L.A.â€œ Ihr KÃ¶rper ist also eine Landkarte von Los Angeles, und dann singt sie von ihrer Brust als Sierra Madre und von ihren HÃ¼ften, auf denen sÃ¤mtliche Haupt- und NebenstraÃŸen zu finden seien. Im Video zum Song steht die SÃ¤ngerin im gleiÃŸenden Gegenlicht und fÃ¤hrt mit ihren HÃ¤nden Ã¼ber die besagten KÃ¶rperpartien. Bis sich das Bild verdunkelt und ihr knappes Shirt zur ProjektionsflÃ¤che wird, auf der Autokolonnen im Zeitraffer Ã¼ber einen nÃ¤chtlichen Highway gleiten.
Eine Verschmelzungsfantasie. Das Lied heiÃŸt â€Arcadiaâ€œ. Ar-ca-dia, drei Silben, die Lana Del Rey im Refrain, gebettet auf Geigen und mit Trompeten im fernen Hintergrund, genÃ¼sslich zerdehnt. Am Ende wird aus â€Arcadiaâ€œ dann â€Americaâ€œ. Amerika als neues Arkadien, als Traumlandschaft, in der sich SehnsÃ¼chte erfÃ¼llen. Klingt Ã¼berkandidelt und ist vielleicht auch nicht so gemeint, weil es in â€Arcadiaâ€œ wohl noch mehr um einen Mann geht. Nach seinen BerÃ¼hrungen sehnt sich die SÃ¤ngerin. Die Wege, die zu ihm fÃ¼hren, sind fÃ¼r sie â€wie Arterienâ€œ.
Ãœberkandidelte Metaphern
â€Arcadiaâ€œ gehÃ¶rt zu den bemerkenswertesten Songs auf Lana Del Reys achtem Studioalbum â€Blue Banistersâ€œ, das am Freitag erschienen ist. Dabei hatte die 36-jÃ¤hrige SÃ¤ngerin erst im MÃ¤rz ihre Platte â€Chemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€œ verÃ¶ffentlicht, bei der sie einen ironischen Abgesang auf die Trump-Ã„ra mit Einblicken in ihr Seelenleben verband.
â€Blue Banistersâ€œ knÃ¼pft an den Folkpop des VorgÃ¤ngers an und ist ihr bislang autobiografischstes Werk. Seit sie 2011 mit ihrer lasziven Hymne â€Video Gamesâ€œ zum Star wurde, ist Elizabeth Grant â€“ so ihr bÃ¼rgerlicher Name â€“ vorgeworfen worden, eine MÃ¤nnerfantasie und eine Antifeministin zu sein.
Auch mangelnde SolidaritÃ¤t mit afroamerikanischen Kolleginnen ist ihr vorgehalten worden. Vor Erscheinen von â€Blue Banistersâ€œ hat sie sich fÃ¼r mehrere Wochen aus den sozialen Medien zurÃ¼ckgezogen. Im Video des Titelsongs streicht sie das GelÃ¤nder eines Landhauses. Auf dem Albumcover zeigt sie sich mit ihren beiden SchÃ¤ferhunden.
Traumauto Ford Thunderbird
Mit einem grummelnden Bass und hellen GlockenschlÃ¤gen setzt das AuftaktstÃ¼ck â€Text Bookâ€œ ein, das von einer gescheiterten Beziehung handelt. Es geht um einen Mann, den sie sich ausgesucht hatte, weil er ihrem Vater Ã¤hnelte. Er besaÃŸ sogar dasselbe Auto wie der Vater: den Ford Thunderbird, einen Klassiker des US-Fahrzeugbaus. Zusammen mit dem Geliebten habe sie â€Black Lives Matterâ€œ bei einer Demonstration skandiert. MutmaÃŸlich ist die Rede von Del Reys Ex-Verlobten Clayton Johnson, von dem sie sich im Sommer trennte.
[Wenn Sie aktuelle Nachrichten aus Berlin, Deutschland und der Welt live auf Ihr Handy haben wollen, empfehlen wir Ihnen unsere App, die Sie hier fÃ¼r Apple- und Android-GerÃ¤te herunterladen kÃ¶nnen.]
â€Donâ€™t tell me to be glad when Iâ€™m sadâ€œ, ruft die SÃ¤ngerin in â€Beautifulâ€œ dem Verflossenen hinterher, einer minimalistischen Klavierballade, die in Trauer badet. Und im von herrlichem Getrommel begleiteten Song â€Black Bathing Suitâ€œ wÃ¼nscht sie einen Boyfriend herbei, mit dem sie Eis vorm Fernsehen essen kann. Wieder eine Bilanz, diesmal des kalorienreichen Lockdowns. Ihr Badeanzug sei das eigene KleidungsstÃ¼ck, das ihr noch passt.
[â€Blue Banistersâ€œ ist bei Polydor/Universal erschienen]
Auch vom Produzenten Jack Antonoff, mit dem sie ihr bestes Album â€Norman Fucking Rockwell!â€œ aufnahm, hat Lana Del Rey sich getrennt. Wichtigster Kollaborateur war nun Zach Dawes, Bassist der Last Shadow Puppets, die Ã¤hnlich nostalgisch im pompÃ¶sen Pop der Sixties schwelgen. Die summend intonierte Folkhymne â€Nectar of the Godsâ€œ kÃ¶nnte auch von Crosby, Stills & Nash stammen, der Countrywalzer â€If You Lie Down With Meâ€œ endet mit frÃ¶hlich trÃ¶tenden New- Orleans-Jazztrompeten.
Das musikalisch interessanteste StÃ¼ck auf â€Blue Banistersâ€œ heiÃŸt â€Dealerâ€œ, eine schwebend schÃ¶ne, von Bass und BeckenschlÃ¤gen getragene Hommage an den Soulrock der Siebziger. Lana Del Rey teilt sich das Mikrofon mit Miles Kane von den Last Shadow Puppets und treibt ihren Gesang in furienhaft kreischenden Zorn.

Sie beginnen mit zaghaften Klavierakkorden, dann setzt der flÃ¼sternd-schlÃ¤frige Gesang ein. Im letzten Song â€Sweet Carolinaâ€œ wird Lana Del Rey von ihrem Vater Rob Grant am Piano begleitet. Es ist ein StÃ¤ndchen fÃ¼r ihre Schwester, die vor kurzem Mutter wurde.

title: Lana Del Rey se firma como poeta millennial do apocalipse em disco
content:
Lana Del Rey se firma como poeta millennial do apocalipse em disco
Cantora que despontou com pop retrÃ´ e modorrento canta a melancolia dos anos Trump e da pandemia em 'Blue Banisters'
Em "Arcadia", Lana Del Rey apresenta seu corpo como o mapa de Los Angeles, enquanto fala de suas curvas como se fossem a serra de San Gabriel, e de suas artÃ©rias como as estradas que levam atÃ© a cidade que dÃ¡ nome Ã  mÃºsica. Ela se diz uma "garotinha perdida", e busca algum tipo de fuga de um perÃ­odo turbulento.
NÃ£o Ã© possÃ­vel saber se essa turbulÃªncia Ã© o ano e meio de pandemia, a era Trump ou apenas um relacionamento mal-sucedido. Fato Ã© que, em seu novo disco, "Blue Banisters", Lana Del Rey parece sentir que o mundo ao seu redor vai acabar a qualquer momento, indo mais a fundo no retrato melancÃ³lico e sarcÃ¡stico da decadÃªncia americana que marcou os seus Ãºltimos discos.
"Se este Ã© o fim, quero um namorado", ela canta em "Black Bathing Suit", canÃ§Ã£o que dÃ¡ o tom do Ã¡lbum, conforme ela descreve um momento de isolamento social, usando o Zoom, bebendo granadina e em que "a Ãºnica coisa que continua cabendo em mim Ã© meu roupÃ£o preto". Del Rey encara a incompatibilidade de um relacionamento enquanto fala freudianamente sobre problemas paternos.
"Blue Banisters", o segundo disco lanÃ§ado pela cantora neste ano, funciona quase como um complemento do antecessor, "Chemtrails Over the Country Club". Desta vez, ela trata um pouco mais de questÃµes pessoais, em faixas que parecem ter sido todas feitas durante o perÃ­odo de isolamento da pandemia.
Se em "Norman Fucking Rockwell", de 2019, a desilusÃ£o era com a era Trump nos Estados Unidos, agora a pandemia Ã© mais um ingrediente no apocalipse iminente que ronda a estÃ©tica de Del Rey. Mas a capacidade da compositora de capturar a melancolia millennial americana parece intacta.
Desde 2012, quando se mudou de Nova York para a CalifÃ³rnia â€“estado que transformou em uma espÃ©cie de musa em sua obraâ€“ e despontou na mÃºsica, Del Rey nunca foi tÃ£o levada a sÃ©rio. No comeÃ§o, era tratada como uma espÃ©cie de piada, enquanto estourava com o pop retrÃ´ e modorrento de mÃºsicas como "Video Games" e declaraÃ§Ãµes polÃªmicas na imprensa.
Em 2017, para "Lust for Life", ela tentou se enquadrar numa sonoridade eletrÃ´nica mais moderna, com acenos para o trap e colaboraÃ§Ãµes com rappers como A$AP Rocky e Playboi Carti. Mas foi no trabalho seguinte, "Norman Fucking Rockwell", que ela enfim ganhou o aval da crÃ­tica, foi indicada ao prÃªmio de Ã¡lbum do ano no Grammy e passou a ser respeitada enquanto compositora.
Ã‰ como se do glamour melancÃ³lico e hedonista, da vida selvagem e dos excessos dos primeiros discos, tivesse sobrado apenas a melancolia, a poesia e o sarcasmo. De certa forma, a desilusÃ£o tambÃ©m acompanha boa parte de seu pÃºblico, que tambÃ©m cresceu e, quase dez anos depois, vÃª apenas a sombra de uma vida libertina e cheia de esperanÃ§as.
Com o Ã¡lbum de 2019, Del Rey foi alÃ§ada ao posto de compositora que melhor captou a angÃºstia dos Ãºltimos anos nos Estados Unidos. De fato, cheio de ironias, bom humor e referÃªncias Ã  cultura pop do paÃ­s, o Ã¡lbum traz personagens perdidos e encapsula o sentimento de estar vivo em meio aos destroÃ§os de um glamour de outrora.
Os versos de "The Greatest" sÃ£o os que mais bem representam o momento. "E eu estou perdida/ NÃ£o vÃ¡ embora, eu sÃ³ preciso que alguÃ©m me dÃª uma real/ Estou encarando a maior/ A maior perda de todas/ A cultura Ã© incrÃ­vel e, se for sÃ³ isso mesmo, eu tive meu momento/ Mas acho que estou exausta depois de tudo/ Se for sÃ³ isso, vou despedindo [...] Los Angeles estÃ¡ em chamas, estÃ¡ ficando quente/ Kanye West estÃ¡ loiro e esquecido/ 'Life On Mars' nÃ£o Ã© apenas uma mÃºsica/ Ah, a live estÃ¡ quase comeÃ§ando."
Nos dois trabalhos seguintes, Lana expande esse sentimento de desilusÃ£o sarcÃ¡stica. "White Dress", principal faixa de "Chemtrails Over the Country Club", ela soa nostÃ¡lgica enquanto canta sobre uma jovem garÃ§onete que trabalha no turno da noite. Em meio a sussurros e uma melodia crescente, lembra de bons momentos do passado â€“ela tem 36 anosâ€“, como "ouvir White Stripes/ Quando eles estavam bombando/ Ouvir rock o dia inteiro."
Agora, com "Blue Banisters", Del Rey grita que nÃ£o quer viver em "Dealer", condena um homem que tenta mudÃ¡-la em "Violets For Roses" e convida o ouvinte para sua intimidade em "Wildflower Wildfire". "Meu pai nunca fazia nada quando a mulher dele brigava comigo/ EntÃ£o acabei estranha mas doce", ela canta na faixa.
Um tema recorrente da mÃºsica â€“e de todo o discoâ€“ Ã© quando Del Rey tenta controlar seu lado selvagem sem apagÃ¡-lo por completo. E em meio Ã  tristeza latente, hÃ¡ a consciÃªncia de sua capacidade como artista. "E se alguÃ©m pedisse a Picasso para nÃ£o ser triste? Eu nunca saberia quem ele era ou o homem que se tornou", ela canta em "Beautiful", quando diz que consegue transformar dor em beleza.
Musicalmente, "Norman Fucking Rockwell" consegue ser mais completo, apesar de ancorado em melodias de violÃ£o e piano. Os dois Ã¡lbuns mais recentes â€“que certamente seriam mais interessantes caso suas faixas fossem cortadas e unidas em um Ãºnico discoâ€“ mantÃªm o formato piano e voz, cada vez mais no estilo cantautora, mas fazendo com os discos soem maÃ§antes para o ouvinte mais desavisado.
A esta altura da carreira, o apelo de Del Rey estÃ¡ em sua voz peculiar e, principalmente, em suas letras â€“muito mais do que na estÃ©tica no entorno dela. Ao conseguir cantar o sentimento de um tempo, a artista se firma como uma das compositoras mais relevantes dessa decadÃªncia americana, uma espÃ©cie de poeta millennial debochada do fim do mundo.
"Blue Banisters"
Quando: A partir de sexta (22)
Onde: Nas plataformas digitais
Autor: Lana Del Rey
Gravadora: Universal

title: 8 New Albums You Should Listen to Now: Lana Del Rey, Grouper, Helado Negro, and More
content:
With so much good music being released all the time, it can be hard to determine what to listen to first. Every week, Pitchfork offers a run-down of significant new releases available on streaming services. This weekâ€™s batch includes new albums from Lana Del Rey, Grouper, Helado Negro, Hand Habits, Parquet Courts, Circuit des Yeux, Jpegmafia, and Nubya Garcia. Subscribe to Pitchforkâ€™s New Music Friday newsletter to get our recommendations in your inbox every week. (All releases featured here are independently selected by our editors. When you buy something through our affiliate links, however, Pitchfork earns an affiliate commission.)
Lana Del Rey: Blue Banisters [Polydor/Interscope]
Blue Banisters is the second studio album from Lana Del Rey this year, following her March release of Chemtrails Over the Country Club. The record includes â€œTextbookâ€ and â€œWildflower Wildfire,â€ the latter co-written and produced by Mike Dean. Other Blue Banisters contributors include Gabriel Edward Simon, Zachary Dawes, and Drew Erickson. Last month, Del Rey shared a music video for the single â€œArcadia,â€ followed by a visual for â€œBlue Banistersâ€ earlier this week.

Grouper: Shade [Kranky]
Shade is Liz Harrisâ€™ first Grouper LP since 2018â€™s Grid of Points. She recorded the album over the span of 15 years, some of it during a residency at Mount Tamalpais, and some in Portland, while a selection of more recent tracks were laid down in Astoria. She released lead single â€œUnclean mindâ€ upon announcing Shade in July. Last month, Harris released a video for â€œOde to the blue.â€ The visual was directed by Dicky Bahto, and it features an appearance from Julia Holter.

title: "Blue Banisters": Neues Album von Lana Del Rey
content:
Von Joachim Hentschel
WÃ¤re man selbst Lana Del Rey, mÃ¼sste man sich stÃ¤ndig diese elenden Fragen stellen, bei jedem neuen Song, jedem Album oder Video. Diese Grundsatzdinge: Was kann eigentlich als NÃ¤chstes noch kommen? Ist das Konzept mit dem ganzen Hollywood-Hills- und Melancholie-GedÃ¶ns nicht langsam ausgereizt? Vielleicht auch: Ist wieder irgendein Detail dabei, fÃ¼r das die Instagram-Leute sie als Rassistin oder Sexismus-Apologetin beschimpfen werden? Ach, es muss unertrÃ¤glich sein.
Das ist im ersten Moment eines der erfreulichsten BegleitgefÃ¼hle, wenn diese SÃ¤ngerin und Songwriterin wieder ein Werk verÃ¶ffentlicht, wie jetzt, zum bereits zweiten Mal im Jahr 2021: die Erkenntnis, dass wir uns mit all diesen Ãœberlegungen nicht abplagen mÃ¼ssen, weil die KÃ¼nstlerin es fÃ¼r uns tut. Im zweiten Moment bemerkt man sogar noch, dass Lana Del Rey, die oft GeschmÃ¤hte und UnterschÃ¤tzte, mit ihrem neuen, seit 2010 insgesamt achten Album "Blue Banisters" in der Tat wieder ein paar bestechend interessante Antworten auf die Fragen gefunden hat. Und so sehr einem die Vernunft auch sagt, dass es jetzt doch mal reicht mit dem Schwarz-WeiÃŸ-Film-Diva-Haften, dem schwersÃ¼ÃŸen Gehauche und den bedeutungshubernden Amerika-Analogien - am Ende muss man auch diese Platte wieder empfehlen. Vielleicht nicht dringend, aber immerhin.
Die Themen fÃ¼r einen Vier-Minuten-Song: Sprache, Jugend, Rausch, Liebe, Freiheit und motorisierte Fortbewegung
"Banister", das Wort ist nicht sonderlich bekannt, bedeutet GelÃ¤nder, an einer Veranda zum Beispiel. Das Video zum Titelsong zeigt in einer Szene buchstÃ¤blich, wie Lana Del Rey mit einer heiteren Gruppe von Freundinnen dieses GelÃ¤nder streicht, nicht grÃ¼n oder gelb, sondern blau. WomÃ¶glich wird es ja das sein, was ihr die Leute dieses Mal unvorteilhaft auslegen: Blau als die Farbe der rechtskonservativen Blaue-Augen-Verherrlichung oder der Kornblumen, die sich Politiker von AfD und FPÃ– gern anstecken.
Solche Symboltafeln dÃ¼rften allerdings das Letzte sein, worÃ¼ber sich die 36-jÃ¤hrige gebÃ¼rtige New Yorkerin hier Gedanken gemacht hat. Wenn der blaue Lattenzaun auf "Blue Banisters" fÃ¼r irgendetwas steht, dann hÃ¶chstens fÃ¼r die groÃŸe Dilemmafrage, wie sich jegliche Art von konzisem Lebensentwurf mit dem inneren Sturm und Wahnsinn vereinbaren lÃ¤sst, den das kreative Ich erlebt. Ob ein Abgleich zwischen den Welten Ã¼berhaupt noch mÃ¶glich ist, ein Kompromiss zwischen den entfesselten Instinkten des neuzeitlichen Menschen und den tradierten sozialen Formen, denen wir mangels Alternative noch folgen. "I get wild and fucking crazy, like the colour blue", singt Lana Del Rey etwa in "Nectar Of The Gods", und obwohl das StÃ¼ck nur gut vier Minuten lang ist, kommt hier alles zur Sprache, Jugend, Rausch, Liebe, Freiheit, motorisierte Fortbewegung, und natÃ¼rlich auch irgendwie: Kalifornien. Nur um den Tod scheint es nicht zu gehen, doch da kann man sich auch tÃ¤uschen.
Ihren KÃ¶rper beschreibt sie in "Arcadia" als Abbild einer amerikanischen StraÃŸenkarte
Vor rund zehn Jahren wurde Del Rey bekannt, als leicht nachtschattiges, schwermÃ¼tiges Update einer Beverly-Hills-Lady, mit allen eingebauten Uneigentlichkeiten. Sie sang von Blue Jeans und Videospielen, klang fÃ¼r die einen nostalgisch, fÃ¼r die anderen clever ironisch, fÃ¼r die Dritten wie ein Cartoon, wie die Zeichentrickfrau aus "Roger Rabbit". Sie fing sich Kritik dafÃ¼r ein, ein devotes, rÃ¼ckstÃ¤ndiges PÃ¼ppchenbild zu verkÃ¶rpern. Antwortete darauf unter anderem mit den fantastischen Alben "Norman Fucking Rockwell!" und "Chemtrails Over The Country Club", auf denen sie ihr Rollenspiel um Gesten einer SelbstermÃ¤chtigung ergÃ¤nzte, die weit weg war von der Sprache der feministischen Akademie.
Aber was macht sie nun? Zum Beispiel singt sie Ã¼ber ihren KÃ¶rper, beschreibt ihn in "Arcadia" als Abbild einer amerikanischen StraÃŸenkarte: Die BrÃ¼ste sind die Sierra Madre, die HÃ¼fte der Interstate Highway, das GesÃ¤ÃŸ ist die Stadt San Gabriel. Was auf Papier wie ein Herrenwitz klingt, wird bei Lana Del Rey - als gravitÃ¤tische Klavierhymne inklusive durchs Bild wehendem Orchester - zu einer brillanten weiblichen Allmachtsfantasie, einer Art musikalischem Selfie, das jede Pore zeigt. Ein passender Ersatz fÃ¼r die Bilder, die sie Mitte September lÃ¶schte, als sie von einem Tag auf den anderen ihre Social-Media-Konten auflÃ¶ste.
Einigen Ã„rger gab es schon vorab um die Passage im Song "Text Book", in dem sie lapidar den Besuch einer "Black Lives Matter"-Demo beschreibt. So weh es bei derartig brennenden Themen auch tun mag, exakt darum dreht sich so vieles in Lana Del Reys Kunst: um das Leiden an der Bedeutungslosigkeit sozialer Rituale, zu denen am Ende eben auch ein Protestmarsch zÃ¤hlen kann. Um die Suche nach Wahrheit im schillernden Reich der Introversion. Und um die Versuche, mithilfe der dort gewonnenen Erkenntnisse vielleicht doch noch funktionierende Bindungen aufzubauen.
Detailansicht Ã¶ffnen
Selbst musikalisch beginnen sich die Strukturen auf "Blue Banisters" mitunter aufzulÃ¶sen. Ab und zu verliert sich der Rhythmus zwischen Klavier und Hintergrundrauschen, fallen die BackgroundsÃ¤ngerinnen im groÃŸartigen "Black Bathing Suit" herrlich aus ihrer Rolle. In "Dealer", einem Duett mit Miles Kane, rastet Lana Del Rey dann auf eine Art und Weise aus, wie man es noch nicht gehÃ¶rt hat. Und brÃ¼llt die Blue-Velvet-CocktailplÃ¼schbar derart zusammen, dass den GÃ¤sten wohl noch tagelang die Ohren zischen werden.
Aus Verbrauchersicht rangiert "Blue Banisters" vielleicht nicht ganz so hoch wie die vergangenen beiden MeisterstÃ¼cke. Das Album wird in der zweiten HÃ¤lfte etwas gleichfÃ¶rmig, einige Ãœberbleibsel aus alten Sessions wurden angehÃ¤ngt, es zieht sich etwas. Vermutlich wird es irgendwann im RÃ¼ckblick als hybrides Ãœbergangswerk gelten, aber um das zu sagen, mÃ¼sste man wissen, was Lana Del Rey hier noch draufsetzen will. Und die Frage mag man heute wirklich nicht beantworten mÃ¼ssen.

title: Lana Del Rey lanÃ§a segundo Ã¡lbum do ano, Blue Bannisters; ouÃ§a
content:
Lana Del Rey lanÃ§ou hoje (22) o seu oitavo Ã¡lbum de estÃºdio da carreira, Blue Bannisters. O disco Ã© o segundo lanÃ§ado pela cantora em 2021, apÃ³s Chemtrails Over the Country Club (de marÃ§o).
Com 15 faixas ao todo, Bannisters inclui as jÃ¡ lanÃ§adas "Wildflower Wildfire", "Text Book", "Arcadia" e "Blue Bannisters" - ouÃ§a completo abaixo.
No Instagram, Del Rey disse que o novo Ã¡lbum Ã© o resultado de uma "exploraÃ§Ã£o profunda de sua prÃ³pria Ã¡rvore genealÃ³gica", e de seus sentimentos sobre crÃ­ticas que recebeu por "fingir fragilidade" em sua persona pÃºblica.
"Eu devo dizer que tenho amado me mover pelo mundo lindamente - como uma mulher com graÃ§a e dignidade", escreveu no post. Pouco antes do lanÃ§amento do Ã¡lbum, no entanto, Del Rey desativou suas redes sociais.

title: Lana Del Rey se firma como poeta millennial do apocalipse em disco
content:
FOLHAPRESS â€“ Em â€œArcadiaâ€, Lana Del Rey apresenta seu corpo como o mapa de Los Angeles, enquanto fala de suas curvas como se fossem a serra de San Gabriel, e de suas artÃ©rias como as estradas que levam atÃ© a cidade que dÃ¡ nome Ã  mÃºsica. Ela se diz uma â€œgarotinha perdidaâ€, e busca algum tipo de fuga de um perÃ­odo turbulento.
NÃ£o Ã© possÃ­vel saber se essa turbulÃªncia Ã© o ano e meio de pandemia, a era Trump ou apenas um relacionamento mal-sucedido. Fato Ã© que, em seu novo disco, â€œBlue Banistersâ€, Lana Del Rey parece sentir que o mundo ao seu redor vai acabar a qualquer momento, indo mais a fundo no retrato melancÃ³lico e sarcÃ¡stico da decadÃªncia americana que marcou os seus Ãºltimos discos.
â€œSe este Ã© o fim, quero um namoradoâ€, ela canta em â€œBlack Bathing Suitâ€, canÃ§Ã£o que dÃ¡ o tom do Ã¡lbum, conforme ela descreve um momento de isolamento social, usando o Zoom, bebendo granadina e em que â€œa Ãºnica coisa que continua cabendo em mim Ã© meu roupÃ£o pretoâ€. Del Rey encara a incompatibilidade de um relacionamento enquanto fala freudianamente sobre problemas paternos.
â€œBlue Banistersâ€, o segundo disco lanÃ§ado pela cantora neste ano, funciona quase como um complemento do antecessor, â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€. Desta vez, ela trata um pouco mais de questÃµes pessoais, em faixas que parecem ter sido todas feitas durante o perÃ­odo de isolamento da pandemia.
Se em â€œNorman Fucking Rockwellâ€, de 2019, a desilusÃ£o era com a era Trump nos Estados Unidos, agora a pandemia Ã© mais um ingrediente no apocalipse iminente que ronda a estÃ©tica de Del Rey. Mas a capacidade da compositora de capturar a melancolia millennial americana parece intacta.
Desde 2012, quando se mudou de Nova York para a CalifÃ³rnia â€“estado que transformou em uma espÃ©cie de musa em sua obraâ€“ e despontou na mÃºsica, Del Rey nunca foi tÃ£o levada a sÃ©rio. No comeÃ§o, era tratada como uma espÃ©cie de piada, enquanto estourava com o pop retrÃ´ e modorrento de mÃºsicas como â€œVideo Gamesâ€ e declaraÃ§Ãµes polÃªmicas na imprensa.
Em 2017, para â€œLust for Lifeâ€, ela tentou se enquadrar numa sonoridade eletrÃ´nica mais moderna, com acenos para o trap e colaboraÃ§Ãµes com rappers como A$AP Rocky e Playboi Carti. Mas foi no trabalho seguinte, â€œNorman Fucking Rockwellâ€, que ela enfim ganhou o aval da crÃ­tica, foi indicada ao prÃªmio de Ã¡lbum do ano no Grammy e passou a ser respeitada enquanto compositora.
Ã‰ como se do glamour melancÃ³lico e hedonista, da vida selvagem e dos excessos dos primeiros discos, tivesse sobrado apenas a melancolia, a poesia e o sarcasmo. De certa forma, a desilusÃ£o tambÃ©m acompanha boa parte de seu pÃºblico, que tambÃ©m cresceu e, quase dez anos depois, vÃª apenas a sombra de uma vida libertina e cheia de esperanÃ§as.
Com o Ã¡lbum de 2019, Del Rey foi alÃ§ada ao posto de compositora que melhor captou a angÃºstia dos Ãºltimos anos nos Estados Unidos. De fato, cheio de ironias, bom humor e referÃªncias Ã  cultura pop do paÃ­s, o Ã¡lbum traz personagens perdidos e encapsula o sentimento de estar vivo em meio aos destroÃ§os de um glamour de outrora.
Os versos de â€œThe Greatestâ€ sÃ£o os que mais bem representam o momento. â€œE eu estou perdida/ NÃ£o vÃ¡ embora, eu sÃ³ preciso que alguÃ©m me dÃª uma real/ Estou encarando a maior/ A maior perda de todas/ A cultura Ã© incrÃ­vel e, se for sÃ³ isso mesmo, eu tive meu momento/ Mas acho que estou exausta depois de tudo/ Se for sÃ³ isso, vou despedindo [â€¦] Los Angeles estÃ¡ em chamas, estÃ¡ ficando quente/ Kanye West estÃ¡ loiro e esquecido/ â€˜Life On Marsâ€™ nÃ£o Ã© apenas uma mÃºsica/ Ah, a live estÃ¡ quase comeÃ§ando.â€
Nos dois trabalhos seguintes, Lana expande esse sentimento de desilusÃ£o sarcÃ¡stica. â€œWhite Dressâ€, principal faixa de â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€, ela soa nostÃ¡lgica enquanto canta sobre uma jovem garÃ§onete que trabalha no turno da noite. Em meio a sussurros e uma melodia crescente, lembra de bons momentos do passado â€“ela tem 36 anosâ€“, como â€œouvir White Stripes/ Quando eles estavam bombando/ Ouvir rock o dia inteiro.â€
Agora, com â€œBlue Banistersâ€, Del Rey grita que nÃ£o quer viver em â€œDealerâ€, condena um homem que tenta mudÃ¡-la em â€œViolets For Rosesâ€ e convida o ouvinte para sua intimidade em â€œWildflower Wildfireâ€. â€œMeu pai nunca fazia nada quando a mulher dele brigava comigo/ EntÃ£o acabei estranha mas doceâ€, ela canta na faixa.
Um tema recorrente da mÃºsica â€“e de todo o discoâ€“ Ã© quando Del Rey tenta controlar seu lado selvagem sem apagÃ¡-lo por completo. E em meio Ã  tristeza latente, hÃ¡ a consciÃªncia de sua capacidade como artista. â€œE se alguÃ©m pedisse a Picasso para nÃ£o ser triste? Eu nunca saberia quem ele era ou o homem que se tornouâ€, ela canta em â€œBeautifulâ€, quando diz que consegue transformar dor em beleza.
Musicalmente, â€œNorman Fucking Rockwellâ€ consegue ser mais completo, apesar de ancorado em melodias de violÃ£o e piano. Os dois Ã¡lbuns mais recentes â€“que certamente seriam mais interessantes caso suas faixas fossem cortadas e unidas em um Ãºnico discoâ€“ mantÃªm o formato piano e voz, cada vez mais no estilo cantautora, mas fazendo com os discos soem maÃ§antes para o ouvinte mais desavisado.
A esta altura da carreira, o apelo de Del Rey estÃ¡ em sua voz peculiar e, principalmente, em suas letras â€“muito mais do que na estÃ©tica no entorno dela. Ao conseguir cantar o sentimento de um tempo, a artista se firma como uma das compositoras mais relevantes dessa decadÃªncia americana, uma espÃ©cie de poeta millennial debochada do fim do mundo.
BLUE BANISTERS

Onde: Nas plataformas digitais
Autor: Lana Del Rey
Gravadora: Universal

title: Lana Del Rey's New Album Reviews: What Critics Are Saying About 'Blue Banisters'
content:
In March 2021, Lana Del Rey released her seventh album, Chemtrails over the Country Club, much to the acclaim of critics.
Only seven months later, she is back with an eighth album, Blue Banisters, in the hope it might receive a similar reception.
Critics from all over the world have given their two cents about the record, but so far it would be fair to say its response is slightly more muted than that of its predecessor.
While many have shared their slight confusion at the subject matter, which brings elements of lockdown life into her usual fare, her voice has been praised once again.
Here's what critics are saying about Lana Del Rey's new album, Blue Banisters.
Here's What Critics Are Saying About Lana Del Rey's Blue Banisters
NME
In NME's four-star review, Rhian Daly hailed the singer for responding to critics through her music to combat the negativity she has received about cultural appropriation, and from those who claim her lyrics glamorise domestic abuse.
Del Rey recently moved away from social media, and so took aim with dulcet tones and piano-based melodies instead, such as in her track "Black Bathing Suit." Daly also noted Del Rey had moved away from the folk roots she has been exploring in her previous two albums.
The Guardian
The Guardian, meanwhile, gave Blue Banisters three stars, suggesting some of its content seems to be outside of Del Rey's usual remit.
Rachel Aroesti praised her boldness in certain songs, again noting the song "Black Bathing Suit," which takes aim at negative press attention.
However, the critic also notes that while some of the more pedestrian topics (like Zoom calls) make her more relatable, seem to be slightly strange additions to the Lana canon.
Pitchfork
Music magazine Pitchfork has an altogether different opinion of Blue Banisters, awarding the album 7.7 out of 10.
Sam Sodomsky, like the other reviewers, honed in on the style and substance of "Black Bathing Suit," while also hailing how the more relatable lyrics about Target parking lots and Zoom calls give the album greater intimacy, as if listeners are in the studio with her.
Slant
Charles Lyons-Burt of Slant magazine gave Blue Banisters four stars, expressing how this album gives a new insight into Del Rey's inner world.
Through the pared-back arrangements and building intensity through the songs, as well as harking back to her old thematic stomping grounds, Lyons-Burt ultimately praised the singer's new album for opening a part of her life which, until now, has felt distant. He also noted her "cherubic and distant" vocals, which sound like they have been plucked from a daydream.
Stereogum
In their Premature Evaluation, Dani Blum enjoyed the singer's return to the theme of break-ups in songs like "If You Lie Me Down," while noting how much more raw this album is to her previous record, Chemtrails over the Country Club.
However, while there is not a star-rating for the album, the review is ultimately mixed, suggesting some of the more drawn-out tracks become slow and dull and the record as a whole is ultimately "disappointing." Having said this, Blum surmised there is a great album in the bones of this, it just needed to be "excavated."

title: Lana Del Rey: Blue Banisters
content:
In the decade since her major-label debut Born to Die, Lana Del Rey has worked so quickly and consistently, navigating so many passing controversies and thorny conversations, that it has been easy to take for granted her steady evolution as an artist. The 36-year-old musician recently took a break from social media, allowing herself an uncharacteristically quiet press cycle, and there she sits on the cover of her second album of 2021, Blue Banisters, nestled between two German shepherds, serene and pastoral, removed from the world. Things, for the moment, seem peaceful.
So letâ€™s take this opportunity to check in on the state of her art with a standout track called â€œBlack Bathing Suit.â€ The subject matter remains in her wheelhouse. She admits to being complicated. She self-identifies as a â€œbad girl,â€ someone with a price on her head, living on borrowed time. She writes with a casual sense of fatalism about loneliness (â€œIf this is the end, I want a boyfriendâ€) and ennui (â€œWhen Iâ€™m being honest, Iâ€™m tired of this shitâ€), drawing our attention to the titular item of clothing with a sense of focus that, when applied in horror films, generally leads us to believe this object will later be used to identify a body. This is all Lana 101.
But there are crucial updates. Unlike the Great Gatsby roleplay of her early work, all the action takes place in the present dayâ€”which we recognize instantly because the opening line goes, â€œGrenadine, quarantine, I like you a lot/Itâ€™s LA, â€˜Heyâ€™ on Zoom, Target parking lot.â€ And while it was once easy to label Lana a pop artistâ€”someone whose songwriting worked with tight structures and hooks, accompanied by fancy videos and dance remixesâ€”â€œBlack Bathing Suitâ€ breaks from any confines. As she moves from verse to pre-chorus to chorus, she lets the seams show, each section finding its own distinct atmosphere with ghostly harmonies, off-time cymbal taps, and, near the end, a hoarse, Fetch the Bolt Cutters wail. Eventually, you start to feel like youâ€™re in the studio alongside her, listening past the fade out as she tweaks and ornaments the music to keep herself interested.
There is a sense of playfulness, unguardedness, and freedom to Blue Banisters. If its predecessor, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, was Lanaâ€™s most traditional singer-songwriter affairâ€”a somewhat monochromatic collection of mid-tempo songs played on piano and acoustic guitarâ€”then these 15 tracks share a more boundless vision. One of its highlights, the closing â€œSweet Carolina,â€ pairs a stunning, delicate vocal performance with a set of lyrics possibly dedicated to her sister. And then, out of nowhere, thereâ€™s a verse that goes like this:
You name your babe Lilac Heaven
After your iPhone 11
â€˜Crypto forever,â€™ screams your stupid boyfriend
Fuck you, Kevin
Itâ€™s funny and real, a reminder that the people we love most arenâ€™t just the ones to whom we dedicate our earnest love songsâ€”theyâ€™re often the recipients of our dumbest jokes.
This freewheeling tone also informs the structure of the album. Placed among modern transmissions like â€œBlack Bathing Suit,â€ â€œSweet Carolina,â€ and â€œText Bookâ€ (â€œThere we were, screaming, â€˜Black Lives Matter,â€™â€ she reflects) are songs like â€œLiving Legendâ€ and â€œCherry Blossom,â€ titles that have circulated among her fanbase in unofficial form for years. These recordings, which date back as far as the sessions for 2014â€™s Ultraviolence, constitute about a third of the tracklist, stretching the runtime past an hour and making the whole thing feel slightly unwieldy, off-balance, lacking the cohesion of her best albums.
And yet, these qualities also make the record stand out: a survey of Lanaâ€™s gifts, stripped of the aesthetic borders she often places around her work. Itâ€™s an approach that aligns her with the legacy artists she has always drawn fromâ€”Neil Young and Bruce Springsteen, craftsmen constantly digging through the archives to recontextualize their mythology. But there is also pop precedent. Were Lana less obsessive about her body of work, she might have sequenced the newer songs onto a deluxe edition of Chemtrails; were she more savvy, she might have issued them as an interlinked companion release to close out the year.
Fortunately, Blue Banisters stands on its own, encompassing the many styles she has by now mastered: The edgy Miles Kane collaboration â€œDealerâ€ returns to the psych-rock hypnosis of Ultraviolence, while the spare â€œBeautifulâ€ draws from the same well of aspirational standards as 2017â€™s â€œLove.â€ Her collaborators include familiar names (Rick Nowels, Zachary Dawes) and literal family members (her father and sister, co-writers on â€œSweet Carolinaâ€), alongside ex-boyfriends and producers like Mike Dean. Still, the whole thing flows with a breezy, self-contained hum. For those unfamiliar with the pivots and scenery changes from album to album, you might not even notice the time-jumps.
Despite the wide range of moodsâ€”the unbridled howl of â€œI donâ€™t wanna liveâ€ in â€œDealer,â€ her old Hollywood quiver returning for â€œNectar of the Godsâ€â€”the clearest evolution is in the writing. Sometime around 2019â€™s high-water mark Norman Fucking Rockwell!, Lana made a shift from character studies and archetypes (best exemplified here in the classic-sounding â€œThunderâ€) to first-person musings on celebrity, inextricable from her own life in the public eye. On Chemtrails, she sang about â€œcoverinâ€™ Joni and dancinâ€™ with Joan,â€ and now she writes about her family, her creative process, and her personal struggles, most directly in â€œText Book.â€ For all the sadness and desperation across her songbook, an early lyric in the song, â€œI didnâ€™t even like myself,â€ feels like her barest, most wounded confession.
When Lana released the piano ballad â€œArcadiaâ€ this summer, she instructed her fans, â€œListen to it like you listened to â€˜Video Games.â€™â€ On one hand, she might have been trying to game the system, encouraging listeners to boost the streaming numbers to match those of her past work. (Born to Die remains her only album to spawn a Top 10 hit.) But maybe she was asking for something more personal. After all, her debut single was likely the last time that Lana could release music to zero expectations, introducing herself to the world on her own terms. Like a lot of people who feel misunderstood, she is a chronic over-explainer, and Blue Banisters sprawls and elaborates past the point where we can place our own projections onto it. We know too much. But at its best, this music offers an even more rewarding thrill: It manages to entertain, enrapture, and even surprise because of how well we know Lana Del Reyâ€”and how much there is still to learn.
Buy: Rough Trade
(Pitchfork earns a commission from purchases made through affiliate links on our site.)

title: Lana Del Rey - Blue Banisters review: Changing the record (slightly)
content:
Review at a glance
T he funereal pace of Lana Del Reyâ€™s songs doesnâ€™t suggest a feverish working environment, but here she is with her second album of the year, her third in just over two years. Without a world tour to occupy her, the LA-based singer-songwriter has been fine-tuning her sound, and at first glance the usual tropes are all here: despondent piano chords, that blurred, swooning voice, and lines that mix ruined romance and Americana. â€œMy body is a map of LA,â€ she sings on Arcadia. â€œLight me up like the Fourth of July,â€ she urges a sometime lover on If You Lie Down With Me.
But while her style has become more easily identifiable since the career high of her album Norman F**king Rockwell! in 2019 â€“ avoiding current sonic trends, wallowing in beautiful sadness â€“ Blue Banisters changes the record if you listen closely. Usually crafting her own stars and stripes mythology with her lyrics, thereâ€™s a lot of specific personal detail here. On the opening track, Text Book, she attends a Black Lives Matter march with a man she likes because he has the same car as her father. The high, fluttering voice she adopts on the charming closer, Sweet Carolina, is addressed to her sisterâ€™s newborn daughter.
After two close Jack Antonoff collaborations, sheâ€™s working with a range of producers and co-writers this time, which leads to impressive anomalies such as Dealer, where British indie guitarist Miles Kane gets the lead vocal, and the swinging string section on Thunder. It counts as this singular artist being eclectic, and it works.

title: Lana Del Rey Drops Second Album of 2021 â€˜Blue Banistersâ€™
content:
Photo: Steve Granitz/WireImage
Lana Del Rey dropped her latest album at midnight, and it took a long, confusing road to get to Blue Banisters. Originally titled Rock Candy Sweet, Del Rey announced her second album of 2021 just days after releasing Chemtrails Over the Country Club. While the original release date was delayed from July to October of 2021, Del Rey didnâ€™t leave fans hanging. She released four singles from Blue Banisters, keeping fans happy while they waited for the new album. However, this album does not feature Jack Antonoff, who was heavily involved in Chemtrails. Blue Banisters was released through Interscope Records and Polydor Records. Del Rey produced the album alongside Gabe Simon, Zachary Dawes, Drew Erickson, Dean Reid, Loren Humphrey, Mike Dean, Barrie-James Oâ€™Neill, and Rick Nowels. Nowels has been a frequent collaborator, working with Del Rey on almost every album, however this time around, he only worked on one song, â€œCherry Blossom.â€

title: Alben der Woche mit Lana Del Rey, Nick Cave, Jarvis Cocker
content:
Von Von den SZ-Popkritikern
Detailansicht Ã¶ffnen
Captain Yossarian - "Bob Marley in Dub" (Echo Beach)
Man hat ja jetzt manchmal wieder Zufallsbegegnungen, und zuletzt begegnete man also zufÃ¤llig einem Mann, der einen ganz wunderbar sperrig in der Welt herumstehenden Boxenturm aufgebaut hatte: pyramidenfÃ¶rmig, breite Subwoofer unten, etwas schmaler im Mittelbau und ganz oben, als HochtÃ¶ner, ein immer noch fulminantes Lautsprecherhorn. Das alles in den Farben Lila und Gelb gestrichen. Man muss auf sehr warme Art lÃ¤cheln, wenn man es sieht. Er kÃ¶nne diese Pyramide, erzÃ¤hlte der Mann, auf einem AnhÃ¤nger herumziehen, es sei also ein komplett mobiles Soundsystem. Dann verschwand er hinter einem wenigstens im Vergleich zum Turm kleineren Kasten mit vielen KnÃ¶pfen und Reglern, an denen er schraubte und drehte und drÃ¼ckte, als suche er einen Radiosender vom Mars, und auf einmal erklang Bob Marley.
Genauer: Bob Marley mit lokalem Instrumentarium aus dem MÃ¼nchner Umland gespielt. Und ab hier kÃ¶nnte es natÃ¼rlich problematisch werden - Ã¤sthetisch, in Fragen der AttitÃ¼de, also bei all den Dingen, die gemeinhin unter Geschmackssicherheit laufen. Bob Marley mit Tuba und Akkordeon, da rechnet das Gehirn des Zynikers natÃ¼rlich automatisch den Kuhstall-Unrat von vielen Wochen an nackte FÃ¼ÃŸe. Man hat Marley in dieser Hinsicht seit seinem Tod viel angetan, und der Mann mit dem Boxenturm spielt, wie sich herausstellte, tatsÃ¤chlich im Hauptberuf Schlagzeug bei LaBrassbanda. Manuel da Coll heiÃŸt er fÃ¼r seinen BrieftrÃ¤ger. Als Soundsystem nennt er sich Captain Yossarian. Und was soll man sagen: Zyniker sind, mit Verlaub, widerliche Zeitgenossen.
Denn was Yossarian auf seinem gerade erschienenen Album "Bob Marley in Dub" (Echo Beach) macht und mittels Pyramiden-Soundsystem durch die Welt zieht, ist eine wirklich ganz famos spÃ¤therbstwarme musikalische Wohltat. Eine Hommage, klar, und ein bisschen Mimikry. Aber die Playbacks treiben auch irre smart, intuitiv und live steuerbar (die KnÃ¶pfe und Regler!) Hall- und Dub-satt durchs Weltall. Sehr elegant. Ganz souverÃ¤n. Extrem wÃ¼rdig. Toll. Anspieltipps: "Three Little Birds", "Stir It Up" und "Exodus". Jakob Biazza
Detailansicht Ã¶ffnen
Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds - "B-Sides & Rarities (Part II)" (BMG/Warner)
Was ist quasi das exakte Gegenteil von Bob-Marley-Tribute-Musik? Genau: Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds. Der dunkle SchmerzensfÃ¼rst und sein Counterpart Warren Ellis, ein Mann, der in der Hauptsache aus Zauselbart und Geheimratsecken besteht und irgendwo dahinter einen genialischen Verstand fÃ¼r verzogene, beÃ¤ngstigende, wunderschÃ¶ne GeisterklÃ¤nge hat. Geschmackssicherheit ist hier die Grundlage fÃ¼r alles, deshalb brauchte man sich eigentlich nicht zu sorgen, ob auch "B-Sides & Rarities (Part II)" (BMG/Warner) vollgepackt sein wird mit lichtabsorbierenden Indie- und Alternative-SchÃ¶nheiten. Eigentlich. Die Vorab-Singles beunruhigten schlieÃŸlich ein bisschen. Zumindest die Live-Version von "Push The Sky Away", diesem im Original alle Leichtigkeit aus der Seele quetschenden Todesvermeidungssong, klingt, spÃ¤testens wenn das Melbourne Symphony Orchestra losschmiert, ein klein wenig, als habe Disney+ Besitz von Cave und Co. ergriffen. Beim Rest sieht es aber dann doch weitestgehend besser aus. Jakob Biazza
Detailansicht Ã¶ffnen
Lana Del Rey - "Blue Banisters" (Universal)
Nur ein gutes halbes Jahr nach "Chemtrails Over The Country Club" kommt schon wieder ein neues Album von Lana Del Rey, dem nachtschattigen, schwermÃ¼tigen Update der klassischen Beverly-Hills-Songschreiberin. Braucht man das? Und ob. "Blue Banisters" gibt in der Tat einige neue, bestechende Kommentare zu den groÃŸen Motiven, um die sich das Werk der KÃ¼nstlerin dreht: Jugend, Rausch, Liebe, Freiheit, motorisierte Fortbewegung. Und natÃ¼rlich Kalifornien. Insgesamt nicht ganz so durchgÃ¤ngig groÃŸ wie die vorangegangenen zwei MeisterstÃ¼cke. Aber die Frage, was Lana Del Rey hier noch draufsetzen will, mag man wirklich nicht beantworten mÃ¼ssen. Joachim Hentschel
Detailansicht Ã¶ffnen
Sly Alone - "Gesegnet" (Hayati Records)
SpÃ¤testens seit ihrem Album "Montenegro Zero" ist die Hamburger Rapperin Haiyti eine der sehr wenigen VerheiÃŸungen im deutschen Rap. Eine manische Arbeiterin, die dem Hip-Hop (und schon auch dem Pop) mit ihrer neon-grell gefauchten Stimme, den sehr stilsicheren Trap-Beats und ihren genau richtig verqueren Texten etwas bringt, das es hier sehr selten gibt: einen wirklich eigenen Kunstanspruch. AuÃŸerdem ist sie jetzt auch noch Labelbetreiberin, und auf diesem Label erscheint am Freitag das Album "Gesegnet" (Hayati Records) ihres ProtegÃ©s Sly Alone. Anschmiegsame, watte-flauschige Trap-Beats zunÃ¤chst, spÃ¤ter dann zusÃ¤tzlich ein paar fein winselnde Emo-Gitarren. Angenehmes Bild von MÃ¤nnlichkeit. In Summe etwas gewÃ¶hnlicher als das Zeug der Chefin. Aber was ist das nicht? Jakob Biazza
Detailansicht Ã¶ffnen
Jarvis Cocker - "Chansons d'Ennui Tip-Top" (Universal)
Und damit noch zum schluffigsten Dandy GroÃŸbritanniens: Jarvis Cocker verÃ¶ffentlicht an diesem Freitag "Chansons d'Ennui Tip-Top" (Universal), also endlich Musik, die in seinen Arbeiten mit Pulp oder zuletzt Chilly Gonzales eh schon immer anklang. Der Name sagt im Grunde alles: Neuinterpretationen von franzÃ¶sischen Chansons, in traurig, ein bisschen verschroben und auch ein klein wenig sexy. Womit man hier verkÃ¼nden kann: Jarvis Cocker klingt nun endlich komplett, als vertonte er (gute) Softpornos aus den 70ern. Jakob Biazza

title: Lana Del Rey Releases New Album Blue Banisters
content:
Lana Del Rey has released her new album Blue Banisters. The LP is the singer and songwriterâ€™s second album of the year, following Marchâ€™s Chemtrails Over the Country Club. Listen to it below. (Pitchfork earns a commission from purchases made through affiliate links on our site.)
A few weeks after announcing an as-yet-unreleased LP titled Rock Candy Sweet, Lana Del Rey announced another new album, titled Blue Banisters. In May, she shared three new songs, describing them as â€œbuzz tracksâ€ in anticipation of a new record: â€œBlue Banisters,â€ â€œText Book,â€ and â€œWildflower Wildflower.â€ She later shared another new track titled â€œArcadia.â€ Last summer, Del Rey released an audiobook version of her poetry collection Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass.
Read Pitchforkâ€™s review of Lana Del Reyâ€™s Blue Banisters.

title: Lana Del Rey's 'Blue Banisters' Album: Stream
content:
Lana Del Rey released her highly anticipated and much delayed album Blue Banisters on Friday (Oct. 22) via Polydor and Interscope Records.
The album, which had an original release date of July 4, was preceded by four songs: "Wildflower Wildfire," "Text Book," "Arcadia" and the title track.
Before dropping "Arcadia" last month, Del Rey told fans what they can expect from Blue Banisters."I guess you could say this album is about what it was like, what happened, and what itâ€™s like now," she wrote on Instagram, which she has since deactivated, along with the remainder of her social media accounts. "As much as the on going criticism has been trying, it at least has pushed me to explore my own family tree, to dig deep, and to continue to exhibit the fact that God only cares about how I move through the world. And for all of the skepticism about feigning fragility and unreasonable explanations of not showing general accountability -- I must say Iâ€™ve enjoyed moving through the world beautifully -- as a woman with grace and dignity."

title: Lana Del Rey se firma como poeta millennial do apocalipse em disco
content:
