Ela se diz uma "garotinha perdida", e busca algum tipo de fuga de um perÃ­odo turbulento.
NÃ£o Ã© possÃ­vel saber se essa turbulÃªncia Ã© o ano e meio de pandemia, a era Trump ou apenas um relacionamento mal-sucedido. Fato Ã© que, em seu novo disco, "Blue Banisters", Lana Del Rey parece sentir que o mundo ao seu redor vai acabar a qualquer momento, indo mais a fundo no retrato melancÃ³lico e sarcÃ¡stico da decadÃªncia americana que marcou os seus Ãºltimos discos.
A cantora Lana Del Rey - Neil Krug
"Se este Ã© o fim, quero um namorado", ela canta em "Black Bathing Suit", canÃ§Ã£o que dÃ¡ o tom do Ã¡lbum, conforme ela descreve um momento de isolamento social, usando o Zoom, bebendo granadina e em que "a Ãºnica coisa que continua cabendo em mim Ã© meu roupÃ£o preto". Del Rey encara a incompatibilidade de um relacionamento enquanto fala freudianamente sobre problemas paternos.
"Blue Banisters", o segundo disco lanÃ§ado pela cantora neste ano, funciona quase como um complemento do antecessor, "Chemtrails Over the Country Club". Desta vez, ela trata um pouco mais de questÃµes pessoais, em faixas que parecem ter sido todas feitas durante o perÃ­odo de isolamento da pandemia.
Se em "Norman Fucking Rockwell", de 2019, a desilusÃ£o era com a era Trump nos Estados Unidos, agora a pandemia Ã© mais um ingrediente no apocalipse iminente que ronda a estÃ©tica de Del Rey. Mas a capacidade da compositora de capturar a melancolia millennial americana parece intacta.
Desde 2012, quando se mudou de Nova York para a CalifÃ³rnia â€”estado que transformou em uma espÃ©cie de musa em sua obraâ€” e despontou na mÃºsica, Del Rey nunca foi tÃ£o levada a sÃ©rio. No comeÃ§o, era tratada como uma espÃ©cie de piada, enquanto estourava com o pop retrÃ´ e modorrento de mÃºsicas como "Video Games" e declaraÃ§Ãµes polÃªmicas na imprensa.
Em 2017, para "Lust for Life", ela tentou se enquadrar numa sonoridade eletrÃ´nica mais moderna, com acenos para o trap e colaboraÃ§Ãµes com rappers como A$AP Rocky e Playboi Carti. Mas foi no trabalho seguinte, "Norman Fucking Rockwell", que ela enfim ganhou o aval da crÃ­tica, foi indicada ao prÃªmio de Ã¡lbum do ano no Grammy e passou a ser respeitada enquanto compositora.
Ã‰ como se do glamour melancÃ³lico e hedonista, da vida selvagem e dos excessos dos primeiros discos, tivesse sobrado apenas a melancolia, a poesia e o sarcasmo. De certa forma, a desilusÃ£o tambÃ©m acompanha boa parte de seu pÃºblico, que tambÃ©m cresceu e, quase dez anos depois, vÃª apenas a sombra de uma vida libertina e cheia de esperanÃ§as.
Com o Ã¡lbum de 2019, Del Rey foi alÃ§ada ao posto de compositora que melhor captou a angÃºstia dos Ãºltimos anos nos Estados Unidos. De fato, cheio de ironias, bom humor e referÃªncias Ã  cultura pop do paÃ­s, o Ã¡lbum traz personagens perdidos e encapsula o sentimento de estar vivo em meio aos destroÃ§os de um glamour de outrora.
Os versos de "The Greatest" sÃ£o os que mais bem representam o momento. "E eu estou perdida/ NÃ£o vÃ¡ embora, eu sÃ³ preciso que alguÃ©m me dÃª uma real/ Estou encarando a maior/ A maior perda de todas/ A cultura Ã© incrÃ­vel e, se for sÃ³ isso mesmo, eu tive meu momento/ Mas acho que estou exausta depois de tudo/ Se for sÃ³ isso, vou despedindo [...] Los Angeles estÃ¡ em chamas, estÃ¡ ficando quente/ Kanye West estÃ¡ loiro e esquecido/ â€˜Life On Marsâ€™ nÃ£o Ã© apenas uma mÃºsica/ Ah, a live estÃ¡ quase comeÃ§ando."
Nos dois trabalhos seguintes, Lana expande esse sentimento de desilusÃ£o sarcÃ¡stica. "White Dress", principal faixa de "Chemtrails Over the Country Club", ela soa nostÃ¡lgica enquanto canta sobre uma jovem garÃ§onete que trabalha no turno da noite. Em meio a sussurros e uma melodia crescente, lembra de bons momentos do passado â€”ela tem 36 anosâ€”, como "ouvir White Stripes/ Quando eles estavam bombando/ Ouvir rock o dia inteiro."
Agora, com "Blue Banisters", Del Rey grita que nÃ£o quer viver em "Dealer", condena um homem que tenta mudÃ¡-la em "Violets For Roses" e convida o ouvinte para sua intimidade em "Wildflower Wildfire". "Meu pai nunca fazia nada quando a mulher dele brigava comigo/ EntÃ£o acabei estranha mas doce", ela canta na faixa.
Capa do disco 'Blue Banisters', da cantora americana Lana Del Rey - ReproduÃ§Ã£o
Um tema recorrente da mÃºsica â€”e de todo o discoâ€” Ã© quando Del Rey tenta controlar seu lado selvagem sem apagÃ¡-lo por completo. E em meio Ã  tristeza latente, hÃ¡ a consciÃªncia de sua capacidade como artista. "E se alguÃ©m pedisse a Picasso para nÃ£o ser triste? Eu nunca saberia quem ele era ou o homem que se tornou", ela canta em "Beautiful", quando diz que consegue transformar dor em beleza.
Musicalmente, "Norman Fucking Rockwell" consegue ser mais completo, apesar de ancorado em melodias de violÃ£o e piano. Os dois Ã¡lbuns mais recentes â€”que certamente seriam mais interessantes caso suas faixas fossem cortadas e unidas em um Ãºnico discoâ€” mantÃªm o formato piano e voz, cada vez mais no estilo cantautora, mas fazendo com os discos soem maÃ§antes para o ouvinte mais desavisado.
A esta altura da carreira, o apelo de Del Rey estÃ¡ em sua voz peculiar e, principalmente, em suas letras â€”muito mais do que na estÃ©tica no entorno dela. Ao conseguir cantar o sentimento de um tempo, a artista se firma como uma das compositoras mais relevantes dessa decadÃªncia americana, uma espÃ©cie de poeta millennial debochada do fim do mundo.

title: Lana Del Rey: Blue Banisters review - as perplexing as she is captivating
content:
Despite some misguided early philosophising, the pandemic has not turned out to be a great leveller: we have all been, to borrow a viral metaphor, navigating the same stormy sea in very different vessels. It has, however, made Lana Del Rey a bit more relatable. The musician has often seemed more highly stylised cipher than everywoman, toying with romantic ideals of American culture and darkly dysfunctional love. Yet on her eighth album, Blue Banisters, she has more pedestrian activities in mind, such as Zoom calls and trips to Target.
The artwork for Blue Banisters
â€œIf this is the end, I want a boyfriend / Someone to eat ice-cream with and watch television,â€ she sings on Black Bathing Suit, a song that appears to nod to lockdown weight gain (â€œThe only thing that still fits me is this black bathing suitâ€). Later, she is overcome by signs of ordinary life returning: on Violets for Roses, once run-of-the-mill sights such as young women frolicking maskless and bookshops reopening can now elicit euphoria.
Ultimately, Black Bathing Suit returns to her favoured themes of â€œbad girlsâ€ and negative press attention. Yet Blue Banisters is perhaps her most autobiographically straightforward album to date, documenting a failed romance and the inception of her current one, and her relationships with her sister (close) and her mother (difficult). The arresting, almost funereal title track begins as a tribute to her girlfriends, before talking about the limits of female solidarity when it comes to heartbreak and unhappy singledom.
The conversation about whether there has ever been any sort of character at play with Del Rey has orbited her career since her 2011 breakthrough, thanks to her evocative aesthetic â€“ a vaguely low-rent, all-American glamour that harks back to the 60s and 70s â€“ fancy pseudonym (her real name is Lizzy Grant) and her borderline-camp treatment of femininity, toxic relationships and her homeland. Yet, in response to a review of her 2019 album, Norman Fucking Rockwell!, Del Rey insisted that sheâ€™d â€œnever had a persona, never needed one, never willâ€. And while her music sometimes seems tongue-in-cheek, her public statements suggest she takes herself very seriously indeed. A recent announcement that alluded to media criticism included the line: â€œI must say Iâ€™ve enjoyed moving through the world beautifully â€“ as a woman with grace and dignity.â€
Lana Del Rey: Arcadia â€“ video
Nevertheless, itâ€™s still impossible to listen to Blue Banisters, where heart-on-sleeve soliloquies and meandering trains of thought rub up against wry humour and oblique braggadocio, and not feel confused. The sweeping but minimal opening track Text Book, about being attracted to a man because he resembles her father, seems to have a knowing wink baked in. Or does it? Is Beautiful â€“ in which Del Rey defends her melancholic tendencies over twinkly keys with the line: â€œWhat if someone had asked / Picasso not to be sad?â€ â€“ at all self-aware? It doesnâ€™t seem like it â€“ especially considering that the creative power of feeling blue is the albumâ€™s overarching theme.
The gorgeous dirge-like closer, Sweet Carolina, co-written with her dad and sister, acts as a moving love letter to the latter as she prepares to give birth. Yet in the middle the mood is completely undercut by a lyric about a woman who calls her child â€œLilac Heaven after your iPhone 11â€, and has a crypto-obsessed bro for a boyfriend. Del Reyâ€™s slipperiness makes her the mirror inverse of Adele â€“ her mainstream counterpart when it comes to down-tempo, morose, â€œclassicâ€ balladry â€“ whose own intentions always seem crystal clear: strictly earnest on record, gleefully irreverent off it.
However disorientating her company can be, Del Reyâ€™s world-building is never less than completely absorbing, and her vocal presence â€“ which also seems to mess with female singing tropes (she is by turns breathily intimate, Joni-level piercing, despondently flat) â€“ is as potent as any singer of her generation. It does mean her songsâ€™ musical foundations, usually either portentous piano or gently plucked guitars, tend to fade into the background. But the fact there is often little tangible difference between them is not the problem it might be for another artist: Del Rey is all about honing her own idiosyncratic melodic grammar â€“ her toplines are always incredibly inventive and beautiful â€“ that her peers inevitably chase years later.
The samey-ness can also seem exaggerated because of Del Reyâ€™s productivity: Blue Banisters is her second full-length album of 2021 after Chemtrails Over the Country Club. It can make an artistâ€™s work seem less special, an impression compounded here by the inclusion of offcuts from 2014â€™s Ultraviolence and an abandoned 2017 collaborative album with Alex Turner and Miles Kaneâ€™s side project the Last Shadow Puppets. Kane lends his voice to the most sonically exciting song on the album, the ambling, bluesy Dealer, on which Del Rey lets rip, woman-on-the-verge style, like a Tennesse Williams heroine, or John Lennon on Mother.
Itâ€™s grimly funny and deserves its spot, but the other throwbacks feel less noteworthy, blending into a glacial dirge. Yet despite the wavering quality, Blue Banisters is an important addition to Lana lore. That she can still manage to be this perplexing after a decade in the game is a massive achievement.

title: Lana Del Rey, Ã¨ uscito il video di "Blue Banisters"
content:
In attesa dellâ€™imminente arrivo del disco â€œBlue Banistersâ€, domani venerdÃ¬ 22 ottobre, Lana Del Rey ha pubblicato su YouTube il videoclip ufficiale della title track. Frame dal sapore malinconico, immersi in una cornice di altri tempi, dove la cantante si affida alla promessa di un uomo che le raccontÃ² sarebbe tornato da lei Condividi:
UscirÃ  domani â€“ venerdÃ¬ 22 ottobre (allo scoccare della mezzanotte) â€“ il tanto atteso nuovo disco di Lana Del Rey, dal titolo â€œBlue Banistersâ€. Nel frattempo, la cantautrice statunitense ha scelto di ingannare lâ€™attesa regalando ai fan il videoclip ufficiale su YouTube del singolo omonimo, pubblicato a maggio. Un tuttâ€™uno di atmosfere bucoliche e di altri tempi che non si discosta di molto dalle riprese ufficiali dei singoli giÃ  estratti dal nuovo album: â€œText bookâ€, â€œWildflower wildfireâ€ e â€œArcadiaâ€.
Il videoclip di â€œBlue Banistersâ€ approfondimento Lana Del Rey, uscita una versione alternativa del videoclip di Arcadia Nel videoclip ufficiale di â€œBlue Banistersâ€, title track del disco di Lana Del Rey, la cantautrice americana sceglie di prendere alla lettera i versi della sua stessa canzone. Rimangono quindi le atmosfere bucoliche e vintage giÃ  viste nei due video di â€œArcadiaâ€ (con la location dei frame che pare inoltre la stessa), mentre lâ€™artista si mostra proprio a bordo del John Deere di cui canta e con le amiche dipinge una staccionata di blu, a richiamare il â€œblue banistersâ€ della canzone. Tra il lento dondolare di unâ€™altalena, con il vento tra i capelli, e la preparazione di una torta di compleanno, Lana Del Rey canta un non so che di malinconico, richiamando il significato della canzone dedicata al rapporto con un uomo che ha promesso che sarebbe tornato da lei, proprio per aiutarla a dipingere le ringhiere. Il tempo scorre, quel gesto e quelle parole diventano immagini di un futuro dal destino differente.

title: Lana Del Rey Releases â€˜Blue Banistersâ€™ Music Video
content:
And the award for Most Literal Music Video goes to! Lana Del Rey released a visual for â€œBlue Banisters,â€ the title track from her upcoming album, and it indeed features her painting some banisters blue, alongside her â€œsisters,â€ presumably Jenny and Nikki Lane. If youâ€™re coming for the titular action, stay to watch Del Rey ride a John Deere tractor, which she also sings about. Also true to the song lyrics, the video features Del Rey and her sisters baking birthday cake, one indeed with a baby on the way, and shows her broken weather vane atop her Oklahoma house. The only thing missing seems to be the chickens!
The video comes just days ahead of Blue Banisters release on October 22. Itâ€™s Del Reyâ€™s second album of 2021, on the heels of Mayâ€™s Chemtrails Over the Country Club, and was originally set to be released on July 4 before its October delay. She first teased â€œBlue Banistersâ€ in April, posting a since-deleted clip of herself and then-fiancÃ© Clayton Johnson; that clip is not part of the officially released music video. Del Rey then released â€œBlue Banistersâ€ in full alongside two other songs, â€œText Bookâ€ and â€œWildflower Wildfire,â€ in May. Last month, she released the Blue Banisters single â€œArcadia,â€ along with its not-quite-as-literal video.

title: Lana Del Rey Shares New â€œBlue Banistersâ€ Video: Watch
content:
Lana Del Rey has released the music video for â€œBlue Banisters,â€ the title track from her next album. In the visual, Del Rey enacts some of the songâ€™s lyrics, riding a John Deere vehicle and painting her banisters blue. Watch the video below.
Blue Banisters is Lana Del Reyâ€™s second album of 2021, following Marchâ€™s Chemtrails Over the Country Club. The new recordâ€”out this Friday, October 22â€”includes â€œBlue Banisters,â€ â€œText Book,â€ â€œWildflower Wildfire,â€ and â€œArcadia,â€ which got an alternate music video earlier this month.
Read about Lana Del Rey in â€œThe 200 Most Important Artists of Pitchforkâ€™s First 25 Years.â€

title: Lana Del Rey's 'Blue Banisters' Video: Watch
content:
Her latest release is the title track from her eighth studio album, out Friday.
Lana Del Rey has released a music video for the title track from her upcoming album Blue Banisters -- her second 2021 project, following March's Chemtrails Over the Country Club. Her eighth studio album will be released this Friday.
In the rustic new video, Del Rey is surrounded by her girlfriends as they paint some banisters (and each other) blue. They also bake up some desserts and sit atop a John Deere tractor in the gauzy visual.
In addition to the title track, Blue Banisters will also include the previously released songs "Wildflower Wildfire," "Text Book" and "Arcadia," whose music video was released earlier this month.

title: Drake's Album Back at No. 1; Lana Del Rey, Elton John Slip Into Top 10
content:
Drakeâ€™s â€œCertifiable Lover Boyâ€ is certifiably the de facto album chart leader of the fall. After moving out of the No. 1 ospot on the Billboard 200 for a week, it moves back in, earning its fifth non-consecutive week in that slot, as the world awaits the blockbuster releases that are coming up on the docket from Taylor Swift and then Adele.
Not that Adele isnâ€™t already represented as a chart behemoth, as â€œEasy on Meâ€ easily retains its status as top dog on Billboardâ€™s Hot 11 for a second week.
The album chart is experiencing a kind of calm before the storm, one that wasnâ€™t much rippled by new releases. Lana Del Rey and Elton John both made it into the the top 10 of the Billboard 200, but not by huge margins.
Del Reyâ€™s oft-delayed â€œBlue Banisters,â€ originally announced by the singer as a July 4 release, finally saw daylight and debuted at No. 8 with 33,000 equivalent album units. Johnâ€™s duets album, â€œThe Lockdown Sessions,â€ bowed at No. 10 with 29,000
It was Del Reyâ€™s second album release in this unusually productive year. Her previous effort, â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ debuted at No. 2 after coming out in March.
Drake returned to the top with 74,000 equivalent album units, down from the week before, but still good enough for No. 1 in a slow week. Morgan Wallenâ€™s â€œDangerous: The Double Albumâ€ rose ever-so-slightly in consumption â€” by 1% â€” yet that as good enough to boost the project from No. 8 back up to No. 2.
Other returning albums included hits by Doja Cat, YoungBoy Never Broke Again, Olivia Rodrigo, Moneybagg Yo and Young Thug at Nos. 3-7. The Young Thug album slipped six spots after debuting as last weekâ€™s chart topper. In the No. 9 spot was Lil Nas Xâ€™s â€œMontero.â€
On the Hot 100, in its second week, Adeleâ€™s â€œEasy on Meâ€ triumphed by accumulating 31.8 million streams and racking up 61.5 million radio audience impressions, according to Billboard and MRC Data.
No songs debuted in the top 10, but Doja Catâ€™s â€œNeed to Knowâ€ did crack it for the first time, rising two spots to No. 9 to become her fourth song to join the top ranks.
Returning songs in the top 10 included the Kid Laroi and Justin Bieberâ€™s â€œStayâ€ at No. 2, followed by lingering hits from Lil Nas X and Jack Harlow, Ed Sheeran, Drake, Olivia Rodrigo and Dua Lipa.
Sheeran has two songs lodged in the Hot 100â€™s top 10: â€œBad Habitsâ€ at No. 5 and â€œShiversâ€ reaching a new high at No. 7.
Billboard points out that Lipaâ€™s â€œLevitatingâ€ has now enjoyed 41 weeks in the top 10 â€” the second-longest for any single in the history of the Hot 100. However, it still has a way to go before catching up with the all-time leader in that particular endurance run, the Weekndâ€™s â€œBlinding Lights,â€ which landed 57 weeks in the top 10. Check in in six months to see if Lipa has moved on from second place to break the record.

title: Lana Del Rey: Blue Banisters review - a star looking to her legacy
content:
â€œMost men donâ€™t want a woman with a legacy,â€ asserts Lana Del Rey on the title track of her eighth album. Her sharp eye, tired of gazing on archetypal bad boys or her own tragic poses, is trained on that legacy now. In 2020 she published her first poetry book, and this, her second record in seven months, will, she has promised, â€œtell my storyâ€. Take that with a pinch of salt: Del Rey was doing autofiction before it was cool, and of late has been doing it exceptionally well.
Blue Banisters, heavy with stately, stark piano ballads, finds her pushing the edges of her askew-Americana shtick. Sure, on the austere classic pop of opener Text Book she sings: â€œYouâ€™ve got a Thunderbird/ My daddy had one tooâ€, but her voice cuts through sharply, shorn of stylised affectation. On Living Legend, she revels in an unfamiliar, deep, throaty register and a weird, wahing impression of a harmonica. Things get wilder on Dealer, a surreal, loungey duet with Miles Kane, Del Rey disrupting her perfectly composed demeanour with soulful, ragged howls.
Blue Banisters could do with a sharper focus â€“ some of these 15 songs are outtakes dating back years â€“ and a hip-hopped-Morricone instrumental interlude feels like an incongruous eruption from her â€œgangster Nancy Sinatraâ€ era. But it offers glimpses of vistas to be explored beyond Lanaâ€™s customary LA backdrops and a legacy already secure.

title: Watch Lana Del Rey Perform â€œArcadiaâ€ on Colbert
content:

title: Elton John, My Morning Jacket, Helene Fischer: Die Pop-Alben der Woche im Soundcheck
content:
Elton John: The Lockdown Sessions (EMI)
Elton John hat versucht, aus der Pandemie das Beste zu machen, zusammen mit Kollegen wie Lil Nas X, Stevie Wonder oder den Gorillaz. Manches aus dieser Mixtur von Discopop, HipHop- und Oldierock klingt rÃ¼hrend, manches ist gelungen. Ein Song schaffte es in England sogar auf Platz 1. Christian SchrÃ¶der, Tagesspiegel
My Morning Jacket: s/t (ATO Records)
Rockmusik, irgendwer? Gibt es noch. Jedenfalls in Kentucky. Nach den pomadigen Waterfall-Alben hat die Band um Jim James wieder zur Form gefunden. Klassisches Songwriting, experimentelle Momente, schamloses Gitarren-Shredding lassen das wie von einem anderen Planeten klingen. Richtig gut. Andreas MÃ¼ller, Moderator
Lana Del Rey: Blue Banisters (Polydor)
Lana Del Rey raunt weiter von schmerzhafter Sehnsucht, verklÃ¤rtem Amerika und motorisierten Fortbewegungsmitteln â€“ man kenntâ€™s. Aber Produzent Jack Antonoff ist nicht mehr dabei. â€Blue Banistersâ€œ hat das Zeug dazu, â€Norman Fucking Rockwell!â€œ als Del Reys bisher beste Platte abzulÃ¶sen. Silvia Silko, Musikkritikerin
Helene Fischer: Rausch (Universal)
Fischer hat erstmals an vielen ihrer Songs â€mitgeschriebenâ€œ. Am Ergebnis Ã¤ndert das nichts: Schlager sind von ihrer Grundsubstanz her verlogen, all die GefÃ¼hle, all die StÃ¼rme der Emotionen bleiben floskelhafte Behauptungen. Gut produziert, das auf jeden Fall, auch gut (und laut) gesungen. Martin BÃ¶ttcher, Musikkritiker

title: First Stream: Swedish House Mafia & The Weeknd
content:
Want to kick your long-awaited group reunion into high gear? If youâ€™re Swedish House Mafia, back together after years apart and staring down a massive upcoming tour that includes a Coachella gig, you simply call one of the biggest superstars on the planet for your new single. â€œMoth to a Flameâ€ brings The Weeknd into their dance revival, and finds the right balance between the trioâ€™s electro impulses and Abel Tesfayeâ€™s pop sheen; if Swedish House Mafiaâ€™s two previously released singles since reuniting set the table for their comeback, this pulsating ode to craving someone you miss serves as a top-notch centerpiece.
Lana Del Rey, Blue Banisters
Lana Del Reyâ€™s artistry will never be easily contained, which is what makes her such a captivating pop singer-songwriter: her output waxes and wanes, her song lengths balloon and shrink, but when she fully harnesses her emotional power on a song or album, there simply are not many musicians who can match her. Blue Banisters continues a prolific moment for Del Rey -- the project arrives less than six months after Chemtrails Over The Country Club -- and while her latest roams around the darkness of her past and her complicated feelings on modern Americana, the brightest songwriting gems here, like the woozy â€œIf You Lie Down With Meâ€ and the incisive â€œWildflower Wildfire,â€ sparkle brilliantly. Elton John, The Lockdown Sessions
Donâ€™t look now, but Sir Elton John has a real top 40 hit on the current Hot 100: â€œCold Heart (PNAU Remix)â€ with Dua Lipa has leapt to No. 25 on the tally by refashioning some of the legendary singer-songwriterâ€™s most beloved hits into a new package -- alongside a modern star for good measure. Johnâ€™s quarantine-created new album The Lockdown Sessions operates in a similar manner, reminding the world of his genius while bringing new stars like Young Thug, Nicki Minaj, Lil Nas X and Charlie Puts into his orbit. Stick around for the end of the album, though, and youâ€™ll find tender collaborations with Johnâ€™s fellow all-timers, including Stevie Nicks on the epic duet â€œStolen Car.â€ Christina Aguilera feat. Becky G, Nicki Nicole & Nathy Peluso, â€œPa Mis Muchachasâ€
In between the 1999 self-titled debut that made her a star and the 2002 album Stripped that made her a cultural lightning rod, Christina Aguilera released an impressive Spanish-language album, Mi Reflejo, and diehard fans have been hoping for a return ever since. The wait is over, as â€œPa Mis Muchachasâ€ previews Aguileraâ€™s first Spanish-language project in 20 years with an all-star lineup of co-stars -- Becky G, Nicki Nicole and Nathy Peluso, all at the top of their games -- and a version of Aguilera that couldnâ€™t sound more confident.
Khalid, â€œPresentâ€
Before the end of the year, Khalid will return with a new project, Scenic Drive, that he likens to his stopgap Sun City EP from 2018. If â€œPresentâ€ is any indication, the pop star will use the tape to interrogate the more rhythmic side of his sound: the new song both embraces the tenets of old-school R&B while relying on Khalidâ€™s warble to convey a sense of urgency, making for a nice reminder of the singer-songwriterâ€™s talent and range. Lady A, What A Song Can Do
Four months ago, country trio Lady A released the first half of their album What A Song Can Do as a seven-song EP dubbed Chapter One of the new full-length. Now that the entire 14-track project has arrived, their intent is a bit more clear: What A Song Can Do aims to refocus the long-running project (which changed its name from Lady Antebellum last year) by honoring their fans and doubling down on immaculately produced country-pop, which shines on the heartfelt new track â€œIn Waves.â€ Majid Jordan, Wildest Dreams

title: Here's how we will choose our next Eurovision song
content:
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Subscribe today to get the latest Coventry Live headlines straight to your inbox with our free email updates
BBC Radio 1 have exclusively revealed that for Eurovision 2022, the BBC will be collaborating with music publishing company TaP Music in order to decide on the song that will be representing the United Kingdom in the upcoming competition.
The global music management corporation is the name behind some of the world's most successful pop sensations, including Dua Lipa, Ellie Goulding and Lana Del Rey.
Ben Mawson at TaP Music has said: "Weâ€™re really excited to be teaming up with the BBC for this event and will use Eurovision to authentically reflect and celebrate the rich, diverse and world-class musical talent the UK is globally renowned for."
The largest and most-watched music contest in the world, the forthcoming 66th Eurovision Song Contest is set to take place in Turin, Italy in May 2022.
The world-famous Grand Final has been confirmed for Saturday 14th May of next year.
BBC Studios will once again produce BBC coverage of the world-famous event.
Kate Phillips, Controller Entertainment Commissioning at the BBC has said: "In the UK our love for Eurovision is as big as ever and we have grand ambitions for the 2022 Contest.
"So, weâ€™re really excited to announce this collaboration that will enable us to tap into some great music talent."
The BBC One broadcast of the Eurovision Grand Final has been one of the most popular entertainment shows aired by the channel, with the 2021 broadcast reaching an average audience of 7.8 million in the UK. This made this year's competition the most-watched Grand Final in the UK since 2014.
(Image: BBC)
68 songs from 27 countries have been crowned winners of the competition as of 2021.
Ireland has the most wins under their belt with a grand total of seven, followed by Sweden with an impressive six. France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and the UK have all bagged five wins each.
The hit contest is also one of the most popular entertainment television shows for young people, with around 1.5 million people aged between 16-24 tuning in.
Suzy Lamb, Managing Director for BBC Studios has also commented: "BBC Studios are proud to once again be producing the coverage of the biggest music competition in world.
"Weâ€™re excited to be collaborating with TaP Music. Their expertise in managing world class artists and finding huge international hit records speaks for itself and we look forward to working with them on the UK act and song for the 2022 contest.â€
Further details will be announced in due course, but for the latest information on the United Kingdom at Eurovision 2022, follow @bbceurovision on Twitter and Instagram and BBC Eurovision on Facebook.

title: Global music management company to help choose UKâ€™s 2022 Eurovision entry
content:
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Get the latest news from Liverpool and Merseyside - don't miss our email bulletins
The UKâ€™s entry for the 2022 Eurovision Song Contest will be chosen in collaboration with a global music management company, the BBC has confirmed.
The broadcaster will work with TaP Music â€“ which counts Dua Lipa, Lana Del Rey and Ellie Goulding among its clients â€“ to select a song and act to represent the UK.
The 66th edition of the contest is due to be held in Turin, Italy, in May and TaP has called on the music industry to put forward â€œexperienced live performersâ€ for consideration.
The chosen song will be released commercially through a partnership with a major label.
In 2019, the BBC scrapped the public vote used to select the UKâ€™s entry, instead opting to give a record label the final say.
The 2021 competition was held in Rotterdam, Netherlands, after the show was cancelled in 2020, and won by Italyâ€™s rock band Maneskin with their song Zitti E Buoni.
The UK was handed a crushing defeat as its entry, singer James Newman, was the only one to score zero points from both the jury and public vote, coming bottom on the leaderboard.
Despite the disappointing result, Newman, the brother of singer John Newman, wrote in an Instagram post: â€œI want to focus on the positives of this amazing experience.
â€œI stood on a stage and sang to hundreds of millions of people with a song that I wrote and love.â€
Speaking soon after the event, former international trade secretary Liz Truss dismissed the idea the UKâ€™s snub was to do with Brexit and said there was a â€œfundamental problemâ€ with the way UK acts were chosen for the contest.
She told LBCâ€™s Nick Ferrari: â€œI think we need to have more competition to get the right entrant, I think they need to be more tested with the public.â€
Co-founder of TaP Music Ben Mawson said: â€œWeâ€™re really excited to be teaming up with the BBC for this event and will use Eurovision to authentically reflect and celebrate the rich, diverse and world-class musical talent the UK is globally renowned for.
â€œFor many years, weâ€™ve witnessed the United Kingdom not doing as well as we wouldâ€™ve liked, when pop music is something we usually excel at. The simple fact is itâ€™s time to show what we can do and the wonderful musical talent we have â€“ ultimately we canâ€™t blame politics.â€
Lipa said: â€œIâ€™m a proud Brit whilst also being a proud Kosovanâ€¦ Iâ€™m happy to lend my manager to the causeâ€¦ Iâ€™ll be cheering them on.â€
Kate Phillips, controller of entertainment commissioning for the BBC, said: â€œIn the UK our love for Eurovision is as big as ever and we have grand ambitions for the 2022 Contest, so weâ€™re really excited to announce this collaboration that will enable us to tap into some great music talent.â€
The managing director for BBC Studios, Suzy Lamb, added: â€œBBC Studios are proud to once again be producing the coverage of the biggest music competition in world.
â€œWeâ€™re excited to be collaborating with TaP Music. Their expertise in managing world class artists and finding huge international hit records speaks for itself and we look forward to working with them on the UK act and song for the 2022 contest.â€
The Eurovision Song Contest is due to take place in May 2022, with the Grand Final confirmed for May 14.
For more stories from where you live, visit InYourArea.

Kate Phillips, controller of entertainment commissioning for the BBC, said: â€œIn the UK our love for Eurovision is as big as ever and we have grand ambitions for the 2022 Contest, so weâ€™re really excited to announce this collaboration that will enable us to tap into some great music talent.â€
The managing director for BBC Studios, Suzy Lamb, added: â€œBBC Studios are proud to once again be producing the coverage of the biggest music competition in world.
â€œWeâ€™re excited to be collaborating with TaP Music. Their expertise in managing world class artists and finding huge international hit records speaks for itself and we look forward to working with them on the UK act and song for the 2022 contest.â€
The Eurovision Song Contest is due to take place in May 2022, with the Grand Final confirmed for May 14.
For more stories from where you live, visit InYourArea.

title: Did Lana Del Rey wear an $18 Shein dress on the red carpet?
content:
Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
Lana Del Rey might be the Artist of the Decade, but she still loves a bargain.
The â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ singer, 36, arrived at Varietyâ€™s Hitmakers Awards on Saturday to accept the prestigious honor.
But rather than rocking ripped-from-the-runway designer duds on the red carpet, she chose a laced-up mini in a green marbled print, casually layered beneath a baggy black jacket.
Fans on social media suspected Del Rey had snagged the revealing frock from popular fast fashion brand Shein, with many sharing screengrabs of a near-identical dress priced at about $18 from the retailerâ€™s website.
Del Rey styled the dress with a boxy black jacket and knee-high suede boots. Getty Images
â€œAbsolutely losing my mind at Lana Del Rey wearing an $18 Shein dress to the Variety Awards,â€ one person tweeted, along with side-by-side snaps of the starâ€™s look alongside the Shein modelâ€™s.
â€œLana in a Shein dress will forever be iconic. Like what does she spend her money on?â€ another asked, while a third quipped, â€œLana Del Rey collecting the Decade Award with an old jacket and a Shein dress. QUEEN.â€
Fans suspected Del Rey was wearing this sold-out Shein dress. Twitter
But there might be more to the â€œYoung and Beautifulâ€ croonerâ€™s ensemble than meets the eye.
Shein has landed in hot water for allegedly copying the work of smaller, independent designers; a rep for the brand previously told Page Six Style that Shein â€œtakes these issues very seriously and respects the intellectual property rights of artists and designers,â€ and that the company â€œ[has] policies and procedures in place to monitor and swiftly rectify any issues.â€
Still, it stands to reason that Del Rey couldâ€™ve snagged her dress elsewhere. @LanaDelReyClosets, a fan account that identifies the musicianâ€™s outfits, pointed out that Girlfairy sells a strikingly similar look for $47, for instance â€” and unlike the Shein dress, itâ€™s still in stock.
Girlfairy also sells a dress thatâ€™s strikingly similar to Del Reyâ€™s. Girlfairy
Del Rey has a history of hitting the red carpet in surprisingly accessible attire; who could forget when she showed up at the 2020 Grammys in a silver beaded gown sheâ€™d bought â€œlast minuteâ€ at the mall?
And while her latest look seems to be dividing her fans â€” â€œChoices. Options,â€ one pointedly tweeted, while another wrote that the dress â€œmakes me a little sadâ€ â€” itâ€™s safe to say Del Reyâ€™s taking it all in stride.
â€œIâ€™m grateful for all the criticism â€” I get a lot,â€ she joked while accepting her Variety award onstage.
A rep for Shein didnâ€™t immediately get back to us.

title: Lana Del Rey Says She Wants To Collaborate With The Migos: "I Love Them"
content:
Lana Del Rey says he wants to land a collaboration with the Migos out of all of her favorite artists. Lana spoke about what it would be like to work with them during an interview on the red carpet at Varietyâ€™s Hitmakers Brunch award ceremony, over the weekend.
â€œI love them. Everything they do,â€ she said. â€œThere was kind of like a new revolution of sound 11 years ago in the singer-songwriter community, which I loved seeing. And then with Migos, I think they kicked off a new super fun, super autobiographical, completely different style of rap. I love them.â€
Kevin Winter / Getty Images
Working with the Migos wouldn't be the first time Lana has crossed over into hip hop. She's previously collaborated with A$AP Rocky and Playboi Carti.
At the ceremony, Lana was awarded Artist Of The Decade for her contributions to music over the last ten years.
â€œThank you, Variety,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™m really always grateful for any acknowledgment and also super grateful for all the criticismâ€¦ I get a lot.â€ She also said that the biggest challenge for her over the last decade was â€œturning criticism into something that you can reflect upon â€¦ Thereâ€™s a lot of opinions. Iâ€™m very sensitive.â€
Lana released her eighth album, Blue Banisters, back in October.
[Via]

title: Producer Mike Dean on Working With Pop Smoke, Kanye West
content:
Mike Dean is fielding texts from Madonna, promoting his latest solo album, â€œ4:22,â€ nursing a joint and trying to answer interview questions. But thereâ€™s beauty in the chaos. Varietyâ€™s Hitmakers Producer of the Year does it so effortlessly â€” like a modern-day maestro conducting his own symphony â€” as he tries to remember the news of the various records heâ€™s worked on.
In March came word that â€œFor the Night,â€ the posthumous record by Pop Smoke, the Brooklyn drill rapper killed in a 2020 shooting, had been certified four-times-platinum. Dean, a co-producer on the song, was tasked with adding the â€œflutes, bells and whistlesâ€ to the ominous track. â€œIt was a little weird,â€ he admits, of the circumstances. â€œI didnâ€™t know him personally, but itâ€™s always hard [to lose someone].â€ Despite the tragedy, the record peaked at No. 6 on the Billboard Hot 100 and and the cert further solidified the late artistâ€™s legacy.
Over a three-decade career, rappers with whom Dean has been inextricably linked include Kid Cudi, Travis Scott and Kanye West, whose long-awaited 10th studio album, â€œDonda,â€ he worked on this year. Beginning in August, West held three public listening events â€” two in Atlanta at Mercedes-Benz Stadium and another in his hometown of Chicago at Soldier Field, each more of a spectacle than a chance to hear a body of music. After each one, West would go back to the drawing board and demand seemingly endless revisions.
Dean was present for both Atlanta events and is somewhat shocked â€œDondaâ€ wound up sounding so seamless. â€œItâ€™s really good,â€ he says of the album. â€œIt came out pretty cohesive. Iâ€™m kind of surprised because it was chaotic in the making. I was flown in at the eleventh hour and it was pretty stressful. I had to mix a ton of songs really fast. I think I did like 35 songs in 10 days.â€
Dean and Westâ€™s collaborative relationship dates back to 2003 when West started working on his debut album, â€œThe College Dropout.â€ Since then, Dean has been an invaluable instrument in the creation of all of Westâ€™s albums, including 2010â€™s critically acclaimed â€œMy Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasyâ€ and 2013â€™s â€œYeezus.â€
But itâ€™s not their similarities that make West and Dean a power duo. â€œWe are like yin and yang,â€ says the Texas native, who toured with Selena Quintanilla in his early days. â€œWe are real opposite personality-
wise,â€ he says of West, â€œand have entirely different skill sets.â€
Dean, a six-time Grammy winner, has recently cultivated a musical partnership with singer-songwriter Lana Del Rey, working on the song â€œWildflower Wildfireâ€ from Del Reyâ€™s eighth studio album, â€œBlue Banisters.â€
â€œIt was really cool,â€ Dean says of their collaboration. â€œShe had a rough sketch of the song and an outline, so she came to my house, we expanded on it and firmed it up a little bit. Hopefully we do more in the future.â€
Dean is focused on the road ahead, and 2022 sounds like itâ€™s shaping up to be another fruitful year. Not only is he continuing his partnership with music platform Beatclub, he also boasts upcoming projects with Christine and the Queens and Scott as well as his own compilation album featuring music from numerous artists heâ€™s worked with over the years â€” and thatâ€™s a lot.
Dean remains in high demand from artists across multiple genres, but there are occasions when he doesnâ€™t gel with someone. He has a simple solution for that. â€œSometimes we donâ€™t see eye-to-eye or donâ€™t have the right vibes,â€ he explains, adding with a laugh: â€œLike a bad first date, you just stop calling back.â€

title: Lana Del Rey's Decade of Music From 'Born to Die' to 'Blue Banisters'
content:
Some artists launch themselves into the world with a cautious toe in the water; some make a huge splash. Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€œVideo Games,â€ which may have been one of the first songs to â€œgo viral,â€ was more than just a song â€” it was a statement of intent and a blueprint for everything sheâ€™s done since. With loved-up, ominous lyrics cloaked in shadowy production, the baroque ballad heralded the arrival of a songwriter who wielded vulnerability like a weapon. Over the course of seven studio albums, the prolific Del Rey has refined her sound into many different shapes â€” all unmistakably her.
It all started in June 2011, when â€œVideo Gamesâ€ hit the internet. â€œI remember being in Long Island with my family and seeing the Weeknd post â€˜Video Gamesâ€™ on Tumblr,â€ Del Rey says. The song wasnâ€™t her debut â€” sheâ€™d released an album the previous year and an EP under her real name, Lizzy Grant, in 2008 â€” but it certainly was a lasting and far-reaching introduction to the world. â€œI canâ€™t say to what extent Iâ€™ve influenced anything. But I can say all of my creative cosplay â€” aka notes from my real life â€” did widen up the sound in popular music for people to make a departure from a pure pop sound to something more diarist.â€
From there, she was off and running. In 2012, she unveiled the sweeping, widescreen â€œBorn to Dieâ€ album; boosted by a deluxe edition (which included the Rick Rubin-produced â€œRideâ€), it spent 400 weeks on the Billboard 200.
She continued to branch out stylistically and seek new collaborators. For the follow-up, 2014â€™s â€œUltraviolence,â€ Del Rey explored a gritty, guitar-driven sound with producer Dan Auerbach of the Black Keys. â€œI learned how good it felt to be singing, writing and producing stylistically in a way that felt very natural and detail-oriented,â€ she recalls.
She would push the boundaries further on 2015â€™s dreamy, soundtrack-esque â€œHoneymoon,â€ a controversial curveball at the time that has since been embraced as a fan favorite. â€œI felt like I might be going in a more jazz-oriented direction, but the music of course did later pivot again,â€ she says.
Indeed: On 2017â€™s â€œLust for Life,â€ she widened her net of collaborators. â€œIt felt good to work with other people,â€ she explains. â€œI had been doing things in a very insular way up until that point.â€
Pivoting again, Del Rey then partnered with Jack Antonoff (known for his work with Taylor Swift, Lorde and St. Vincent) on â€œNorman Fucking Rockwell!â€ The multilayered, slightly â€™70s-flavored opus earned her a Grammy nomination for album of the year. Says Del Rey: â€œThat meant a lot because I knew it was probably my best album. Iâ€™m usually almost exactly right on my gauge of what people will probably hate or love. Iâ€™m somewhat psychic in that way.â€ Antonoff also produced her first 2021 album, â€œChemtrails Over the Country Club,â€ but Del Rey largely took the helm for the majestic follow-up, â€œBlue Banisters.â€
Yet when looking back at her body of work, Del Rey is hard-pressed to offer highlights. â€œThere were moments while I was making â€˜Honeymoon,â€™ moments while mixing â€˜Ultraviolence,â€™ then writing â€˜Norman Rockwell!â€™ and producing my own album, â€˜Blue Banisters,â€™ that all stand out to me,â€ she reflects. â€œBut to be honest â€” and this is the takeaway â€” my proudest achievement is continuing to uphold my personal truth in a time when truth is often questioned and rarely valued.â€

title: TaP Music's Ed Millet and Wendy Ong on Managing Lana Del Rey, Dua Lipa
content:
In this weekâ€™s installment of Strictly Business, Varietyâ€™s weekly podcast featuring conversations with industry leaders about the business of media and entertainment, TaP Musicâ€™s Ed Millet and Wendy Ong go deep about the rewards and challenges of managing such prominent and pioneering artists as Lana Del Rey, Dua Lipa, Ellie Goulding, Caroline Polacheck, Noah Cyrus and many more.
The conversation starts with Millet discussing founding the company in 2010 with his partner, fellow co-CEO Ben Mawson, and how Del Reyâ€™s skyrocketing career basically dominated their first 18 months in business. But it soon turns toward the challenges that she and they faced, first from skeptical record companies, then from Del Reyâ€™s insistence that â€œVideo Gamesâ€ â€” â€œa five-minute song that doesnâ€™t really have a chorus,â€ as he says â€” be her first single, and then trying to keep her career on track as it took off faster and bigger than they had expected.
He and Ong, who joined the company as president in 2018, also get deep about the aggressive nastiness and outright misogyny their largely female roster encounters online, and how they help their artists cope with it â€” they even propose that record-label contracts should include provisions for therapy and other forms of mental health, if theyâ€™re going to so strongly encourage artists to engage on social media and share so much of their lives in public forums.
They also discussed Dua Lipaâ€™s decision to release her very party-centric album â€œFuture Nostalgiaâ€ just as the pandemic was beginning in March of 2020 â€” and how, even though it seemed completely out of step with the mood of that time, it went on to win a Grammy and, more importantly, provide a welcome relief and release for so many people, who got their grooves on at home in their pajamas instead of the club.
Of course, thereâ€™s much more to TaP Music than the above artists. The company also represents many other up-and-coming artists, as well as songwriters and producers, and also boasts a label, publishing company and digital marketing unit. Millet, who co-founded TaP in 2010 with music attorney Ben Mawson, had previously worked in management for Moby and the Kinksâ€™ Ray Davies as well as his own band. Ong, a veteran of Varietyâ€™s Power of Women list, brings a remarkably diverse background to TaP. She began her career with music industry posts in her native Singapore as well as Hong Kong before moving to the U.S. to take prominent marketing roles at major labels, working alongside Clive Davis and Diddy. She then transitioned to New Yorkâ€™s Metropolitan Opera â€” and then made an even more dramatic shift to chief marketing officer of Jay-Zâ€™s Roc Nation â€” before settling at TaP Management, where she was named president in 2018.
Listen to this weekâ€™s episode of Strictly Business below.

title: Cat Power - Covers review: Her finest set of interpretations yet
content:
Review at a glance
D oing a cover version is often the easy option â€“ a shortcut to audience approval for a new band, a tribute that requires less effort than writing something new, or a hastily rehearsed novelty for Radio 1â€™s Live Lounge segment. In contrast Chan Marshall, the Miami-based singer-songwriter who trades as Cat Power, has spent her long career putting more effort into them than most. This is her third covers album, after The Covers Record in 2000 and Jukebox in 2008. Thereâ€™s also a covers EP, Dark End of the Street, while the strongest moment on her last album of mostly original songs, Wanderer, was a spooky reworking of the Rihanna hit Stay.
She tends to push the songs into her world rather than meeting them where they sit, which means languid, multi-layered vocals, loosely arranged organic instrumentation, and a casual way with phrasing and melody that can make the source close to unrecognisable. Itâ€™s hard to hear Liza Minnelli or Frank Sinatra anywhere in her Jukebox version of New York, New York, for example. Her distinctive style also allows wildly disparate songs to become comfortable neighbours. This collection opens with Frank Oceanâ€™s tortured ballad Bad Religion, from 2012, its churchy organ replaced by steady piano chords and a textured electric guitar line, while it finishes with Iâ€™ll Be Seeing You, a torch song made famous by Billie Holiday, Frank Sinatra and Bing Crosby in the 1940s.
The only song that feels underthought is These Days, where the plucked guitar line is slower but much the same as on Nicoâ€™s famous version. Elsewhere she ditches the maudlin piano of Lana Del Reyâ€™s White Mustang in favour of shimmering keyboards and a howling guitar, finds a groovier bassline than Iggy Popâ€™s when she reimagines his 1979 song The Endless Sea, and takes The Poguesâ€™ A Pair Of Brown Eyes to another level of beauty when she strips it back to just a wispy mellotron and the tale of lost love in the lyrics.
The songs are picked for their personal significance rather than wider familiarity, a strategy that extends to covering herself. Unhate is a new chapter to her 2006 recording Hate, on which the line â€œI hate myself and want to dieâ€ becomes â€œI hated myselfâ€¦â€. It shows that sheâ€™s in a good place â€“ a strong position from which to deliver her finest set of interpretations yet.

title: Cat Power: Covers review - the healing work of a singer reborn
content:
Dancing, ceremony, aural wallpaper: the uses of music are legion. Often, though, succour is key, a kind of aural hug you could elevate to the 10th power when it comes to cover versions.
It would be limiting to cast Cat Powerâ€™s three albums of other peopleâ€™s songs as mere public acts of self-soothing â€“ Georgia-born, New York-seasoned, Miami-dwelling Chan Marshall, three decades in the game, is far too versatile and canny a musician for that. She has eight albums of her own soft-touch incantation under her belt, and a particular aesthetic all her own.
Her sense of space, the way she overdubs and layers her vocals, her predilection for trance-like repetition and the gauzy veils she places between the listener and her bandâ€™s instruments, her midlife repositioning as a soul singer of soothing warmth: all attest to Marshallâ€™s ongoing artistic imperatives and technical nous.
But through The Covers Record (2000), Jukebox (2008) and now Covers, there is a sense that, for Marshall, other peopleâ€™s songs provide not just tunes to tune up to, but sustenance and fellow-feeling. These tracks seem very much the aural companions to a life that has rarely been straightforward, even by itinerant musician standards: bouts of ill health, a breakdown. Itâ€™s possible Marshall has always multitracked her vocals to feel less alone. Now, she has a particularly sonorous band too â€“ veterans of her standout 2018 album, Wanderer â€“ making this record the best-played and arguably the classiest of the series.
If thereâ€™s a recurrent theme to this set of diverse covers, itâ€™s probably drinking. By her own admission, Marshall spent the early to mid-00s â€œliving inside a bottleâ€. On Covers, she pours herself into a couple of famous barflyâ€™s laments. It takes a lot of courage to tackle the Pogues; Marshall takes on A Pair of Brown Eyes, in which two men are wrecked by alcohol, lost love and the vicissitudes of war, armed only with a Mellotron and a couple of microphones. Her own backing vocals maintain a thread of the songâ€™s link to Irish folk.
Marshallâ€™s tendency to abbreviate and deconstruct songs is one of her outstanding assets
Here Comes a Regular by the Replacements, by contrast, was on the jukebox at Monaâ€™s, the East Village bar Marshall frequented in her 20s. This Cat Power version ditches guitar for piano, making a very sad song about being a regular â€“ the anti-Cheers, if you will â€“ even more bereft.
Happily, this brace of songs comes at a time when the singerâ€™s fortunes have been on the up, buoyed up by the success of Wanderer, her rebirth. Dropped by her former label, Marshall found a new one, then garnered mainstream plaudits and received generous dues and support slots from a welter of artists.
Sheâ€™s been tight with Lana Del Rey for some time, a sisterhood reflected on Covers in Marshallâ€™s rendition of Del Reyâ€™s 2017 track White Mustang. The only downside is that few artistic surprises result.
Until Woman â€“ Cat Powerâ€™s 2018 female-forward track with Del Rey on backing vocals â€“ Marshall rarely mentioned gender in any pointed way. Here, [ONLINE ONLY] She also covers the extraordinary It Wasnâ€™t God Who Made Honky Tonk Angels, by the postwar country star Kitty Wells, as a slinky, bluesy roll. Although Marshallâ€™s affection for the song dates back to childhood, it has renown too. Written by a man, JD Miller, but owned by Wells, the song despaired at women being forever blamed for the infidelity of men. In 1952 it took Wells to the top of the Billboard country charts, the first woman to get there solo, amid considerable disquiet from the music establishment. Again, pedal steel and the steady pulse of bass retain the songâ€™s country roots.
It would be unreasonable to complain about a Cat Power album sounding too much like a Cat Power album, especially when this might well be the most well-rounded and sophisticated of her three outings of homage. Marshallâ€™s tendency to abbreviate and deconstruct songs is one of her outstanding assets as an interpreter. Witness this albumâ€™s excellent lead track, Frank Oceanâ€™s Bad Religion, or previously, on Jukebox, her cut-up version of Rihannaâ€™s Stay. Yet Marshallâ€™s pointillist take on Nick Caveâ€™s I Had a Dream, Joe, just emphasising certain lines from the songâ€™s narrative, doesnâ€™t land as convincingly as it might.
This record is not samey, exactly. The distance travelled between the Cave cover, or Iggy Popâ€™s The Endless Sea â€“ all prowly portent â€“ and Iâ€™ll Be Seeing You, the closing lament made famous by Billie Holiday, is not insignificant. But the prevailing atmosphere remains one of wistfulness, of lives taking only many left turns. All this is perhaps not surprising, given Marshallâ€™s long-ago backstory and the events of the past 20 or so months. If Wanderer promised more bold artistic statements, Covers pivots on sorely needed understanding. That feeling is relayed in turn to the listener: hugs galore.

title: Father John Misty Announces New Album, Shares Video for New Song â€œFunny Girlâ€: Watch
content:

The new album was produced with Josh Tillmanâ€™s longtime collaborator Jonathan Wilson. It was mixed by Dave Cerminara and the album features arrangements from Drew Erickson. In addition to the standard vinyl, CD, cassette, and digital releases, the albumâ€™s limited deluxe edition comes in a hardcover book featuring bonus 7" singles. One includes Lana Del Reyâ€™s cover of the album track â€œBuddyâ€™s Rendezvous,â€ and the other features Jack Cruzâ€™s version of â€œKiss Me (I Loved You).â€ Find the albumâ€™s tracklist and artwork below.
Father John Misty last released Godâ€™s Favorite Customer in 2018. Since November, heâ€™s been posting cryptic imagery teasing the albumâ€™s arrival on his Instagram.
