title: The best albums of 2021, from Dave and Arlo Parks to Lana del Rey and Little Simz
content:
W hile gig going is far from back to normal, at least musicians havenâ€™t forgotten how to make great albums. The past year has been stuffed with recorded music, both lockdown creations and big releases that had been delayed in hope of the old ways returning.
Itâ€™s many years since we had an autumn quite so starry, with Adele, ABBA, Ed Sheeran and Coldplay all making comebacks, but the very best releases were elsewhere. Here are a dozen of them.
Clairo â€“ Sling
(Fader/Republic/Polydor)
Bedroom pop, the current term for lo-fi, understated music that couldnâ€™t sit further from an arena confetti explosion, stepped out into the open in 2021. Dodie, Girl in Red and Claire â€œClairoâ€ Cottrill all made sophisticated albums. The latterâ€™s second is the most surprising, a transition from her debut that abandons her previous indie electronic mix in favour of chamber pop strings, muted brass, piano and acoustic guitar. Maybe it was part of producer Jack Antonoffâ€™s plan to create a new Laurel Canyon â€“ his recent work with Lana Del Rey, Lorde and Taylor Swift has a similar warm folky feel. Either way it successfully shunted Clairo from an internet curiosity to a mature songwriter whoâ€™ll last.
Dave â€“ Weâ€™re All Alone in This Together
(Neighbourhood)
David Orobosa Omoregie set himself an extremely high bar with his 2019 debut, Psychodrama, which went platinum and won the Mercury Prize and the Brit Award for Album of the Year. On the follow-up he keeps the musical backdrop minimal but really stretches out with his lyricism, digging deeper into the hardships of his early life but also, on Three Rivers, tacking the immigrant experience as a whole. Heart Attack in particular is an extraordinary 10-minute journey, with Dave carrying on rapping long after the music has stopped and wrapping up with a sobbing speech from his mother.
Lana Del Rey - Chemtrails Over the Country Club
(Polydor)
Without a world tour to eat into her time, Lana Del Rey has been recording at a fierce clip lately. This one was the second of three albums she released in just over two years, not including a spoken word recording of her poetry. Chemtrails Over the Country Club isnâ€™t as expansive as its career-high predecessor, Norman F***ing Rockwell!, but hangs together more coherently than its follow-up, Blue Banisters. Del Rey keeps the feel as romantic and tortured as ever but also seems at ease, putting her friends on the sleeve and bringing some low-key musical buddies in for a cover from Joni Mitchellâ€™s Ladies of the Canyon album.
Sam Fender - Seventeen Going Under
(Polydor)
Like a northern indie rock version of Dave, Sam Fender put himself under the microscope on his second album, presenting unflinching personal detail that also said something profound about the rest of us: teenage fist fights, difficult fathers and suicidal thoughts are all present in his heartwrenching songs. The difference is the music, which is so exhilarating and euphoric â€“ massed guitars, strings and stratospheric choruses â€“ itâ€™s no wonder heâ€™ll be playing it to ecstatic arenas in the spring. Yes, he still sounds like his idol Bruce Springsteen, but his honesty makes the songs unmistakably his own.
For Those I Love - For Those I Love
(September)
I keep playing this one to people this year, insisting how great it is, and it doesnâ€™t always get a positive reaction. Some will falter at David Balfeâ€™s thick Irish accent, which transports the dance beats and spoken word tales of The Streets to the streets of Dublin. But the pain in that brogue is profoundly powerful as he details the fallout from the suicide of his best friend. Thereâ€™s bleak drinking and attempts at partying: â€œThe songs sound fun and you dance with your mates/And itâ€™s grand then until the next day,â€ he says, sounding like things definitely arenâ€™t grand. Thereâ€™s also, eventually, a glimmer of hope.
Fred again.. - Actual Life (April 14 - December 17 2020)
(Atlantic)
Londoner Fred Gibson has been the main producer on Ed Sheeranâ€™s last two albums and worked on rap tracks by Stormzy and Headie One. None of that music indicates the intimate appeal of the two solo albums he has released this year. Both Actual Life and last monthâ€™s follow-up, Actual Life 2, have date ranges as their subtitles to show their status as musical diaries. The songs are named after the people he has sampled, scattering these found sounds over dance music with a soft sadness at its core. Itâ€™s a moving chronicle of a year like no other, dominated by one supportive slogan: â€œWe gonâ€™ make it through.â€
Valerie June - The Moon and Stars: Prescriptions for Dreamers
(Fantasy)
Memphis singer-songwriter Valerie June has a reputation as a vintage throwback, previously working with retro enthusiast producer Dan Auerbach of The Black Keys and memorably describing her songs as â€œorganic moonshine roots musicâ€. Which makes her latest album a fascinating surprise. It roams widely, sprinkling a shimmer of psychedelia over her country-folk baseline. There are digital beats on Within You, trippy interludes designed for meditation and a guest spot from Stax soul veteran Carla Thomas, whose voice is a fine counterpoint to Juneâ€™s feline purr.
Little Simz - Sometimes I Might Be Introvert
(Age 101)
The reclusive producer Inflo released yet another excellent Sault album this year, as well as making some key contributions to Adeleâ€™s 30, but his best work was on the expansive soul sound of Simbiatu Ajikawoâ€™s fourth long player. The opening track Introvert in particular is significantly less timid than its title, an onslaught of choir, drums and orchestra that confirm Little Simz as our most sonically ambitious rapper. Meanwhile, lyrically speaking she is more gripping than ever, tackling broken family relationships, feminism and her own love-hate relationship with fame.
Arlo Parks - Collapsed in Sunbeams
(Transgressive)
Arlo Parks pipped Wolf Alice and Celeste to this yearâ€™s Mercury Prize with a debut album that was a comforting hug in a dark year. Though itâ€™s almost too softly spoken musically, with an easygoing, jazzy style that recalls Nineties trip hop, her status as a poet allows her to hit nails on heads throughout. There are fascinating microscopic details and universal themes, and overall, a feeling of much needed reassurance. On Hope, she sings: â€œYouâ€™re not alone like you think you are/We all have scars, I know itâ€™s hard.â€
Olivia Rodrigo â€“ Sour
(Interscope)
Olivia Rodrigoâ€™s well-trodden path from Disney Channel to pop singer might have suggested obligatory career box-ticking rather than anything genuinely special. However, the Californian teenagerâ€™s debut single, the slow-burning emotion of Drivers License, was a phenomenon, spending nine weeks at number one in the UK and 10 in the US. She pulled off its trick â€“ making opera-level drama out of the standard experiences of growing up â€“ again and again on her debut album, wishing happiness but not too much of it to an ex on Happier, and wondering â€œWhereâ€™s my f***ing teenage dream?â€ on the appropriately named Brutal.
Self Esteem â€“ Prioritise Pleasure
(Fiction)
Not many pop singers are making albums that suggest everything is great these days, but Sheffieldâ€™s Rebecca Taylor did a particularly fine job of sticking chilis in the ice cream. Her big, loud synthpop songs are riddled with pain and insecurity, also encouraging the women listening to â€œLook up, lean back, be strong,â€ as she puts it on her breakthrough single, I Do This All The Time. The rumbling opening song, Iâ€™m Fine, trumpets feminist freedom while finishing with a woman revealing that she and her friends bark like dogs in an attempt to defuse intimidating groups of men. Itâ€™s a brilliant album that voices the contradictions of being a woman today and never stints on the tunes.
Wolf Alice - Blue Weekend
(Dirty Hit)

title: Lana Del Rey Wants to Collaborate With the Migos: 'I Love Them'
content:
Lana Del Rey has worked with various artists throughout her lengthy career. Over the years, the Grammy-nominated singer has worked with rappers, despite much of her music shying away from traditional hip-hop sounds.
Lana Del Rey | Rodin Eckenroth/FilmMagic
Lana Del Rey wants to make a song with the Migos
Del Rey has collaborated with A$AP Rocky and Playboi Carti on songs before; Rocky even appeared in the music video for her 2012 hit â€œNational Anthem.â€
In December 2021, Del Rey attended Varietyâ€™s Hitmakers Brunch award ceremony and spoke on the red carpet about who she would love to work with in the future: Atlanta-bred hip-hop group Migos.
â€œI love them. Everything they do,â€ the singer said. â€œThere was kind of like a new revolution of sound 11 years ago in the singer-songwriter community, which I loved seeing. And then with Migos, I think they kicked off a new super fun, super autobiographical, completely different style of rap. I love them.â€
(L-R) Quavo, Offset, and Takeoff of Migos | Kevin Winter/Getty Images for Global Citizen
RELATED: Why Lana Del Rey Refuses to Sing a Line From Her Controversial Song â€˜Ultraviolenceâ€™
Lana Del Rey once looked up to Eminem â€” until he rapped about wanting to punch her
Del Reyâ€™s appreciation for hip-hop dates back years. In a 2012 interview with Italian publication R&B Junk, she said â€œI f***ing love Eminemâ€ and dubbed him â€œthe master of lyrics.â€
Eminem responded â€” sort of â€” in a 2014 cypher promoting the Shady Records compilation Shady XV. Slim Shady took the stage in a group freestyle after artists such as Royce Da 5â€™9â€³ and Yelawolf and rapped how he really felt about Del Rey.
â€œBut I may fight for gay rights, especially if they d*** is more of a knockout than Janay Rice / Play nice? B**** Iâ€™ll punch Lana Del Rey right in the face twice, like Ray Rice in broad daylight in the plain sight of the elevator surveillance / â€™Til her head is banging on the railing, then celebrate with the Ravens,â€ Eminem said.
RELATED: Lana Del Rey Incites Fan Fury For Implying â€˜The Cultureâ€™ Supports BeyoncÃ©, Nicki Minaj Over Women Like Her
Lana Del Rey has criticized artists like BeyoncÃ© and Nicki Minaj in the past
In the past, Del Rey herself has had a bone to pick with rappers and other women singers in the industry. In May 2020, in a now-deleted infamous Instagram post, Del Rey posed a â€œquestion to the cultureâ€ and revealed she was fed up with â€œfemale writers and alt singersâ€ saying she glamorizes abuse in her music.
â€œNow that Doja Cat, Ariana, Camila, Cardi B, Kehlani, and Nicki Minaj and BeyoncÃ© have had number ones with songs about being sexy, wearing no clothes, f*****g, cheating etc â€“ can I please go back to singing about being embodied, feeling beautiful by being in love even if the relationship is not perfect, or dancing for money â€“ or whatever I want â€“ without being crucified or saying that Iâ€™m glamorizing abuse??????â€ she said.

title: Go easy on me: why pop has got so predictable
content:
The biggest album launch of 2021 began with a social media statement tacitly assuring fans that nothing had changed. Adele was once more in a state of heartbreak â€“ â€œa maze of absolute mess and inner turmoil â€¦ consumed by my own griefâ€ â€“ and that the contents of her album 30 would reflect that, as mired in romantic misery as its predecessors, 25 and 21. It was the musical equivalent, she said, of a friend who comes over â€œwith a bottle of wine and a takeawayâ€ to discuss the disastrous state of your love life.
The second-biggest album launch of 2021 was preceded by its creators proudly announcing they had written it â€œabsolutely trend-blindâ€. Abba had traversed a considerable musical distance over the course of their original career, buffeted by the shifting musical trends of the 70s and early 80s â€“ from the clompy Europop of their debut album to the sophisticated, chilly electronics of The Visitors, by way of glam and sleek disco â€“ but Voyage would offer them preserved in amber, exactly as they were in the late 70s, unspoiled by any musical trends from the 40 years since their split.
Elsewhere, Ed Sheeranâ€™s fourth solo album = was not built to startle fans or cause detractors to reconsider their position â€“ whatever you already thought of him, positive or negative, you could find evidence to support your view â€“ and Lana Del Rey released not one but two albums that, like every Lana Del Rey album, consisted of variations on the same theme. More morose, glacial ballads, more neâ€™er-do-well boyfriends who â€œnever give nothing backâ€, more ruminations on the dark side of fame, more musical evidence of her love of Mazzy Star, more lyrical assurances that its author is a bad girl. You could construct an argument that she has honed her aesthetic over the last decade, but sheâ€™s certainly not dramatically overhauled it. And then there was Drakeâ€™s Certified Lover Boy, as one critic put it, â€œan 86-minute omnibus of all things Drakeâ€. The listener confronted with its stew of self-pity, braggadocio, passive-aggression and solipsism could have complained that we had been here before, many times, over the course of Drakeâ€™s career, but there didnâ€™t seem to be many dissatisfied customers: the album broke first-day streaming records on both Apple Music and Spotify.
Perhaps what people want from pop music is reassurance and comfort rather than startling novelty
There was a time when artists who wilfully repeated themselves were the subject of mockery â€“ think of all the jokes aimed Status Quoâ€™s way in the late 70s and 80s, and the snarky comparisons to Status Quo lobbed at Oasis once Britpopâ€™s shine wore off â€“ or when continually doing the same thing was a sure-fire way to truncate your career. You didnâ€™t have to be David Bowie or Prince, constantly reinventing yourself in such dramatic style that you were bound to shed at least a few puzzled fans along the way, but if you simply dealt in more of the same, audiences would realise your limitations had been reached and move on to something else. In 2021, however, it frequently felt as if the best way to maintain oneâ€™s place at the pinnacle of pop was by doing exactly what audiences expected them to.
Certainly, one of the factors in the relatively muted response to another of 2021â€™s hotly anticipated albums, Billie Eilishâ€™s Happier Than Ever, seemed to be that it shifted from the blueprint established on its predecessors: the hoodie-clad teenage goth who made them replaced by a blonde vamp posing for Vogue in an Alexander McQueen corset; the trap-influenced bangers that had populated 2019â€™s multi-platinum When We All Fall Asleep Where Do We Go? were now mostly absent. Moreover, you got the feeling that Eilish had done it deliberately, keen to calm down the hysteria that, judging by the albumâ€™s lyrics, had made her life a misery. She had realised that, in the current climate, just altering her approach slightly â€“ it was hardly a completely confounding, who-is-this? reinvention â€“ would do the trick. Meanwhile, Lordeâ€™s also highly anticipated third album Solar Power â€“ another retreat from stardom and angst, this time into benign sun-worshipping pop and homespun wisdom â€“ sank without trace.
Why has the predictable become a preference? One theory is that itâ€™s linked to the turbulence of modern times. In a year that began with the storming of the Capitol and ended with the Omicron variant, the wider world provided more than enough shocks: perhaps what people want from pop music is reassurance and comfort rather than startling novelty.
Another is that it has something to do with the oft-mentioned desire for a kind of putative â€œauthenticityâ€ in pop music. We are always hearing about how important it is for 21st-century artists to appear #relatable, something that is certainly central to the success of Adele andSheeran, as well as Drakeâ€™s whole Iâ€™m-a-multi-millionaire-playa-but-Iâ€™m-sad-too shtick and Lana Del Reyâ€™s dogged, angry insistence that she is not inhabiting a Ziggy Stardust-ish character, but writing about herself. How #relatable can an artist be if they keep changing all the time, if the music you #related to suddenly becomes different?
Or perhaps it has more to do with the shifts in the way we consume music. Before the internet, pop existed in a relatively small, heavily curated space, bounded by radio, whatever TV shows featured it and the music press: comparatively few artists broke into it, so audiences expected those that did to keep things fresh by regularly altering their approach. Now the opposite is true. We live in a madly diverse, globalised media climate. The sheer availability and abundance of music is overwhelming: 60,000 new tracks are added to Spotify alone every day, and the number of sources from which we can access music at the touch of a button (TikTok, Bandcamp) is constantly expanding. The stylistic and generic boundaries and striking, short-circuiting shifts in taste that once informed pop musicâ€™s progress â€“ the rise of punk, or electronic pop, the dramatic flowering of hip-hop, the arrival of acid house â€“ increasingly seem like a thing of the past. The chaotic recombinations of hyperpop or the thrilling propulsion of drill show that there is still innovation at popâ€™s fringes. But in a crowded, confusing market, in which music fans act as their own curators, cherrypicking from a vast variety of sources, it is more important than it once was for big artists to maintain an immediately recognisable sonic brand.
If that is the case, then this isnâ€™t a trend or an example of failing inspiration â€“ itâ€™s the way things are, and are likely to stay. If you want to get to the top of pop, you will have minimal room for manoeuvre if you want to stay there.

title: Kim Kardashian is promoting the trend for short nails. Is this the end of long â€œclawsâ€ to which celebrities have got us used to?
content:
Models, rap artists, influencers, singers â€“ many of them promote the fashion for very long nails. Is this the end of this era? Perhaps, especially since Kim Kardashian began to promote the short manicure trend.
Cardi B, Kylie Jenner, RosalÃ­a, Lana del Rey, Billie Eilish, Dua Lipa â€“ these are just a few celebrities who have promoted very long acrylic nails. And although this type of mani looks great in music videos, in â€œreal lifeâ€ such nails make everyday life more difficult. There are many indications that the trend for natural, short nails will return. Reason? All thanks to the aforementioned Kim Kardashiana celebrity inspired by millions of women â€“ also in show business.
Kim Kardashian is promoting the trend for short nails. Is this the end of long â€œclawsâ€ to which celebrities have got us used to?
It all started with instastory. A few days ago, Kim showed her fans how to play with plastic mass for children, but it was not the toy that everyone paid attention to, but the American manicure. A star known for her love of long nails showed a look inspired by New York shows for the spring-summer 2022 season. Yes! At presentations of brands such as Ulla Johnson, Jason Wu or Tory Burch, short mani in neutral colors were promoted. BeÅ¼ has already liked Kardashianka and itâ€™s only a matter of time until this trend continues.
Looking at Kim Kardashianâ€™s previous actions, now many of her fans will embrace this idea. After all, it is known for a long time that the Kardashian-Jenner clan is responsible for many trends. Letâ€™s recall the contouring craze that started a few years ago because of the star of the reality show â€œWith the Kardashianâ€™s Cameraâ€.

title: Why Lana Del Rey Wanted A$AP Rocky to Play JFK in the 'National Anthem' Video
content:
A$AP Rocky played JFK in the music video for Lana Del Reyâ€˜s â€œNational Anthem.â€ During an interview, Del Rey explained why she cast A$AP Rocky as the president. The videoâ€™s director also discussed his interpretation of the casting.
A$AP Rocky | Arturo Holmes/Getty Images for Tribeca Festival
Why Lana Del Reyâ€™s music video for â€˜National Anthemâ€™ depicts JFK, Jacqueline Kennedy, and Marilyn Monroe
The music video for â€œNational Anthemâ€ features A$AP Rocky as JFK and Del Rey in a dual role as Jacqueline Kennedy and Marilyn Monroe. The video was directed by Anthony Mandler. Mandler is a music video director known for helming videos by Rihanna, Taylor Swift, Nicki Minaj, Drake, and numerous other stars. During a 2012 interview with MTV News, he discussed the idea behind the â€œNational Anthemâ€ video.
Mandler saw the love triangle between JFK, his wife, and Monroe as a classic forbidden love story. He repeatedly compared their real-life tragedies to Romeo and Juliet. He said Del Rey used the lives of these three historical figures to explore loss.
JFK and Jacqueline Kennedy | Bettmann / Contributor
RELATED: Adele Says This Lana Del Rey Song Makes Her Feel Like She Is Flying
Lana Del Rey wanted A$AP Rocky in the video from the beginning
In a 2012 interview with BBC Radio 1, Del Rey discussed A$AP Rockyâ€™s casting. â€œEvery so often, I top what Iâ€™ve done, and this video is definitely the most beautiful thing Iâ€™ve ever done,â€ she said. â€œI wrote a treatment for me and A$AP Rocky, because I just thought heâ€™d be really perfect to star in it. I love it.â€
In the MTV News interview mentioned above, Mandler discussed the significance of A$AP Rockyâ€™s casting. â€œWe used the Kennedy framework to kind of implement this new Camelot, this racially diverse Camelot, this maybe socially diverse Camelot â€¦ bringing it into the modern era, but still keeping that classic framework,â€ he explained. For context, â€œCamelotâ€ is a term used to refer to JFKâ€™s presidency.
Mandler also revealed there was social commentary in the casting of the video. â€œThereâ€™s a kind of micro-commentary of â€˜This is the new royalty,â€™ you know, A$AP and Lana, trying to pick two people to maybe represent the next generation of something,â€ he revealed. â€œI think even with an African American president, itâ€™s still controversial to see him sitting and playing JFK, itâ€™s still taboo, even if it shouldnâ€™t be.â€
RELATED: Elvis Presley: Lana Del Rey Feels Sheâ€™s Friends With Him and Other Dead Celebrities
The way the world reacted to â€˜National Anthemâ€™
â€œNational Anthemâ€ was a modest hit in the United States. The tune reached No. 37 on Billboardâ€™s Hot Rock & Alternative Songs chart. Meanwhile, Born to Die peaked at No. 2 on the Billboard 200 and lasted 417 weeks on the chart.
â€œNational Anthemâ€ became a minor hit in the United Kingdom as well. According to The Official Charts Company, the song reached No. 92 there and stayed on the chart for two weeks. â€œNational Anthemâ€ appeared on Del Reyâ€™s album Born to Die. Born to Die was No. 1 in the U.K. for two weeks of its 150 weeks on the chart.
â€œNational Anthemâ€ became a minor hit â€” and its video wouldnâ€™t be the same without A$AP Rocky.
RELATED: John Lennonâ€™s Son Said Making a Song With Lana Del Rey Changed His Life

title: â€˜Euphoria,â€™ â€˜Shang-Chiâ€™ & More Bring Soundtrack Songs to Global Charts
content:
The Encanto soundtrack continues to infuse Billboardâ€˜s charts, with eight of its songs on the Feb. 5-dated Billboard Global 200 and five on the Billboard Global Excl. U.S. list. The newest addition to the animated filmâ€™s global chart haul is the almost-title track, Carlos Vivesâ€™ â€œColombia, Mi Encanto,â€ which arrives at No. 172 on the Global 200.
(In the U.S., the soundtrack tops the Billboard 200 for a third week, while its breakout ensemble anthem â€œWe Donâ€™t Talk About Brunoâ€ hits No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming just the second leader ever from a Disney animated film.)
Still, other films and television series spark entrances on the latest global charts.
Currently in its second season, HBOâ€™s Euphoria is not only enjoying booming ratings, but a cultural breakthrough due to its original songs. Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€œWatercolor Eyes,â€ released Jan. 21 in advance of the Jan. 23 episode of the seriesâ€™ second season, debuts at Nos. 101 and 125 on the Global 200 and Global Excl. U.S. rankings, respectively. In the week ending Jan. 27, the song drew 11.2 million streams and sold 2,500 downloads worldwide, according to MRC Data.
Along with Del Reyâ€™s contribution, the showâ€™s momentum also props up songs from its first season, which aired in 2019. Labrinth debuts on the Global 200 with â€œAll for Us,â€ featuring vocals by the seriesâ€™ Emmy Award-winning star Zendaya, at No. 154. The song was featured in the first seasonâ€™s finale in a surreal choreographed scene akin to a music video.
â€œAll for Usâ€ scored 9.6 million streams in the tracking week, up 19% from the previous frame. It consistently circled 1-to-1.5 million global streams a week in the final months of 2021, before Euphoria returned. At the same time, its weekly worldwide sales have grown from less than 100 downloads to around 600.
Labrinthâ€™s only previous global chart appearance (since the surveys launched in September 2020) was via another Euphoria track: â€œStill Donâ€™t Know My Nameâ€ spent seven weeks on both lists in 2020. That song was drawing 3.5-to-3.75 million global streams per week before the second season premiere and grew to 8.4 million in the latest tracking week.
Elsewhere, Niki debuts at No. 181 on the Global Excl. U.S. chart with â€œEvery Summertime,â€ her contribution to the soundtrack for Marvelâ€™s Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings. And as Shang-Chi marked a breakthrough for Asian actors in major blockbusters, Nikiâ€™s global chart arrival marks further representation among Indonesian artists; fellow Indonesian singer-songwriter/actor Pamungkas spent a week on the Global Excl. U.S. list with â€œTo the Boneâ€ last April.
Meanwhile, Ellie Goulding scores her first global hit as 2015â€™s â€œLove Me Like You Do,â€ from Fifty Shades of Grey, cracks the Global Excl. U.S. chart at No. 196. Seven years after hitting No. 3 on the Hot 100, the song reaches the global tally thanks to a 1% bump to 7.9 million streams outside the U.S.

title: A$AP Rocky Once Said Lana Del Rey Was His 'Dream Girl' He Made Songs With Her
content:
A$AP Rocky has recently garnered lots of media attention for his relationship with Rihanna. During the 2010s, he said he had a crush on Lana Del Rey. He collaborated with her multiple times over the course of several years.
A$AP Rocky | Arturo Holmes/Getty Images for Tribeca Festival
Why A$AP Rocky appeared in the music video for Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜National Anthemâ€™
Del Rey released one of her most famous albums, Born to Die, in 2011. One of the singles from the album was â€œNational Anthem.â€ The video for â€œNational Anthemâ€ features A$AP Rocky as President John F. Kennedy and Del Rey in a dual role as Marilyn Monroe and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. The music video recreates famous moments from the Kennedy administration, including Monroe performing â€œHappy Birthday, Mr. President.â€
During an interview with BBC Radio 1, Del Rey discussed A$AP Rockyâ€™s casting in the music video. â€œEvery so often, I top what Iâ€™ve done, and this video is definitely the most beautiful thing Iâ€™ve ever done,â€ she said. â€œI wrote a treatment for me and A$AP Rocky, because I just thought heâ€™d be really perfect to star in it. I love it.â€
RELATED: Adele Says This Lana Del Rey Song Makes Her Feel Like She Is Flying
How A$AP Rocky developed a crush on Lana Del Rey
According to Billboard, an A$AP Rocky/Del Rey collaboration called â€œRidin'â€ appeared online in 2012. Afterward, the rapper discussed his feelings about Del Rey with Billboard. â€œYou didnâ€™t know about me being a huge Lana Del Rey fan?â€ he said. â€œThatâ€™s all I kept talking about all winter.â€
A$AP Rocky discussed his crush on the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ singer. â€œI first had had a crush on her from seeing her on the Internet â€” I fell in love with her voice the first time I heard it,â€ he recalled. â€œI probably heard it in July, August for the first time, I think it was â€˜Blue Jeans.â€™ And from then on, Iâ€™m like â€¦ I love her!â€
A$AP Rocky explained why he wanted to work with Del Rey. â€œMind you, we never even spoke to each other, and then in Complex [magazine], when she said I was her favorite rapper, I was like, â€˜Oh f*** no, man. I gotta work with her! My dream girl acknowledges me!'â€
RELATED: Elvis Presley: Lana Del Rey Feels Sheâ€™s Friends With Him and Other Dead Celebrities
The 2 artists collaborated on multiple songs from the album â€˜Lust for Lifeâ€™
A$AP Rocky also collaborated with Del Rey on the song â€œSummer Bummerâ€ from her album Lust for Life. â€œSummer Bummerâ€ became a minor hit. It reached No. 23 on Billboardâ€™s Bubbling Under Hot 100 chart. The song stayed on the chart for one week.
Meanwhile, Lust for Life peaked atop the Billboard 200 for one week. Lust for Life stayed on the Billboard 200 for 22 weeks. A$AP Rocky also appeared on â€œGroupie Love,â€ another song from the album.
Even if they were never a couple, A$AP Rocky and Del Rey have a fascinating history together.
RELATED: Why Wendy Williams Once Thought Lana Del Rey Was a Porn Star

title: Lana Del Rey Born To Die turns 10 this week, so we ranked all the songs
content:
My dad didnâ€™t have a music magazine subscription, but every month, his mate would shove a crumpled up and well read copy of last monthâ€™s Q magazine through the door. I soaked in my secondhand music journalism about a month after everybody else because of this. I found Q to be a bit white-men-with-guitars leaning for my taste, but I always read it nonetheless. One month, the cover star was a woman Iâ€™d never seen or heard of before but was instantly enamoured with. Lana Del Rey practically radiated star quality off the print, blood running down her face in a tiara wearing cover shoot that was paying homage to Carrie. I remember going straight to YouTube and soaking in every Lana Del Rey song I could find â€“ Video Games, Born To Die, Blue Jeans. Iâ€™d never so quickly felt like Iâ€™d found an artist I was going to spend the rest of my life being obsessed with.
10 years later, and the Born To Die era easily defined and soundtracked an entire generation coming of age, and left in its wake a new cohort of alt-pop female artists who cite it as the reason they now make the music they do. Hereâ€™s every song on Born To Die by Lana Del Rey reflectively ranked, a birthday present from me to an album that Iâ€™ve listened to more than literally any other album.
15. Lolita
The worst song on Born To Die by a mile. It was my worst song on the record 10 years ago and itâ€™s my worst song on it now. I also think itâ€™s not just the worst song on Born To Die, but the worst song in the entire Lana Del Rey discography. The lyrics are crap, the melody unlikeable, the chorus shouty and annoying and the production tinny. A complete misfire.
14. Lucky Ones
Iâ€™m laughing a lot thinking about 16 year old me hearing this and saying itâ€™s going to be my first dance song at my wedding. Can you imagine? Everyone would just be silently and awkwardly watching me and my new husband sway to a saccharine song that has the ugliest cymbal crash in the world stomping all over its chorus.
Play
13. Carmen
The thing about Born To Die is itâ€™s so iconic and we look back with such nostalgia, but the fact of the matter is itâ€™s often a real mess. Carmen is so dated, but I adored it when the album first came out. A bad girl fable. Carmen was a lost soul, bless her.
12. Million Dollar Man
Lanaâ€™s first Bond song. Non canonical of course, but itâ€™s always felt SO James Bond to me. I love how woozy the pre-chorus is. It kind of reminds me of the way Rihanna sounds drunk when she sings Love On The Brain. Million Dollar Man is at its best when Lana sings it live, occasionally belting the final chorus up the octave and leaning into a really theatrical performance. I love how Lana uses her baby voice on this track â€“ such a trademark of the era.
11. Dark Paradise
Dark Paradise sounds like itâ€™s been written by one of those TikTokkers that create songs in the style of artistâ€™s trademark styles. Itâ€™s so many stereotypical Lana Del Rey tropes all bundled into one package, a dark cinematic melodrama about wishing you were dead and loverâ€™s that have left. Early Lana summed up in a song.
10. This Is What Makes Us Girls
The final song on the standard edition of BTD, This Is What Makes Us Girls is a high school coming of age film in a pop package and a reflection on Lanaâ€™s rebellious teenage years back in Lake Placid (she was actually sent away to boarding school by her family to try and combat the behaviour). The lyric where she sings â€œLana how I hate those guysâ€ is one of the most serotonin inducing moments of the album.
Play
9. Without You
â€œEverything I want I have, money, notoriety and rivieras / I even think that I found God, in the flashbulbs of your pretty cameras.â€ The first and best of the bonus tracks, the opening lyrics are engrained into my memory forever because Lana used to have them as het Twitter bio and I thought it was stunning. I still do. The â€œHello hello c-can you hear meâ€ is so iconic.
8. Diet Mountain Dew
The effortlessly cool and breezy Diet Mountain Dew sounds as cool now as it always has â€“ I love that rush of euphoria when the first chorus drops and the verse boots in. People who think Lana Del Rey just makes depressing music to weep to never really looked hard enough â€“ she was producing bops like this from day dot. â€œLetâ€™s take Jesus off the dashboard, got enough on his mind.â€
7. Off To The Races
Absolute chaos in the best way. Sounds like nothing else on Born To Die and is one of the most unique songs Lana Del Rey has ever released â€“ a slow verse that gets more and more frenetic with an ever-changing vocal delivery that goes from so deep to the sickliest, baby head voice. The way Lana gargles the â€œIâ€™m your little scarlet starletâ€ changed the entire world.
Play
6. Summertime Sadness
Forget the Cedric Gervais remix, the OG mix bangs as hard as it needs to! This is Lana at her most commercial, a fave for the locals and the straights but still great and iconic in its own right. Even if the chorus is low key and underwritten, the pre chorus is so historically important that it should be studied in music textbooks.
5. National Anthem
Responsible for what is perhaps still her greatest music video ever, National Anthem is all 4th of July weekend fireworks and American dreams crumbling and burning. â€œMoney is the anthem, GOD youâ€™re so handsomeâ€ is such a fun refrain to build a jaded song about opulence around, and stands with Off To The Races as one of the most distinct things Lana Del Rey has ever put out. Itâ€™s full pop star.
4. Radio
The best album track, and a fan favourite for a reason. Radio is just a lush spectacle, all grandeur and great lyricism in a dreamy package. â€œYeah my life is sweet like cinnamon / like a fucking dream Iâ€™m living inâ€ feels like the soundtrack to every 2012 pastel grunge Tumblr blog.
3. Blue Jeans
That guitar. THAT GUITAR. It both changed and ended lives. I canâ€™t think of many opening verses more iconic than Blue Jeansâ€™ actually â€“ the first time I heard it I was HOOKED. The blue jeans / white shirt combo has never been the same. Every thing about Blue Jeans feels epic, but itâ€™s the bridge that really solidifies it as a stone cold classic.
Play
2. Born To Die
The fact that a song this perfect isnâ€™t even the very best on the album really hits home how incredible and influential Born To Die is. The title track sums up the recordâ€™s atmosphere perfectly. Itâ€™s cinematic, grand and it all feels instantly doomed. Thereâ€™s a constant sense of dread that permeates through. One of the best choruses of all time as far as Iâ€™m concerned â€“ so crystal clear in its visual world that itâ€™s building.
1. Video Games
Not only the best song on Born To Die, but the best song of the decade. Sits comfortably amongst the greatest songs ever made, too â€“ and when Rolling Stone did their 500 Greatest Songs of All Time list and put Summertime Sadness in over Video Games I wanted to slap their keyboards out of their hands. Video Games is THEE song, itâ€™s always been THEE song. 10 years on and itâ€™s a song that you only need to spend one minute in the company of and know exactly why it was the megahit that it was.
Video Games made a superstar of one of the greatest singer songwriters we have â€“ with good reason. Itâ€™s the centrepiece of Born To Die, the song that defined an era and helped solidify the record into such a classic. Itâ€™s songs like Video Games that have made Born To Die an album weâ€™re all looking back on 10 years later as so seminal.
Recommended stories by this writer:
â€¢ Erm so Lana Del Reyâ€™s Born To Die album shoot was done in Watford?
â€¢ Oh baby, baby: Here are all nine iconic Britney Spears albums ranked from worst to best
â€¢ The definitive ranking of Britney Spears music videos, based on how iconic they are

title: Lana Del Rayâ€™s â€˜Born to Dieâ€™ Videos: Collaborators Talk Classic Clips
content:
On Lana Del Reyâ€™s debut album, 2012â€™s Born to Die, she sings of loss, love, evil, goodness, money, fame, destruction and redemption. With vivid lyrics, seductive strings, and dark, brooding guitar twangs, each song sounds like a scene from a movie. With lyrics so vivid and descriptive, itâ€™s easy for the listener to create their own version of each songâ€™s music video in their head â€“ but Lana had very specific visions in mind.
Explore Explore Lana Del Rey See latest videos, charts and news See latest videos, charts and news
Through striking camera techniques and visual effects, Lana Del Rey was able to create a cinematic universe with each of the music videos from. Born to Die, which turns 10 today (January 27). Although Lana began the Born to Die era by self-releasing several videos comprised of clips from old movies, including ones for â€œCarmen,â€ â€œDiet Mountain Dew,â€ and her breakout single â€œVideo Games,â€ she later connected with other artists who were able to bring her cinematic visions to life â€“ aligning with the overall themes of the album, and helping Born to reach No. 2 on the Billboard 200 albums chart and triple-platinum certification from the RIAA.
In the music video for the albumâ€™s title track â€œBorn to Die,â€ the first to receive a proper budget and video treatment, we get a glimpse of Lanaâ€™s idea of heaven. Directed by Yoann Lemoin (better known as Woodkid), alongside Andre Chemetoff, who served as the director of photography, â€œBorn to Dieâ€ was filmed at the Palace of Fontainebleau in France, in which Chemetoff and crew helped recreate a Romanian castle.
Portions of the video were shot in the Palace of Fontainebleauâ€™s Trinity Chapel, where Lana is seated on a throne between two tigers. Lana and the tigers were filmed separately, and with the tigers, the crew â€œused this crane to replicate [the tigersâ€™] moves,â€ Chemetoff says. â€œWe would do several takes, but Lana was never close to the tigers.â€
Additional clips see Lana and her lover, played by model Bradley Soileau, driving in a car, making out and taking a fateful trip, in the end of which, Soileau is seen carrying Lanaâ€™s bloodied corpse.
Star-crossed love is a recurring theme on Born to Die. Albeit not as dark as the title track, â€œBlue Jeansâ€ tells the story of a woman lamenting a lover who walks out of her life in pursuit of â€œchasing paperâ€ and getting â€œcaught up in the game.â€ Also directed by Lemoine, the songâ€™s visual is a brooding ode to film noir, shot in black and white.
Soileau also appears in this video, reuniting with Lana for another ill-fated love story â€“ this time, poolside in a 1950s Hollywood home. In the pool, joined by two alligators, Soileau and Lana enjoy a swim, before meeting their implied demise by drowning â€“ Lana, in the arms of Soileau. To this day, the videoâ€™s producer Oualid Mouaness says it is his most beautiful work, one he was determined to execute without compromise.
â€œLana was quite present and wonderfully real in her process with us on this video,â€ Mouaness says. â€œShe had worked with [Lemoine] on â€˜Born to Dieâ€™ prior to this, so there was a certain level of comfort. â€˜Blue Jeans,â€™ was, in some way, the prequel to â€˜Born to Die.â€™ She approached the filming as an actor would. She knew she had to embody a character â€“ one that is desperate for love and all the beauty that comes with it.â€
The biggest hit from the album â€“ and perhaps one of the most memorable songs of this era â€“ was â€œSummertime Sadness.â€ While the album version remains one of Lanaâ€™s signature songs, a remixed version of the song by Cedric Gervais didnâ€™t take off until over a year after the originalâ€™s release. The new version peaked at No. 6 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart, marking Lanaâ€™s first entry into the top 10, and still her highest charting song to date. (Unaware of how successful the song would later prove to be, Interscope Records did not provide a budget for the songâ€™s accompanying visual, according to director Spencer Susser.)
Lana conceived the idea for the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ video with actress Jaime King, who co-stars in the video. The video opens with a flash forward of Lana jumping to her death from a cliff. Throughout the video, King drives to a bridge, as visions of Lana appear to her in the passenger seat. King jumps off the bridge, and when Lana learns of Jamieâ€™s death, she jumps from a cliff, joining her in the afterlife. Then, the two smile, laugh and share moments of bliss.
When Lana and King came up with the ideas, King later called Susser, who at the time hadnâ€™t heard of Lana, to invite him to plan a treatment â€“ along with Kingâ€™s then-husband, Kyle Newman. King sent Susser â€œSummertime Sadness,â€ and within 15 minutes, Susser headed over to King and Newmanâ€™s home to lay out the concept for the video.
â€œ[â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ is] the idea of this love story, or friendship, or whatever you want it to be, that was broken up by a death,â€ Susser says. â€œAnd the idea that life without your best friend or your lover isnâ€™t fulfilling enough, so you want to join them wherever they are, whatever that is.â€
To shoot the video, Susser used a camera with 16mm film, an iPhone 4S, an iPad and an app to create â€œsuper 8â€ effects. Clips of King and Lana dancing and having fun at a party are interspersed throughout the visual, sequences shot by Newman on an iPhone at a party in the home of film director Eli Roth.
The scene with King contemplating suicide and jumping from a bridge transpire within the matter of seconds, which is about how long the crew was able to film this part. According to Susser, while he, Newman, King and Lana were filming, he heard a helicopter flying and noticed a light moving past Kingâ€™s face.
â€œI thought, â€˜Oh, maybe itâ€™s a camera thing,â€™â€ Susser says. â€œAs I go to take my eye off the eyepiece, this loudspeaker, like the voice of God says, â€˜What youâ€™re doing is illegal, get off the bridge.â€™ And I look up and thereâ€™s this helicopter hovering over us. And theyâ€™re talking to us on the loudspeaker. So we scram, and it was quite dramatic.â€
To close the Born to Die era, Lana Del Rey released the video for â€œNational Anthem,â€ a short film inspired by John F. Kennedy and Jackie Onassis Kennedy. In the Anthony Mandler-directed clip, Lana channels both Marilyn Monroe and Jackie O, alongside rapper A$AP Rocky, who embodies JFK.
The nearly eight-minute long visual shows Lana and Rocky partying, dancing in an Oyster Bay mansion and on yachts, and spending time on the beach with their three children. Toward the end, Rocky is shot off-screen as he and Lana are riding in a car; Lana then reads a forlorn monologue from the perspective of Jackie O, reflecting on her time with Rockyâ€™s JFK: â€œI always got the sense that he became torn between being a good person and missing out on all of the opportunities that life could offer a man as magnificent as himâ€¦ And in that way, I understood him and I loved him.â€
The video was shot in New York City, with Lanaâ€™s creative team only having two weeks to plan and execute the shoot. â€œThe creative was and is not an easy type of project to pull off in a short period of time,â€ says Heather Heller, a producer of the â€˜National Anthemâ€™ video, â€œespecially with the locations and storyline needed. How do you re-create the JFK assassination with A$AP Rocky as JFK in a music video in less than two weeks?â€
The â€œNational Anthemâ€ video was unlike anything Heller had ever worked on before, but ultimately, the challenge of the shoot is what excited her about the project. â€œWe set out to find the locations that would look like Texas and Cape Cod in New York, and ultimately we did. I had always been fascinated with Camelot and the entire era and story. Itâ€™s both so tragic, yet romantic and glamorous at the same time. When I read the concept I was completely hooked.â€
Heller, Mandler and crew filmed the video using super 8, 16mm and 35mm film. Lanaâ€™s longtime stylist, Johnny Blueeyes, helped her recreate Monroe and Jackie Oâ€™s aesthetics â€“ but according to Heller, becoming these icons â€œwas all Lana,â€ as she easily assumed form after the production team set the stage.
Heller would later produce the video for â€œRideâ€ and a short film called â€œTropico,â€ both of which accompany an extended version of Born to Die subtitled The Paradise Edition. â€œAll of the videos we made during that period were more like films than music videos,â€ Heller says. â€œIt definitely tested me as a producer, and I donâ€™t know if I have made anything as great or difficult as these three pieces since.â€
Although the Born to Die era is often associated with its old-Hollywood references and motifs, Heller remembers Lana as someone who values her looks and image, but always makes sure it doesnâ€™t overshadow the message of the work. â€œShe is not looking for a designer wardrobe or the most perfect hair,â€ Heller says, â€œshe is looking to become the character that she is portraying.â€
Born to Die helped Lana garner a cult following, and even helped popularize a â€œTumblr girlâ€ and â€œInstagram hottieâ€ aesthetic. Over the past decade, Lana has played around with her look, and although sheâ€™s traded in the flower crowns, croptowns and white gowns for sweaters, baseball caps and mall dresses, the cinematic quality of the music videos from this era is undeniable and inimitable. Having undergone several rebrands after recording music under the names May Jailer and Lizzy Grant, Lana Del Reyâ€™s reintroduction of herself to the world set a high bar to a new audience, creating visual elements that would still feel iconic 10 years later.
Lana Del Rey â€œwill work until she drops,â€ says Hellet. â€œShe will give you everything she has, and she is magic on screenâ€¦Music has changed so much in the last 10 years, especially for female artists and what we see in her is a woman in charge of her own voice, touching on all aspects of the female psycheâ€”sexuality, beauty, strength, frailty, power and freedom. She speaks for women in such an authentic way. She doesnâ€™t pander to anyone. She is completely, unapologetically Lana.â€

title: 10 anni di "Born To Die", che ha fatto nascere una stella
content:
LOS ANGELES - Il 27 gennaio 2012 usciva in Svizzera, Germania, Austria Belgio e pochi altri paesi europei "Born To Die" di Lana Del Rey. Ãˆ il primo album della cantautrice statunitense classe 1985, che fino a quel momento era nota solo per essere un'interessante artista di nicchia e che, da un giorno all'altro, si ritrova a essere sospinta verso la celebritÃ  internazionale sull'onda di una grande macchina mediatica, fatta di merchandising e gossip.
Un talento meno solido di quello di Lana sarebbe naufragato dopo i vari scossoni ricevuti (le critiche sull'estetica e sulla scarsa capacitÃ  a reggere il palcoscenico), ma lei ha saputo dimostrare di non essere un fuoco di paglia. Tanto che "Born To Die", snobbato da parecchi nell'immediato, Ã¨ stato rivalutato negli anni successivi e ora costituisce il primo esempio di un scintillante percorso artistico. Non il migliore, d'accordo, ma senza "Born To Die" e le sue hit (ricordiamo "Blue Jeans" e soprattutto "Video Games") non avremmo avuto gli album degli anni successivi, come lo splendido "Norman Fucking Rockwell!" del 2019 o l'ottima accoppiata dello scorso anno, "Chemtrails Over The Country Club" e "Blue Banisters".
"Born To Die" Ã¨ un disco che, a distanza di un decennio, vale la pena di riascoltare.

title: Lâ€™esercito americano ha usato Lana Del Rey per una campagna di reclutamento
content:
Una citazione sul coraggio e il fallimento Ã¨ stata attribuita alla cantautrice in un post pubblicato sull'account ufficiale di Twitter di U.S. Army. Tuttavia non ci sono prove che attestino che l'abbia davvero pronunciata la popstar... L'attribuzione alla famosa artista sarebbe finalizzata ad aumentare il reclutamento tra le donne. A chiedere un commento sia alla cantante sia all'esercito Ã¨ stato Rolling Stone USA. Per ora ha risposto solo l'esercito
Condividi
L'esercito degli Stati Uniti d'America ha pubblicato sul proprio account ufficiale di Twitter una citazione che ha attribuito a Lana Del Rey, ossia la seguente.
â€œBeing brave means knowing that when you fail, you donâ€™t fail foreverâ€, che tradotto significa: "Essere coraggiosi significa sapere che quando fallisci, non fallisci per sempreâ€. La frase porta la firma dello pseudonimo di Elizabeth Woolridge Grant , la cantautrice, poetessa e modella statunitense meglio conosciuta con il nome d'arte di Lana Del Rey.
Tuttavia non ci sono prove che attestino che quelle siano davvero parole da lei proferite (o anche scritte andrebbe bene, anzi: ci sarebbero piÃ¹ prove, dato che verba volant, scripta manent).
Ma se quella frase non fosse riconducibile alla star, la domanda sorgerebbe spontanea: possibile che lâ€™U.S. Army abbia attribuito in maniera falsa una citazione a una celebritÃ ?
Secondo alcuni, potrebbe essere una mossa strategica finalizzata ad aumentare il reclutamento di donne all'interno dell'esercito statunitense. Cosa che peraltro potrebbe spiegare la foto di una soldatessa durante l'addestramento militare a cui la citazione fa da corredo su Twitter. Ma comunque sia, ripetiamo: possibile che lâ€™U.S. Army abbia attribuito in maniera falsa una frase a una celebritÃ ?
Se l'Ã¨ chiesto l'edizione a stelle e strisce di Rolling Stone, tra gli altri.
â€œLâ€™esercito degli Stati Uniti sembra aver rubato una citazione direttamente dagli annali dei post di ispirazione su Pinterest e, per qualche motivo, l'ha attribuita a Lana Del Rey come parte di quello che apparentemente Ã¨ uno sforzo per aumentare il reclutamento tra le donneâ€, scrive il famoso magazine musicale americano.
Aggiungendo un: â€œSiamo ancora tutti completamente confusiâ€.
Il racconto di come il tweet incriminato sia nato in rete ce lo fornisce direttamente la â€œBibbia del Rockâ€, nella sua edizione oltreoceano.
Il tweet con la cit. "incriminata"
approfondimento Euphoria, Lana Del Rey presente con una canzone Lo scorso sabato sera, il 22 gennaio (per la precisione alle 18.03 esatte) l'esercito americano ha condiviso una foto di una donna in tenuta militare che striscia sotto il filo spinato, corredando lo scatto con la frase motivazionale di cui sopra, firmata da Lana Del Rey.
Il post Ã¨ stato coronato dall'hashtag #SoldierSaturday.
â€œSe l'esercito americano che cita Del Rey Ã¨ surreale giÃ  di per sÃ©, non Ã¨ chiaro - e piuttosto improbabile - se Del Rey abbia mai effettivamente pronunciato quelle paroleâ€, continua RS.
Ma il mistero non finisce qui: le investigazioni in salsa rock di Rolling Stone USA spiegano che, se si cerca la citazione su Google, viene visualizzata sÃ¬ una lunga sfilza di risultati che attribuiscono quelle parole a Lana Del Rey, alcuni risalenti addirittura al lontano 2016.
La citazione â€œforse fintaâ€ Ã¨ apposta su innumerevoli jpeg e GIF motivazionali. E, come ogni fake news che â€œsi rispettiâ€ (si fa per dire. Non sono mai da rispettare le fake news), si Ã¨ moltiplicata come i pani e i pesci nel giro di poche ore. Figuriamoci quando il lasso di tempo Ã¨ quello dal 2016 a oggi.
La citazione viene riproposta in molte zone ombrose del sottobosco della rete, come nei post intitolati "15 Courageous Quotes to Spark Your Inner Brave" (su un sito web che si chiama Success.com, per dire), e viene cementata nella memoria delle generazioni odierne e future grazie al suo inserimento nel compendio di citazioni online, AZQuotes.com.
Tuttavia ci si aspetta che lâ€™esercito statunitense dia un poâ€™ piÃ¹ di valore alle fonti, combattendo le fake news con la stessa tenacia con cui difende l'America...
â€œIl fatto Ã¨ che nessuno di questi post di cui sopra si collega a una fonte originale, che si tratti di un'intervista, una canzone, un TED Talk, un discorso motivazionale aziendale, qualunque cosa. In effetti, si puÃ² trovare la stessa citazione attribuita interamente ad altri, come un video di YouTube di nove secondi senza audio del 2018 in cui Ã¨ abbinato alla foto di un cavallo. Francamente, sembra altrettanto possibile che l'abbia detto il cavallo come Del Reyâ€, scrive Jon Blistein su Rolling Stone, strappandoci una risata.
La svolta "nellâ€™inchiesta"
approfondimento Lana Del Rey, Ã¨ uscito il video di "Blue Banisters" La svolta in questa bizzarra inchiesta in salsa "Army â€™nâ€™ Roll" Ã¨ la naturale fase due: contattare i rappresentanti di Lana Del Rey e l'esercito degli Stati Uniti per avere un commento sulla questione.
Ad averci pensato Ã¨ sempre Rolling Stone USA, che dopo aver sollevato la questione ha deciso di andare a fondo. Ma per ora ha avuto un riscontro soltanto da parte dellâ€™esercito.
Un rappresentante dellâ€™U.S. Army ha fornito una spiegazione abbastanza semplice su come e perchÃ© sia stata scelta la citazione: â€œÃˆ stata trovata durante una ricerca online di citazioni motivazionali sul coraggio. Usiamo spesso citazioni motivazionali nei nostri contenuti sui social media", ha dichiarato il portavoce a Rolling Stone.
Non Ã¨ ancora pervenuta, invece, una risposta della popstar o di chi per lei.
Il passato â€œartistico-patriotticoâ€ di Lana Del Rey
approfondimento Lana Del Rey Ã¨ tornata su Instagram BenchÃ© oggi l'associazione che lega Lana Del Rey allâ€™esercito americano suoni un tantino stonata, in realtÃ  se si guarda indietro, con sguardo al passato della cantautrice, la cacofonia si attenua parecchio.
Del Rey ha infatti costruito la propria carriera un po' criticando e allo stesso tempo esaltando la cultura e la nostalgia a stelle e strisce.
Quando era agli esordi, per esempio, la cantante si esibiva spesso davanti a una bandiera americana. Solo dopo l'elezione di Donald Trump nel 2016 ha affermato di sentirsi a disagio al riguardo...
Non da ultimo, quello che potremmo definire il â€œcitation-gateâ€ - lo scandalo della citazione lanadelreyana forse fake - trova in un tweet una nuova luce sotto cui guardare la cosa.
Il regista Dylan Park ha affermato di essere stato incaricato di dirigere un video musicale di Del Rey, un videoclip che come tema avrebbe dovuto raccontare tipo â€œdalla Seconda Guerra Mondiale all'America militare di oggiâ€. In stile Marilyn Monroe che canta per i soldati, insomma.
Parks ha aggiunto che l'esercito avrebbe finanziato il video musicale e fornito "Carri armati, elicotteri, tutto quanto". Ma lâ€™esercito avrebbe poi chiesto di utilizzare la clip al fine di reclutare nuove leve e Lana Del Rey a quel punto avrebbe rifiutato.
"Anni fa (correva lâ€™anno 2017, ndr) ero stato scelto per dirigere un video di Lana Del Rey. Il tema erano i militari americani, dalla Seconda guerra mondiale ai giorni nostri. Tipo le esibizioni di Marilyn Monroe per i militari allâ€™estero. Lâ€™esercito avrebbe finanziato il video. Carri armati, elicotteri, tutto quanto. Esigevano perÃ² di utilizzare il video per fare reclutamento e Lana Del Rey li ha mandati a farsi fo****e", fa sapere Dylan Park dal suo account di Twitter.
Ma il commento piÃ¹ bello su tutta questa storia rimarrÃ  quella del conservatore Jason Rantz, patron dellâ€™omonimo show radiofonico statunitense, il quale se ne Ã¨ uscito con questa massima: "Il nostro esercito Ã¨ spacciato se arriva a usare un testo di Lana Del Rey per attirare le reclute". Che lo Zio Sam abbia passato il testimone nel Nuovo Millennio alla "Cugina Lana"? Ai post l'ardua sentenza. Magari non ai post dell'esercito statunitense con cit. musicali annesse, ecco.

title: U.S. Army Uses Lana Del Rey Quote to Encourage Soldiers
content:
â€œRed, white, blue is in the skyâ€ for both Lana Del Rey and apparently her fans running the U.S. Army Twitter account.
The Army took to Twitter over the weekend (Jan. 22) to share a #SoldierSaturday photo taken by Markus Rauchenberger, featuring a female soldier crawling through a field. The tweet also included a quote attributed to Lana Del Rey: â€œBeing brave means knowing that when you fail, you donâ€™t fail forever.â€
"Being brave means knowing that when you fail, you donâ€™t fail forever." -Lana Del Rey ğŸ“¸ by Markus Rauchenberger#SoldierSaturday pic.twitter.com/57Aa4TnT2R â€” U.S. Army (@USArmy) January 22, 2022
While the post was meant to be inspiring for current and potentials soldiers, the Internet had a lot to say about the alleged Lana Del Rey quote used in the tweet. LDR fans were confused as to why the singer was used by an official Army account to recruit soldiers and made jokes about the unlikely pairing, while others rebuked the quote by pointing out that if â€œyou fail at combat it kinda is forever.â€

title: Pusha T's Lana Del Rey Photo & New Music Preview Has Fans Excited
content:
Pusha T's 2018 album Daytona, a 7 track drug dealer's diegesis, was met with high praise and critical acclaim. Produced entirely by GOOD Music head and worldwide phenomenon Kanye West, the exquisitely chopped samples and infectious drum patterns, coupled with Push's demeanor and delivery, instantly put the album in contention for classic status over time.
Victor Boyko/Getty Images For Kenzo
After that album's release, the track "Infrared" reignited the Pusha T and Drake beef, leading to a series of diss tracks which came to a head with Pusha T's "Story Of Adidon." With another highly regarded album and a victory over Drake, fans couldn't wait to hear more of what the GOOD Music executive had to offer. While the wait was more than 3 years in length, listeners have finally received new snippets from Push, and have been loving what they're hearing.
One of the new snippets came by way of Elliott Wilson's Twitter. The 52 second clip shows Pusha T rapping over a previously unheard track, which seems to pick up just where Daytona left off:
Another clip shows Pusha T and Kanye West, enjoying the preview of what's to come:
Fans were ecstatic to hear new verses from the self-proclaimed "cocaine cowboy." They took to Twitter to express their excitement:
Along with these snippets came an IG post, featuring a printed photograph of Lana Del Rey with white powder placed on top. Considering it's Pusha T, one could only assume what that is.
Are you excited for new Pusha T? How do you feel about the snippets? Let us know in the comments below.

The Game vier sitt vers til det han har drevet med siden gjennombruddet i 2005 â€“ grovhugd glorifisering av gangstertilvÃ¦relsen pÃ¥ gateplan â€“ mens Kanye drÃ¸fter skilsmisse, Gud og Pete Davidson (som han har lyst til Ã¥ jule opp) pÃ¥ sitt. Selve produktet er pÃ¥fallende gledeslÃ¸st, og at et produsentteam som teller Mike Dean og DJ Premier kan kverne ut noe sÃ¥ middelmÃ¥dig, er rent pussig.
Sigala â€“ Â«MelodyÂ»
Den britiske tropehouse-DJ-en Bruce Fielder kaller seg Sigala nÃ¥r han gir ut sine lettfattelige, dovne og ofte regelrett kyniske lÃ¥ter â€“ hans stÃ¸rste hit, Â«Easy LoveÂ», inkorporerer et sample av Jackson 5s Â«ABCÂ» pÃ¥ en nÃ¦rmest imponerende fantasilÃ¸s mÃ¥te. Â«MelodyÂ» representerer mer av den samme dritten â€“ en uidentifisert kvinne synger Â«la la laÂ» sÃ¥ enerverende og monotont hun er i stand til pÃ¥ refrenget, og selve musikken har tilsynelatende irritasjon som sin viktigste drivkraft. Det kan ikke sies ofte nok: Livet. Er. For. Kort. For. Dette.

title: Lana Del Rey Shares New Song â€œWatercolor Eyesâ€: Listen
content:
As previously teased, a new Lana Del Rey song has premiered ahead of new episode of Euphoria, which airs on Sunday (January 23). The track is titled â€œWatercolor Eyes,â€ and it appears in a forthcoming scene in the HBO drama. The rest of the soundtrack arrives on February 25. Check out â€œWatercolor Eyesâ€ below.
Last winter, Billie Eilish and RosalÃ­a shared a song called â€œLo Vas a Olvidar,â€ which got a sync in an episode of Euphoria. Lorde recently sat down with Euphoria star Hunter Schafer for a conversation about the hit show, fashion, and more.
Lana Del Rey released two albums last year: Chemtrails Over the Country Club, and Blue Banisters. In early November, she set a new record as the artist with the most No. 1 albums on Billboardâ€™s Alternative Albums chart.
Read â€œThe Euphoria Teensâ€™ Taste in Rap Is Ridiculousâ€ over on the Pitch, and revisit Pitchforkâ€™s feature â€œLife, Liberty, and the Pursuit of Happiness: A Conversation With Lana Del Rey.â€

title: [LISTEN] Euphoria: Lana Del Rey
content:
Photo: Photograph by Courtesy of HBO
Cool teens going to parties and getting in trouble? Of course, theyâ€™re listening to Miss Lana Del Rey! HBO announced last week that Lana Del Rey would be premiering a new song on Sunday nightâ€™s episode of the glittery vibe that is Euphoria. The dreamy track features lyrics like, â€œI think that you taste like rock candy, Sweet like beaches, leave me all sandy, Why do you leave me with watercolor eyes?â€ Euphoriaâ€™s official Twitter confirmed that Del Reyâ€™s song would be released online tonight, ahead of the third episode. The song preview showed cast members vibing to the song like Rue, Jules, Nate, and Kat but focused mainly on Rue and Jules, hinting that the song may be a part of their relationship storyline. Produced by songwriter Nasri, this will be Del Reyâ€™s first song premiering on a television series. The Blue Bannistersâ€™s singer has performed several songs for film soundtracks such as The Great Gatsby, Big Eyes, and Charlieâ€™s Angels; the latter song, â€œDonâ€™t Call Me Angel (Charlieâ€™s Angels),â€ peaked at #13 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
According to an HBO press release, the full soundtrack for Euphoria season two will be out on February 25th.

title: Los mejores temazos de la serie 'Euphoria': Volumen 2
content:
(AtenciÃ³n: spoilers de la 2T de Euphoria)
Rue Bennett bailaba al ritmo de Call Me Irresponsible en su recaÃ­da en las drogas y ante la estupefacciÃ³n de su hermana, quien enseguida caÃ­a en la cuenta de que algo no marchaba bien. Una secuencia tragicÃ³mica que nos adelantaba su salto al vacÃ­o y tambiÃ©n formaba parte de la promociÃ³n de la segunda temporada de Euphoria. Quedaba demostrado asÃ­ una vez mÃ¡s el buen gusto de Sam Levinson en la selecciÃ³n de las melodÃ­as de la serie y la maestrÃ­a para unirlas junto a las imÃ¡genes mÃ¡s impactantes.
Un mimo hacia la mÃºsica que ha vuelto a estar muy presente en estos nuevos episodios y nos ha regalado algunas melodÃ­as originales de artistas de cabecera como Labrinth y la recuperaciÃ³n de otros tantos clÃ¡sicos. A continuaciÃ³n, algunas de los temazos mÃ¡s sonados en esta segunda temporada de la serie de HBO Max.
I'm Tired (Labrinth & Zendaya)
DespuÃ©s de amenizar el confinamiento con un concierto en streaming en 2020 con las melodÃ­as de Euphoria, el compositor y cantante Labrinth se ha convertido otra vez en el principal creador para la banda sonora de la ficciÃ³n. En esta ocasiÃ³n, el mÃºsico se atrevÃ­a a realizar un cameo interpretando I'm Tired, que entonaba junto a Zendaya en un momento en el que su personaje casi tocaba las puertas del cielo, despuÃ©s de un importante chute. Una canciÃ³n que suponÃ­a un himno cuasi eclesiÃ¡stico en el que no faltaba el Ã³rgano y los coros, sin renunciar a los sonidos mÃ¡s actuales.
Yeh I Fuckin' Did It (Labrinth)
En el otro lado de la balanza, los sonidos mÃ¡s experimentales de Labrinth ocupaban un lugar relevante a travÃ©s de Yeh I Fuckin' Did It, un sonido perfecto para acompaÃ±ar la huida de Rue en pleno sÃ­ndrome de abstinencia. Una conjunciÃ³n ideal para el trepidante quinto episodio de la 2T, que dejaba al pÃºblico con el alma en vilo. Enfrentada a su familia, a sus amigos y las autoridades policiales, la joven emprendÃ­a un viaje de difÃ­cil retorno. Otras de las canciones del artista que podrÃ­amos escuchar en estos nuevos episodios eran The Lake, Formula, Whatâ€™s Up y, una vez mÃ¡s, la formidable All For Us.
Watercolor Eyes (Lana del Rey)
DespuÃ©s de que RosalÃ­a y Billie Eilish sorprendieran con la canciÃ³n original para la serie Lo vas a olvidar, que formaba parte de los dos capÃ­tulos especiales de Rules lanzados para dejarnos boquiabiertos ante de la 2T, Lana del Rey hacÃ­a de las suyas en estos nuevos episodios. El pop alternativo y melancÃ³lico de la artista estadounidense estÃ¡n presentes en Watercolor Eyes, que sonaba en el tercer episodio y se sumaba al sonido de otras artistas como Mazzy Star, Madonna, Chika Di y Kylie Minogue.
Holocausto CanÃ­bal (Riz Ortolani)
Euphoria ha reiterado en el reciclaje de melodÃ­as adaptando algunas de las bandas sonoras mÃ¡s sobresalientes en el mundo del cine, algunas de las cuales formaban incluso parte del controvertido musical de Lexi (Maude Apatow), Our Life. Entre estas canciones encontrÃ¡bamos Holocausto CanÃ­bal, compuesta por Riz Ortolani y procedente de la perturbadora pelÃ­cula homÃ³nima de 1980, dirigida por el italiano Ruggero Deodato. La canciÃ³n instrumental en cuestiÃ³n podÃ­a ser escuchada en la parte final del episodio 7, donde la furia de Cassie (Sydney Sweeney) se tornaba verdaderamente terrorÃ­fica.
Holding Out for a Hero (Bonnie Tyler)
Sin embargo, el instante mÃ¡s importante del musical de Lexi tenÃ­a lugar bajo el hilo musical del rock wagneriano de Bonnie Tyler. Una escena subidita de tono en la que una serie de deportistas, untados en aceite y muy ligeritos de ropa, revolucionaban a los espectadores al restregarse entre ellos. La canciÃ³n que formaba parte de la banda sonora original de Footloose, tambiÃ©n era parte del disco de la artista galesa Secret Dreams and Forbidden Fire (1986). Un tema utilizado para demostrar la masculinidad frÃ¡gil de Nate (Jacob Elordi), quien denunciaba la presunta 'homofobia' de la obra al verse acorralado.
Uno che grida amore (Ennio Morricone)
Entre la mÃºsica instrumental del final de la segunda temporada vemos un claro homenaje a la mÃºsica de artistas clÃ¡sicos como Piero Piccioni (Amore Min Aiutam), John Williams (The Fury), Francis Lai (Concerto Pour La Fin Dâ€™un Amou) y, especialmente, del desaparecido italiano Ennio Morricone. Este Ãºltimo aportaba a los nuevos episodios la magia de Uno Che Grida Amore y Ti Prego Amami, que pertenecen a la banda sonora de la pelÃ­cula Supongamos que una noche, cenando... (Giuseppe Patroni Griffi, 1969). Un emotivo homenaje de Levinson al compositor fallecido en 2020.
Never Tear Us Apart (INXS)
La banda australiana de rock de los 70 INXS, conformada por los hermanos Farris, tambiÃ©n ha sido una de las que mÃ¡s se ha dejado escuchar en la 2T con canciones como Mystify, Need You Tonight, Devil Inside y Need You Tonight. A destacar, Never Tear Us Apart que sonaba en un viaje al pasado de Cal Jacobs (Elias Kacavas, en su versiÃ³n joven), quien experimentaba con su sexualidad junto a su amigo e interÃ©s amoroso Derek (Henry Eikenberry). Su baile pegados junto a esta canciÃ³n se transformaba al instante en una de las escenas mÃ¡s emotivas de la ficciÃ³n.
Dead of night (Orville Peck)
En el primer episodio de la serie, la tensiÃ³n sexual entre Nate y Cassie aumentaba en plena Nochevieja. Su acercamiento iba acompaÃ±ado del tema con toques country Dead of night, del artista canadiense Orville Peck, conocido por sus modelitos (mÃ¡scara con flecos incluida) de El Llanero Solitario. Un preludio de su historia posterior, de la que como confesaba la propia Maddy (Alexa Demie): "este es solo el comienzo".
Drink Before the War (Sinead O'Connor)
El toque deprimente de la mÃºsica de Sinead O'Connor construÃ­a una atmÃ³sfera depresiva alrededor de Cal y Cassie, dos de los grandes protagonistas de esta segunda temporada. La historia vital de ambos personajes en paralelo se acompaÃ±aba de la melodÃ­a de 1987, que el mayor introducÃ­a a travÃ©s del tocadiscos de un pub LGTBI. Esta composiciÃ³n formaba parte del disco debut de la artista irlandesa Lion and the Cobra, donde postrÃ³ la influencia de artistas como Bob Dylan, David Bowie y The Pretenders.
Pick Me Up (James Blake ft. Labrinth)
El artista britÃ¡nico James Blake sonaba como parte de las nuevas colaboraciones de Labrinth, traduciÃ©ndose en el reflejo de los desamores de los personajes a travÃ©s de Pick Me Up. "He hecho las maletas y estoy listo. Estoy listo para irme. Solo llÃ©vame a cualquier parte", reza esta letra. Uno de los anhelos que hemos podido ver esta temporada por parte de personajes como Cassie.
Little Star (Dominic Fike)
Labrinth y Zendaya tambiÃ©n coescribÃ­an el tema entonado por Elliot (Dominic Fike) en Euphoria, quien entonaba esta conmovedora melodÃ­a ante Rue. Un momento especial en el que los dos amigos demostraban la mala influencia que ejercÃ­an entre ambos y que ha estado detrÃ¡s de algunas teorÃ­as alocadas sobre el desenlace, como la de que el personaje de Elliot serÃ­a una metÃ¡fora de las drogas y no alguien real. Guitarra en mano, Fike nos emocionaba, al igual que hiciera con Zendaya.
Blue Monk (Thelonious Monk)
Levinson tambiÃ©n ha vuelto a demostrar el gran casamiento entre los sonidos mÃ¡s frescos y actuales, y la nostalgia por los grandes clÃ¡sicos, que permitÃ­a que escuchÃ¡ramos de nuevo Blue Monk. La canciÃ³n del pianista y compositor de jazz Thelonious Monk tenÃ­a lugar con motivo del apadrinamiento de Ali (Colman Domingo) a Rue, quien intentaba enfocar a un personaje abstraÃ­do por las drogas y que se perdÃ­a las maravillas que ofrece la vida.
Stand By Me (Ben E. King)
La aÃ±oranza por la mÃºsica y el cine del pasado causaba un verdadero clÃ­max en Euphoria con Stand By Me, la canciÃ³n interpretada en 1961 por Ben E. King y compuesta por Jerry Leiber y Mike Stoller. Este rhythm and blues tendrÃ­a sus propias versiones posteriores como la espaÃ±ola RogarÃ©, de Bruno Lomas, o las adaptaciones de Seal, Prince Royce o Florence and the Machine. De hecho, esta canciÃ³n sonÃ³ hasta en la ceremonia real entre el PrÃ­ncipe Harry y Meghan Markle, interpretado por una banda de gÃ³spel. Un momento romÃ¡ntico que se repetÃ­a cuando Lexi y Fez (Angus Cloud) se unÃ­an tras disfrutar del filme Cuenta conmigo (Rob Reiner, 1986), el clÃ¡sico protagonizado por River Phoenix que tambiÃ©n incluÃ­a esta canciÃ³n en su banda sonora.
Hypnotize (B.I.G.)
Una Rue hasta las cejas de estupefacientes sacaba de quicio a Fez y Ashtray (Javon Walton) en su viaje en coche, durante los primeros minutos de la segunda temporada. Zendaya rapeaba asÃ­ la canciÃ³n Hypnotize del estadounidense The Notorious B.I.G., que supuso el primer single de su Ã¡lbum Life After Death. Se trata de la Ãºltima canciÃ³n publicada por el artista antes de que falleciera trÃ¡gicamente en 1997, precisamente por un tiroteo de un coche en marcha. Levinson hila fino.
How Long (Tove Lo)
La sueca Ebba Tove Elsa Nilsson, mÃ¡s conocida como Tove Lo, estÃ¡ detrÃ¡s de una de las canciones mÃ¡s hipnÃ³ticas de toda la serie. How long puede escucharse en el cumpleaÃ±os de Maddy, que terminaba en tragedia e introducÃ­a magistralmente el tema creado por la artista durante el confinamiento, donde el amor, la traiciÃ³n y la negaciÃ³n quedan patentes. La compositora y cantante saltaba a la fama internacional en 2014 con su EP Truth Serum, y tambiÃ©n ha trabajado estos aÃ±os en las letras de melodÃ­as de Lorde, Lea Michele o Icona Pop. Una joven promesa que ha llegado para arrasar.

Men lÃ¥ngt ifrÃ¥n alla tog Lana Del Rey till sina hjÃ¤rtan. â€Jag trodde att kraven pÃ¥ autenticitet i musiken var pÃ¥ vÃ¤g bort, i vÃ¥r hypermediala vÃ¤rld med alla dess mÃ¶jligheter till identitetslekarâ€, skrev DN:s Nils Hansson i sin recension av â€Born to dieâ€, som fick en trea i betyg. SjÃ¤lv formulerade hon det, i lÃ¥ten â€National anthemâ€, som att hon Ã¤gnade sig Ã¥t â€blurring the lines between real and the fakeâ€.

NÃ¤r den insatsen vÃ¤l ligger dÃ¤r pÃ¥ bordet kommer allas blickar att dras dit, och hon kan vara precis vem hon vill dÃ¤r bakom, sÃ¤ger Kristoffer Leandoer.
MÃ¥nga av lÃ¥tarna pÃ¥ â€Born to dieâ€ skildrade kÃ¤rleksrelationer som var ojÃ¤mlika ur ett Ã¥lders- eller maktperspektiv. Lana Del Rey sjÃ¶ng om sig sjÃ¤lv som undergiven och stÃ¤ndigt lÃ¤ngtande efter en mÃ¶rk, frÃ¥nvarande mansgestalt, och pÃ¥ omslaget till singeln â€Blue jeansâ€ lÃ¥g hon med slutna Ã¶gon och en tatuerad manshand runt sin hals. Det stack i Ã¶gonen i en tid dÃ¥ kvinnliga mainstreamartister just bÃ¶rjat lansera sig som feminister och Taylor Swift lÃ¥g pÃ¥ topplistorna med â€We are never ever getting back togetherâ€.
I heard that you like the bad girls, honeyIs that true?
Kristoffer Leandoer tror att albumets mÃ¥nga blinkningar till Nabokovs roman â€Lolitaâ€ kan fÃ¶rstÃ¥s som en kommentar till det han kallar amerikansk populÃ¤rkulturs kvinnoskrÃ¤ck.
â€“ Den visar sig i att kvinnor aldrig kan vara unga nog eller sÃ¥rbara nog. Det verkar finnas ett underfÃ¶rstÃ¥tt likhetstecken mellan offer och sexig. Hon verkar pÃ¥ ett sÃ¤tt identifiera sig lika mycket med Humbert Humbert som med Lolita â€“ hon har den cyniska, litterÃ¤rt bildade, genomskÃ¥dande, smarta blicken som ser igenom den glÃ¤ttiga ytan till alla dolda drifter under den. Humbert Ã¤r melankolisk och nostalgisk precis som Lana Del Reys musik, medan Lolita lever i nuet.
Tio Ã¥r kan tyckas ha gÃ¥tt fort, men i dag framstÃ¥r mÃ¥nga av konflikterna kring â€Born to dieâ€ som fÃ¶rÃ¥ldrade. Ett par potentiellt fÃ¶rstorade lÃ¤ppar skulle i dag inte fÃ¥ musikkritiker att gÃ¥ i taket, och det Ã¤r svÃ¥rt att fÃ¶restÃ¤lla sig att leken med autenticitet och yta i dag skulle orsaka sÃ¥ mycket harm. Dagens kvinnliga popidoler, oavsett om de heter Billie Eilish, Lorde eller Olivia Rodrigo, har Lana Del Rey att tacka fÃ¶r mycket.
Lana Del Rey 2012. Foto: E-Press/TT
I Jia Tolentinos essÃ¤samling â€Falsk spegelâ€ frÃ¥n 2020 skriver hon i essÃ¤n â€Den besvÃ¤rliga kvinnans kultâ€, apropÃ¥ popstjÃ¤rnor som Britney Spears och Amy Winehouse: â€En gÃ¥ng framstod besvÃ¤rliga kvinnor som perversa; numera framstÃ¥r kvinnor som inte Ã¤r besvÃ¤rliga som perversa. Hela tolkningsramen hÃ¥ller pÃ¥ att bli ohÃ¥llbar. Vi kan betrakta besvÃ¤rliga kvinnor ur en traditionell synvinkel och tycka att de Ã¤r kontroversiella, och vi kan betrakta blida kvinnor ur en feministisk synvinkel och tycka att de ocksÃ¥ Ã¤r kontroversiella. Vi befinner oss i en situation dÃ¤r kvinnor fÃ¶rkastar den traditionella kvinnligheten i frigÃ¶relsens namn och sedan kommer pÃ¥ sig sjÃ¤lva med att omvÃ¤xlande fÃ¶rakta och sukta efter den.â€
I det grÃ¤nslandet rÃ¶r sig Lana Del Rey pÃ¥ â€Born to dieâ€, och pÃ¥ varje skiva hon slÃ¤ppt sedan dess. Genom Ã¥ren har kontroverserna som stÃ¤ndigt tycks omge henne blivit fler, men de har Ã¤ndrat skepnad, liksom Lana Del Rey har Ã¤ndrat skepnad. Hon Ã¤r inte lÃ¤ngre den vÃ¥ldsromantiserande Lolitafiguren som portrÃ¤tteras pÃ¥ â€Born to dieâ€. Men besvÃ¤rligheten bestÃ¥r.
