title: Lana Del Rey indicates she might pull out of Glastonbury after line-up announcement
content:
G lastonburyâ€™s headliners have now all been announced and the top of the ticket acts are all white men.
The Arctic Monkeys and Guns Nâ€™ Roses were announced on Friday as the final two headliners joining Elton John on the Pyramid Stage over the June weekend.
John was already confirmed as one of the headlining acts in December: it will be his last ever UK show, as the musician is currently on his pre-retirement Farewell Tour.
In an interview with The Guardian today, Glastonburyâ€™s organiser Emily Eavis responded to the line-up, saying that she is â€œentirely focused on balancing our bill. Itâ€™s not just about gender, itâ€™s about every aspect of diversity,â€ but that the issue is that thereâ€™s a â€œpipelineâ€ problem when it comes to finding top female headliners.
But star act Lana Del Rey also seemed to take issue with the announcement as headliners of the Other Stage, the second biggest stage, were not specifically announced.
Commenting under Glastonbury Festivalâ€™s line-up Instagram post, Lana Del Rey said: â€œThanks for announcing that I was headlining the other stage. Thumbs up.â€ Her comment now seems to have been deleted.
Glastonbury released a poster introducing 55 of 2023â€™s acts, but did not detail which stage any of the acts would be playing on. Lana Del Rey is on the seventh row of the poster. Del Rey was then reported by several outlets as commenting elsewhere: â€œWell, Iâ€™m actually headlining the 2nd stage... But since there was no consideration for announcing that weâ€™ll see.â€
Defending the line-up, Eavis said that there should be two female headliners next year, and said that a female act had been scheduled to play in the Saturday Guns Nâ€™ Roses slot, but then â€œchanged her touring plansâ€.
While Eavis would not say who this was, some fans were anticipating that Taylor Swift, who was set to perform at Glastonbury in 2020, might be one of the musicians headlining the Somerset festival this year. Swift will in fact spend the summer performing her ERAS tour in America.
55 Glastonbury 2023 acts have now been revealed, and they include Lizzo, Alt-J, Blondie, Lana Del Ray, Leftfield, Carly Rae Jepsen, Alison Goldfrapp, Christine and the Queens, Lil Nas X, Wizkid, Thundercat, Shygirl, Kelis and Fever Ray. 53 per cent of the 55 announced acts are male, and 43 per cent of the announced acts are non-white (or are mixed groups).
â€œWeâ€™re trying our best,â€ said Eavis about creating a balanced line-up, but said that the music industry as a whole needed to continue to progress.: â€œThe pipeline needs to be developed. This starts way back with the record companies, radio. I can shout as loud as I like but we need to get everyone on board.â€
Eavis said that Lizzo â€œcould totally headline... Many of the artists could. But the headline slot had already been promised to someone else.â€
Guns Nâ€™ Roses, she added, will â€œbe brilliant and provide something totally different to the rest of the headliners.â€
Eavis also said that if everything goes ahead as planned thereâ€™ll be two female headliners next year. One act has already been confirmed while the other is likely to confirm soon. Some fans have suggested that Madonna, who has never played at the UK festival and whose Celebration Tour ends in January 2024, could be one of these top female acts.
Eavis also said that confirming any of the top acts was a difficult feat: â€œPeople assume that because weâ€™re the â€˜Christmas of musicâ€™ we can breezily book whoever â€“ but to get Elton doesnâ€™t happen easily, so thatâ€™s a really big moment for us,â€ she said.
In 2018 Eavis told MusicWeek: â€œEvery booking Glastonbury make is conscious; weâ€™re trying to address the imbalance.
â€œI mean, there are a lot of old guys in the music industry; unfortunately itâ€™s not been a topic which people have been conscious of,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s not necessarily purposeful, itâ€™s just that it hasnâ€™t ever been top of the agenda like it is now. I keep saying to some of our older bookers who have been doing it for 30 years, â€˜Come on guys, you need to engage with thisâ€™.â€
Glastonbury 2023 will take place June 21-25; glastonburyfestivals.co.uk

title: dÃ©couvrez le programme
content:
Glastonbury Festival 2023 : Arctic Monkeys, Lizzo, Lana Del Reyâ€¦ dÃ©couvrez le programme et tous les artistes qui seront prÃ©sents.
Arctic Monkeys, Guns N â€˜Roses, Elton John sont les tÃªtes dâ€™affiche du festival de Glastonbury. Cependant pour Emily Eavis, câ€™en est trop. En effet, lâ€™organisatrice a dÃ©clarÃ© quâ€™il Ã©tait nÃ©cessaire de dÃ©velopper des actes fÃ©minins dans les gros titres. Selon elle, les festivals ont une pÃ©nurie de tÃªtes dâ€™affiche fÃ©minines. Cela serait en raison dâ€™un problÃ¨me de Â« pipeline Â» de lâ€™industrie. Suite Ã  lâ€™annonce quâ€™Elton John conclurait lâ€™Ã©dition 2023, Emily Eavis a confirmÃ© quâ€™Arctic Monkeys serait en tÃªte dâ€™affiche vendredi, tandis que Guns N â€˜Roses ferait ses dÃ©buts Ã  Worthy Farm samedi.
Le groupe Guns N â€˜Roses â€“ qui a ajoutÃ© une claviÃ©riste, Melissa Reese, Ã  leur formation en 2016 â€“ avait Ã©tÃ© discutÃ©e comme une figure clÃ© potentielle avant la pandÃ©mie. Â« Ils seront brillants et offriront quelque chose de totalement diffÃ©rent du reste des tÃªtes dâ€™affiche. Â» a dÃ©clarÃ© Emily Eavis. La programmation du festival de cette annÃ©e comprend les premiÃ¨res performances des gagnants de lâ€™Eurovision MÃ¥neskin. Mais Ã©galement du groupe de filles britannique Flo et des stars amÃ©ricaines du pays, les Chicks. Lil Nas X reviendra jouer avant Elton John, et Lana Del Rey sera aussi prÃ©sente sur scÃ¨ne.
Un festival qui se veut Ã©quilibrÃ©
52% des 54 noms de lâ€™annonce partielle de la programmation sont des hommes. Pour lâ€™organisatrice, il est nÃ©cessaire que le programme reste Â« entiÃ¨rement concentrÃ©e sur lâ€™Ã©quilibre de notre facture. Il ne sâ€™agit pas seulement de genre, il sâ€™agit de tous les aspects de la diversitÃ©. 46% de ces 54 noms ne sont pas blancs ou comportent des membres non blancs: la star dâ€™Afrobeats Wizkid sera la tÃªte dâ€™affiche de lâ€™autre scÃ¨ne vendredi. Nous sommes probablement lâ€™un des seuls grands spectacles qui se concentre vraiment sur cela. Â»
Il est donc clair que lâ€™industrie de la musique doit investir davantage dans les musiciennes pour crÃ©er de futures tÃªtes dâ€™affiche, a dÃ©clarÃ© Emily Eavis. Â« Nous faisons de notre mieux. Je peux crier aussi fort que je veux, mais nous devons embarquer tout le monde. Â» Le festival de lâ€™annÃ©e prochaine devrait voir deux femmes artistes Ã  la une : Rihanna et Madonna font partie des vedettes qui nâ€™y ont jamais jouÃ©. Une nouvelle qui rÃ©jouira le public !

title: Glastonbury Festival 2023: Arctic Monkeys and Guns N' Roses join Sir Elton John as headliners
content:
Arctic Monkeys and Guns N' Roses will join Sir Elton John in headlining this year's Glastonbury Festival.
The Glastonbury line-up also includes Christine And The Queens, Fatboy Slim, Lana Del Rey, Lewis Capaldi, Lil Nas X, Maneskin, Rudimental, Manic Street Preachers, The War On Drugs and Royal Blood.
Cat Stevens will fill the Legends slot on Sunday afternoon.
Instagram Due to your consent preferences, youâ€™re not able to view this. Open Privacy Options
Arctic Monkeys, who recently released their seventh album The Car, will close the Pyramid Stage on Friday night. It will be their third time topping the bill.
Guns N' Roses will headline on Saturday night after the original line-up of Axl Rose, Slash and Duff McKagan reunited in 2015.
Lizzo will play immediately before and has joint headline billing on the line-up poster.
Sir Elton previously said he "couldn't be more excited" to be appearing at Glastonbury 2023 in what will be his final ever gig in the UK after more than 50 years on the road.
Last year Billie Eilish, Sir Paul McCartney and Kendrick Lamar headlined Glastonbury, with Diana Ross performing in the traditional Sunday Legends slot.
Sir Paul became the festival's oldest solo headliner when he performed a week after his 80th birthday, while 19-year-old Eilish became the youngest-ever solo headliner.

title: Olivia Rodrigoâ€™s Tribute to Lana Del Rey at Women in Music
content:
Lana Del Rey was honored with the Visionary Award at the 2023 Billboard Women in Music Awards at the YouTube Theater in Los Angeles on Wednesday (March 1). And last yearâ€™s Woman of the Year, Olivia Rodrigo, stopped by to introduce the trailblazing singer-songwriter.
Rodrigo, a chart-topping, award-winning superstar is just 20 but sheâ€™s already packed in more highlights than many would achieve in a full life. But tonight, it was all about Del Rey and the many and varied gifts sheâ€™s shared with her fans.
â€œLana has raised an entire generation of music lovers and songwriters like me,â€ Rodrigo enthused, â€œand taught them that thereâ€™s beauty in their vulnerability and power in their melancholy.â€
Like many of us, it was 2012â€™s â€œVideo Gamesâ€ that hooked-in Rodrigo. â€œI still consider that song to be probably the best love song of all time,â€ she explained. â€œShe captures sadness, anger and sensuality in a way only the greatest of songwriters ever could.â€
The greatness doesnâ€™t end with those â€œperfectly written albums, life-changing poetry and heavenly voice,â€ said Rodrigo, praising the living legendâ€™s â€œunwavering authenticity.â€
Billboardâ€™s Visionary Award recipient, she continued, â€œhas forged her own path, her entire career constantly raising the bar for herself and creating art that pushes boundaries and changes lives.â€
Rodrigo, a three-time Grammy Award winner, is one of those fans whoâ€™s life is changed by Del Rey, for the better.
Read Olivia Rodrigoâ€™s induction speech in full below.
Hey guys, I am so grateful to be here tonight celebrating so many incredible women. And Iâ€™m beyond honored to present the visionary award to someone who couldnâ€™t be more deserving of it if they tried, Miss Lana Del Rey.
Lanaâ€™s career has spawned 15 Hot 100 hits and eight consecutive top 10 albums on the Billboard 200. Sheâ€™s brought equal passion to poetry, photography and film, including collaborations with soundtracks like â€œBig Eyesâ€ and â€œThe Great Gatsby.â€
More important than her lost list of accolades though, is the unique way she impacts everyone who encounters her in her music. Lana has raised an entire generation of music lovers and songwriters like me, and taught them that thereâ€™s beauty in their vulnerability and power in their melancholy.
The first song that I ever heard of Lanaâ€™s was â€œVideo Games.â€ I still consider that song to be probably the best love song of all time. She captures sadness, anger and sensuality in a way only the greatest of songwriters ever could.
What I admire most about Lana though, even more than her perfectly written albums, life-changing poetry and heavenly voice is her unwavering authenticity.
Lana has forged her own path, her entire career constantly raising the bar for herself and creating art that pushes boundaries and changes lives.
She never sacrificed her unique voice and perspective on a world and an industry that constantly tries to put people in a box. And if that doesnâ€™t make you a visionary, I truly donâ€™t know what does.
Sheâ€™s also just the coolest, kindest, nicest girl to ever exist, and Lanaâ€¦I love you.

title: Billboard Women In Music 2023: Show Photos
content:
Lana Del Rey and Olivia Rodrigo at Billboard Women In Music held at YouTube Theater on March 1, 2023 in Los Angeles, California.
Lana Del Rey and Olivia Rodrigo at Billboard Women In Music held at YouTube Theater on March 1, 2023 in Los Angeles, California. Michael Buckner/PMC
Some of musicâ€™s biggest names and rising stars gathered to celebrate and support woman artists, executives, producers and creators who have made an impact in their communities and the music industry at Billboardâ€™s annual Women In Music event on Wednesday (March 1) at the YouTube Theater in Los Angeles.
The star-studded event featured performances from Woman of the Year honoree SZA, Becky G (Impact Award), Doechii (Rising Star), Kim Petras (Chartbreaker), Lainey Wilson (Rulebreaker) and TWICE (Breakthrough Artist). On hand to present were Sabrina Carpenter, Dove Cameron, Chloe Bailey, Coi Leray and Wondagurl. There was also a surprise appearance by global superstar Bad Bunny, who was on hand to present Ivy Queen with the Icon Award.
This Women In Music Executive of the Year honoree was Sylvia Rhone, the CEO and chairwoman of Epic Records. During her speech, she gave a shout-out to her fellow honorees SZA and Rosalia, who received the inaugural Producer of the Year Award. â€œYou changed the game for R&B music, and R&B music is where I come from, and weâ€™re back!â€ Rhone said of the â€œKill Billâ€ artist. â€œAnd Rosalia particularly because thatâ€™s a historic win to be producer of the year.â€
During her own acceptance speech â€” which was unscripted â€” SZA shared her deep respect for the other women in the room. This could have been any of us,â€ she said.
This yearâ€™s ceremony was hosted by Emmy Award-winning actress and writer Quinta Brunson. Check out moments from the 2023 Billboard Women In Music event below.

title: Lana Del Rey at Women in Music: â€˜Being Happy is the Ultimate Goalâ€™
content:
After a night spent honoring some of this yearâ€™s most impactful female musicians, Lana Del Rey closed out the 2023 Billboard Women in Music list of awards recipients Wednesday (March 1) by accepting the nightâ€™s Visionary Award, well-earned after 14 years and nine genre-defining studio albums.
Last yearâ€™s Woman of the Year Olivia Rodrigo was on hand to present the 37-year-old singer-songwriter with the Visionary Award, with Lana mouthing â€œI love you so muchâ€ to the â€œDeja Vuâ€ singer from her seat in the audience before taking the stage to deliver her acceptance speech.
â€œI canâ€™t tell you how much it means that someone who wrote â€˜Drivers Licenseâ€™ is standing next to me,â€ Lana said after Rodrigo handed her the award, before shouting out this yearâ€™s Woman of the Year: â€œSZA, from the minute I heard you, I knew I wanted to know you.â€
â€œI donâ€™t exactly have a long-term vision at all, but if you were curious, I am very, very happy,â€ Lana continued during the speech. â€œWhen I released my first album 14 years ago, the waters were not quite as warm. Iâ€™m really happy for everyone who feels like itâ€™s a wonderful time in the culture to be themselves and express themselves. It didnâ€™t feel that way in 2008.â€
â€œI feel like being happy is the ultimate goal, so I did it,â€ she concluded. â€œThank you, Billboard!â€
After hitting a career high No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 with â€œSnow On The Beach,â€ her Midnights collaboration with Taylor Swift, and donating a celestial original song to Euphoriaâ€™s Season 2 soundtrack, the indie pop auteur is now gearing up to release her next album Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd â€” her fourth record in under four years â€” on March 24. The two singles to be released so far off the project, â€œA&Wâ€ and its title track, are peak Lana: ethereal, gloomy, jarring and, well, visionary.
â€œEleven years ago I wanted it to be so good,â€ she told Billboard of the new album in her Women in Music interview. â€œNow, I just sing exactly what Iâ€™m thinking. Iâ€™m thinking a little less big and bombastic. Maybe at some point I can have fun creating a world again, but right now, I would say thereâ€™s no world building. This music is about thought processing. Itâ€™s very, very wordy. Iâ€™m definitely living from the neck up.â€

title: Billboard Women In Music Awards â€“ Watch Live
content:
The Billboard Women in Music Awards are underway Wednesday, with the ceremony taking place at the YouTube Theater at Hollywood Park in Los Angeles and hosted by Abbott Elementary creator-star Quinta Brunson.
You can watch the livestream above.
Among those being honored tonight are SZA (Woman of the Year), Becky G (Impact Award presented by American Express), Doechii (Rising Star Award presented by Honda), Ivy Queen (Icon Award), Kim Petras (Chartbreaker Award), Latto (Powerhouse Award), Lainey Wilson (Rulebreaker Award), Lana Del Rey (Visionary Award), RosalÃ­a (Producer of the Year Award) and TWICE (Breakthrough Award).
Presenters include Dove Cameron, Sabrina Carpenter, Chloe Bailey, Coi Leray and Wondagurl.
Billboard and show producer dick clark productions (through Penske Media Eldridge JV) are owned by PMC, Deadlineâ€™s parent company.

title: Lo nuevo de Depeche Mode, Lana del Rey, Janelle MonÃ¡e, Gorillaz, Shania Twain y otras canciones de febrero
content:
El sencillo de adelanto del que serÃ¡ el decimoquinto disco de Depeche Mode, titulado Memento Mori y escrito durante la pandemia, mantiene las constantes de la banda: texturas electrÃ³nicas e intensidad atada a una letra que refuerza las melancÃ³licas y dramÃ¡ticas emociones que desprende la mÃºsica. En este caso, â€˜Ghosts Againâ€™ habla sobre la naturaleza fugaz de la vida. La Ãºnica esperanza que nos queda es, canta Dave Gahan, que algÃºn dÃ­a â€œvolveremos a ser fantasmasâ€. El videoclip, inspirado en El SÃ©ptimo Sello de Bergman y dirigido por Anton Corbijn, refuerza esa reflexiÃ³n sobre la muerte, asunto que ha adquirido para el grupo y sus fans otro peso tras el repentino fallecimiento de su teclista, Andy Fletcher, hace unos meses. Gahan ha reconocido que hasta se planteÃ³ abandonar la mÃºsica. Esta canciÃ³n, escrita entre Martin Gore y Richard Butler (The Psychedelic Furs), le hizo cambiar de idea. BEATRIZ G. ARANDA
Durante aÃ±os, el llamado drumâ€™nâ€™bass mÃ¡s noventero permaneciÃ³ arrinconado en la mÃºsica popular. Demasiado complejo, demasiado rÃ¡pido. Su inaccesibilidad convirtiÃ³ al gÃ©nero en un lugar que visitar en busca de autenticidad. Caroline Polachek vuelve a sorprender con una canciÃ³n de ritmo de estilo drumâ€™nâ€™bass y formas barrocas, acompaÃ±Ã¡ndose para la ocasiÃ³n de las voces de Grimes en los agudos y de Dido en las secuencias mÃ¡s dulces. â€˜Fly To Youâ€™, incluido en el segundo disco en solitario de Polachek, que acaba de publicarse y que no deja de recibir elogios por su audaz propuesta pop, destaca por una producciÃ³n que deja la complejidad rÃ­tmica al fondo para que las voces manejen la melodÃ­a y el Ã¡nimo final de la pieza. Los versos hablan sobre la fe ciega que mueve al ser humano y la evasiÃ³n como espacio de confort. â€œBusco algo / que nadie mÃ¡s puede verâ€, canta Dido, en un registro cercano a sus colaboraciones con la banda Faithless. Otro argumento mÃ¡s que confirma que los noventa son el exuberante trastero de la mÃºsica actual. B. G. A.
En el Ãºltimo lustro, Lana Del Rey se ha convertido en una de las voces mÃ¡s destacadas y sugerentes de la mÃºsica norteamericana. Un prodigio que brilla con luz personalÃ­sima para alumbrar un universo donde Los Ãngeles se presenta como un territorio onÃ­rico, donde las sensaciones de bÃºsqueda y redenciÃ³n se sienten entre luces de neÃ³n y humo de madrugadas pasadas de rosca. Ese sonido nebuloso, absorbente y casi exclusivo de ella y el talentoso productor Jack Antonoff, estÃ¡ en esta nueva canciÃ³n ambiciosa, dividida en dos partes, con guitarra, sintetizadores, teclados y una voz distorsionada, ofreciendo un toque de urbano, rapeado, tremendamente interesante y sutil tan propio de Lana. EstÃ¡ que lo rompe y es increÃ­ble cÃ³mo ensancha su universo de sueÃ±os rotos pero resplandecientes en cada nueva canciÃ³n. â€˜A&Wâ€™ â€”por American Whoreâ€” es el segundo adelanto del noveno Ã¡lbum de estudio de Lana Del Rey, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, que sale a la venta el 24 de marzo. FERNANDO NAVARRO
QuizÃ¡ todavÃ­a haya prejuiciosos que pongan en duda el valor artÃ­stico de Bad Bunny. Damon Albarn, inquieto explorador musical, no va a ser uno de ellos. En el nuevo disco de Gorillaz â€“25 aÃ±os ya de carreraâ€”, Cracker Island, participan nombres respetados del pop como Stevie Nicks, Beck, Thundercat o Tame Impala. Que Albarn haya contado con el reguetonero no hace sino colocar al puertorriqueÃ±o en el mismo nivel de los citados. Ojo, hablamos de un tipo, el lÃ­der de Blur, que se ha formado escuchando a The Kinks y que no tiene problema es valorar una mÃºsica bastante diferente. Y de la canciÃ³n Â¿quÃ©? Pues estÃ¡ muy bien Tormenta, con un ritmo bossa y refrescante y el protagonismo de la voz de Bad Bunny, que, como si resumiese toda esta historia, canta: â€œY que se joda el resto, Â¿quiÃ©n dice lo que estÃ¡ correcto?â€. CanciÃ³n del verano a la hora del cÃ³ctel desde ya. CARLOS MARCOS
Leslie Feist, en el vÃ­deo de 'In Lightning'.
El anti-folk, o pop barroco, o experimento conceptual de Leslie Feist, suena mÃ¡s que nunca en este In Lightning a una sincopada y etÃ©rea BjÃ¶rk con gusto, aÃºn, por la guitarra elÃ©ctrica â€”ese solo como arquitectura efÃ­mera en el epicentro del corteâ€”, y la fragmentaciÃ³n. Parte del inminente Multitudes, su primer Ã¡lbum en seis aÃ±os, â€˜In Lightningâ€™ apuesta por la ruptura y el brillante desequilibrio, desordenado elementos en la canciÃ³n y sirviÃ©ndolos bajo el prisma, sincopado y relampagueante, de una percusiÃ³n que, como telÃ³n de fondo y a la vez esqueleto, vertebra tan extraÃ±a criatura, prima lejana de su decididamente aterciopelada antecesora, un Hiding Out In the Open que prometÃ­a un disco Ã­ntimo y personal, y que aquÃ­ se lanza a redescubrirse. DespuÃ©s de todo, dice la de Toronto que Multitudes es un Ã¡lbum en el que oscuridad y luz van de la mano, y se muestran no como el reverso una de la otra sino como algo que estÃ¡ contenido en la misma cosa: nosotros mismos. Eso sÃ­, el videoclip es poderosamente oscuro, por mÃ¡s que se ambiente en un lugar donde tiende a lucir el sol. LAURA FERNÃNDEZ
Jessie Ware, vestida de fulgurante blanco, manoseando un collar de perlas, con esponjosas plumas por todas partes, se dice a sÃ­ misma ante el espejo de su cuarto, en su tocador, que es una seÃ±ora, una amante, una freak y una madre â€”â€I am a lady, I am a lover, a freak, a motherâ€â€” en el arranque de este Pearls, un vitamÃ­nico chute de neo soul tan Donna Summer que parece estar resucitÃ¡ndola para un descreÃ­do siglo XXI en el que nada ni nadie deberÃ­a tomarse en serio. â€œLa canciÃ³n no se toma en serio a sÃ­ mismaâ€, ha dicho, de hecho, la propia Ware, y ha aÃ±adido que lo Ãºnico que quiere, la canciÃ³n en sÃ­, es que la bailes. Que la bailes hasta que las perlas te salten por los aires. Y sÃ­, hay ironÃ­a feroz, y diversiÃ³n en cada lÃ­nea de la canciÃ³n â€”y en cada fotograma del videoclipâ€”, que constituye en sÃ­ misma el relato de una metamorfosis de torpe soÃ±adora ante el tocador a diva de un camp sofisticadamente sarcÃ¡stico. Todo apunta a que That! Feels Good!, su disco respuesta a su anterior Ã¡lbum pregunta, Whatâ€™s Your Pleasure?, va a ser una pequeÃ±a gran fiesta. L. F.
Janelle MonÃ¡e ya no pertenece a quienes viven convencidos de que sus tres discos son de lo mejor que ha dado la mÃºsica en la Ãºltima dÃ©cada, a la altura de las aventuras de BeyoncÃ© o las producciones de Kanye West. Pocos sonidos tan satisfactorios para el cuerpo, el alma, el intelecto y la tensiÃ³n arterial hay como los editados hasta hoy por Monae. Pero ahora la de Kansas City pisa otro territorio, el de Netflix, gracias a su exitoso papel en la Ãºltima de la saga PuÃ±ales por la espalda. Y para catar el Ã©xito en Netflix hay que intentar â€”y lograrâ€” gustar a todo el mundo. Float se asemeja mÃ¡s a la traducciÃ³n musical de esa Janelle que es tambiÃ©n actriz en una peli de misterio que le gusta a tu suegro que a esas vaginas gigantes y bailarinas que decoraban â€˜Pynkâ€™, el brillante y delirante sencillo que adelantÃ³ su anterior disco. â€˜Floatâ€™ es mucho mÃ¡s convencional, con unos vientos cortesÃ­a de Seun Kuti and Egypt 80, un poco de trap y un algo de estribillo de aquellos que se caen casi sin querer al final de la estrofa. Todo suena bien, porque Janelle no sabe sonar mal, pero falta algo. XAVI SANCHO
El grupo californiano Gabriels, en una imagen promocional.
â€˜Offeringâ€™ es el tema que sirve de adelanto de lo que serÃ¡ la segunda parte del disco con el que este trÃ­o de Los Ãngeles debutÃ³ el pasado aÃ±o, Angels & Queens Part One. Desde que irrumpieran en 2020 con â€˜Love and Hate in a Different Timeâ€™, el grupo ha ido ganando adeptos al mismo ritmo que sus sencillos iban perdiendo algo en frescura y sorpresa. Esto Ãºltimo se revierte por completo con este apabullante â€˜Offeringâ€™, lo mejor que han lanzado desde aquel ya mÃ­tico tema de debut. Suena a bautismo en MisisipÃ­, entre sortilegios, invocaciones al demonio y gallinas decapitadas. Gospel, soul blues del delta, Marlena Shaw y Ramsey Lewis a tortazo limpio en un casino flotante para un tema que se escucha tan bien que casi se ve. Una maravilla tan precisamente vintage que no suena ni antigua, porque es perfecta. Y eso de la perfecciÃ³n no tiene Ã©poca, solo gente que la ve y gente que no. X. S.
El 31 de marzo, el productor James Holden publicarÃ¡ su primer disco en seis aÃ±os y â€˜Contains Multitudesâ€™ es el primer adelanto. Nueve minutos que empiezan con lo mÃ¡s parecido a mÃºsica de baile que ha hecho en una dÃ©cada. Todo gira alrededor de un loop que manipula para que suene en todas las variaciones posibles. Pero cuando a los dos minutos y 46 segundos comienza a sonar la tabla, empiezas a sospechar que lo que estÃ¡ diciendo es: â€œAbrÃ³chense los cinturones que vamos a despegarâ€. Lo que sigue son siete minutos en los que Holden atraviesa varios sistemas solares. AquÃ­ todo es caÃ³tico, pero ordenado, y eso es genial, porque a pesar de la confusiÃ³n, estÃ¡s siempre seguro y calentito. Ã‰l dice haberse inspirado en los collages de John Stezaker, que hacÃ­a cosas tan sencillas como pegar una postal en el retrato de una estrella de Hollywood, y con eso parecÃ­a haber abierto una ruta a sus pensamientos mÃ¡s profundos. Atando cabos con que la canciÃ³n se titula Contiene multitudes, todo parece indicar que nos ha llevado de viaje por su cabeza. Entonces recuerdas que su nuevo disco se va a titular Imagine This Is a High Dimensional Space of All Possibilities y piensas: â€œEsto prometeâ€. IÃ‘IGO LÃ“PEZ PALACIOS
De entrada, parecÃ­a que Pink iba a ser la menos durable de todas las nuevas estrellas del pop que surgieron alrededor del Ãºltimo cambio de milenio. Y, sin embargo, la cantante ha tenido una carrera mÃ¡s longeva que casi todas sus contemporÃ¡neas. Desde su debut en 2000, se ha mantenido fiel a una fÃ³rmula eficaz: pop con actitud contestona de chica mala de barrio residencial (â€˜Get the Party Startedâ€™, â€˜Raise Your Glassâ€™, â€˜So Whatâ€™) y un puÃ±ado de medios tiempos y power ballads un tanto genÃ©ricos (â€˜Soberâ€™, â€˜Just Give Me a Reasonâ€™, â€˜What About Usâ€™), pero entonados siempre con su reconocible vozarrÃ³n. Su nuevo disco en cuatro aÃ±os no se distancia de la receta original, aunque lo intente con el sencillo que le da tÃ­tulo, coescrito con Johnny McDaid (Snow Patrol) y Fred Again, productor de Ed Sheeran y de nombres con mÃ¡s pedigrÃ­ como Charli XCX o FKA Twigs. â€˜Trustfallâ€™ aspiraba a ser un himno para la pista de baile digno de la mejor Robyn, aunque se acabe pareciendo mÃ¡s al tercer single de cualquier disco de Katy Perry. Con todo, es preferible al pathos con regusto a sacarina que Pink se gasta en otros temas del disco, como â€˜When I Get Thereâ€™, oda a su difunto padre donde confunde, como tantas veces, lo emotivo con lo edulcorado. Ã. VICENTE
La cantante canadiense Shania Twain, en una imagen promocional.
Aviso para despistados: nos encontramos en plena Shaniassance, el renacimiento de Shania Twain mÃ¡s de dos dÃ©cadas despuÃ©s de los dÃ­as de â€˜Man! I Feel Like a Womanâ€™ y otros superÃ©xitos finiseculares. Tras superar un relativo ocaso y una enfermedad autoinmune (como refleja su nuevo documental en Netflix, Not Just a Girl), Twain vuelve convertida en un referente para las nuevas generaciones. AhÃ­ estÃ¡ el culto que le rinden las hermanas Haim u Orville Peck, el precedente que ella supuso para futuras reinas del country-pop como Taylor Swift y Miley Cyrus, los descarados guiÃ±os que le han dedicado Lady Gaga (â€˜Ayoâ€™) o Rina Sawayama (â€˜This Hellâ€™), o bien el homenaje que le hizo Harry Styles al invitarla a cantar con Ã©l en Coachella en 2022. Por todo ello, resulta decepcionante escuchar un regreso como este â€˜Giddy Up!â€™, recalentado tema de reminiscencias vaqueras al que le falta la garra y el encanto de sus viejos hits. Previsible y olvidable. Ã. V.

title: 'American Idol' Alum Adam Lambert Made a Lana Del Rey Song Sound Like Led Zeppelin on His New Album
content:
On Feb. 24, famous American Idol runner-up Adam Lambert released a new album called High Drama. The album features 11 covers of popular songs by Lambert with different vocal and production arrangements. In an interview with Wonderland Magazine, Lambert revealed he made a Lana Del Rey song sound like a â€œLed Zeppelin type song.â€
Adam Lambert | Christopher Willard via Getty Images
Adam Lambert covered a Lana Del Rey song on â€˜High Dramaâ€™
Before the release of High Drama, Lambert was interviewed by Wonderland Magazine about the album. In the interview, Lambert shared that he really wanted to cover Del Reyâ€™s song â€œWest Coast.â€
â€œWith â€˜West Coastâ€™, it is my favourite Lana song, for sure. I find it very sexy. Being that I am from the West Coast myself, I thought it was appropriate,â€ he said.
Lambert also teased that he made the popular Del Rey song sound quite different than Del Reyâ€™s version.
â€œThe idea behind the way we created the track was, I heard the blues guitar in the original and I thought well, if we make that a bit heavier and real electric all of a sudden it almost turns into a sort of Led Zepplin type song and I thought thatâ€™d be a really cool flavour to add to the album, something sort of heavy and intense,â€ Lambert told Wonderland Magazine.
Fans can listen to Lambertâ€™s cover of â€œWest Coastâ€ below.
Adam Lambert covered multiple songs on his new album
High Drama is Lambertâ€™s fifth studio album and it is an album of covers. On the album, Lambert covered 11 songs by other artists. The complete tracklist for High Drama can be viewed below.
High Drama tracklist:
â€œHolding Out For a Heroâ€ by Bonnie Tyler â€œChandelierâ€ by Sia â€œOrdinary Worldâ€ by Duran Duran â€œGetting Olderâ€ by Billie Eilish â€œI Canâ€™t Stand the Rainâ€ by Ann Peebles â€œWest Coastâ€ by Lana Del Rey â€œDo You Really Want To Hurt Meâ€ by Culture Club â€œSex on Fireâ€ by Kings of Leon â€œMy Atticâ€ by Pink â€œIâ€™m a Manâ€ by Jobriath â€œMad About The Boyâ€ by Noel Coward
Speaking with Wonderland Magazine, Lambert revealed why he decided to release an album consisting of covers instead of new original songs.
â€œWell, I decided that it was time to do an album of covers. I think the response to my cover of â€˜Believeâ€™ by Cher at the Kennedy Center was so good, people really seemed to love it,â€ the singer told the magazine.
He continued, â€œWhat I did with that was I flipped it from the upbeat dance original to an emotional ballad with strings. So, I wanted to take a similar approach with this album, in taking the songs and changing them up drastically.â€
My newest album 'High Drama' is available to stream everywhere now! ?https://t.co/RUUk2vvJe0 pic.twitter.com/hPyFy5sQ8m â€” ADAM LAMBERT (@adamlambert) February 24, 2023
Lana Del Rey released â€˜West Coastâ€™ in 2014
Del Rey originally released the song â€œWest Coastâ€ on her 2014 album Ultraviolence. The song was released as the albumâ€™s lead single in April 2014, and Del Rey went on to release Ultraviolence in June 2014.
While Lambertâ€™s cover gives â€œWest Coastâ€ a rock â€˜nâ€™ roll twist, Del Rey performs â€œWest Coastâ€ as a soft rock track.
The song is a tribute to California and tells the story of Del Rey having to leave behind a partner to follow her dreams.
â€œDown on the West coast, they got a sayinâ€™/ â€˜If youâ€™re not drinkinâ€™, then youâ€™re not playinâ€/ But youâ€™ve got the music/ Youâ€™ve got the music in you, donâ€™t you?/ Down on the West coast, I get this feeling like/ It all could happen, thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m leaving/ You for the moment, you for the moment/ Boy Blue, yeah, you,â€ Del Rey sings in the opening verse.
Lambertâ€™s album High Drama is available now.

title: Lana Del Rey Would Have Sang More on Taylor Swift Collab
content:
Photo-Illustration: Vulture. Photos: Jeff Kravitz/FilmMagic, Kevin Winter/Getty Images
Looks like Lana Del Rey was silent, not silenced. To the disappointment of many fans, the soda-loving singer didnâ€™t have a lot to say (literally, less than 20 murmured words) in her featuring appearance on Taylor Swiftâ€™s â€œSnow on the Beach.â€ Now, Del Rey has confirmed to Billboard that Swift also wanted her to sing more on the Midnights collab. â€œI had no idea I was the only feature [on that song]. Had I known, I would have sung the entire second verse like she wanted,â€ Del Rey said. â€œMy job as a feature on a big artistâ€™s album is to make sure I help add to the production of the song, so I was more focused on the production.â€ Surely a middle man â€” perhaps Jack Antonoff, who co-wrote this song with them â€” could have helped rectify this miscommunication, but we digress.
Now, we simply have to live with the knowledge that we could have gotten a version of the track where Del Rey says something other than â€œSnow on the beach,â€ â€œItâ€™s coming down,â€ â€œAre we falling?,â€ â€œJanet,â€ and â€¦ â€œAha.â€ In fact, based on the current second verse of the song, Del Rey wouldâ€™ve actually gotten to sing several full sentences, including words with three whole syllables, such as â€œaurora borealis,â€ â€œperiphery,â€ and â€œdishonest.â€ Or perhaps Del Rey wouldâ€™ve written her own lyrics. As it stands, the song is about falling in love, so there are plenty different ways she couldâ€™ve added another perspective to that message. She couldâ€™ve been singing to Swift as if they were having a proper back-and-forth conversation, or even catered to the Gaylors by singing about Swift â€¦ the possibilities are endless. Listen to the track below and imagine â€œSnow on the Beach (Lanaâ€™s Version)â€ for yourself.

title: Lana Del Rey Opens Up About Her Family on â€˜Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€™
content:
There is, in fact, a tunnel under Ocean Boulevard. Though a few online spectators suspected the tunnel, which inspired the name of Lana Del Reyâ€™s upcoming album Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, out March 24, might be located in Myrtle Beach, S.C., Del Rey recently revealed that the underground tunnel is actually in Long Beach, Calif. â€” not far from Los Angeles, where Del Rey has lived for the last six years.
The singer-songwriterâ€™s use of SoCal iconography has been a cornerstone of her songwriting for over a decade, from Born To Dieâ€™s (2012) depictions to old Hollywood glamor to Norman Fucking Rockwellâ€™s (2019) allusions to Venice Beach. While itâ€™s present on her new project as well, Del Rey admits she is not quite as focused on â€œworld buildingâ€ as she once was, and instead is â€œliving from the neck up,â€ focusing her craft on more lyrically driven and intimate songwriting.
Del Reyâ€™s Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd discusses unrevealed details and stories about her â€œfamily of origin,â€ especially in songs like â€œFingertips,â€ which she says â€œtells everything about everyone from day one.â€ Just weeks before its release, Del Rey â€“ who is Billboardâ€™s 2023 Women in Music Visionary honoree â€” talks about creating the album in her living room, and why she is ready to talk about her family.
How did your new album begin to take shape?
Mike Hermosa, who produced the majority of the songs on this album, would come over to my house, and I would hear him in my living room playing piano. Heâ€™s not even a musician full time. Heâ€™s a DP, a cameraman. I would hear him play, and Iâ€™d be like â€œcan I record that?â€ or Iâ€™d sneakily record something.
Eventually I asked if he could just keep playing, and I could sing. Then, every Sunday when he wasnâ€™t working, he would just kind of noodle around, and I would sing. Thatâ€™s how we wrote the first song: â€œDid You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd.â€ I knew right away that I really, really liked it.
I enjoyed how casual writing with Mike was. He didnâ€™t have a dog in the race. He wasnâ€™t interested in anything beyond just playing. Itâ€™s fun that the entire album didnâ€™t feel like we were making one until the end when Jack Antonoff came in and was like â€œI really like this. Can I put something on top of this?â€ When Jack comes in, you know youâ€™re making a real record.
Do you feel this casual approach to songwriting was able to open you up creatively?
This process was almost like automatic singing. I just knew exactly every word to sing for everything he played because the chords were perfectly arranged. I think my overall feeling when writing this album was just, â€œwow, I got lucky.â€
Also, I realized that, even when Iâ€™m seeking so many other things in my life, music really seeks me. Itâ€™s like a little bird following me around. Somehow when I didnâ€™t want to make music, I was presented with the best collaborators Iâ€™ve met. I just had them in my living room. I realized music is the one thing that constantly shows up for me, even when Iâ€™m looking for something else.
Since you were singing so automatically, as you put it, did you go back and edit, or did you leave it as is?
There was a lot of editing, because it was mostly a stream of consciousness, but every now and then Iâ€™ll have a complete song come to me fully formed. The song â€œFingertipsâ€ I created in one sitting, voice memoed it, and sent it to [the producer and composer] Drew Erickson. He came back to me the next day with a full orchestra. Again, I just felt so lucky: lucky for the songs, lucky for these producers, lucky for the project.
You have Jack Antonoff coming back on this record. Heâ€™s worked on so many major albums in the last five years, including two of your own (Norman Fucking Rockwell and Chemtrails Over the Country Club). As someone who has worked with him so often, whatâ€™s his secret? Why does everyone want to work with him?
He can play anything on any instrument. He can fit the right instruments and melodies to any idea youâ€™ve had. I think he plays something like 16 instruments. For us, itâ€™s definitely very collaborative. I think probably out of any projects heâ€™s worked on, he would say I give him the most direction.
Itâ€™s funny because I recently heard all of his records he made from when he was in high school, and I still hear so much of what heâ€™s done on Taylor [Swift]â€™s new record from that high school record. Heâ€™s just prolific. Itâ€™s absolutely wild to watch. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s so fun because you really get to create any sound with him.
Heâ€™s also a girlâ€™s guy. He gets it!
Heâ€™s also a featured artist on the album too. How did that come about?
I was done with the album, and he came in for a couple days. We sat there, and I said, â€œletâ€™s just play the piano.â€ I can make a song out of anything Jack plays. Thatâ€™s actually how Norman got started too. He just plays and I just sing. He started playing something and then I was thinking about his fiancÃ©e [Margaret Qualley] who I just canâ€™t live without! I love her. I started singing â€œhe met Margaret on a rooftop / she was wearing white / and he was like / â€˜I might be in trouble.â€™â€
I asked him what he thought we should say in the second verse because with him and Margaret it was a â€œwhen you know you knowâ€ situation. He had the idea to sing about what you should do when you donâ€™t know. He started singing, and I told him he should just sing it on the record. It was really fun.
What overall themes did you try to capture in this record?
Family of origin is the overall theme. I think with Blue Banisters I wanted to capture this idea too, but I flew it under the radar. I was trying to address some criticisms that I had heard said after Chemtrialsâ€¦ mostly that people donâ€™t know much about me. I didnâ€™t promote that theme of Blue Banisters at all intentionally.
In this album, I got to really finish my thoughts and get super specific, which I was not comfortable with completely beforeâ€¦ I do list my grandpa, my brother, my dad, my Uncle Dave.
In the song â€œFingertips,â€ I sing â€œCharlie stop smoking / Caroline will you be with me / will the baby be alright? / Will I have one of mine?â€ I think I was able to open up about this because Mike was so casual to work with. All in my living room. It allowed for that.
â€œFingertipsâ€ tells everything about everyone from day one until now.
Are you nervous about being so forthcoming about your family in this record?
I was. I was so uncomfortable. Then, by the grace of God, I felt completely unburdened.
Your father, Rob Grant, is releasing an album on Decca Records on June 9, and youâ€™ll be featured on two songs. Has he always been musical?
My dad has always played piano and he sang when he was younger with my uncle whoâ€™s a traveling organ player for Emmylou Harris and Buddy Guy. They wrote country records back in the day. I donâ€™t know how and when it came to him. But I think he just decided he wanted to record it. And [my manager] played it for Decca Records, and they loved it.
Iâ€™m not talkative when it comes to myself, but you will learn so much about me in hearing him. It gives so much context to the family.

title: Lana Del Rey: Billboard Women In Music Visionary Interview
content:
Lana Del Rey practices â€œautomatic singing.â€ Using the improvisational songwriting technique, she lets her voice carry over accompaniments, not commandeering where her words or melodies take her, accepting all ideas she has in the moment and editing them later. Lately, her voice has led her home, back to memories of her childhood in Lake Placid, N.Y., and to ruminations on relationships with her family and the divergent paths theyâ€™ve taken.
That subject underpins her upcoming ninth album, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd (out March 24). Del Rey, 37, says she hesitantly began to unpack this subject matter with her previous album, Blue Banisters â€” but now, sheâ€™s ready to dig deeper. â€œAt first I was so uncomfortable,â€ she says of the more personal material. â€œThen, by the grace of God, I just felt completely unburdened.â€
Lia Clay Miller
As a singer-songwriter, this yearâ€™s Visionary honoree has embodied that word for over a decade. Her 2012 major-label debut, Born To Die, made her a star and defined musicâ€™s Tumblr era, as a young Del Rey toyed with both the romantic and the darker sides of the American dream. Her â€œworld building,â€ as she calls it now, for her early work created a collage of beautiful and disparate images, pairing hip-hop aesthetics with references to the Kennedy family, Elvis Presley with John Wayne, and old Hollywood glamour with biker gang grit.
Since then, Del Rey has pushed musical boundaries â€” seamlessly peppering an album with features from Stevie Nicks to Playboi Carti (2017â€™s Lust for Life), reworking a Sublime cover into a contemporary Billboard Hot 100 hit (2019â€™s â€œDoinâ€™ Timeâ€), for instance â€” while achieving both critical acclaim and commercial success. She has earned six Grammy nominations and holds the record for most No. 1s on Billboardâ€™s Alternative Albums chart. And somehow, each week, it seems a new song from her vast catalog gains traction on TikTok. (â€œWest Coastâ€ and â€œHow To Disappearâ€ are two recent breakouts.) Younger artists often cite her as an inspiration â€” including Billie Eilish, whom Del Rey now calls â€œmy girl. It makes me feel comforted that music is going in such a good direction.â€
Lia Clay Miller
Since 2019, youâ€™ve released four albums. Is it fair to say you have more creative energy than ever?
I think it might look like that! Itâ€™s funny because I keep telling people, â€œI havenâ€™t worked in three years,â€ but really I just havenâ€™t done shows in three years. As soon as I start getting ready for a show, thatâ€™s when it feels like work.
How has your process changed since Born To Die came out?
Eleven years ago I wanted it to be so good. Now, I just sing exactly what Iâ€™m thinking. Iâ€™m thinking a little less big and bombastic. Maybe at some point I can have fun creating a world again, but right now, I would say thereâ€™s no world building. This music is about thought processing. Itâ€™s very, very wordy. Iâ€™m definitely living from the neck up.
Lia Clay Miller
Can you remember what it felt like creatively when you were just starting out?
I think back to the beginning, being in New York. I would just go to a little deli by Grand Central and all you had to do to sit at the table for hours was buy a black coffee. I remember thinking, â€œIâ€™m doing it. Iâ€™m living it.â€ It was all very thrilling. I was so psyched back then.
You recently featured on Taylor Swiftâ€™s â€œSnow on the Beach.â€ What was collaborating with her like?
Well, first of all, I had no idea I was the only feature [on that song]. Had I known, I would have sung the entire second verse like she wanted. My job as a feature on a big artistâ€™s album is to make sure I help add to the production of the song, so I was more focused on the production. She was very adamant that she wanted me to be on the album, and I really liked that song. I thought it was nice to be able to bridge that world, since Jack [Antonoff] and I work together and so do Jack and Taylor.
Who do you consider to be a visionary?
Joan Baez. I sang with her recently. She gave me a challenge: She said, â€œGo down a little road and look for a left turn and find my house [in Northern California]. If you find it and can play â€˜Diamonds and Rustâ€™sâ€™ high harmony, Iâ€™ll come to Berkeley with you and sing.â€ So my sister and I rented a car and searched for the house. I was very nervous. I donâ€™t play guitar that well, but I learned the first three chords and sat across from her, [and when] we stopped playing, she was like, â€œGreat, Iâ€™ll see you at Berkeley.â€
And another visionary to me is Cat Power. I had heard that she would run offstage when she wasnâ€™t feeling it or just turn her back to the [audience] and keep playing. Thatâ€™s when I knew I could probably do this.
Lia Clay Miller
This story will appear in the Feb. 25, 2023, issue of Billboard.

title: Lana Del Reyâ€™s Father, Rob Grant, Prepping Debut Album, â€˜Lost At Seaâ€™
content:
Lana Del Rey isnâ€™t the only one in the family with chops. Her dad, Rob Grant, is getting into the music business this summer when he drops his debut album. â€œRob Grant here! And the rumors are true! My new album Lost At Sea is coming out on June 9th,â€ wrote Grant on Instagram along with an image of the album cover, on which the hale and hearty singer stares out over the ocean as seagulls swarm around him.
Grant also released the collectionâ€™s first single, the majestic instrumental piano ballad â€œSetting Sail on a Distant Horizon,â€ which was co-produced by Del Reyâ€™s frequent collaborator, Jack Antonoff along with Luke Howard. While Lana does not appear on that song â€” though she reportedly adds vocals to two other songs on the album â€” the singer makes a smiling cameo in a promo video Grant posted.
According to label Decca Records Grantâ€™s compositions are the work of an admitted amateur with a passion for music. â€œAn accidental recording artist, Grant has never had a lesson on any instrument in his life. No kind of formal musical training at all. He canâ€™t read sheet music. But when he sits down at a piano, something magical happens,â€ reads a description on the labelâ€™s site.
â€œNotes flow from him and out pours composition after composition. The father of international icon Lana Del Rey, he enlisted an array of talent to contribute to the making of the album.â€ The collection promises features and writing assistance from his famous daughter, as well as production from Antonoff, Howard, Laura Sisk, and Zach Dawes.
Del Reyâ€™s new album, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, is due out on March 24.
Check out Grantâ€™s album announce and listen to â€œSetting Sailâ€ below.

title: Caroline Polachek, Lana Del Rey, Feist, and More: This Weekâ€™s Pitchfork Selects Playlist
content:
The staff of Pitchfork listens to a lot of new music. A lot of it. On any given day our writers, editors, and contributors go through an imposing number of new releases, giving recommendations to each other and discovering new favorites along the way. Each Monday, with our Pitchfork Selects playlist, weâ€™re sharing what our writers are playing obsessively and highlighting some of the Pitchfork staffâ€™s favorite new music. The playlist is a grab-bag of tracks: Its only guiding principle is that these are the songs youâ€™d gladly send to a friend.
This weekâ€™s Pitchfork Selects playlist features Caroline Polachek, Lana Del Rey, Feist, Mega Bog, Nia Archives, Maxo, Skrillex, and more. Listen below and follow our playlists on Apple Music and Spotify. (Pitchfork earns a commission from purchases made through affiliate links on our site.)

title: Lana Del Reyâ€™s Soda Lyrics, Ranked
content:
Photo-Illustration: Vulture. Photos: Getty Images
From walking out with an orange pop in the â€œRideâ€ music video to enjoying and gifting soda in paparazzi pictures, sodas are Lana Del Reyâ€™s greatest sober muse. Sheâ€™s named three songs after carbonated drinks: â€œCola,â€ â€œDiet Mountain Dew,â€ and her latest single, â€œA&W.â€ The second single off of Del Reyâ€™s upcoming album, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, fits the theme of the album title, as it is one of her longest songs to date. The song also continues Del Reyâ€™s history of referencing fizzy pop drinks, beginning with her first official Lana Del Rey album, Born to Die. But what is it about soda that makes Lana Del Rey grab a pen and paper? Are her favorite sodas worth singing about?
Judging is based on the lyrical use of the soft drink, if she has been known to drink the beverage in real life, and its probability of it being her favorite soda, thus determining its overall score in the universe that is Lana Del Reyâ€™s stimulants. Drink up!
5. A&W â€” â€œA&Wâ€
Lyrical use of the drink: Del Reyâ€™s latest release brings her back to her soda-loving roots. However, she uses the root beer icon as a metaphor for â€œAmerican Whore.â€ There is no direct reference to the soda in the song, which knocks it down a few points, but the deep beats and vocals during the song are reminiscent of the dark flavors of Root Beer.
Have we seen Lana actually drink it? Much like the mystery of the missing direct lyric reference, Del Rey hasnâ€™t been spotted with a root beer of any kind.
Is it her favorite soda? Considering that it wasnâ€™t good enough for a direct reference nor for Miss Del Rey herself to be sipping on under Ocean Blvd, itâ€™s a no-go.
Rating: ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤
4. Coca-Cola â€” â€œCherryâ€ and â€œWild At Heartâ€
Lyrical use of the drink: A classic soda for that gets a soft spoken mention in â€œCherry.â€ Her breathy voice whispers Coca-Cola underneath the bridge of the song, almost to be completely missed if you werenâ€™t reading the lyrics. As someone from a Coca-Cola household, its appalling that Del Rey dismisses the superior cola. Even in â€œWild At Heart,â€ she mixes it with alcohol, drinking a Jack and Coke. Is she opposed to none flavored Colas? Does it have to be mixed in order to make it out of her soda fridge?
Have we seen Lana actually drink it? Del Rey has countless photos of her with a Coca-Cola. She uses a bottled Cola, referred to as Mexican Coke, in many photo shoots during the Born to Die era with photographer Nicole Nodland.
Is it her favorite soda? Coca-Cola isnâ€™t more than a prop to her on its own
Rating: ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤
3. Pepsi Cola â€” appears on â€œColaâ€
Lyrical use of the drink: Her most notable soda reference, and probably the most overrated, she describes her pussy as a Pepsi Cola. Inspired by her boyfriend at the time, Del Rey told Rolling Stone: â€œHe was talking about American girls, his vision of American girls was that all their pussies tasted like Pepsi Cola, and that they were such a dream. I thought that was the funniest fucking thing Iâ€™d ever heard. And I thought, â€˜Well â€¦â€™â€ Look, if we had to pick the most American soft drink, it has to be the 136-year-old Coca-Cola, not Pepsi. However, despite a bias towards Coke, the lyric is objectively incredibly funny and speaks to Del Rey as the soda enthusiast that she is.
Have we seen Lana actually drink it? Sheâ€™s been spotted buying Pepsi in its most purest form: from a gas station (iconic).
Is it her favorite soda? While sheâ€™s enjoyed a Pepsi on the go, the original song is inspired by Harvey Weinstein and isnâ€™t played on tour anymore, tainting the taste.
Rating: ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤
2. Diet Mountain Dew â€” appears on â€œDiet Mountain Dewâ€
Lyrical use of the drink: Gamers unite. Almost begging to be paired with another Del Rey song, â€œVideo Games,â€ she sings of the ethereal beauty and grace of New York City and an unnaturally green soda. She speaks of the soda as a metaphor to a bad relationship â€œYouâ€™re no good for me, but baby, I want you.â€ Of course, a diet bright lime green soda is terrible for you, but how could she resist?
Have we seen Lana actually drink it? She takes a big gulp of a 2 liter bottle in a self-made music video for the song from 2017, so itâ€™s safe to say sheâ€™s a true fan.
Is it her favorite soda? Despite wanting something thatâ€™s bad for her, her over consumption of the soda feels more like an unhealthy addiction.
Rating: ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤ğŸ¥¤
1. Cherry Coke â€” appears on â€œBartenderâ€
Lyrical use of the drink: Del Rey sure loves a flavored Cola, enough to mention it in two songs: â€œBartenderâ€ and â€œFlorida Kilos;â€ the latter is a reference to a vape juice flavor, but nonetheless, she loves her Cherry Coke. â€œBartenderâ€ is for all the people who honestly just want a tasty lil soda at the bar when everyone is drinking liquor (specifically wine). It calls to soda girlies who can never say no to a delicious pop. She refers to the literal soda â€œthat Cherry Coke you serve is fine,â€ served behind a bar, hopefully from a soda dispenser and not a can.
Have we seen Lana actually drink it? In the â€œNorman Fucking Rockwellâ€ music video that features â€œBartenderâ€ sheâ€™s seen drinking a dark-colored soda, but thereâ€™s no confirmation that itâ€™s a Cherry Coke.
Is it her favorite soda? Del Rey appreciates a Cherry Coke purely for its taste. She loves the flavor in all forms, including vape pens.

title: Friday Wrap: Yellowstone fans outed, Marvel movie malaise, and Lana Del Rey's new seven-minute song
content:
For today's weekly wrap-up, Commotion's panel of experts crossed space, time and planes of existence.
Culture writers Kathryn VanArendonk, Niko Stratis and Kathleen Newman-Bremang joined host Elamin Abdelmahmoud to talk about everything from the puzzling appeal of Yellowstone and the rumoured departure of its star Kevin Costner, to Lana Del Rey's bold decision to release a seven-minute song in a TikTok-dominated music market, to Marvel's latest offering â€” and whether we even want it at this point.
We've included some highlights below. For the full discussion, listen and follow the Commotion with Elamin Abdelmahmoud podcast, on your favourite podcast player.
Is Kevin Costner riding off into the sunset on Yellowstone?
Elamin: I want to start by talking about Yellowstone. And the reason I want to start talking about Yellowstone is, it's not a show that your cool Internet friends talk about a lot, but it is a phenomenon. I myself watched it over four or five days because I had COVID in the summer and I was in my basement, and I did nothing else but watch Yellowstone and I came out a libertarian on the other side.
You'd think that that's a pretty good gig if you're a TV actor but apparently not, because some reports have emerged suggesting that Kevin Costner [the star of Yellowstone] actually might want to throw the future of Yellowstone away. There's a lot of drama in this. Kathryn, I'm going to start with you on this. I think it'd be good to maybe start by contextualizing the popularity of Yellowstone. It's not just me watching it in a basement, right?
Kathryn: No, although I cannot tell you how many people I have heard from who are like, "you know, I had COVID, and I just somehow watched all of Yellowstone." Like, I think we really need to be frightened about co-morbidities here. But Yellowstone is, even without the pandemic, a bona fide phenomenon, and it is a phenomenon in ways that are a little bit surprising because the shows that have tended to get that much of an audience share tend to be streaming shows â€” your Wednesdays, your Squid Games or the buzzy HBO-Sunday-night kinds of things that you can also watch on a streaming platform and catch up throughout the week. It is astonishing to me that Yellowstone is so hard to watch if you want to go stream it somewhere in the United States.
Elamin: It's not easy in Canada either.
Kathryn: Yeah. It's not available on the same streaming platform that it airs on as a channel in the United States. And it is a linear show. Basically, you need a cable package or you need to say, "sure, I'll just pay $20 for this season of this show." And yet, it has been wildly, wildly popular here, and that audience has not petered out. It continues to grow as each season comes out.
Elamin: Right, and there's something about Kevin Costner's character as this sort of stoic-old-white male who is a familiar figure, but maybe not a very contemporary figure. And maybe Kathleen, that's a reason why a lot of people don't write about this show. What do you make of the fact that it is so popular and yet so few people talk about it? You watch the show, and you don't even talk about it. You're like a secret, closeted Yellowstone watcher. Out yourself.
Kathleen: Wow. I mean, first of all, I live with a white man, so that's who I blame for the fact that I watch Yellowstone. But I did try to write about Yellowstone in a piece tentatively titled, "Are Black People Watching Yellowstone? An Investigation." But barely anyone wanted to go on record to say that they were watchingâ€“
Elamin: For the record, I did. I wanted to go on the recordâ€“
Kathleen: Except for you.
Elamin: That's right. It's true.
Kathleen: And I think it's because as you said, it is not cool. Its core audiences are older, male, very middle-America â€” not necessarily the demo of people who are extremely online. And I don't think it has that self-aware, eat-the-rich vibe that Succession does, it doesn't have a youth element like Euphoria does, it very earnestly has the energy of Make America Great Again â€¦ So it's messy, and I just think it's a little embarrassing to say out loud that you love Yellowstone. So if anyone asks, I have never seen a single episode.
Elamin: Wow, I am left out in the cold as the only person who's ever seen an episode of Yellowstone. That's fine. So the reason we're talking about this this week is that Kevin Costner is supposed to start shooting Yellowstone again in March, but there's been all these reports from very reputable sources that there are conflicts with his shooting schedule. And Kathryn, there's all these rumors that he's kind of angling for an exit. Is that surprising to you, this idea that the biggest star on the biggest show would say five seasons in, "alright, this is over for me."?
Kathryn: No, not particularly, given Kevin Costner's general reputation as being an actor who feels like he wants to have a lot of say over the role that he takes in a show, and the the fact that he has been a movie star for his entire career. When you do a movie, you sign onto the movie, it takes a certain number of months, maybe it's a year, to do a movie, that's your life â€” and then you get to leave. And TV goes for a long, long time and, unless he wants this to be sort of the last big project he ever does, he is going to need to leave so that he can become a director, so that he can do other things. And, it's also hard work having to get off and on all of those horses over and over again. And when you shoot out in the middle of nowhere, you become much more distanced from a sort of general production, the ability to be involved in all the meetings you need to do to do other things. No, I'm not particularly surprised.
Aren't we all Marvel-ed out by now?
Elamin: Niko, it's been 15 years since the first movie in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. We've followed this brand for, at this point, 32 movies. How much Marvel is too much? Are we at our breaking point? Help me.
Niko: You said 15 years and my bones just turned to dust.
Elamin: That's Iron Man, 2008.
Niko: I mean, I still can't believe we started this thing with Iron Man, a comic book character that nobody cared about at all, and 15 years later we're still making these things.
Elamin: And billions of dollars.
Niko: Billions of dollars. It is such a feat.
Elamin: Do you still care?
Niko: I do. And if everybody's outing themselves with their fandom today, I am a big Marvel person. I grew up reading comics, but I find the movies to be really tiring. I didn't see the last Doctor Strange one because I just was like, who has the time? You know?
Elamin: Doctor Strange does, the whole thing is he plays with time. My question is about Marvel fatigue, Kathryn, because it feels like we should be approaching the point of getting exhausted with Marvel. I'm not sure that we are, because alongside the movies they've also launched, at this point, a dozen different TV shows; they're not slowing down anytime soon. Is the interest in them slowing down?
Kathryn: I think it is. I think it's interesting that even though they have launched all these TV shows, very few of them have release dates for new seasons this year. Which is not to say there won't be any, but I have not seen that schedule come out so far. The other thing that I think is really fascinating is Kevin Feige, the head of Marvel Entertainment, came out and said in an interview with Entertainment Weekly that he wants all of the Marvel TV shows to become more episodic, which to me is great. I love episodic television. But, it also signals this awareness that you have to give people a full story inside an episode because something about what they have been getting already has not been satisfying to them. And the way that all these big interconnected universes have been also kicking the can of narrative satisfaction just down the road, farther and farther and farther, I think is finally starting to catch up with them as far as how they are building these stories. If there is this much story, but also it never pays off, you are going to have a hard time with an audience wanting to come back again and again.
Elamin: What you're describing is my experience with Moon Knight, the series starring Oscar Isaac, the one that I'm convinced not a single person in the world saw.
Kathleen: I watched one episode.
Elamin: Niko, what do you want to see Marvel do with their series?
Niko: You know, Star Wars did a really interesting thing with Andor. I loved Star Wars when I was a kid, and I got so burnt out on Star Wars, like I just stopped caring. And Andor came in, and I all of a sudden realized, "oh, I love this world, if they were willing to do something interesting with it." And it's the first Star Wars thing that doesn't even have a John Williams score. It just feels like they need to find something new that tells a story in this world. The episodic thing is perfect because comic books are like that, right? They're not these things that tie into a grander universe, they're small snippets of stories that don't have to connect to each other. Watching TV shouldn't be homework.
Why did Lana Del Ray release a seven-minute song?
Elamin: Lana Del Rey released a seven-minute single called A&W from her highly anticipated album, Did You Know That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd. Lana has had this aesthetic of a certain kind of American era that has gone by that she's really fixated on. And Niko, I could never tell if Lana Del Rey is serious or if this is a persona. Because I look at her and I go, "this is not pastiche. You're deadly serious about this." When you listen to the new Lana Del Rey song, what do you make of it?
Niko: I do think I think she's a pastiche of herself. She moves through these iterations of herself and she's constantly creating herself as a persona. We never know who the real Lana Del Rey is, and I don't think we're meant to know who the real Lana Del Rey is. I think she is always sort of a variation on a theme. When I first heard A&W, and you're like "seven-minute single? Okay, we're back to this," because she's done this where she made a nine-minute song. You listen to it and it's like, okay, we're moving through. It's the Marvel Cinematic Universe of Lana Del Rey. We're moving through it, right? It is very cinematic, and it is very interesting to hear all these layers of her laid out on a line.
Elamin: There's something to me that's fascinating about watching Lana do her work, Kathleen, because what she's done is continually refined her voice and to me that's interesting because she's, in a way, writing her public persona and repeatedly being like, "I'm not lying to you. I really am like this." She worked with Jack Antonoff on this record, and anyone who works with Jack tends to take on some Jack characteristics, which is kind of bothersome to me, but this sounds like Lana Del Rey. What do you make of the collaboration between one of the biggest producers in pop [music] and then Lana Del Rey?
Kathleen: I mean, I think they're both really interesting. And also, this entire episode has been a ploy from you, Elamin, to get me to publicly admit that I watch Yellowstone and listen to Taylor Swift's songs.
Elamin: My favorite day of the week. I love this day.
Kathleen: I do really appreciate a good Jack Antonoff-produced track, and so I think this collaboration is really interesting because both of these pop culture figures, Jack Antonoff and Lana Del Rey, are pretty divisive. They got popular doing a signature sound really well, and then they both kind of became punchlines for it, or the fatigue kind of set in, I think, because of their popularity. And I think this song is some of their most interesting work, maybe because it doesn't have as much of that Jack Antonoff signature that people are sick of right now, but also because I think the Lana Del Rey lore is that she is just made from a machine and she's not real, and I think this song feels like it has a depth and a realness to it that I haven't heard in a long time.
Elamin: Kathryn, I'm curious about your perspective about the fact that this song is seven minutes long. We are inundated with all these sort of 30 second-to-one minute soundbites that work really well on TikTok. Is this as radical as some people make it out to be?
Kathryn: I don't think so. There have been long songs forever, and it's not like TikTok cannot clip the bit that they're going to decide [is a trend]. I mean, picking that one moment that switches to a synth pop, or later when the song starts to incorporate like American camp songs, I think is going to be very easy to pull out. I love a long song.
You can listen to the full discussion from today's show on CBC Listen or on our podcast, Commotion with Elamin Abdelmahmoud, available wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Feistâ€™s Electrifying Return, and 9 More New Songs
content:
Lana Del Rey works in liminal spaces: between breath and melody, between confession and persona, between image and experience, between commerce and art. The pretty but utterly bleak â€œA&Wâ€ has nothing to do with root beer or fast food; the initials echo â€œAmerican whore,â€ something she calls herself in the song. She sings as a woman without illusions or hopes, a celebrity whoâ€™s always under scrutiny: â€œDo you really think I give a damn what I do/After years of just hearing them talking?â€ In this long, subdued, radio-defying track, she sings about a loveless hotel hookup that may have turned into a rape; â€œDo you really think anyone would think that I didnâ€™t ask for it?â€ she wonders. Halfway through, the track turns to synthetic sounds and the lyrics drift into a different obsession: â€œJimmy only love me when he want to get high.â€ In this song, everyone is a user. PARELES
Janelle MonÃ¡e, â€˜Floatâ€™

title: New music from Feist, beabadoobee, Lana Del Rey and more
content:
Star Tracks compiles the most interesting new music from a broad range of established and emerging artists. This weekâ€™s playlist features tracks from Feist, beabadoobee, Daughter, Lana Del Rey, Kelela, Tayc, You Me At Six, and Caroline Polachek featuring Grimes and Dido.
Click here to listen along to the Spotify playlist.
Feist: Love Who We Are Meant To
On Valentineâ€™s Day, Canadian singer-songwriter Feist returned after a six-year stretch without new solo music to offer a simple but poignant reminder: â€œSometimes we donâ€™t get to love who we are meant to.â€
Coming from a lesser artist, that sentiment (and its timing) might feel like a bit of a buzz kill, but in the hands of Leslie Feist, it becomes a moving meditation on the alluring imperfection of love.â€œSo will I let it wreck me / Or wreck my dream of family?â€ she sings softly over delicately plucked nylon strings, quietly conjuring the spirit of Joni Mitchell. â€œEven denial is romantic/ And thatâ€™s romanceâ€™s disadvantage.â€
This one will leave you in a puddle, but it packs the type of emotional punch typically absent from a Hallmark holiday. Feistâ€™s sixth studio album, â€œMultitudes,â€ drops April 14. â€” Richie Assaly
beabadoobee: Glue Song
Old-fashioned, romantic, dreamy, lilting â€” how fitting beabadoobeeâ€™s swoony single landed on Valentineâ€™s Day. â€œGlue Songâ€ feels like a classic love ballad, heavily inspired by the likes of Elvis and Frankie Valli. You can sense Taylor Swiftâ€™s influence here, too â€” echoes of â€œLoverâ€ that peek through beabadoobeeâ€™s echoing guitar and earnest lyrics â€” and that makes sense, given the Filipino-British singerâ€™s upcoming stint on Swiftâ€™s Eras Tour. Strings, horns and classy percussion frame the guitar-forward â€œGlue Songâ€ with nostalgia and ambience as beabadoobee sings of gentle, comfortable love. A surefire add to wedding and anniversary playlists around the world. â€” Aisling Murphy
Daughter: Party
Everything about Daughterâ€™s new single, â€œParty,â€ is nostalgic to me. The subdued guitar and minimalist 2010s indie rock production take me back to the echoey soundscape I bore witness to at 16, dressed in my best black turtleneck for their â€œNot to Disappearâ€ tour. The new pressed flower album cover hearkens to the past, dried and preserved for future introspection. Lyrically, lead singer Elena Tonra reflects on the night she decided to give up alcohol and what she lost to get there.
Something that feels different, though, is the delicate optimism woven through the track, in Tonraâ€™s gentle ad-libs or the exultant bursts of rolling snare. The trioâ€™s upcoming album, â€œStereo Mind Game,â€ promises to explore the â€œconflicting voices we all have in our heads.â€ I canâ€™t wait for it to break and then mend my heart in all sorts of ways. â€” Dhriti Gupta
Lana Del Rey: A&W
Yes, Lana Del Reyâ€™s latest song, â€œA&W,â€ is named in reference to the fast-food chain, but it also serves as a look into her â€œexperience as an American whore,â€ taking listeners on a seven-minute journey through each era â€” and perhaps a new one â€” in her discography.
Beginning with slower vocals (think: â€œChemtrails Over the Country Clubâ€) and a classic Jack Antonoff background track, Lana sings of her childhood innocence before exploring adulthood: mainly of sex and getting high with â€œJimmy,â€ a recurring character in her work.
â€œItâ€™s not about havinâ€™ someone to love me anymore / No, this is the experience of beinâ€™ an American whore,â€ she sings in the Old Hollywood style the artist is known for. But around the midpoint of the song, Lana ditches the ballad-esque vibe for â€¦ trap music?
Similar to the sounds of â€œLust for Lifeâ€ and â€œUltraviolence,â€ Lana raps, albeit with pretty repetitive lyrics, over a track that is unlike anything weâ€™ve heard from the artist to date, complete with heavy bass, distorted vocals and the most iconic line in the song: â€œYour mom called, I told her youâ€™re f---ing up big time!â€ OK, Lana!
A new era of Lana has clearly arrived. And love him or hate him, (Iâ€™m looking at you, Richie), Antonoff deserves all the praise for producing â€œA&W.â€ â€” Alessia Passafiume
Kelela: Raven/Bruises
Over the past several years, R&B has been reshaped and stretched in fascinating new directions by a vanguard of mostly women, from Solange to SZA to FKA twigs to Sudan Archives to Syd. But perhaps no artist feels as mysterious and subversive as Kelela, whose long-awaited sophomore album â€œRavenâ€ arrived this week.
Influenced by Black futurists like Herbie Hancock and Sun Ra, and created in collaboration with mainly queer and Black producers like Nguzunguzu and Kaytranada, the album is a seamless blend of R&B and electronic club music â€” one that immediately wraps its tentacles around you until you are fully immersed.
Itâ€™s tough to recommend a single song from the album, though Iâ€™m partial to transition from the title track â€” a starkly beautiful song about moving on from a broken romance â€” to the slow-burning â€œBruises.â€
â€œItâ€™s like youâ€™re running in slow motion but still so fast taking different turns,â€ Kelela told Vulture. â€œBasically, I want it to feel like a whirlwind. Or like a slide. When youâ€™re on a water slide, it gets dark at a period right before it spits you out.â€ â€” RA
Tayc: Encorps
If youâ€™re still bouncing off the love and energy from loved ones and friends from Valentineâ€™s Day, Taycâ€™s romantic, R&B and Afrobeats-infused EP, â€œROOM 96,â€ might be the perfect addition to your weekend playlist.
The Cameroonian-French artist dropped 10 tracks on Valentineâ€™s Day, following a two-year hiatus. From start to finish, the EP takes you on a romantic listening journey through a perfect mixture of lively Afrobeats and slow, melodic R&B vocals.
â€œEncorpsâ€ is one of the tracks I instantly gravitated toward for its bouncy beats, Taycâ€™s silky, harmonic vocals and hint of trumpet instrumentals, as he sings about sharing an intimate night with a lover. The single is expected to be accompanied by a music video.
And if you enjoy â€œROOM 96,â€ some of Taycâ€™s past bangers that are beloved internationally include â€œLe Temps,â€ â€œNâ€™y pense plusâ€ and â€œD O D O.â€ â€” Madison Wong
You Me At Six: A Love Letter to Those Who Feel Lost (feat. Cody Frost)
English band You Me At Sixâ€™s song â€œA Love Letter to Those Who Feel Lost,â€ off their newly released eighth album â€œTruth Decay,â€ is a standout on an album that sometimes feels like itâ€™s being a little too safe.
Throughout their long career, the best word I can think of to describe the band has been â€œreliable.â€ Never taking more than three years to release an album, theyâ€™ve been a pop-punk and alt-rock mainstay, delivering a constant sound even as the genreâ€™s popularity had its ebbs and flows. On â€œTruth Decay,â€ they do experiment at times, but I often found myself longing for something more.
â€œA Love Letter to Those Who Feel Lost,â€ which features guest vocals from Cody Frost alongside frontman Josh Franceschi, is a sweet, simple album closer that instantly rose above the rest of the recordâ€™s tracks for me. Reminiscent of their older song â€œTake On the World,â€ â€œA Love Letter to Those Who Feel Lostâ€ feels a bit like a warm hug. Itâ€™s earnest and heartfelt and, while not overly complex, it ends the album on a high note. â€” Sima Shakeri
Caroline Polachek: Fly to You (feat. Grimes and Dido)
Like many art-pop fans, I was immediately intrigued to see that Caroline Polachekâ€™s (very, very good) new album, â€œDesire, I Want to Turn Into You,â€ included a track featuring my problematic fave (Grimes) and the extremely unproblematic British singer Dido. More often than not, these seemingly random collaborations fall flat, but oh boy, â€œFly to Youâ€ is an instant classic.
Trading verses, Polachek, Grimes and Dido each bring a distinct flavour to the songâ€™s simple melody, the ambling serenity of their voices thrown into relief by the presence of a somehow understated drum and bass breakbeat. â€œOoh, I fly to you / After all the tears, youâ€™re all I need,â€ Polachek sings on the climactic chorus, her vocals weaving among Grimesâ€™s robotic intonations.
Itâ€™s a bizarre, immediately arresting track, one that offers testimony of pop musicâ€™s limitless bounds. â€” RA
Sima Shakeri is a digital producer at the Toronto Star.
