title: Midweek U.K. Chart: Lana Del Rey Leads With â€˜Ocean Blvdâ€™
content:
Lana Del Rey doesnâ€™t need to take the tunnel, sheâ€™s on a direct path to the U.K. No. 1.
The alternative pop artist leads the midweek U.K. chart with Did you know that thereâ€™s a tunnel under Ocean Blvd (via Polydor), her ninth studio album.
If it holds its course, Ocean Blvd will give Del Rey her sixth U.K. chart crown in just over a decade, a list that includes Born to Die (2012), Ultraviolence (2014), Lust for Life (2017), Norman F*cking Rockwell! (2019) and Chemtrails Over the Country Club (2021).
Lanaâ€™s latest leads an all-new top 5 on the Official Chart Update, which sees Depeche Mode and Fall Out Boy set to snag podium spots.
DMâ€™s Memento Mori (Columbia), the Rock Hall-inducted synth-pop legendsâ€™ first album since the death last year of bandmember Andy Fletcher, is on track for a No. 2 debut, the bandâ€™s highest position on the U.K. chart in 10 years. Dave Gahan and Co. have raked-in 17 top 10 appearances on the U.K albums survey, most recently with 2017â€™s Spirit (No. 5).
Reunited U.S. pop-rock act Fall Out Boy is eyeing a fifth U.K. top 10 finish, with So Much (for) Stardust (Parlophone) debuting at No. 3 on the chart blast.
Pink Floyd could return to the top 5 with a live version of the prog-rock legendsâ€™ iconic album Dark Side of the Moon, which this year celebrates its 50th anniversary. The Dark Side of the Moon â€“ Live At Wembley 1974 (via Parlophone) forms part of a special anniversary collection, which includes a boxed set of Dark Side, which has chalked-up 557 weeks on the Official U.K. Albums Chart (and counting) but remarkably has never hit No. 1. Its peak position is No. 2, though Floyd has led the chart with six titles.
Completing the top five on the midweek survey is U.S. country star Luke Combsâ€™ Gettinâ€™ Old (Sony Music CG), at No. 5. Itâ€™s on course to become Combsâ€™ highest charting LP in the U.K.
Further down the list, Japanese rock act BABYMETAL is heading for a first U.K. top 10 appearance with The Other One (Cooking Vinyl), new at No. 7 on the midweek survey, while Georgian/British singer and songwriter Katie Melua could bag a ninth U.K. top 10 with Love & Money (BMG), set to debut at No. 10.
All will be revealed when the Official U.K. Albums Chart is published Friday, March 31.

title: Hundreds Flock To Long Beach To Celebrate Lana Del Rey's New Album
content:
Arts & Entertainment Hundreds Flock To Long Beach To Celebrate Lana Del Rey's New Album The city was overrun with hundreds of the singer's fans over the weekend as they enjoyed many themed events relating to her new album. Reply
A themed pop-up shop inspired by Lana Del Rey's newest album "Did you know that there's a tunnel under Ocean Blvd" attracted hundreds of the singer's fans to Long Beach over the weekend. (Rachel Barnes/Patch)
LONG BEACH, CA â€” Long Beach was overrun with hundreds of Lana Del Rey fans over the weekend as they celebrated the release of the artist's new album "Did you know that there's a tunnel under Ocean Blvd" with various pop-up activities throughout the city.
Fans traveled from all over to participate in events such as an album listening party at Fingerprints Music on 4th Street and a three-day pop-up shop at Shoreline Aquatic Park next to the Aquarium of the Pacific. Rumors ran rampant with many fans speculating that Del Rey would make an appearance at either event. Speculation grew pretty loud causing officials at Fingerprints to issue a statement confirming the singer was not going to be at the music shop's official listening party.
"First, and foremost, Lana Del Rey will NOT be at this event. Just like all 80 of the other events for this release, itâ€™s a LISTENING PARTY for the new album," Fingerprints said in the statement. "... this is NOT, and has NEVER been, a 'Live With Lana' event." Despite the minor letdown of not getting to meet their idol, fans still flocked to Long Beach for the opportunity to spend time together and be immersed in the new album. On all three days of the pop-up shop, fans began lining up in the early hours of the morning to ensure they got their hands on some exclusive merch.
The shop sold shirts, mugs, vinyl records, jewelry and other items that couldn't be purchased anywhere else. Many embarked on long journeys to essentially stand in hours-long lines each day at the pop-up shop that was scheduled to open at 11 a.m. each day but consistently opened up later.
"It took two hours to get here, we woke up a little early but it was kind of spontaneous too," one fan at the pop-up shop told Patch. "It was worth it, listening to the new album as we drove on the PCH." Though the level of excitement was high, some fans had less-than-ideal experiences and they waited in lines with some reporting that they got sunburnt and merch selling out extremely quickly, leaving only a few options for fans to choose from.

title: Lana Del Rey Has Come to Confess
content:
Photo: Lana Del Rey/Universal Music
Lana Del Rey is a colorful study in contrasts: Sheâ€™s a quintessentially West Coast presence who spent her formative years in Lake Placid, a Catholic-school kid who blossomed into a songwriter with a flair for the salacious and the macabre, and a pop star whose work evokes not sunny seaside shindigs but harrowing, deadening inertia. Lana is not your chipper, reserved celebrity, either â€” the kind whose gift for avoiding controversy and unpleasantness should be studied in a lab. In December, she shared photos of a billboard announcing her ninth album, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, on her private Instagram account. â€œThereâ€™s only one and itâ€™s in Tulsa,â€ the caption explained. Her ex, police officer Sean Larkin, lives there. But Ocean Blvd isnâ€™t a breakup record. Itâ€™s about healing, opening a new chapter in the oeuvre of an artist who fixates on troubles hiding in plain sight, and the fears and sorrows swirling behind our public masks of contentment. Where past releases pulled you into a world of cinematic ennui and seedy Americana, offering the thrill of a sightseeing tour of Hollywood horrors, this one pierces the enshrouding darkness, seeking solace from pain through companionship and spirituality.
Each Lana Del Rey album is a travelogue of sorts, a constellation of geographical spots where something impactful or unfortunate happened. The Nebraska haze depicted in 2021â€™s â€œNot All Who Wander Are Lost,â€ the New York thatâ€™s pined for in 2019â€™s â€œThe Greatest,â€ the Miami lights gleaming in 2015â€™s â€œSalvatore,â€ and the Las Vegas chaos documented in 2012â€™s â€œOff to the Racesâ€ push back against a litany of reference points in and around Los Angeles, implying a love-hate relationship with the whole of the San Fernando Valley, a story of opposing urges to escape the city and to later come booming back. Ocean Blvd is steeped largely in West Coast lore â€” the Beverly Center, the Ramada by Rosemead, and John Lennon and Harry Nilssonâ€™s lost-weekend artifact Pussy Cats come up, to say nothing of the shuttered beach thoroughfare the new albumâ€™s title recalls â€” but whatâ€™s mapped out in the sharpest detail are the songwriterâ€™s greatest fears and the sources of strength that keep them at bay. Opener â€œThe Grantsâ€ cuts to the quick of the core concerns here: â€œMy pastor told me / When you leave / All you take is your memory.â€ Backed by a choir, Lana promises to carry her love for her niece and grandmother to the afterlife. The balance of religion, Disney orchestration, and family are key themes throughout Ocean Blvd, where petty mortal worries get burned for kindling piece by piece.
It seems important to Lana to express that she is cutting a noisy path to a quieter life, figuring things out as she goes. â€œSweetâ€ pauses during a hookup to muse about the fleeting nature of the connection â€” â€œLately weâ€™ve been making out a lot, not talking about the stuff thatâ€™s at the very heart of thingsâ€ â€” before resolving to continue to embrace nothingness together. â€œA&Wâ€ suggests that enlightenment involves both knowing yourself and freeing yourself from other peopleâ€™s lofty standards. â€œIâ€™m a princess, Iâ€™m divisive,â€ Lana sings. â€œMaybe Iâ€™m just kinda like this.â€ The verses flip the bird at her detractors while the chorus visits hotel romps that further express that sheâ€™s unfazed by years of having every move nitpicked. The seven-minute song is an astute balancing act split almost down the middle between hushed folk and chilly trap â€” a reminder that she can do acoustic tunes like â€œNorman Fucking Rockwellâ€ and â€œVideo Gamesâ€ and beat-oriented pop songs like â€œSummer Bummerâ€ and â€œLust for Life.â€ â€œA&Wâ€ is poking holes in the old myths about desirability, laughing at the lie that itâ€™s all downhill for us after 30 and the notion that yearning for a physical connection means she needs a man, since heâ€™s the one looking to fill a void in his life.
Ocean Blvd really gets strange in the following track, â€œJudah Smith Interlude,â€ in which the controversial Churchome pastor whose services Lana visits from time to time delivers a sermon about the uselessness of chasing nice things. (It sounds like she snuck a portable recorder into a service. You hear commentary from women both absorbing and chuckling at the celebrity preacherâ€™s charismatic, if surreal, dispatches: â€œI woke up this morning, and God said, â€˜Check the Bible app.â€™â€ â€œAt some point tonight before you go to bed, go, â€˜Yo, Elohim,â€™ and heâ€™ll hear. â€˜Youâ€™re the best artist ever.â€™â€) Ocean Blvd delights in these dualities â€” in the chain hotel in the affluent neighborhood, in trap beats rolling into sad folk songs like sunlight burning through clouds, in following the self-deprecating poise of â€œFishtailâ€ (â€œIâ€™m not that smart, but Iâ€™ve got things to sayâ€) with the boasts in the surf-rap Tommy Genesis collab â€œPeppersâ€ (â€œMe and my boyfriend listen to the Chili Peppers / We write hit songs without trying, like / All the time, all the timeâ€), and in the pastor denouncing lust after the singer has darkly intoned, â€œThis is what it feels like to be an American whore.â€
The work past Lana albums have put into prodding American pop culture is turned inward as Ocean Blvd gets free from the carnal concerns of â€œSweet,â€ â€œA&W,â€ and â€œCandy Necklaceâ€ and dives into musings on grief, mortality, and coping mechanisms backed by little more than shimmering swells of strings, guitars, and pianos. In the middle of the album, the chilling â€œKintsugi,â€ â€œFingertips,â€ and â€œParis, Texasâ€ face tragedy with shattering candor. The first song opens with a pang of guilt about being unavailable during a series of family emergencies, then picks apart the way Lana processes painful experiences (â€œIâ€™m in the mountains / Iâ€™m probably running away from the feelingsâ€) before arriving at grizzled optimism gleaned from Japanese pottery repair. â€œFingertipsâ€ expresses how the anxieties about mortality voiced in â€œKintsugiâ€ extend to her loved ones: â€œCharlie, stop smoking / Caroline, will you be with me? / Will the baby be all right?â€ â€œParis, Texasâ€ name-checks the classic Wim Wenders road flick and reworks folk-pop singer-songwriter SYMLâ€™s 2020 moody instrumental â€œI Wanted to Leaveâ€ as Lana sings about heeding the urge to make a run for it and how it abates the loneliness waiting back at home: â€œI had to leave / Knew they wouldnâ€™t understand.â€
Draped in acoustic instruments reverberating with a churchlike echo, these admissions, coupled with lines about suicidal ideations in â€œCandy Necklaceâ€ and â€œMargaret,â€ feel like confessions. Sheâ€™s systematically letting go of her darkest inklings and least inspiring acquaintances, closing ranks and ditching excess baggage, nourishing her mind and soul while having second thoughts about what her body craves. (â€œThis music is about thought processing,â€ Lana told Billboard this year. â€œIâ€™m definitely living from the neck up.â€) Stripping down arrangements and getting unnervingly diaristic about pain puts the spotlight on the pen and not the stickiness of the grooves. Ocean Blvd manages a smoother blend of delicate pop and hip-hop accents over plush folk than the too-slick Born to Die and the sometimes delightfully zany Blue Banisters.
Ocean Blvdâ€™s cleverest inversion is turning all of this sorrow into a message of hope. Lanaâ€™s one of our most successful writers of breakup songs, because the best ones suspend us in moments of totalizing angst like still lifes of houses in disrepair. This albumâ€™s doing something else, suggesting that all that moroseness is temporary, and, as â€œKintsugiâ€ advises, cracks in our veneer create spaces for light to take hold. Near the end of the album, â€œMargaretâ€ flips the â€œWhen you know, you knowâ€ refrain â€œParis, Texasâ€ uses to cover the motives for skipping out on places and people, instead underscoring a promise that itâ€™s okay to feel lost and confused and to weave through a jagged, arduous path toward maturity: â€œIf you donâ€™t know, donâ€™t give up / â€™Cause you never know what the new day might bring / Maybe youâ€™ll know tomorrow.â€
These remembrances of relatives and anxiety spirals about what the future holds are really about making sure we leave something of substance behind when weâ€™re gone. The curiosity in â€œKintsugiâ€ about whether anyone will remember Lanaâ€™s music the way the teen in the third verse knows Scottish folks songs, the fixation on memory in â€œThe Grants,â€ the cosmic concerns that come up briefly in â€œSweet,â€ the Churchome sermon, and the dilapidated tunnel the albumâ€™s named after are all circling the same question: What are you doing that will resonate after youâ€™re gone, whom will it resonate for, and how are you rewiring your life to make sure your time goes to them, not to whatever bullshit is said behind your back or whomever you yearn for who doesnâ€™t feel the same way? You donâ€™t have to know now. Ocean Blvd makes that clear. Lana Del Rey is right there with you looking for an answer.

title: Lana-Land: â€Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€œ von Lana Del Rey
content:
Auf ihrer neunten Platte zitiert Lana Del Rey hemmungslos sich selbst. Trotzdem klingt sie darauf so, wie sie nie zuvor klang. Wie macht sie das bloÃŸ?
Nie zuvor klang Lana Del Rey so luftig, dunstig und dabei doch labyrinthisch, wie auf ihrer neunten Langspielplatte mit dem verwegenen Titel â€Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€œ. Schon die (inszenierte?) A-cappella-Gospel-Folk-Chorprobe im Opener gibt die Stimmung vor: Die Platte wirkt im besten Sinne spontan, oft so, als wÃ¼rde Lana Del Rey vÃ¶llig losgelÃ¶st von popprÃ¤gnanten Strophen-Bridge-Refrain-Strukturen in einem Open-Mic-Keller losjammen und losjammern; nur ist halt zufÃ¤llig ein Kammerorchester dabei, manchmal.
Es ist eine Entwicklung weg von den groÃŸartigen, aber doch auch sehr mÃ¼hevoll polierten Vorzeigeballaden aus dem gefeierten â€Norman Fucking Rockwell!â€œ (2019). Ein Weg, den Lana Del Rey schon auf â€Blue Banistersâ€œ (2021) vorzeichnete â€“ und den sie nun konsequent weitergeht. Aber doch mit UnerhÃ¶rtem.
Lana Del Rey, die Americana-Collagen-KÃ¼nstlerin, vor der schon seit Langem kein Song, keine Referenz links oder rechts des Laurel Canyons sicher ist, zitiert so exzessiv wie nie ihr eigenes Material: Lana Del Rey â€remixtâ€œ ihr eigenes Material auf eine Weise, die man bislang nicht von ihr kannte. Das ist auch eine Abkehr vom zur Schau gestellten Amerika-Patriotismus hin zu einer familiÃ¤reren Innenschau: Sie singt Ã¼ber ihre Familie statt Ã¼ber ihr Heimatland. Schon das ErÃ¶ffnungslied â€The Grantsâ€œ verweist auf ihren Familiennamen: Grant.
â€A&Wâ€œ fÃ¼hrt die Sounds aller Lana-Schaffensphasen zusammen. Somit ist auch der Boombap der frÃ¼hen â€Born To Dieâ€œ-Pop-Jahre wieder da, aber diesmal psychedelisch verwoben mit der reiferen Joni-Mitchell-Lana. Das finale â€Taco Truck x VBâ€œ bedient sich schamlos an ihrer eigenen â€Venice Bitchâ€œ von 2019. Lana ist nicht mehr sicher vor Lana. Im Grunde ist es formal-musikalisch die Message, die sich in ihren Texten seit jeher ausdrÃ¼ckte: das Manifest einer Frau, die ihre â€SchwÃ¤chenâ€œ (Drogen, harte MÃ¤nner, feiner Glamour, Depressionen) zelebriert wie keine zweite zurzeit.
Lana Del Rey: â€Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€œ (Interscope/Universal)

title: Lana Del Rey si racconta pensando alla maternitÃ
content:
Per Lana Del Rey questo Ã¨ un disco importante, che marca un passaggio importante nella carriera della cantautrice newyorchese. Co-prodotto dallâ€™artista assieme a Mike Hermosa, Jack Antonoff, Drew Erickson, Zach Dawes, Benji, include le collaborazioni con Jon Batiste, Bleachers, Father John Misty, Judah Smith, Tommy Genesis e SYML. Il tunnel del titolo esiste veramente, si tratta del Jergins Tunnel, a Long Beach. Ora abbandonato dopo la chiusura negli Anni 60, con le sue piastrelle bianche e i mosaici beige, era un sottopasso che permetteva ai turisti di accedere alla spiaggia ed era popolato da venditori di souvenir e zucchero filato. Per Lana Del Rey Ã¨ diventato una metafora del suo mondo affettivo: "Come sarebbe rimanere chiusi lÃ¬ dentro, con tutte quelle belle cose, senza che nessuno possa entrare, eccetto forse la tua famiglia?" dice lei.
Un disco ampio e variegato Un progetto caratterizzato da morbidezze jazz, canzoni classiche al pianoforte, sfumature gospel, suoni acustici e perfino sonoritÃ  hip-hop che si esprimono nell'arco di ben sedici brani e quasi un'ora e venti di musica. In una recente intervista dellâ€™artista rilasciata all'edizione inglese di "Rolling Stone" Ã¨ interventuo anche Jack Antonoff, che ha prodotto diversi brani allâ€™interno del disco. "Lana non ha confini. Nel suo lavoro Ã¨ arrivata a un tale punto, che poi Ã¨ il mio preferito per lavorare, in cui non puÃ² avventurarsi in alcun posto che non sia la cazzo di natura artistica piÃ¹ selvaggia - ha detto a proposito del suo lavoro con l'artista -. Andare a caccia di ascolti radiofonici? Sarebbe una stupidaggine. Correre dietro alle mode? Che sciocchezza. Le tendenze le ha create lei. Ãˆ una posizione liberatoria, se lâ€™accetti. Non ti resta che essere una leader".
Canzoni che arrivano dai suoi legami affettivi "Did You Know That There's A Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd" Ã¨ un album in cui Lana Del Rey mette in scena il suo mondo familiare e affettivo, non solo citando direttamente parenti stretti, ma facendo entrare nei testi anche pezzi di conversazioni con le amiche. C'Ã¨ poi il tema della maternitÃ , che torna piÃ¹ volte all'interno del disco. "Il bambino starÃ  bene? / Ne avrÃ² uno mio? / RiuscirÃ² a gestirlo anche se lo avrÃ²" si interroga nel brano orchestrale "Fingertips".
La copertina in topless scartata Qualche mese fa la Del Rey aveva postato nella sua pagina Instagram privata (aperta ai primi due milioni di fan che sono riusciti a collegarsi e poi chiusa) le immagini per diverse cover alternative dell'album. Una di queste fotografie per la copertina la ritraeva in topless. Alla fine perÃ² la cantautrice ha deciso di scartare quell'immagine e ha spiegato il perchÃ© nel corso di una conversazione con Billie Eilish. "La copertina del disco originale era uno scatto di me nuda, poi ci ho riflettuto e ho pensato che forse non era il momento, perchÃ© ci sono altre cose a cui voglio dare precedenza - ha detto Lana -. L'idea alla base era di rivelare qualcosa di me stessa che pensavo fosse davvero bello, ma alla fine, mi sono innervosita all'idea di presentarla perchÃ© mi chiedevo se fosse una reale ispirazione artistica o una reazione a qualcosa che avverto come critico nei miei confronti? Non so se uscirÃ  mai, ma se la pubblicherÃ², vorrei solo assicurarmi che sia qualcosa di super divertente e non figlia della necessitÃ  di mostrare qualcosa alla gente".

title: Lana Del Reys neues Album: Lass doch mal das Licht ins Leben
content:
Bei Lana Del Rey wird das KÃ¼nstlertum demonstrativ herausgehÃ¤ngt. Ihr neues Album heiÃŸt â€Did You Know That Thereâ€™s A Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€œ und darauf dÃ¼rfen wir sogar einer Predigt ihres Celebrity-Pastors lauschen. Nur was gibt es dabei zu lachen?
Anzeige
Lana Del Rey schreibt keine Hits mehr, sie macht Platten, und â€Did You Know That Thereâ€™s A Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€œ (Universal) ist die ruhigste LP seit Langem. Viele der Songs haben keine Hookline, es bleibt nicht sofort etwas hÃ¤ngen an der Songwriter-Angel, eher hat man das GefÃ¼hl, ihr beim Fliegenfischen zuzusehen, was ja vor allem meditativen Zwecken dient.
Anzeige
In â€Tunnelâ€œ wÃ¤hnt sich der HÃ¶rer oft in einem leeren, dunklen Saal, der nur hier und da von Kerzen erhellt wird und in dem Lana Del Rey vor dem Mikrofon seufzt. Die Instrumentierung ist spÃ¤rlich, die Streicher bleiben im Hintergrund, nur sehr selten pumpt ein Beat.
Lesen Sie auch Meinung Herbert GrÃ¶nemeyer In der Zwangsjacke des Zweifels
Es ist das neunte Album der 1985 als Elizabeth Woolridge Grant geborenen Singer-Songwriterin. Zusammengearbeitet hat sie nach einer Pause beim VorgÃ¤ngeralbum â€Blue Bannistersâ€œ wieder mit ihrem bewÃ¤hrten Produzenten Jack Antonoff. Drei der 16 Songs waren vorab verÃ¶ffentlicht worden, zuletzt â€The Grantsâ€œ.
Anzeige
Die Ã¼brigen nach einmaligem VorabhÃ¶ren zu bewerten ist gar nicht leicht, denn Lana Del Reys Musik wirkt, Ã¤hnlich wie manche Medikamente, erst nach regelmÃ¤ÃŸiger Einnahme. Sanft schaben sich die melancholischen Kadenzen ins Gehirn, wieder und wieder singt sie dieselben Zeilen, und ein paar merkt man sich dann doch gleich. â€I met my boyfriend down at the Taco truckâ€œ zum Beispiel, oder das â€Uuhhhh, let the light in / Uuhhh, turn your light onâ€œ im Song, den sie mit Father John Misty aufgenommen hat und der von einer Amour fou erzÃ¤hlt.
Lesen Sie auch â€Memento Moriâ€œ Depeche Mode und ihre letzten Lieder
Dieser zwÃ¶lfte Track ist ein kleiner Kracher, vielleicht auch ein groÃŸer. Danach wird es seltsam. Wenn man etwa ihrem Pastor Judah Smith beim Reden zuhÃ¶rt (derselbe Celebrity-Priester, auf den auch Justin Bieber schwÃ¶rt und der fÃ¼r seine mitreiÃŸenden Predigten bekannt ist): Warum lacht sie dabei? Oder lacht eine andere Frau? Worum geht es in dieser Predigt? Und wer soll sich das viereinhalb Minuten lang anhÃ¶ren mitten auf der neuen Platte eines Mega-Popacts?
Das KÃ¼nstlertum wird offenbar umso demonstrativer herausgehÃ¤ngt, je mehr sich LDR mit denselben Menschen umgibt, in einer kleinen, aber sehr produktiven Blase. So schrieb sie fÃ¼nf der Songs gemeinsam mit ihrem Ex-Freund Mike Hermosa.
Anzeige
Eine Gute-Laune-Platte ist es nicht, wirklich tieftraurig ist der Song â€Kintsugiâ€œ, benannt nach der japanische Kunst des Reparierens. LDR kann aber auch lustig sein. â€If you want a basic bitch, go to Beverly Hillsâ€œ heiÃŸt es in â€Sweetâ€œ oder so Ã¤hnlich. Wir wissen es nicht so genau, die Plattenfirma hat noch keine Lyrics geschickt. Apropos Bitch. Die SÃ¤ngerin lieÃŸ ein einziges Album-Billboard in Tulsa (Oklahoma) anbringen, weil dort ihr Ex herkommt, der Polizist Sean Larkin â€“ die AnkÃ¼ndigung des Albums fiel auf seinen Geburtstag.
Lesen Sie auch â€Tempoâ€œ Das Magazin, das sich traute, was heute kein Journalist mehr wagt
â€Itâ€™s something personalâ€œ, kommentierte sie diese Mikrokampagne auf Instagram. Of course it is. An â€Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€œ ist alles persÃ¶nlich. Manchmal vielleicht ein wenig zu sehr. Aber dann eignet sich das Album immer noch fÃ¼r das, wofÃ¼r Lana-Alben jenseits des Abspielens von Einzelhits meistens verwendet werden: als Klangtapete unseres eigenen, dann ja leider doch nicht so dramatischen Lebens.

title: CrÃ­tica: Novo disco de Lana Del Rey confronta sua famÃ­lia
content:
Did You Know Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd Quando DisponÃ­vel nas plataformas de streaming
DisponÃ­vel nas plataformas de streaming Autor Lana Del Rey
Lana Del Rey Gravadora Universal
Os fÃ£s de Lana Del Rey podem respirar aliviados com o lanÃ§amento de seu nono Ã¡lbum, "Did You Know Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd", pois nÃ£o falta nele nenhum dos elementos que a cantora e compositora vinha trabalhando ao longo de toda a sua carreira.
Nos deparamos com a paisagem californiana, Ã­cones decadentes da cultura americana, momentos depressivos, confissÃµes Ã­ntimas, relaÃ§Ãµes familiares e diversas citaÃ§Ãµes, tanto a outros artistas, quanto autorreferÃªncias a suas mÃºsicas de Ã¡lbuns anteriores.
Capa do Ã¡lbum 'Did You Know That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd', de Lana Del Rey - DivulgaÃ§Ã£o
O disco tem, na maior parte do tempo, uma atmosfera sombria e instrumental minimalista. A primeira faixa, "The Grants", que estampa o sobrenome paterno da famÃ­lia de Lana Del Rey, comeÃ§a com um coral gospel, ao qual se segue um clima tenso criado pela combinaÃ§Ã£o entre piano e cordas.
Nessa primeira mÃºsica, logo de cara a cantora invoca John Denver e sua "Rocky Mountain High", mas ainda abordando a religiÃ£o. O tema se repete no primeiro interlÃºdio que compÃµe o Ã¡lbum, um sermÃ£o do pastor Judah Smith â€”celebridade religiosa dos Estados Unidos, que inclusive gravou, tambÃ©m, com Justin Bieber em "Freedom", em 2021.
Mas, por mais sÃ©rio que pareÃ§a a entrada do interlÃºdio, enquanto ouvimos o que a BÃ­blia tem a nos dizer, hÃ¡ inserÃ§Ãµes de fundo com conversas e risadas nÃ£o muito sutis.
O sermÃ£o vem apÃ³s uma das melhores faixas do disco, jÃ¡ divulgada como single em fevereiro deste ano, "A&W" â€”sigla para a expressÃ£o "American whore", ou prostituta americana, termo aplicado de maneira pejorativa Ã s mulheres que se permitem liberdade sexual em uma sociedade cada dia mais conservadora.
A canÃ§Ã£o Ã© uma clara crÃ­tica Ã  misoginia e Ã  chamada cultura do estupro. Ã‰ a mÃºsica mais longa do Ã¡lbum, com mais de sete minutos, e se divide em duas partes. A primeira, com voz e um piano predominante, e na segunda, o clima muda com a entrada de bases eletrÃ´nicas. A faixa foi produzida Jack Antonoff, antigo parceiro e amigo de longa data da cantora.
AliÃ¡s, a relaÃ§Ã£o de Del Rey e Antonoff segue tÃ£o estreita que ela dedica uma das faixas Ã  noiva do produtor, em "Margaret". Talvez a mÃºsica seja uma espÃ©cie de presente de casamento, que tem a data revelada na letra â€”o que intimamente pode atÃ© ser uma homenagem sensÃ­vel, mas destoa do restante da obra.
Dentre as participaÃ§Ãµes, hÃ¡ Jon Batiste, em "Candy Necklace", que, alÃ©m de dividir os vocais na faixa, compÃµe o segundo interlÃºdio do Ã¡lbum logo em seguida. Outro destaque Ã© John Father Misty em "Let the Light In", um indie folk bem ao estilo do artista, guiado sobretudo pelo violÃ£o. Participam do Ã¡lbum tambÃ©m a banda SYLM e o pianista Riopy.
Mas o que mais chama a atenÃ§Ã£o em "Did You Know Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd" Ã© como Lana Del Rey apresenta a relaÃ§Ã£o com sua famÃ­lia. HÃ¡ tempos suas composiÃ§Ãµes deixam claro a relaÃ§Ã£o de desentendimento com a mÃ£e.
Em "Fingertips" ela canta como se estivesse lendo seu diÃ¡rio ou conversando diretamente com o irmÃ£o, a irmÃ£ e o pai. A mÃºsica soa como uma crÃ´nica de desabafo e nÃ£o traz nenhum refrÃ£o. AlÃ©m disso, ela toca em um tema bastante sensÃ­vel a ela, a maternidade.
Depois de perguntar Ã  irmÃ£ Caroline, que jÃ¡ Ã© mÃ£e, se o bebÃª ficarÃ¡ bem, ela pergunta "eu vou ter um eu mesma?". "Eu vou conseguir lidar com isso, se eu tiver?", acrescenta, se referindo ao seu diagnÃ³stico de depressÃ£o.
Em "Kintsugi", ela descreve o episÃ³dio da morte de um tio e sua tristeza ao saber da notÃ­cia enquanto estava em turnÃª. Del Rey se refere diversas vezes nÃ£o sÃ³ ao pai e aos irmÃ£os, mas tambÃ©m aos avÃ³s. Com o tÃ­tulo em japonÃªs, ela utiliza a tÃ©cnica milenar de reparo de cerÃ¢mica como metÃ¡fora para a dor do luto e sua superaÃ§Ã£o.
AliÃ¡s, a faixa-tÃ­tulo do Ã¡lbum tambÃ©m Ã© uma espÃ©cie de metÃ¡fora, em que Del Rey se refere a um espaÃ§o fechado e abandonado, o tÃºnel Jergins em Long Beach, nos Estados Unidos, para pensar sobre sua trajetÃ³ria, carreira e uma recente relaÃ§Ã£o amorosa.
Lana Del Rey conseguiu mais uma vez criar, ou reforÃ§ar, um universo criativo e estÃ©tico muito prÃ³prio, usando samples e autorreferÃªncias para botar o novo disco de pÃ© de maneira cuidadosamente trabalhada e nÃ£o simplesmente como um processo impensado de colagens.

title: Ed Sheeran, Lana Del Rey & More: Favorite New Music Poll
content:
Spring has officially sprung, and with it comes the arrival of new music from multiple artists on the first new music Friday of the season. Among them are brand new tracks and albums from Ed Sheeran, Lana Del Rey, Luke Combs and more.
Sheeran offers a preliminary look at Subtract, the final installment of his mathematics album series, with new track â€œEyes Closed.â€ The song serves as a tribute to his late best friend, Jamal Edwards, who died suddenly from a heart attack, and offers a potent message of mourning after an unexpected loss. the British pop star worked with Aaron Dessner for the production, which combines Sheeranâ€™s calling cards â€” acoustic guitar, sparse drum beats and memorable hooks â€” with whirring arrangements, making for a radio-friendly track, regardless of its sad subject matter.
Del Reyâ€™s ninth album, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, also arrived on Friday. In the set, she muses on sex, devotion, family and American decay, but this time, with a series of guests providing an assist â€” Tommy Genesis, Jon Batiste and Bleachers to name just a few â€” showing that once again, sheâ€™s trying to challenge herself in ways she previously hasnâ€™t. (Read a full review and tracks ranking of Lana Del Reyâ€™s latest album here.)
The follow-up to Luke Combsâ€™ Growinâ€™ Up, the aptly titled Gettinâ€™ Old, sees the country star further honing in on his songwriting skills, reflecting peacefully on his hometown, his career beginnings and the unfurling of a promising romance.
BTSâ€™ Jimin, RosalÃ­a with Rauw Alejandro, and Fall Out Boy also return with new music. Which new release is your favorite? Vote in our poll below.

title: Review: Lana Del Rey's 'Ocean Blvd' is an intimate epic
content:
This image released by Interscope shows "Did You Know That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd" by Lana Del Rey. (Interscope via AP)
This image released by Interscope shows "Did You Know That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd" by Lana Del Rey. (Interscope via AP)
â€œDid You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd,â€ by Lana Del Rey (Interscope Records)
Lana Del Rey is a complicated, enigmatic pop star â€” since the height of her breakout album, â€œBorn to Die,â€ the singer has been labeled one of the best songwriters of her generation. Her songs tell stories of dark, wistful American glamour, yearning for a dangerous time in our history with glimmers of red-hot, toxic infidelity-riddled romances and an audaciously psychedelic allure.
â€œDid You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€ is the next mega storytelling adventure for the singer-songwriter â€” she cuts deep into her fears, future and family instead of longing for things that arenâ€™t hers to dream about. This time, sheâ€™s enduring the human experience in the real world â€” not a pretend one.
The lengthy, 16-song album explores themes of spirituality with religious undertones featuring gospel singers in â€œThe Grantsâ€ and an interlude with Pastor Judah Smith, the leader of a controversial celebrity megachurch, Churchome. She also features Grammy award-winning uber talent Jon Batiste on â€œCandy Necklaceâ€ and â€œJon Batiste Interlude,â€ producer-musician and Del Reyâ€™s most frequent collaborator, Jack Antonoff, as his moniker Bleachers, and Father John Misty (â€œLet The Light Inâ€).
ADVERTISEMENT
Del Rey sings melancholically about her impermanence in the albumâ€™s title track, â€œDonâ€™t forget me/Like the tunnel under Ocean Boulevard.â€ On another album single, â€œA&W,â€ co-written and produced by Antonoff, the singer gorgeously speaks to the experience of a liberated woman who wears a metaphorical scarlet letter on her chest. She examines the paradox of liberation and the condemnation sexually liberated women face as the result of their agency.
â€œFingertips,â€ allows Del Rey to slowly ponder in a dreamy, strings-heavy ballad about her family, death and legacy: â€œWill I die? Or will I get to that 10-year mark?/Where I beat the extinction of telomeres?/And if I do, will you be there with me, Father, Sister, Brother?â€
â€œParis, Texas,â€ featuring SYML, feels and sounds like a lullaby, Del Rey whispering about wanderlust, scouring the world for a place to call home. â€œWhen youâ€™re home, youâ€™re home (Venice, California),â€ she sings in her breathy vocals.
ADVERTISEMENT
â€œGrandfather please stand on the shoulders of my father while heâ€™s deep-sea fishing,â€ is another fairytale-like ballad that dissects Del Reyâ€™s public image and legacy. She opens the profound song with the lyrics, â€œI know they think that it took somebody else/To make me beautiful, beautiful/As they intended me to be/But theyâ€™re wrong.â€
Other brights spots include â€œMargaretâ€ featuring Bleachers â€” it is simply a larger-than-life love song about fated true love written for Antonoff about his relationship with actress Margaret Qualley. In a typical Antonoff and Del Rey production, the song is still and stripped back until it waits for a burst of bells and trumpets in the outro.
The wandering hour-long album closes with â€œTaco Truck x VBâ€ a dark ballad that transitions to a trap-ified sample of â€œVenice B(asterisk)(asterisk)(asterisk)(asterisk),â€ one of Del Reyâ€™s songs from her hit album â€œNorman F(asterisk)(asterisk)(asterisk)(asterisk)(asterisk)(asterisk) Rockwell.â€ Sampling her own work shows Del Rey doesnâ€™t have anything to prove in â€œ...Ocean Blvd,â€ sheâ€™s never sounded more succinct and brazenly herself.
___
More AP music reviews: https://apnews.com/hub/music-reviews

content:

title: Lana Del Rey fait la danse des sept voiles sur son nouvel album, "Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd"
content:
Sur son neuviÃ¨me album, la chanteuse amÃ©ricaine Lana Del Rey pousse plus avant le dÃ©voilement de son intimitÃ©, en particulier concernant sa famille, tout en prÃ©servant une fois encore jalousement ses secrets.
Lana Del Rey est une pop star pas comme les autres. Elle nâ€™est pas de celles dont on guette les prochains hits, mais de celles, rares aujourdâ€™hui dans une industrie du single-roi bien calibrÃ©, dont on attend les albums. Parce quâ€™en reine du songwriting, elle nous emmÃ¨ne chaque fois en balade dans les mÃ©andres de ses souvenirs, de ses tourments et de sa psychÃ© dÃ©glinguÃ©e â€“ offrant au passage quelques Ã©lÃ©ments du puzzle de lâ€™AmÃ©rique dâ€™aujourdâ€™hui.
DÃ©voilements intimes
Avec Lana Del Rey, il faut, on lâ€™a appris au fil du temps depuis ses dÃ©buts fulgurants en 2011 avec Video Games, se laisser avant tout embarquer, envoÃ»ter. Mais il faut aussi, au fil des histoires sentimentales impudiques et touchantes qui font le sel de ses chansons, Ã©viter de surinterprÃ©ter les indices personnels, souvent douloureux, quâ€™elle sÃ¨me comme de petits cailloux, ne pas chercher Ã  tout prix Ã  dÃ©mÃªler le vrai du faux pour ne pas lui dÃ©nier le droit au fantasme et Ã  la fiction.
Or cet exercice de distanciation sâ€™avÃ¨re particuliÃ¨rement difficile pour lâ€™auditeur sur son neuviÃ¨me album. La chanteuse se livre en effet plus que jamais, dÃ©voilant une grande part de son intimitÃ© sur Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd. Ses paroles se font plus prÃ©cises, moins allusives, en particulier en ce qui concerne sa famille et son entourage, au cÅ“ur de cet album : elle nomme les personnes, sâ€™adresse Ã  elles directement et donne rÃ©guliÃ¨rement Ã  lâ€™auditeur lâ€™impression de tourner les pages dâ€™un journal intime.
La famille et ses chers disparus, thÃ¨me majeur du disque
DÃ¨s le titre dâ€™ouverture, The Grants, qui se rÃ©fÃ¨re Ã  son vÃ©ritable nom de famille, elle promet dâ€™emmener avec elle "le dernier sourire" de sa grand-mÃ¨re et "le premier-nÃ©" de sa sÅ“ur Caroline. Elle revient sur la mort de sa grand-mÃ¨re rÃ©cemment disparue sur Kintsugi, et Ã©voque celle de son grand-pÃ¨re sur Grandfather Please Stand on the Shoulder of my Father, Ã  qui elle demande de lui envoyer un signe de l'au-delÃ , sous la forme de trois papillons blancs. Dans cette mÃªme chanson, Lana Del Rey rappelle avec amertume les rumeurs dÃ©nonÃ§ant une chanteuse entiÃ¨rement fabriquÃ©e qui ont accompagnÃ© les premiers temps de son avÃ¨nement il y a douze ans.
Pour clouer le bec de ses dÃ©tracteurs et montrer la substance de son vÃ©cu douloureux, il faut se pencher sur le trÃ¨s rÃ©vÃ©lateur Fingertips. Dans cette chanson particuliÃ¨rement riche et poignante, elle interroge son pÃ¨re, sa sÅ“ur et son frÃ¨re (serez-vous lÃ  avec moi ?), avant de rÃ©clamer un mausolÃ©e Ã  Rhode Island oÃ¹ elle reposerait avec son pÃ¨re, ses grands-parents et son oncle Dave "qui sâ€™est pendu" Ã  lâ€™Ã¢ge de 61 ans, Ã  lâ€™Ã©tÃ© 2016. Un deuil visiblement mal Ã©teint : lorsquâ€™elle a appris la nouvelle, Lana Del Rey Ã©tait en tournÃ©e en Europe et devait jouer "devant le prince de Monaco deux heures plus tard", chante-t-elle, et ne sâ€™est accordÃ©e "que deux minutes pour pleurer", "assise dans la douche". Dans cette mÃªme chanson, la plus explicite de lâ€™album, elle sâ€™interroge Ã©galement sur la maternitÃ© : "Aurais-je un enfant ?", "Saurais-je mâ€™en occuper ?", avant, plus loin, dâ€™Ã©voquer lâ€™attitude mal digÃ©rÃ©e de sa propre mÃ¨re, avec laquelle elle est en dÃ©licatesse depuis longtemps.
Au-delÃ  de la famille, il est aussi question de lâ€™entourage. Ainsi, Margaret a Ã©tÃ© Ã©crite pour lâ€™actrice Margaret Qualley, la fiancÃ©e de son producteur et collaborateur Jack Antonoff (qui chante ici sous pseudo Bleachers), dans le but dâ€™Ãªtre Ã©ventuellement jouÃ©e Ã  leur futur mariage. Car sâ€™il y est souvent question de ses chers disparus, mais aussi des tourments sentimentaux auxquels elle nous a habituÃ©s, cet album est globalement apaisÃ© - il y a une lumiÃ¨re au bout de ce tunnel. Lana Del Rey y promÃ¨ne sa mÃ©lancolie et ses interrogations mÃ©taphysiques avec dÃ©licatesse, comme animÃ©e dâ€™une nouvelle philosophie de la vie â€“ "Donâ€™t give up, cause you never know what the new day might bring" ("nâ€™abandonne pas, parce que on ne sait jamais ce que la nouvelle journÃ©e pourrait apporter"), chante-t-elle sur Margaret.
Une audace musicale mesurÃ©e
Musicalement, cet album fait preuve dâ€™une certaine audace, mais moins que ne le laissait augurer le magistral second single A&W sorti Ã  la mi-fÃ©vrier pour la Saint-Valentin. DivisÃ©e en deux parties, avec un dÃ©but folk Ã©voluant de faÃ§on inattendue vers un rythme trap et un phrasÃ© presque rap, cette ballade provocante dans laquelle elle assume sa sexualitÃ© d'amoureuse sans illusion â€“ "Itâ€™s not about havinâ€™ someone to love me anymore / This is the experience of an american whore" - , est une chanson dÃ©jÃ  inscrite au sommet de sa discographie.
Lâ€™album, qui mÃ©lange orchestrations majestueuses et dÃ©pouillement (adorable simplicitÃ© au piano de Paris Texas ou Candy Necklace), incursions gospel, folk et pop, recÃ¨le dâ€™autres petites surprises expÃ©rimentales, en particulier vers la fin de lâ€™album, avec un couplet de la rappeuse canadienne Tommy Genesis (Peppers), et une nouvelle version de Venice Bitch en clÃ´ture (Taco Truck x VB). Sans compter les prouesses vocales joueuses dont elle nous gratifie tout du long.
Ce disque n'a qu'un dÃ©faut : il est long -16 morceaux et plus de 77 minutes - , trop long pour espÃ©rer Ã©galer le sans faute Norman Fucking Rockwell (2019). Pourtant, on serait bien en peine, on lâ€™avoue, de dÃ©terminer ce quâ€™on en aurait Ã´tÃ© de superflu, exceptÃ© le sermon sur la fidÃ©litÃ© de 4 minutes du pasteur controversÃ© Judah Smith. Elle qui chante comme elle respire - "La musique est comme un petit oiseau qui se trouve toujours sur mon Ã©paule", dit-elle - nâ€™a pas su choisir. On referme en tout cas ce journal intime en admirant lâ€™exercice de mise Ã  nu de Lana Del Rey, une danse des sept voiles plus qu'un strip-tease en grand, qui parvient une fois encore Ã  prÃ©server les mystÃ¨res de la vraie Elizabeth Woolridge Grant.
"Did You Know That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd" (Universal) est sorti vendredi 24 mars 2023

title: A release day songs ranking of the new Lana Del Rey album, Ocean Blvd
content:
3 days ago
Before I am a human being, I am a Lana Del Rey fan. Weâ€™re talking the kind of fan who was sneaking off from sixth form early so I could rush to the Manchester Apollo and queue to get to the front off the Paradise tour â€“ a feat which I achieved. It was a spiritual awakening for me, and in the years that followed my stanning has never wavered. Nearly all Lana Del Rey albums are family to me, and with the singles released for her ninth major label LP Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd being so exciting and of such interesting, high quality â€“ my excitement for this album was palpable to say the least. This era has made me feel 16 again. Iâ€™ve listened four times all the way through now, and it is time. Hereâ€™s my release day ranking of all the songs on Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd â€“ the new album by Lana Del Rey.
16. Judah Smith Interlude
Not to start this off miserably, but my GODâ€¦ I hate this.
15. Jon Batiste Interlude
A lot better than the preacher interlude ranked before it, but this one is still a bit too bloody long considering itâ€™s just a bit of a vibe. This album runs at an hour and 17 minutes, and I think almost nine minutes of interlude could be left on the cutting room floor.
14. Sweet
I would like to preface everything that comes next by saying I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s a bad song left to talk about on this album. Everything is beautifully written and eternally special â€“ but Sweet falls short due to its placement between three HEAVY HITTERS. It doesnâ€™t quite hit the same heights.
13. Candy Necklace
ğŸš¨ LANA DEL REY MUSIC VIDEO FOR CANDY NECKLACE IS COMING pic.twitter.com/COvFqYhcu7 â€” LDR Crave (@LDRCRAVE) March 23, 2023
This one seems primed to be the next single if the music video teasers are anything to go by. I love how the chorus vocal and piano melody come together but I do think itâ€™s one of the safer and more filler sounding moments on Ocean Blvd.
12. Kintsugi
Itâ€™s killing me to rank this so low, but its wow factor is just getting outwowed. Lana described this and Fingertips as two songs are a trail of thought rather than songs â€“ and I think Fingertips does it better. I love the metaphor of Kintsugi, the Japanese art of filling smashed plates and bowls with gold to put them back together and create something new and beautiful from the broken.
11. Peppers
In the immortal words of Kelly Rowland, who knew you were doing uptempo owwwww! Sampling a 2015 Tommy Genesis track with lyrics singing of not giving a shite about her fella having Covid because sheâ€™s got it if sheâ€™s been snogging him anyway and a streaming session of the Chilli Peppers, the banger is a nice lighthearted slapper that feels like a Lana we havenâ€™t heard in a while. Summer vibes are here!
Lana Del Rey writing Peppers pic.twitter.com/bs8ofdXimf â€” Luke (@thatLF) March 24, 2023
10. Fishtail
Itâ€™s giving Tulsa Jesus Freak: The Sequel. And thatâ€™s what we ALL needed.
9. Fingertips
Fingertips feels like it was never meant to be heard by us, but thank god Lana Del Rey let us in to a stream of consciousness that exists between her songwriting and her poetry. Itâ€™s messy, wordy, personal, complex and endlessly fascinating. No other artist making music right now could record this.
8. Let The Light In
A fully fledged collaboration between Lana Del Rey and Father John Misty that is so overdue it feels like it happened years ago, when all weâ€™ve had is him in her video and a cover. This duet takes me right back to that cosy Chemtrails sound that I love so much and Iâ€™d be over the moon if the two of them recorded a full duet album together. Wowing.
7. Grandfather please stand on the shoulders of my father while heâ€™s deep-sea fishing
So much of Ocean Blvd is centred on the Grants, and Lana Del Rey reflecting on the legacy of her family â€“ having so much of the album be existential and personal simultaneously makes ranking things so intimate hard, but this song is just beautiful. Sweeping vocals over the top of a sampled piano melody makes any naysayers of the long title shut up once they press play. â€œI know they think that it took somebody else to make me beautifulâ€¦â€
6. Paris, Texas
Me at 12 am listening to Paris, Texas by Lana Del Rey pic.twitter.com/73Sw4fm2jg â€” Antony SalvatierrağŸ«‚ (@Ab_salvatierra) March 24, 2023
Lana fully samples SYMLâ€™s I Wanted To Leave on her geographical tour of locations that share names with big European cities, Paris, Florence and Venice, but are small American towns. The way her vocals roll so lusciously over the piano here is timeless â€“ no wonder itâ€™s been trending on Twitter all day.
5. Margaret
The impact on Lana Del Rey and the way she makes music that Jack Antonoff has had, despite the naysayers who have decided they no longer like him because he works prolifically with a lot of artists and makes great music with them, is unparalleled. Lanaâ€™s pre and post Jack Antonoff career feels like two different artists at times. Margaret, written for Jack and his wife who the song is named after, is the song â€œthat could hypothetically be played at their wedding.â€ To me, it sounds like a gorgeous thank you to a friend she holds dear â€“ and itâ€™s great to hear Jack on vocals after his presence has been in the background since 2019.
This is the kind of song that makes jaded single people like me believe in love again. â€œWhen you know you know.â€
4. Taco Truck x VB
I feel like this song was written with me in mind. Not just because Iâ€™m annoyingly main character, but because it hits every hallmark of the Lana sounds I love. The Ultraviolence-y Taco Truck is all guitar and woozy attitude, it feels like a song Iâ€™m going to be blasting for the rest of my life. And thatâ€™s before we flip to the latter half, the outdo of the album â€“ a trap reworking of Venice Bitch â€“ her 2018 single, the highlight of Norman fucking Rockwell and, in my opinion, the best Lana song of all time.
Thereâ€™s an epicness to Venice Bitch that makes it feel like a closer to a record, and giving it a second life here to finish up her best album since Norman Fucking Rockwell is absolutely sensational. Euphoric. Listening to a new album and having a finale you can sing out loud to like a familiar hug is so special.
3. The Grants
Play
The Grants, and the whole record, starts with a beautiful mistake. Lanaâ€™s backing singers make an error and then correct themselves â€“ and she shoved it at the start of the record. Itâ€™s a very human and honest way to start an album â€“ and one that throws you off with its unexpectedness and then makes you feel comfortable. Ocean Blvd often sounds like youâ€™re with Lana in the studio as she pours her heart into these songs.
The Grants is a reflection on those whoâ€™ve came before â€“ your familyâ€™s legacy and everything that means as we go through our lives Itâ€™s just beautiful. She chose the singles for this album perfectly. Ranking this as one of the most gorgeous Lana Del Rey songs ever, not just out of Ocean Blvd.
2. Did you know that thereâ€™s a tunnel under Ocean Blvd?
The lead single. The title track. The centrepiece of the record.
An instant classic as soon as I heard it. From her little exhale in the opening seconds, you just know youâ€™re in for something special. How it took until album nine to get a chorus with the lyrics â€œOpen me up, tell me you like it, fuck me to death, love me until I love myselfâ€ Iâ€™ll never know.
When the huge backing vocals come in itâ€™s literally over for everyone. A 10/10 stone cold masterpiece. â€œWhenâ€™s it gonna be my turn?â€
1. A&W
Play
I mean this with the highest level of respect, but A&W listens kind of like if Lana Del Rey decided she wanted to do her own version of The Saturdays Megamix. By that I mean its seven minute runtime plays out like youâ€™re listening to a CliffsNotes brief of the entire history of Lana Del Rey, and I am ranking it at the top of Ocean Blvd as an album because itâ€™s a celebration of everything that makes Lana Del Rey special to me. It celebrates the past, the present and pushes her career into somewhere new.
Both halves celebrate everything I love about Lanaâ€™s music. I love that Jack Antonoff said itâ€™s his favourite song he and Lana have ever made together â€“ one listen of this and I knew it would be one of mine too. Instant classic. What an artist, what an album.
Disagree with the ranking of every song on Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd by Lana Del Rey? DM me below for heated Del Rey debate.
@harrisonjbrock
Recommended stories by this writer:

â€¢ Every Lana Del Rey single definitively ranked from worst to best
â€¢ The definitive ranking of every Billie Eilish song, from worst to best

title: Friday Music Guide: Ed Sheeran, Lana Del Rey, Jimin, Luke Combs
content:
Billboardâ€™s Friday Music Guide serves as a handy guide to this weekâ€™s most essential releases â€” the key music that everyone will be talking about today, and that will be dominating playlists this weekend and beyond.
Explore Explore Ed Sheeran See latest videos, charts and news See latest videos, charts and news
This week, Ed Sheeran honors a fallen friend, Lana Del Rey hoists up her ambitions, and Luke Combs ages gracefully. Check out all of this weekâ€™s picks below:
Ed Sheeran, â€œEyes Closedâ€
One year after tragically losing his best friend, Jamal Edwards, to a sudden heart attack, Ed Sheeran has returned with a poignant single that makes his struggle universal and attempts to help any listener mourning a loved one. â€œEyes Closed,â€ which previews the superstarâ€™s affecting new album â€“ (Subtract), combines producer Aaron Dessnerâ€™s knack for subtly whirring arrangements with Sheeranâ€™s gift for delivering a memorable hook; grief is a tricky subject for a top 40 mainstay to address in a non-ballad, but â€œEyes Closedâ€ provides catharsis through lyrical detail and a unifying refrain.
Lana Del Rey, Did you know that thereâ€™s a tunnel under Ocean Blvd
â€œIâ€™m a different kind of woman,â€ Lana Del Rey states plainly on â€œSweet,â€ adding a few seconds later, â€œIf you wanna go where nobody knows, thatâ€™s where youâ€™ll find me.â€ The singer-songwriter has spent her career proving the former statement â€” taking a personalized approach to pop craft, forever valuing honesty and innovation â€” but Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, her mammoth and often luminous ninth full-length, indeed exists at a wholly unique intersection in modern music, as the artistâ€™s most singular statement to date.
Click here to read a full review and tracks ranking of Lana Del Reyâ€™s latest album.
Luke Combs, Gettinâ€™ Old
As a companion piece to last yearâ€™s Growinâ€™ Up, Luke Combsâ€™ Gettinâ€™ Old better plays to the songwriting strengths of the country superstar, who reflects on his experiences and the time he has left (â€œThat hourglass we have donâ€™t last forever / Been thinking â€˜bout it more and more these days,â€ he sings in the opening minutes of the album) in a way thatâ€™s both gracious and entertaining. Whether heâ€™s looking back on a lost love, his hometown, his career beginnings and the start of a more durable type of romance, Combs sounds comfortable in his own skin on Gettinâ€™ Old, and the song quality lives up to his perspective.
RosalÃ­a & Rauw Alejandro, RR
Itâ€™s not every day that a couple gets to announce their engagement concurrently with releasing a highly anticipated collaborative project, but RosalÃ­a and Rauw Alejandro are in rarefied air: RR, a three-song release that captures the flamenco pop queenâ€™s predilection for yearning melodies and the reggaeton starâ€™s charisma across quickening tempos, could have been a vanity project for the happy couple but instead crackles with creative chemistry. And RR sound like itâ€™s just the tip of the iceberg â€” as Alejandro puts it in a press release, â€œI will be spending my days writing and writing many more songs about and with her.â€
Jimin, Face
Itâ€™d be easy (and a bit lazy) to place the BTS membersâ€™ solo projects side-by-side as they continue rolling out, but Jiminâ€™s new album Face resists comparison: the tracks here represents an account of personal evolution amidst mind-boggling fame, a global pandemic, feelings of loneliness and the process of growing into the man that the singer-songwriter has become. Jiminâ€™s gentle vocals ground songs like the sizzling â€œFace-offâ€ and the â€˜80s-indebted â€œLike Crazy,â€ accentuating the melodies with a light touch and expressing each lyric with impressive confidence.
Fall Out Boy, So Much (For) Stardust
Fall Out Boyâ€™s new album, So Much (For) Stardust, arrives almost 10 years to the day after the band returned with 2013â€™s Save Rock and Roll, which ended a prolonged hiatus and returned the Warped Tour breakouts to arena audiences. The group has spent the subsequent decade humming along, collecting more hits and touring the world, and their new album represents the work of a locked-in collective: on songs like â€œHold Me Like a Grudgeâ€ and â€œSo Good Right Now,â€ Fall Out Boyâ€™s long-running pop appeal remains intact but the turns are pinpoint and the grooves are tighter, as if the quartet is operating with machine-like efficiency for maximum enjoyment.

title: Plateanmeldelse: Lana Del Rey - "Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd": Sjelens americana
content:
KVINNE FOR SITT PERLEKJEDE: Lana Del Rey har et skarpt blikk for hva USA betyr â€“ mytologisk sÃ¥ vel som personlig.
Plateanmeldelse: Lana Del Rey â€“ Â«Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean BlvdÂ»: Sjelens americana
Lana Del Rey befester posisjonen som sin generasjons Dylan.
Visste du at det finnes en tunnel under Ocean Boulevard i Long Beach, California, som Ã¥pnet i 1928 og stengte i 1967, med forseggjorte fliser og mosaikk langs veggene og taket? Ikke jeg heller.
SÃ¥nt vet imidlertid Lana Del Rey, som holder til i nabolaget. Men langt viktigere: Hun makter Ã¥ bruke det som en poengtert og mangefasettert metafor for den amerikanske tilstanden her og nÃ¥, og hennes egen forgjengelighet oppi det hele:
There's a girl who sings Â«Hotel CaliforniaÂ»
Not because she loves the notes or sounds that sound like Florida
It's because she's in a world, preserved, only a few have found the door
It's like Camarillo, only silver mirrors, running down the corridor
Dylanologer vil trolig allerede hytte med neven over pÃ¥standen i ingressen, og Nobelkomiteen er neppe pÃ¥ ballen, men fuck dem: Lana Del Rey skÃ¥rer hÃ¸yt pÃ¥ alle omrÃ¥der som gjorde His Bobness til et ikon for sin tid.
Smarte, rÃ¸rende og ikke minst observante snapshots av samtiden? Check. Et bredt arsenal av amerikanske musikktradisjoner? Heck yeah. Forvirrende, eksperimentelle skruballer, forekomster av bÃ¥de hÃ¸ye og lave lyriske motiver og uimotstÃ¥elige melodier? Joa.
Der fjorÃ¥rets Â«Blue BanistersÂ» opplevdes en smule avdempet og tilkneppet, lyrisk sÃ¥ vel som musikalsk, strekker Del Rey ut sitt betydelige vingespenn pÃ¥ Â«Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean BlvdÂ» (heretter Â«Ocean BlvdÂ»).
Ã…pningslÃ¥ten Â«The GrantsÂ» er en gospelvakker familiehymne, Â«A&WÂ» (eller Â«American WhoreÂ», som den burde hete i trygg avstand fra Walmarts utstillingsvinduer) er en rystende fortelling kledd opp som en grunge-ballade som eskalerer i doo-wop-fraser og trap-beats.
Â«KintsugiÂ» og Â«FingertipsÂ» er dikt som fÃ¥r lov til Ã¥ utfolde seg over tilstrekkelige avstander.
Hun minner om en hviskende PJ Harvey pÃ¥ Â«Candy NecklaceÂ». Â«Grandfather Please Stand on the Shoulders of My Father While He's Deep-Sea FishingÂ» er utrolig nok enda bedre enn tittelen antyder. Mot slutten av albumet er vi tilbake i det dÃ¸sige, frakoblede hiphop-landskapet der Del Rey slo gjennom, og Â«Venice BitchÂ» lÃ¥ter bedre enn noensinne.
Det meste av popmusikk akkurat nÃ¥ er sÃ¥ uendelig generisk og kjedelig. Â«Ocean BlvdÂ» byr ikke bare pÃ¥ fem-seks av Del Reys aller beste lÃ¥ter. Albumet gjÃ¸r egenhendig popsjangeren levelig igjen.
BESTE LÃ…T: Â«A&WÂ»

content:

O Ãºltimo Ã¡lbum de Del Rey foi â€œBlue Banistersâ€, em outubro de 2021, meses apÃ³s â€œChemtrails over the Country Clubâ€. Em outubro do ano passado, contudo, ela fez uma participaÃ§Ã£o no novo Ã¡lbum de Taylor Swift, â€œMidnightsâ€, na faixa â€œSnow On The Beachâ€.

title: Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜Ocean Blvdâ€™ Album: Songs Ranked
content:
â€œIâ€™m a different kind of woman,â€ Lana Del Rey states plainly on â€œSweet,â€ adding a few seconds later, â€œIf you wanna go where nobody knows, thatâ€™s where youâ€™ll find me.â€ The singer-songwriter has spent her career proving the former statement â€” taking a personalized approach to pop craft, forever valuing honesty and innovation â€” but Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, her mammoth and often luminous ninth full-length, indeed exists at a wholly unique intersection in modern music, as the artistâ€™s most singular statement to date.
Del Reyâ€™s voice has always been unmistakable, but no other artist could have come close to showcasing this 77-minute set of ideas, sometimes mysterious and occasionally shambolic, but always exciting and brimming with integrity. The adventurous spirit of this album flirts with a gleeful recklessness: Del Rey has explored her thoughts on sex, devotion, family and American decay in the past, but never with so many unexpected guests, songs mashed into each other and restless detours. In an era of the music industry that rewards TikTok-ready hooks, Del Rey has sprinted in the opposite direction: the songs here proudly stretch out, dismissing verse-chorus structures so that Del Rey can travel across another bridge or three.
Yet Del Reyâ€™s pen holds Ocean Blvd together. Writing primarily with Jack Antonoff, Mike Hermosa and Drew Erickson, Del Rey conjures images that continue to haunt her and presents lyrics that jangle around the listenerâ€™s brain. From the boarded-up past of the title track to the post-grief forward motion of â€œKintsugiâ€ to the giddy friendship of â€œMargaret,â€ Del Rey roams across topics and deftly handles them all. For an album that clearly challenges its creator, Ocean Blvd once again concludes that Del Rey is different, in the best way possible.
While all of Lana Del Reyâ€™s new album is worth digging into, we already have some early favorites after several listens. Here is our preliminary track rankings for Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd:

title: SehnsÃ¼chtige Reise: Lana Del Rey ist zurÃ¼ck
content:
SehnsÃ¼chtige Reise: Lana Del Rey ist zurÃ¼ck
Teilen
Lana Del Rey nimmt ihre Fans mt auf eine fast 80-minÃ¼tige Song-Reise. Â© -/Universal Music/dpa
Zwischen Poesie, Melancholie und abgeklÃ¤rtem Hip-Hop bewegt sich das neue Album von Lana Del Rey. Es vereint Altes mit Neuem - und das mit einem inhaltlich Ã¼berraschenden Schwerpunkt.
Berlin - Seitdem Lana Del Rey 2012 mit dem Song â€Video Gamesâ€œ und ihrem offiziellen DebÃ¼talbum â€Born to Dieâ€œ berÃ¼hmt wurde, hat sie mit dem nach Sehnsucht klingenden Melancholie-Pop den Sound der letzten Dekade geprÃ¤gt. Auf ihrem neunten Studioalbum mit dem Titel â€Did You Know That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€œ beweist die US-Musikerin nun ein weiteres Mal, dass sie viel mehr kann, als traurige Indie-Hymnen in die Welt hauchen.
Musikalisch erinnert das Album an Del Reys ganz frÃ¼he Kompositionen, als sie 2008 noch unter dem Namen Lizzy Grant ihr erstes Album verÃ¶ffentlichte. Auch 15 Jahre spÃ¤ter finden sich Genre-Kreuzungen und die Experimentierfreude, die zur Handschrift der 37-JÃ¤hrigen wurde. Kein Wunder also, dass sie das Album als eines ihrer persÃ¶nlichsten bezeichnet. Nun gut, das behaupten viele KÃ¼nstler zu ihrem aktuellen Werk, aber hier geht es tatsÃ¤chlich weit zu ihren Wurzeln zurÃ¼ck. Und auch inhaltlich wird es Ã¼berraschend persÃ¶nlich und familiÃ¤r.
PersÃ¶nlich und tiefgrÃ¼ndig
Der Opener-Song â€The Grantsâ€œ startet mit sanften GospelklÃ¤ngen und fÃ¼hrt in das groÃŸe Thema des Albums ein: ihre Familie. Sie besingt die Erinnerungen an ihre Nichte, ihre GroÃŸmutter und ihren Onkel, die sie mit ins Grab nehmen wird. Aber auch mit ihrer eigenen Sterblichkeit setzt sie sich auf dem Album mehrfach auseinander. So singt Del Rey im Titelsong davon, dass sie nicht vergessen werden will, wie der einstige FuÃŸgÃ¤ngertunnel unter dem Ocean Boulevard in Long Beach, Kalifornien. Der ist 1967 geschlossen worden, aber noch immer intakt.
â€All die Mosaik-Decken sind noch perfekt erhalten, aber niemand kann mehr hereinâ€œ, erzÃ¤hlte Del Rey dem US-amerikanischen Magazin â€Interviewâ€œ im Vorfeld der AlbumverÃ¶ffentlichung. FÃ¼r sie war die Idee eines wunderschÃ¶nen Tunnels, in den niemand hinein kommt, die Inspiration fÃ¼r das Album.
In der Mitte des Albums finden sich Orchester- und Klavierballaden, die Del Rey als die persÃ¶nlichsten Songs des Albums beschreibt. In â€Kintsugiâ€œ verarbeitet sie zum Beispiel den Schmerz, den sie durch den Tod ihrer Verwandten fÃ¼hlt. â€Fingertipsâ€œ wiederum erinnert an ihren Gedichtband (â€Violets Bent Backwards Over The Grassâ€œ, 2020), weil sie auch in diesem Song ihre innersten GefÃ¼hle teilt. â€Werde ich jemals Kinder haben?â€œ und â€Wird meine Familie bei mir sein, wenn ich sterbe?â€œ, fragt sich Del Rey in dem Song.
Eine 77 minÃ¼tige Musikreise
Ein wenig abschreckend wirkt zunÃ¤chst die LÃ¤nge des Albums, das sich mit Ã¼ber 77 Minuten in 16 Tracks jedoch zu einer wohlÃ¼berlegten Reise entpuppt. â€A&Wâ€œ markiert als vierter Titel den ersten Bruch der musikalischen Reise durch Del Reys Gedankenwelt. In dem Song zu sexueller Selbstbestimmung und ihrem medialen Image gibt es in der Mitte einen rapiden Wechsel von dunklem Gitarrenpop zu einem Trapbeat aus massiven, ja aggressiven Basstrommeln und einer verspielteren Seite mit rollenden Hi-Hat-Becken, die Del Rey bereits in frÃ¼heren Produktionen - so zum Beispiel â€Lust For Lifeâ€œ von 2017 - zeigte. An dieser Stelle wird auch das Album von einer sehnsÃ¼chtigen Traumreise zu einem manischen Fiebertraum.
Teils arrhythmische und dissonante Klavierkompositionen (â€Candy Necklacesâ€œ) fÃ¼llen das Album mit Spannung. Die beiden rund vier Minuten langen sogenannten Interludes, also Zwischenspiele, lassen mehr Fragen offen, als sie beantworten. In einem verfolgt der ZuhÃ¶rer eine Predigt eines Pastors, im anderen ist der Oscar- und Grammy-PreistrÃ¤ger Komponist Jon Batiste (â€We Areâ€œ) zu hÃ¶ren.
FÃ¼r den einen oder anderen wirkt der Mittelteil der Platte womÃ¶glich etwas zÃ¤h und undurchdringlich. Wer dran bleibt, wird am Ende aber belohnt: â€Taco Truck x VBâ€œ liefert eine Ã¼berraschende Neuauflage ihres Songs â€Venice Bitchâ€œ (2019), mit â€Peppersâ€œ und â€Let The Light Inâ€œ liefert Del Rey gleich zwei sehr gelungene Features mit Rapperin Tommy Genesis und Folk-SÃ¤nger Father John Misty.
Altbekannte Gesichter
Neben diesen GÃ¤sten finden sich auf dem Album auch altbekannte Wegbegleiter wie Jack Antonoff, der auch mit Taylor Swift arbeitet und schon frÃ¼here Alben produzierte (â€Norman Fucking Rockwellâ€œ,2019; â€Chemtrails Over The Country Clubâ€œ, 2021). Auch Produzent Drew Erickson ist nach dem letzten Album â€Blue Banistersâ€œ (2021) wieder dabei.
â€Did You Know That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€œ ist kein Album, das sich unbeschwert nebenher anhÃ¶ren lÃ¤sst. Wer zu einem Album von Lana Del Rey greift, erwartet das aber auch nicht unbedingt. Die Platte bietet viel mehr eine Tiefe, die sich nach dem ersten HÃ¶ren nicht sofort erschlieÃŸt und ergrÃ¼ndet werden will. Es lohnt sich, die knapp 80-minÃ¼tige Reise anzutreten. dpa

title: Neue Platten fÃ¼rs Wochenende: Lana Del Rey, Depeche Mode, Herbert GrÃ¶nemeyer
content:
Lana Del Rey: â€Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€œ (Interscope/Universal)
Nie zuvor klang Lana Del Rey so luftig, dunstig und dabei doch labyrinthisch wie auf ihrer neunten Langspielplatte mit dem verwegenen Titel â€Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€œ. Schon die (inszenierte?) A-cappella-Gospel-Folk-Chorprobe im Opener gibt die Stimmung vor: Die Platte wirkt im besten Sinne spontan, oft so als wÃ¼rde Lana Del Rey, vÃ¶llig losgelÃ¶st von Pop-prÃ¤gnanten Strophen-Bridge-Refrain-Strukturen, in einem Open-Mic-Keller losjammen und losjammern; nur ist halt zufÃ¤llig ein cinemathisches Kammerorchester dabei, manchmal.
Es ist eine Entwicklung weg von den groÃŸartigen, aber doch auch sehr bemÃ¼ht polierten Vorzeige-Balladen aus dem gefeierten â€Norman Fucking Rockwell!â€œ (2019). Ein Weg, den Lana Del Rey schon auf â€Blue Banistersâ€œ (2021) vorzeichnete â€“ und den sie nun konsequent weitergeht. Aber doch mit UnerhÃ¶rtem: Lana Del Rey, die Americana-Collagen-KÃ¼nstlerin, von der schon seit langem kein Song, keine Referenz links oder rechts des Laurel Canyons sicher ist, zitiert so exzessiv wie nie ihr eigenes Material; es ist auch eine Abkehr vom zur Schau gestellten Amerika-Patriotismus hin zu einer familiÃ¤reren Innenschau; aber sie â€remixtâ€œ es eben doch auf eine Weise, die man bislang nicht von ihr kannte.
â€A&Wâ€œ fÃ¼hrt die Sounds aller Lana-Schaffensphasen zusammen. Somit ist auch der Boombap der frÃ¼hen â€Born To Dieâ€œ-Pop-Jahre wieder da, aber diesmal psychedelisch verwoben mit der reiferen Joni-Mitchell-Lana. Das finale â€Taco Truck x VBâ€œ bedient sich schamlos an ihrer eigenen â€Venice Bitchâ€œ von 2019. Lana ist nicht mehr sicher vor Lana. Im Grunde ist es formal-musikalisch die Message, die sich in ihren Texte seit jeher ausdrÃ¼ckte: das Manifest einer Frau, die ihre â€SchwÃ¤chenâ€œ (Drogen, harte MÃ¤nner, feiner Glamour, Depressionen) zelebriert wie keine zweite zurzeit, Respekt!
Depeche Mode: â€Memento Moriâ€œ (Columbia/Sony)
Depeche Mode sind da â€“ und wie! Sie haben ihre stÃ¤rkste Platte des Jahrtausends produziert, die, gemessen am kommerziellen Erfolg der Band, Ã¼berraschend wenig fÃ¼rs Konsensradio tut. Dabei wÃ¤re zu befÃ¼rchten gewesen, dass LeadsÃ¤nger Dave Gahan und Keyboarder-Gitarrist Martin Gore nach dem Tode ihres Dritten im Bunde, Andy Fletcher, 2022 nicht mehr gut zueinanderfinden; galt Fletcher doch stets als der VersÃ¶hner zwischen Gore und Gahan, die privat nicht eben beste Kumpels sind. Aber dieser Tod scheint Wunden aufgerissen und Gore und Gahan zu einer Zweier-Konfrontation gezwungen zu haben, die (so widersprÃ¼chlich es auch klingen mag) kÃ¼nstlerisch auf â€Memento Moriâ€œ, nun FrÃ¼chte trÃ¤gt, einer Platte, deren todestrunkenen Titel Fletcher Ã¼brigens noch zu Lebzeiten beisteuerte.
Die Bassdrum pocht tief, es drÃ¶hnt und faucht noisy. Dave Gahans Stimme klingt wie frisch aus dem Hades. Die Synthesizer schmettern zart wie SchmetterlingsflÃ¼gel im Opener â€My Cosmos Is Mineâ€œ; die Zerbrechlichkeit, die Endlichkeit gemahnend. â€Wagging Tongueâ€œ stampft wie ein Nachtclub in der Stadt der Todesengel. In â€Ghosts Againâ€œ stÃ¼rmen und drÃ¤ngen die Synths; und funkeln dann wie TrÃ¤umereien von Robotern. Auf â€My Favorite Strangerâ€œ schleifen sich denn auch endlich die Gitarren scharf. Der Bass turnt wie auf einem Stufenbarren. â€Soul With Meâ€œ hat etwas von einem blÃ¤tterraschelndem Herbstspaziergang mit George Michael und â€Carolineâ€™s Monkeyâ€œ schwingt sich trotz zart disharmonisch verschobener Keyboards zum eingÃ¤ngigen instant classic auf.
Zum finalen Albumdrittel wird das Tempo stark gedrosselt. Es stellen sich erste monotone LÃ¤ngen ein. Doch gerade wenn man meint, Depeche Mode gehen nun auf Chiller-Modus, laufen sie doch noch zum Endspurt an. Auf â€Never Let Me Goâ€œ (ein Verweis aufs gleichnamige Placebo-Album 2022?) klingt Gahans Edel-Goth-Stimme so schauderlichschÃ¶n von DÃ¤monen gequÃ¤lt, er verschleppt die Silben. Das eine Nahtod-Erfahrung verhandelnde â€Speak To Meâ€œ beschwÃ¶rt dann eine Kraft herauf, die kein Erbarmen kennt. Was fÃ¼r ein fieses Finale, was fÃ¼r eine starke Platte!
Der Depeche-Mode-Pop-Up-Bus wird am VÃ–-Freitag, dem 24. MÃ¤rz, in Berlin am Palais Kulturbrauerei von 18 bis 24 Uhr parken. Man kann dort unter anderem ein Meet & Greet mit der Band in Leipzig gewinnen. Ab 22 Uhr steigt zudem im Palais der Kulturbrauerei die offizielle Depeche-Mode-Releaseparty.
Herbert GrÃ¶nemeyer: â€Das ist losâ€œ (GrÃ¶nland/Vertigo/Universal)
GrÃ¶nemeyer will niemanden zurÃ¼cklassen. Und deshalb holt er uns dort ab, wo er uns vermutet. An einem Ort, der wohl etwas von einer Kirmes-Diskothek haben muss. So zumindest klingt der Titeltrack von â€Das ist losâ€œ: wie ein hektischer Jahrmarkt der AufmerksamkeitsÃ¶konomie. Ein soziales Bierzelt, in dem getanzt, gesoffen und geschrien wird. Aus allen Ecken ruft wer, bis man kaum noch weiÃŸ, was Sache ist.
Einen Schwenk in Richtung Klima-Kleber gibt es auch auf GrÃ¶nemeyers neuer Platte: â€Oh Oh Ohâ€œ heiÃŸt der Song: â€Da sind so viele offene Gesichter / gewappnet fÃ¼r den Klimakampf / voll durchgenervt von alten Geschichten / Sie wollen voran, stehen unter Dampf.â€œ Im Klimakampfdampf lÃ¤sst sich derweil prÃ¤chtig schunkeln. Bis Onkel Herbert die Geduld verliert, ermahnt: â€Muss die Welt erst in Flammen stehen / dass wir aneinander Anteil nehmen / Wichtig ist, alle sind oh oh oh / dabei rÃ¼ber in die neue Zeit.â€œ Oh oh oh! Oh, lÃ , lÃ .
Herbert GrÃ¶nemeyer hat sein Herz am rechten Fleck, so viel ist klar. Er meint es gut und will uns Mut zusprechen, Mut zupoetisieren. Ein Anti-Spalter, ein ZusammenfÃ¼hrer in polarisierender Zeit. FÃ¼r jemanden, der dabei so viele Mittel hÃ¤tte wie Chartking GrÃ¶nemeyer, ist der Sound der Platte aber Ã¼berraschend unspektakulÃ¤r.

title: Lana Del Rey titre ses morceaux comme personne dâ€™autre, une habitude qui en dit long
content:
Gilbert Flores / Billboard via Getty Images Gilbert Flores / Billboard via Getty Images
MUSIQUE - Le sens de la formule. Le morceau Ã©ponyme - le premier Ã  avoir Ã©tÃ© dÃ©voilÃ© avant la sortie du disque - ne fait pas seulement rÃ©fÃ©rence au tunnel historique construit dans les annÃ©es 1920 pour permettre aux piÃ©tons de la ville de Long Beach, en Californie, dâ€™accÃ©der plus facilement Ã  la plage, il a aussi beaucoup Ã  dire de la peur de lâ€™abandon de la chanteuse.
La suite aprÃ¨s cette publicitÃ©
Il est deuxiÃ¨me dans la tracklist de ce disque placÃ© sous le thÃ¨me de lâ€™enfance et de ses relations avec sa famille, loin devant une autre balade au titre (attention) encore plus Ã  rallonge : Grandfather please stand on the shoulders of my father while heâ€™s deep-sea fishing. En franÃ§ais : Â« Grand-pÃ¨re, sâ€™il te plaÃ®t, monte sur les Ã©paules de mon pÃ¨re quand il pÃªche en haute mer Â».
Pour la journaliste amÃ©ricaine Kathy Iandoli, les noms de ces deux morceaux sont, comme la plupart des titres de Lana Del Rey, une sorte de chasse aux Å“ufs de PÃ¢ques pour les fans de la chanteuse. Â« Elle joue avec eux et leur glisse des indices Â», nous explique celle qui, entre octobre et dÃ©cembre 2022, a donnÃ© une sÃ©rie de cours Ã  lâ€™universitÃ© de New York sur la pop star de 37 ans.
Leur longueur est Ã©tonnante, mais pas inÃ©dite. Le morceau final de Norman Fucking Rockwell (sorti en 2019) peut en tÃ©moigner. Il sâ€™intitule hope is a dangerous thing for a woman like me to have - but I have it. Deux titres sortis sur Lust For Life (2017) sont plus courts, mais nous procurent le mÃªme effet : God Bless America - And All The Beautiful Women In It (Que Dieu bÃ©nisse lâ€™AmÃ©rique - Et toutes les belles femmes qui sâ€™y trouvent) et When The World Was At War We Kept Dancing (Quand le monde Ã©tait en guerre, on a continuÃ© Ã  danser).
La suite aprÃ¨s cette publicitÃ©
Lana Del Rey, la poÃ©tesse
Cette drÃ´le dâ€™habitude, devenue par ailleurs un mÃ¨me, nous rappelle, selon Kathy Iandoli, que Â« Lana Del Rey est une poÃ©tesse Â». La chanteuse sâ€™y connaÃ®t en haÃ¯kus, ces petits poÃ¨mes extrÃªmement brefs dâ€™origine japonaise. La parution, en 2020, de son premier recueil de poÃ©sie, qui en comptait quelques-uns, peut en tÃ©moigner. Il sâ€™intitulait Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass (Violette sur lâ€™herbe Ã  la renverse, Seuil). Un second (Behind the Iron Gates â€“ Insights from the Institution) a Ã©tÃ© annoncÃ©.
Et quand ce nâ€™est pas dans les titres de ses chansons ou dans un livre, câ€™est dans ses paroles que la compositrice joue avec les mots. Lâ€™ouverture de The Grants le rappelle. Â« Iâ€™m gonna take mind of you with me Â», chantent des choristes. Câ€™est une erreur volontaire. Ils disent Â« mind Â» (lâ€™esprit) au lieu de Â« mine Â» (mien). Cela donne : Â« Je vais prendre ton esprit avec moi Â», au lieu de Â« Je vais prendre les miens avec moi Â». Quelquâ€™un les arrÃªte et les guide. Ils se reprennent, mais le Â« d Â» ne disparaÃ®t jamais vraiment.
Loin de lâ€™Ã©poque de son premier album Born To Die, oÃ¹ ses dÃ©tracteurs disaient dâ€™elle quâ€™elle Ã©tait une supercherie et une gosse de riche Ã©rigÃ©e en pin-up vintage par sa maison de disques, Lana Del Rey est aujourdâ€™hui largement estimÃ©e pour sa prose. Elle est lâ€™artiste fÃ©minine visionnaire de 2023, selon lâ€™hebdomadaire amÃ©ricain Billboard. Et, dâ€™aprÃ¨s le magazine Rolling Stone, la meilleure autrice-compositrice de notre siÃ¨cle.
La suite aprÃ¨s cette publicitÃ©
Une influence majeure
Lana Del Rey nâ€™a pas inventÃ© les titres Ã  rallonge. Il est difficile de rivaliser avec celui de lâ€™album, sorti en 2012, par Fiona Apple : The Idler Wheel Is Wiser Than the Driver of the Screw and Whipping Cords Will Serve You More Than Ropes Will Ever Do (La roue libre est plus sage que le pilote de la vis et les fouets vous serviront plus que les cordes ne le feront jamais).
On doit, cependant, Ã  lâ€™interprÃ¨te de High By The Beach (chanson de 2015) le mÃ©rite dâ€™avoir introduit un nouveau courant dans la pop music en lâ€™espace dâ€™une petite dizaine dâ€™annÃ©es, nous dit Kathy Iandoli. Â« Elle parle de sujets graves, tristes, mÃ©lancoliques et introspectifs Â», soulÃ¨ve la spÃ©cialiste. Ses thÃ¨mes : la mort, les drogues, lâ€™alcool ou lâ€™argent. Le tout, sur fond de romance tragique, contrairement aux amours joyeux auxquels le genre musical nous a habituÃ©s depuis son apparition dans les annÃ©es 1960.
Â« Câ€™est peut-Ãªtre aussi pour Ã§a que beaucoup de gens, qui nâ€™Ã©coutent pas forcÃ©ment de pop music en rÃ¨gle gÃ©nÃ©rale, se retrouvent dans ce quâ€™elle chante. Elle fÃ©dÃ¨re ses fans et les personnes qui se retrouvent dans ce quâ€™elle dit Â», constate lâ€™universitaire new-yorkaise.
La suite aprÃ¨s cette publicitÃ©
Dâ€™aprÃ¨s le magazine Billboard, la derniÃ¨re dÃ©cennie musicale nâ€™aurait pas Ã©tÃ© la mÃªme sans lâ€™encre noire de Lana Del Rey. Â« Elle a une influence majeure Â», ajoute Kathy Iandoli, selon qui certaines pop stars comme Billie Eilish et Lorde empruntent ces mÃªmes chemins assombris. Il faut ajouter Phoebe Bridgers, Halsey et encore Sky Ferreira. La liste sâ€™allonge. Presque autant que ses titres.

content:

Â« Je veux dire, soyons rÃ©alistes : la star, Ã§a a toujours Ã©tÃ© lui Â», sâ€™amuse encore la chanteuse, dont lâ€™album de la rÃ©vÃ©lation Â« Born to die Â» (2012) sâ€™est Ã©coulÃ© Ã  plus de 14,5 millions dâ€™exemplaires, selon sa maison de disques Polydor.
