title: Como Lana Del Rey canta para barrar extrema direita
content:
[RESUMO] Lana Del Rey, que se apresenta em SÃ£o Paulo (3/6) no Festival Mita, estruturou seus discos a partir de referÃªncias, cifradas ou explÃ­citas, aos personagens do romance "O Grande Gatsby", clÃ¡ssico de F. Scott Fitzgerald. Tida pela mÃ­dia como mais uma cantora pop, ela compÃ´s canÃ§Ãµes subversivas sobre o desejo feminino que buscam no fracasso dos tiranos "homens de bem" uma saÃ­da para os extremismos de hoje.

Querem impedir o avanÃ§o da extrema direita? EntÃ£o ouÃ§am com atenÃ§Ã£o a obra de Lana Del Rey.
A chave para entender esta relaÃ§Ã£o encontra-se em dois autores e seus livros concebidos hÃ¡ cem anos.
O primeiro Ã© o americano F. Scott Fitzgerald. Em 1922, ele iniciou a redaÃ§Ã£o de um romance que, trÃªs anos depois, transformou-se em "O Grande Gatsby". O segundo Ã© o alemÃ£o Oswald Spengler, que, em 1923, lanÃ§ava a ediÃ§Ã£o definitiva, em dois volumes, de seu grande painel de filosofia da histÃ³ria, "A DecadÃªncia do Ocidente".
A cantora Lana Del Rey se apresenta no festival Lollapalooza, em SÃ£o Paulo, em 2018 - Bruno Santos/Folhapress
A trama de "Gatsby" Ã© simples. Nick Carraway, um idealista que nÃ£o sabe se serÃ¡ um escritor ou mais um investidor em Wall Street (antes do crash de 1929), conta como um contrabandista milionÃ¡rio, Jay Gatsby, recriou a sua biografia apenas para reconquistar um amor do passado, a interesseira Daisy Buchanan, casada com Tom, um brutamontes entupido de dinheiro e crente de que Ã© um "homem de bem", apesar de maltratar a esposa.
Acompanhado pela astuta Jordan Baker, Nick testemunha as festas luxuosas que Gatsby dÃ¡ para chamar a atenÃ§Ã£o de Daisy â€”assim como a tragÃ©dia decorrente do triÃ¢ngulo amoroso que acontece entre o casal e o personagem-tÃ­tulo do romance.
JÃ¡ "A DecadÃªncia do Ocidente" desenvolve a tese de que a civilizaÃ§Ã£o estava em uma fase de petrificaÃ§Ã£o polÃ­tica e cultural, e nÃ£o haveria outro destino exceto a ruÃ­na de nossas instituiÃ§Ãµes democrÃ¡ticas, destruindo assim sÃ©culos de conquistas religiosas e culturais.
Para reverter este processo em curso â€”semelhante Ã  decomposiÃ§Ã£o de um organismo, o que fez Spengler dar uma importÃ¢ncia exagerada Ã  "raÃ§a"â€” era fundamental aceitar o advento do cesarismo, no qual um "homem forte" dominaria tudo o que fosse possÃ­vel dentro do seu alcance.
No meio deste sanduÃ­che insÃ³lito, estÃ¡ Lana Del Rey â€”ou melhor, Elizabeth Grant, nascida em 1985, filha de um publicitÃ¡rio e de uma professora, moÃ§a da alta classe mÃ©dia americana.
Ela estudou filosofia na Universidade de Fordham, instituiÃ§Ã£o catÃ³lica de Nova York (a mesma que teve entre seus alunos o mÃ¡gico David Copperfield e o ator Denzel Washington), e insistiu em afirmar a Deus e ao mundo que era uma cantora capaz de unir os diversos fragmentos da cultura dos EUA. A princÃ­pio, ninguÃ©m a levou a sÃ©rio.
Assim, Elizabeth (nessa fase identificando-se como " Lizzy") entregou-se Ã  bebida e aos distÃºrbios alimentares, ao mesmo tempo em que consumia a literatura de Vladimir Nabokov ("Lolita", obviamente) e os filmes de David Lynch ("Twin Peaks" e "CoraÃ§Ã£o Selvagem", com certeza).
Pouco a pouco, reencontrou o prumo e fez seu primeiro Ã¡lbum, intitulado "Lizzy Grant" (2010). Descontente com o rumo que a gravadora tinha dado ao disco e com a sua prÃ³pria persona pÃºblica, ela mudou subitamente de ideia, arquivou a estreia como cantora profissional e criou um novo nome: Lana Del Rey.
A transformaÃ§Ã£o seria definitiva com o segundo disco, lanÃ§ado em 2012 e intitulado "Born To Die". Eram outros tempos: ninguÃ©m iria imaginar que, pouco depois, o Brasil passaria por manifestaÃ§Ãµes em massa que tirariam uma presidente de esquerda do poder e que um empresÃ¡rio fanfarrÃ£o como Donald Trump seria o prÃ³ximo comandante dos EUA.
A mÃºsica celebrada por Lana era a recuperaÃ§Ã£o de uma nostalgia que poucos experimentaram nos anos 2000. A sua melancolia, contudo, nÃ£o era sobre o que aconteceu no passado, mas sim a respeito de um futuro que jamais existiu.
Isso ficou mais evidente nos Ã¡lbuns seguintes, oito discos em um breve espaÃ§o de uma dÃ©cada, e uma dezena de singles distribuÃ­dos em ediÃ§Ãµes especiais, coletÃ¢neas e trilhas sonoras de sÃ©ries de TV e filmes.
Em um desses pedaÃ§os aparentemente espalhados a esmo, hÃ¡ uma canÃ§Ã£o chamada "Young and Beautiful", composta para a adaptaÃ§Ã£o cinematogrÃ¡fica que o diretor Baz Luhrmann fez de... "O Grande Gatsby", em 2013..
O elenco do filme tinha Leonardo DiCaprio no papel principal, Carey Mulligan e Joel Edgerton como Daisy e Tom Buchanan, Elizabeth Debicki na pele de Jordan Baker e Tobey Maguire sendo o Nick Carraway que imita o prÃ³prio Fitzgerald, com direito a dramatizar o colapso nervoso que o romancista sofreria anos depois, apÃ³s o fracasso de crÃ­tica e pÃºblico de seu livro.
"Young and Beautiful" parece ser mais um single de venda fÃ¡cil no catÃ¡logo de Lana, mas isso Ã© um engano. Ela sabe muito bem o que faz, controla todos os passos de sua carreira musical (em uma entrevista, Lana citou a expressÃ£o atribuÃ­da ao filÃ³sofo Leo Strauss de que seus discos devem ser "lidos nas entrelinhas").
A canÃ§Ã£o Ã© um lamento lÃ­rico sobre um amor irrecuperÃ¡vel, em sintonia com o triste mundo de Fitzgerald.
A inclusÃ£o de Lana Del Rey no universo fitzgeraldiano nÃ£o Ã© somente uma bela estratÃ©gia de marketing. Cada disco dela Ã© uma referÃªncia, ora cifrada, ora explÃ­cita, ao quarteto central do enredo de "O Grande Gatsby".
A comeÃ§ar pela trajetÃ³ria da prÃ³pria Lana, que para ser a superstar de hoje foi obrigada a recriar a sua prÃ³pria biografia â€”assim como um tal de Jay Getz fez para se transformar no Gatsby que encanta a narrativa de Nick Carraway.
E, para mostrar que nÃ£o hÃ¡ acaso na sequÃªncia de seus discos, Lana os estruturou de tal forma que Ã© impossÃ­vel nÃ£o perceber a conexÃ£o de temas de suas melodias e seus versos com a cÃ©lebre obra de Fitzgerald.
Em primeiro lugar, temos a trilogia moldada em Tom Buchanan, com "Born To Die", "Ultraviolence" (2014) e "Honeymoon" (2015); depois, hÃ¡ o que podemos chamar de "disco solo" de Daisy Buchanan, "Lust For Life" (2017); aÃ­ chegamos ao dÃ­ptico que emula Jordan Baker, "Norman F... Rockwell" (2019) e "Chemtrails over the Country Club" (2021), para depois contemplarmos o que Nick Carraway pensaria sobre os nossos tempos insanos, em "Blue Banisters" (2021).
Todavia, a grande novidade de Lana Del Rey Ã© que ela nÃ£o faz isso do ponto de vista desses "homens de bem", e sim das mulheres fascinadas por eles. Seu assunto Ã© nada mais, nada menos que o labirinto do desejo â€”e de como somos incapazes de encontrar um fio de Ariadne para escapar desta prisÃ£o.
Nos trÃªs primeiros Ã¡lbuns da sua nova carreira, Lana interpreta uma mulher que se rende a alguÃ©m como Tom Buchanan. Em "Gatsby", ele Ã© um boÃ§al que cita opiniÃµes e frases retiradas de livros inspirados em... Oswald Spengler.
Fitzgerald nÃ£o cita "A DecadÃªncia do Ocidente", mas sim um autor marcado por ele, Lothrop Stoddard. Com seu " The Rising Tide of Color" (1920), Stoddard reiterava a abordagem de Spengler no primeiro tomo da sua sÃ­ntese, lanÃ§ado em 1918, e afirmava que a Europa em pouco tempo testemunharia a "ascensÃ£o dos impÃ©rios de cor".
Mas Tom Buchanan nÃ£o Ã© o Ãºnico personagem com delÃ­rios de ser um CÃ©sar na vida privada. Gatsby sofre do mesmo problema, e Nick Carraway tambÃ©m. Fitzgerald fez, com esses personagens, uma anatomia implacÃ¡vel do fracasso que Ã© ser um "homem de bem", o homem supostamente honesto que, no fim, deseja ser um pequeno tirano entre suas amadas (e no resto da sociedade por extensÃ£o).
Lana Del Rey percebeu isso como poucas artistas contemporÃ¢neas â€”o que Ã© extremamente inovador e subversivo em um mundo como o nosso, intoxicado tanto pelo discurso da extrema direita como pela polÃ­tica identitÃ¡ria. E, com sua obra idiossincrÃ¡tica, ela consegue encontrar uma saÃ­da para esse impasse.
Em "Ultraviolence", Lana canta que "fodi o meu caminho atÃ© chegar ao topo", uma versÃ£o menos sofisticada da famosa observaÃ§Ã£o de Fitzgerald de que a voz de Daisy Buchanan era "cheia de dinheiro".
No "dÃ­ptico Jordan Baker", Lana brinca com a mecÃ¢nica de "quem-come-quem", sabendo que, no fim, Ã© uma mocetona que gosta de passear na praia de Venice, em Los Angeles, apenas para praticar seus jogos de seduÃ§Ã£o.
Em "Blue Banisters", a cantora apela para uma melancolia cada vez mais constante, ao intuir como sofre uma mulher que precisa entender o trauma vivido por Nick Carraway no final trÃ¡gico de "O Grande Gatsby".
Todavia, Ã© no seu disco mais recente, o sublime "Did You Know That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd" (2023) que Lana dÃ¡ seu passo mais insÃ³lito: ela simplesmente assume a persona de F. Scott Fitzgerald.
Mas nÃ£o se trata do escritor bem-sucedido dos loucos anos 1920, e sim do artista atormentado que produziu ensaios memorÃ¡veis como "The Crack-Up" (1936), em que narra em detalhes seu mergulho nas trevas da depressÃ£o e do alcoolismo.
Lana faz isso de maneira deliberada em duas canÃ§Ãµes: "A&W" e "Kintsugi". A primeira Ã© uma confissÃ£o de como foi usada e abusada pela mÃ­dia, que fez de tudo para assassinar sua reputaÃ§Ã£o; a segunda traz uma reflexÃ£o comovente a respeito do encontro de Lana com a prÃ³pria finitude.
"Kintsugi" Ã© tambÃ©m uma referÃªncia crÃ­ptica a um tipo de arte oriental (japonesa, no caso). Ela reelabora uma determinada perspectiva existencial a partir das ruÃ­nas que, supostamente, formam a nossa prÃ³pria trajetÃ³ria individual.
O pintor Makoto Fujimura, autor de "Arte & FÃ©", defendeu recentemente esse tipo de manifestaÃ§Ã£o, explicando cuidadosamente que "kintsugi Ã© o remendar que nos conduz ao novo" e a uma nova esperanÃ§a.
Ora, Ã© justamente o que Lana Del Rey insiste em realizar, como se fosse uma obsessÃ£o. A Ãºltima faixa do novo Ã¡lbum, "Taco Truck X VB", recria "Venice Bitch", de "Norman F... Rockwell" â€”Ã¡lbum que pertence Ã  fase Jordan Baker, se seguirmos a nossa descriÃ§Ã£o da estratÃ©gia Ã  la Fitzgerald.
De novo, isso tambÃ©m nÃ£o Ã© algo aleatÃ³rio. Lana sabe que Ã© impossÃ­vel imitar moÃ§as como Daisy Buchanan ou mulheres fascinadas por "homens de bem", como Gatsby, Tom Buchanan e Nick Carraway. Em um mundo contaminado pelos detritos do discurso de Oswald Spengler, copiar a astÃºcia de uma Jordan Baker Ã© mais do que um manifesto feminista: Ã© uma atitude de sobrevivÃªncia.
Lana Del Rey e sua obra retratam a verdade de que vivemos em uma permanente "noite escura da alma". E Ã© apenas este tipo de conhecimento que nos ajuda a impedir a ascensÃ£o de qualquer perigo iminente, seja a extrema direita, sejam as nossas prÃ³prias ilusÃµes.
DisfarÃ§ada pelo manto da beleza, Lana Ã© o espelho maldito dos nossos desejos, pronta para se sacrificar em estilhaÃ§os que mostrarÃ£o como somos, no fim, segundo as derradeiras palavras de Nick Carraway em "O Gande Gatsby", "barcos indo contra a corrente, impelidos incessantemente de volta ao passado".

title: Narcisa usa megafone para falar com Lana Del Rey no Copacabana Palace
content:
De Splash, em SÃ£o Paulo

In case you didnâ€™t know, the Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd singer previously confirmed that it was her choice to sing less â€” she was more focused on production, and didnâ€™t feel like she needed to do the entire second verse like Swift initially wanted. But the extended version doesnâ€™t only give Lana more lines. It also sounds like her mic has been turned up, making her background vocals and ad libs stand out like snow on the â€¦ well, you get it.

title: Taylor Swift Announces New Midnights Deluxe Album Featuring Ice Spice and Lana Del Rey
content:
Taylor Swift is releasing a deluxe version of Midnights on Friday, May 26. Midnights (The Til Dawn Edition) includes the original album, the â€œ3amâ€ tracks, the Target CD bonus song â€œHits Different,â€ and two more new songs: a new version of â€œKarmaâ€ with Ice Spice, and a new version â€œSnow on the Beachâ€ featuring even more contributions from Lana Del Rey. At her show on Friday, Swift will be offering an exclusive CD edition of the new deluxe album that has another new track, â€œYouâ€™re Losing Me.â€
After Midnights got released last October, fans lamented the small role that Del Rey played in â€œSnow on the Beach.â€ Swift apparently took notice. â€œYou asked for it, we listened: Lana and I went back into the studio specifically to record more Lana on Snow on the Beach,â€ she wrote today. â€œLove u Lana ğŸ¥°ğŸ˜†â˜ºï¸.â€
Del Rey, for her part, told Billboard in a recent interview:
Well, first of all, I had no idea I was the only feature [on that song]. Had I known, I would have sung the entire second verse like she wanted. My job as a feature on a big artistâ€™s album is to make sure I help add to the production of the song, so I was more focused on the production. She was very adamant that she wanted me to be on the album, and I really liked that song. I thought it was nice to be able to bridge that world, since Jack [Antonoff] and I work together and so do Jack and Taylor.
Swift is still on her Eras Tour. Sheâ€™s releasing Speak Now (Taylorâ€™s Version) on July 7.

title: Taylor Swift, Ice Spice â€˜Karmaâ€™ Remix (And More Lana) Coming Soon
content:
In the midst of her Eras tour, Taylor Swift has announced a handful of new releases related to her current era: the superstar has revealed that â€œKarma,â€ a fan favorite from Midnights, would be getting a new remix featuring rising rap star Ice Spice, out this Friday (May 26). Meanwhile, a different version of the Lana Del Rey collaboration â€œSnow on the Beachâ€ would also be released, as would â€œYouâ€™re Losing Me,â€ a â€œvault trackâ€ from Midnights â€” all as part of a new Midnights (Til Dawn Edition) deluxe album.
Explore Explore Taylor Swift See latest videos, charts and news See latest videos, charts and news
â€œUm. SO much to tell you,â€ Swift wrote in a message to fans on Wednesday (May 24). â€œIâ€™m a massive fan of this brilliant artist and after getting to know her I can confirm: she is THE ONE to watch. So delighted to say that Karma Featuring the incredible @icespice will be out TOMORROW night at MIDNIGHT ET as a part of the new Midnights (Til Dawn Edition) deluxe album that you can pre-order now at store.taylorswift.com!
â€œIn addition to Karma Ft Ice Spiceâ€¦,â€ Swift continued. â€œYou asked for it, we listened: Lana and I went back into the studio specifically to record more Lana on Snow on the Beach. Love u @honeymoon ğŸ¥°ğŸ˜†â˜ºï¸.â€
â€œKarmaâ€ originally debuted at No. 9 on the Hot 100 chart upon the October 2022 release of Midnights, and was among the tracks that helped Swift become the first artist in Hot 100 history to dominate the chartâ€™s entire top 10 in one week. Swift has been closing out her Eras set lists with â€œKarmaâ€ â€” which rises three spots to No. 32 on the current Hot 100 â€” since the stadium tour began in March.
Meanwhile, Ice Spiceâ€™s popularity has exploded since she first shot to viral fame with â€œMunch (Feelinâ€™ U)â€ last fall. Her debut EP, Like..?, arrived in January on 10K Projects/Capitol, and Ice Spice proceeded to score top 10 smashes on the Hot 100 with the PinkPantheress team-up â€œGirlâ€™s a Liar Pt. 2â€ and the Nicki Minaj-assisted remix to her song â€œPrincess Diana.â€
â€œI saw all of my supporters being like, â€˜Sheâ€™s the Peopleâ€™s Princess! Sheâ€™s Princess Diana!â€™ â€ Ice told Billboard in her recent cover story. â€œAt first, I was confused. I was like, â€˜Um, Princess Diana? Out of everybody?â€™ But [then] I was like, â€˜Fâ€“k it, sheâ€™s iconic.â€™ â€
â€œSnow on the Beachâ€ is the lone Midnights track with a featured guest, as Swift and Del Rey worked on the song with their shared frequent collaborator, Jack Antonoff. Midnights is back up to No. 2 on the Billboard 200 in its 30th week on the chart â€” and as Swift tours the U.S. performing her catalog of hits, nine of her albums chart in the top 40 of the current tally.
â€œBut wait thereâ€™s moreâ€¦ for those of you going to the East Rutherford shows â€“ we will have a new special edition CD available ONLY on site starting at 12:30pm ET on Friday!â€ Swift wrote. â€œThis CD will have a never before heard Midnights vault track called â€˜Youâ€™re Losing Meâ€™!â€
Swiftâ€™s Eras tour continues this Friday with three nights at MetLife Stadium outside of New York City in East Rutherford, N.J. In addition to the unexpected Midnights releases, Swifties can also look forward to Speak Now (Taylorâ€™s Version), Swiftâ€™s third re-recorded album in her six-song project, set for a July 7 release.

title: Taylor Swift Reveals Deluxe 'Midnights' With Ice Spice, Lana Del Rey
content:
Taylor Swift announced a new deluxe edition of her â€œMidnightsâ€ album, titled â€œMidnights: Til Dawn,â€ that will feature Ice Spice as her guest on a fresh version of â€œKarmaâ€ and additional, newly recorded lead vocals from Lana Del Rey on their â€œSnow on the Beachâ€ collaboration.
Digital and physical editions will each have a format-exclusive track. For the digital release, it will be â€œHits Different,â€ a song that was previously only available on the Target version of â€œMidnights.â€ More interestingly for fans, the physical edition will have a â€œVaultâ€ track never before heard from the â€œMidnightsâ€ writing sessions.
The all-new song is titled â€œYouâ€™re Losing Me,â€ the title of which will obviously set fansâ€™ minds aflutter even before they hear it, given recent revelations about Swiftâ€™s personal life.
Fans at her New Jersey stadium show this Friday afternoon will have first crack at the physical release, when the merch stands open at 12:30 p.m..
Although Swiftâ€™s announcement of the collaboration with Ice Spice made no mention of a music video, the image that she released to go along with the reveal strongly indicates that a video may already be in the can.
Del Rey went back into the studio to cut new vocals for â€œSnow on the Beach,â€ said to be in response to fans of both artists saying they couldnâ€™t hear enough of the guest artist on the original version that appeared on â€œMidnights.â€

So delighted to say that â€˜Karmaâ€™ Featuring the incredible Ice Spice will be out TOMORROW night at MIDNIGHT ET as a part of the new â€˜Midnights (Til Dawn Edition)â€™ deluxe album that you can pre-order now at http://taylor.lnk.to/thetildawneditionâ€¦!â€
The singer added, â€œIn addition to â€˜Karma Ft Ice Spiceâ€™â€¦ You asked for it, we listened: Lana and I went back into the studio specifically to record more Lana on â€˜Snow on the Beach.â€™ Love u Lana.
â€œBut wait thereâ€™s more,â€ she continued. â€œFor those of you going to the East Rutherford shows â€“ we will have a new special edition CD available ONLY on site starting at 12:30pm ET on Friday! This CD will have a never before heard Midnights vault track called â€˜Youâ€™re Losing Meâ€™!â€

title: Lana del Rey sublima la mitologÃ­a pop y el clima de Ã©poca de Estados Unidos
content:
(Foto: EFE/Mario Ruiz/Archivo)
En sus comienzos, el hype que rodeaba a Elizabeth Grant, mÃ¡s conocida como Lana Del Rey, era tan grande que amenazaba con terminar con su carrera al momento de comenzar. Se la â€œacusabaâ€ de muchas cosas, entre ellas, la de no ser â€œautÃ©nticaâ€, un pecado mortal en el mundo del rock, tan afecto a los mitos y la supuesta bÃºsqueda de la pureza. Hasta se la llegÃ³ a criticar por usar un nombre inventado -como si Bob Dylan, o Axl Rose se llamaran asÃ­ de nacimiento, por poner apenas dos ejemplos- o de impostar una personalidad depresiva y oscura, hecha a imagen.y semejanza de cierto cine noir de los aÃ±os 50 o de las novelas negras de Raymond Chandler.
Proveniente de una familia de clase alta de Manhattan, Nueva York, Grant siempre se vio a sÃ­ misma como una artista total, donde el personaje que presenta ante el pÃºblico es igual de importante que las canciones. Si Lana Del Rey parece salida de un cuadro de Edward Hopper o de La noche del cazador es porque su personaje estÃ¡ modelado a imagen y semejanza de un tiempo mÃ­tico de la historia de los Estados Unidos. Ella nunca ocultÃ³ que su mayor inspiraciÃ³n para escribir canciones proviene de ese lugar.
Te puede interesar: Encantado, fantasmal y plebeyo: el universo de Lula Mari se presenta en el Rojas
Candy Necklace, de Lana Del Rey
Como una especie de Bruce Springsteen mÃ¡s depresiva y oscura, el nÃºcleo de la obra de Lana es la mitologÃ­a estadounidense. Sus canciones se encuentran plagadas de referencias a la moda -un single de su disco debut, Born to die, se llama â€œBlue Jeansâ€, con citas a James Dean -rock, jazz, la edad dorada de Hollywood, la tradiciÃ³n literaria norteamericana-, Walt Whitman, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Jack Kerouac y los beats, pero tambiÃ©n a grupos como Guns N- Roses (asÃ­ se titulÃ³ una canciÃ³n suya publicada en Ultraviolence, de 2014) o Red Hot Chilli Peppers.
La comparaciÃ³n con Springsteen no es antojadiza. En la canciÃ³n â€œAmericanâ€, tambiÃ©n de su disco debut, ella canta: Springsteen is the king, donâ€™t you think I was like, hell yeah that guy can sing -Springsteen es el rey, Â¿no crees? Yo estaba como, diablos, sÃ­, ese tipo puede cantar-. Bruce se refiriÃ³ a su colega neoyorquina en 2020 como â€œuna de las mejores cantautoras que hay en el paÃ­sâ€ y una de sus favoritas. SÃ­ el Jefe naciÃ³ para correr -Born to Run-, Lana naciÃ³ para morir -Born to die-, pero ambos, sin dudas, son Born in the U.S.A. -nacidos en los Estados Unidos-, con todo lo que eso implica, para bien y para mal.
El nuevo disco de Lana del Rey cuenta con la producciÃ³n de Mike Hermosa, Drew Erickson y Zach Dawes (Foto: Getty Images)
En â€œThe Greatestâ€, una de las cimas del disco que quizÃ¡s sea su obra maestra, Norman Fucking Rockwell (2019), prefigura como pocas el clima cultural de la pandemia del Covid-19. Entre citas a los Beach Boys y Dennis Wilson, Lana dice: I miss New York and I miss the music, me and my friends, we miss rock â€˜nâ€™ roll, I want shit to feel just like it used toâ€¦ The culture is Lit and if this is it I had a ball, I guess that Iâ€™m burned out after all (â€ExtraÃ±o Nueva York y extraÃ±o la mÃºsica, mis amigos y yo extraÃ±amos el rock â€˜nâ€™ roll, quiero que todo se sienta como antesâ€¦ La cultura estÃ¡ encendida, y si esto es todo me la pasÃ© bien, supongo que estoy quemada despuÃ©s de todoâ€).
Para terminar con una crÃ­tica a Kanye West y lo que el rapero reconvertido en ferviente militante trumpista representaba para la cultura: L.A. is in flames, itâ€™s getting hot, Kanye West is blond and gone (â€L.A. estÃ¡ en llamas y hace calor, Kanye West es rubio y estÃ¡ acabadoâ€). La canciÃ³n que mejor capturÃ³ la atmÃ³sfera de aÃ±os tan extraÃ±os como el 2020 y el 2021 fue compuesta y grabada en 2019, como suelen hacer las grandes artistas, Lana interpretÃ³ el clima de Ã©poca.
Blue Banisters, de Lana Del Rey
En un paÃ­s tan polarizado como los Estados Unidos de los Ãºltimos aÃ±os, una estrella como Lana Del Rey no es ajena a esto. Uno de sus comentarios mÃ¡s criticados por la prensa progresista fue cuando, tras la toma del Capitolio del 6 de enero de 2021 por parte de seguidores trumpistas que protestaban tras los resultados de las elecciones, dijo que la presidencia del magnate republicano â€œtenÃ­a que pasarâ€: â€œLa locura de Trump por muy mala que fuera, realmente tenÃ­a que suceder. Realmente necesitÃ¡bamos un reflejo del mayor problema de nuestro mundo, que no es el cambio climÃ¡tico, sino la sociopatÃ­a y el narcisismo. Especialmente en AmÃ©rica. Va a matar al mundo. No es capitalismo, es narcisismoâ€.
TambiÃ©n fue especialmente criticada por sectores del feminismo, que la acusaron de â€œglorificar el abusoâ€: â€œEstoy harta de que las escritoras y cantantes alternativas digan que hablo del abuso con glamour, cuando en realidad solo soy una persona glamorosa que canta sobre las realidades de lo que todos estamos viendo ahora, que son relaciones emocionalmente abusivas muy frecuentes en todo el mundo.â€.
Money, glory, power -Dinero, gloria, poder- y Old Money -dinero viejo, una expresiÃ³n para referirse a las familias que son acaudaladas desde hace varias generaciones en los Estados Unidos y en gran parte del mundo-, son dos titulos de canciones de su segundo disco, Ultraviolence. Como espejos de un paÃ­s tan obsesionado con el Ã©xito y el dinero, las canciones de Lana no dejan de tratar esa temÃ¡tica, que vuelve una y otra vez como una de sus principales obsesiones.
Casi al nivel de hacer The next best American rÃ©cord (â€El prÃ³ximo gran disco americanoâ€), como dice una de las canciones de Norman Fuckinâ€™ Rockwell, plagada de referencias a bandas clÃ¡sicas como Led Zeppelin, o a lugares clÃ¡sicos de California como Topanga, a los que suele volver seguido. Porque a pesar de haber nacido en la costa este, el â€œlugar mentalâ€ de Lana nunca deja de ser California, o, mejor dicho, una construcciÃ³n mitificada de una California donde conviven las estrellas del viejo Hollywood, los Beach Boys y los Eagles, el Laurel Canyon, y las estrellas de rock de glam-metal de los aÃ±os 80.
Las canciones de Lana del Rey estÃ¡n llenas de referencias a Ã­conos de Hollywood y de la cultura pop de Estados Unidos (Foto: Getty Images)
La muerte tambiÃ©n es uno de los temas que siempre la obsesionaron, desde su disco debut, pero ahora parece encararla desde otro lado. En su Ãºltimo disco, ya serio candidato a integrar todas las listas de los mejores del aÃ±os, Did you know thereâ€™s a Tunnel under Ocean Blvd (â€SabÃ­as que hay un tÃºnel debajo de Ocean Boulevardâ€), abundan las referencias y name checks a figuras legendarias de la mÃºsica estadounidense como John Denver o Harry Nilson, pero tambiÃ©n a los Chilli Peppers. Una de las grandes novedades del disco es el componente espiritual, casi gospel, que sobrevuela toda la obra. My pastor told me when you leave all you take is your memory and Iâ€™m gonna take mine of you with me (â€Mi pastor me dijo que cuando te vas todo lo que te llevas es tu memoria y me llevarÃ© lo mio con vosâ€) canta en â€œThe Grantsâ€, la canciÃ³n que abre el disco.
Todo el personaje creado por Elizabeth Grant tiene California y la cultura estadounidense, mÃ¡s particularmente, la de la Costa Oeste, como transfondo insoslayable. El Chateau Marmont frecuentado por las estrellas del viejo Hollywood como Greta Garbo, pero tambiÃ©n por los cantautores folkies de los 70 como Joni Mitchell o David Crosby, Allen Ginsberg y Jack Kerouac abandonando Nueva York por el San Francisco de los aÃ±os 50, el movimiento hippie de Haight Ashbury y su contracara oscura con los asesinatos de Charles Manson en Cielo Drive, Dennis Wilson ahogÃ¡ndose en Marina del Rey mientras buscaba un portarretrato con una foto junto a su esposa en Ã©l que se habÃ­a caÃ­do al mar. Lana Del Rey podrÃ­a existir tranquilamente dentro de Los Ãngeles siniestro e inquietante generado por David Lynch en Mulholland Drive. Pero por suerte lo hace en este plano, para que todos podamos musicalizar nuestros propios mitos.

title: Lana Del Rey sort " Say Yes To Heaven " 10 ans aprÃ¨s lâ€™avoir enregistrÃ©
content:
Christopher Polk / Billboard via Getty Images Christopher Polk / Billboard via Getty Images
MUSIQUE - Ses fans ne lâ€™attendaient plus et pourtant. Dix ans aprÃ¨s lâ€™avoir enregistrÃ©, le single Say Yes To Heaven de Lana Del Rey est enfin sorti sur les plateformes de streaming et sur la chaÃ®ne YouTube officielle de la chanteuse.

title: Does Lana Del Ray's song 'Margaret' disclose Jack Antonoff's wedding date?
content:
Does Lana Del Ray's song 'Margaret' disclose Jack Antonoff's wedding date?
Lana Del Rey's recent collaboration with Jack Antonoff, titled "Margaret," sparked speculation among fans about the wedding date of Antonoff and Emmy-nominated actress Margaret Qualley.
Del Rey's lyrics include the line, "join the party/By the way, the party is Dec. 18." However, Qualley confirmed to the Los Angeles Times that the wedding is not on that date, and Del Rey did not include their actual wedding date in her song.
â€œ[Lana] was kind enough to not put my real wedding date in the song. But I love that song so much. It makes me feel like Iâ€™m living in a dream. Sheâ€™s my favorite poet. I adore her,â€ Qualley said.
During a recent concert, Antonoff revealed that Del Rey had suggested writing a song about his fiancÃ©e, which turned out to be "Margaret."
The mystery of Del Rey's Dec. 18 party invitation remains unresolved, but it could be related to events such as Keith Richards' 80th birthday or the fourth anniversary of Donald Trump's first impeachment trial.
Lana Del Rey's latest album, titled "Did You Know That There's A Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd," was released on March 24. It's her ninth album and her lengthiest yet, featuring intricate songs about family and romantic relationships.

title: Lana Del Rey â€˜Candy Necklaceâ€™ Video With Jon Batiste: Watch
content:
Lana Del Rey premiered the glamorous grayscale music video for â€œCandy Necklaceâ€ featuring Jon Batiste on Wednesday (May 10).
However, rather than sharing a typical visual, the alt-pop chanteuse uses the nearly 11-minute clip to take her fans behind-the scenes right in the midst of the action. Just as sheâ€™s escorted into a moody L.A. estate by the legendary John Waters, the camera cuts to the director explaining, â€œSo Lana? All that was cool. Weâ€™re gonna go and reset for a shot on John, his reveal.â€
The atmospheric music never stops; instead it draws the track off Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd out to double its length, as Del Rey sings, â€œYouâ€™ve been actinâ€™ pretty reckless/ Dancinâ€™ like the young and restless/ And Iâ€™m obsessed with this/ All his candy necklacesâ€ as Batiste accompanies her on the piano.
Later, production captures the â€œA&Wâ€ singer explaining the entire concept of the video, saying, â€œWhy it was all supposed to be behind the scenes was because all these women who, like, changed their name, changed their hair, like me and stuff. Itâ€™s like they all fell into these different snakeholes. So the whole point is like, how do you learn from that and not fall into your own thing?â€
Del Reyâ€™s latest album bowed at No. 3 on the Billboard 200 upon its release last March and also contains singles like the title track, â€œA&Wâ€ and â€œThe Grantsâ€ as well as additional collabs with SYML (â€œParis, Texasâ€), Father John Misty (â€œLet the Light Inâ€), Bleachers (â€œMargaretâ€) and more.
Watch Del Rey and Batiste in the brooding video for â€œCandy Necklaceâ€ below.

title: Lana Del Rey and Jon Batiste Share New â€œCandy Necklaceâ€ Video: Watch
content:
Lana Del Rey and Jon Batiste have released the music video for their Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd collaboration, â€œCandy Necklace.â€ The lengthy visual, directed by Rich Lee, finds Del Rey acting as Hollywood icons like Marilyn Monroe and Elizabeth Short. Watch the new video below.
â€œCandy Necklaceâ€ is the first Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd song to get the music video treatment. Lana Del Rey had previewed the album with the title track, â€œA&W,â€ and â€œThe Grants.â€
Revisit Pitchforkâ€™s reviews of Lana Del Reyâ€™s 2021 studio albums, Chemtrails Over the Country Club and Blue Banisters.

title: The Best Albums of 2023 (So Far)
content:
billy woods and Kenny Segal, Maps
Hailing from New York City by way of Washington, D.C., and Zimbabwe, rapper and Backwoodz Studioz label head billy woods is a writer with an expansive purview and a rhymer with a seemingly inexhaustible supply of intriguing flows. Maps, his second collaborative album with L.A. producer Kenny Segal, turns the experience of touring the world into a kind of heroâ€™s journey, a story of zany inklings and occurrences coming between the traveling musician and the comfort of home.
Read Craig Jenkinsâ€™s interview with billy woods.
Fires in the Distance, Air Not Meant for Us
Air Not Meant for Us, the sophomore album from Connecticut death and doom merchants Fires in the Distance, achieves a precarious blend, counterbalancing a collection of musings on decay and despair with gorgeous arrangements that tease out brighter melodies without undercutting a songâ€™s heaviness. Pianos dart around punishing riffs throughout â€œWisdom of the Falling Leaves,â€ and instrumental breaks in opener â€œHarbingersâ€ make the noise and desperation of the chorus â€” â€œTheyâ€™re gaining on us!â€ â€” hit even harder. The sweetness punctuating these anguished observations is a message: Donâ€™t let that beauty die.
Bell Witch, Futureâ€™s Shadow Part 1: The Clandestine Gate
Futureâ€™s Shadow Part 1: The Clandestine Gate, the fifth album from Seattle doom-metal duo Bell Witch, is a careful step forward for singer-bassist Dylan Desmond and singer-drummer Jesse Shreibman. Itâ€™s an 83-minute continuous song cycle inspired by reading Nietzsche and watching the unnervingly patient films of Russian director Andrei Tarkovsky, itâ€™s a meditation on the promise and dread that greet us each new morning, and itâ€™s a massive expanse of swelling organ drones, beguiling poetry, and triumphant riffs, the opening act of a planned triptych. While Clandestine Gateâ€™s dawn illuminates fields of pulsing worms and decaying corpses, one wonders what terrors await as Futureâ€™s Shadow creeps into the twilight hours.
Everything But the Girl, Fuse
Tracey Thorn and Ben Watt hung up their successful musical collaboration Everything But the Girl in 2000 after they became parents to twins and band engagements began to clash with familial obligations. 2020 cleared their schedules, and they put parallel careers as authors and solo artists on halt to craft Fuse, the 11th Everything But the Girl album and a careful comeback that pleases admirers of the plaintive, elegant dance-pop of â€œWrongâ€ and â€œMissingâ€ while sharpening the writing and gently modernizing the production.
Read Craig Jenkinsâ€™s review of Fuse.
Kara Jackson, Why Does the Earth Give Us People to Love
On her debut studio album, Kara Jackson, our 2019-2020 National Youth Poet Laureate, sings with the aching honesty that gripped fans of her writing, sharing wry observations on romance â€” â€œEvery man thinks Iâ€™m his fuckinâ€™ mother / Good for milk and good for supper,â€ â€œtherapyâ€ laments â€” and grief, emoting plainly over lush arrangements like the constellation of strings and voices that envelope Jacksonâ€™s voice in â€œfreeâ€ or the bells and pianos of â€œdickhead blues.â€ Why Does the Earth Give Us People to Love dresses modern concerns in the garb of a â€™70s singer-songwriter album.
Metallica, 72 Seasons
Much is rightfully made of the â€™80s and early-â€™90s heyday of Metallica and the force with which the Cali quartet helped carry metal music into mainstream American popular culture, but itâ€™s worth noting that right now, Robert Trujillo has been in the band longer than any other bass player, and the lineup introduced on 2008â€™s Death Magnetic really seems to have jelled. 72 Seasons, Metallicaâ€™s 11th studio album, makes a satisfying peace with the past in its sweeping survey of sounds from different parts of the catalogue and in the stories singer-guitarist James Hetfield tells, where protagonists escape the ghouls that hound them.
Read Craig Jenkinsâ€™s review of 72 Seasons.
Yaeji, With a Hammer
On her debut album, With a Hammer, Korean American singer-songwriter and producer Yaeji showcases the excellence in sound architecture she fine-tuned across EPs and mixtapes like 2017â€™s Yaeji or 2020â€™s What We Drew. Melodies and rhythms stack carefully and methodically, from opener â€œSubmerge FM,â€ a jazz-flute reverie that transforms incrementally into a pillowy bass-music groove, to the title track, where scattered drums and staccato vocals abruptly morph into a spacious pop banger. Sweet melodies, strange textures, and disparate genres clash and combine, giving the feeling of waking up inside a video game.
Read E. Alex Jungâ€™s profile of Yaeji.
boygenius, the record
Boygenius â€” comprising Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers, and Lucy Dacus, each an impressive indie-rock singer-songwriter in her own right â€” set anticipation sky high with their self-titled 2018 debut EP. This yearâ€™s bluntly titled the record meets those expectations head on. From the bittersweet romance of â€œTrue Blueâ€ to the smirking self-destruction of â€œ$20â€ to the nihilistic resign of â€œSatanist,â€ the record is the sound of a few of the sharpest pens doing devastating work over a batch of the catchiest tunes of their careers.
Read Craig Jenkinsâ€™s review of the record.

title: Taylor Swiftâ€™s 2022 LP Midnights climbs charts following release with Ice Spice
content:
M idnights by Taylor Swift has leapt to the number two position in the albums chart following the release of The Till Dawn Edition, the Official Charts Company has said.
The new version of the album includes a remix of Karma with American rapper Ice Spice, an updated recording of the Lana Del Rey collaboration Snow On The Beach and new track Hits Different.
Swift revealed to her fans that The Till Dawn Edition could be pre-ordered in a post that announced the release of a new special edition CD with an unheard track called Youâ€™re Losing Me, which she said would only be available for purchase at shows in East Rutherford, New Jersey.
Following its release last October, Midnights debuted at number one in the charts and became Spotifyâ€™s most streamed album in a single day.
Midnights has now climbed eight spots in the charts to number two, sitting under the album Broken By The Desire To Be Heavenly Sent by Lewis Capaldi.
Capaldiâ€™s album has become the fastest-selling album of the year so far, according to the Official Charts Company, having totalled an excess of 95,000 chart units around the time it got to number one.
Elsewhere, Harry Stylesâ€™ album Harryâ€™s House has also climbed eight places in the albums chart to number three and is followed by Ed Sheeranâ€™s Subtract â€“ positioned at number four.
In spot number five is album The Highlights which was released in 2021 by The Weeknd.
Reigning the singles charts is Miracle by Calvin Harris and Ellie Goulding which has been number one for eight non-consecutive weeks.
This is followed by David Kushnerâ€™s Daylight, which is in the number two position, while Calm Down by Rema claims the number three spot.
At number four is As It Was by Harry Styles, followed by React from Switch Disco and Ella Henderson.
In the singles top 40, two tracks from the late Tina Turner have returned, with The Best re-entering at number 25, while 1984 song Whatâ€™s Love Got To Do With It returns at number 35.
The â€œQueen of Rock and Rollâ€ died â€œpeacefullyâ€ in May at her home near Zurich, Switzerland, aged 83.

title: â€œBrincadeirasâ€ com aparÃªncia de Lana Del Rey sÃ£o gordofobia disfarÃ§ada
content:
A volta de Lana Del Rey, apÃ³s quatro anos longe dos palcos, aconteceu no Ãºltimo sÃ¡bado (27), no Rio de Janeiro. Se na plateia a cantora foi muito bem recebida pelos fÃ£s brasileiros, na internet, uma onda de comentÃ¡rios sobre a sua aparÃªncia ganharam espaÃ§o. Alguns deles criticavam abertamente o corpo da artista, condenando o ganho de peso, mas muitos dos posts escondiam a gordofobia por trÃ¡s de â€œbrincadeirasâ€ â€“ que de inofensivas ou engraÃ§adas nÃ£o tinham nada.
Ao republicar um vÃ­deo da Lana no aeroporto do Rio de Janeiro, em que ela vestia um jeans bÃ¡sico, uma camiseta branca de manga longa e um casaco, um usuÃ¡rio tweetou que â€œela tinha muita cara de que trabalha num escritÃ³rio ali no centro do Rio e sÃ³ saiu pra almoÃ§ar no self-service com os amigos da firmaâ€. Em seguida, muitos outros comentÃ¡rios comeÃ§aram a comparar a aparÃªncia da cantora com outros estereÃ³tipos de trabalhadores e pessoas mais humildes. â€œEla realmente tem cara das pessoas que eu atendo no restaurante e passa vr ou ticketâ€, escreveu outra seguidora.
E nem todos os posts vinham de haters. Muitos fÃ£s e pessoas que admiram a cantora acabaram entrando no que acharam que era apenas uma brincadeira. â€œSe chama Alana, administra empresas e nas horas vagas costuma ir a bares de esquina tomar aquela geladinha e pegar um praia aos domingos. Laninha Ã© tudoâ€, tweetou uma delas, por exemplo.
Acontece que a cantora sempre optou por um estilo mais simples, sÃ³ que as crÃ­ticas sÃ³ comeÃ§aram depois que ela ganhou peso. Uma seguidora ressaltou isso: â€œEla sempre foi â€˜gente como a genteâ€™, sempre usou roupas simples e nÃ£o falavam isso quando ela magra. Antes ela era a â€˜sad girlâ€™, todo mundo queria ser igual, passar a mesma vibeâ€. Sem contar que as comparaÃ§Ãµes tambÃ©m podem refletir um prec
Infelizmente, por conta da gordofobia, Lana e muitas outras mulheres que nÃ£o estÃ£o no corpo (considerado) padrÃ£o viram alvo de ataques e â€œpiadasâ€ por usarem roupas que, quando estÃ£o no corpo magro, nÃ£o sÃ£o alvo dos mesmos comentÃ¡rios.
NÃ³s mostramos aqui na CAPRICHO quando a modelo Tess Holliday sofreu vÃ¡rias crÃ­ticas ao usar um vestido de tule com morangos bordados no Grammy Awards. Na Ã©poca, o mesmo vestido era uma das peÃ§as mais populares do TikTok, com mais de 13 milhÃµes de visualizaÃ§Ãµes na hashtag #strawberrydress, que faz referÃªncia a ele.
Muitas vezes, nÃ£o Ã© sÃ³ uma â€œbrincadeiraâ€ ou o â€œlook que nÃ£o combinouâ€, Ã© gordofobia â€“ e nÃ£o dÃ¡ mais para deixar isso passar.

title: Scouse band's 'crazy dream' of playing Glastonbury comes true
content:
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Invalid email Something went wrong, please try again later.
Love Glastonbury? From tickets to headliners, sign up here for the latest updates from Worthy Farm
The lead singer of an emerging Scouse band has said their â€œcrazy dreamâ€ has come true after it was announced that they would be performing at Glastonbury this year.
Stone are an indie-rock band, who played their first gig just over three years ago at The Shipping Forecast on Slater Street. As part of their recent UK tour, they performed in their hometown in April at the 02 Academy on Hotham Street.
Now, the bandâ€™s recent successes look set to continue, with frontman Fin Power announcing on Twitter this morning that they would be playing at the UKâ€™s most famous music festival. They will be part of the BBC Music Introducing stage.
READ MORE: Maya Jama says public will choose couples in first Love Island vote
Wavertree-born Fin, who first visited Glastonbury aged five, said he was excited to show the rest of the band how â€œmagicalâ€ the festival is. He said: â€œThis is a crazy dream come true for us as a band and we canâ€™t believe it really. When I was five years old I went to Glastonbury for the first time on a year when it rained and poured so badly that pretty much most of the festival was flooded.â€
He added: â€œI remember crying loads and my mum made me carry a box of red wine so I could feel helpful. Little did I know I would be playing the same festival 18 years later that claimed my five year old tears and covered me in mud.â€
Stoneâ€™s other members are Alex Smith, Sarah Surrage and Elliot Gill. Speaking to the ECHO earlier this year, Fin said they had achieved their hopes of a career in music after â€œgrafting for seven yearsâ€ through various different bands.
The group met through chance meetings at college and education. Soon after that first gig in town, they were embarking on karaoke-fuelled tours of Europe, supporting artists such as The Kooks in Portugal and Louis Tomlinson in Malaga.
Fin said: "I remember watching other bands do live tours and I envied them. I read once that it takes 20 years to become an overnight success, which rings true in our case.â€
Their hits range from the politically-charged Money to the melancholic Save Yourself, with the band describing their genre of music as "post-apocalyptic scally rock". Stone's gigs, labelled as "vicious and beautiful" by Fin, have become well known among indie lovers. Their Liverpool performance earned a five star review from the ECHO.
Glastonbury 2023 will take place from June 21 to June 25. Fellow Scouser Jamie Webster will also be present at Left Field, with other confirmed acts including Lewis Capaldi, Lilzzo and Lana Del Rey.
Discover, learn, grow. We are Curiously. Follow us on TikTok , Instagram , Facebook and Twitter .

Com os cabelos presos em uma tranÃ§a e sentada sobre uma toalha fina, Lana usava um body bege decotado e de mangas compridas.

title: U.K. Singles Chart: â€˜Miracleâ€™ Enters Seventh Week at No. 1
content:
Calvin Harris and Ellie Goulding enter a seventh non-consecutive week at No. 1 in the U.K. with â€œMiracleâ€ (Columbia), while Lana Del Rey enjoys a chart miracle of her own.
â€œMiracle,â€ the throwback rave number, is once again the most-streamed song in the U.K., as it becomes Harrisâ€™ second-longest reigning single in his homeland, passing the six-week streak for â€œWe Found Loveâ€ with Rihanna and â€œPromisesâ€ with Sam Smith. Itâ€™s just one week from equaling the Scottish EDM starâ€™s longest reign, the eight-week run for â€œOne Kissâ€ with Dua Lipa.
The seven-week stretch for â€œMiracleâ€ sees Goulding rise up the all-time ranks. Other female acts to enjoy seven weeks at No. 1 include Cher with â€œBelieveâ€ and the Spice Girls with â€œWannabe.â€
The highest debut this week belongs to Lana Del Rey, whose â€œSay Yes To Heavenâ€ (Polydor) starts at No. 9. Originally recorded in 2012, â€œSay Yesâ€ failed to secure a spot on any Del Rey album. The somber tune sat on the shelf until it was leaked in recent years and made its own journey on TikTok. Itâ€™s Del Reyâ€™s sixth top 10 appearance, and first solo U.K. top tier entry since â€œBorn To Dieâ€ also hit No. 9 in 2012.
Eurovision 2023 is in the books, but a trio of songs from the annual song festival continue to fly high on the U.K. chart.
Following a record-setting week for Eurovision on the Official U.K. Chart, the 2023 champion, Swedenâ€™s Loreen, sees her winning song â€œTattooâ€ (UMG International) dip 2-4; Finlandâ€™s KÃ¤Ã¤rijÃ¤â€™s â€œCha Cha Chaâ€ (WM Finland) down 6-15, and Great Britain rep Mae Mullerâ€™s â€œI Wrote A Songâ€ (Capitol) down 9-18.
According to the Official Charts Company, â€œTattooâ€ is the first Eurovision entry to spend two consecutive weeks in the U.K. Official Singles Chart top 5 in 27 years. The last to do so was Australia-born U.K. contestant Gina Gâ€™s â€œOoh Ahhâ€¦Just A Little Bit,â€ which logged nine consecutive weeks in the top 5 back in 1996, including a one-week stint at No. 1.
Finally, Australiaâ€™s pop princess Kylie Minogue bags her 52nd U.K. top 40 with â€œPadam Padamâ€ (BMG). The electro pop tune new at No. 26, on the chart, published May 26, for the Melbourne pop veteranâ€™s highest-charting song in her adopted homeland since â€œInto The Blueâ€ hit No. 12 back in 2014. â€œPadam Padamâ€ is the most-downloaded song of the week in the U.K., for top spot on Official Singles Sales Chart and Download Chart.

According to Del Rey, Swift originally asked her to sing the entire second verse of the original version of â€œSnow on the Beach.â€ â€œMy job as a feature on a big artistâ€™s album is to make sure I help add to the production of the song, so I was more focused on the production,â€ she told Billboard. â€œShe was very adamant that she wanted me to be on the album, and I really liked that song.â€
Ice Spice has had a breakout year following the success of â€œMunch.â€ She recently shared â€œBoyâ€™s a Liar Pt 2â€ with PinkPantheress; sheâ€™s also set to appear on the Barbie soundtrack alongside Nicki Minaj on â€œBarbie World.â€ Del Reyâ€™s new album Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd came out earlier this year. title: Taylor Swift announces 'Midnights' deluxe album with Ice Spice
content:
Singer Taylor Swift has something special in store for her fans. She has announced a new deluxe edition of her 'Midnights' album, titled 'Midnights: Til Dawn', that will feature Ice Spice as her guest on a fresh version of 'Karma' and additional, newly recorded lead vocals from Lana Del Rey on their 'Snow on the Beach' collaboration, Variety reported.
Digital and physical editions will each have a format-exclusive track. For the digital release, it will be "Hits Different," a song that was previously only available on the Target version of "Midnights." More interestingly for fans, the physical edition will have a "Vault" track never before heard from the "Midnights" writing sessions. Although Swift's announcement of the collaboration with Ice Spice made no mention of a music video, the image that she released to go along with the reveal strongly indicates that a video may already be in the can.
"SO much to tell you. I'm a massive fan of this brilliant artist and after getting to know her I can confirm: she is THE ONE to watch. So delighted to say that Karma Featuring the incredible @icespice will be out TOMORROW night at MIDNIGHT ET as a part of the new Midnights (Til Dawn Edition) deluxe album that you can pre-order now at store.taylorswift.com! In addition to Karma Ft Ice Spice... You asked for it, we listened: Lana and I went back into the studio specifically to record more Lana on Snow on the Beach. Love u @honeymoon," she posted on Instagram. Meanwhile, Ice Spice's popularity has exploded since she first shot to viral fame with "Munch (Feelin' U)" last fall. Her debut EP, Like..?, arrived in January on 10K Projects/Capitol, and Ice Spice proceeded to score top 10 smashes on the Hot 100 with the PinkPantheress team-up "Girl's a Liar Pt. 2" and the Nicki Minaj-assisted remix to her song "Princess Diana," Billboard reported. (ANI)
(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)

title: Taylor Swift Announces Midnights Vault Track & Ice Spice Collab
content:
Watch : Taylor Swift Says She's Never Been Happier 1 Month After Joe Alwyn Split
As Taylor Swift sings, two is better than one.
And now, the 12-time Grammy winner is collaborating with another artist for a remix of her Midnights hit "Karma." No need to guess who is filling in the blank space as Taylor recently revealed that Ice Spice will be The 1 featured on the track.
"Um. SO much to tell you," Taylor wrote on Instagram May 24. "I'm a massive fan of this brilliant artist and after getting to know her I can confirm: she is THE ONE to watch."
While fans aren't out of the woods just yet in terms of having to wait for the song to drop, the countdown won't be much longer. In fact, Taylor said she's "so delighted" to announce that "Karma" featuring the "incredible" Ice Spice will drop May 26 at, of course, midnight as part of the Midnights (Til Dawn Edition) deluxe album.
And she isn't the only one excited about the release.
"Karma ft me tmm night," Ice Spice wrote in a separate Instagram post. "thxx @taylorswift for being the coolest person on earth ilu 5/26."

content:

Swifties still have to wait over a month for Speak Now (Taylorâ€™s Version), but Taylor Swift is giving her fans something else to munch on in the meantime. That is, a remix of â€œKarmaâ€ with up-and-coming drill-pop rapper Ice Spice. â€œIâ€™m a massive fan of this brilliant artist and after getting to know her I can confirm: she is THE ONE to watch,â€ Swift wrote on social media. Ice Spice confirmed the news with love on Twitter: â€œsweetest person ever thank u sm ğŸ˜ğŸ’œ i love yuuuu.â€ The remix is part of a new Midnights (Til Dawn Edition), out May 26 on midnight. And thatâ€™s not it â€” Swift is also releasing a new version of â€œSnow on the Beachâ€ with a bit more Lana after fansâ€™ jokes about the Midnights track. â€œYou asked for it, we listened,â€ Swift wrote. The Til Dawn Edition also features â€œHits Different,â€ the Target exclusive track for Midnights, on streaming platforms for the first time. In addition to being available for preorder, the Til Dawn Edition will also be for sale at Swiftâ€™s New Jersey shows this weekend as a special physical edition including the â€œvaultâ€ track â€œYouâ€™re Losing Me.â€
The Ice Spice remix is Swiftâ€™s first hip-hop collaboration since Reputation, when she worked with Future on the song â€œEnd Game.â€ And it could be a bit of karma after Swiftâ€™s rumored new boyfriend, the 1975â€™s Matty Healy, was part of a racist discussion about Ice Spice on a recent podcast appearance. Healy apologized to Ice Spice at a 1975 show in Auckland, New Zealand, last month. â€œItâ€™s not because Iâ€™m annoyed that me joking got misconstrued,â€ he told the crowd. â€œItâ€™s because I donâ€™t want Ice Spice to think Iâ€™m a dick. I love you, Ice Spice. Iâ€™m so sorry.â€ Just remember who Taylorâ€™s real boyfriend is.

title: "The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel" and the rise of the nepo parent
content:
The ethereal piano. The sweeping, memorable melody which feels both timeless and bittersweet. We could be in a Lana Del Rey song. But we're not. We're listening to a track by her father, pianist and composer Robert Grant (Del Rey's birth name is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant). The song, from his upcoming album "Lost at Sea," due out June 9, is music only, but one could easily imagine Del Rey's nostalgic vocals drifting over the keys (and they will, on several tracks). "The talent really runs in the family," reads one comment on a YouTube video of another song.
It's almost like â€¦ it's really hard to break into the arts and having a famous, wealthy and industry-established family helps.
Grant senior has become the latest to claim nepo parent fame (something he jokes openly about to the point of merchandise). Late last year, prompted by a New York Magazine cover story, the phrase "nepo baby" entered the cultural bloodstream. Referring to the adult child of famous parents, helped along by their family's showbiz connections, associations and wealth, the internet was suddenly full of examples of celebrities who had ridden that nepotism wave. Gracie Abrams? J.J. Abrams' daughter. Dakota Johnson? The child of Melanie Griffith and Don Johnson. TimothÃ©e Chalamet? His mother is Broadway star Nicole Flender, father is filmmaker Rodman Flender and grandfather was screenwriter Harold Flender. It's almost like . . . it's really hard to break into the arts and having a famous, wealthy and industry-established family helps.
The nepo parent trend flips the idea. The kid is the one who has made it. And now their older, often retired parent or parents are coming along. And as with Grant, a white-haired former real estate broker and CEO who now is a deep sea fisherman, the trend is looked upon lovingly. It's sweet that the album cover of "Lost at Sea" recalls Del Rey's 2019 "Norman F****ing Rockwell!" with a figure standing on a boat. On "Late Night with Seth Myers," actor Ike Barinholtz joked affectionately about his nepo dad, Alan Barinholtz, a former lawyer and latent aspiring actor, "He's a new ingenue in Los Angeles. And his name is my dad."
But when nepo parents come to "The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel," they come with a whole host of other issues involving pressure and expectation. Even though the roles are reversed, it's something else for Midge (Rachel Brosnahan) to handle, to manage both the emotions and career of her mother.
In its fifth and final season on Prime Video, "Maisel," has treated us to a series of flash-forwards through time, designed to let us know where the characters end up, many years later. "Maisel" is no "Quantum Leap" and these time jumps are not always satisfying or sensible in the context of the long-established characters. Joel (Michael Zegen) goes to jail, for example, largely to protect his ex-wife Midge. Alex Borstein's Susie becomes a pothead, for some reason. And Midge's mother Rose (Marin Hinkle) is a matchmaker, still, many years on.
Marin Hinkle (Rose Weissman) in "The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel" (Prime Video)Her rise to matchmaking, as detailed in multiple seasons, has been a bit rocky. She was threatened by the mafia of established matchmakers (including a lovely turn by the wonderful Kelly Bishop). They threatened her husband Abe too, and burned down a beloved tea room in retribution. But Rose is good at finding love for clients â€” and managing their parents â€” and she persists.
In the future "Maisel" shows us, something has gone wrong. Or at least, gotten expensive. It's 1973, and Rose, in a Cher-type gauzy Mumu ensemble and flowers in her hair bigger than her head, is trying to star in a commercial for her matchmaking business. She's going regional and getting TV ads, baby. But it's not easy or natural for her. Midge assures her that the crew's complaining is "completely normal." Midge does a lot of reassuring.
Rachel Brosnahan (Miriam 'Midge' Maisel), Marin Hinkle (Rose Weissman) and Caroline Aaron (Shirley Maisel) in "The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel" (Prime Video)
Although it's not the child capitalizing on the parents' success, it is the child trying desperately to keep their parent happy.
On many levels, the nepo parent phenomenon makes sense. Artistic ability is sometimes inherited, often modeled and when an older parent starts doing the thing that their child loves, it's the ultimate taking an interest in their children's lives. Barinholtz describes the nepo parent as "a good thing . . . Everyone likes a nepo dad." We love a late bloomer, like Annette Badland of "Ted Lasso" or even Jennifer Coolidge.
With "Maisel," the nepotism is more adjacent than, for example, Catherine Scorsese becoming an actor after being cast by her son Martin Scorsese. But Midge is still using her connections to give her mother access, possibly (as the flashforward to the '70s shows us) after Rose has stopped being really good or completely invested in what she does. "You wanted this, remember," Midge tells her mother. And although it's not the child capitalizing on the parents' success, it is the child trying desperately to keep their parent happy. It's still pressure, as Midge stands behind the camera the whole time so Rose can look and say her lines to her, which seems like something Mama Rose might do.
Want a daily wrap-up of all the news and commentary Salon has to offer? Subscribe to our morning newsletter, Crash Course.
As the departure of housekeeper, cook, nanny and all-around apartment manager Zelda (Matilda Szydagis) proves, Rose has never been great about being grown-up. She doesn't understand what a linen closet is or how to turn on a vacuum (in her defense, Midge and Tony Shalhoub's Abe don't either). Rose's best season was when she went to Paris, leaving behind her husband with his learned helplessness and grandchildren in order to find herself, to latently be actualized. And it feels like she never really recovered from being pulled away from there, and the satisfying, simple life she had carved out for herself. In the future, she looks like a caricature of herself in the matchmaking commercial, propped up by her famous daughter, and that's a sad ending for such a complex and once independent character.

title: Lana Del Rey Takes Puff Of Fan's Vape At Dublin Show
content:
Lana Del Rey was seen smoking a fan's vape during her show at Dublin's 3Arena on Friday.
The Norman F******g Rockwell singer was performing in the capital on Friday after announcing the gig just a week and a half prior, with tickets selling out in minutes.
Today's top videos STORY CONTINUES BELOW
Lana has been known to vape during her shows -- including one infamous incident where she stopped a show so she could find her lost vape -- and one person at the barrier managed to give her a hand just in case she didn't have one on her.
I gave Lana my vape tonight in Dublin ğŸ˜­ queen was looking sick and like she needed a puff pic.twitter.com/MFA8Jx4z7R â€” Neil ğŸ¦Š (@bruthaniall) July 7, 2023
Lana fan Neil was in front row at the show, and once Lana came down to greet her fans, he offered her a hit of his disposable vape, with her immediately taking a hit.
The clip went viral on Twitter, with Neil tweeting 'I gave Lana my vape tonight in Dublin, queen was looking sick and like she needed a puff.'
Lost Mary in hand, Lana took a hit of the vape with pleasure -- only realising that it probably wasn't the best idea in front of over 10,000 people. Pic: Neil/Twitter
Other fans thought the clip was hilarious, with one person surprised at how quickly she took the vape -- while another added 'HELP she took the biggest puff ever.'
Others joked that Neil needed to sell the vape on eBay now, while one person suggested something more creative, tweeting 'The way iâ€™d never use it again and place it in a glass container on display on my bookshelf for years to come.'

title: Lana Del Rey in Dublin: â€˜Iâ€™m sorry I didnâ€™t give you enough noticeâ€™
content:
Lana Del Rey
3Arena, Dublin
â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
Lana Del Rey walks on stage looking like a character from an old Hollywood movie or from an All-American fashion line going through a gloomy phase: Ralph Lauren with a splash of gothic.
â€œThey told me this was the land of the fairies and good luck,â€ she declares late in a rapturous concert. â€œIâ€™m sorry I didnâ€™t give you enough notice.â€
She refers to her decision to announce an Irish show just 10 daysâ€™ ahead of time. Itâ€™s Taylor Swift syndrome in reverse. Half of Ireland is in a flap over getting tickets to Swiftâ€™s Aviva residency next summer.
Meanwhile, Del Rey has slipped in practically under the radar with a guerrilla gig in the countryâ€™s largest indoor venue.
READ MORE
Lana Del Rey performs at 3Arena, Dublin. Photo: Tom Honan for The Irish Times.
Not that there is anything under-rehearsed about either Del Rey or the audience. An ecstatic performance doubles as full-throttle love-in. The crowd belts aloud the lyrics even to the B-sides (especially to the B-sides perhaps). Del Rey, doing her bit, soaks up the love in a state of humble elation.
The music never feels like an afterthought. Del Rey emerges dressed like a high-concept version of Linda Gray in Dallas or a grimdark Dolly Parton â€“ an American icon with just a hint of decadence. Her dress glimmers with sequins. Her hair, to quote her hit Summertime Sadness, is â€œdone up ... real big, beauty queen styleâ€.
With the volume in the room already cranked up to â€œear-splitting shriekâ€, she opens with A&W. Itâ€™s a brooding highlight from her latest album, Do You Know Thereâ€™s A Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd? Produced by Taylor Swift regular Jack Antonoff, the tune grapples with themes that recur throughout her repertoire: wild, unhinged obsession and physical passion used to fill in the blanks where true love should be.
Del Rey specialises in stately ballads, which somehow never tip into hairdryer belters â€“ she is, in the very best sense, the anti-Adele. But with much of the evening proceeding in a stately shuffle, she feels there is a requirement to liven up the set â€“ to put on both a visual and musical spectacle.
To that end, she is flanked by a swirl of vocalists and backing dancers. Their task is to bring melodrama to music which is already gloriously baroque. They fan around her as she swoons on Pretty When You Cry, from arguably her best album, Ultraviolence.
Lana Del Rey at the 3Arena. Photograph: Tom Honan/The Irish Times
Later, two of her ensemble waft back and on swings during Ride â€“ a bonus cut from her debut LP Born To Die, which has grown into an anthem even as it circles such grim subjects as alcoholism and intergenerational trauma.
Del Rey comes to Ireland a fortnight after her late arrival at the Glastonbury festival led to the organisers pulling the plug with one song left. In Dublin, sheâ€™s just a few minutes later than advertised, the concert a gripping celebration of her decade as a cult mega-star and her intense relationship with her audience.
There is some banter â€“ she talks about how moved she was by all the fans she has met in Ireland (she was in Temple Bar that morning giving out tickets to the show). She also plunges into the front row for a Princess Diana style ropewalk, posing for selfies and accepting bouquets (and then quietly chugs her vape as she returns to the stage).
The conclusion is glorious too. After the David Lynch fever-dream of Summertime Sadness, Del Rey brings out her breakthrough hit, Video Games, delivering the chorus from one of those swings. Higher and higher she soars. The crowd, singing along, soars higher yet, joining this melancholic cheerleader in her bruised rhapsody in red, white and blue.
A wave of smartphones capture the gig. Photograph: Tom Honan/The Irish Times
Lana Del Rey takes a seat during her set. Photograph: Tom Honan/The Irish Times
Lana Del Rey in Dublin. Photograph: Tom Honan/The Irish Times

title: What time is Lana Del Rey on stage for BST Hyde Park?
content:
L ana Del Rey has announced her support acts for when she will headline BST Hyde Park on Sunday July 9.
With just days to spare, fans had worried that the lack of a support bill might mean the enigmatic singer-songwriter would pull out. But she has now confirmed her collaborators Father John Misty and Gang of Youths will be the primary warm-up before she takes to the Great Oak Stage.
After her top-billed performance on Glastonburyâ€™s Other Stage was beset by technical issues, fans will be hoping the rare chance to see her perform in the UK will be free of hitches.
She will be the last of the British Summer Time headliners to perform â€“ following sets from Pink, Gwen Stefani, Bruce Springsteen, Billy Joel, Blackpink and Guns Nâ€™ Roses.
The US singer earlier this year released her ninth album, Did You Know Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Boulevard?
Fans can expect songs from the LP as well as favourites from previous records, judging by her setlists from her summer of touring festivals worldwide.
Other acts include The Last Dinner Party, SYML, Riopy, Tommy Genesis, Holly Macve, Etta Marcus, Kings Elliot and Siights. Several of those names also featured on Did You Know Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Boulevard?
Tickets are sold out except for the final few Great Oak Premium VIP seats. For those lucky enough to have tickets, here is what you need to know.
What time will Lana Del Rey be on stage?
Priority entry is at 1pm and general entry 2pm, with last entry at 8.30pm.
BST organisers have yet to confirm when Lana Del Rey or the support will be on stage.
However, when timings are revealed, fans will know to take them with a pinch of salt, especially given Del Rey was half an hour late to her set at Glastonbury.
So far, most of the acts have been on stage before 9pm.
There is a 10.30pm curfew and the show will be over by then, whether Del Rey has got through her setlist or not.
Lana Del Rey Gun ... singer's cheeky homage to Axl Rose at London gig 1 / 2 Lana Del Rey Gun ... singer's cheeky homage to Axl Rose at London gig lana2.jpg On song: Lana Del Rey performs at the Jazz Cafe lana.jpg Homage? The singer has been linked to Guns 'N Roses frontman Axl Rose
What will Lana Del Reyâ€™s setlist be?
Glastonbury fans will never know how the final quarter of her set would have sounded but the singer has been consistent in what she has played at previous festivals.

title: Lana Del Rey Enjoys A Spot Of Shopping In Temple Bar
content:
US superstar Lana Del Rey was spotted out and about in Dublin this week ahead of her sold-out 3Arena show on Friday.
The Video Games singer delighted fans in Temple Bar vintage shop Nine Crows, stopping in to browse the selection and even offering them tickets to her gig.
Today's top videos STORY CONTINUES BELOW
Lana announced an impromptu Dublin gig last month as part of her ongoing European tour, with Irish fans scrambling for the coveted tickets.
Influencer and Nine Crows employee Alex Morgan took to Instagram on Thursday to share her delight at rubbing shoulders with the songstress.
'I met Lana Del Ray earlier. Still shaking. What a gorgeous soul,' Alex excitedly wrote.
Alex shared a sweet snap of her and four of her fellow employees smiling alongside the singer, right before she invited them to the highly-anticipated gig.
The Video Games singer delighted fans in Temple Bar vintage shop Nine Crows, stopping in to browse the selection and even offering them tickets to her gig. Pic: David Wolff - Patrick/Getty Images
The superstar took to the stage at the 3Arena on Friday, July 7, in what will be one of the biggest concerts of the year.
Following on from scheduling issues at her landmark Glastonbury performance, the singer announced three new additions to her European tour in Amsterdam, Dublin and Paris.

title: Madison Beer Reacts to Lana Del Rey Shout-Out, Talks Upcoming Album
content:
Madison Beer reacts to Lana Del Rey giving her a shout-out on the red carpet of Billboardâ€™s 2023 Women In Music, reflects about growing up in the music industry in her new memoir, talks about her upcoming new album â€˜Silence Between Songsâ€™ and more.
Madison Beer
Itâ€™s like what kills you make you stronger? Like I didnâ€™t need to be stronger. I needed to be a kid. Hey guys, itâ€™s Madison Beer and you are watching Billboard News.
Rania Aniftos
Hey everybody, itâ€™s Rania Aniftos with Billboard News, and Iâ€™m here with the wonderful singer, songwriter, author Madison Beer.
Rania Aniftos
You have an exciting year, you just announced your album â€˜Silence Between Songs.â€™ And I would love to know the inspiration behind the song title because it seems metaphorical.
Madison Beer
Yeah, definitely is. I think that to summarize it sort of simply, I kind of have always been a person, you know, I got sort of really, really young doing this. And I feel like Iâ€™ve had a very busy 12 years or so in this industry. And I kind of convinced myself that, you know, the moments where I was making music, and I was on tour. And I was, you know, my busiest was actually when I was growing. But as Iâ€™ve gotten a little older, Iâ€™ve realized that itâ€™s actually been the moments that Iâ€™ve been able to tune out the noise and Iâ€™ve been able to be alone and really reflect and like, you know, be more isolated that Iâ€™ve actually grown the most. So. So yeah, itâ€™s been sort of the silence between songs, when the noises turned out that I feel like Iâ€™ve learned to I am the most.
Watch the full interview above!

title: Lana Del Rey in Ireland: Stage times, doors, setlist
content:
(via Getty Images)
Lana last performed in Ireland in 2019.
Lana Del Rey is coming to Dublin's 3Arena this Friday, 7th of July.
The singer announced a surprise gig just last week in Dublin, Amsterdam and Paris.
Lana said: "I love Europe and after playing Glastonbury, have decided to play a few more shows in various countries around my Hyde Park Show in London on July 9."
Last time, Lana Del Rey last performed in Dublin in 2019 at Malahide Castle.
Check out everything you need to know before the gig.
Stage times
Doors open at 6:30pm. Lana will be on stage between 8pm and 9pm.
Public transport
The 3Arena is very well served by public transport. The Luas Red Line will drop you right at the door and also serves Heuston and Connolly stations.
Dublin Bus also offers a number of bus routes. The 151 route runs every 10 minutes during rush hour.
Set list
The rumoured setlist that may be similar to her recent shows looks like this:

Bartender

Ultraviolence

Diet Mountain Dew

Did You Know That There's A Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd
Video Games
Tickets
The concert is sold out but keep an eye on Ticketmaster for a chance to grad a ticket from someone reselling.

title: Lana Del Rey: our greatest millennial troubadourâ€™s secret to success
content:
W hen you find yourself in the snow globe world of Lana Del Rey you immediately realise you couldnâ€™t be anywhere else. The pink-sunset desert vista is sepia-tinted and slightly solarised, the smell a mixture of bougainvillea and weed, the whole thing seen through the lens of David Lynch or Kourtney Roy. There are hints of the past, plenty of West Coast pop-cultural references, and a veneer of perennially doomed relationships.
It is VERY Lana.
She remains our greatest millennial troubadour, whose songs are saturated in Americana. Cinematic, melancholic and deliberately transgressive, she uses Californiaâ€™s tarnished dreams as a metaphor for her own, and vice versa. She mixes romance and dread like no one since Lou Reed. Sometimes itâ€™s a bit gloopy, but basically itâ€™s pretty damn good.
And her Hyde Park concert this weekend is one of the most hotly anticipated of the year.
Fresh from a confusing performance at Glastonbury, this week she brings her tortured beauty queen persona (detached yet sincere, coy but deadly) to London. Her last appearance here was six years ago at a one-off performance at the Academy in Brixton, a massively oversubscribed gig which sold out in minutes. As she attracts the kind of super fans who donâ€™t brook criticism, the show was more like a rally than a concert. She generated the kind of adulation not seen since Beatlemania.
Lana Del Rey at the 2023 Billboard Women in Music awards in March / AFP via Getty Images
With velvet green curtains draped from the top of the stage, as well as a smattering of trees and glitzy podiums, the set looked like one of those photographs of disused petrol stations in the Midwest that are so popular with art photographers these days. You know, Twin Peaks seen through the eyes of Wes Anderson. In Brixton she played just 14 songs, a kind of greatest hits setlist including Video Games, Blue Jeans and Summertime Sadness.
This new London date promises to be spectacular, not least because it gives her the opportunity to showcase her recent material, and in particular the classic set of songs on her 2019 album Norman F***ing Rockwell! as well as this yearâ€™s almost-as-good Did You Know That There Is a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd. Her previous two tours were not brought to the UK, meaning that she has not toured here since her Paradise tour 10 years ago.
In Lana Del Rey world you can cover a lot of neon-lit backstreets in a decade, a lot of California scrub, and a hell of a lot of West Coast freeway. In that time, she has spun new icons out of old, playing with imagery, tropes and touchstones of the past and separating them from their original context in such a way as to completely reinvent them.
A critic in the New Yorker said that her work is becoming more personal, if not necessarily autobiographical; this isnâ€™t as crass as it sounds and is perhaps an example of just how successful her alter ego has become at maturing. She might still be tragi-glam, but itâ€™s the kind of kohl-eyed style that only works if youâ€™ve got the energy and the talent to sustain it.
She is revered by musicians from the generation before hers: Stevie Nicks, who appeared on Del Reyâ€™s 2017 Lust for Life; Cat Power, whoâ€™s covered her White Mustang; and Courtney Love, who recently said that Del Rey and Kurt Cobain are â€œthe only two true musical geniuses Iâ€™ve ever known.â€
Elizabeth Woolridge Grantâ€™s decision to pursue her career using a stage name is no more complicated than Bob Dylanâ€™s. Robert Zimmerman may have taken a little longer to become famous, while white-bread East Coast boarding-school alum Grant obviously felt that Lana Del Rey had more of an enigmatic feel to it. Is her angsty rebellion simply a kind of sullen glamour? Is her low-fi chamber pop just the pivot of an anxious generation, or is it more than that? Some have said that she increasingly paws for happiness in a world more hardened than the one in which her star rose, although maybe sheâ€™s just better now at impersonating how she feels.
Promotional of Lana Del Rey shot from 2021 / Handout
â€œWith past stuff, I would talk about the garden of evil and good and bad, but I really was meeting some characters,â€ she told Billie Eilish earlier in the year. â€œLike they used to say, â€˜When girls got to Hollywood, they were fresh off the boatâ€™. I didnâ€™t hear that term until later, but I did meet some people that I thought were really cool who were like, â€˜Do you want to go to the Guns Nâ€™ Roses concert?â€™ And I would be like, â€˜Yeah.â€™ Then, somehow, I would be sitting in a garden and I would see David Lynch behind a red curtain with a cigarette.
â€œI got to LA I was mostly touring. I didnâ€™t know that many people. I had a lot of random experiences that I wrote about, and at the time, they made me really happy because I was like, â€˜Iâ€™m not just watching someone else live their life, Iâ€™m living my life,â€™ which was new for me because Iâ€™ve always been so shy. I think the storytelling vibe that people get is because I was just in awe of the things that were going on. Coming from a farming town, LA was never a possibility. My brother and sister and I always say, every time we drive through a perfectly symmetrical palm tree lane, we feel like weâ€™re on a set. Maybe it was my lens on how heightened everything felt.â€
When her spaceship lands in Hyde Park at the weekend, she will no doubt be greeted with a kind of blind appreciation, but after her disastrous Glastonbury performance a few weeks ago the press will not be so forgiving. Being half an hour late, blaming your hairdresser and misunderstanding the curfew didnâ€™t endear her to anyone who waited for her on the Other Stage. Especially as she didnâ€™t have enough time to play her signature hit, Video Games.
However, for some her appearance on Sunday will be the closest they come to a religious experience this year, a physical manifestation of a character who has spent much of her career amplifying a weird hinterland.
Letâ€™s see.
Lana Del Rey plays BST Hyde Park on July 9; bst-hydepark.com
