title: BST Hyde Park updates fans amid Lana Del Rey 'cancellation' rumours
content:
Love Glastonbury? From tickets to headliners, sign up here for the latest updates from Worthy Farm
BST Hyde Park festival-goers have been given an update about headlining act Lana Del Rey as rumours circulated that she might have her set cancelled. Over the last few days, many fans have speculated the American songstress won't be taking to the stage at this year's event due to minimal announcements about her support acts.
Several comments on BST Hyde Park's latest Instagram post come from music fans complaining at the lack of updates regarding the acts that are meant to perform this Sunday (July 9). Francesborrie commented: "At this point itâ€™s either cancelled or Iâ€™m going to be opening for Lana."
Chlopiecy added: "You guys left me on read! Where is the line-up? The show is in 6 days." Xshaye.s said: "If you cancel Lana's show, I will cancel myself. you will be to blame. kisses." Charlotttereid fumed: "I have not given you 130 great British pounds for you to act like this."
Sigrnm wrote: "Please Lana!! I've payed 600 pounds to fly to London from Norway to see her, been my dream since i was 14 and now in really started to worry that she's cancelled pls give us a peace of mind." Marielouise said: "You could at least just do a story saying that the Lana support acts are announced soon to provide peace of mind."
However, one of our sister publications, MyLondon, has received information about the event fans have been desperately waiting for. After reaching out to BST Hyde Park about the rumours, festival organisers assured the gig is still going ahead and the support acts will be announced this week.
A spokesperson said: "This is going ahead and supports will be announced." Lana Del Rey's manager Ben Mawson also gave reassurance to fans by taking to his Instagram story last night to write: "Excited 4 Sunday @ Hyde Park. Support acts announced soon."
It comes after Lana Del Rey caused quite a stir at Glastonbury Festival last month by arriving on stage late and having her set cut short and her microphone cut off due to running over the allotted time limit.
Thousands turned up to watch her headline the Other Stage on Saturday (June 24), but many were left frustrated as the 38-year-old was 30 minutes late. The Blue Jeans singer was scheduled to perform at 10.30pm, but didn't arrive until 11pm.
She explained to the crowd that her tardiness was due to her hair taking to long to do. Grovelling to festival-goers as she appeared on stage, she said: "I'm so f*****g late that I am about to rush this set today.
"If they cut power, they cut power. I'm super f*****g sorry, my hair takes so long to do. I love you all. Let's keep on running the set as it's supposed to go."

title: Jon Batiste New Album Featuring Lana Del Rey, Lil Wayne & More Collabs
content:
Just two years after releasing his Grammy-winning album We Are, cross-genre savant Jon Batiste is gearing up to unleash his next record upon the world. On Wednesday, (June 28), the multi-hyphenate took to Twitter to reveal that his new studio album, titled World Music Radio, is slated for an Aug. 18 release â€” and will feature collaborations with Lana Del Rey, Lil Wayne, Kenny G and more.
â€œWorld Music Radio is a concept album that takes place in the interstellar regions of the universe,â€ Batiste wrote on Twitter. â€œThe listener is led through the album by an interstellar traveling griot named Billy Bob Bo Bob, who takes you sonically all around the world at the speed of light.â€
Alongside his announcement of the albumâ€™s title and release date, Batiste also debuted the official visualizer for the setâ€™s lead single, â€œCalling Your Name.â€ â€œI created this album with a feeling of liberation in my life and a renewed sense of exploration of my personhood, my craft and of the world around me unlike anything I had ever felt before,â€ mused Batiste.
In addition to Del Rey, Lil Wayne, and Kenny G, the album will also feature collaborations with Jon Bellion, Fireboy DML, J.I.D., NewJeans and more. World Music Radio â€” which is executive produced by Batiste, Bellion and Ryan Lynn â€” is certainly a star-studded affair. According to the press release, Batisteâ€™s purpose for the new album is to explore the idea that all music is â€œworld music,â€ and forge an international, cross-cultural community through different kinds of popular music from different regions around the world.
Two years ago, Batiste made history as the first Black artist to win the Grammy for Album of the Year in 14 years when he triumphed in the category for his genre-spanning We Are. He won four other awards that night, adding a handful of trophies to a mantle that already boasts an Academy Award for Best Original Score thanks to his work on 2020â€™s Soul alongside Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross of Nine Inch Nails.
Batiste has landed two titles on the Billboard 200: 2014â€™s Social Music (No. 134, as Jon Batiste & Stay Human) and 2021â€™s We Are (No. 25).
See his World Music Radio announcement and listen to â€œCalling Your Nameâ€ below.

title: Jon Batiste's 'World Music Radio' Will Include Lana Del Rey, Lil Wayne
content:
The 2024 Grammy race may have just gotten a shakeup. Jon Batiste, who dominated the 2022 awards with his breakout album â€œWe Are,â€ has announced a followup, â€œWorld Music Radio,â€ set to come out Aug. 18 on Verve/Interscope.
Among the guests on the album is Lana Del Rey, returning the favor from Batisteâ€™s recent appearance on two tracks on her â€œDid You Know Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€ release earlier this year. Their collaboration, â€œLife Lesson,â€ is listed as a bonus track wrapping up the 21-song release, but is likely to be the most anticipated track, however itâ€™s billed.
Other guests include Lil Wayne on â€œUneasy,â€ Kenny G on â€œClair De Lune,â€ Native Soul on â€œRaindance,â€ Leigh-Anne on â€œRunning Away,â€ Jon Bellion and Fireboy DML on â€œDrink Water,â€ Rita PayÃ©s on â€œMy Heart,â€ Heroes on â€œMovement 18â€²â€ and Michael Batiste on â€œCall Now (504-305-8269).â€
On Wednesday morning Batiste also released the first single from the album, â€œCalling Your Name.â€ This may not represent his ultimate major play for record of the year honors, seeing as it clocks in at a blink-and-youâ€™ll-miss-it one minute and 57 seconds.
â€œI created this album with a feeling of liberation in my life and a renewed sense of exploration of my personhood, my craft and of the world around me unlike anything I had ever felt before,â€ Batiste said in a statement accompanying the release news.
One of the songs, â€œBe Who You Are,â€ was already released this month as part of a Coke promotion.
Befitting his interest in crossover, the Interscope imprint is a new one for Batiste, as his last release was solely attributed to the traditionally jazz- and singer-songwriter-oriented Verve label.
Batiste, the former television band leader for Stephen Colbert, shocked Grammy prognosticators when the â€œWe Areâ€ album picked up 14 nominations in seven categories in 2021 and went on to win five trophies the following year, including record of the year. Those honors came atop the best original score Oscar he collected alongside Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross for his work on Pixarâ€™s â€œSoulâ€ in 2020.
â€œWorld Music Radioâ€ is being released as a double-LP, among other formats, with signed green vinyl available in his webstore.
The full track list:
Tracklist:
1. Hello, Billy Bob
2. Raindance (ft. Native Soul)
3. Be Who You Are (ft. J.I.D, NewJeans, Camilo)
4. Worship
5. My Heart (ft. Rita PayÃ©s)
6. Drink Water (ft. Jon Bellion, Fireboy DML)
7. Calling Your Name
8. Clair De Lune (ft. Kenny G)
9. Butterfly
10. 17th Ward Prelude
11. Uneasy (ft. Lil Wayne)
12. CALL NOW (504-305-8269) (ft. Michael Batiste)
13. Chassol
14. BOOM FOR REAL
15. MOVEMENT 18â€™ (Heroes)
16. Master Power
17. Running Away (ft. Leigh-Anne)
18. Goodbye, Billy Bob
19. White Space
20. Wherever You Are
21. (Bonus track) Life Lesson (ft. Lana Del Rey)

title: Glastonbury fans divided over who was to blame for Lana Del Rey's performance being cut off
content:
Our free email updates are the best way to get headlines direct to your inbox
People have been left divided over who was in the wrong for Lana Del Rey's Glastonbury set being cut off. The US songstress performed at the UK's biggest music festival over the weekend, but was take off after she went over the allotted time.
Thousands turned up to watch her headline the Other Stage on Saturday (June 24), but many were left frustrated as the 38-year-old was 30 minutes late. The Blue Jeans singer was scheduled to perform at 10.30pm, but didn't arrive until 11pm.
She explained to the crowd that her tardiness was due to her hair taking to long to do. Grovelling to festival-goers as she appeared on stage, she said: "I'm so f*****g late that I am about to rush this set today.
"If they cut power, they cut power. I'm super f*****g sorry, my hair takes so long to do. I love you all. Let's keep on running the set as it's supposed to go."
Before the end of her set, her microphone was cut off by festival workers as she had reached the midnight cut off point. This forced the singer-songwriter to perform her final song Video Games acapella.
The image of the artist on the big screen was then replaced with an advert for the festival's Arcadia stage as Skepta B2B Jammer's performance began. Lana Del Rey went on to mouth an apology to fans before stepping off stage to go down and greet them along the front row.
However, she was swiftly escorted off by security due to Glastonbury having a curfew, and performing past it can get the festival into a spot of bother with the local council. The whole situation has left many fans feeling mixed, with some blaming the singer for spending too long on her hair, while others argued the festival shouldn't have cut her off.
Muse frontman MattBellamy tweeted: "Canâ€™t believe they cut Lana Del Rey sound @glastonbury before finishing set, best Glasto performance Iâ€™ve seen for years. Insanity." Pollybirkbeck argued: "But she was late! Big trouble (fines?) if set over runs the allotted curfew."
Muddymudskipper gushed: "Lana Del Rey being late and having to end her set early because she was getting her hair up real big beauty queen style is exactly what I'd expect from her (complimentary)."
Rambunctiousgus stated: "Sheâ€™s literally LDRâ€¦ she can be as late as she wants to?! Did you not hear her?? She said it was her hairs fault! Not hers! Stop whining, you werenâ€™t even there lol." Readdork said: "Lana Del Rey, you may have been late, they may have cut you off, but you will go down in legend. 5 stars out of 5. #glastonbury2023."
However, Fatalliety fumed: "Exactly what paying fans want to hear Iâ€™m going to rush through my set lmfao." Nonposter10 added: "Disrespectful to loyal fans to turn up late. There's no excuse... especially just hair."
Ash_mcnally90 exclaimed: "Lana Del Rey turning up 30 mins late after having all day to do her hair is pathetic. People paying Â£400 for tickets and some of the artists couldn't give a f***." Simsyg ranted: "No one gets around the curfew, and using your hair taking too long as an excuse is pathetic."

title: Lana Del Rey coming to Dublin for surprise gig next week after amazing Glastonbury set
content:
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Invalid email Something went wrong, please try again later.
Sign up to our free email alerts for the best Promotions sent straight to your e-mail
Glastonbury smash hit Lana Del Rey has revealed three more surprise dates around Europe over the next three weeks including a concert in Dublin.
Top line
Lana Del Rey has followed her incredible Glastonbury performance by announcing three surprise European concerts including one in Dublin.
The Summertime Sadness singer will play 3Arena Dublin NEXT WEEK on Friday July 7.
Tickets for Lana Del Rey at 3Arena, Dublin, are priced from â‚¬69.70 and go on sale this Friday, 30th June, at 9 am from Ticketmaster.
Lana also plays Ziggo Dome in Holland on July 4 and Olympia Paris on July 20.
READ MORE: The Weeknd at Marlay Park, Dublin: Ticket information, support acts, stage times, set list, travel, parking and more
What was said
â€œ I love Europe and after playing Glastonbury, have decided to play a few more shows in various countries around my Hyde Park Show in London on July 9th. Today I am announcing shows in Amsterdam on July 4th, Dublin on July 7th and Paris on July 10th. I look forward to seeing you all .â€
(Image: Getty)
Glastonbury treat
The buzz surrounding Lana Del Rey 's Glastonbury performance began long before she set foot on the iconic Worthy Farm.
The 38-year-old artist took the stage fashionably late and was abruptly cut off midway through her set.
Fans eagerly awaited Lana Del Rey's headline set at The Other Stage, scheduled for 10.30pm. The anticipation grew as crowds gathered to witness the Blue Jeans singer's performance.
After an agonising 30-minute delay, Lana finally took the stage and humbly addressed the festival-goers: "I'm so f**king late that I am about to rush this set today.
(Image: Getty)
"If they cut power, they cut power. I'm super f***ing sorry, my hair takes so long to do. I love you all. Let's keep on running the set as it's supposed to go."
As the clock struck midnight, following the festival's strict curfew for the main stages, Lana's microphone was abruptly cut off. However, instead of bowing out, Lana defiantly continued, launching into her iconic hit Video Games. The crowd at The Other Stage quickly caught on and joined her in an impromptu sing-along.
What happened next
Lana decided to treat her adoring fans to a surprise meet and greet at the front of the crowd. She shook hands and posed for selfies and joined forces with her fans in a rendition of Summertime Sadness. However, the impromptu meet and greet took an unexpected turn when security intervened.
(Image: Getty)
Filmed footage captured the moment Lana was escorted away from the crowd, leaving her fans in a mix of emotions. Some expressed their disappointment with boos, while others cried out and screamed, yearning for more.

title: Lana Del Rey announces 3Arena show this summer
content:
(Lana Del Rey)
Lana Del Rey announces additional July European dates.
Lana Del Rey reveals three more surprise dates around Europe over the next three weeks â€œI love Europe and after playing Glastonbury, have decided to play a few more shows in various countries around my Hyde Park Show in London on July 9th.
Today I am announcing shows in Amsterdam on July 4th, Dublin on July 7th and Paris on July 10th. I look forward to seeing you all.â€
Tickets for Lana Del Rey at 3Arena, Dublin, are priced from â‚¬69.70 go on sale this Friday, 30th June, at 9 am from Ticketmaster.
The dates are as follows:
JULY 4 ZIGGO DOME- Amsterdam, Holland
JULY 7 3ARENA -Dublin, Ireland
JULY 10 OLYMPIA- Paris, France

title: Lana Del Rey announces surprise Dublin gig
content:
Lana Del Rey has announced a surprise gig in Dublin's 3Arena on July 7th as part of her European tour.
Del Rey surprised her Irish fans with this news on June 27th. She also announced shows in Amsterdam on July 4th and in Paris on July 10th.
Advertisement
She made the decision to add extra dates to her European tour following her performance at Glastonbury Festival. She said: "I love Europe and after playing Glastonbury, have decided to play a few more shows in various countries around my Hyde Park Show in London on July 9."
The American singer experienced several difficulties at Glastonbury Festival as her mic was cut off at midnight after she arrived more than 30 minutes late to the festival, leaving her fans waiting because her "hair takes so long". As a result, she had to sing her hit song "Video Games" acapella as the crowd sang along.
Advertisement
Tickets for the concert go on sale this Friday, June 30th, at 9am and prices will start from â‚¬69.70.

title: Lana Del Rey nuovo singolo e unica data italiana a sorpresa
content:
La cantante sarÃ  sul palco del festival La Prima Estate al parco Buyssoladomani di Lido di Camaiore (Lucca) domenica 2 luglio, un evento speciale che il festival ha annunciato a sorpresa per la sua seconda edizione. La cantautrice americana, che nella sua carriera ha venduto piÃ¹ di 16 milioni di album ed e ha collezionato negli anni molti riconoscimenti tra cui sei candidature ai Grammy Awards, una al Golden Globe e due Mtv Music Awards, torna cosÃ¬ in Italia cinque anni dopo il suo ultimo concerto nel Belpaese.
Undici anni dopo aver conquistato il pubblico con "Born to die", l'album di Blue Jeans e Summertime Sadness, Del Rey torna sul palco con "Did you know that there's a tunnel under ocean Blvs", il suo nono disco uscito a marzo. Disarmante e sincera, ipnotica, eterea e dalla voce inconfondibile con il suo nuovo lavoro discografico Lana celebra la bellezza della vita. Il disco ha debuttato in Italia nella top10 dei dischi piÃ¹ venduti. Sempre a sorpresa lo scorso maggio l'artista ha pubblicato un nuovo singolo "Say Yes To Heaven", non incluso nel precedente album, e che Ã¨ diventato subito virale su TikTok.
"Did you know that there's a tunnel under Ocean Blvd" Ã¨ il sesto album ad andare alla #1 nella classifica inglese ed Ã¨ diventato l'album a vendere copie piÃ¹ velocemente del 2023 ad oggi e con il maggior numero di copie e stream nella prima settimana. In Gran Bretagna Ã¨ la quinta artista femminile ad aver avuto piÃ¹ album alla numero 1 in classifica dietro solo a Madonna, Taylor Swift, Kylie Minogue e Barbra Streisand. In Italia l'album ha debuttato nella top10 degli album piÃ¹ venduti (classifica Fimi/Gfk). E' stato co-prodotto da Lana con Mike Hermosa, Jack Antonoff, Drew Erickson, Zach Dawes e Benji e contiene le collaborazioni con Jon Batiste, Bleachers, Father John Misty, Judah Smith, Tommy Genesis e Syml.

title: VerspÃ¤tung: Lana Del Rey durfte Konzert nicht fertig spielen
content:
Sie musste ihr Konzert abbrechen! Lana Del Rey (38) begeistert ihre Fans auf der ganzen Welt bereits seit einigen Jahren. Mit Hits wie "Summertime Sadness" oder "Video Games" stÃ¼rmt die Musikerin regelmÃ¤ÃŸig die Charts. Im Dezember 2022 kÃ¼ndigte sie sogar ein neues Album an. Aktuell befindet sich die SÃ¤ngerin auf Tour â€“ doch eines ihrer Festival-Konzerte durfte Lana nicht bis zum Ende spielen.
Zu Beginn ihres Auftritts entschuldigte sich die 38-JÃ¤hrige bei ihren Fans in Glastonbury fÃ¼r eine knappe halbe Stunde VerspÃ¤tung â€“ ihre Frisur habe zu lange gedauert. "Ich bin so verdammt spÃ¤t dran, dass sie mein Set abbrechen kÃ¶nnten. Es tut mir leid", gab Lana zu. Der Grund: In dem Ort gilt eine strikte Sperrstunde, aufgrund derer nach 24 Uhr keine Musik mehr gespielt werden darf, wie Daily Mail berichtet. Nach etwa einer Stunde wurde dann tatsÃ¤chlich alles abgebrochen.
Doch bevor die Show ganz beendet wurde, kam es zu einem besonderen Moment. Videos, die derzeit auf TikTok viral gehen, zeigen die Musikerin auf der BÃ¼hne, wie sie ihr Publikum dazu animiert, mit ihr "Video Games" zu singen. "An diesen Moment wird sie sich ihr Leben lang erinnern. Magisch!", kommentiert nur einer der zahlreichen Fans den Clip.

title: Lana Del Rey in Glastonbury von BÃ¼hne eskotiert - wegen ihrer Haare
content:
Singer-Songwriterin Lana Del Rey ("Video Games", 38) hat auf dem derzeit stattfindenden Glastonbury Festival im SÃ¼dwesten Englands einen kuriosen Auftritt hingelegt. Nachdem die SÃ¤ngerin rund eine halbe Stunde zu spÃ¤t zu ihrem fÃ¼r 22:30 Uhr am Samstagabend (24. Juni) angesetzten Set erschienen war, wurde ihr um Mitternacht das Mikrofon abgedreht. Der Grund: In Glastonbury gilt eine strikte Sperrstunde. Nach 24 Uhr darf auf den groÃŸen BÃ¼hnen des Traditions-Festivals kein Sound mehr gespielt werden, wie unter anderem "Daily Mail" berichtet.
Lana Del Rey kommt zu Glastonbury-Auftritt zu spÃ¤t: "Meine Frisur hat so lange gedauert"
Gleich zu Beginn ihres Auftritts entschuldigte sich Del Rey fÃ¼r ihr ZuspÃ¤tkommen. "Ich bin so verdammt spÃ¤t dran, dass sie mein Set abbrechen kÃ¶nnten. Es tut mir leid, meine Frisur hat so lange gedauert", erklÃ¤rte der Musik-Star dem anwesenden Publikum. WÃ¤hrend ihres laufenden Gigs holte Del Rey dann noch eine Stylistin auf die BÃ¼hne, die weiter an ihrer Frisur arbeitete, und kÃ¼ndigte zudem an, durch ihre Performance "eilen" zu wollen.
Doch es half alles nichts. Nach weniger als einer Stunde und bei mindestens sechs noch zu spielenden Songs - darunter einige ihrer grÃ¶ÃŸten Hits - drehten die Verantwortlichen des Glastonbury Festivals Del Rey das Mikrofon ab. Ihren 2011 verÃ¶ffentlichten Hit "Video Games" ihres Major-Label-DebÃ¼ts "Born to Die" sangen Del Reys Fans noch a cappella mit der Musikerin. Im Anschluss geleitete Security-Personal die 38-JÃ¤hrige von der BÃ¼hne.

title: Glastonbury 2023: from Lana Del Rey to Lewis Capaldi - the memorable and controversial moments
content:
Glastonbury 2023: During Lewis Capaldi's biggest hit, Someone You Loved, the 100,000-strong crowd took over the song as his voice broke. Photograph: Oli Scarff/AFP via Getty
This yearâ€™s Glastonbury festival was not short of dramatic moments and surprise appearances. Here is a look back at some of the weekendâ€™s most memorable moments.
McCartneyâ€™s surprise appearances
Paul McCartney, who headlined the Pyramid stage at the festival last year, made an unexpected appearance midway through Saturday nightâ€™s performance by the Pretenders.
A surreal moment amongst an already mad weekend. Walked to the top of the @glastonbury hill for a sunset photo, turns out Paul McCartney had the same idea! #lovehim #icon #legend pic.twitter.com/K7b6R7hkGt â€” Chris Arnold (@ChrisArnoldInc) June 24, 2023
This time around, his appearance was a brief one, coming on stage to give the audience a thumbs up before exiting a moment later.
[ Elton John at Glastonbury delivers a send-off to remember, Britney or no Britney ]
Foo Fighters revealed as â€˜mysteryâ€™ act
Many had speculated that the mystery band billed to perform at the Pyramid stage on Friday afternoon would be Foo Fighters, and the rumour was confirmed to be true when the American rock band, led by Dave Grohl, emerged on stage to rapturous applause.
READ MORE
Glastonbury 2023: Dave Grohl and the Foo Fighters perform on the Pyramid Stage at this year's festival. Photograph: Oli Scarff/AFP via Getty
â€œYou guys f**king knew it was us this whole time, didnâ€™t you?â€ Grohl said, before performing hits including All My Life and My Hero. â€œWeâ€™re happy to see you guys. Itâ€™s nice to see you guys after all this time,â€ he said.
Security escort Del Rey off stage
Lana Del Reyâ€™s headline performance at the Other stage on Saturday night was certainly memorable. After the singer-songwriter took to the stage more than 30 minutes late, she apologised to fans: â€œIâ€™m sorry. My hair takes so long.â€
Rey was also seen vaping between songs, and was later joined by her stylist, who finished the singerâ€™s hairdo on stage. Her set was then dramatically cut short at midnight when her microphone was cut off, and she was seen arguing with the stageâ€™s management about whether she would be able to finish the eight songs remaining on her setlist. Del Rey then performed Video Games a cappella before being escorted off stage by security.
Crowd comes to Capaldiâ€™s aid
Off the back of cancelling all of his scheduled performances for mental health reasons in the run-up to the festival, there was speculation whether Lewis Capaldi would be able to finish his set.
We love you Lewis Capaldi â¤ï¸
Glastonbury crowds are the best. pic.twitter.com/x6ZnIIgRpP â€” BBC Radio 1 (@BBCR1) June 24, 2023
The Scottish singer was noticeably affected by tics as a result of Touretteâ€™s syndrome. He admitted that he was struggling, saying: â€œIâ€™m really sorry. I hope the Eavises will have me back on, even though itâ€™s been a bit of a s**t show.â€
During his biggest hit, Someone You Loved, the 100,000-strong crowd took over the song as his voice broke. It left Capaldi visibly emotional.
Astleyâ€™s Harry Styles and AC/DC covers
Clad in a salmon-pink suit, Rick Astleyâ€™s lunchtime performance on the Pyramid stage on Saturday was full of energy.
Glastonbury 2023: Rick Astley performs on the Pyramid Stage at this year's festival. Photograph: Ben Birchall/PA Wire
There was something for everyone in his Glastonbury debut, with the veteran pop star playing his 80s classics including Never Gonna Give You Up, a cover of Highway to Hell by AC/DC during which he showed off his drumming skills, and his own rendition of Harry Stylesâ€™s hit single As It Was. â€“ Guardian

title: Why is all Lana Del Reyâ€™s set still not on BBC iPlayer as fans fume
content:
F ans have called on the BBC to â€œsort it outâ€ as they are still not able to watch Lana Del Rayâ€™s Glastonburyâ€™s set on the BBC iPlayer.
The star was 30 minutes late to the stage, saying to fans that she did not have enough time to get ready.
She came on shouting: â€œIf they cut power, they cut power. Iâ€™m super f**king sorry, my hair takes so long to do. If they cut the power, letâ€™s keep going!â€
Glastonbury 2023 | Elton John 1 / 26 Glastonbury 2023 | Elton John PA Wire AFP via Getty Images Elton John and Rina Sawayama Leon Neal/Getty Images AFP via Getty Images Leon Neal/Getty Images Getty Images PA AFP via Getty Images Elton John and Rina Sawayama Leon Neal/Getty Images AFP via Getty Images PA Davey Johnstone and Brandon Flowers performing with Elton John PA PA AFP via Getty Images Brandon Flowers performs on stage with Elton John Leon Neal/Getty Images AFP via Getty Images AFP via Getty Images Elton John kisses the hand of US singer Jacob Lusk AFP via Getty Images AFP via Getty Images AFP via Getty Images
But her mic was cut off halfway through her set, as her time had run out.
Festival-goers queued eagerly before her set to get a good spot. She was due to start at 10.30pm, but did not step out until around 11pm.
But now, fans have been left questioning whether the star is â€œon the naughty stepâ€ as her set still cannot be viewed on the iPlayer.
One wrote: â€œIs the #lanadelrey set going to be on BBC #glastonbury #iPlayer? Still not gone live. Or is she on the naughty step? Sort it out.â€
What happened to Lana Del Rey at Glastonbury?
The star had her mic cut and was asked to get off the stage, with tweets from fans showing her trying to continue her set through the crowd.
Glastonbury says under the terms of the festival, it is not allowed to play music on any major stages past midnight, and Lanaâ€™s set had been due to end at 11.45pm, but was still going on more than 15 minutes later. The Video Games singer, 38, was headlining the Other Stage at the same time as Guns nâ€™ Roses were headlining the Pyramid stage on Saturday night.
One wrote: â€œWhy is Lana Del Reyâ€™s set not on iPlayer? She was a headliner,â€ while another complained: â€œSo disappointing that Lanaâ€™s set isnâ€™t on iplayer. Leaving us in the dirt here.â€
How to watch Lana Del Reyâ€™s set on iPlayer
The BBC has since said the full set is not available, but said they did have coverage of â€œselected tracksâ€ from the act on the night.
A spokesman said: â€œâ€œLana Del Reyâ€™s set was broadcast in full on Saturday night and we are delighted that we can include selected tracks as part of our on-demand offer on BBC iPlayer, as agreed with the artist.â€

title: Inside Lana Del Rey's chaotic Glastonbury Festival set - crying crowd to BBC 'snub'
content:
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Invalid email Something went wrong, please try again later.
Want all the latest Showbiz news direct to your inbox? Share your email for news, gossip and more
Lana Del Rey's highly-anticipated Glastonbury set hit the headlines before she even travelled to Worthy Farm.
And, after her gig last night, the 38-year-old's performance has continued to dominate the Twitter-sphere and those visiting Glastonbury this weekend as she arrived on stage 30-minutes late and was cut off midway through her set.
Here we take a look at the brutal battle between Glastonbury and Lana Del Rey, which resulted in a chaotic set which everyone is talking about...
War of the words
The American singer-songwriter had a war of the words with the popular festival's organisers in the lead-up to the big weekend.
Lana appeared to be angered when she spotted a 'mix-up' with the line-up announcement.
The original line-up post listed Arctic Monkeys, Guns N' Roses, Elton John and Lizzo before listing the remaining acts in alphabetical order.
Lana's name was below more than 20 other acts and the singer complained the poster failed to recognise she was headlining the Other Stage.
(Image: WireImage)
Writing on Instagram in a later deleted post, Lana sarcastically said: "Thanks for announcing that I was headlining the other stage. Thumbs up."
She also took to her private Instagram to share the poster and added: "Well, Iâ€™m actually headlining the 2nd stage. But since there was no consideration for announcing that, weâ€™ll see," appearing to threaten to not show up.
The poster was subsequently re-released with Lana's name bumped up to the second row along side other big artists and Other Stage headliners including Lil Nas X, Wizkid and Yusuf/Cat Stevens.
Despite her earlier fury, Lana later confirmed she would be performing on The Other Stage.
During an appearance on BBC Radio 1 in March, DJ Clara Amfro asked whether she's still planning to headline at Glastonbury, she said: "I am, I am, I am, I am. I've been excited to tell people, so I wanted to tell people because, as we started to announce some festivals, its unfathomable to me to headline the second stage of Glastonbury.
"They had asked me to play Glastonbury the last three years but we just weren't ready. I didn't want to say yes before we had a big band."
Late arrival and boos from the crowd
Blue Jeans singer Lana was due to take to The Other Stage and perform her headline set at 10.30pm.
Eager crowds began to gather around the performance area to watch the singer â€“ but festival-goers began to grow impatient when he didn't show up on time.
Fans even threatened to leave if she didn't show up within good time â€“ but she made her audience wait and after a whopping 30 minutes before making an appearance on stage and was greeted by boos.
Lana grovelled to festival-goers as she appeared on stage: "I'm so f**king late that I am about to rush this set today.
(Image: WireImage)
"If they cut power, they cut power. I'm super f**king sorry, my hair takes so long to do. I love you all. Let's keep on running the set as it's supposed to go."
Midway through the set Lana was filmed having her hair done after she admitted her hair was the cause of her tardiness.
The Summertime Sadness songstress was seen sitting on a chair in between tunes as a stylist came onto the stage to change her locks as she continued to perform.
Cut off and brutal dig
As the clock stroked midnight, Lana's mic was cut off.
The image of Lana on the big screen was then replaced with an advert for the festivals Arcadia stage popped up as Skepta B2B Jammer's performance began in a brutal dig.
Despite losing power, Lana was seen pleading with a someone at the side of the stage â€“ perhaps asking for power to be restored.
Despite Glastonbury's strict curfew on the big stages Lana refused to leave and kept the audience entertained as she began to sing her hit Video Games with the crowd at The Other Stage joining in.
However, some fans couldn't help but feel disappointed as one told the Mirror: "It was beyond a joke. She had a headline set and ruined it by being late. Iâ€™m gutted we didnâ€™t get to hear her full setlist."
Meeting fans before being escorted by security
The singer took it upon herself to do a spontaneous meet and greet with fans at the front of the crowd, shaking hands and taking selfies.
She was praised by some on Twitter as one wrote: "Shame on Glastonbury for cutting off #LanaDelRey when others were still playing elsewhere. No word, no warning, no respect? The GRACE of her going down to meet fans and sing along, I can't. I'm so gutted for her and the crowd. This should have been more."
(Image: BBC)
"The fact she feels so bad and got the crowd to sing and then went out to meet fans despite her mic being cut off [cute face emoji] #LanaDelRey," another said.
One moment saw her singing Summertime Sadness with those at the front of the crowd.
The spontaneous meet and greet was soon interrupted by security and she was filmed being escorted from in front of the crowd by security as her audience cried and screamed with some disappointed boos mixed in too.
BBC 'snub'
Like every headline act playing at Glastonbury, Lana Del Rey fans were expecting to watch her eventful appearance on BBC iPlayer after it was broadcast live.
But, Lana's gig is yet to appear on the channels catch-up stream.
Fans are now wondering if the move is a snub from the BBC following her late appearance as she is the only headliner this year to not have her performance available on the iPlayer.
One urged: "Bbc iplayer where her set? You best put it on! #lanadelrey @BBCiPlayer".
"Lana Del Rey on the naughty step by any chance? 30 minutes late and then escorted offstage at midnight due to the curfew. Now BBC iplayer appear to have airbrushed her out of the festival. Can YOU find her?," another pointed out.
A third wrote: "Is it just mine or is Lana Del Rey coverage not available on the BBC iplayer? Iâ€™m on headliners and she is not there".
"thereâ€™s no way bbc iplayer has worked for every single performance so far at Glasto but suddenly doesnâ€™t work for Lana Del Rey??? surely not,"another quizzed.
The BBC issued a statement on Sunday night regarding the backlash, saying: "Lana Del Reyâ€™s set was broadcast in full on Saturday night and we are delighted that we can include selected tracks as part of our on-demand offer on BBC iPlayer, as agreed with the artist."

title: Fans fury as Lana Del Rey's Glastonbury set CUT OFF early after she arrived 30 mins late
content:
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Invalid email Something went wrong, please try again later.
Want all the latest Showbiz news direct to your inbox? Share your email for news, gossip and more
Music fans erupted with fury after Lana Del Reyâ€™s Glastonbury headline set was cut short â€“ after she rocked up to the stage half an hour late.
The 38-year-old Summertime Sadness star brought chaos to Worthy Farm on Saturday night when she headlined The Other Stage at the end of the night.
She had been due to appear on stage at 10:30pm, but it wasnâ€™t until 11pm that she actually arrived for her slot â€“ and her hair was still being styled on stage while her performance began.
But due to her late start, Lana ended up going over her allotted performance time, meaning organisers cut off her microphone and stopped the video link to the screens on the stage as Glastonbury has a strict midnight curfew for the large stages.
(Image: WireImage)
Lana was already greeted by some boos in the crowd as she arrived on stage, but the abrupt end of the show sparked a fresh wave of booing from fans who had been left disappointed â€“ with some bewildered fans seen crying.
One angry fan told the Mirror: â€œIt was beyond a joke. She had a headline set and ruined it by being late. Iâ€™m gutted we didnâ€™t get to hear her full setlist.â€
However, the singer took it upon herself to do a spontaneous meet and greet with fans at the front of the crowd, shaking hands and taking selfies.
Fans watching coverage from home took to Twitter to express their anger at the star getting cut off early.
One fan fumed: â€œNot seen anything like that before. Plug pulled on #lanadelrey for overrunning curfew and she gets the crowd to do Video Games.â€
(Image: BBC)
Another grumbled: â€œCanâ€™t believe they cut Lana Del Rey sound @glastonbury before finishing set, best Glasto performance Iâ€™ve seen for years. Insanity.â€
And another blasted: â€œLana gracefully went down the stage, barefooted, and embraced the crowds after Glastonbury CUT off her set at midnight. You robbed Venice B*tch, Diet Mt Dew, Summertime Sadness, Ocean Blvd, & Video Games from us. We won't forget, we wonâ€™t.â€
It comes after Lana arrived 30 minutes late getting to the stage.
Earlier in the evening, fans threatened to walk away from the Other Stage when she failed to materialise on time â€“ while others feared she wouldnâ€™t show up at all.
Speaking to the Mirror in the crowd as they waited for Lana to grace the stage with her presence, one festival-goer said they feared the Born to Die singer was bailing on her set.
Following Lanaâ€™s comments earlier this year about her position on the Glastonbury poster, the fan feared the star was â€œboycotting and sat at home.â€
Another added: â€œSheâ€™s not even got a line-up set time for a headliner anyway, she canâ€™t be this late for someone with such a short set.
â€œThe Guns â€˜Nâ€™ Roses werenâ€™t even this late and theyâ€™re known for being late!â€
One fan threatened to leave if Lana didnâ€™t make an appearance â€œin the next five minutesâ€.
Back in March, there was a backlash when the Glastonbury line-up was announced and revealed there were no female performers headlining the main stage.
Lana hit out at the festival at the time as her own headline slot on The Other Stage didn't get a big promotion.
She tweeted at the time: â€œWell, Iâ€™m actually headlining the 2nd stage. But since there was no consideration for announcing that weâ€™ll seeâ€ â€“ leading many to fear she would boycott the event as a result.

title: Lana Del Rey Apologies to Glastonbury Fans After Late Arrival
content:
Lana Del Reyâ€˜s headlining set at the 2023 Glastonbury Festival on Saturday (June 24) was cut short after the singer showed up late to the performance.
The â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ songstress, who was slated to perform at 10:30 p.m., according to the festivalâ€™s website, arrived about 30 minutes behind schedule, the Guardian reports. Del Rey blamed the tardiness on issues with her hair.
Explore Explore Lana Del Rey See latest videos, charts and news See latest videos, charts and news
â€œI was so fâ€”ing late that I am about to rush this set to death,â€ she told the crowd. â€œIf they cut power, Iâ€™m super fâ€”ing sorry, my hair takes so long to do. Letâ€™s keep on running the set as itâ€™s supposed to go.â€
Del Reyâ€™s microphone was cut off at midnight while she was performing her 2012 track â€œVideo Games,â€ forcing her to sing it a cappella alongside festival-goers. She then walked around the stage for a brief time before being gently escorted away by what appeared to be security and stagehands.
The singer returned to the live stage for the first time in more than three years at Rio De Janeiroâ€™s MITA Festival on May 27. She performed 20 songs in Brazil, while her Glastonbury set only made it to 15 songs before its abrupt midnight ending.
Del Reyâ€™s ninth album, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, debuted at No. 3 on the Billboard 200 albums chart in March 2023. The 16-song release includes guest appearances by Jon Batiste, Bleachers, Father John Misty, Judah Smith, Tommy Genesis, and SYML.
She is scheduled to perform at numerous other music festivals this year, including Lollapalooza, Outside Lands and the All Things Go festivals.
Watch Del Reyâ€™s apology to Glastonbury fans below.
Lana Del Rey apologizing to fans for being late pic.twitter.com/WbITGRDC50 â€” jude (@jfloridakilos) June 24, 2023

Es tut mir leid, meine Frisur hat so lange gedauert", erklÃ¤rte der Musik-Star dem anwesenden Publikum. WÃ¤hrend ihres laufenden Gigs holte Del Rey dann noch eine Stylistin auf die BÃ¼hne, die weiter an ihrer Frisur arbeitete, und kÃ¼ndigte zudem an, durch ihre Performance "eilen" zu wollen.

title: 'Plug pulled' on Lana Del Rey as she arrives to Glastonbury stage late
content:
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Invalid email Something went wrong, please try again later.
Subscribe to our daily What's On newsletter to keep up with what's happening around Greater Manchester
Lana Del Rey disappointed fans as she arrived late to the stage at Glastonbury on Saturday night (June 25), leaving festival organisers no choice but to cut her performance short. The 38-year-old Summertime Sadness star blamed being late by half an hour due to the fact her hair wasnâ€™t done.
She had been due to appear on stage at 10:30pm, but it wasnâ€™t until 11pm that she actually arrived for her slot â€“ and her hair was still being styled on stage while her performance began.
READ MORE: LIVE: Glastonbury Festival updates as Elton John prepares to say goodbye with final - latest updates
Fans were furious when the plug was pulled on her performance due to her late start as the Young and Beautiful singer ran over her allotted time, meaning organisers cut off her microphone and stopped the video link to the screens on the stage as Glastonbury has a strict midnight curfew for the large stages.
Lana was already greeted by some boos in the crowd as she arrived on stage, but the abrupt end of the show sparked a fresh wave of booing from fans who had been left disappointed â€“ with some bewildered fans seen crying.
One angry fan told the Mirror: â€œIt was beyond a joke. She had a headline set and ruined it by being late. Iâ€™m gutted we didnâ€™t get to hear her full setlist.â€
However, the singer took it upon herself to do a spontaneous meet and greet with fans at the front of the crowd, shaking hands and taking selfies.
Fans watching coverage from home took to Twitter to express their anger at the star getting cut off early. One fan fumed: â€œNot seen anything like that before. Plug pulled on #lanadelrey for overrunning curfew and she gets the crowd to do Video Games.â€
Another wrote: â€œCanâ€™t believe they cut Lana Del Rey sound @glastonbury before finishing set, best Glasto performance Iâ€™ve seen for years. Insanity.â€
One Twitter user said: â€œLana gracefully went down the stage, barefooted, and embraced the crowds after Glastonbury CUT off her set at midnight. You robbed Venice B*tch, Diet Mt Dew, Summertime Sadness, Ocean Blvd, & Video Games from us. We won't forget, we wonâ€™t.â€

title: Lana Del Rey apologises for Glastonbury late show: â€˜my hair takes so longâ€™
content:
Lana Del Reyâ€™s headline set at Glastonbury was cut short after the US star arrived on stage 30 minutes late.
Fans were left waiting for the Ivor Novello-winning singer-songwriter, who admitted her Other stage appearance was delayed because â€œmy hair takes so longâ€.
â€œIâ€™m so fucking late they may cut my set,â€ she said shortly before the midnight curfew for Glastonburyâ€™s two main stages. â€œIâ€™m sorry, my hair takes so long. If they cut the power, letâ€™s keep going.â€
Del Reyâ€™s microphone and video screens were then suddenly switched off as she fell to her knees and removed her in-ear monitors.
The abrupt end came just an hour after she walked on stage for one of the most highly anticipated performances of the weekend before a crowd of tens of thousands.
Footage filmed by fans showed her remonstrating with crew on stage as she apparently pleaded to finish her set as boos rang through the crowd.
She then tried to address the crowd despite her microphone being switched off, soon followed by the huge on-stage screens which suddenly turned to black.
Del Rey then climbed down from the stage barefoot to sing an impromptu a cappella version of Summertime Sadness to fans close enough to be able to hear her.
The curtailed set left many fans disappointed. â€œItâ€™s just kind of devastating, because ... apparently she did like less than half her set according to the security people and I basically just came to this festival to see her,â€ Sasha Watkins told the PA Media news agency.
The 18-year-old from London said despite Del Reyâ€™s performance starting half an hour late she â€œwas fine and she was doing herselfâ€.
â€œThen you got to [about] midnight and all the screens went black, her mic cut out, everything went black,â€ she added.
â€œThen the whole audience started singing Video Games together ... she was like conducting it, which was really, really amazing. She kind of came and said hello to the people in the front.â€

After arriving on stage 30 minutes late, Del Rey smoked an electronic vape between her songs â€“ in defiance of Glastonburyâ€™s well-publicised ban on the devices this year.
Her performance had generated minor controversy weeks ago when she appeared to complain about having a less prominent place on the Glastonbury poster than Pyramid stage headliners Arctic Monkeys, Guns Nâ€™ Roses and Elton John.
In a comment posted on the festivalâ€™s Instagram announcement, she wrote: â€œThanks for announcing that I was headlining the other stage. Thumbs up.â€
She then reportedly took to her own private Instagram account to share the poster, adding: â€œâ€˜Well, Iâ€™m actually headlining the 2nd stage. But since there was no consideration for announcing that, weâ€™ll see.â€

title: Lana Del Rey on the Other Stage at Glastonbury - on the cusp of greatness... then the plug was pulled
content:
Review at a glance
G lastonbury waits for nobody, not even Lana Del Rey. The singer-songwriter, best known for her sprawling, baroque anthems that untangle the lie of the American dream, was 30 minutes late on stage. â€œIf they cut power, they cut power. Iâ€™m super f**king sorry, my hair takes so long to do,â€ she told the crowd once on stage. â€œIf they cut the power, letâ€™s keep going!â€ Come on, Lana â€“ even infamously tardy Guns Nâ€™ Roses were on time.
In fairness, the styling comment was likely tongue in cheek and unlikely to be the actual reason for the delay â€“ the meticulously choreographed set, which moved through stagings like a theatre production, featured a segment in which Lana has her hair and make-up done live on stage, seated at an ornate dressing table. At another stage she pulled off a costume change from inside a velvet circular curtain in the middle of the Pyramid.
Dancers wafted elaborate candelabras, threw dramatic shapes behind backlit sheets, and lay in a lackadaisical tangle on the floor with the singer as she performed. If you ignored the special half-height mic stand Lana brought on stage to safely house her disposable vape (did she not get the memo? Theyâ€™ve been banned this year!) overall, it had the vague appearance of a haunted Victorian stately home.
Many highlights from her back catalogue were specially tailored for the headline set on the Other Stage: 2012â€™s Blue Jeans, from breakthrough album Born to Die, smouldered out with an extended outro, while that recordâ€™s Ride featured amped up injections of new vocals ahead of the chorus.
Gloomy red plumes of flare-smoke and bright, saturated waves that would look at home on the cover of a Seventies surf-rock record raged behind her. As time went on, a disarmingly sexy rendition of the immensely dark Born to Die (complete with exceedingly bendy dancers), Norman F***ing Rockwell, Ultraviolence, and White Mustang gradually picked up the pace.
Though she was poised throughout, she occasionally broke character; smirking as she attempted to wrestle her vape back into its stand, and giggling at the ridiculous spectacle of getting her hair restyled in front of many, many thousands of people.
This was not a set heavy on crowd-pleasing covers, special guests, or tactically-deployed confetti guns; but in fairness, nobody really expected that from an artist who has carved out a path making epic, sprawling classic rock ballads that drawn on American iconography, rockâ€™nâ€™roll glamour, and Beat tropes: bad blokes on motorbikes, getting high on the beach, the great myth of the American songbook itself.
By the time her biggest hit Video Games began to hum into life, it felt as if Del Rey was on the cusp of greatness, sending the fizzling atmosphere sheâ€™d cultivated up in theatrical flames; but instead, she was intercepted by a member of production, and spent several moments at the side of the stage in a hurried exchange. â€œI canâ€™t singâ€¦â€ she appeared to say (though her microphone was now off) as she walked helplessly back onto the stage. The musician despairingly sank to her knees, tugging her in-ear monitors out as the big screens suddenly plunged into darkness. The plug was officially pulled.
Moments later, a green screen began urging a field full of disgruntled punters to make their way to Arcadia â€“ a giant spider which houses DJs and spews fire up a nearby hill; a fairly jarring suggestion which was met by yells and boos.
As Del Rey reappeared with her dancers and ran down to greet the front row, singing Video Games with them, sans-microphone, roadies began packing down the stage behind her as she scrambled to give some sort of meaningful farewell. It all just felt rather sad. What should have been a bold, career-defining moment instead felt like a wasted opportunity.

title: Lana Del Rey booed by Glastonbury crowd after turning up 30 minutes late for headline set
content:
LANA Del Rey was booed by crowds at Glastonbury after arriving more than 30 minutes late.
She was headlining The Other Stage at 10.30pm, but upset fans complained as she failed to appear.
2 Lana Del Ray was booed on stage Credit: Getty
The Mirror reports furious festival-goers booed the 38-year-old when she eventually arrived to perform.
One complained: "This is messing up everyone's evening plans as there are other late night acts to see after her!"
After arriving on stage, Lana apologised to fans.
She said: "I was so f***ing late that I am about to rush this set today. If they cut the power, then they cut power, then I'm super f***ing sorry.
"My hair take so long to do. Let's do the set as it's supposed to go."
The Summertime Sadness singer's set was cut off at midnight because she had been late.
She led a singalong with the crowd to finish her performance.
Lana was then escorted off my security in order to halt the gig.

title: Lana Del Rey Goes A Capella with Glastonbury Crowd
content:
Photo: Joseph Okpako/WireImage
Lana Del Rey learned the hard way that music festivals really arenâ€™t kidding around about those set times. Del Rey arrived at her Glastonbury set on Saturday a half hour late, and the festival subsequently cut off her power during her performance of â€œWhite Mustang.â€ The singer explained that she was â€œsuper sorryâ€ and that she was late in part because her hair â€œtakes so long to do.â€ In footage of the incident, Del Rey mouths to the audience that sheâ€™s sorry before leading the crowd in an a cappella rendition of â€œVideo Games.â€ The clearly upset crowd sang along until Del Rey was escorted off the stage with security. Watch the dramatic and chaotic footage below.
Lana Del Rey sings Video Games even when her mic cut off â¤ï¸pic.twitter.com/UL8l0bxXKV â€” lana del rey hq (@LDRHQ) June 24, 2023

title: Lana Del Rey at Glastonbury review - modern popâ€™s greatest auteur gets cut off in her prime
content:
There were few sets at this yearâ€™s Glastonbury festival more anticipated than Lana Del Reyâ€™s Saturday night Other stage headline slot. Itâ€™s been nearly 10 years since the cult American singer-songwriter last played on Worthy Farm; in that time, sheâ€™s released six albums and established herself as one of pop musicâ€™s greatest living songwriters, period â€“ a bold and experimental musician whose renown only seems to grow as her music becomes more introspective and self-referential. Her latest record, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, is already one of the yearâ€™s most acclaimed, and one of the strangest pop records to be released in recent memory: across the sprawling, conceptually dense album, Del Rey samples herself three times, collaborates with â€œfetish rapperâ€ Tommy Genesis, and, for the first time in her career, writes openly about her family and personal history.
At the time of writing, Lana is the 27th most streamed musician in the world on Spotify â€“ an impossibly huge feat, given how idiosyncratic, and downright anti-pop, her vision of pop music is. While Del Rey will probably never be played on pop radio, her fans are devoutly loyal â€“ more so, perhaps, than the fans of many other pop stars. They prove their devotion at the end of Del Reyâ€™s set: after walking on stage 30 minutes late, her sound is cut at midnight, after a raucous, exhilaratingly dense-sounding rendition of the 2017 song White Mustang. Del Rey pleads with various stage managers as the gargantuan Other stage crowd watch on, aghast; she is eventually escorted offstage, and the crew packing up her gear are met with emphatic, resounding boos.
Bold and experimental â€¦ Lana Del Rey. Photograph: Samir Hussein/WireImage
And you can understand why: the hour of Del Reyâ€™s set that she is able to perform is an absolutely ripper tour through her discography, including intense and psychedelic takes on tracks from 2014 fan-favourite Ultraviolence, a wistful rendition of the title track from 2019â€™s generation-defining Norman Fucking Rockwell, and rapturously-received performances of songs from her 2012 debut Born to Die. Del Rey is not a high-energy performer, but she doesnâ€™t need to be one: surrounded by a band and about 10 dancers, she puts on an artfully choreographed show that walks a perilous line between discomfiting intimacy and stadium-show grandeur.
In the style of her records, Del Reyâ€™s live show is ramshackle and intensely thought-out at the same time; sometimes, she looks as if sheâ€™s forgotten the words to her own song, even as the dancers around her are pulling off an intricate, frenetic routine. Itâ€™s hard to pinpoint a specific highlight, because each song brings a new, surprising standout moment: Del Rey leads the crowd in a speak-along to the spoken word bridge of Ultraviolence; fans scream along to 2012â€™s Ride; White Mustang, perhaps my favourite song of all time but still, nonetheless, an underappreciated track in Del Reyâ€™s catalog, is turned into a depressing-slash-euphoric festival anthem.
When her sound gets cut, after White Mustang, thereâ€™s a ripple of discontent among the crowd; if I had to guess, I would think that at least a few hundred people traveled here just to see Del Reyâ€™s first UK show in four years. No matter â€“ the hour that she did perform was compelling and brilliant, a showcase of one of the worldâ€™s greatest living pop stars.

title: Lana Del Rey Settles â€˜Summertime Sadnessâ€™ Music Video Lawsuit
content:
Lana Del Rey has reached a settlement to end a lawsuit claiming her music video for â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ featured 17 seconds of material lifted directly from a copyrighted short film, weeks after a federal judge refused to dismiss the case.
Explore Explore Lana Del Rey See latest videos, charts and news See latest videos, charts and news
Lucas BolaÃ±o sued Del Ray (real name Elizabeth Grant) and Universal Music Group last year, accusing them of â€œblatant disregardâ€ of his rights. He claimed the 2012 video not only copied the footage from his short film â€œSky,â€ but even stole audio of a voice saying â€œRemember, I will always love you, bye.â€
But in a filing in California federal court on Tuesday, lawyers for both sides said they had reached an agreement for BolaÃ±o to drop his case. Specific terms of the settlement were not disclosed, and neither side immediately returned requests for comment.
The settlement came just a month after a federal judge refused to dismiss the lawsuit against Del Rey. The starâ€™s lawyers had argued that BolaÃ±o waited far too long to sue, but in a May 16 ruling, Judge Stephen Wilson sent the case to a jury trial â€” a risky proposition even for any defendant.
BolaÃ±o sued in July 2022, claiming the first 17 seconds of the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ music video was copied directly from his film, with â€œonly marginal differencesâ€ like cropping and color saturation: â€œThese minor alterations do not make Defendantsâ€™ copying any less apparent or egregious.â€
His lawyers claimed the video, which had more than 350 million views on YouTube when he filed his case, had â€œgenerated millions of dollars in royaltiesâ€ for Del Rey and UMG. â€œUnfortunately, Plaintiffs have not seen a dime of these ill-gotten proceeds and have never even been credited for their work,â€ they wrote.
In April, attorneys for Del Rey asked a federal judge to toss the case out. They didnâ€™t argue about whether or not the clip appeared in the music video, but said simply that BolaÃ±o had waited years too long to sue. In particular, they pointed to a 2015 YouTube comment on his short film, in which a user said â€œthis was used in Summertime Sadness!â€
â€œThe undisputed facts demonstrate that plaintiffs had actual knowledge of the music video and Del Reyâ€™s use of their works no later than 2015,â€ the starâ€™s lawyers wrote. â€œIgnoring clear, indisputable, and specific notice, plaintiffs waited an additional seven years to bring this suit.â€
But BolaÃ±o argued that he never saw that comment and didnâ€™t notice Del Reyâ€™s video until 2021. And last month, a Judge Wilson said a jury might believe that argument: â€œThese arguments are more properly resolved before the jury.â€

title: Gunna Gets a Viral â€˜Giftâ€™ With Early â€˜Fukumeanâ€™ Streaming Success
content:
Welcome to Billboard Proâ€™s Trending Up newsletter, where we take a closer look at the songs, artists, curiosities and trends that have caught the music industryâ€™s attention. Some have come out of nowhere, others have taken months to catch on, and all of them could become ubiquitous in the blink of a TikTok clip.
This week: Gunna changes the conversation with a new viral hit, Lana Del Rey brings fans back to â€œRadioâ€ days, a new viral hit revives the rapper who first had the internet going nuts and more.
Gunnaâ€™s New Album Is More â€˜Giftâ€™ Than â€˜Curseâ€™ With Viral â€˜Fukumeanâ€™
Last Friday (June 16), all eyes were on Gunna as the Grammy-nominated rapper returned with his first full-length project since his release from jail. Titled A Gift & A Curse, the album finds Gunna addressing his tumultuous past year, including his decision to plead guilty to a single racketeering charge after being included in a 56-count RICO indictment alongside fellow rapper Young Thug.
Like â€œPushin Pâ€ from Gunnaâ€™s last album, â€œFukumeanâ€ has emerged as an early fan-favorite and potential defining hit from A Gift & A Curse. According to Luminate, â€œFukumeanâ€ collected 10.3 million official on-demand U.S. streams during the period of June 16-20. From Sunday, June 18 to Monday, June 19, â€œFukumeanâ€ experienced a 20.4% increase in streams, and the following day that tally increased further to 2.2 million streams on June 20 â€” the songâ€™s biggest streaming day yet.
From the irresistible â€œQP, QP-skiâ€ ad-lib to the earworm that is the looped â€œeyuhâ€ vocal in the production, â€œFukumeanâ€ has garnered praise from fans and music listeners across social media. The official â€œFukumeanâ€ sound has been used in over 17,000 videos on TikTok in just six days of availability, with the most popular caption being some variation of â€œme still listening to Gunna even though he snitched.â€ Widespread misunderstandings of what an Alford Plea is aside, â€œFukumeanâ€ is undoubtedly the song to watch from A Gift & A Curse. â€” KYLE DENIS
Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜Radioâ€™ Edit Takes Over TikTok
Three months after issuing her ambitious studio album Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, Lana Del Rey has already watched two songs older than that album go viral on TikTok and gain in streams. First there was â€œSay Yes to Heaven,â€ a dreamy outtake from her Ultraviolence era that leaked online and became such a fan favorite that Del Rey released an official version in May, resulting in â€œHeavenâ€ reaching No. 54 on the Hot 100. Now, â€œRadio,â€ the pillowy anthem that was an album cut on Del Reyâ€™s 2012 major label debut Born To Die, has taken off on TikTok and nearly doubled in weekly streams over the past month â€” although this time, Del Reyâ€™s new album is partially responsible.
In addition to selecting the original â€œRadioâ€ to soundtrack clips â€” like Hailey Bieber did a few days ago to show off her stunning gown â€” TikTok users have adopted a mash-up of the track with the Ocean Blvd song â€œTaco Truck x VBâ€ (which is itself a mash-up of sorts, re-contextualizing her 2019 song â€œVenice Bitchâ€). Dozens of TikTok clips feature the â€œTaco Truckâ€ line â€œI know, I know, I know, that you hate meâ€ leading directly into the â€œRadioâ€ hook â€œNow my life is sweet like cinnamon,â€ often to crystallize a luxury-lifestyle flex (think a lavish wedding reception, rendered in slow-motion).
In any context, â€œRadioâ€ is running hot: the song earned 1.71 million U.S. on-demand streams during the week ending June 15, up from 864,000 streams from three weeks prior, according to Luminate. Although â€œHeavenâ€ is still earning more weekly streams, the rise of â€œRadioâ€ demonstrates Del Reyâ€™s continued power with Gen Z listeners: in the same way that Taylor Swift fans keep getting non-current songs to go viral and re-chart, Del Rey has a sprawling fan base ready and willing to champion decade-old deep cuts. â€“ JASON LIPSHUTZ
â€œDangâ€ Good Streaming Growth for That Mexican OT Viral Jam
The early TikTok tease still has power. 24-year-old Bay City, Texas rapper That Mexican OT posted a snippet of the then-unreleased â€œJohnny Dang,â€ which also features Houston stalwart Paul Wall along with DRODi, on the app May 9th. Commenters were quick to respond with urgent requests â€” â€œSomeone just give me the song name;â€ â€œI need itâ€ â€” and rave reviews: â€œAnyone elseâ€™s mini obsession rn?â€
In the week following the trackâ€™s official release through Cinematic Music Group on May 26th, it earned more than 2.5 million official on-demand U.S. streams, according to Luminate. The three rappers toss rollicking, rat-a-tat lines back and forth over a somber synthesizer loop, paying tribute to the Texas jeweler Johnny Dang. â€œGot me feeling like a baby thatâ€™s fiending, so where my bottle at?â€ That Mexican OT jokes. â€œIâ€™m just rhyminâ€™ words, I donâ€™t even know how to rap.â€ Rhyminâ€™ words is more than enough: On-demand streams have nearly doubled since the trackâ€™s release, rising to more than 4.5 million, good for a No. 44 debut on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. â€” ELIAS LEIGHT
Jey Oneâ€™s â€œOnanaâ€ Makes Major Gains
Even though the season technically started yesterday (June 21), the hunt for an indisputable song of the summer has already commenced. Jey One, a rising Dominican singer and rapper, is the latest artist to enter the ring.
With its thumping dembow riddim and the endlessly catchy â€œUh, na-na-naâ€ hook, Jey Oneâ€™s â€œOnanaâ€ has been making steady streaming gains thanks to its virality on TikTok. According to Luminate, â€œOnanaâ€ has had three consecutive weeks of double-digit streaming gains. The song earned 226,000 official on-demand U.S. streams during the week of May 19-25, and that tally increased by 36.5% for a total of 309,000 streams during the week of May 26 â€“ June 1. The following week, streams rose by 19.2% for a total of 368,00 0 official on-demand U.S. streams, and for the week of June 9-15, â€œOnanaâ€ streams rose by a further 25.6%, bringing its tally to 463,000 official on-demand U.S. streams for the period.
On TikTok, the official â€œOnanaâ€ sound boasts over 200,000 videos. Although there does not appear to be a consistent trend for videos using the song, some users have taken to mimicking Jey Oneâ€™s dances with his baby daughter using everything from their own children to their pet cats. Currently, â€œOnanaâ€ ranks within the top 25 of Apple Musicâ€™s New York City chart (which is updated daily); the track also ranks at No. 7 on the platformâ€™s Top Reggae Songs chart. â€“ KD
Q&A: Kimmy Summers, Artist Partnerships Lead at Spotify, on Whatâ€™s Trending Up in Her World
Frequency is Spotifyâ€™s content brand for amplifying Black artists and creators. How would you describe its day-to-day operations and goals?
No two days are the same as our team is very malleable with their job functions. From providing marketing support, advising on artists to include in campaigns, to tapping partners on how we can better invest in and build equity within the community â€“ weâ€™re never not thinking about how to further the narrative of Black artistry.
On a daily basis, weâ€™re collaborating on how we can highlight Black artists and creators on platform. Weâ€™re not only speaking to Black audiences, but to the companyâ€™s global audience via our social handle @OurFrequency, and strategizing on how we show up as a brand in a meaningful and authentic way. Our goal is to continue to find unique ways we can increase Spotifyâ€™s investment and visibility of Black talent through Frequency.
How has Frequency showcased Black voices during Black Music Month?
Iâ€™d be remiss if I didnâ€™t point out that Frequency was created specifically to highlight Black creativity all year roundâ€” not just on a holiday or designated month. From brand campaigns to targeted partnerships, we generally focus on spreading content, investment and editorial support on our hub on an ongoing basis vs funneling it into certain timeframes.
For Black Music Month, we wanted to redefine what Black artistry looks and sounds like to the average listener. We were really proud to feature and celebrate three Black, alternative-rock artists, collaborating with Meet Me @ The Altar, Zulu, and Jean Dawson to reimagine one of their original songs and a cover of another artistâ€™s single in partnership with Spotify Singles, a program that has driven over 7 billion streams since its 2017 launch. This special edition of Singles was promoted on and off platform via several marketing initiatives, including exclusive BTS social content, a billboard in L.A., and on-platform support driving to the content.
Why was it important to spotlight Black artists outside of hip-hop and R&B in those programs?
Itâ€™s important to show that Black artistry is not a monolith and itâ€™s not just represented by a singular genre. I think this industry has been hyper-focused on defining artists by one genre and putting them into a box which limits creativity and expression. Thatâ€™s why I work closely with Carl Chery [Spotifyâ€™s Head of Urban Music] and other members of the artist partnerships team to identify a diverse group of artists. Across every genre, thereâ€™s an array of talented Black creatives whose contributions deserve to be celebrated.
Fill in the blank: to emphasize user interest and engagement even (and especially) when social activism is not front-page news, music platforms must _________.
Continue to invest in all Black creators and amplify their voices. Music platforms have to remember that they are a vehicle and have the responsibility and power to not only amplify the voices of artists and creators, but empower them as well. â€“ JL
Seasonâ€™s Gainings: Father Streams Best
While we looked at Motherâ€™s Day bumps in Trending Up last month, itâ€™s Dadâ€™s turn now, as several classic paternally themed songs saw big gains this Sunday (June 18). Cat Stevensâ€™ â€œFather and Sonâ€ â€” which we also just covered in TU thanks to its Ted Lasso finale synch â€“ was a predictable big riser, up 50% to 185,000 daily official on-demand U.S. streams on Sunday (according to Luminate), helped by its placement atop Spotifyâ€™s official Fatherâ€™s Day playlist. Harry Chapinâ€™s â€œCatâ€™s in the Cradle,â€ another â€˜70s father-son classic, was also up 28% in daily streams to 163,000. And a pair of Fatherâ€™s Day jams from Daddyâ€™s Girl BeyoncÃ© Knowles also saw major gains: 2003â€™s â€œDaddyâ€ was up a whopping 398% to 38,000 streams, while 2016â€™s â€œDaddy Lessonsâ€ rose 45% to 46,000. â€” ANDREW UNTERBERGER

title: Did Olivia Rodrigo Tease a Lana Del Rey Collaboration? Fans Think So
content:
Olivia Rodrigo is officially moving into her next era, but will Lana Del Rey be coming with her? One seemingly innocent but possibly revealing Instagram post has convinced fans that the answer is yes.
The grounds for speculation are simple enough: On Wednesday (June 14), Rodrigo posted a mirror selfie posing next to a bright red lipstick kiss print on the glass in front of her, using lyrics to Lanaâ€™s â€œVenice Bitchâ€ in her caption. â€œBang bang kiss kiss,â€ the â€œDrivers Licenseâ€ singer wrote.
Now, it could just be the makings of a simple, cute Instagram post on Rodrigoâ€™s part, but some fans think thereâ€™s definitely more to the story. First of all, the 20-year-old singer-songwriter shared the lyrics just one day after announcing that her highly anticipated next era kicks off June 30 with a new single called â€œVampire,â€ her first release since her 2021 blockbuster debut album Sour. Itâ€™s also the first thing sheâ€™s posted since the announcement.
Second, Rodrigo and Del Rey are friends and fans of one another, as displayed at the 2023 Billboard Women in Music event earlier this year, where the two were filmed multiple times chatting and hugging in the audience. The former High School Musical: The Musical: The Series star presented Lana with the Visionary Award at the March ceremony and told the crowd, â€œLana has raised an entire generation of music lovers and songwriters like me, and taught them that thereâ€™s beauty in their vulnerability and power in their melancholy.â€
Accepting the award, the 37-year-old â€œA&Wâ€ musician gushed, â€œI canâ€™t tell you how much it means that someone who wrote â€˜Drivers Licenseâ€™ is standing next to me.â€
In conclusion, whether or not itâ€™s actually happening, a collaboration between the two artists on Rodrigoâ€™s upcoming sophomore album is definitely possible â€” at least, it is in the eyes of fans. â€œTHE CAPTION? COLLAB W LANA??â€ commented one on Rodrigoâ€™s post.
â€œBANG BANG KISS KISS?? VENICE BTC??? COLLAB WITH LANA?!!! OMG,â€ wrote another.
â€œGIRL DONT U DARE TELL ME IM GETTING A LANA COLLAB,â€ one fan added.
See Oliviaâ€™s post below:

title: Glastonbury Festival headliners reimagined doing 'normal' jobs in new AI pictures
content:
Fans can see what Elton John would look like working at a supermarket checkout and if Lana Del Rey was a police officer
A Glastonbury Festival fan has used AI to imagine what some of the top acts from the UK's biggest music event would look like doing 'normal' jobs. Images show Elton John on a supermarket checkout, The Arctic Monkey's Alex Turner as a milkman and Guns N' Roses vocalist Axl Rose as a mechanic.
Lana Del Rey is also featured as police officer, rock guitarist Slash can be seen working as a fast food chef and Milkshake singer Kelis in a McDonald's drive-thru. Creator Duncan Thomsen, 53, says he wasn't aiming for a retro look for the images, but says he is happy with the results.
The freelance film editor, from Brighton, said: "They actually look really real; they look just like them. I did them all in about a day, but you can work on one of these for up to a few days. They look quite retro which wasn't intentional but they look very cool.
"I particularly like the second one of Elton when he's looking over his shoulder - it looks just like him. I also thing the one of Alex Turner as a 1960's milkman looks really cool. It really fits his vibe - if he was around in the 60s I think he would be a milkman.
"Lana Del Rey also quite simply looks so cool as a policewoman. That one turned out very well."
General Widget
AI responds to prompts and commands set by the user and creates pictures by referencing billions of images online. Duncan uses the software Midjourney to make his own hyper-realistic photos.
He added: "It can be quite a lengthy process but the results are fantastic. I've been to Glastonbury myself 13 times but didn't manage to get a ticket this year.
"Which is a shame as the line-up is clearly fantastic. These pictures are just a way to join the fun and I'm very happy with how realistic and fun they are."
Glastonbury Festival will be running from from June 21 to June 26 this year. It will be held at its usual location of Worthy Farm in Somerset.
