title: Lana Del Rey's 'Say Yes to Heaven' Includes a John Lennon Reference
content:
Lana Del Rey's "Say Yes to Heaven" references a John Lennon song. Notably, the tune recontextualizes the title of one of John's most famous solo songs.
Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€œSay Yes to Heavenâ€ references a John Lennon song. Notably, the tune recontextualizes the title of one of Johnâ€™s most famous solo songs. In the same vein, Del Rey has paid homage to many other classic rock icons.
Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜Say Yes to Heavenâ€™ uses the title of John Lennonâ€™s â€˜Give Peace a Chanceâ€™
Looking through Del Reyâ€™s catalog, she clearly has a healthy obsession with classic rock. Here catalog includes lyrical shout-outs to tunes by Elvis Presley, The Beatles, The Beach Boys, Elton John, David Bowie, The Mamas & the Papas, Lou Reed, Harry Nilsson, The Crystals, and numerous other great artists. Sheâ€™s also covered tunes by Donovan, Nirvana, Nancy Sinatra, Sublime, and other rock stars.
In â€œSay Yes to Heaven,â€ Del Rey sings â€œIf you dance, Iâ€™ll dance / And if you donâ€™t, Iâ€™ll dance anyway / Give peace a chance / Let the fear you have fall away.â€ This is a clear callback to Johnâ€™s â€œGive Peace a Chance.â€ Of course, Del Reyâ€™s use of the phrase changes its meaning.
Johnâ€™s track was a protest against the Vietnam War. On the other hand, Del Rey turns â€œgive peace a chanceâ€ into a piece of interpersonal advice. In â€œSay Yes to Heaven,â€ she uses the phrase to encourage her love interest to let go of his emotional baggage.
Lana Del Rey doesnâ€™t regurgitate the peaceful message of John Lennonâ€™s song
Of course, â€œSay Yes to Heavenâ€ is not an entirely peaceful track. In one of the later verses, Del Rey sings â€œIf you dance, Iâ€™ll dance / Iâ€™ll put my red dress on, get it on / And if you fight, Iâ€™ll fight / It doesnâ€™t matter now, itâ€™s all gone.â€ Strangely, John might have been alright with that.
The book All We Are Saying: The Last Major Interview with John Lennon and Yoko Ono includes a 1980 interview. In it, John discussed the meaning of â€œGive Peace a Chance.â€ â€œIt wasnâ€™t like â€˜You have to have peace!'â€ he said. â€œJust give it a chance. We ainâ€™t giving any gospel here â€” just saying how about this version for a change? We think we have the right to have a say in the future. And we think the future is made in your mind.â€
How â€˜Give Peace a Chanceâ€™ and â€˜Say Yes to Heavenâ€™ performed on the chart
â€œGive Peace a Chanceâ€ was a hit for the Plastic Ono Band. It reached No. 14 on the Billboard Hot 100, staying on the chart for nine weeks. The track was originally a non-album single. Eventually, John released it on the compilation album Shaved Fish. That record reached No. 12 on the Billboard 200, remaining on the chart for 32 weeks.
On the other hand, â€œSay Yes to Heavenâ€ is a more modest hit thus far. It reached No. 53 on the Billboard Hot 100, lasting on the chart for three weeks. The â€œRideâ€ singer has yet to include â€œSay Yes to Heavenâ€ on any of her albums.
â€œSay Yes to Heavenâ€ is a fascinating song and it shows Johnâ€™s music is relevant to modern singers.

title: Lana Del Rey's dad, Rob Grant, releases new album: 'Nepo daddy'
content:
Youâ€™ve heard all about nepo babies â€” the derogatory term for Hollywood offspring who magically wind up following in their celebrity parentsâ€™ footsteps.
Now, meet the worldâ€™s first nepo daddy.
As a former advertising copywriter, itâ€™s possible that 69-year-old Rob Grant, piano man and father to Lana Del Rey, might have eventually come up with the term as a way to market himself and his debut album, â€œLost at Sea.â€
But someone on social media beat him to the verbal punch.
And he loved it.
â€œI first saw it in my comments, and I thought, â€˜Holy smokes, thatâ€™s a beautiful brand!â€™ â€ Grant told The Post.
â€œSo I went out and registered the domain nepodaddy.com, and then I called the guys at Decca [Records, his label] and said, â€˜Weâ€™ve got to do merch around this â€¦ I love kind of being the first nepo daddy out there.â€
Grant has his 37-year-old firstborn â€” whose alt-pop allure has led her to six Grammy nominations, including an Album of the Year nod for 2019â€™s â€œNorman Fâ€”king Rockwell!â€ â€” to thank for his new nepo-daddy notoriety. And with Fatherâ€™s Day just a week away, heâ€™s one proud papa about working with his famous daughter on his first LP.
â€œFor over a decade, she has persevered,â€ said Grant of his daughter, born Elizabeth Grant, who made her major-label debut with 2012â€™s â€œBorn to Die.â€ â€œSheâ€™s stayed totally true to her own unique style of music. And sheâ€™s now arrived at a point, culturally, where I think sheâ€™s at her apex. You know, so many artists look up to her. Her music is loved around the world. So thatâ€™s really wonderful for me as a father to see.â€
Rob Grant first collaborated with daughter Lana Del Rey on 2021â€™s â€œSweet Carolina.â€ PeBu / BACKGRID
Getting Del Rey to add her signature sultry vocals to two â€œLost at Seaâ€ tracks â€” the title tune and â€œHollywood Bowlâ€ â€” Grant made new discoveries about his daughter. â€œOne thing that I really learned and I really appreciate about Lana is she is remarkably intuitive,â€ he said.
Father and daughter first collaborated on â€œSweet Carolinaâ€ â€” the final track on Del Reyâ€™s 2021 album â€œBlue Bannisters â€” while he was visiting her at her home.
â€œThat came about because she had been listening to me playing the piano â€¦ and she yelled down, â€˜What is that?â€™ And I said, â€˜Iâ€™m just improvising,â€™ â€ said Grant. â€œShe came down, and she said, â€˜Can you create a bridge?â€™ And I did. And right away she began to sing. It was very spontaneous. And within Iâ€™d say 30 or 40 minutes we had composed that lovely piano ballad. And honestly, thatâ€™s how all of our songs since then have been composed. Itâ€™s really a remarkable process where she hears something that Iâ€™m playing, and she begins to sing lyrics literally on the fly.â€
Rob Grant and daughter Lana Del Rey make it a family affair in their new video for â€œLost at Sea.â€ Chuck Grant
On the mostly instrumental â€œLost at Sea,â€ Grant displays a penchant on the keys for the same kind of moody melancholy as his daughter.
â€œItâ€™s somewhere in our DNA, way down deep,â€ he said. â€œI love the minor chords. I love that haunting, melancholy sound. And so does Lana.â€
The video for the new single, â€œLost at Sea,â€ is even more of a family affair.
Rob Grant formerly worked at Grey Advertising in New York before launching new music career at 69. Chuck Grant
â€œMy other daughter, Caroline, was a director and then Charlie, my son, was very involved in the production,â€ said Grant. â€œWe found these old VHS tapes that I had 30 years ago with the kids growing up, and we decided to intersperse the video with those beautiful, very nostalgic pieces of film. It makes it so sweet.â€
With â€œLost at Sea,â€ Grant has found a new career as a retiree who has worked in advertising, real estate and domain investment. And as a nepo daddy, he is also standing up for the nepo babies of the world.
â€œThe whole nepo baby thing was, you know, basically an attempt to undermine all of those kids who had come from celebrity parents,â€ he said. â€œAnd thatâ€™s the problem with our culture today. We live in a very cynical world, and nobody wants to give anybody credit for doing anything.â€

title: Irish gig guide: Lana Del Rey, Dermot Kennedy, Damien Dempsey, Otherside Festival
content:
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Invalid email Something went wrong, please try again later.
Sign up to our free email alerts for the best Promotions sent straight to your e-mail
LANA DEL REY
3Arena, Dublin,
Tonight, SOLD OUT
Lana Del Rey has never been out of the music press since emerging a decade or so ago, but her recent Glastonbury headline spot spilled over into mainstream.
READ MORE - Beyond The Pale 2024: Tickets on sale Friday as festival returns for third year
The New Yorkerâ€™s set was cut short after she arrived on stage 30 minutes late, saying: â€œIâ€™m so fucking late they may cut my set. Iâ€™m sorry, my hair takes so long. If they cut the power, letâ€™s keep going.â€
Despite a spirited attempt to carry on a capella after the power was switched off, Lana was escorted offstage amind bemusement and the faithful doing the heavy lifting singing her lines back at her.
Still, it didnâ€™t knock her back. A few days later she announced: "I love Europe and after playing Glastonbury, have decided to play a few more showsâ€¦ I look forward to seeing you all.â€
Dublin, Amsterdam and Paris were the chosen ones, and tickets predictably sold out right away.
Itâ€™s her first Dublin show since Malahide Castle in 2019, and she headlined Electric Picnic in 2016, but this is her first indoor show in an age, hopefully adding more intensity to her so-called â€˜Hollywood Sadcoreâ€™.
Far from the hyped-up â€œhello Irelandâ€ antics, expect more aloof goings-on among the dark pop and woozy, cinematic nods to 1950s and 60s Americana.
Accused for years by snooty critics of inauthenticity and being an industry plant, her live shows â€” maybe apart from Glasto â€” are often transcendent affairs, so what do they know.
OTHERSIDE FESTIVAL
Rock Farm Slane, Co Meath
Tonight-Sunday, â‚¬200 (day tickets â‚¬69)
Otherside at Slane is a quite a few degrees of separation (and a few tens of thousands) away from the iconic events at the same Slane Castle grounds.
While modern pop hero Harry Styles headlined at the castle this year, since the 1980s Slane has been a traditional home of heritage rock, but Otherside is looking further leftfield.
Theyâ€™re pitching at â€œstar-gazers, trailblazers and those at home amidst the smoke and lasersâ€, with a â€œcarefully crafted line-up reflecting our values of diversityâ€.
While many Irish festivalsâ€™ sustainability credentials are shady at best, Slane Rock Farm is an eco-sustainable working farm, with a goal of â€œrelaxing and replenishingâ€.
That part of the deal is sealed with a wellness programme, glamping, a lake for swimming and a higher class of festival food.
That spirit of diversity is reflected in the eclectic line-up, which skews towards house, techno and electronica for the late nights, with the likes of Kolsch, SBTRKT, Fatima Yamaha, Skream and 49th & Main, for starters.
But thereâ€™s plenty more if youâ€™re not into strobes and relentless beats. Country-pop superstar CMAT is headlining tomorrow, and indie-rockers Bombay Bicycle Club finish off Sunday, while other highlights include disco duo Confidence Man, rapper and spoken word artist Maverick Sabre, and delicate electronic pop from George Fitzgerald.
DERMOT KENNEDY
Thomond Park, Limerick,
Tonight, tomorrow and Sunday, â‚¬53.65
The last artist to do multiple dates at Thomond Park was Ed Sheeran, and his double-drop at the famous rugby stadium tripled revenues for a typical year.
Dermot Kennedy has gone one better with three gigs this weekend, so itâ€™s another big money-spinner.
Three stadium gigs outside of Dublin may seem excessive for a young artist, but Kennedy is one of Irelandâ€™s biggest blockbuster draws, with over three billion streams on Spotify alone.
Heâ€™s a broad radio-friendly crowd pleaser, with his super sleek production, on-the-nose earnestness and just the right amount of electronic pop sheen that wonâ€™t scare the middle ground.
In 2017, Kennedy was playing Dublinâ€™s 350-capacity Sugar Club, and by 2019 heâ€™d played four sold-out gigs at the Olympia, Electric Picnic, Malahide Castle and dozens of gigs in Europe and North America, including Glastonbury and Coachella.
Since then heâ€™s moved to big outdoor stages like Marlay Park and St Anneâ€™s Park, and this trio is the next logical step.
TOO MANY ZOOZ
Sugar Club, Dublin,
Tonight, 7.30pm (SOLD OUT) and late show (â‚¬25.40)
FORMER buskers Too Many Zooz first broke after a viral video of a performance at a New York subway, when the filming passenger was so blown away she let her train go past three times to catch more of their DIY show.
The trio have dubbed their music â€˜brasshouseâ€™, and this stuff needs to be done right so itâ€™s not just a quirky contrivance that adds a buzz to your step when youâ€™re running for a train. Itâ€™s a hyper horned-up dance music fusion on saxophone, trumpet and a makeshift drum kit.
You can pick out elements of ska, jazz, house, metal, punk and whatever else you can project onto them to lose the plot and try to dance with as much abandon as sax player Lee Pellegrino.
Theyâ€™re now a regular touring band so theyâ€™re not really hustling in tunnels anymore â€” but they still lean into their street performer cred, and their promo video for this European tour was shot at NYCâ€™s Union Square.
Itâ€™d be funny if they decide on a random spot in Dublin today, among the acoustic lads singing Ed Sheeran and Dermot Kennedy, and some lad making a labrador out of sand.
DAMIEN DEMPSEY
Iveagh Gardens, Dublin,
Tonight & tomorrow, SOLD OUT
DAMIEN Dempseyâ€™s annual festive run of shows at Vicar Street have become a sort of collective outpouring of emotion for loyal fans, but a Damo gig is not just for Christmas.
The north Dublin singer-songwriter, poet, activist and all-round working class hero is taking it to the great outdoors for another hometown show.
Damo paid an emotional tribute to the late Christy Dignam, who he called â€œthe peopleâ€™s great chanter and characterâ€ â€” a title that could easily be applied to himself, with his unassuming manner, deep poetic writing and heartfelt, honest ballads and protest songs.
These two sold-out shows should be an emotional sucker-punch and the biggest singalong in the city all weekend.

title: Jon Batiste Announces New Album World Music Radio, Shares New Song â€œCalling Your Nameâ€
content:
Jon Batiste has announced the follow-up to 2021â€™s We Are, which won the Grammy Award for Album of the Year in 2022. World Music Radio is out August 18 (via Verve/Interscope). The first single is â€œCalling Your Name.â€ Lil Wayne, Lana Del Rey, Kenny G, JID, Fireboy DML, Camilo, NewJeans, and producer Jon Bellion all contributed to the album. Listen to the new song below.
â€œI created this album with a feeling of liberation in my life and a renewed sense of exploration of my personhood, my craft and of the world around me unlike anything I had ever felt before,â€ Batiste said in a statement. A few months after he won the Grammy, Batiste stepped down from his role as Stephen Colbertâ€™s Late Show bandleader. In 2021, Batiste won an Academy Award alongside Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross for his work on Soul.

title: Lana Del Rey announces surprise concert in Dublin with just 10 days notice
content:
L ana Del Rey has thrilled fans with news of a last-minute gig in Dublin - but only gave them ten daysâ€™ notice to find tickets.
Today, the singer announced she would perform a surprise show in Dublinâ€™s 3Arena on July 7. The news come after her mic cut off while performing at Glastonbury this weekend.
Lana may be trying to make amends after she was 30 minutes late to her set at Worthy Farm because her hair wasnâ€™t finished. Organisers at Worthy Farm were forced to cut her off mid-set as they did not have permission to carry on having live music on the main stages past midnight.
In addition to the Dublin date, Lana has also added extra shows in Paris and Amsterdam.
She said: â€œI love Europe and after playing Glastonbury, have decided to play a few more shows in various countries around my Hyde Park Show in London on July 9th. Today I am announcing shows in Amsterdam on July 4th, Dublin on July 7th and Paris on July 10th. I look forward to seeing you all.â€
Tickets for the 3Arena gig are priced from â‚¬69.70 (Â£59.93) and go on sale this Friday, June 30, at 9am from Ticketmaster here.
Lana seemed to have left fans disappointed when she was late to her set on Sunday. Festivalgoers queued eagerly before her set to get a good spot. She was due to start at 10.30pm, but did not step out until around 11pm.
Telling her fans at the Other Stage about her wardrobe malfunctions, she said: â€œIâ€™m so f**ing late they may cut my set. Iâ€™m sorry, my hair takes so long. If they cut the power, letâ€™s keep going.â€
She stepped down from the stage and tried to sing to the crowd without her mic but was forced to call it quits.

title: Glastonbury 2023 review: giggly rap on Friday, Smiths covers on Saturday - and a mystery act that surprised no one
content:
This yearâ€™s Glastonbury festival site seemed to be as awash with wild speculation as ever. Sundayâ€™s headliner Elton John would supposedly be performing with special guest Britney Spears â€“ for some reason, a post on Spearsâ€™s Instagram account featuring a photograph of a segmented apple was held up as incontrovertible proof that she was boarding a Somerset-bound helicopter. Others were convinced that Elton was going to bring on Harry Styles: after last year, when you could barely walk a few feet without hearing someone sagely informing someone else that Styles was definitely going to turn up on stage with Paul McCartney, or Billie Eilish, or Kendrick Lamar, or perhaps dishing up pad thai in a food stall just south of the Other stage, the former One Direction heart-throb now appears to be a permanent fixture of the Glasto rumour mill. Most lurid of all, there were those who insisted that the final British show of Johnâ€™s record-breaking farewell tour was going to be enlivened by the spectral appearance of a hologram of the late George Michael.
Nevertheless, what was supposed to be the weekendâ€™s biggest surprise turned out to be its worst-kept secret. Stories that the mysterious band who appear on Friday afternoonâ€™s Pyramid stage bill as the Churnups are actually Blur or Pulp â€“ two Britpop heroes currently reformed and playing shows â€“ have long died out: everyone seems to know it is actually Foo Fighters, playing more or less the same slot at the festival as they did 25 years ago, when they were making their Glastonbury debut. Still, the audience gamely play along, roaring as if itâ€™s an incredible and welcome revelation when the Churnupsâ€™ logo vanishes from the stage-side screens and is replaced by that of Dave Grohl and co.
The secretâ€™s out â€¦ Dave Grohl of Foo Fighters on the Pyramid stage, with new drummer Josh Freese. Photograph: David Levene/The Guardian
Foregone conclusion or not, theres a genuine sense of excitement about their hour-long performance. Foo Fightersâ€™ recent albums have arrived with an accompanying sense of obligation, as if they have been made simply to give the band an excuse to continue touring without slipping into the â€œheritage rockâ€ category, filled with songs designed to tolerably plug the gaps between the hits in concert. However, this yearâ€™s But Here We Are â€“ their first album since the 2022 death of drummer Taylor Hawkins â€“ felt charged with a fresh sense of purpose and energy, as does their Glastonbury set. The band literally run on stage, already playing their guitars; as they charge through All My Life and a version of 2020â€™s No Son of Mine that comes interpolated with the riffs of Black Sabbathâ€™s Paranoid and Metallicaâ€™s Enter Sandman, they sound more raw and vital than any artists rightfully should 28 years into their career. Grohlâ€™s daughter Violet makes a brief appearance on vocals â€“ impressively, sheâ€™s the very model of gum-chewing nonchalance in front of tens of thousands of people â€“ but the most striking thing about their performance is how relaxed the songs sound, extended with lengthy solos and impressive fills from Hawkinsâ€™ replacement, Josh Freese. However awful the circumstances leading up to their most recent album, they sound like a band with something to prove, who are enjoying themselves enormously in the process of proving it.
Glastonbury is famously eclectic, its sheer scale and plethora of stages enabling it to be all things to all people: this is an event at which you can kickstart your Saturday morning by watching Rick Astley performing AC/DC covers while playing the drums, the Unthanks essaying trad arr folk, New York alt-disco trio Say She She followed by veteran Congolese soukous musician Kanda Bongo Man, or indeed by heading up to the Park stage to take in post-minimalist composer Max Richter accompanied by a string quartet and Tilda Swinton, reading the spoken word passages from his 2003 suite The Blue Notebooks.
The face of optimism â€¦ Carly Rae Jepsen. Photograph: Maja Smiejkowska/Shutterstock
Even so, the sense that the festival is now actively trying to court two different generations at once feels very pronounced on the two main stages. On Friday afternoon, the Lightning Seeds lead a nostalgic singalong through Three Lions, before being replaced on the Other stage by Carly Rae Jepsen, resplendent in a pink trouser suit, belting out the dance-pop of Call Me Maybe and I Really Like You from atop a platform draped with gold lamÃ©. Jepsen is held to be one of popâ€™s great mysteries: since her 2015 breakthrough Emotion, her albums have been rapturously received by critics â€“ sheâ€™s very much a poster girl for the influential strain of music criticism known as â€œpoptimismâ€, a reaction against rockâ€™s dominance of the music press â€“ but have consistently underperformed commercially. Her Glastonbury set gives an indication of what the issue might be, beyond the fact that people who buy pop albums couldnâ€™t give a monkeyâ€™s what music critics say about anything. Jepsen is infectiously enthusiastic â€“ running from the stage to press the flesh with the front rows, before realising sheâ€™s not going to make it back to the stage in time for the start of the next song â€“ but she isnâ€™t a hugely charismatic performer: her songs are great, but whatever ingredient she has that might set her apart from the serried ranks of pop vocalists isnâ€™t obvious. Still, if itâ€™s charisma youâ€™re after, Sharleen Spiteri has it in abundance during Texasâ€™s parallel set on the Pyramid stage: there is something hugely engaging about the gulf between the honeyed sweetness of her singing during Summer Sun, and her Glasgow-accented earthiness between songs, berating the crowd for their â€œshit dad dancingâ€.
Generating mass euphoria â€¦ Fred Again on the Other stage. Photograph: Maja Smiejkowska/Shutterstock
The task of following Foo Fighters hangs heavy over Royal Blood, who perform to a significantly smaller crowd than you might expect of a band second from top of the bill on the Pyramid stage. You get the feeling people have had their fill of hard rock and headed off to hear something different. Certainly, the crowd that assembles at the Other stage for dance auteur Fred Again suggests so. There are so many festivalgoers there that queues form just to get into the field, a state of affairs that seems to render Fred Again himself almost speechless: whenever he attempts to talk to the audience, his voice dissolves into disbelieving giggles. But, watching him, you can totally understand his popularity: his sound draws on Burial-esque dubstep, grime â€“ Rumble features MC Flowdan â€“ and house, neatly tied up with a keen pop sensibility. You could argue that the end result is a little depthless â€“ thereâ€™s a one-size-fits-all quality to the vocal samples he uses, which tend to non-specific evocations of vague melancholy (â€œpull me out of thisâ€,â€œthe night is darkâ€), but that feels like quibbling in the face of its ability to generate mass euphoria, particularly this evening, where it fits the moment perfectly. It appears that a lot of those present are using his set as a kind of aperitif before hurling themselves into an evening of dance tents and altered states, a job for which itâ€™s perfectly suited: itâ€™s music that carries a sense of anticipation â€“ the promise of the night, if you like â€“ within its textures.
Arctic Monkeysâ€™ headlining Pyramid stage set presents something of a conundrum. They are probably the biggest alternative rock band in Britain, but, judging by the albums chart, their mass popularity rests on two albums, their 2006 debut and 2013â€™s muscular, hard-rock influenced AM: certainly, there have been fewer takers for the more expansive and serpentine sound of the more recent Tranquility Base Hotel & Casino and The Car, albums which also deal largely in slow-paced atmospherics. The obvious thing to do when confronted with a huge festival crowd would be to lean heavily on their biggest sellers, but a band who called their debut album Whatever You Say I Am, Thatâ€™s What Iâ€™m Not were perhaps never likely to take the obvious, crowd-pleasing option. They open with The Carâ€™s brooding Sculptures of Anything Goes, play Whatever You Say I Am â€¦â€™s Mardy Bum at funereal pace, dramatically rearrange 505 â€“ a huge viral hit on TikTok that one suspects introduced them to a younger audience â€“ throw in occasional songs from AM, then dissipate the excitement they generate with the next track. Itâ€™s a state of affairs compounded by the fact that frontman Alex Turner inhabits a character on stage â€“ a kind of parodic version of an oily cabaret crooner. You can understand why he does it, and the bandâ€™s diehard fans love it, but itâ€™s hard to generate a rapport with a broader audience if they arenâ€™t in on the joke, if everything you say to them sounds sarcastic: he even has a way of saying thank you that sounds like itâ€™s got inverted commas around it.
A parody cabaret crooner â€¦ Alex Turner fronting Arctic Monkeysâ€™ Friday-night headline slot. Photograph: Jonny Weeks/The Guardian
The set peters out rather than ends explosively â€“ an extended version of The Carâ€™s Body Paint â€“ but by then, a significant chunk of the crowd have drifted off: for all Glastonburyâ€™s reputation for bountiful good vibes, thereâ€™s a certain no-thanks brutality to audiences here, borne out by the fact that thereâ€™s always something else to go and see. Itâ€™s hard to work out whether to applaud the band for bullishly sticking to their guns and doing things their way, or see it as a missed opportunity: on social media, it provokes a debate that rages into the night.
Saturdayâ€™s bill looks like such an embarrassment of riches, itâ€™s hard to work out a path through it: youâ€™re going to miss something you want to see. Thereâ€™s a strong UK rap presence on both main stages. It would take a fairly mammoth effort to dislike the cheeky shtick of Manchesterâ€™s Aitch â€“ he arranges a moshpit in the crowd and plays My G, a song dedicated to his sister, who has Downâ€™s syndrome, featuring a sample of Ed Sheeran, then follows it with the words â€œbut letâ€™s not get soft and sentimental, letâ€™s go fucking mental insteadâ€, then brings on singer Anne-Marie to perform their hit Psycho in character as a warring couple. Central Cee, meanwhile, is both a lavishly gifted rapper, capable of giving drill a pop sheen without denuding it of its edge â€“ a hugely impressive feat â€“ and responsible for perhaps the flat-out weirdest moment of the weekend, when he elects to perform his current No 1 hit Sprinter not just in the company of guest star Dave, but a profoundly nonplussed-looking baby (the same baby, apparently, that features in the songâ€™s video).
Astonishing power â€¦ Raye on the Pyramid stage on Saturday. Photograph: Dave Hogan/Hogan Media/Shutterstock
Pop star Raye can rap, too, although your attention is grabbed more by the astonishing power of her voice â€“ sheâ€™s emotive and effortless, never descending into showy oversinging â€“ and her easy Croydon-accented charm on stage. â€œDating rappers,â€ she advises, â€œI wouldnâ€™t recommend it.â€ Sheâ€™s also blessed with a plethora of fantastic, hard-hitting songs that act as a kind of diary, detailing the pitfalls that await a young woman in the music business, from sexually predatory producers to unsympathetic record labels to substance abuse. A year ago, she had been more or less written off by her label, she explains, and now sheâ€™s holding a sizeable Glastonbury crowd rapt, investing Ice Cream Man with such force that she seems to be struggling not to cry as she sings. For the more nostalgically minded, thereâ€™s punk supergroup Generation Sex blazing their way through a set of Sex Pistols and Generation X classics on the Other stage â€“ â€œIâ€™m at a party at Stonehenge later, Iâ€™m gonna get fucked up tonight,â€ offers the surprisingly elocuted voice of Billy Idol as a parting shot â€“ while up on the Woodsiesâ€™ stage, Rick Astley â€“ him again â€“ is performing a set of songs by the Smiths accompanied by indie band Blossoms. The response is immediate euphoria, a mass singalong of such volume that it threatens to drown Astley out entirely, a sense that heâ€™s not playing a gig so much as performing a public service in reclaiming the joy of the Smithsâ€™ back catalogue for anyone put off by some of the more troubling pronouncements from the bandâ€™s former lead singer. He also looks as if heâ€™s having the time of his life doing it: stopping the sets to drink â€œa snifterâ€ with his backing band, literally miming hanging someone during Panic, flailing the microphone lead around in an affectionate impersonation of Morrissey. The fact that thereâ€™s an enormous inflatable sausage being batted around the crowd â€“ something you suspect would cause the notoriously meat-opposing Morrissey to abandon the gig at a stroke â€“ only seems to add to the dizzy enjoyment.
An explosion of elation â€¦ Lizzo on the Pyramid stage. Photograph: Jonny Weeks/The Guardian
Thereâ€™s also dizzy enjoyment on the Pyramid stage, courtesy of Lizzo, who looks incredible in a succession of catsuits, surrounded by plus-sized dancers and an all-female band â€“ called, magnificently, the Lizzbians â€“ her face a constantly shifting mass of stagey expressions. You could, if you wished, take a cynical attitude to the way she constantly underlines her message of self-love â€“ and a more cynical attitude still to the fact that she starts hawking her shapewear range, Yitty, between songs â€“ but her performance is such an explosion of elation, filled with wit and energy and hooky tunes, that you donâ€™t really feel like taking her to task over any of it.
Perhaps Lizzo and Astleyâ€™s good humour is infectious: the big surprise about Guns Nâ€™ Rosesâ€™ headlining performance is how polite Axl Rose â€“ once the living embodiment of shows-starting-hours-late and litigious bad attitude â€“ is. Their performance starts bang on time (no such luck for Lana Del Rey fans, who wait half an hour for the singer to show up on the Other stage and see her set cut short by eight songs as a result). â€œYou had a good day?â€ he asks the audience, solicitously. â€œGlad to hear it.â€
Cut short â€¦ Lana Del Rey on the Other stage. Photograph: Samir Hussein/WireImage
If Roseâ€™s falsetto is a little more ragged now than it was in the late 80s, he can still hit the high notes, while the bandâ€™s appealingly loose stew of Stones-y slide guitar, metallic edge and punk insolence â€“ their version of Back on the Farm is presumably the first time a song by second-wave Brit punk band UK Subs has boomed forth from the Pyramid stage â€“ underlines why they were so successful in the first place. Their set not only picks its way through their back catalogue, it pays homage to their influences, sartorially and musically: bassist Duff McKagan sports a leather vest with the logo of the debut album by Johnny Thundersâ€™ Heartbreakers; as well as the UK Subs, there are covers of the Stoogesâ€™ TV Eye and snatches of Jimi Hendrix and Alice Cooper worked into their own songs. It ends with a pile-up of authentic classics â€“ November Rain, Night Train, Paradise City, the latter featuring Dave Grohl, beaming like a man keen to suggest that the famous feud between Guns Nâ€™ Roses and Nirvana was nothing to do with him. â€œWhat a lovely evening,â€ offers Axl Rose, like a man taking his leave from a dinner party: unexpectedly charming to the last.

title: Glastonbury 2023: From Dave Grohl's pop-ups to Lana Del Rey's hair delay and Cate Blanchett's surprise boogie on stage - all the moments you might have missed
content:
"I love its weirdness. It's consistently strange compared to other festivals - they bring the weirdness every time."
This was his eleventh time at Glastonbury Festival, but for Matt Baker, from Devon, there is always something new to explore. First-timers Rob and Vanessa Burnham, from Brighton, echoed the sentiment: "It's uncensored fun at every turn. You never know what you'll stumble across and that's what makes it so different."
It is a feeling shared by tens of thousands of other fans who make the trip to Worthy Farm each year - while the headliners put on a spectacular show, it's the unexpected moments and weird and wonderful things you stumble across away from the main stages that really make this the best festival in the world.
Arctic Monkeys closed the first night, Guns 'n' Roses rocked on Saturday, and Sir Elton John provided the grand finale with what he has said will be his final UK tour show. Oh, and Dave Grohl popped up (almost) everywhere.
But away from those big names, here are the moments you might not have seen.
Celeb spotting
Glastonbury is known for attracting A-listers, from the big stars headlining the main stages to those simply enjoying the fun.
This year was no exception, with Sir Paul McCartney seen stage-side for the Foo Fighters' not-so-surprise set on the Friday night - and apparently also spotted having a wander near to the famous Glastonbury sign (sadly, we just missed him) on Saturday evening.
Oscar-winner Cate Blanchett brought some real star power on Friday as she joined US pop-rock duo Sparks for a performance of their track The Girl Is Crying In Her Latte, for which she features in the music video, while fellow actress Tilda Swinton (pictured above) performed with modern classical instrumentalist Max Richter.
Advertisement
Kate Hudson, Stormzy, Lily James, Billie Piper, Holly Willoughby, Princess Beatrice and more were also among the stars checking out acts including Aitch and Tom Grennan.
Rick Astley proves to be a Glastonbury fave
As many festival-goers are still sleeping off the night before, the daily opening slot on the Pyramid stage is usually a quieter affair for those who have made it out of their tents early.
Not so for Rick Astley, who drew an enormous crowd to the Pyramid Stage at midday on Saturday.
Astley, 57, proved that while Never Gonna Give You Up is undoubtedly a pop banger, he has many more strings to his bow, giving Glastonbury a set of cleverly selected tracks that included something for everyone - from a cover of Harry Styles' mega hit As It Was to showing off his drumming skills on AC/DC's Highway To Hell.
"One of my dreams has been to perform at Glastonbury - that dream has come true today," he told the crowd.
Later on, the star also performed a "surprise" set with Blossoms - hailed as a highlight by many watching coverage from home.
Glastonbury pays tribute to a Queen
Image: Pic: Henry Mills
In what is known as the festival's "naughty corner" there are all sorts of clubs and secret hidey-holes to continue the party way after the main stages have closed.
At The NYC Downlow, in the Block9 area, the crew paid tribute to the late Paul O'Grady in spectacular style on Saturday night - think "Liverpool glam housewife on steroids".
And on Sunday, for those who might have wanted to avoid the main stage crowd for Sir Elton, there was a night of Rocket Glam, with excess as the brief.
Raving around the Greenpeace tree
Image: Pic: Greenpeace/Marie Jacquemin
The rather magical rave tree, situated in Greenpeace's corner of the festival, has become one of the best places to party at Glastonbury over the past few years.
Last year saw sets from the likes of Spice Girl Mel C and Self Esteem, while this year Fatboy Slim surprised the crowd with an unexpected afternoon set on Sunday - complete with confetti and airhorns.
Earlier in the day, those looking to loosen up were treated to a session of power ballad yoga. And this wasn't the only event to help people keep up with their fitness...
Joe Wicks PE
Image: Pic: Maja Smiejkowska/Shutterstock
When you're living in a tent for the best part of a week, it's good to have a stretch, and early risers on the Friday were treated to some help in this department from none other than Joe Wicks.
The Body Coach took to the Gateway stage on Friday at midday to guide thousands in a warm-up and 25-minute workout, with eager exercisers sweating it out in everything from sequinned skirts to kilts and even Where's Wally costumes.
Runners were also invited to a 5km earlier in the festival to dust off the cobwebs.
The DJ giant spider and secret bars
If you like your DJs playing from inside a giant, fire-breathing spider, you've come to the right place - Glastonbury's Arcadia corner provides just this.
This is one of the many incredible spectacles you might come across during your travels around site, with the flames visible from afar.
Other venues are a little more hidden - the Rabbit Hole's secret bar, for example, which involves Alice In Wonderland riddles and some crawling to find your way in, and the underground piano bar, which is said to move around the site. As far as secret sets go, this would have been the perfect location for Elton to pop up should he have felt in the mood for surprising fans after his headline slot. We called it here first.
Lana Del Rey's hair causes problems
Image: Pic: BBC/Glastonbury
We've all been there. You're getting ready for a big night out but your hair just isn't playing ball, so you have to start all over again.
Unfortunately this is what happened to Lana Del Rey as she prepared for her night out on Saturday - a headline slot on Glastonbury's Other stage.
The star ended up being half an hour late. "I was so f****** late that I am about to rush this set," she told the crowd after making it to the stage. "If they cut power, they cut power. I'm super f****** sorry, my hair takes so long to do."
They did indeed cut the power - leading to an a capella performance of the star's final song Video Games, helped with a sing-along from the crowd.
The TURDIS and other escape rooms
Image: Pic: Bewilder Box/ Rebel Brain
Working your way around the Glastonbury site and its different nooks and crannies can be a puzzle in itself, but for those who don't find it challenging enough there are escape rooms to put those skills to the test.
One of these is a solar-powered escape tent, while another is the TURDIS (Toilet Utilities Requiring Dexterity, Intelligence & Skill) - a disco Portaloo escape room.
Not a working Glastonbury Portaloo, it should be noted.
Find out your future
Be the first to get Breaking News Install the Sky News app for free
Step off Glastonbury's old railway track, one of the main thoroughfares of the festival, and you might come across the Healing Fields and Stone Circle - an area of tranquility away from the madness.
Here, you can get a massage, try some meditation, or learn what the future holds from tarot readers and life readers such as Timaeon, pictured above.
Near the Stone Circle, you might also find the Lost Horizon Nomadic Spa, which provides a space to relax and unwind - and where clothing is optional.
Anything goes at Glastonbury.
Grohl-stonbury
Image: Pic: Anna Barclay
Okay, so this one made all the headlines, but we couldn't finish a Glastonbury moments piece without highlighting the work of Dave Grohl over the weekend.
First of all he played with the Foo Fighters - who turned out to be the "secret" Friday evening Pyramid stage act The ChurnUps - but hung around to join The Pretenders on The Park stage the following day, and then Guns'n'Roses for their headline set later that night.
Looks like Grohl could soon be taking Chris Martin's crown for impromptu Glastonbury pop-ups.

title: Lewis Capaldi fans hailed by Piers Morgan after singer's Glastonbury Tourette's battle
content:
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Invalid email Something went wrong, please try again later.
Get the latest festival news sent to your inbox with Worthy Welly
Piers Morgan shared his amazement as he posted a video of the Glastonbury crowd helping Lewis Capaldi sing his song Somebody You Love.
In a nutshell
Lewis was struggling to sing his song as he dealt with his Tourette's syndrome, and had to stop singing as he could be seen having issues on the stage,
He told the crowd: "Glastonbury, I'm really sorry. I'm a bit annoyed with myself."
READ MORE: Arctic Monkeys: Irish fans react as band play Glastonbury days after cancelling Dublin gig
Lewis then suggested he would need to continue his break to try and recuperate, as he said: "I feel like I'll be taking another wee break over the next couple of weeks. So you probably won't see much of me for the rest of the year, maybe even.
"But when I do come back and when I do see you, I hope you're still up for watching us."
What has been said
Piers shared the special moment on Twitter as he wrote: "Wow. This was amazing. Kudos to @LewisCapaldi for not quitting - and kudos to the #glastonbury2023 crowd for singing him through his obvious issues."
Fans rushed to social media to share their thoughts as one said: "This is so incredible. The energy of love is overwhelming in that space."
Another added: "Even thanking the crowd for putting him at ease too â€¦ heâ€™s an inspiration."
A third agreed: "A genuinely precious moment in time where the gift of music won."
Background
Lewis' performance comes after he posted a statement on social media saying he was scrapping all of his tour dates in the run-up to Glastonbury to recuperate.
He wrote: "The last few months have been full-on both mentally and physically," he wrote, "I haven't been home properly since Christmas and at the moment I am struggling to get to grips with it all."
"I need to take a moment to rest and recover, to be at my best and ready for Glastonbury, and all of the other incredible shows coming up so that I'm able to continue doing what I love for a long time to come."
Elsewhere at Glastonbury
Glastonbury 's The Other Stage Saturday night headliner Lana Del Rey was forced to apologise after she had her power cut off after starting late.
She arrived on the stage 30 minutes late to the sound of the crowd singing "we want Lana", and was quick to apologise for her late start.
Lana said: "I was so f****** late that I am about to rush this set,â€ she said.
(Image: WireImage)
"If they cut power, they cut power. Iâ€™m super f****** sorry, my hair takes so long to do."
American rock band Guns N' Roses performed their Pyramid Stage headline slot at Glastonbury on Saturday night to a massive crowd.
It was the band's first ever stint at the iconic festival, and they treated fans to a two-hour set full of all the hits such as Paradise City and Sweet Child O' Mine.
Original members Axl Rose, Slash and Duff McKagan all took to the stage for the performance, but many fans on social media complained that they couldn't hear frontman Axl's voice very clearly.

title: Glastonbury plunged into chaos as headline act arrives late and is then hit by power cut
content:
Love Glastonbury? From tickets to headliners, sign up here for the latest updates from Worthy Farm
Glastonbury 2023 was plunged into chaos as a headline act arrived on stage half an hour late - and was then hit by a power cut. Lana Del Rey was headlining The Other Stage and after being missing for the first 30 minutes of her slot, she finally appeared - but then lost the power to her microphone.
The US singer was forced to lead fans in an acappella performance of her final song Video Games after power to her microphone was cut. Del Rey apologised profusely to fans, urging them to help her sing the track and then going down to meet and greet them.
Her late arrival had left the Glastonbury crowds restless with chants of "we want Lana" ringing out across the field. The delay came after reports the Born To Die singer was not impressed she was not initially billed as the main act on the stage for Saturday on the first line-up poster.
READ MORE: Glastonbury fans poke fun at Phillip Schofield as Holly parties at festival in Â£1k jacket
The poster had been listed in alphabetical order, with Del Rey featuring further down, but not marking her out as the headline act for The Other Stage.
During her Saturday show she voiced concerns she might be forced to finish her set early because of the late start. "I was so f****** late that I am about to rush this set," she said. "If they cut power, they cut power. Iâ€™m super f****** sorry, my hair takes so long to do."
Del Rey was also beset with an apparent technical difficulty during her performance, which forced her to restart her song White Mustang and she later skipped performing Venice Bitch.

title: Guns Nâ€™ Roses triumph with Glastonbury debut as Lana Del Rey has power cut off
content:
G uns Nâ€™ Roses delivered a triumphant debut performance at Glastonbury on Saturday while The Other Stage headliner Lana Del Rey had her power cut off after starting late.
The US singer was forced to lead fans in an a capella performance of her final song Video Games after power to her microphone was cut.
Del Rey apologised profusely to fans, urging them to help her sing the track and then going down to meet and greet them.
She had taken to the stage 30 minutes late, leaving fans restless with chants of â€œwe want Lanaâ€ ringing out across the field.
The delay came after reports the Born To Die singer was not impressed she was not initially billed as the main act on the stage for Saturday on the first line-up poster.
The poster had been listed in alphabetical order, with Del Rey featuring further down, but not marking her out as the headline act for The Other Stage.
During her Saturday show she voiced concerns she might be forced to finish her set early because of the late start.
â€œI was so f****** late that I am about to rush this set,â€ she said.
â€œIf they cut power, they cut power. Iâ€™m super f****** sorry, my hair takes so long to do.â€
Del Rey was beset with an apparent technical difficulty during her performance, which forced her to restart her song White Mustang and she later skipped performing Venice Bitch.
On the Pyramid Stage, Guns Nâ€™ Roses rocked through their extensive catalogue during a two-hour-plus set playing tracks including Live And Let Die, Knocking On Heavenâ€™s Door, Sweet Child Oâ€™ Mine and November Rain.
Crowds exploded as guitarist Slash struck up the famous opening riff to their 1987 hit song Welcome To The Jungle, the 57-year-old later jumping off a stage block and shredding his strings furiously.
Switching up the lyrics, Axl Rose sang: â€œDo you know where you are? Youâ€™re in the jungle, Glastonbury!â€
The lead singer later invited Foo Fighters frontman Dave Grohl onstage to help them close out the show with an explosive performance of Paradise City.
Grohl had appeared earlier on Saturday as a guest for The Pretenders, having previously performed a secret slot with Foo Fighters on Friday.
Lizzo, who performed immediately before Guns Nâ€™ Roses, delivered a high energy set packed with her usual messages of diversity, inclusion and body positivity.
The US pop star said she was â€œso movedâ€ as she expressed gratitude to fans for helping her to reach the heights of the Glastonbury mainstage.
Finishing a rendition of her hit song Truth Hurts, she told crowds: â€œIâ€™m just so overwhelmed.
â€œLast time I played this festival was 2019, and I was like â€˜man, Iâ€™m doing big shit, because the first time I played this festival was 2018 â€“ in one of those big tents. Nobody was in there.
â€œBut me and my DJâ€¦ we kept playing, and we played our hearts out, and now I stand before you and Iâ€™m so moved.â€
Expressing further gratitude to her fans, Lizzo said: â€œI want to say thank you Glastonbury for having me and putting me on this stage.
â€œI want to say thank you all for being here â€“ your time means the world to me. Itâ€™s very important that I let you know that.â€
Scottish superstar Lewis Capaldi earlier powered through an emotional set on the mainstage as he steadily lost his voice.
At the end of the show the 26-year-old revealed he plans to take some more time off, after previously cancelling all his other commitments in June ahead of the festival at Worthy Farm to allow himself time to â€œrest and recoverâ€.
After performing Bruises, he admitted he was having voice issues, telling the crowd: â€œIâ€™m going to be honest everybody but Iâ€™m starting to lose my voice up here, but weâ€™re going to keep going and weâ€™re going to go until the end.
â€œI just need you all to sing with me as loud as you can if thatâ€™s OK?â€
He continued to apologise to the crowd, and the Eavis family who organise Glastonbury, for his voice starting to go â€“ but the ocean of fans replied by cheering him on and chanting â€œOh Lewis Capaldiâ€.
Rick Astley opened the Pyramid Stage on Saturday, performing a Harry Styles cover and also showing off his drumming skills as he made his debut at the music festival.
Dressed in a dusky rose coloured suit, the 57-year-old singer opened the set with his hit song from the 1980s Together Forever, and later launched into a cover of Stylesâ€™ As It Was.
Other songs featured included his song Whenever You Need Somebody from 1987 as well as new song Dippin My Feet, from his upcoming ninth studio album titled Are We There Yet?, due for release in October.
Following his performance, which he ended with his 1987 hit Never Gonna Give You Up, Astley joined indie band Blossoms on the newly-named Woodsies stage.
Elsewhere on Saturday, actress Tilda Swinton joined composer and pianist Max Richter on the Park stage to provide spoken word alongside his classical set, with Richter telling the crowd: â€œItâ€™s great to be here, really great to be here. Itâ€™s my first time playing here and itâ€™s just an honour to be opening up this stage today.â€
Labourâ€™s shadow climate secretary Ed Miliband joined a panel in a talk called One Minute To Midnight: Can Politics Deliver On Climate Action?

title: Saturday at Glastonbury 2023: Rick Astley, Raye and Richard Thompson
content:
Benâ€™s out scouting Glastoâ€™s stylish people: â€œI asked these people why they were all in blue and they looked at me like I was an idiot. â€˜Just because!â€™â€
18m ago 07.42 EDT The Last Dinner Party â€“ reviewed! Ben Beaumont-Thomas
Woodsies, 11.30am
Since time immemorial, music journos have massively overhyped bands to a degree that isnâ€™t actually fair on them, leaving an inevitable gulf between the hype and reality, disappointing audiences and creating a backlash, which we journos can then write about. Itâ€™s the circle of life! Couple this with audience suspicion of anyone who seems to have been anointed by the industry in this way and there have been quite a few dark mutters about â€œindustry plantsâ€ of late â€“ none louder than those about the Last Dinner Party, a quintet signed to major label Island Records before releasing any music. Sexism surely amplified the grouching, from men suspicious that a group of young women with a cohesive image could actually have formed themselves.
On the bad-faith internet, the music can feel immaterial â€“ and the stage banter here suggests the band wonâ€™t beat the posho allegations. But what are they actually like? They fit into a lineage of proudly theatrical alt-pop alongside Patrick Wolf, HMLTD or Anna Calvi (and while musically theyâ€™re nothing like Porridge Radio, they share that bandâ€™s massed declamatory vocals). Some of these songs are a bit episodic, shunting from one middling section to another with a bold flourish to paper over the lack of finesse or arc. But the crowd are punching the air to Sinner despite having never heard it before, and while Godzilla isnâ€™t to my personal taste â€“ a sort of big-production blues rock that recalls the most money-soaked end of Britpop â€“ the band really sell it.
Neo-Victoriana aesthetic â€¦ the Last Dinner Party on the Woodsies stage. Photograph: Ben Beaumont-Thomas/The Guardian
Their neo-Victoriana aesthetic stands out, and while some may find lead singer Abigail Morrisâ€™s repertoire of Kate Bush-ish twirls and self-conscious prowling a bit irritating, there are plenty more who will find it the very essence of pop panache. She can really sing, too, beautifully topping off Mirror with a pristine chirrup around her high notes. The tent is pretty much full and everyone seems to know insistent debut single Nothing Matters â€“ thereâ€™s clearly enough here, in songcraft and rapport, to drown out the keyboard warriors.

title: Glastonbury Festival 2023: full line up and set times for Friday, Saturday and Sunday
content:
We have more newsletters
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Invalid email Something went wrong, please try again later.
Love Glastonbury? From tickets to headliners, sign up here for the latest updates from Worthy Farm
Arctic Monkeys and Guns N' Roses will headline the Pyramid Stage at Glastonbury this week.
Arctic Monkeys will headline the Pyramid Stage on Friday, June 23 and Guns N' Roses on Saturday, June 24. Other huge names on the line up include the likes of Elton John and Lizzo.
The festival will run from June 21 - 25 at the iconic Worthy Farm location, where huge names like Diana Ross performed last year. Singer-songwriter Cat Stevens will play the coveted "legend slot", which has previously seen the likes Kylie and Dolly Parton perform.
READ MORE:Glastonbury Festival warning as motorists told to prepare for 'very busy' week
Sir Elton John is likely to be the biggest attraction this year, as the star will play the last UK show of his farewell tour, Farewell Yellow Brick Road, at Glastonbury. The line-up also includes Christine And The Queens, Fatboy Slim, Lana Del Rey, Lewis Capaldi, Lil Nas X, Maneskin, Central Cee, Manic Street Preachers, The War On Drugs and Royal Blood.
Hereâ€™s the full line up for everyday at Glastonbury 2023:

title: 32 Toys To Keep Your Child Entertained This Summer
content:
This bubble maker includes: bubble gun, two bottles of bubble solution, a rechargeable battery, a charger, and a plate to place the bubble solution.
Promising review: "I ordered this for my daughter's birthday and she has always loved bubbles!. So when I found this bubble gun on TikTok, it was a no-brainer. The amount of bubbles that you get out of that is so fun and it lights up. It's easy to use and pretty inexpensive for what we wanted. Even the adults enjoyed it." â€”Tina
Get it from Amazon for $35.99+ (available in two versions and three colors).

title: Glastonbury Festival headliners reimagined doing 'normal' jobs in new AI pictures
content:
Fans can see what Elton John would look like working at a supermarket checkout and if Lana Del Rey was a police officer
A Glastonbury Festival fan has used AI to imagine what some of the top acts from the UK's biggest music event would look like doing 'normal' jobs. Images show Elton John on a supermarket checkout, The Arctic Monkey's Alex Turner as a milkman and Guns N' Roses vocalist Axl Rose as a mechanic.
Lana Del Rey is also featured as police officer, rock guitarist Slash can be seen working as a fast food chef and Milkshake singer Kelis in a McDonald's drive-thru. Creator Duncan Thomsen, 53, says he wasn't aiming for a retro look for the images, but says he is happy with the results.
The freelance film editor, from Brighton, said: "They actually look really real; they look just like them. I did them all in about a day, but you can work on one of these for up to a few days. They look quite retro which wasn't intentional but they look very cool.
"I particularly like the second one of Elton when he's looking over his shoulder - it looks just like him. I also thing the one of Alex Turner as a 1960's milkman looks really cool. It really fits his vibe - if he was around in the 60s I think he would be a milkman.
"Lana Del Rey also quite simply looks so cool as a policewoman. That one turned out very well."
General Widget
AI responds to prompts and commands set by the user and creates pictures by referencing billions of images online. Duncan uses the software Midjourney to make his own hyper-realistic photos.
He added: "It can be quite a lengthy process but the results are fantastic. I've been to Glastonbury myself 13 times but didn't manage to get a ticket this year.
"Which is a shame as the line-up is clearly fantastic. These pictures are just a way to join the fun and I'm very happy with how realistic and fun they are."
Glastonbury Festival will be running from from June 21 to June 26 this year. It will be held at its usual location of Worthy Farm in Somerset.

title: 16 summer festivals to warm any music fan
content:
The smoke has cleared, the rain is, well, intermittent, and festival season is underway. As usual, thereâ€™s a wealth of live music happening around Massachusetts and Rhode Island, starting this weekend when boygenius, LCD Soundsystem, and Steve Lacy headline the touring festival Re:SET at the Stage at Suffolk Downs. If thatâ€™s not your thing, something will be: Thereâ€™s folk, hip-hop, soul music, jam bands, indie-rock, electronic music, jazz, experimental music, and contemporary classical happening in a variety of settings, from state parks to a contemporary art museum. Here are 16 options:
Where: Franklin Park Playstead Field, Boston
When: June 23-25
Advertisement
Vibe: A celebration of Black artists and Afro-centric identity tied this year to the 50th anniversary of hip-hop. The festival includes a vendorsâ€™ market, food from Boston-area Black and brown chefs, a dance zone, activities for kids, and a beer and wine garden.
Whoâ€™s playing: Grandmaster Flash, Maimouna Youssef, Zyah Belle, Terri Lyne Carrington, Kevin Ross, Cake$wagg, Dreion, Tim Hall, Kei, Nate Nics, Notebook P, Clinton Tesla, Tori Tori, International Show, Alexus Lee, Kei, Mary Orji, HG Drumline and HG Youth Choir.
Get The Big To-Do Your guide to staying entertained, from live shows and outdoor fun to the newest in museums, movies, TV, books, dining, and more. Enter Email Sign Up
Ticket info: Register for free tickets at bamsfest.org. (VIP tickets are $175.)
GREEN RIVER FESTIVAL
Where: Franklin County Fairgrounds, Greenfield
When: June 23-25
Vibe: Rootsy indie music presented in a relaxed, family-friendly setting, with activities for kids and an array of food and crafts from around Western Massachusetts.
Whoâ€™s playing: Little Feat, the Wood Brothers, St. Paul & The Broken Bones, Sierra Ferrell, Sammy Rae & the Friends, Rubblebucket, the Felice Brothers, Thee Sacred Souls, Jon Cleary & the Absolute Monster Gentlemen, Eilen Jewell, Mark Erelli, Sarah Shook & the Disarmers.
Ticket info: Weekend pass: $169, $110 for students, children under 10 are free. Single-day tickets: $59.99 for Friday, $74.99 for Saturday, $74.99 for Sunday. greenriverfestival.com
Advertisement
Levitate Music and Arts Festival in Marshfield returns July 7-9 for its 10th annual event. Levitate Music and Arts Festival
LEVITATE MUSIC AND ARTS FESTIVAL
Where: Marshfield Fairgrounds, Marshfield
When: July 7-9
Vibe: Trends jammy, but with plenty for fans of indie-rock and roots music, too. This year marks the 10th anniversary of Levitate, and will include art installations and skate exhibitions curated by pro skater Nora Vasconcellos, a Pembroke native.
Whoâ€™s playing: Brandi Carlile, Trey Anastasio Band, Stick Figure, Goose, Rebelution, Ziggy Marley, Ripe, Shakey Graves, Lucius, Peach Pit, Larkin Poe, Celisse.
Ticket info: General admission three-day pass: $249. Single-day tickets: $99 for Friday, $129 each for Saturday and Sunday. levitatemusicfestival.com
CHARLES RIVER JAZZ FESTIVAL
Where: Herter Park Amphitheater, Boston
When: July 16
Vibe: Founded in 2021, this successor to the BeanTown Jazz Festival emphasizes musical and cultural diversity with performers from Boston and beyond, along with local art and food vendors and family-friendly activities.
Whoâ€™s playing: Braxton Cook, Michael Mayo, Anastassiya Petrova, Farayi Malek, Seba Molnar.
Ticket info: Free admission. charlesriverjazzfest.org
NICE, A FEST
Where: Crystal Ballroom and the Rockwell, Somerville
When: July 20-23
Vibe: A four-day showcase for local musicians, most of whom have Massachusetts connections, split between two venues in Davis Square.
Whoâ€™s playing: Karate, Guerilla Toss, Swirlies, Frances Forever, Ovlov, Valleyheart, Bent Knee, Beeef, Dino Gala, Izzy Heltai, Will Dailey, and many, many more.
Ticket info: Four-day pass: $90. Three-day pass: $65. Thursday only: $25. Friday, Saturday, or Sunday only: $27. musicspace.xyz/nice
BANG ON A CAN: LOUD WEEKEND
Where: Mass MoCA, North Adams
When: July 27-29
Advertisement
Vibe: An eclectic mix of contemporary music with an experimental vibe, in a former factory complex converted into a first-rate contemporary art museum.
Whoâ€™s playing: Kronos Quartet, Bang on a Can All-Stars, Love in Exile (Arooj Aftab, Vijay Iyer, and Shahzad Ismaily), Tarta Relena, Paola Prestini and Jeffrey Zeigler, Joan Tower, Jeffrey Brooks, Ensemble Klang, Jeffrey Tower, and David Lang featuring Theo Bleckmann.
Ticket info: Three-day pass: $129 general admission, $225 reserved tickets (includes a T-shirt and signed poster). massmoca.org/event/bang-on-a-can-loud-weekend-2023
Fans fill Fort Adams State Park for last summer's Newport Folk Festival. Ben Stas for The Boston Globe/file
NEWPORT FOLK FESTIVAL
Where: Fort Adams State Park, Newport, R.I.
When: July 28-30
Vibe: Not so folky this year, but the broader horizons mean something for just about everyone in a famously laid-back setting by Narragansett Bay.
Whoâ€™s playing: Lana Del Rey, Los Lobos & Friends, Jason Isbell & the 400 Unit, the Hold Steady, Billy Strings, Nickel Creek, John Oates, Jon Batiste & Friends, Angel Olsen, Bartees Strange, Goose, Maggie Rogers, the Beths, Turnpike Troubadours, Willi Carlisle.
Ticket info: Sold out, but tickets available on the secondary market. Thereâ€™s also a waitlist at newportfolk.org/tickets.
The free Lowell Folk Festival features performers from around the world. Handout
LOWELL FOLK FESTIVAL
Where: Downtown Lowell
When: July 28-30
Vibe: A wide range of music from around the world on four stages scattered around downtown Lowell, with family activities, crafts demonstrations, and mostly local food vendors representing Portuguese, Brazilian, Greek, Polish, Asian, Latin, and Burmese cuisines.
Whoâ€™s playing: Hot Club of Cowtown, Chuck Mead, Fran Grace, Cheres, Fred Thomas, Heart of Afghanistan featuring Ahmad Fanoos and Sohail Karimi, Jason Samuels Smith, Melody Angel, Lakou Mizik, Revma, Sara Correia, Sona Jobarteh, Springfield Exit, Trian, Tâ€™Monde, Zuni Olla Maidens.
Advertisement
Ticket info: Free. lowellfolkfestival.org
NEWPORT JAZZ FESTIVAL
Where: Fort Adams State Park, Newport, R.I.
When: Aug. 4-6
Vibe: Thereâ€™s more than jazz happening at the OG of American music festivals, which has an enviably picturesque location alongside Narragansett Bay.
Whoâ€™s playing: Herbie Hancock, Diana Krall, Jon Batiste, Kamasi Washington, Thundercat, the Soul Rebels (featuring Rakim & Talib Kweli), Big Freedia, Charles Lloyd New Quartet, Samara Joy, Cimafunk, Julian Lage, Marcus Miller, Durand Jones, Bill Charlap Trio, Christian McBrideâ€™s Jam Jawn, Soulive, Big Gigantic.
Ticket info: Three-day general admission: $281.19. Two-day general admission: sold out. Single-day general admission: $100.94. newportjazz.org
IN BETWEEN DAYS FESTIVAL
Where: Veterans Memorial Stadium, Quincy
When: Aug. 19-20
Vibe: An eclectic mix of indie-rock acts playing two stages, along with shopping opportunities that include vintage fashion, home dÃ©cor, and vinyl records, plus a retro arcade and local food and drink.
Whoâ€™s playing: Modest Mouse, Sunny Day Real Estate, the Beths, Blitzen Trapper, Lord Huron, Phantogram, Trampled by Turtles, Cautious Clay.
Ticket info: Two-day general admission tickets: $175.50 (with no fees). One-day general admission: $105 (with no fees). inbetweendaysfestival.com
Leon Bridges is part of a stacked lineup at Beach Road Weekend Aug. 25-27 on Martha's Vineyard. Amy Harris/Invision/AP/file
BEACH ROAD WEEKEND
Where: Vineyard Haven, Marthaâ€™s Vineyard,
When: Aug. 25-27
Vibe: Beachy and relaxed, with big-name acts in a comparatively intimate outdoor setting.
Whoâ€™s playing: Bon Iver, Patti Smith, Leon Bridges, Mumford & Sons, Dispatch, Japanese Breakfast, the Head and the Heart, Gary Clark Jr., Regina Spektor, Dinosaur Jr., Sammy Rae & the Friends, John Hiatt, Mary Chapin Carpenter, Alvvays.
Advertisement
Ticket info: Three-day general admission: $400. One-day general admission: $150. beachroadweekend.com
RHYTHM & ROOTS FESTIVAL
Where: Ninigret Park, Charlestown, R.I.
When: Sept. 1-3
Vibe: This long-running roots-music showcase changed hands in 2022 but retains the essence of what has made Rhythm & Roots a draw for nearly 25 years: a no-frills, camping-friendly experience that puts the emphasis on the music.
Whoâ€™s playing: Greensky Bluegrass, Trombone Shorty, JJ Grey & Mofro, the Robert Cray Band, Dumpstaphunk, the Infamous Stringdusters, Shinyribs, Dustbowl Revival, Tuba Skinny, Donna the Buffalo, Son Little.
Ticket info: Three-day pass with camping: $269. Three-day pass without camping: $219. Two-day passes: $134 (Friday and Saturday) and $164 (Saturday and Sunday). Single-day tickets: $59 (Friday) and $89 (Saturday and Sunday). rhythmandroots.com
Dar Williams is curating the inaugural River Roads Festival in Easthampton, where she'll also perform. Ben Stas for The Boston Globe/file
RIVER ROADS FESTIVAL
Where: Millside Park, Easthampton
When: Sept. 9
Vibe: A bit like Lilith Fair, organizers say, referring to the â€˜90s traveling festival focused on women performers. Curated by headliner Dar Williams, the inaugural version of River Roads will feature a â€œwater justiceâ€ theme that includes waterway cleanup efforts around the Pioneer Valley the day after the show.
Whoâ€™s playing: Williams, Shawn Colvin, Lisa Loeb, Amy Ray, Sweet Honey in the Rock, Heather Maloney, Aisha Burns.
Ticket info: $65 for adults 18 and older, $20 for children 13-17, free for children 12 and younger. laudable.productions/events/river-roads-festival-2023
ARCADIA FOLK FESTIVAL
Where: Mass Audubon Arcadia Wildlife Sanctuary, Easthampton
When: Sept. 17
Vibe: A little crunchy; the festival is solar-powered and carbon neutral, with valet bicycle parking at the entrance and solely plant-based food and drink for sale.
Whoâ€™s playing: Valerie June, James McMurtry & Band, the Suitcase Junket, Chatham Rabbits, Taylor Ashton, Al Olender, Wallace Field.
Ticket info: $54.99 for early general admission. arcadiafolkfest.com
BREAKAWAY
Where: The Stage at Suffolk Downs, Boston
When: Sept. 15-16
Vibe: A touring festival focused on electronic music with local food trucks and vendors, this weekend marks Breakawayâ€™s only stop in the Northeast.
Whoâ€™s playing: Griz, Lane 8, Porter Robinson DJ set, Madeon DJ set, Tchami, Elderbrook, Knock2, Evan Giia, Forester, Gashi, Night Tales, Surf Mesa.
Ticket info: Two-day general admission tickets: $153, with single-day tickets to come. breakawayfestival.com
FRESHGRASS
Where: Mass MoCA, North Adams
When: Sept. 22-24
Vibe: Mostly roots music, sometimes with a twist, held in and around a world-class contemporary art museum.
Whoâ€™s playing: Dropkick Murphys (acoustic), Lukas Nelson & Promise of the Real, Sierra Ferrell, Rhiannon Giddens, the Devil Makes Three, Aoife Oâ€™Donovan, Allison Russell, Mighty Poplar.
Ticket info: Three-day pass: $184 for general admission, $129 for students, $64 for children between 6-16. massmoca.org/event/freshgrass-2023
Follow Eric R. Danton on Twitter @erdanton.

title: Lana Del Rey a quittÃ© Instagram
content:
La chanteuse de "Summertime Sadness" a affirmÃ© qu'elle n'avait plus besoin d'utiliser cette plateforme de mÃ©dias sociaux maintenant que ses dates de tournÃ©e ont Ã©tÃ© publiÃ©es et que l'album de son pÃ¨re Rob Grant, intitulÃ© "Lost at Sea", sur lequel elle apparaÃ®t sur deux chansons, "Hollywood Bowl" et la chanson titre, a Ã©tÃ© publiÃ©.
Elle a annoncÃ© sur sa Story Instagram : "Merci beaucoup pour tout. Maintenant que l'album de Rob est sorti et que vous savez oÃ¹ je vais en tournÃ©e, ce compte va fermer. Bonne chance et je vous aime."
Lana avait dÃ©jÃ  quittÃ© la plateforme en 2021 afin de se concentrer sur "d'autres emplois" qui nÃ©cessitaient "intimitÃ© et transparence". Ã€ l'Ã©poque, elle avait expliquÃ© dans une vidÃ©o : "Salut les gars, je voulais juste vous faire savoir qu'Ã  partir de demain, nous allons dÃ©sactiver nos comptes de mÃ©dias sociaux, mes comptes de mÃ©dias sociaux. C'est simplement parce que j'ai tellement d'intÃ©rÃªts et d'autres emplois que je fais qui nÃ©cessitent de l'intimitÃ© et de la transparence."
La chanteuse de "Blue Jeans" a assurÃ© Ã  ses fans qu'elle continuerait Ã  travailler sur sa musique, ses albums de poÃ©sie et ses albums de spoken word, mais qu'elle se lanÃ§ait Ã©galement dans "de nouvelles entreprises". Elle a ajoutÃ© : "Je suis toujours trÃ¨s prÃ©sente et j'adore ce que je fais. Je suis absolument lÃ  pour la musique."
Lana a offert Ã  ses fans un "sincÃ¨re merci" pour tout leur soutien au fil des annÃ©es, mais elle a admis qu'elle avait hÃ¢te de travailler sur d'autres choses en dehors des projecteurs. Elle a dÃ©clarÃ© : "Je veux dire un sincÃ¨re merci pour, vous savez, continuer Ã  me suivre Ã  travers la musique. Il est toujours important d'Ãªtre tÃ©moin, et il est Ã©galement trÃ¨s important d'Ãªtre tÃ©moin par les personnes proches de vous que vous connaissez et en qui vous avez confiance. Pour l'instant, je pense que je vais juste garder mon cercle un peu plus restreint et continuer Ã  dÃ©velopper d'autres compÃ©tences et intÃ©rÃªts."
Elle est ensuite revenue sur Instagram, il n'est donc pas clair si elle fait juste une autre pause temporaire cette fois-ci.

title: The 100 Best Album Covers of All Time
content:
Music isnâ€™t just about the music. Yes, the sounds are certainly the most essential element, but a lot of other things go into making an album a classic. Almost since the full-length album format began, cover art has been a key piece of the puzzle, adding visual interest (and occasionally a physically interactive component) to a work of art.
From the fold-out gatefolds of the vinyl era to pull-out liner notes in CD jewel cases to the small icon on a digital player, cover art has changed over the years, but it still helps define how we look at a particular album. Some go for the less-is-more approach, while others are stuffed with a kaleidoscope of imagery for fans to pore over and decipher. You might see photographic portraits, paintings, sketches, collages or nearly nothing at all. The artist might appear front and center, or perhaps they take a backseat entirely, letting evocative imagery pull the listener into their world. Some album covers are arguably better known than the music inside, having been parodied in pop culture, lauded with awards, used in advertisements or hung up in art museums. It all began in 1939 when Alex Steinweiss, a graphic designer who worked at Columbia Records, realized that the label could sell more copies of an album if the cover caught the consumerâ€™s attention. It worked, and soon became an indispensable part of the creative process when crafting (and marketing) an album.
Weâ€™ve rounded up a list of the 100 greatest album covers of all time, reaching as far back as the 1930s and running through the birth of rock nâ€™ roll, the start of hip-hop and beyond, right up to present day.

title: 2023 Lollapalooza Hulu Streaming Schedule
content:
Photo: Axelle/Bauer-Griffin/FilmMagic
There was a time when you had to brave crowds, porta-potties, and Wrigleyville bros to enjoy sets at Lollapalooza. But itâ€™s the 21st century, and now you can enjoy Sudan Archives from the comfort of your own home. Hulu is streaming Lollapalooza 2023 live starting at 2:05 p.m. on Thursday, August 3. The festival will take two channels on the streaming site with broadcasts going through Sunday night. Chicagoâ€™s Grant Park will host headlining sets by Billie Eilish, Kendrick Lamar, Lana Del Rey, Lana Del Rayâ€™s vape, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Odesza, Karol G, the 1975, and Tomorrow X Together. Featured acts include Rina Sawayama, Sudan Archives, Lil Yachty, Maggie Rogers, Carly Rae Jepsen, Pusha T, Beabadoobee, and Magdalena Bay.
Itâ€™s an exciting time for these artists to be performing. Eilish is hot off depressing the fuck out of TikTok with her song from the Barbie soundtrack. Lamar has been cheering TikTok back up with the â€œgo stinkâ€ part of â€œAmerica Has a Problem.â€ The 1975 and Sawayama will be on the same festival ticket (though on different days) after Sawayama appeared to call out Matty Healy in multiple intros to her song â€œSTFU.â€ And Jepsen just released The Loveliest Time with dark-horse song of the summer entrant â€œPsychedelic Switch.â€ Below is a full schedule of Huluâ€™s Lollapalooza 2023 livestream. title: Find out when Shaq, Lana Del Rey take stage
content:
Organizers have announced the set times for the 2023 Outside Lands festival.
That means that fans can find out when Kendrick Lamar, Foo Fighters, Lana Del Rey, Maggie Rogers, Odesza, Megan Thee Stallion, Lil Yachty, the 1975, Diesel (aka NBA legend Shaquille Oâ€™Neal), Zedd and the dozens of the festivalâ€™s other acts will perform Aug. 11-13.
The set times are available at the festivalâ€™s website, sfoutsidelands.com.
Music fans can also find them by downloading the festival app.
In other Outside Lands news, organizers have announced that Amazon Music will exclusively livestream performances throughout the three-day festival.
The stream will be available via Prime Video and the Amazon Music channel on Twitch beginning at 1 p.m. each day.
The full stream lineup will be announced soon.

title: Lana Del Rey: a great American poet
content:
The corner lot of 100 E Ocean Boulevard is not mythic. Itâ€™s a small patch of scrubland, rubble and grass, graffitied wall panels, a couple of vertebral palms. Round the back, a parking lot, asphalt bleached and sickly under the Los Angeles sun, and a chain-link fence, easily scalable. It wasnâ€™t always like this. Built in 1919, the Jergins Trust Building used to stand on the site, its square-jawed conformity tempered by the carved pillars that used to adorn the top of its ten storeys, straight-backed against the blue sky. The office block was demolished in 1988, despite the modest efforts of government officials to save it â€“ the owners claimed a hotel would be built on the grounds and blocked all attempts to add it to the heritage register. The Jergins Trust Building exists now only in a couple of archived newspaper reports, a local history blog and the memories of some older LA residents. And that is it: a blip, an interesting anecdote, a piece of little-known local history.
But there is one remnant of its existence. Behind that nondescript fence in the parking lot is the south entrance to the Jergins Pedestrian Subway. The 181-foot-long tunnel was built in 1927 and ran the width of Ocean Boulevard, enabling pedestrians to walk safely from the arcade beneath the Jergins Trust Building to the Pike, a now-demolished theme park that clung, bubblegum-on-sole, to the Long Beach shoreline. During its prime, a lit-up sign that read â€œENTRANCE TO THE BEACHâ€, parasol jauntily extending from the â€œAâ€ in â€œbeachâ€, beckoned pedestrians down below street level, where booths selling candy and 50-cent bottles of orange-blossom perfume lined the walls. The vendors left, slowly, until there were none left at all, and in 1967 the subway was closed: entrances bricked up, skylight entombed.
In â€œDid You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€, Lana Del Rey makes the tunnel an American legend. The song starts with an exhale, the kind of breath taken to subdue a panic attack, or avert the onset of tears. Itâ€™s why her voice, when it arrives, is steady. â€œDid you know that thereâ€™s a tunnel under Ocean Boulevard?â€ she asks. â€œMosaic ceilings, painted tiles on the wallsâ€. A drum beats, bearing us ceaselessly back into the past, ceaselessly forward into the present. Violins call to something lost, irretrievable, something that never existed. â€œI canâ€™t help but feel somewhat like my body marred my soul,â€ she sings. â€œHandmade beauty sealed up by two man-made walls/Whenâ€™s it gonna be my turn?â€¦ Donâ€™t forget me!â€
It builds and builds, then there is the supernova. If, as Del Rey sings, Harry Nilssonâ€™s voice breaks at precisely 2.05 in â€œDonâ€™t Forget Meâ€, then hers breaks at the four-minute mark. Her voice ascends as she pleads her final â€œDonâ€™t forget me!/Like the tunnel under Ocean Boulevardâ€, a vision of pain that sounds like ecstasy. The song circles a central enquiry: the question â€œdid you know?â€ is seemingly the star that it orbits. But only at the end do we understand that itâ€™s really a black hole â€“ swallowing all questions, all answers, until all that remains is the inescapable gravitational pull of that desperate â€œDonâ€™t forget me!â€. Itâ€™s telling that the title contains no question mark. Del Rey always knew that the tunnel â€“ and all of LA, all of America, including herself â€“ was doomed to be forgotten. If, for Jean Baudrillard, LA was the apotheosis of â€œAmerican realityâ€, then Del Rey is the cityâ€™s greatest poet. She understands that the story of the Jergins Trust Tunnel is part of some greater American story, one of boom and bust, of oil money and land banking and short-sighted capitalism, of pioneer spirit and metropolitan decay. And so she immortalises it, gilds it: spins it into the myth of the United States.
Related
Itâ€™s no coincidence that, while her account was still active, Del Reyâ€™s Twitter bio quoted Walt Whitman: â€œDo I contradict myself?/Very well then I contradict myself,/I am large, I contain multitudes.â€
