THANK YOU Close
In Leaves of Grass, Walt Whitman both eulogises and prophesies America, remaking it in the image of its people, in the image of himself. As he writes in the poetry collectionâ€™s preface, â€œThe power to destroy and remould is freely used by him (the greatest poet).â€ In her music, Del Rey does the same. This ability to make myth elevates Del Rey to American singer-songwriter laureate, the progeny of Bob Dylan and Joni Mitchell and Joan Baez and Brian Wilson. The arrival of this Whitman-esque Lana can be located in 2019, when her album Norman Fucking Rockwell! was released, announcing her emergence as the great American poet of the 21st century.
[See also: The cultural divide no one wants to talk about]
The transformation was monumental, as swift and all-encompassing as heat lightning. Prior to this, Del Rey was a much more conventional pop star, breathy voice, orchestral trap-pop beats, whose lyrics traded in self-aware stereotypes â€“ fuck-me-daddy, glacÃ©-cherry, Lolita-cum-Nancy-Sinatra pastiches. The singular genius of NFR! and each album released since is the mark of an artist who, after spending the early part of her career shaped by narratives of America, has decided to shape those narratives herself.
In other words, NFR! heralded the arrival of a poet: liquescent, precise, strange, making the mundane transcendent and the transcendent mundane, eternally constructing and destroying the â€œIâ€. Her influences draw from American culture across the last 150 years â€“ Ernest Hemingway, the White Stripes, Robert Frost, rose-gold iPhones, JD Rockefeller, Slim Aarons, crypto-bros, John Denver, Kanye West, Sylvia Plath, ranches and pools and the Topanga canyon at night, ice cubes rattling in their glasses â€“ broken down and reconstituted through the careful, confessional depiction of her relationships, her memories, her â€œinsaneâ€ brain. It feels vast, generational, emblematic of 21st-century America.
In â€œThe Song of Myselfâ€, Whitman tells us â€œI am the man, I suffered, I was thereâ€. The poetic force of his work, which the American poet James Wright terms his â€œdelicacyâ€, arises from the exactness of his observations; Whitmanâ€™s dedication to what he called â€œevery organ and attributeâ€. This commitment to specificity is vital in understanding Del Reyâ€™s artistic evolution; in her work on NFR! and beyond, she exhibits an oblique approach to individual experience, one that places a similar emphasis on precision. An instinct for poetic specificity is most apparent on â€œBlue Bannistersâ€, â€œKintsugiâ€ and â€œFingertipsâ€, sprawling, stream-of-consciousness confessionals that speak to Jesus, her family, lovers past and present, the dead and the living and the unborn, America, the Earth and the heavens, herself. Thereâ€™s a Whitman-esque delicacy to her lyrics, whether theyâ€™re about the way John Denver holds the note on â€œRocky Mountain Highâ€, her sister making birthday cake while chickens run around the yard, or dropping a location pin to her lover on a hot night in the canyon.
Her vocals, too, heighten this prosody â€“ lines slide into each other; words elongate and shrink; syllables catch in the throat â€“ as do her melodies. These are songs that change and flow, crest and break. They transform as we listen. The best example of this might be â€œVenice Bitchâ€, which mutates repeatedly over the course of its 9-minute, 37-second run-time. Its acoustic guitar gives way to electric psych-folk as Del Rey sings to her lover that theyâ€™re â€œAmerican-madeâ€. Itâ€™s acid-trip Americana, Pet Sounds for a world engulfed in flame.
On 21 July 2023, Del Rey visited a Waffle House in Florence, Alabama. In the photos, mostly selfies posted to social media, she is wearing a name tag and a Waffle House uniform, gifted to her by employees. The outfit is the blue of many things: as blue as the Tennessee River as it eddies across the map; as blue as old glory blue; as blue as Leviâ€™s 501s; as blue as Joni, 1971; as blue as a Blue Razz Lemonade vape. Oklahoma, Arkansas, Nebraska: as much as sheâ€™s queen of California, Del Rey is also the poet of the flyover state, captivated by the regulars at the diner, elbows on the counter. â€œThe United States themselves are essentially the greatest poem,â€ wrote Whitman in his preface to Leaves of Grass. Itâ€™s something Del Rey intuitively understands. With her personal mythology of waitresses and bartenders, Bowery bums and bikers and businessmen, poets and protesters, she has a fascination with American lives, an ability to be, as Whitman put it, â€œcommensurate with a peopleâ€. Her empathy with them and the places in which they live is part of the reason, I think, why sheâ€™s so often stereotyped as a Republican.
To paint Del Rey as conservative is to fundamentally misunderstand her work. Her interest in how seemingly small stories inform larger narratives allows her to compellingly communicate the climate crisis in a way no other artist does. Take, for instance, the ending of â€œThe Greatestâ€, â€œHawaii just missed a fireball/LAâ€™s in flames, itâ€™s getting hot/Kanye West is blonde and goneâ€. Here, celebrity culture exists not to distract or undermine the climate crisis, but to strengthen it: the dream of America is dead. What initially seems disaffected is replaced by the affect of somebody who knows it is too late to even grieve. These are the facts, Del Rey tells us. What else is left to say? The cover of Norman Fucking Rockwell! is at first glance so beautiful, so American-made, all gleaming yacht and Stars and Stripes and Hollywood progeny. Itâ€™s only when you look closer that you see it: the California shoreline engulfed in fire and smoke. â€œBlue Banistersâ€ contains the devastating line: â€œJenny was smoking by the pool, we were writing with Nikki Lane/I said, â€˜Iâ€™m scared of the Santa Clarita Fires,/I wish that it would rain.â€™â€ It has the quality of a panicked interjection, a white-hot horror building in the veins. But, as with â€œThe Greatestâ€, itâ€™s simply a paean. Thereâ€™s nothing to be done but bear witness.
There have been many proposals for the vacant Jergins Trust Building lot. Some of them have involved sealing off the tunnel, some have planned to incorporate it into a new project. An individual who purchased the land in the 1980s, whose plans involved destroying the structure to build a five-storey subterranean car park, didnâ€™t even know the tunnel existed when he bought the lot. Nothing has yet been built. The tunnel is still there, mostly forgotten, and the sounds of the traffic above echo off tiles the orange of Long Beach sunsets before fading into the darkness.
In â€œDid You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€, Lana Del Rey tells us of a girl who â€œsings â€˜Hotel Californiaâ€™/Not because she loves the notes or sounds that sound like Florida/Itâ€™s because sheâ€™s in a world preserved, only a few have found the doorâ€¦â€. Del Rey knows that narrative is the only way to truly immortalise. This is the ballad of America, and she is its poet.
[See also: Inside the â€œpsychopathicâ€ battle for Taylor Swift tour tickets]

title: Cosa ci fa Lana Del Rey dietro il bancone di una Waffle House in Alabama?
content:
di Luca Venturino 28 Luglio 2023
Ãˆ lei o non Ã¨ lei? Certo che Ã¨ lei! Immaginiamo che a unâ€™occhiata distratta la curiosa somiglianza tra una delle dipendenti della Waffle House in quel di Florence, Alabama, e Lana Del Rey fosse stata archiviata come fortunata e simpatica coincidenza: â€œChissÃ  in quanti le chiederanno se sa che le assomiglia!â€, avranno pensato. Ci chiediamo quale sarÃ  stato il dettaglio che avrÃ  confermato i sospetti e reso chiaro a tutti che sÃ¬, quella cameriera Ã¨ proprio lei â€“ Lana Del Rey in carne e ossa: avrÃ  cominciato a cantare durante il servizio? Qualche fan particolarmente ossessionato ha seguito una rigorosissima dieta a base di waffle per qualche giorno pur di osservarla al meglio e confermare i propri sospetti?
Lana Del Rey come non lâ€™avete mai vista: cameriera in una Waffle House
A onore del vero va detto che la nostra protagonista non ha fatto nulla per nascondere la propria identitÃ  (e perchÃ© dovrebbe, dâ€™altronde? Immaginiamo che il contesto fosse anacronistico al punto da non necessitare di alcun camuffamento), tanto che era solita indossare unâ€™uniforme con tanto di targhetta con il nome â€œLanaâ€. ChissÃ  in quanti lâ€™avranno notato e, pensando che si trattasse di una curiosa malizia del destino, hanno finito per ignorare il fatto che a portare al loro tavolo waffle e caffÃ¨ Ã¨ stata una cantante sei colte candidata ai Grammyâ€™s?
Lâ€™elemento piÃ¹ particolare di questa intera vicenda Ã¨ che, al momento, nessuno conosce con sicurezza il motivo per cui Lana Del Rey abbia deciso di lavorare come cameriera in una Waffle House. Non mancano, naturalmente, i fatalisti da social: â€œDeve stare attraversando un periodaccioâ€ scrive un utente â€œe ha bisogno di piÃ¹ soldiâ€. Qualcun altro specula di una carriera finita nel fango: â€œIl suo ultimo album non ha venduto una copia e non ha piÃ¹ un dollaro in tascaâ€. Altri ancora, invece, hanno domande piÃ¹ pressanti: â€œMa le sarÃ  permesso di utilizzare il cellulare mentre lavora?â€.
https://www.instagram.com/reel/Cu8OYJANYPp/
Scherzi a parte, lâ€™ipotesi piÃ¹ gettonata Ã¨ quella di uno â€œstudio sul campoâ€ per una nuova canzone, ma Ã¨ bene notare che i media locali hanno giÃ  contattato i due principali studi di registrazione della zona, FAME Studios e Muscle Shoals Sound, e ha appreso che la nostra protagonista non ha prenotato alcuna sessione; e che non sono attesi suoi concerti negli Stati Uniti del Sud.
Altra briciola di pane seguita dagli investigatori dellâ€™internet Ã¨ il fatto che Lana Del Rey aveva giÃ  citato la cittÃ  di Florence â€“ in cui, come accennato, si trova la Waffle House in cui sta lavorando â€“ nella canzone â€œParis, Texasâ€ nel suo album piÃ¹ recente Did You Know That There a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd: lâ€™idea Ã¨ che Lana abbia intenzione di registrare una videoclip proprio in quel locale. E giÃ  che passava da quelle parti, perchÃ© non dare una mano a portare gli ordini ai tavoli?

title: Cantando en el trabajo: Lana del Rey sigue sorprendiendo a sus fans en su nueva "etapa laboral" de camarera
content:
Desde que aparecieran las imÃ¡genes de Lana del Rey trabajando en una cadena de comida rÃ¡pida de EE UU, todos sus fans han estado pendientes de cuÃ¡les serÃ¡n los prÃ³ximos pasos de la intÃ©rprete. Y es que nadie sabe exactamente el motivo del porquÃ© de la nueva faceta empresarial de la cantante.
Lejos de su vida en los escenarios, la locura de las giras y los platÃ³s de televisiÃ³n, Lana se ha enfundado en el uniforme del restaurante para atender a los clientes y, como no podrÃ­a ser de otra manera, hacer las delicias de los seguidores que acuden a verla.
Prueba de ello han sido la gran cantidad de vÃ­deos que han aparecido en redes sociales. Y es que, como muchos han asegurado, Lana del Rey ha demostrado ser "humilde y cercana con sus seguidores". Por ello, no duda en cantar, hacerse fotos o firmar autÃ³grafos si asÃ­ se lo piden
Una de las grabaciones que mÃ¡s han llamado la atenciÃ³n ha sido en la que se ve a la intÃ©rprete agachÃ¡ndose para cantar junto a un cliente mayor uno de sus temas mÃ¡s importantes, Amazing Grace. Un emotivo vÃ­deo que se ha hecho viral a los pocos minutos.
Actualmente, el vÃ­deo roza las tres millones de reproducciones y supera los 54.000 'me gusta'. Por ello, no es de extraÃ±ar que se haya llenado de miles de comentarios asegurando que estÃ¡n "llorando" por lo bonita que es la publicaciÃ³n: "Es literalmente un Ã¡ngel".

title: David Letterman works surprise shift bagging groceries at Hy-Vee
content:
Stars: Theyâ€™re just like us! ... except after working a shift, they can go home and polish their awards.
On July 24, David Letterman appeared in a video posted by supermarket chain Hy-Vee working a shift at one of its stores in Des Moines, Iowa. In the three-minute video, the host of â€œMy Next Guest Needs No Introductionâ€ revisits his roots, restocking canned goods, bagging groceries and frankly, cutting it up with everyone he speaks to, as only an iconic comedian could.
â€œI spent a considerable amount of my life in a grocery store in Indianapolis,â€ Letterman says in the video. â€œIt was the last of the singular, independent owned grocery stores, and I loved it. And if I can give something back to the marketing community, I would like to do that, but I donâ€™t have all day, of course.â€
Itâ€™s true: In the 1960s, Letterman worked at Atlas Supermarket, a locally owned independent grocer in Indianapolis that went out of business in 2002 after 55 years in business. While he was a teen, Letterman started out stocking grocery shelves while he attended high school.
Get Boston local news, weather forecasts, lifestyle and entertainment stories to your inbox. Sign up for NBC Bostonâ€™s newsletters.
According to the videoâ€™s caption, the Emmy-winning host worked his shift at Hy-Vee while in town for the Hy-Vee Indycar Race Weekend, an event featuring auto racing and other events, including performances by Zac Brown Band and Carrie Underwood.
Letterman is one of the owners of RLL Racing â€” in fact, heâ€™s the first â€œLâ€ in its name â€” and heâ€™s also part-owner of Hy-Veeâ€™s No. 45 car, which ended up finishing 19th in the race.
Letterman shows himself to still be a true goofball, joking around with Hy-Vee employees while donning a branded apron and, later, straightening canned goods before spotting a slightly open can of Campbellâ€™s soup. He then does something Hy-Vee employees are likely discouraged from doing.
â€œWhoa, minestrone. Thatâ€™s good,â€ Letterman says before fully opening the can and taking a chug. He offers the can to another employee, who obliges and takes a sip himself. â€œYou want some? Go crazy.â€
Letterman then does the following instantly fireable activities for a grocery worker in rapid succession: announcing on the storeâ€™s intercom that â€œtoday and today onlyâ€ celery was â€œabsolutely free,â€ eating spilled nuts directly off of the floor and getting on the intercom again to make speeding race car noises.
At the end of his shift, Letterman asks how he did â€” but actually doesnâ€™t want to know the managerâ€™s true assessment.
â€œWell, you donâ€™t need to be honest with me. Iâ€™m 100, please donâ€™t be honest,â€ says Letterman, who is actually 76, by the way. At the end of the video, the staff applauds his undoubtedly stellar performance. You know, more people should clap at the end of the workday â€” not just when an Emmy winner stops by.
Shockingly, this is not the first time this month that a star has been spotted off the red carpet and in uniform working a shift at a food establishment. On July 20, social media posts began popping up showing singer Lana Del Rey at several spots around Florence, Alabama, including at a Waffle House, where the chanteuse served coffee and met with fans young and old, for a reason no one is quite sure of yet.Hereâ€™s hoping this is the start of a new trend: Megawatt stars shining a light on the everyday jobs of their fans.
This story first appeared on TODAY.com. More from TODAY:

All the stars are headed to Rhode Island this weekend.
From July 28-30, the annual Newport Folk Festival is returning to Fort Adams State Park for three days of delicious food and drink, good times and great music.
Just a few of the stars on hand this year to deliver the folks-y jams include Lana Del Rey, My Morning Jacket, Maggie Rogers, Jason Isbell and John Oates.
Aimee Mann, Billy Strings, Angel Olsen, Goose and Los Lobos will be there too.
Heck, even Stephen Colbertâ€™s bandleader Jon Batiste is slated to perform.
Donâ€™t forget The Hold Steady either.
Seriously, we could do this all day â€” Newport has a truly exciting three-day lineup planned for music fans.
As a result, ticket prices are quite high.
At the time of publication, the lowest price we could find on multi-day general admission passes was $993 before fees on Vivid Seats.
Single-day passes start at $721 before fees.
Want to find out more about the multi-day extravaganza before committing?
Hereâ€™s everything you need to know and more about the 2023 Newport Folk Festival.
All prices listed above are subject to fluctuation.
Newport Folk Festival 2023 ticket prices
A complete breakdown of all the best single and multi-day general admission passes for the Newport Folk Festival can be found below.
Newport Folk Festival 2023 dates Ticket prices
start at Saturday, July 29 through Sunday, July 30

Single-day pass $721 Saturday, July 29
Single-day pass $1578 Sunday, July 30
Single-day pass $1777
(Note: The New York Post confirmed all above prices at the publication time. All prices are in US dollars, subject to fluctuation and include additional fees at checkout.)
Vivid Seats is a verified secondary market ticketing platform, and prices may be higher or lower than face value, depending on demand.
They offer a 100% buyer guarantee that states your transaction will be safe and secure and your tickets will be delivered prior to the event.
Newport Folk Festival 2023 complete lineup
In total, there are over 50 huge acts set to play over the long weekend.
For a closer look at everyone whoâ€™s performing â€” from Abraham Alexander all the way to Willi Carlisle â€” you can find the Newport Folk Festivalâ€™s complete 2023 lineup here.
Huge music festivals in 2023
If Pitchfork is a little too last-minute for you, there are a ton of other options for you these next few months.
Personally, we recommend keeping an eye out on these five fests with lineups so bomb youâ€™ll be kicking yourself for missing them live.

NÃ£o faz muito tempo que Lana Del Rey deixou sua marca no Brasil depois de tanto prometer. Acontece que a queridinha voltou a ficar na boca do povo ao aparecer de garÃ§onete em um restaurante nos EUA. O vÃ­deo viralizou na web e muitos fÃ£s jÃ¡ criaram diversas teorias sobre o seu novo trabalho.

title: Lana Del Rey Works a Shift Waffle House in Alabama: Photos
content:
How is Lana Del Rey beating summertime sadness this year? By working at a Waffle House in Alabama, serving it up Lana style.
The 38-year-old singer-songwriter was spotted Thursday (July 20) pouring coffee and chatting with customers at a Waffle House location in Florence, Ala., in full employee uniform complete with a â€œLanaâ€ name tag. During break times, she was able to snap a few photos with fans, blue vape pen in hand.
Neither Lana nor folks on the scene have provided any explanation as to why she was working there. (Billboard has reached out to her reps for comment.) The â€œDoinâ€™ Timeâ€ singer is, however, notorious for including homages to Americana aesthetics and traditions in her music â€” she even name-checked the city of Florence in her Ocean Blvd. track â€œParis, Texas.â€
â€œShe was there, wearing a uniform and everything,â€ Karina Cisneros Juarez, who met the artist at the restaurant, told local news site AL.com. â€œIt was a bit surreal. I just told her how much I loved her music and her work in general. She was super lovely, and incredibly nice.â€
â€œIt was great! She was so down to earth and real with us,â€ Macy Ladner, who also met the musician, told the publication. â€œTalked with me and my friend about our jobs as teachers, about how sheâ€™s working on a new recording.â€
Whatever the reason, fans online think the situation is hilarious. One person commented on Twitter, â€œThis is just so unbelievably Lana coded, she is so unserious,â€ while another joked, â€œUnfortunately Lana Del Rey was fired today at waffle house for vaping in the walk in refrigerator :(â€œ
This isnâ€™t the first time the Grammy nominee has been spotted in Alabama this week. Pictures and videos have been cropping up online for the past few days of her going about her business in the southern state, getting her nails done in a salon in Birmingham and signing autographs outside of an Americaâ€™s Thrift Store in Florence.
See snaps of Lana working at Waffle House below:
Lana Del Rey working at Waffle House pic.twitter.com/7V5av4OFrs â€” honeymoun (@honeymounz) July 20, 2023

title: Lana Del Rey is working as a waitress at a Waffle House in Alabama
content:
CNN â€”
Lana Del Rey is serving up waffles.
The â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ singer has apparently been moonlighting as a waitress at a Waffle House in Florence, Alabama, according to social media posts from a few of her customers shared on a fan account. Pictures posted Thursday show Del Rey in uniform, warmly serving patrons and working behind the counter.
In one video, she can be heard saying, â€œOh look at this guy. Oh God, Charlie donâ€™t film him without his permission.â€
â€œJust Lana Del Rey working as a waitress at a restaurant,â€ the caption reads.
She even has her own Waffle House name badge.
Another person posed with the singer inside the Waffle House, writing, â€œTo say I am ecstatic is an understatement!!!.â€
Itâ€™s not known why Del Rey is currently in Alabama, but she has reportedly been spotted in recent days at an area nail salon and a Starbucks.
CNN has reached out to her representative for comment.
Del Rey recently played at Glastonbury Festival in Somerset, England.
She also released her new album, titled â€œDid You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd.â€

title: Lana Del Rey seen working as a waitress at a Waffle House
content:
L ana Del Rey has been caught on video working at a Waffle House in Alabama.
The 38-year old singer was filmed by a fan as she made coffee behind the counter in the popular Florence Waffle House wearing a uniform and name tag.
In the clip, the star, who recently headlined Glastonbury Festival, is heard saying: â€œOh look at this guy! Oh God, Charlie donâ€™t film him without his permission."
An Alabama resident named Karina Cisneros Juarez wrote on Facebook alongside a snap of her at the restaurant: â€œTo say I am ecstatic is an understatement!â€
â€œI have been a huge fan of Lana Del Rey for over a decade, so meeting her today was truly insane,â€ he also told local website AL.com: â€œIt was a bit surreal. I just told her how much I loved her music and her work in general. She was super lovely, and incredibly nice.â€
Another fan, Vanson Clendenin, poated a snap of himself with the star and captioned it: â€œToday was actually insane! Lana you are a legend and thanks for serving me at the local Florence Waffle House!â€
The reason the acclaimed singer took on the restaurant shift is not known. However, some fans have suggested the move wasnâ€™t for publicity or a project, but her being â€œhumbleâ€ or wanting to be â€œnormalâ€.
One person tweeted: â€œSheâ€™s humble. I respect it.â€ Another wrote: â€œShe just wants to be normal. I feel her.â€
A third said: â€œImagine just going to eat and Lana Del Rey is your waitress.â€ While a fourth commented: â€œSinger, actress, waitress, 10 minute songs, Waffle House employee. What is it Miss Lana Del Rey canâ€™t do?â€
Back in 2021, Del Rey said while accepting Varietyâ€™s Artist of the Decade Award that she was â€œvery flexibleâ€ and had â€œother job opportunitiesâ€ away from music.

title: Pillan a Lana Del Rey trabajando en una conocida franquicia de 'waffles' de EE UU
content:
Lana Del Rey mueve a millones de fans cada mes en su cuenta de Spotify. Sus canciones se han convertido en himnos internacionales y cada uno de sus pasos son seguidos y celebrados a partes iguales. Por ello, cuando algunos de sus seguidores la encontraron trabajando, no pudieron quedarse mÃ¡s sorprendidos.
Y es que, lejos de estar subida en un escenario interpretando sus temas, llevaba el uniforme de Waffle House, una conocida franquicia de EE UU. En uno de los establecimientos de Alamaba la cantante se movÃ­a con naturalidad.
Los clientes, al descubrir a la intÃ©rprete con una placa con su nombre atendiendo, se quedaron atÃ³nitos. Pero ella, con calma, no dudÃ³ en posar con sus fans y hacerse todas las fotos que quisieron. "Â¡Decir que estoy extasiada es poco!", asegurÃ³ una de las afortunadas.
Lana Del Rey spotted working at a Waffle House in Alabama. pic.twitter.com/CLWuvEyazr â€” Pop Crave (@PopCrave) July 20, 2023
"Fue un poco surrealista. Le dije lo mucho que me gustaba su mÃºsica y su trabajo en general. Fue encantadora e increÃ­blemente amable", ha asegurado una de sus seguidoras. De hecho, por esta acciÃ³n ha recibido una gran cantidad de halagos: "Es humilde. Lo respeto".
Lana Del Rey fue vista trabajando en un Waffle House en Alabama. pic.twitter.com/43uVoe8jwn â€” Indie 505 (@Indie5051) July 21, 2023
No hay una razÃ³n exacta del porquÃ© de las acciones de la cantante, aunque segÃºn han explicado algunos usuarios de las redes, el personal de Waffle House le regalÃ³ el uniforme y la placa con su nombre y que decidiÃ³ animarse y probar a servir mesas.

title: Lana Del Rey Works A Shift At Waffle House In Alabama: Photos & Video
content:
Lana Del Rey, 38, served looks and local customers during a recent shift at Waffle House in Alabama on Jul. 20! The pop star rocked a black mini-skirt and a blue Waffle House t-shirt along with a name tag during her work day at the restaurant chain. Lana made sure to accessorize her look with sparkly hoop earrings and a few dainty bracelets on her arm. The â€œVideo Gamesâ€ hitmaker notably opted to style her raven-hued tresses in a messy updo. Lana has not publicly confirmed if she did indeed work a full shift or what the purpose of the visit was for.
During her shift, Lana was even pictured posing with a fan (see the photo below). The 38-year-old not only stopped for a photo with the admirer but she was also pictured pouring cups of coffee and chatting with customers. At one point, she told a friend to be careful when filming people inside the food joint. â€œOh look at this guy! Oh god Charlie donâ€™t film him without his permission,â€ Lana quipped in the video.
Soon after photos of the Grammy nominated artist working at the restaurant landed online, many of her fans took to Twitter to react and swoon over Lanaâ€™s Waffle House moment. â€œShe just wants to be normal I feel her,â€ one fan wrote, while another joked, â€œimagine just going to eat and lana del rey is your waitress.â€ Meanwhile, one of her admirers couldnâ€™t help but make a play on words with Lanaâ€™s latest stunt. â€œSheâ€™s serving â€¦literally,â€ they tweeted, while a fourth fan wrote, â€œLana Del Rey serving me eggs, coffee and sausage would be the highlight of my life.â€
Why is Lana Del Rey working at Waffle House now ğŸ˜­ pic.twitter.com/sYsePInfjG â€” honeymoun (@honeymounz) July 20, 2023
The â€œLust for Lifeâ€ songstressâ€™ recent shift at the local Waffle House comes nearly four months after Billboard reported that Lana is engaged to Range Media Partnersâ€™ Evan Winiker. Although the two remain extremely private about their relationship, she did rock a diamond ring on â€œthatâ€ finger at the 2023 Billboard Women In Music event on Mar. 1. More so, while channeling her inner server, Lana did sport the diamond ring on her hand.
While at the music event earlier this spring, Lana was honored with the Music Visionary Award for her work. â€œDrivers licenseâ€ hitmaker Olivia Rodrigo, 20, even presented Lana with the award moments before Lana delivered a viral speech. â€œI donâ€™t exactly have a long-term vision at all, but if you were curious, I am very, very happy,â€ she said during her acceptance speech. â€œWhen I released my first album 14 years ago, the waters were not quite as warm. Iâ€™m really happy for everyone who feels like itâ€™s a wonderful time in the culture to be themselves and express themselves. It didnâ€™t feel that way in 2008.â€ She also revealed that she was â€œhappy,â€ which was her â€œultimate goal.â€

title: Lana Del Rey Spotted Working at Alabama Waffle House, No One Knows Why
content:
Lana Del Rey was spotted working a shift at a Waffle House in Florence, Alabama.
It's unclear why she was there, leading her fans to speculate on a variety of possibilities.
One theory is that the visit was linked to a single from her new album, which references the town.
Get the inside scoop on todayâ€™s biggest stories in business, from Wall Street to Silicon Valley â€” delivered daily. Loading Something is loading. Thanks for signing up! Access your favorite topics in a personalized feed while you're on the go. download the app Email address By clicking â€˜Sign upâ€™, you agree to receive marketing emails from Insider as well as other partner offers and accept our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy
Lana Del Rey has left fans puzzled after she was spotted working a shift at a Waffle House in Florence, Alabama, on Thursday.
In photographs circulated on social media, the "Blue Jeans" singer was photographed behind the Waffle House counter, brewing coffee while wearing a Waffle House uniform and a "Lana" name tag.
A widely shared video clip also shows her requesting a patron not to film somebody else without their permission.
During her time at the Alabama eatery, Del Rey also posed for photos with fans.
A local, Karina Cisneros Juarez, detailed her encounter with Del Rey to local media outlet AL.com.
"It was a bit surreal," Juarez said, adding: "I just told her how much I loved her music and her work in general. She was super lovely and incredibly nice."
The reason why Del Rey was at the Waffle House remains unclear, leaving fans to speculate on a variety of possibilities.
On fan forums, some speculated that she might be recording a music video, while others suggested it could be a publicity stunt for upcoming songs. Others jokingly suggested that she might be exploring a new career path.
In recent days, Del Rey has also been spotted at a number of other unlikely places in Alabama, including downtown Florence and a Birmingham nail salon.
AL.com reported that she doesn't appear to be in Alabama working on new music. Local recording venues FAME Studios and Muscle Shoals Sound both told the outlet that she hadn't been recording with them.
It's possible that the visit could be linked to a song from her new album, "Did You Know That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd."
In "Paris, Texas," she sings: "I took a train to Spain, just a notebook in my hand/Then I went to see some friends of mine, down in Florence, Alabama."
Del Rey's publicist and Waffle House did not immediately respond to Insider's requests for comment.

title: Enivrante Lana Del Rey
content:
Lana Del Rey, sur la scÃ¨ne des Plaines â€“ lâ€™artiste et son Ã©quipe ont refusÃ© la prise de photos par des mÃ©dias.

Avec une vingtaine de minutes de retard (pour que le public soit au juste niveau dâ€™anticipation), Lana Del Rey sâ€™est prÃ©sentÃ©e sur scÃ¨ne sur une introduction vaporeuse qui a menÃ© Ã  une version Ã©courtÃ©e de la superbe A & W, tirÃ©e de son plus rÃ©cent â€“ et magnifique â€“ album, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Boulevard.
Young and Beautiful a suivi, les chants (et les cris) des festivaliers accompagnant la douce voix de lâ€™AmÃ©ricaine.
HabillÃ©e dâ€™une majestueuse robe blanche ornÃ©e de perles et de fleurs, fidÃ¨le Ã  son esthÃ©tique, la chanteuse a fait en sorte que son immense traÃ®ne devienne un Ã©lÃ©ment scÃ©nique, flottant derriÃ¨re elle jusquâ€™au fond de la scÃ¨ne. Toute la mise en scÃ¨ne du spectacle a Ã©tÃ© fantastique, Ã©volutive. Pour Bartender, elle sâ€™est installÃ©e devant une vanitÃ©, pendant que ses danseuses ont dÃ©fait son chignon pour laisser ses cheveux retomber sur ses Ã©paules.
Tout au long du spectacle, au moyen dâ€™accessoires et avec lâ€™aide de ses quatre danseuses, elle a maintenu une thÃ©Ã¢tralitÃ© qui a donnÃ© une vie nouvelle et captivante Ã  ses chansons mÃ©lancoliques.
Lana Del Rey, sur le plan vocal, a Ã©tÃ© toujours Ã  la hauteur, toujours juste. Sur The Grants, elle et ses choristes nous ont permis de nous envoler au son de leurs harmonies.
Ensuite sont venues Cherry, Pretty When You Cry, (quâ€™elle a chantÃ©e couchÃ©e sur scÃ¨ne), puis Ride. Del Rey a puisÃ© dans tout son rÃ©pertoire pour ce spectacle, qui nous a ramenÃ©s Ã  lâ€™Ã©poque de Born To Die, de son album homonyme, et de Lust for Life, mais a aussi permis de voir sur scÃ¨ne ses plus rÃ©cents morceaux.
Un moment magique
En prÃ©sentant des versions Ã©courtÃ©es de certaines chansons (comme Born To Die, juste aprÃ¨s), lâ€™auteure-compositrice-interprÃ¨te a prÃ©sentÃ© un spectacle gÃ©nÃ©reux oÃ¹ beaucoup de terrain a Ã©tÃ© couvert. Des super fans, juste devant nous, complÃ¨tement extatiques chaque fois quâ€™une chanson dÃ©butait, montraient parfaitement le ressenti dans la foule. Au moment dâ€™Arcadia, quand des dizaines de milliers dâ€™Â« Ã©toiles Â» se sont allumÃ©es sur les Plaines (grÃ¢ce aux cellulaires des festivaliers), la chanteuse a semblÃ© Ã©mue et a ensuite remerciÃ© son public pour ce moment magique.
Le moment partagÃ© avec Lana Del Rey sâ€™est vite envolÃ©. Une heure et demie a semblÃ© nâ€™Ãªtre quâ€™une demi-heure. AprÃ¨s Ultraviolence, White Mustang, Candy Necklace (pour laquelle elle a grimpÃ© sur le piano Ã  queue sur scÃ¨ne) et Venice Bitch, on en Ã©tait dÃ©jÃ  au dernier segment de la soirÃ©e.
Juste avant White Mustang, elle est descendue au parterre parler Ã  ses fans, les Ã©treindre, prendre des Ã©goportraits et rÃ©colter quelques cadeaux pendant un long moment. Mais avant dâ€™atteindre la fouleâ€¦ elle est tombÃ©e sur le sol. Â« Ce ne serait pas un spectacle si je ne tombais pas Â», a-t-elle lancÃ©, pleine dâ€™autodÃ©rision, le genou tachÃ© de boue et de sang aprÃ¨s sa chute.
La soirÃ©e sâ€™est terminÃ©e bien aprÃ¨s 23 h, avec Venice Bitch, Diet Mountain Dew, la trÃ¨s populaire Summertime Sadness, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Boulevard et, finalement, lâ€™ultrapopulaire Video Games.
Â« Câ€™est probablement le plus gros spectacle que lâ€™on a jouÃ© depuis un an Â», a dit Lana Del Rey aux multiples dizaines de milliers de personnes devant elle, touchÃ©e et impressionnÃ©e, Ã  la toute fin de son concert, avant de monter sur une balanÃ§oire pour la derniÃ¨re chanson de la soirÃ©e, Video Games. Â« Merci de mâ€™avoir Ã  la maison durant les jours. Â»
Câ€™Ã©tait un moment planant et magnifique. Merci Ã  Lana Del Rey.
Allan Rayman et The War on Drugs
Le Canadien Allan Rayman, dÃ¨s 19 h, a Ã©tÃ© impeccable. Cet Ã©nergumÃ¨ne Ã  lâ€™Ã©nergie aussi mystÃ©rieuse que captivante a profitÃ© des trois quarts dâ€™heure qui lui Ã©taient allouÃ©s pour enchaÃ®ner ses chansons au groove entraÃ®nant, aux rythmes parfois explosifs, souvent sombres et langoureux.
PHOTO CAROLINE GRÃ‰GOIRE, LE SOLEIL Allan Rayman
Â« Je ne suis pas le plus Ã©loquent, je suis meilleur chanteur Â», a intimÃ© le chanteur introverti Ã  la foule qui scandait son nom, manifestement sous le charme de sa jolie voix rauque, de son charisme et de sa prÃ©sence aussi dÃ©calÃ©e quâ€™attachante.
Sâ€™il nâ€™a pas beaucoup parlÃ© Ã  son public, Allan Rayman a tout donnÃ© sur scÃ¨ne (sans Ãªtre trÃ¨s dÃ©monstratif, il exprime clairement son plaisir de partager ce moment). Une premiÃ¨re partie de haut calibre.
The War on Drugs nâ€™a pas non plus failli Ã  la tÃ¢che.
Il ne lui a fallu quâ€™une chanson (Oceans of Darkness) pour nous rappeler pourquoi ce groupe ne nous dÃ©Ã§oit jamais. EntourÃ© de ses acolytes, un t-shirt tie-dye violet sur le dos, lunettes fumÃ©es sur le nez, le meneur Adam Granduciel a gardÃ© bien en vie lâ€™ambiance planante quâ€™Allan Rayman avait installÃ©e (et que Lana Del Rey a fait perdurer ensuite).
PHOTO CAROLINE GRÃ‰GOIRE, LE SOLEIL Le chanteuer Adam Granduciel, de The War on Drugs
En tournÃ©e depuis la sortie de son album I Donâ€™t Live Here Anymore en 2021, la formation amÃ©ricaine sâ€™est arrÃªtÃ©e Ã  MontrÃ©al vendredi et sâ€™est immÃ©diatement rendue Ã  QuÃ©bec ensuite pour la soirÃ©e de samedi.
Une prestation de The War on Drugs Ã©tait tout indiquÃ©e pour prÃ©cÃ©der celle de Lana Del Rey. Non, les deux styles de musique nâ€™ont rien Ã  voir, mais le groupe originaire de Philadelphie a excellÃ©, participant Ã  rendre cette soirÃ©e mÃ©morable.
Solide cÃ´tÃ© instrumental, le groupe dâ€™expÃ©rience a donnÃ© le genre de prestation qui tÃ©moigne dâ€™un rÃ©pertoire bien garni et dâ€™une aisance sur scÃ¨ne que seules les annÃ©es peuvent amener. Une production simple a permis de garder toute lâ€™attention sur sa musique alternative qui flirte parfois doucement avec la pop.
Le FEQ, cette annÃ©e, doit composer avec divers reports et annulations, pour toutes sortes de raisons. Heureusement, aucun des artistes de la soirÃ©e de samedi nâ€™a eu Ã  se dÃ©sister. Malheureusement, ce sera le cas dimanche, puisque Patrice Michaud a dÃ» annuler sa prÃ©sence pour des raisons de santÃ©.
Les frais dâ€™hÃ©bergement ont Ã©tÃ© payÃ©s par le Festival dâ€™Ã©tÃ© de QuÃ©bec, qui nâ€™a eu aucun droit de regard sur le contenu de ce reportage.

title: En retard, Princesse Lana hypnotise les Plaines
content:
AprÃ¨s avoir vu son programme Ãªtre Ã©courtÃ© abruptement Ã  Glastonbury il y a quelques semaines en raison dâ€™un retard dâ€™une trentaine de minutes, la princesse de la pop, Lana Del Rey nâ€™avait visiblement pas appris. Elle est arrivÃ©e sur les plaines dâ€™Abraham avec un retard dâ€™une vingtaine de minutes. Heureusement, cette fois, ce fut sans consÃ©quence pour ses admirateurs qui ont pu profiter de son spectacle complet.
La foule particuliÃ¨rement jeune et surtout composÃ©e dâ€™un public fÃ©minin attendait de pied ferme sa dÃ©esse. DÃ¨s lâ€™ouverture des portes du site sur le coup de 17h45, ce sont des milliers dâ€™amateurs.trices de la New-Yorkaise qui ont couru en quÃªte de la meilleure place disponible. Alors, dÃ¨s quâ€™elle est apparue sur la scÃ¨ne, presque tous lui ont instantanÃ©ment pardonnÃ© son retard.
VÃªtue dâ€™une chic robe blanche et dâ€™un bandeau dÃ©corÃ© de diamants, la princesse Lana a enchaÃ®nÃ© ses chansons planantes Ã  la douce mÃ©lodie entourÃ©e de nombreux danseurs. Se faisant tantÃ´t peigner les cheveux pendant Bartender, ou se cachant un autre tantÃ´t derriÃ¨re un voile pendant Ultraviolence, elle a prÃ©sentÃ© un concert dont la mise en scÃ¨ne Ã©tait soigneusement rÃ©flÃ©chie. Pendant Ride, deux balanÃ§oires sont mÃªme apparues au bÃ©nÃ©fice des danseurs.
AprÃ¨s Ultraviolence, la chanteuse est descendue de la scÃ¨ne pour aller Ã  la rencontre des fans dans la premiÃ¨re rangÃ©e. Sur fond de musique douce, elle a pris le temps de discuter avec plusieurs dâ€™entre eux sans utiliser son microphone et de signer des autographes. Bien quâ€™inutilisÃ© par la chanteuse, le micro est demeurÃ© bien ouvert permettant ainsi au reste de la foule dâ€™entendre les nombreux Â«LanaÂ» et Â«I love youÂ» criÃ© par les festivaliers prÃ¨s des clÃ´tures.
Au moment de remonter sur scÃ¨ne, elle sâ€™est aperÃ§ue que du sang avait tachÃ© sa robe puisquâ€™elle avait trÃ©buchÃ© en se rendant prÃ¨s des spectateurs, puis a enchaÃ®nÃ© avec White Mustang et Candy Necklaces, une collaboration enregistrÃ©e avec Jon Batiste. Avant cette derniÃ¨re elle a invitÃ© le public Ã  prendre le temps dâ€™aller visionner le vidÃ©oclip rÃ©alisÃ© pour cet extrait et lancÃ© il y a environ deux mois.
Une fois le grand succÃ¨s Summertime Sadness et Did you know that thereâ€™s a tunnel under Ocean Blvd interprÃ©tÃ© devant des marÃ©es de tÃ©lÃ©phone capturant le toutâ€¦ pendant quâ€™aucun photographe ou vidÃ©aste de la presse locale nâ€™avait le droit de prendre quelque image que ce soit, la chanteuse sâ€™est arrÃªtÃ© pour observer le public. Â«Je ne peux pas croire combien de personnes il y a ici. Pouvez-vous? Est-ce que câ€™est la normalitÃ© pour vous? Câ€™est probablement le plus grand spectacle que nous avons fait dans la derniÃ¨re annÃ©e! Non, depuis toujours!Â», a-t-elle lancÃ©.
Puis, en montant sur lâ€™une des balanÃ§oires, elle a conclu la soirÃ©e avec VidÃ©o Games. Saluant le public, elle a ensuite quittÃ© la scÃ¨ne avec ses danseurs sous un air digne dâ€™un gÃ©nÃ©rique de film et le mot Â«FinÂ» est apparu sur les Ã©crans dans la langue de MoliÃ¨re.

title: Lana Del Rey review - Hyde Park has seen nothing like this
content:
Never cheat on a songwriter. Especially not Lana Del Rey. We learn this at Hyde Park, under a sun-dappled sky streaked with clouds shaped like chemtrails. Appropriately, the American balladeer is caressing the final verse of Chemtrails Over the Country Club, steering its lullaby-like coda to gentle sleep, when she veers suddenly off-road without warning. Squatting, staring inscrutably, she replaces the basic yet romantic line â€œyouâ€™re born in December, Iâ€™m born in Juneâ€ with â€œhe was born in Decemberâ€¦ and got married when we were still togetherâ€.
Shrieks and wails of affirmation greet Lanaâ€™s revelation, as she continues, crooning â€œsometimes I wonder what his wife would think if she knewâ€ and follows that faux-naif savagery with â€œhe got married when we were in couples therapy togetherâ€. As a published poet, Del Rey knows that (a) this doesnâ€™t scan, and (b) it doesnâ€™t matter. Itâ€™s electrifying, and gloriously odd. What just happened? Did she really call out her ex to 60,000 strangers? Is it true? Itâ€™s a goosebump moment, four songs into her biggest UK gig, that proves precisely why her audience are so invested in every second of her every performance.
Mini Lanas hug each other ecstatically, singing along to beautifully arranged alt-rockers White Mustang and Cherry
Weirdness, messiness and dark comedy are what thefans are here for. For them, Lana is more recognisably human, more relatable, than the distant, alien perfection of a BeyoncÃ©, which explains why Del Reyâ€™s abbreviated Glastonbury appearance â€“ when her usual tardiness crashed into an immovable curfew â€“ is an escapade to add to her myth rather than detract from it. Everywhere there are little Lanas in lacy petticoats, white dresses, flower crowns, cowgirl boots, heart-shaped sunglasses, fizzing with Mentos-in-Coke-bottle levels of excitement. A mass wedding of brides, waiting for their mother-wife. On Chemtrails, Del Rey says sheâ€™s still â€œstrange and wildâ€, while describing a life of placid domesticity. Itâ€™s clear her fans see themselves in Lana, and her songs are mirrors that they find themselves in.
As this is only the eighth British concert Del Rey has played during a decade in which she has put out seven albums, many here have never seen her live before. Or, judging by the yelps with which they greet the roadies setting up, never seen anyone live before. It proves how loved she is. Some thought BST organisers were ambitious to book her as the final headliner in a programme studded with Rushmores such as Springsteen, Guns Nâ€™ Roses and Billy Joel. Yet the sophisticated, mature Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd is the UKâ€™s fourth bestselling album released this year, and the transformative power of Del Reyâ€™s ongoing success radiates with every step she takes. While her early gigs were marked by awkwardness, tonightâ€™s careful choreography grants her a confidence to roam and own the stage that she didnâ€™t have 10 years ago.
Even when she seems most effortless, drifting around, attended by six dancers, three superb gospel singers and a four-man band, itâ€™s clear that plenty of work has gone into this remarkable show and its theatrical tableaux. Del Rey doesnâ€™t say much â€“ but doesnâ€™t need to. Like her songs, the set, screens and staging donâ€™t always offer obvious, fixed meanings but artfully employ familiar signifiers or iconography to sketch her cinematic universe of complicated relationships and unresolved trauma.
There are gold arches, a dressing area, two flower-strewn swings and a huge wedding train, which her dancers attach to her floral Zimmermann Wonderland dress during A&W then unfurl for Young and Beautiful. A luminous torch song for a world on fire, it gets a rapturous reception. But then so does Pretty When You Cry, which Del Rey sings draped on a seedbed of writhing dancers. Or Bartender, delivered as she vapes at her dressing table while her stylist gets to work. Perhaps in 1969, Mick Jagger sang flawlessly while having his already immaculate hair gussied up, but it seems more plausible that this is the first time Hyde Park has seen anything like this, and it reacts accordingly.
Singer and stylist at work. Photograph: Samir Hussein/WireImage for ABA
Mini Lanas hug each other ecstatically, singing along to beautifully arranged, blues-adjacent alt-rockers White Mustang and Cherry, or sway alone to the music, eyes closed. Ultraviolence, with its queasy emotional masochism (â€œhe hit me and it felt like a kissâ€), is a narcotic, transgressive swirl punctuated by Del Rey punching herself in the face. These intense, intimate moments shouldnâ€™t really work on a crowd this size, but the strength of her writing and singing swells the newer songs to stadium scale, while classics Born to Die and Ride take flight on the audienceâ€™s feral enthusiasm. Even the five minutes she spends greeting tearful front-row stans canâ€™t spike the gigâ€™s serene momentum towards a titanic Video Games, which of course she sings while oscillating back and forth on a giant garlanded swing. With astonishing performances like this, Del Rey will always be her fansâ€™ main character, never a side chick.

title: PrÃ©cieuse et paradoxale Lana del Rey sur les Plaines
content:
Pour un samedi soir de festival, lâ€™ambiance Ã©tait pour le moins dramatique sur les plaines dâ€™Abraham â€“ au bonheur des dizaines de milliers de fans de la diva amÃ©ricaine Lana del Rey, qui a offert une vingtaine de chansons en 90 minutes lors dâ€™une de ses rares apparitions en sol quÃ©bÃ©cois. Personne nâ€™a dansÃ©, ni fÃªtÃ© dâ€™ailleurs, communiant plutÃ´t avec la musicienne dans sa vision dâ€™une AmÃ©rique idÃ©alisÃ©e.
Au festival britannique Glastonbury il y a trois semaines, la diva a irritÃ© lâ€™auditoire en se pointant sur scÃ¨ne avec une bonne demi-heure de retard, la forÃ§ant Ã  amputer sa performance. Samedi soir dernier, la vingtaine de minutes de retard sur lâ€™horaire nâ€™Ã©tait pas un caprice : lâ€™Ã©quipe technique avait du pain sur la planche pour dÃ©barrasser lâ€™imposant Ã©quipement de scÃ¨ne des excellents The War on Drugs qui la prÃ©cÃ©daient (nous y reviendrons) et amÃ©nager le dÃ©cor de la musicienne comprenant, entre autres, un lampadaire, des arches, un piano Ã  queue Ã©rigÃ© sur une petite estrade, des balanÃ§oires et un arbre.
La poignÃ©e de concerts quâ€™elle avait donnÃ©s Ã  MontrÃ©al (le dernier Ã  Osheaga en 2016) ne nous avait pas laissÃ© une forte impression, del Rey nâ€™Ã©tant pas exactement une bÃªte de scÃ¨ne avec son filet de voix joli, juste, mais sans envergure. Une bÃªte, elle ne le fut pas davantage hier soir, mais voilÃ  tout le gÃ©nie de sa scÃ©nographie : ambitionner sur le dÃ©cor, lâ€™entourer de six trÃ¨s bonnes danseuses et de trois excellentes chanteuses gospel, sans compter ses quatre compÃ©tents musiciens de scÃ¨ne. La manoeuvre rÃ©ussit : pendant que tout ce beau monde sâ€™active, Lana Ã©clÃ´t prÃ©cieusement, chantant trÃ¨s bien mais trÃ¨s doucement (on perdait parfois sa voix dans lâ€™orchestre), dansant peu sinon avec inconfort.
VoilÃ  le paradoxe du phÃ©nomÃ¨ne Lana del Rey. RÃ©vÃ©lÃ©e par son deuxiÃ¨me album Born to Die grÃ¢ce aux magnifiques Blue Jeans et Video Games, portÃ©e aux nues Ã  titre dâ€™autrice-compositrice grÃ¢ce Ã  lâ€™album Norman Fucking Rockwell (2019), la musicienne est vÃ©nÃ©rÃ©e comme une icÃ´ne de la nouvelle chanson pop, mais sa chanson relÃ¨ve plutÃ´t du secret que lâ€™on garde pour soi, de lâ€™intime quâ€™elle installe entre elle et lâ€™auditeur. Elle serait Ã  sa place dans une petite salle sombre, mais son succÃ¨s la condamne aux grandes scÃ¨nes. Câ€™est tragique, au fond, mais cette tragÃ©die colle justement Ã  son personnage.
Sa chanson est une expÃ©rience intime, introspective, aux textes qui fantasment lâ€™AmÃ©rique, et particuliÃ¨rement la Californie, des annÃ©es 1950 et 1960. Une dÃ©tresse de vivre exprimÃ©e par des images ingÃ©nieuses et une voix Ã  fleur de peau qui semble nous chanter une vÃ©ritÃ© Ã©clairant les coins sombres de nos propres existences â€” rien, en somme, pour Ã©lectriser 80 000 spectateurs rÃ©unis par un beau samedi soir de juillet devant lâ€™une des plus grandes scÃ¨nes du QuÃ©bec.
Et pourtant, une magie opÃ¨re. La basse gronde pour A&W en ouverture, tirÃ©e de lâ€™album Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, paru plus tÃ´t cette annÃ©e. Del Rey porte une robe de mariÃ©e, ses choristes seront ses demoiselles dâ€™honneur, alors que les danseuses soulÃ¨vent son voile long comme un parachute pendant Young and Beautiful.
Â« Thank you so much Quebec ! Â», dit-elle avec un sourire quâ€™on ne lui voit jamais dans ses vidÃ©oclips lÃ©chÃ©s. Tout dâ€™un coup, lâ€™image de la diva sâ€™estompe, alors quâ€™elle nous raconte avoir grandi tout prÃ¨s dâ€™ici, Â« Ã  3 h 30 au sud du fleuve Â», dans les Adirondacks. Plusieurs fois durant le concert, elle sortira de son personnage pour offrir quelques mots sincÃ¨res aux festivaliers, qui en retour chanteront avec elle ses refrains les mieux connus.
Les autres, souvent chantÃ©s simplement accompagnÃ©s dâ€™un accompagnement de piano, de guitare diffuse et de cymbale, susciteront moins dâ€™intÃ©rÃªt. Durant les longs moments trop calmes des deux premiers tiers du concert, on entend trop les conversations entre spectateurs, parfois distraits par les chorÃ©graphies Ã©tudiÃ©es. Les favorites rompent les discussions : Chemtrails Over the Country Club, Pretty When You Cry, Born to Die, lâ€™excellente Blue Jeans nous faisant enfin comprendre quâ€™un authentique orchestre rock ayant de lâ€™aplomb lâ€™accompagne.
AprÃ¨s avoir interprÃ©tÃ© le rock langoureux Ultraviolence, Lana del Ray est descendue de son piÃ©destal pour aller saluer les fans tassÃ©s le long des clÃ´tures de sÃ©curitÃ©. Moment fascinant qui, Ã  nouveau, brisait lâ€™image de diva quâ€™elle a studieusement construite au fil des annÃ©es : serrant des mains, acceptant de se faire faire la bise, elle sâ€™arrÃªtait parfois pour Ã©changer avec un ou une fan, sâ€™emparait dâ€™un tÃ©lÃ©phone pour prendre un selfie.
Elle a ainsi visitÃ© la rangÃ©e de fans de bout en bout ; en remontant sur scÃ¨ne pour chanter White Mustang, elle sâ€™excuse : Â« Un peu de sang, Ã§a ne vous dÃ©range pas ? Fini les ballades Ã©plorÃ©es avec Diet Mountain Dew, Summertime Sadness, la chanson titre de son dernier album et, Ã©videmment Video Games, clou de ce spectacle opposant la personnalitÃ© fragile et sophistiquÃ©e de la musicienne aux artifices dâ€™un Ã©vÃ©nement dâ€™une telle envergure.
En revanche, The War on Drugs Ã©tait taillÃ© sur mesure pour une telle scÃ¨ne. La bande Ã  Adam Granduciel, chanteur, preux chevalier de la guitare rock psychÃ©dÃ©lique, mÃ¨ne un orchestre devenu expert dans lâ€™art dâ€™installer un groove et de le propulser pendant sept, huit, dix, douze minutes.
Riche, planant, spontanÃ©, le son de lâ€™orchestre a inondÃ© les plaines avec ses chansons aux rÃ©fÃ©rences familiÃ¨res (Springsteen, Tom Petty), mais engraissÃ©es de nappes de synthÃ©s habilement Ã©tendues par Robbie Bennett. Mentionnons Ã©galement la contribution essentielle de Jon Natchez au saxophone basse et de la formidable Eliza Hardy Jones aux percussions, guitares, claviers et sourire rayonnant. The War on Drugs nâ€™a jouÃ© quâ€™une heure, sans gaspiller une minute de son temps de scÃ¨ne â€“ on en aurait pris davantage.
Enfin, une nouvelle tuile sâ€™est abattue sur lâ€™organisation du FEQ : pour des raisons mÃ©dicales, Patrice Michaud a dÃ» annuler le reste de sa tournÃ©e estivale, qui devait notamment le mener au Festif ! de Baie-Saint-Paul, au Festival en chanson de Petite-VallÃ©e, et sur une des scÃ¨nes du parc de la Francophonie ce dimanche. title: PrÃ©cieuse et paradoxale Lana del Rey sur les Plaines
content:
Pour un samedi soir de festival, lâ€™ambiance Ã©tait pour le moins dramatique sur les plaines dâ€™Abraham â€“ au bonheur des dizaines de milliers de fans de la diva amÃ©ricaine Lana del Rey, qui a offert une vingtaine de chansons en 90 minutes lors dâ€™une de ses rares apparitions en sol quÃ©bÃ©cois. Personne nâ€™a dansÃ©, ni fÃªtÃ© dâ€™ailleurs, communiant plutÃ´t avec la musicienne dans sa vision dâ€™une AmÃ©rique idÃ©alisÃ©e.
Au festival britannique Glastonbury il y a trois semaines, la diva a irritÃ© lâ€™auditoire en se pointant sur scÃ¨ne avec une bonne demi-heure de retard, la forÃ§ant Ã  amputer sa performance. Samedi soir dernier, la vingtaine de minutes de retard sur lâ€™horaire nâ€™Ã©tait pas un caprice : lâ€™Ã©quipe technique avait du pain sur la planche pour dÃ©barrasser lâ€™imposant Ã©quipement de scÃ¨ne des excellents The War on Drugs qui la prÃ©cÃ©daient (nous y reviendrons) et amÃ©nager le dÃ©cor de la musicienne comprenant, entre autres, un lampadaire, des arches, un piano Ã  queue Ã©rigÃ© sur une petite estrade, des balanÃ§oires et un arbre.
La poignÃ©e de concerts quâ€™elle avait donnÃ©s Ã  MontrÃ©al (le dernier Ã  Osheaga en 2016) ne nous avait pas laissÃ© une forte impression, del Rey nâ€™Ã©tant pas exactement une bÃªte de scÃ¨ne avec son filet de voix joli, juste, mais sans envergure. Une bÃªte, elle ne le fut pas davantage hier soir, mais voilÃ  tout le gÃ©nie de sa scÃ©nographie : ambitionner sur le dÃ©cor, lâ€™entourer de six trÃ¨s bonnes danseuses et de trois excellentes chanteuses gospel, sans compter ses quatre compÃ©tents musiciens de scÃ¨ne. La manoeuvre rÃ©ussit : pendant que tout ce beau monde sâ€™active, Lana Ã©clÃ´t prÃ©cieusement, chantant trÃ¨s bien mais trÃ¨s doucement (on perdait parfois sa voix dans lâ€™orchestre), dansant peu sinon avec inconfort.
VoilÃ  le paradoxe du phÃ©nomÃ¨ne Lana del Rey. RÃ©vÃ©lÃ©e par son deuxiÃ¨me album Born to Die grÃ¢ce aux magnifiques Blue Jeans et Video Games, portÃ©e aux nues Ã  titre dâ€™autrice-compositrice grÃ¢ce Ã  lâ€™album Norman Fucking Rockwell (2019), la musicienne est vÃ©nÃ©rÃ©e comme une icÃ´ne de la nouvelle chanson pop, mais sa chanson relÃ¨ve plutÃ´t du secret que lâ€™on garde pour soi, de lâ€™intime quâ€™elle installe entre elle et lâ€™auditeur. Elle serait Ã  sa place dans une petite salle sombre, mais son succÃ¨s la condamne aux grandes scÃ¨nes. Câ€™est tragique, au fond, mais cette tragÃ©die colle justement Ã  son personnage.
Sa chanson est une expÃ©rience intime, introspective, aux textes qui fantasment lâ€™AmÃ©rique, et particuliÃ¨rement la Californie, des annÃ©es 1950 et 1960. Une dÃ©tresse de vivre exprimÃ©e par des images ingÃ©nieuses et une voix Ã  fleur de peau qui semble nous chanter une vÃ©ritÃ© Ã©clairant les coins sombres de nos propres existences â€” rien, en somme, pour Ã©lectriser 80 000 spectateurs rÃ©unis par un beau samedi soir de juillet devant lâ€™une des plus grandes scÃ¨nes du QuÃ©bec.
Et pourtant, une magie opÃ¨re. La basse gronde pour A&W en ouverture, tirÃ©e de lâ€™album Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, paru plus tÃ´t cette annÃ©e. Del Rey porte une robe de mariÃ©e, ses choristes seront ses demoiselles dâ€™honneur, alors que les danseuses soulÃ¨vent son voile long comme un parachute pendant Young and Beautiful.
Â« Thank you so much Quebec ! Â», dit-elle avec un sourire quâ€™on ne lui voit jamais dans ses vidÃ©oclips lÃ©chÃ©s. Tout dâ€™un coup, lâ€™image de la diva sâ€™estompe, alors quâ€™elle nous raconte avoir grandi tout prÃ¨s dâ€™ici, Â« Ã  3 h 30 au sud du fleuve Â», dans les Adirondacks. Plusieurs fois durant le concert, elle sortira de son personnage pour offrir quelques mots sincÃ¨res aux festivaliers, qui en retour chanteront avec elle ses refrains les mieux connus.
Les autres, souvent chantÃ©s simplement accompagnÃ©s dâ€™un accompagnement de piano, de guitare diffuse et de cymbale, susciteront moins dâ€™intÃ©rÃªt. Durant les longs moments trop calmes des deux premiers tiers du concert, on entend trop les conversations entre spectateurs, parfois distraits par les chorÃ©graphies Ã©tudiÃ©es. Les favorites rompent les discussions : Chemtrails Over the Country Club, Pretty When You Cry, Born to Die, lâ€™excellente Blue Jeans nous faisant enfin comprendre quâ€™un authentique orchestre rock ayant de lâ€™aplomb lâ€™accompagne.
AprÃ¨s avoir interprÃ©tÃ© le rock langoureux Ultraviolence, Lana del Ray est descendue de son piÃ©destal pour aller saluer les fans tassÃ©s le long des clÃ´tures de sÃ©curitÃ©. Â» Quelque part dans son bain de foule, la musicienne sâ€™est Ã©raflÃ©e un genou. Le dernier droit du spectacle fut le plus dynamique. Fini les ballades Ã©plorÃ©es avec Diet Mountain Dew, Summertime Sadness, la chanson titre de son dernier album et, Ã©videmment Video Games, clou de ce spectacle opposant la personnalitÃ© fragile et sophistiquÃ©e de la musicienne aux artifices dâ€™un Ã©vÃ©nement dâ€™une telle envergure.
En revanche, The War on Drugs Ã©tait taillÃ© sur mesure pour une telle scÃ¨ne. La bande Ã  Adam Granduciel, chanteur, preux chevalier de la guitare rock psychÃ©dÃ©lique, mÃ¨ne un orchestre devenu expert dans lâ€™art dâ€™installer un groove et de le propulser pendant sept, huit, dix, douze minutes.
Riche, planant, spontanÃ©, le son de lâ€™orchestre a inondÃ© les plaines avec ses chansons aux rÃ©fÃ©rences familiÃ¨res (Springsteen, Tom Petty), mais engraissÃ©es de nappes de synthÃ©s habilement Ã©tendues par Robbie Bennett. Mentionnons Ã©galement la contribution essentielle de Jon Natchez au saxophone basse et de la formidable Eliza Hardy Jones aux percussions, guitares, claviers et sourire rayonnant. The War on Drugs nâ€™a jouÃ© quâ€™une heure, sans gaspiller une minute de son temps de scÃ¨ne â€“ on en aurait pris davantage.
Enfin, une nouvelle tuile sâ€™est abattue sur lâ€™organisation du FEQ : pour des raisons mÃ©dicales, Patrice Michaud a dÃ» annuler le reste de sa tournÃ©e estivale, qui devait notamment le mener au Festif ! de Baie-Saint-Paul, au Festival en chanson de Petite-VallÃ©e, et sur une des scÃ¨nes du parc de la Francophonie ce dimanche. title: Lana Del Rey e o letreiro de Hollywood
content:
Uma bolsa, um sapato e um casaco. Estavam jogados sob as famosas letras de Hollywood. Uma mulher que passava encontrou os objetos. Dentro da bolsa havia uma nota de suicÃ­dio. Longe das luzes da ribalta, um corpo.
Famoso letreiro de Hollywood Ã© visto de rua residencial de Hollywood, na CalifÃ³rnia, nos EUA - Robyn Beck/AFP Photo
Peg Entwistle era uma atriz galesa de talento. Encenou Ibsen e Shakespeare na Broadway e recebeu elogios da crÃ­tica e admiraÃ§Ã£o de Bette Davis, que declarou querer "ser como ela", numa inversÃ£o do papel que faria em "A malvada".
Um dos parceiros de palco da atriz deprimida, que nÃ£o resistiu Ã s dificuldades de entrar para o mundo do cinema, era um tal Humphrey Bogart, sempre com cigarro na mÃ£o e um drinque na outra.
O letreiro sobre as montanhas em Los Angeles existe hÃ¡ exatos cem anos. No sensacional "O Vendido" Paul Beatty compara o monumento a "antigas maravilhas da engenharia como o Partenon (...) e as grandes pirÃ¢mides."
O exagero irÃ´nico faz ainda mais sentido quando se sabe que as letras gigantes â€”hoje tÃªm cerca de 15 metros de altura e 137 de comprimentoâ€” antes indicavam um empreendimento imobiliÃ¡rio. O produtor Howard Hughes foi um dos compradores. DaÃ­ que o "Hollywood" era acrescido de "Land" â€”Hollywoodland. Muito comprido para caber no inconsciente coletivo.
O crescimento da indÃºstria cinematogrÃ¡fica na cidade abaixo tratou de espelhar o letreiro Ã  sua semelhanÃ§a, deixando apenas o nome do distrito onde ficavam alguns dos grandes estÃºdios e as estrelas que pavimentam a CalÃ§ada da Fama.
A atriz que pulou do "H" em 1932, aos 24 anos, virou mais uma atraÃ§Ã£o turÃ­stica, uma lenda lÃºgubre. Em "Lust for Life", Lana Del Rey, mencionando Entwistle, canta: "dizem que os bons morrem cedo". No clipe da canÃ§Ã£o, ela aparece no alto do letreiro de Hollywood, danÃ§ando com o parceiro The Weeknd e celebrando a vida ao mesmo tempo que se arrisca a cair.
Del Rey sempre flertou com o perigo. Aos 14 anos os pais a mandaram para um internato para que ela parasse de beber. Aparentemente nÃ£o funcionou, jÃ¡ que as bebidas, as drogas e charme indiscreto do hedonismo sÃ£o presenÃ§a constante em suas mÃºsicas. Uma delas, por exemplo, chama-se "Bartender".
Sua imagem Ã© calculadamente ligada ao glamour das grandes estrelas da Ã©poca de ouro de Hollywood. Os cabelos lembram Lana Turner, que inspirou o nome adotado (Del Rey veio de um automÃ³vel vintage.) E a figura esguia, de cintura fina e pernas longas, rima visualmente com belas taÃ§as de martini.
A sÃ©rie "Hollywood", em que os personagens sÃ³ param de tomar coquetÃ©is para respirar, Ã© uma festa dos sentidos e tambÃ©m se utiliza do centenÃ¡rio letreiro e do salto fatÃ­dico. Bem intencionada e um tanto sentimental, a ficÃ§Ã£o de Ryan Murphy muda o destino de Entwistle na hora H.
Ã‰ uma releitura politicamente correta dos bastidores do cinema, simpÃ¡tica, mas um tanto forÃ§ada e simplista. A despeito das falhas, torcemos muito para os personagens que enfrentam o racismo e a homofobia. Na abertura, eles sobem as letras que formam o sÃ­mbolo do cinema clÃ¡ssico. O sentido Ã© onÃ­rico e triunfante, de conquista dos holofotes.
Ambos com projetos ligados Ã  psicodelia de "Alice No PaÃ­s das Maravilhas", Lana Del Rey e Aldous Huxley, que morou numa casa sob o segundo "O", tÃªm visÃµes menos aÃ§ucaradas. Ela com sua melancolia suntuosa, ele abrindo as portas da percepÃ§Ã£o.


Bata os ingredientes primeiro a seco e depois com gelo. Coe para uma taÃ§a coupe gelada.

title: Lana Del Rey a envisagÃ© de tout arrÃªter
content:
Tom Holland a admis que la sobriÃ©tÃ© Ã©tait "la meilleure chose qu'il ait jamais faite" aprÃ¨s Ãªtre devenu "esclave" de l'alcool.
L'acteur de "Spider-Man" est sobre depuis plus d'un an maintenant, et il a parlÃ© en toute franchise de sa dÃ©pendance Ã  l'alcool lorsqu'il s'est rendu compte qu'il devait prendre un nouveau dÃ©part.
Lors de son passage dans l'Ã©mission "On Purpose with Jay Shetty", il a dÃ©clarÃ© : "J'Ã©tais vraiment accro Ã  l'alcool, je ne le cache pas du tout. Je pense que toute personne qui boit une biÃ¨re tous les jours a probablement un petit problÃ¨me."
Tom, 27 ans, "buvait et buvait et buvait et buvait" jusqu'au point de rupture, puis se rÃ©veillait le matin avec "un terrible mal de tÃªte".
Il se demandait : "Pourquoi suis-je esclave de cette boisson ? Pourquoi suis-je si obsÃ©dÃ© par l'idÃ©e de boire ? Avec le recul, je me suis rendu compte que j'allais Ã  des Ã©vÃ©nements pour le travail et que je ne pouvais pas m'amuser avant d'avoir bu quelques biÃ¨res, et je me sentais tellement sous pression."
Il a dÃ©cidÃ© d'arrÃªter l'alcool en relevant le dÃ©fi du "mois de janvier sec", puis en essayant d'Ã©tendre ce dÃ©fi au mois de fÃ©vrier, en essayant d'Ã©viter tout endroit oÃ¹ il y a de l'alcool.
Il a expliquÃ© : "J'avais l'impression de ne pas pouvoir Ãªtre sociable. J'avais l'impression que je ne pouvais pas aller au pub et prendre un soda au citron vert. Je ne pouvais pas sortir dÃ®ner. J'Ã©tais vraiment, vraiment en difficultÃ© et j'ai commencÃ© Ã  m'inquiÃ©ter que j'avais peut-Ãªtre un problÃ¨me d'alcool".
Cependant, Ã  l'approche de son anniversaire le mois dernier, il a pris un tournant et s'est fixÃ© pour objectif de passer "six mois sans alcool" afin de prouver qu'il n'avait pas de "problÃ¨me".
Il poursuit : "Et lorsque je suis arrivÃ© au 1er juin, je n'avais jamais Ã©tÃ© aussi heureux de ma vie... Je dormais mieux. Je pouvais mieux gÃ©rer les problÃ¨mes."

title: Lana Del Rey breaks silence over controversial Glastonbury show after turning up late to BST Hyde Park gig
content:
Love Glastonbury? From tickets to headliners, sign up here for the latest updates from Worthy Farm
Lana Del Rey has spoken about her controversial Glastonbury set for the first time since it happened last month. The American songstress caused quite a stir after turning up late to her headline show on the Other Stage at Worthy Farm, due to her hair taking 'so long to do'.
The Summertime Sadness singer was scheduled to perform at 10:30pm on Saturday, June 24, however she didn't make it out until 11:00pm - leaving fans waiting 30 minutes. Her much-anticipated headlining set was then cut short due to breaching the strict festival curfew, forcing organisers to turn her mic off.
Lana's set had been due to end at 11.45pm, but was still going on more than 15 minutes later. At the time, she told the crowd: "I was so f****** late that I am about to rush this set today, if they cut power, they cut power.
"I'm super f****** sorry, my hair takes so long to do. I love you all. Let's run the set as it's supposed to go, let's do it!" When midnight hit, her microphone was cut off and an advert for the festival's Arcadia stage appeared on stage as Skepta B2B Jammer's performance began.
Lana was escorted off after trying to keep the audience entertained by singing her hit single Video Games acapella as fans sung along. Fast forward to the weekend, the 38-year-old was scheduled to perform at this year's BST Hyde Park in London on Sunday night (July 9).
She was meant to head on stage at 8.40pm, but arrived 20 minutes late - not coming on until 9pm. After greeting the crowd and introducing her track Diet Mountain Dew, Lana joked: "I think this is where I got cut off last time. Sorry about that."
Moments before her final song Video Games played, she made another reference to her Glastonbury set, adding: "Itâ€™s worth it if the power is cut." The singer-songwriter went on to finish her set just before the 10:30pm curfew.
Ahead of her BST Hyde Park set, many fans took to Twitter to comment on whether she'll be late again or not. LDRbartender posted: "10:30 pm curfew tonight ! Hope Lana wonâ€™t be late." Buglass_michael put: "Lana del rey better be cracking on with her hair right now so that sheâ€™s not late and has to be cut off due to the strict London curfew."
While at the time of her show, Shgerber12 wrote: "Lana del rey late again smh [shake my head]." Lanasdivacup put: "Lana Del Rey is 5 minutes late to her long awaited concert," before going on to add: "Lana Del Rey is now 10 minutes late to her long awaited concert."

Mis en vente lundi 3 juillet, Ã  10 heures du matin, les 2 000 billets se sont Ã©coulÃ©s en quatre minutes, 420 000 personnes sâ€™Ã©tant connectÃ©es dans la file dâ€™attente en ligne dans lâ€™espoir dâ€™acheter une place (de 98 Ã  199 euros) pour ce concert intime (le reste des dates europÃ©ennes se partageant entre arÃ¨nes et festivals gÃ©ants). Dimanche 9 juillet, la veille du show, une colonne bien rÃ©elle dâ€™admirateurs sâ€™alignait cette fois boulevard des Capucines, campant la nuit jusquâ€™Ã  la rue Scribe dans lâ€™espoir dâ€™Ãªtre, le lendemain soir, dans les premiers rangs de lâ€™orchestre.
Cette ferveur, Lana Del Rey la doit Ã  sa raretÃ©, mais surtout Ã  une carriÃ¨re attisant lâ€™admiration. GrÃ¢ce Ã  son personnage de vamp fatale de la mÃ©lancolie, Ã  sa capacitÃ© Ã  faÃ§onner un univers visuel et musical alliant obsessions nostalgiques et dÃ©sillusion contemporaine. A sa faÃ§on de constituer une Å“uvre reconnaissable entre toutes, mais aussi de se renouveler, en sâ€™affirmant de plus en plus maÃ®tresse de son destin. Ses albums les plus rÃ©cents, Ã  lâ€™instar de Norman Fucking Rockwell ! (2019) ou du tentaculaire Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, paru en mars, nâ€™Ã©tant pas loin dâ€™Ãªtre ses plus passionnants.
Mythologies hollywoodiennes
Celle qui, il y a dix ans, sur cette mÃªme scÃ¨ne, surjouait le glamour dâ€™une starlette Ã  lâ€™Ã©trangetÃ© lynchienne, revient, Ã  38 ans, habillÃ©e dâ€™une longue et sage robe fleurie de blanc, vert et jaune, les cheveux sertis de bijoux. Entre prom queen des annÃ©es 1950 et princesse de conte de fÃ©es, elle semble beaucoup sâ€™amuser en meneuse de revue, entourÃ©e dâ€™un quatuor dâ€™instrumentistes, de trois choristes en strass argentÃ© et de six danseuses autant inspirÃ©es par le ballet classique, les cabarets de Las Vegas, les shows sixties de la Motown que par la gymnastique rythmique.

title: Lana Del Rey apologises for Glastonbury lateness after late arrival at BST
content:
A merican singer Lana Del Rey dazzled crowds at British Summer Time (BST) festival in London and apologised for arriving late to the stage, just weeks after her microphone was cut off at Glastonbury when her set overran because of her late arrival.
This time the star, 38, wrapped up her show a minute before Hyde Parkâ€™s 10.30pm curfew, despite arriving to the stage 17-and-a-half minutes late.
At Glastonbury in June, she led her fans in an acapella-style rendition of her hit Video Games after the power was cut from her mic when her set overran.
After arriving late on stage at Worthy Farm, she had told the audience â€œmy hair takes so long to doâ€ and said â€œif they cut power, they cut powerâ€.
She appeared to refer to that incident when at 10.05pm, five minutes before her set was due to finish and just after a rendition of Candy Necklace, she joked: â€œI think this is where I got cut off last time. Sorry about that.â€
Del Rey thanked the crowd and her musicians and said: â€œThank you so much London. My friends from Scotlandâ€¦ Thank you so much.
â€œThis was a second home for a very long time.
â€œYou guys basically made us what we were and allowed us to tour for the last 13 years.â€
Reaching into her back catalogue of hits, the singer kickstarted the night with a shortened version of the single A & W, from her latest LP Did You Know That Thereâ€™s A Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd (2023).
This was followed by the record Young And Beautiful, which appears on the soundtrack to 2013 film The Great Gatsby starring American actor Leonardo DiCaprio.
Floating across the stage in a flowery dress cinched with a white belt, the singer made her way to a table and chair and intermittently took puffs from her vape while someone made up her hair.
The stage was decorated with flowing white curtains attached to two golden doorways and a golden grand piano which stood centre stage atop a set of stairs painted the same colour.
The songstress was joined on stage by six dancers and three backing singers wearing dazzling glittery dresses.
She performed singles from a variety of albums including Blue Jeans, from studio album Born To Die (2012), and Ultraviolence, which was the title track from her third LP released in 2014.
The singer also discussed her latest record Did You Know That Thereâ€™s A Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd and told fans: â€œI absolutely love it, (the record) it came straight from the heart.â€
To finish, Del Rey sang her 2012 single Video Games and twirled around on a swing adorned with swathes of flowers.
Earlier on in the day, the artist had been supported by acts that included Australian rock band Gang Of Youths, pianist Riopy, London five-piece The Last Dinner Party and American musician Father John Misty, who stunned with high-octane performances of I Love You, Honeybear and The Ideal Husband.
Other US musical superstar headliners at BST festival this year included Pink, Billy Joel, Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, and Guns Nâ€™ Roses.

title: Lana Del Rey at BST Hyde Park
content:
Review at a glance
M idway through her headline set at Londonâ€™s Hyde Park, Lana Del Rey abandoned the stage to embrace fans on the front row, posing for selfies as she went. Moments earlier, sheâ€™d been sitting under a fairy light-adorned tree, playing with the glittering confetti that rained down from above, and singing about cult leaders. That ability to stride between otherworldly excess and fierce relatability has always been an important part of Del Reyâ€™s music and on Sunday night, it defined her 90-minute set.
Del Reyâ€™s delicately beautiful songs of bone-scratching heartache, quiet fury and rose-tinted escapism arenâ€™t typically suited for massive venues, and it had been six long years since she last played London. A 2020 arena tour was cancelled a week before it was set to kick off, and in the run-up to this Hyde Park gig, rumours swirled online that it was due to be pulled as well, after her Other Stage headline set at Glastonbury was abruptly cut short.
Still, if Del Rey had anything to prove, she didnâ€™t let it show. â€œGod damn, this is a big crowd,â€ she exclaimed after pulsating opening track A&W, while the lush Young & Beautiful saw her glancing around the mammoth venue and smirking whenever she saw a familiar face in the audience. By the time she sat down to get her hair redone by an onstage stylist while singing a soaring Bartender, Del Rey was clearly having a lot of fun. And she wasnâ€™t the only one.
Previous tours have been understated affairs, but a lot of care and attention was poured into the slick, choreographed show. The stage was decked out in gold, and Del Rey was joined by a four-piece band, a trio of backing singers and an array of dancers. Some songs were shortened, others were extended, but they were all met with screams. Despite the theatrics, there was a giddy chaos to the gig, Del Rey clambering on top of the piano for the pained Candy Necklace . A spiky Chemtrails Over The Country Club came with new, barbed lyrics aimed at an ex.
Elsewhere, a mid-set run of Born To Die and Blue Jeans was a powerful reminder of just how much of a game-changer her breakthrough 2012 album was, while the title track to 2023â€™s ninth album Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd was extended into a lush, gospel song. â€œEven if you get the power cut, itâ€™s worth it,â€ she smirked, knowing another curfew was fast-approaching, but refusing to rush.
Del Reyâ€™s always been seen as a cult concern but in recent months, sheâ€™s found a new audience on TikTok, while a collaboration with Taylor Swift on her Midnights album was so well-received, the pair went back into the studio to record an expanded version. As it stands, sheâ€™s the 31st most listened to artist on Spotify and it felt like all 60,000 people at Hyde Park were well-versed in her back catalogue.
Dusting herself off after Glasto-gate, Sunday nightâ€™s gig was an overdue victory lap, charged with playful defiance. Del Rey closed things out while gleefully sitting on a giant swing as she performed the aching Video Games. â€œItâ€™s only up from here,â€ she promised, looking very comfortable indeed.

title: Lana Del Rey annoys fans by turning up late to BST Hyde Park gig after being booed Glastonbury
content:
summertime sadness Lana Del Rey annoys fans by turning up late to BST Hyde Park gig after being booed Glastonbury
SINGER Lana Del Rey frustrated fans by turning up late to her BST Hyde Park gig - just weeks after being booed at Glastonbury.
Crowds moaned she hadn't turned up when her set was meant to start.
2 Lana Del Rey has turned up late again Credit: Getty
She had been originally billed to perform just after 8pm, but a message appeared on-screen informing fans her set would start at 8.40pm.
But the crowd was forced to wait another 20 minutes until she eventually performed.
One fan said: "Lana Del Rey late again."
Another joked: "Lana Del Late."
"Only 20 minutes late is this some sort of new record for Lana," said another.
Someone else said: "Lana, what's your excuse for being late this time?"
A fan added: "Can always count on Lana to be late."
Lana was half an hour delayed to headline The Other Stage at Glastonbury a fortnight ago.
The Summertime Sadness singer's set was then cut off at midnight because she had overrun.
She led a singalong with the crowd to finish her performance.
Lana was then escorted off my security in order to halt the gig.
After arriving on stage at Glastonbury, Lana apologised to fans.
She said: "I was so f***ing late that I am about to rush this set today. If they cut the power, then they cut power, then I'm super f***ing sorry.
"My hair take so long to do. Let's do the set as it's supposed to go."
