Lana Del Rey has been the final act of another hugely successful BST Hyde Park 2023, presented by American Express.
For its 10th anniversary year, legendary headliners including P!NK, Guns Nâ€™ Roses and Take That delivered unforgettable performances.

title: Electric Picnic: 15 of the most memorable moments, from a blistering Fontaines DCâ€™s set to Lana Del Reyâ€™s tears
content:
Itâ€™s almost time to set the table for another Electric Picnic â€“ the 18th, to be exact. The Picnic, which began life as a charmingly esoteric â€œboutiqueâ€ festival at Stradbally Estate in Co Laois, in 2004, has grown into a huge mainstream event headlined by some of the worldâ€™s biggest acts. Hereâ€™s our pick of the most memorable moments from almost two decades of Picnicking.
15. For Those I Love bring the feels
Electric arena, 2022
David Balfeâ€™s spoken-word electronic project was a vehicle for articulating his grief over the death of a friend. Photograph: Debbie Hickey/Getty
David Balfeâ€™s spoken-word electronic project was a vehicle for articulating his grief over the death of his friend Paul Curran, the poet and musician. The duo had attended Electric Picnic together, which made this performance by For Those I Love all the more emotional. What a rollercoaster it was, from joy to devastation, all illuminated by Balfeâ€™s memories of his hard-knock upbringing in the Dublin suburbs. â€œI can feel you in this room,â€ he said towards the end, talking both to the audience and to his dear friend.
14. The Cure play on and on
Main stage, 2012
In all, The Cure performed 39 tracks during the set. Photograph: Dave Meehan
The Cure werenâ€™t pandering to the lightweights among their fans when they pummelled through a three-hour set at Stradbally, chucking in the hits but playing lots of B-sides and obscurities too. It did go on and on â€“ to the point where you could nip off and enjoy a lean 40-minute performance by The Horrors in an adjoining tent and then return to The Cure without feeling that youâ€™d missed all that much. In all, they performed 39 tracks, starting with Plainsong, from Disintegration, and concluding â€“ a long time later â€“ with 10:15 Saturday Night and Killing an Arab.
[ Electric Picnic: Paolo Nutini to headline festival ]
13. Scary Ã‰ire say goodbye
Salty Dog Stage, 2019
A poignant 1am gig by the influential early-1990s Irish hip-hop crew became even more significant after the fact. They blitzed through a gangsta-influenced repertoire informed by their experiences of life on social welfare in that pre-Celtic Tiger purgatory when Ireland was poor and miserable. It would be a poignant Picnic farewell to remember, with founder member and MC Dada Sloosh (aka James Molloy) dying a few years later, in 2022. In the dark, in front of a devoted crowd, he and the rest of Scary Ã‰ire left us with something to remember.
READ MORE
12. Charli XCX is joined by Christine and the Queens
Electric arena, 2019
A rare Charli XCX performance in Ireland was elevated when HÃ©loÃ¯se Letissier, aka Christine and the Queens, appeared. Photograph: Dave Meehan
A rare Charli XCX performance in Ireland was elevated when her occasional collaborator HÃ©loÃ¯se Letissier, aka Christine and the Queens, guested on their single Gone. The only black mark is Charli continually saying, â€œHello, Dublin!â€ As Richard Ashcroft, late of The Verve, would declare from the main stage later that weekend, this was the time to be â€œunleashed in Laoisâ€. Still, it was a searing turn by Charli â€“ who also performed her Troye Sivan nostalgia juggernaut 1999 and even covered the Spice Girls.
[ â€˜There are always people complainingâ€™: Electric Picnic must ensure a feast for everyone in the audience ]
11. Fontaines DC storm the Body & Soul stage
2018
Fontaines DC were not yet on the radar when they played the arcadian Body & Soul stage. Photograph: Dave Meehan
Fontaines who? The Dublinersâ€™ early single Liberty Belle had come out just a year earlier and they were not yet on the radar when they played the arcadian Body & Soul stage. What a treat of a gig it was, with those in the know hearing early versions of Boys in the Better Land and Hurricane Laughter. Irelandâ€™s new stars had arrived. It was just that nobody knew it yet â€“ them least of all.
10. Julian Casablancas goes on a rant
Main stage, 2019
Julian Casablancas radiated a not-a-care-in-the-world energy. Photograph: Debbie Hickey/Getty
â€œHey, whatâ€™s with these fancy TVs?â€ the Strokes frontman said as the louche New Yorkers headlined Saturday night in 2019. He was referring to the new wraparound screens on either side of the Picnicâ€™s main stage. That wasnâ€™t important, however. What mattered was the not-a-care-in-the-world energy that Julian Casablancas radiated. On a nippy night, it warmed the cockles â€“ especially when he responded to chants of â€œOlÃ©, olÃ©, olÃ©â€ with a derisive, â€œWhat does it mean?â€
[ GardaÃ­ billed promoters more than â‚¬300,000 for policing Garth Brooks concerts and Electric Picnic ]
9. Sigridâ€™s secret gig
Other Voices stage, 2018
Sigrid was so overwhelmed that she started crying â€“ a moment that inspired the track Sight of You. Photograph: Dave Meehan
Sigrid, the Norwegian pop star, had fallen in love with rural Ireland when playing the Other Voices festival. The day she headlined the Electric arena she made her feelings plain with a secret performance at the Other Voices stage. Back at the arena, she was so overwhelmed that she started crying â€“ a moment that inspired the track Sight of You, on her second LP, How to Let Go.
8. King Kong Company close the Body & Soul stage
2019
Such was the interest in the final-ever gig at the Body & Soul arena that the gates had to be closed so the crowd stayed within capacity. Attendees were rewarded with a set of knockout electro-rock from the Waterford group.
7. Grace Jones turns up as the grim reaper
Main stage, 2015
Grace Jones said she was surprised it wasn't raining. Photograph: Dave Meehan
Taking to the stage to the strains of Nightclubbing, Grace Jones was dressed as the grim reaper until she tossed off her robes to reveal head-to-toe body paint. â€œI know my Jamaican accent sounds a bit Irish,â€ Jones says, followed by, â€œIâ€™m surprised itâ€™s not raining.â€
6. Beastie Boysâ€™ final Irish show
Electric arena, 2007
The Brooklyn rappers delivered a powerful performance at the Electric arena, concluding with the mosh-pit frenzy of Sabotage. Five years later, Adam Yauch, aka MCA, would die of cancer, aged 47. Beastie Boys disbanded and their Picnic set would take on a poignant note.
[ Lewis Capaldi cancels Electric Picnic gig, announcing break from touring â€˜for the foreseeable futureâ€™ ]
5. My Bloody Valentine stage a glorious return
Electric arena, 2008
Kevin Shields, the mercurial leader of the Irish-British shoegaze quartet, was spotted having a carvery lunch with his parents in Portlaoise the afternoon MBV headlined Electric Picnic. The dinner must have blown away the cobwebs as their concert was rafter-shaking and beautifully uncompromising. It was memorable for other reasons, too: 2008 was the last year of Electric Picnicâ€™s early incarnation as a collaboration between John Reynoldsâ€™ Pod group and Aiken Promotions.
4. Mark E Smith Discovers Mumford and Sons
Backstage, 2010
Mark E Smithâ€™s response to encountering Mumford and Sons backstage has gone down in the annals. Photograph: Niall Carson/PA
The Fallâ€™s 2010 set at the Picnic is not widely remembered. Mark E Smithâ€™s response to encountering Mumford and Sons backstage, however, has gone down in the annals. â€œThere was this other group warming up in the next sort of chalet and they were terrible,â€ he recalled. â€œI said, â€˜Shut them c**ts up,â€™ and they were still warming up so I threw a bottle at them. The band said, â€˜Thatâ€™s the Sons of Mumford or something. Theyâ€™re number five in charts!â€™ I just thought they were a load of retarded Irish folk singers.â€
3. Lana Del Rey cries
Main stage, 2016
The Video Games star has long had an intense relationship with Ireland, having been feted like royalty when she played Vicar Street in 2012. Four years later, headlining Sunday night at Electric Picnic, she became overwrought. Her tour had been long and she was growing ambivalent about stardom and its pressures. As the crowd sang back, the floodgates opened. â€œItâ€™s just heavy performing for people who really care about you and you donâ€™t really care that much about yourself sometimes. I thought it was sad. I thought my position was sad. I thought it was sad to be in Ireland singing for people who really cared when I wasnâ€™t sure if I did.â€
[ Plastic cups, disposable plates and a sea of abandoned tents: Can festivals ever be ecofriendly? ]
2. Arcade Fire knock the blocks off
Electric arena, 2005
Much like Billie Eilish in 2019, Arcade Fire had yet to fully cement their stardom when they played their first Irish show. They knocked the roof off the Electric arena in the early afternoon â€“ and later spoke of the show as transformative in their history. Their reputation has since been sullied because of reports about the behaviour of their singer, Win Butler. For 40 shining minutes 18 years ago, though, they were the most exciting band in the universe. And Electric Picnic discovered them first.
1. Billie Eilish draws a record crowd
Main stage, 2019
Billie Eilish drew a record main-stage crowd of more than 50,000 for her Friday-evening set. Photograph: Kieran Frost/Redferns
Billie Eilish wasnâ€™t even listed as a headliner when the festival line-up was first announced. She drew a record main-stage crowd of more than 50,000 for her Friday-evening set, though. It was emotional for Eilish â€“ whose real name is Billie Oâ€™Connell and is of Irish and Scottish heritage â€“ and even more so for the audience, including many teenagers and children who were overwrought as she high-kicked her way through her hits. â€œThat show was awesome,â€ Finneas, her brother and co-songwriter, would tell The Irish Times. Can they top it as they return to headline in 2023?

The Fallâ€™s 2010 set at the Picnic is not widely remembered. Mark E Smithâ€™s response to encountering Mumford and Sons backstage, however, has gone down in the annals. â€œThere was this other group warming up in the next sort of chalet and they were terrible,â€ he recalled. â€œI said, â€˜Shut them c**ts up,â€™ and they were still warming up so I threw a bottle at them. The band said, â€˜Thatâ€™s the Sons of Mumford or something. Theyâ€™re number five in charts!â€™ I just thought they were a load of retarded Irish folk singers.â€
3. Lana Del Rey cries
Main stage, 2016
The Video Games star has long had an intense relationship with Ireland, having been feted like royalty when she played Vicar Street in 2012. Four years later, headlining Sunday night at Electric Picnic, she became overwrought. Her tour had been long and she was growing ambivalent about stardom and its pressures. As the crowd sang back, the floodgates opened. â€œItâ€™s just heavy performing for people who really care about you and you donâ€™t really care that much about yourself sometimes. I thought it was sad. I thought my position was sad. I thought it was sad to be in Ireland singing for people who really cared when I wasnâ€™t sure if I did.â€
[ Plastic cups, disposable plates and a sea of abandoned tents: Can festivals ever be ecofriendly? ]
2. Arcade Fire knock the blocks off
Electric arena, 2005
Much like Billie Eilish in 2019, Arcade Fire had yet to fully cement their stardom when they played their first Irish show. They knocked the roof off the Electric arena in the early afternoon â€“ and later spoke of the show as transformative in their history. Their reputation has since been sullied because of reports about the behaviour of their singer, Win Butler. For 40 shining minutes 18 years ago, though, they were the most exciting band in the universe. And Electric Picnic discovered them first.
1. Billie Eilish draws a record crowd
Main stage, 2019
Billie Eilish drew a record main-stage crowd of more than 50,000 for her Friday-evening set. Photograph: Kieran Frost/Redferns
Billie Eilish wasnâ€™t even listed as a headliner when the festival line-up was first announced. She drew a record main-stage crowd of more than 50,000 for her Friday-evening set, though. It was emotional for Eilish â€“ whose real name is Billie Oâ€™Connell and is of Irish and Scottish heritage â€“ and even more so for the audience, including many teenagers and children who were overwrought as she high-kicked her way through her hits. â€œThat show was awesome,â€ Finneas, her brother and co-songwriter, would tell The Irish Times. Can they top it as they return to headline in 2023?

title: Billie Eilish: Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜Born to Dieâ€™ â€˜Changed Music for Girlsâ€™
content:
Without Lana Del Rey, there would be no Billie Eilish. While speaking with Dua Lipa for a recent episode of the At Your Service podcast, the 21-year-old â€œBad Guyâ€ singer shared that the 38-year-old Americana alt-pop crooner completely changed her outlook on music when she was growing up â€” particularly with 2012â€™s Born to Die.
â€œI feel that that album changed music,â€ Eilish told Dua of the sophomore album from Del Rey, who was the Visionary honoree for Billboardâ€˜s Women in Music 2023. â€œAnd especially changed music for girls and the potential of what is possible.â€
The seven-time Grammy winner also noted that Believe (2012) and Journals (2013) by Justin Bieber â€” â€œThatâ€™s my sâ€“tâ€ â€” Because The Internet (2013) by Childish Gambino and Wiped Out! (2015) by her ex-boyfriend Jesse Rutherfordâ€™s band The Neighbourhood as major influences on her life.
Eilish and Lipa both appeared on the soundtrack for Greta Gerwigâ€™s blockbuster Barbie film; in fact, both of their songs from the project, â€œWhat Was I Made For?â€ and â€œDance The Night,â€ respectively, were jousting for a U.K. No. 1 earlier this week. The two also chatted about growing up in the public eye and evolving as artists on Lipaâ€™s BBC podcast, with Eilish noting that â€œitâ€™s hard to acceptâ€ the ways making new music has changed or gotten more challenging as sheâ€™s gotten older.
â€œEverything is different about it,â€ the â€œHappier Than Everâ€ artist shared. â€œIâ€™ve been trying to compare recently, just because Iâ€™m getting used to doing it in a different way. And trying to be like, â€˜Itâ€™s OK to do that. Iâ€™m OK. Iâ€™m still able to do that, Iâ€™m capable still.â€™â€
â€œThe jump between 18 and 21 is a big jump,â€ she added. â€œJust mentally and physically, and realistically. Itâ€™s just been completely different.â€
Then, giving an update on the status of her upcoming third album, she shared that â€œFinneas and I are just â€” hate to say it â€” but only starting to hit our stride for this next album. But Iâ€™m feeling good about it. Iâ€™m not worried, really. Iâ€™m feeling pretty comfortable and confident and excited.â€
Listen to Eilishâ€™s full interview with Dua Lipa below:

title: Lana Del Rey, Billie Eilish, Coldplay, entre los artistas mÃ¡s escuchados en Spotify sobre canciones tristes
content:
La aplicaciÃ³n de mÃºsica creÃ³ una lista de reproducciÃ³n con mÃºsica triste para que los usuarios conecten con sus emociones. (Unsplash)
La GeneraciÃ³n Z estÃ¡ marcando un rumbo diferente en las tendencias de consumo de mÃºsica en plataformas como Spotify, quienes encontraron que el consumo de este estilo de contenidos estÃ¡ creciendo en la plataforma por diferentes motivos.
Durante los Ãºltimos meses, las canciones tristes no solo ocupan un lugar especial en los corazones de los oyentes de la GeneraciÃ³n Z, sino que tambiÃ©n lideran las listas de reproducciÃ³n mÃ¡s populares en la aplicaciÃ³n.
La plataforma de transmisiÃ³n de mÃºsica ha evidenciado un aumento notable en la bÃºsqueda del tÃ©rmino â€˜tristeâ€™ entre los oyentes de 11 y 26 aÃ±os a nivel global. Escuchando contenidos desde el pop infundido de melancolÃ­a hasta los tonos inspirados en el R&B, pasando por el rap emotivo.
La aplicaciÃ³n de mÃºsica creÃ³ una lista de reproducciÃ³n con mÃºsica triste para que los usuarios conecten con sus emociones. (Spotify)
â€œExiste algo verdaderamente Ãºnico en esta generaciÃ³n. Abrazan sus sentimientos de manera significativa y desafÃ­an el estigma de la vulnerabilidad. La GeneraciÃ³n Z ha aportado una realidad cruda y autÃ©ntica a la expresiÃ³n de sus emociones, y lo vemos reflejado en su forma de escuchar mÃºsicaâ€, asegurÃ³ Krista Scozzari, lÃ­der de marketing de Spotify en AmÃ©rica del Norteâ€.
La bÃºsqueda de pistas musicales que evocan nostalgia, perdida y deseos se ha convertido en una constante para los oyentes mÃ¡s jÃ³venes.
Sin embargo, es importante destacar que no todo gira en torno a canciones como â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ de Lana Del Rey. La diversidad de subgÃ©neros como el indie pop, el rap melancÃ³lico y el sad sierreÃ±o ha experimentado un crecimiento exponencial en el Ãºltimo aÃ±o, con artistas destacados como Phoebe Bridgers y Joji liderando el camino.
Otros artistas que destacan en esta tendencia son Billie Eilish, Frank Ocean, Big Thief, Olivia Rodrigo, Arctic Monkeys, Zach Bryan, Coldplay, Lewis Capaldi y Radiohead.
Lista de reproducciÃ³n triste en Spotify
Ante el crecimiento de este contenido, la aplicaciÃ³n creÃ³ la lista de reproducciÃ³n Bummer summer. Esta secciÃ³n, con 50 pistas, no solo busca destacar la influencia de las canciones tristes en la vida de las personas, sino tambiÃ©n normalizar la expresiÃ³n de las emociones humanas.
La mÃºsica triste va mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de una simple experiencia auditiva; tiene la capacidad de generar un impacto emocional profundo. El doctor Michael Bonshor, experto en psicologÃ­a de la mÃºsica, afirma que la mÃºsica triste puede ayudarnos a liberar y expresar nuestras emociones.
La aplicaciÃ³n de mÃºsica creÃ³ una lista de reproducciÃ³n con mÃºsica triste para que los usuarios conecten con sus emociones. (Spotify)
Las melodÃ­as lentas disminuyen la velocidad de la respiraciÃ³n y el ritmo cardÃ­aco, induciendo una sensaciÃ³n de relajaciÃ³n. â€œAdemÃ¡s de escuchar velocidades mÃ¡s lentas, escuchar mÃºsica con letras tristes crea una sensaciÃ³n de conexiÃ³n personal con los artistas que las escribieron; vÃ¡lida que nuestras experiencias humanas son compartidasâ€, dijo el experto.
De esta manera, las nuevas generaciones estÃ¡n generando una conexiÃ³n diferente con la mÃºsica, buscando encontrar un reflejo de sus emociones y verse reflejados en historias propias de los artistas o sentimientos que ellos plasmen, sin ser necesariamente algo triste o negativo.
â€œLa mÃºsica triste es algo que a veces se siente mejor que cualquier otra cosa. Existe una forma realmente poderosa en la que la letra y el tempo de la mÃºsica te permiten realmente reflexionar, sentir tus sentimientos. Es poderoso para las personas sin importar el estado de Ã¡nimo en el que se encuentrenâ€, concluyÃ³ Scozzari.
La lista de reproducciÃ³n Bummer summer ya se encuentra disponible en la plataforma de mÃºsica y se puede acceder a ella sin necesidad de ninguna suscripciÃ³n.

title: Jon Batiste on his awards glory: â€˜Overnight a lot of stuff changedâ€™
content:
On a Friday night at New York Cityâ€™s Brooklyn Steel, Jon Batiste is giddily dancing around the stage while blowing into a melodica, the handheld instrument that resembles a mini-keyboard. His new album, World Music Radio, came out earlier today and here in Williamsburg itâ€™s part-show, part-celebration. Naturally, Batiste is in characteristically high spirits.
Batiste is playing the albumâ€™s Stevie Wonder-influenced Calling Your Name, a two-minute song that he stretches into a roughly 15 minute freestyle during which he jumps into the audience and parades around before plucking four members from the crowd, ushering them on stage and having them take turns singing and dancing. Itâ€™s a unique spectacle composed of equal parts pop anthem and jazz freestyle, all delivered with a distinct flavor of his native New Orleans (his family is a fixture in the townâ€™s music scene and as a result Batiste has a penchant for leading theater crowds out into the street). It also demonstrates an artist at the intersection of a lifetime of performances on a litany of stages with a mainstream perch heâ€™s continually finding the apex of.
â€œThis might be your last chance to dance,â€ he proclaims into the microphone as the drummer taps his cymbal to a perky beat. â€œYou live once. This moment is once. This night is once. Thatâ€™s it.â€
That cheery attitude isnâ€™t an act. Offstage, Batisteâ€™s habit for seeing lifeâ€™s bigger picture is just as dominant in his mindset, seeping into everything he does. â€œMindfulness is such a big part of what I do,â€ he explained a couple days earlier in an interview. â€œParticularly with art, itâ€™s about the person transmuting their experiences. You canâ€™t make it if you donâ€™t live it. You canâ€™t be the thing youâ€™re aspiring to in your art, if youâ€™re not that as a person.â€
However Batiste sees himself and his art, it seems to be working judging by acclaim alone. Consider the recent evidence: last year, he won an Oscar, Bafta, and Golden Globe alongside Trent Reznor and Attitcus Ross for their score for the animated Disney hit Soul. A few months later, he followed that up with a Grammy win for album of the year, with Batiste the most nominated artist at last yearâ€™s ceremony. With that, he subsequently departed his seven-year-long gig as bandleader for Stay Human, the house band for The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, and dove headfirst into World Music Radio, a sonic victory lap that sounds like someone with the industry at his fingertips.
â€œOvernight a lot of stuff changed, but also a lot of stuff was in the making for years,â€ says Batiste of the Grammy win. â€œThe album is a culmination of a lot of things artistically, philosophically, and in my life.â€ One sign that Batiste was on that cumulative journey dawned on him as he was handed the album of the year Grammy from presenter Lenny Kravitz. A long-time supporter of Batiste who used to sit in with his band when he was still performing New York-area basement shows (â€œWe were always your favorite bandâ€™s favorite bandâ€), here he was receiving the biggest award in music from his mentor.
It was a nice moment, but Batiste has never chased his accolades. In fact, he has a mantra: the end result is not as important as the process. â€œI absolutely live by that,â€ he says. â€œI find that if you focus on the end result verses the process, it changes your state. Your state ultimately is the thing thatâ€™s most important, more than a melody.â€
But before he could dive head-first into World Music Radio, he reached a crossroads with The Late Show. After originally taking a temporary leave of absence last year, Colbert later announced on-air that he actually wasnâ€™t coming back after all (his band, Stay Human, would stay behind). And after the camaraderie the host and bandleader shared, there was no grand farewell and Batiste hasnâ€™t returned since.
â€œWhen the decision was mutually made for me to move forward, it was during the Late Showâ€™s longest break of the summer and I had already started working on World Music Radio,â€ he recalls of the roots of the albumâ€™s intense creative process which centered on Malibuâ€™s iconic Shangri-La studios. â€œSo when it came to the Late Show, the choice was to come back and do a farewell show or continue to record. So what we decided was that Iâ€™ll come back at some point.â€ Batiste notes that the ongoing writersâ€™ strike squashed any plan for him to come on to promote his current album. â€œMe and Stephen are friends for life. You donâ€™t go through something like that and not bond with the person who youâ€™ve been on stage with for seven years.â€
Stephen Colbert and Jon Batiste Photograph: CBS Photo Archive/CBS/Getty Images
Back in Shangri-La (appropriately run by fellow mindful-master Rick Rubin) Batiste exploded with creativity. He moved there for a period of months and embarked on a quest to create a musical world of â€œzero limitationsâ€.
â€œIt was about getting these ideas out of my unconscious mind, and we had engineers, musicians and producers rolling through 24/7 whenever I wanted to record or jam.â€ That also includes a starry list of featured artists who found their way onto the record from Lana Del Rey (a collaboration seven years in the making after a mutual friend set them up ) and Lil Wayne (they grew up not far from each other in New Orleans). Along the way, he perfected his sound, a singular one he dubs Social Music. â€œI never really adhered to genre, so I wanted to just name and define not only the music, but the philosophy behind it.â€
Batiste was already introspective growing up (he thinks it could be because he didnâ€™t speak until he turned 10), but his cheery demeanor and stunning success is continually put to the test watching the struggles of his wife, the 35-year-old writer Suleika Jaouad. They met when they were pre-teens, reconnected a decade later and have been devoted to each other since, including through Jaouadâ€™s multiple bouts of cancer. Right around the time Batiste became the Grammyâ€™s most nominated artist, Jaouad was re-diagnosed with leukemia, which sheâ€™s battled since she was 22. The two subsequently married last February, the day before she was scheduled to undergo a bone marrow transplant. For Batiste, it was a whiplash of lifeâ€™s extremes.
â€œSheâ€™s doing incredible,â€ he says of Jaouadâ€™s current prognosis. â€œSheâ€™s incredible how sheâ€™s able to do so much, while also coming out of such an invasive and deeply draining type of treatment.â€ Experiencing those high-highs and low-lows only served to cement Batisteâ€™s outlook. â€œUltimately the duality of life is perception,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s about knowing how to conduct the symphony of the life, with every section comes together, from the oboes to the strings. Sometimes it can get very intense. And you have to know how to reach your center, like a conductor conducts an orchestra. So what Iâ€™ve learned is to center yourself: where are those places, what are your practices and who are those people? Hold onto all of that, and use those things to conduct the best possible life that you can.â€
Back on stage at Brooklyn Steel Batiste is, no doubt, in one of the places that centers him. Still, after a nearly two-hour show, heâ€™s ready to call it a night.
â€œIâ€™ve loved the energy thatâ€™s in here right now,â€ he says into the mic as he begins to wrap-up. â€œIâ€™m so grateful for yâ€™all.â€

title: Taylor Swift roasts Jack Antonoff, Margaret Qualley at wedding
content:
Click to email a link to a friend (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
Taylor Swift made a raucous 15-minute speech at Jack Antonoff and Margaret Qualleyâ€™s wedding on Long Beach Island, NJ, Saturday night, we hear â€” and Lana Del Rey serenaded the newlyweds for their first dance.
Spies tell Page Six exclusively that Swift, 33, hilariously and lovingly â€œroastedâ€ the couple during her lengthy toast, and that Del Rey, 38, sang her tune about Qualley, â€œMargaret.â€
We hear that Swiftâ€™s speech included a crack about how she always thanks Antonoff, her frequent musical collaborator, in her awards show acceptance speeches â€” and that he never mentions her in any of his.
The Bleachers frontman has won eight Grammys, including Producer of the Year in 2022 and 2023, while Swift has taken home 12. They met in 2012 and have joined forces on multiple albums, including her 2022 smash, â€œMidnights.â€
Taylor Swift had the crowd in stitches during her toast at Jack Antonoff and Margaret Qualleyâ€™s New Jersey wedding, we hear. WavyPeter / SplashNews.com
Lana Del Rey sang her tune â€œMargaretâ€ at the nuptials, sources say. Peter Cruz / SplashNews.com
The couple married Saturday night in a starry ceremony. Daniel William McKnight for Page Six
Also at the party, we hear that a tattoo artist was on hand to ink permanent memories of the occasion.
Spies say that speakers at the wedding reception also included the bride and groomâ€™s parents, Andie MacDowell, Paul Qualley, and Rick Antonoff and Shira Antonoff and siblings Rainey Qualley, Justin Qualley and Rachel Antonoff, as well as â€œBrittany Runs a Marathonâ€ filmmaker Paul Downs Colaizzo.
Communications strategist and close friend of the couple Andy Snyder officiated the proceedings, we hear.
Swift joked about her many awards with Antonoff during her speech, we hear. WavyPeter / SplashNews.com
Mark Seed â€” who coordinated Jennifer Lawrenceâ€™s 2019 wedding to Cooke Maroney â€” planned the star-studded event, where A-list guests also included Cara Delevingne, Channing Tatum and ZoÃ« Kravitz, The 1975 drummer George Daniel and â€œReal Housewives of New York Cityâ€ star Jenna Lyons.
Del Reyâ€™s â€œMargaretâ€ features Antonoffâ€™s band Bleachers.
The â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ singer, who received backlash for wearing white to the nuptials, previously told Rolling Stone in an interview that the song â€œcould hypothetically be played at their wedding.â€
Del Rey once said her song â€œMargaretâ€ could be played at Antonoff and Qualleyâ€™s wedding. Page Six
Swift also reunited with former â€œgirl squadâ€ member Delevingne, 31, at the ceremony.
We reported that the superstar pals spent three hours inside Shore hotspot Bird & Bettyâ€™s, where they danced and watched the newlyweds cut their cake.
Antonoff and Qualley have been a couple since 2021.

content:
