title: Jack Antonoff and Margaret Qualley wedding: Celebrity guests
content:
Music producer Jack Antonoff and actor Margaret Qualley were wed over the weekend.
Record producer Jack Antonoff and actor Margaret Qualley were far from the only stars at their New Jersey wedding over the weekend.
The Bleachers frontman and the â€œMaidâ€ star tied the knot Saturday at Parkerâ€™s Garage on Long Beach Island, according to TMZ. Celebrity attendees included a mix of Qualleyâ€™s actor peers and Antonoffâ€™s musical collaborators, from Taylor Swift and Lana Del Rey to â€œHereditaryâ€™sâ€ Alex Wolff.
Antonoff, 39, and Qualley, 28, wed a little over a year after getting engaged in May 2022, per People magazine. The Grammy winner and the Emmy nominee have reportedly been together for about two years.
Hereâ€™s a sampling of the famous guests who were spotted celebrating the happy couple before, during and after the ceremony.
Advertisement
Cara Delevingne
Model and actor Delevingne was photographed arriving at the event in a black jumpsuit. She was among the attendees who found herself surrounded by a crowd of fans while interacting with arguably the coupleâ€™s most prominent guest, Swift.
Lana Del Rey
Del Rey was spotted strolling around the venue in a lacy mini-dress and white sweater. The singer has collaborated with Antonoff on several projects â€” including the song â€œMargaret,â€ which features his band, Bleachers.
â€œMargaretâ€ was inspired by Qualley, who shut down a rumor earlier this year that the lyrics revealed her wedding date.
â€œShe was kind enough to not put my real wedding date in the song,â€ Qualley told the Los Angeles Times.
â€œBut I love that song so much. It makes me feel like Iâ€™m living in a dream. Sheâ€™s my favorite poet. I adore her.â€
Advertisement
ZoÃ« Kravitz and Channing Tatum
Kravitz was seen attending the wedding with her boyfriend and fellow actor, Tatum. The â€œBatmanâ€ star wore a long, black sleeveless dress to the reception, while the â€œMagic Mikeâ€ heartthrob donned a gray blazer and black pants.
Kravitz â€” like her father, Lenny Kravitz â€” is also a musician, and Antonoff is producing her upcoming solo album, according to Elle magazine.
Andie MacDowell
Also in attendance, of course, was Qualleyâ€™s mother and fellow actor, MacDowell. The â€œGroundhog Dayâ€ star arrived at the event in an elegant, blue gown with a palm-frond pattern.
Rainey Qualley
MacDowell and Qualley arenâ€™t the only members of their family who have caught the acting bug. Margaret Qualleyâ€™s older sister, Rainey Qualley, has appeared in several films such as â€œUltrasoundâ€ and â€œOceanâ€™s Eight.â€
She wore a long, brown dress while accompanying the bride to some of her wedding festivities.
Sarah Ramos
Actor Ramos was spotted at Qualley and Antonoffâ€™s rehearsal dinner on Friday, according to Us Weekly. She and Qualley have both appeared in the charitable TV series, â€œActing for a Cause.â€
Taylor Swift
Easily attracting the most attention during the celebration was Swift, who showed up to the rehearsal dinner, wedding and reception shortly after completing the first United States leg of her sold-out Eras tour at Los Angelesâ€™ SoFi Stadium. She wore a delicate, baby-blue dress to the ceremony.
The pop sensation has worked with Antonoff for nearly a decade on multiple records, including â€œMidnights,â€ â€œEvermoreâ€ and â€œFolklore,â€ which won album of the year at the 2021 Grammy Awards. Swift also has a lesser-known connection to Qualley: The latter starred opposite the singer-songwriterâ€™s ex-boyfriend, Joe Alwyn, in the 2022 film â€œStars at Noon.â€
â€œâ€˜Midnightsâ€™ is a wild ride of an album and I couldnâ€™t be happier that my co pilot on this adventure was @jackantonoff,â€ Swift wrote on Instagram in October.
â€œâ€˜Midnightsâ€™ actually really coalesced and flowed out of us when our partners (both actors) did a film together in Panama. Jack and I found ourselves back in New York, alone, recording every night, staying up late and exploring old memories and midnights past.â€
Mae Whitman
Actor Whitman attended Fridayâ€™s rehearsal dinner, Us Weekly reported. She is known for her work in movies and TV series such as â€œThe Perks of Being a Wallflowerâ€ and â€œParenthood.â€
Alex Wolff
The â€œHereditaryâ€ star was photographed leaving Qualley and Antonoffâ€™s wedding reception. Qualley reportedly dated Wolffâ€™s older brother, Nat, also an actor, for a brief period after working with him on the 2013 movie â€œPalo Alto.â€
Qualley and Alex Wolff are also both credited on â€œActing for a Cause.â€

title: New Celebrity College Courses to Put Your Knowledge to the Test
content:
With college becoming more and more expensive, it's important to choose the right course for you. So, pop culture fans will be pleased to know there's a range of celebrity-inspired classes out there.
Whether you're a die-hard Swifty or a Yeezy fan, put your knowledge to the test with these five super star-themed college coursesâ€”some of which you can enroll in right now.
Psychology of Taylor Swiftâ€”Advanced Topics of Social Psychology
On August 10, Arizona State University announced it will be offering a course on record-breaking singer Taylor Swift later this year.
Led by social psychologist Alexandra Wormley, the class examines Swift's seven albums, each linked to a topic within social psychology.
"For example, when we talk about Lover, we'll talk about romantic relationships and love," Wormley told Newsweek.
"How do we define it? Are romantic relationships good for us? How do they help us achieve goals?"
Taylor Swift performing onstage during "The Eras Tour" at SoFi Stadium, California, on August 9, 2023. Getty Images Entertainment
Students are required to read scientific articles on the subject prior to class, where they will apply them to the 33-year-old pop icon's work. There will also be discussions on how rumors are spread and whether a person's music preference can predict their personality.
"I am incredibly excited to engage with students in such a creative environmentâ€”after all, this class was designed by my students last year," Wormley said.
"They have grown up alongside Taylor Swift, and after COVID-19, they're ready for a classroom environment that is fun and interesting while still being academically rigorous."
Harry Styles and the Cult of Celebrity: Identity, the Internet and European Pop Culture
Since leaving his boyband days behind, former One Direction singer Harry Styles has undergone quite the rebrand. According to course instructor Louie D. Valencia, Texas State University students will explore the 29-year-old singer-songwriter's art and dedicated fandom, and how it relates to modern life.
"In the same way that The Beatles can tell us something about the 1960s, studying the art of Harry Styles gives us insight into the world that we live in today," the associate professor told Newsweek.
Harry Styles attends The BRIT Awards 2023 at The O2 Arena in February 2023. Styles has rebranded himself since his boyband days, with Texas State University offering a course on his career. Jo Hale/Redferns
The class will examine topics such as celebrity culture, social change, bodily autonomy, consumerism and the environment, among others, using Style's music as a touchstone.
"We've used celebrities to tell the tale of who we are as a people for millennia," Valencia said.
"I think courses like this show that the issues that matter to young people are important."
The class ran for the first time in spring 2023 and filled up within the first minute of registration. Fortunately, students who missed out the first time can enroll in 2024.
Nicki Minaj â€” Black Barbie Femmecee & Hip-Hop Feminisms
The 40-year-old rapper may be a divisive figure, but you can't deny the impact Minaj has had on pop culture over the last decade. In this class run by UC Berkeley professor Peace and Love El Henson, students examine Minaj's career in both the context of hip-hop and feminism.
Iâ€™d love to stop by â€” Nicki Minaj (@NICKIMINAJ) October 6, 2022
Responding to a tweet about the course, which was announced in October 2022, Minaj said she'd "love to stop by." The post delighted fans and Henson, who told the star: "We would be hella happy & honored for u to stop by!"
Topics in Recorded Music: Lana Del Rey
In September 2022, New York University announced a new course focusing on pop star Lana Del Rey. Led by journalist Kathy Iandoli, the class explored the 38-year-old's contribution to music, her influences, and the impact she has had on other artists.
However, two-credit course also examined the Born to Die singer's relationship with social issues (and her controversial comments), including feminism, Black Lives Matter and #MeToo.
Lana Del Rey at the 24th annual Elton John AIDS Foundation's Oscar viewing party on February 28, 2016. A course at New York University explores Del Rey's work in relation to various social issues. Getty Images Entertainment/Jason LaVeris
"In so many ways, I feel like Lana Del Rey is both a blueprint and a cautionary tale," Iandoli told Variety.
"A complicated pop star who resonates so much with her fans, not because of how she makes them feel about her, but rather how she makes them feel about themselves."
Kanye vs Ye: Genius by Design
Minaj isn't the only rapper to have a college course dedicated to their art. In autumn 2022, Concordia University in Montreal, Canada, ran a course dedicated to Kanye West.
Led by professor Yassin "Narcy" Alsalman, who is also a rapper, the class used the 46-year-old hitmaker's work as a jumping-off point for discussions on music, fashion, social issues and activism.
"This class isn't only about Kanye," Alsalman wrote on Instagram. "It's about community, creativity, responsibility, accountability, fame and mental health, dreams and nightmaresâ€” and more importantly, self-actualization."

title: Jon Batiste Got Lil Wayne to Pick Up His Guitar Again
content:
Photo: Naht Jona, LLC
Lil Wayne revealed earlier this year that he couldnâ€™t pick his hitmaking album Tha Carter III out of a lineup. â€œI believe that [God] blessed me with this amazing mind, but would not give [me] an amazing memory to remember this amazing shit,â€ he told Rolling Stone. One thing Wayne does remember, though: how to play guitar. Weezy picked up the axe over a decade ago, first as a trick during his live shows, and then to pivot to rock for his 2010 album Rebirth. Now, heâ€™s back to rip a solo for his fellow Louisianan Jon Batiste, on â€œUneasy,â€ off Batisteâ€™s new album, World Music Radio. Itâ€™s only a simple, 30-second ditty, coming in the middle of a John Legendâ€“y interlude toward the end of the song. Still, weâ€™d say Wayne has a better chance of remembering that than the verse he dropped here.
Somehow, Lil Wayne playing guitar may not be the most chaotic thing on WMR, Batisteâ€™s first album since his Grammy hit We Are. Thereâ€™s an Afrobeats linkup with Fireboy DML, a sax solo from Kenny G, and another collab with Lana Del Rey after they linked up earlier this year on Del Reyâ€™s Ocean Blvd. What takes the cake, though, is â€œBe Who You Are,â€ a song that features rising K-pop group NewJeans, Colombian singer-songwriter Camilo, and breakout Dreamville rapper J.I.D. Yeah, youâ€™ve just gotta hear that one for yourself too.

title: La impactante caÃ­da masiva en efecto dominÃ³ que sufrieron los fans de Lana del Rey durante su concierto en MÃ©xico
content:
Siete aÃ±os mÃ¡s tarde de la Ãºltima visita de Lana del Rey a MÃ©xico por motivo de su participaciÃ³n en el festival Corona capital, la artista indie mÃ¡s internacional ha regresado por todo lo alto al paÃ­s azteca.
Esta vez, con dos rotundos sold out en las dos fechas que anunciÃ³ en el Foro Sol, uno de los recintos mÃ¡s grandes del paÃ­s.
Sin embargo, la que tendrÃ­a que haber sido una noche de ensueÃ±o para los 65.000 asistentes que acudieron el pasado martes al primero de los conciertos que ofreciÃ³ la cantante de Summertime sadness, terminÃ³, inesperadamente, en una fatalidad. Y es que, en mitad del espectÃ¡culo, una caÃ­da masiva de los espectadores sembrÃ³ el caos dentro del Foro Sol mexicano.
Al parecer, este inexplicable incidente sucediÃ³ mientras Lana del rey interpretaba el tema Prety when you cry, perteneciente a su disco Ultraviolence, en la secciÃ³n A del recinto. De pronto, varios de los asistentes comenzaron a caerse de adelante para atrÃ¡s, en un peligroso efecto dominÃ³, que dejÃ³ a los Ãºltimos aplastados por una oleada de personas.
Several fans at Lana Del Reyâ€™s show in Mexico got knocked over due to a â€˜domino effectâ€™ wave in the audience. pic.twitter.com/nPbnQgRrnu â€” Pop Base (@PopBase) August 17, 2023
En algunos de los vÃ­deos compartidos por los propios afectados en redes sociales, se puede ver cÃ³mo los asistentes todavÃ­a coreaban la canciÃ³n cuando comenzaba esta caÃ­da masiva. No obstante, en cuestiÃ³n de segundos, los cÃ¡nticos se transformaron en gritos y ataques de pÃ¡nico y, posteriormente, tambiÃ©n en heridos. Actualmente, se calcula que al menos 15 personas resultaron gravemente lesionadas durante el incidente.
SegÃºn una usuaria de Twitter -ahora llamado X- que asistiÃ³ al concierto, la caÃ­da podrÃ­a haberse producido tras una pelea entre un hombre que intentaba colarse a gatas para acercarse al escenario y un grupo de asistentes, que, entre empujones, terminÃ³ perdiendo el equilibrio y provocando una reacciÃ³n en cadena.
se parÃ³ como 10 personas frente a mi y otras personas comenzaron a pelearse con Ã©l y de alguna manera acabÃ³ en el piso; no sÃ© si llegaron a patearlo o si lo tiraron pero generÃ³ que muchas personas se cayeran al suelo + â€” pauchisss (@urfavpauuu) August 16, 2023
Desde entonces, ha habido varios seguidores de Lana del rey que han seÃ±alado directamente a la empresa encargada de organizar el evento, Ocesa, debido a su mala gestiÃ³n del suceso. Y es que, no solo habÃ­a una falta de protocolo de ayuda, sino que, segÃºn relatan estos internautas, el personal de seguridad no hizo nada, hasta que no se les comunicÃ³ que habÃ­a gente lesionada.
Lana del rey se encuentra con Mon Laferte
Entre concierto y concierto, Lana del rey tambiÃ©n ha aprovechado su corta estancia en MÃ©xico para codearse con algunos de los artistas mexicanos mÃ¡s importantes. Este ha sido el caso de Mon Laferte, quien no quiso perderse el concierto de la cantante y, en el backstage, ha intercambiado halagos con ellas. "Yo tambiÃ©n te amo", respondÃ­a Lana en un intento de espaÃ±ol.

title: Jon Batiste Unleashes â€˜World Music Radioâ€™: Stream It Now
content:
Jon Batisteâ€™s talents as a bandleader are on show once again with World Music Radio, the U.S. musicianâ€™s collaboration-jammed new album.
The multi-hyphenate, Grammy Award-winning artist dropped World Music Radio at the stroke of midnight, an LP that clocks-in at more than one hour and features assists from Lana Del Rey, Lil Wayne, Kenny G and others.
â€œWorld Music Radio is a concept album that takes place in the interstellar regions of the universe,â€ Batiste explained earlier in June, with the announcement of the new studio effort. â€œThe listener is led through the album by an interstellar traveling griot named Billy Bob Bo Bob, who takes you sonically all around the world at the speed of light.â€
In addition to Del Rey, Lil Wayne, and Kenny G, the album boasts guest spots with Jon Bellion, Fireboy DML, J.I.D., NewJeans, and is executive produced by Batiste, Bellion and Ryan Lynn.
â€œI couldnâ€™t be prouder of this project. Iâ€™m so grateful to all my collaborators,â€ he says in a new piece-to-camera, posted at launch.
World Music Radio arrives two years after Batiste made history as the first Black artist to win the Grammy for album of the year in 14 years, when he triumphed in the category for his genre-spanning We Are.
He was nominated for 11 awards at the 2022 Grammys, more than any other artist, winning a total of five on the night, adding to a collection that already boasts an Academy Award for best original score thanks to his work on 2020â€™s Soul alongside Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross of Nine Inch Nails.
Batiste is familiar to millions of night-owls as the former bandleader on The Late Show With Stephen Colbert, which he exited last year after seven seasons to focus on his work.
The jazz master has landed two titles on the Billboard 200: 2014â€™s Social Music (No. 134, as Jon Batiste & Stay Human) and 2021â€™s We Are (No. 25).
Stream World Music Radio below.

title: Jon Batiste: World Music Radio review - safety-first global pop from a jazz superstar
content:
You might have imagined that Jon Batisteâ€™s triumph at the 2022 Grammy awards would be greeted with delight. He won more gongs than anyone else: five in total, becoming the first Black artist to win album of the year, for 2021â€™s We Are, in 14 years. Here was a virtuoso musician who existed on the margins of the mainstream â€“ best-known as the bandleader on Stephen Colbertâ€™s talkshow and the author of the â€œuser-friendly jazz songsâ€ from the Disney film Soul â€“ hoisted into the spotlight by dint of his talent alone.
Jon Batiste - World Music Radio album cover. Photograph: PR
Instead, his success was more ambivalently received. Batiste, the naysayers suggested, was was a safe choice, more redolent of the past than the musical present. We Are had abandoned the traditionalist jazz found on his previous album, 2018â€™s Hollywood Africans, in favour of soul with a distinct retro flavour. Batiste, one writer complained, wasnâ€™t â€œsomeone at the forefront of this centuryâ€™s defining hip-hop and R&B soundsâ€.
Listening to World Music Radio, you wonder whether that criticism lodged with Batiste, whether he was keen to use his increased profile â€“ in addition to his Grammy haul, the Soul OST won him an Oscar and a Golden Globe â€“ as a platform to reach a wider audience, or if he is just unwilling to repeat himself. For whatever reason, We Areâ€™s follow-up is a markedly different beast to its predecessor. It posits Batiste as a very 21st century kind of artist: pop-facing, unafraid of things that Julliard-trained jazz musicians tend to look askance at, among them AutoTune and cravenly manufactured pop. Instead of Trombone Shorty and Mavis Staples, it features K-pop quartet NewJeans, Lana Del Rey and Leigh-Anne Pinnock of Little Mix, part of a supporting cast required to fulfil Batisteâ€™s vision of modern pop, one in which music from the US, east Asia, Africa and South America forms a kaleidoscopic whole.
Itâ€™s at this point you might find yourself suggesting he hangs on a minute: isnâ€™t that what the pop charts are already like? This is an era in which Nigerian Afrobeats, K-pop, hip-hop and Latin American reggaeton happily coexist in the Top 20. Itâ€™s an argument underlined by the fact that virtually all Batisteâ€™s guests are already stars: NewJeansâ€™ last EP made No 1 in the US; Colombian singer Camilloâ€™s 2021 album Mis Manos went double platinum and won a Grammy.
Jon Batiste: Drink Water ft Jon Bellion and Fireboy DML â€“ video
Itâ€™s also underlined by some of the music on World Radio. The early tracks Raindance and Be Who You Are variously involve Camillo, NewJeans, South African Ampiano producers Native Soul and Atlanta rapper JID, which seems an awful lot of eclectic talent to engage in making amiable beach bar pop-reggae. It is not the last time you find yourself listening to something that sounds remarkably familiar: big-room pop EDM (Worship), the clipped mid-80s electropop-inspired sound that underpinned Ed Sheeranâ€™s Bad Habits and Harry Stylesâ€™ As It Was (Calling Your Name), epic ballads in piano, synth-based, Lana Del Rey-ish forms (Butterfly, Running Away and the Del Rey-featuring Life Lesson respectively). Itâ€™s worth noting that the songs are tightly written and hooky, but it is hard to see exactly what Batiste is bringing to the table: even the albumâ€™s radio show concept, complete with between-song announcements by a DJ, is pretty well-worn.
But equally, there are points when something original sparks. My Heart is fantastic, a fragmented, lo-fi track where Rita PayÃ©sâ€™ Spanish-language vocals and trombone collide with a doo-wop-inspired melody and a jazz trumpet solo. Boom for Real stirs together a disco beat with a vaguely yacht rock-esque song, coats both in distortion and throws in 30 seconds of Batisteâ€™s atonal piano improv and melodica. The ramshackle country rock and drawled sprechgesang vocals of Master Power is great, and it is hard not to smile at the middle finger to the jazz establishment that is easy listening star Kenny G soloing away on Clair de Lune.
The highlight is Uneasy: a more fractured, electronic take on We Areâ€™s neo-soul style, synthesisers weaving around Batisteâ€™s falsetto vocal. Thereâ€™s a fabulous moment when Lil Wayne takes over the microphone, and everything else drops out except the beat and Batisteâ€™s piano, which slowly shifts from accompanying the rapper to battling him for space, becoming ever-more jagged and jarring.
skip past newsletter promotion Sign up to Sleeve Notes Free weekly newsletter Get music news, bold reviews and unexpected extras. Every genre and from every era Privacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Privacy Policy . We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. after newsletter promotion
It is fresh and daring â€“ and you wish there were more moments like it. If pop has a problem in 2023, it is not a lack of geographical diversity, but a paucity of new ideas. World Music Radio proves that Jon Batiste is capable of coming up with them. They seem to arrive when he sounds most like himself: an artist with jazz background, a deep knowledge of musical history and an iconoclastic streak. It also proves he is capable of sublimating his own individuality to fit in;when it tries too hard, it simply adds to the slush pile of nondescript pop.
This week Alexis listened to
RÃ³isÃ­n Murphy â€“ What Not to Do (Moodymann Remix)
Releasing a remix of a song before the song itself is odd, but Moodymannâ€™s reworking of a highlight from Murphyâ€™s forthcoming album is more a complete reinvention: decorated with his own vocals, a subtle, jazzy slink.

title: Jon Batiste, el mÃºsico que derrotÃ³ a Taylor Swift en los Grammy: â€œMi nuevo disco es como â€˜El padrino 2â€
content:
Hace quince aÃ±os, la primera vez que Jon Batiste visitÃ³ EspaÃ±a con la banda de Cassandra Wilson, era poco mÃ¡s que una gran promesa del jazz: un pianista de 21 aÃ±os, con apellido ilustre para los conocedores de los Ã¡rboles genealÃ³gicos de la tradiciÃ³n en su Nueva Orleans natal, aunque desconocido para la mayorÃ­a, que brillaba con un talento inmenso cada vez que acercaba los dedos al teclado. Hoy, Batiste (Louisiana, 36 aÃ±os) es mucho mÃ¡s que un mÃºsico brillante. Se ha convertido en un icono, uno de los grandes referentes de la cultura negra en Estados Unidos y, en definitiva, en algo que ningÃºn jazzista, por mucho talento que tenga, aspira a ser: una superestrella.
MÃ¡s informaciÃ³n El dolor y la gloria de Jon Batiste, el nuevo faro mundial de la mÃºsica negra
A lo largo de la pasada dÃ©cada, Batiste pasÃ³ de buscarse la vida y autoeditar sus discos a protagonizar una espiral de hitos que lo han llevado hasta lo que es hoy: de aparecer en algunos episodios de la serie Treme a fichar con su grupo Stay Human como banda residente en el televisivo The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, firmar con el sello Verve y crecer Ã¡lbum a Ã¡lbum o explotar definitivamente con su participaciÃ³n en la pelÃ­cula de Pixar Soul y con su Ã¡lbum We Are, un colosal catÃ¡logo de influencias negras, del jazz al soul o hip hop. Aparte de ganar el Oscar y el Globo de Oro con la banda sonora de la pelÃ­cula, el aÃ±o pasado acumulÃ³ un total de 11 nominaciones en los Grammy y ganÃ³ cinco premios, incluido uno extremadamente relevante y representativo: el de Ãlbum del AÃ±o con We Are, batiendo a gigantes del pop como Billie Eilish, Taylor Swift o Justin Bieber.
Jon Batiste actuando el pasado 5 de agosto en en Jazz Festival de Newport (Estados Unidos). Boston Globe (Boston Globe via Getty Images)
Llegados a este punto, estÃ¡ claro que Batiste ya no es solo un brillante mÃºsico de jazz, sino un artista transversal que se nutre de todo tipo de mÃºsicas y que se dirige a audiencias masivas. AsÃ­ lo sentencia su nuevo Ã¡lbum, World Music Radio (se publica el 18 de agosto), con el que da un salto apabullante hacia el pop global, apoyado en un sonido contemporÃ¡neo y radiable, con la firme intenciÃ³n de no renunciar a una visiÃ³n y concepto artÃ­sticos, tal y como el artista cuenta a EL PAÃS por videollamada: â€œSiempre he intentado coger todo lo que sÃ© y me ha inspirado, y crear una versiÃ³n personal que sintetice todo ello en algo nuevo. Pero si hablamos Ãºnicamente de mÃºsica no es toda la verdad, porque mi objetivo es transmitir lo que hago como una unidad que continÃºa creciendo y evolucionando para ser parte de la cultura contemporÃ¡nea. Esto es para lo que creo que soy bueno de forma natural, y el lugar que ocupo en la cultura, porque tengo la capacidad de hacerlo de forma autÃ©ntica y amo hacerloâ€.
A pesar de cierto aire esotÃ©rico en su reflexiÃ³n, es indudable que Batiste tenÃ­a los mimbres para acometer esa trayectoria, porque llegar a donde estÃ¡ hoy no es cuestiÃ³n de talento, ni de suerte, ni de pulsar los botones adecuados en la propia carrera, sino una afinada combinaciÃ³n de todos estos factores. PodrÃ­amos decir que Batiste siempre lo tuvo, pero es innegable que jugÃ³ un gran papel el momento y el lugar en que se crio: â€œMi evoluciÃ³n comienza en el hecho de haber nacido en una familia musical de Nueva Orleans, pero tambiÃ©n en la particularidad de que mis primeras influencias musicales fueron la mÃºsica de videojuegos y Bach, cuando empecÃ© a estudiar piano clÃ¡sico. Aparte, despuÃ©s estudiÃ© tambiÃ©n con cuatro veteranos del jazz contemporÃ¡neo y la vanguardia de Nueva Orleans: Ellis Marsalis, Alvin Batiste, Kidd Jordan y Clyde Kerr Jrâ€. Cuando tenÃ­a 12 aÃ±os, Batiste estaba metido en todos estos Ã¡mbitos musicales, ademÃ¡s de â€œescuchar todo lo que sonaba en la radio: mÃºsica soul y artistas de rap como Juvenile, Lil Wayne, Mannie Fresh, Master Pâ€¦â€.
Con este caldo de cultivo es natural pensar que a Batiste el jazz iba a, digamos, quedÃ¡rsele pequeÃ±o tarde o temprano, y por esto un Ã¡lbum tan variado como We Are, lleno de influencias afroamericanas de todo tipo, moderno y tradicional al mismo tiempo, supuso la cristalizaciÃ³n de todas las mÃºsicas con las que creciÃ³. Sin embargo, el salto estilÃ­stico a World Music Radio es abrumador, y escuchÃ¡ndolo es difÃ­cil no pensar en un claro anhelo comercial que tiene mÃ¡s que ver con la mercadotecnia que con la mÃºsica. SegÃºn Batiste el fondo del Ã¡lbum es creativo, aludiendo a una cuestiÃ³n de medios a su alcance: â€œMi Ã¡lbum de 2013, Social Music, querÃ­a ser lo que hoy es World Music Radio, pero entonces aÃºn no estaba en el lugar que tenÃ­a que estar. Para mÃ­ es como las pelÃ­culas de El padrino: We Are serÃ­a como la primera de la saga, que nadie sabÃ­a que iba a convertirse en lo que acabÃ³ siendo, y tuvo un montÃ³n de desafÃ­os durante su producciÃ³n. Cuando tuvo un enorme Ã©xito, hubo un gran presupuesto disponible para hacer la segunda parte, y en ese sentido World Music Radio es como El padrino 2. Mi visiÃ³n artÃ­stica no ha cambiado, solo ha ido evolucionando desde 2013, con aquel concepto que representÃ³ Social Musicâ€.
Aparte del concepto, la aspiraciÃ³n global de Batiste estÃ¡ perfectamente representada en la lista de colaboradores invitados en World Music Radio, tan variada que llega a aunar en el mismo tema al rapero J.I.D, las estrellas del k-pop New Jeans o el cantautor colombiano Camilo. Ante semejante combinaciÃ³n la cosa podrÃ­a no tener pies ni cabeza, mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de ese interÃ©s comercial que sobrevuela el disco, aunque Batiste incide en su fÃ©rrea direcciÃ³n artÃ­stica: â€œYo he tomado todas las decisiones creativas. Es un disco conceptual, muy narrativo, y querÃ­a seleccionar cada colaboraciÃ³n como en el casting de una pelÃ­cula. Hasta que creÃ© y estructurÃ© el Ã¡lbum no supe a quiÃ©n necesitaba en cada tema. Hay cosas que vienen de lejos: pensÃ© que Kenny G, a quien conozco desde hace mucho, serÃ­a increÃ­ble invitarlo a tocar la manifestaciÃ³n musical del vuelo de una mariposaâ€.
Jon Batiste en abril de 2022 en Las Vegas con sus cinco premios Grammy en la ediciÃ³n en la que ganÃ³ a Taylor Swift, Justin Bieber y Billie Eilish. ETIENNE LAURENT (EFE)
TambiÃ©n hay otras colaboraciones que surgieron inadvertidamente, como la de Lana Del Rey (junto a quien Batiste ya aparece en Candy Necklace, uno de los temas de su Ãºltimo Ã¡lbum): â€œEl productor Rick Rubin me invitÃ³ a sus estudios Shangri-La en Malibu para el primer mes de grabaciÃ³n, y todo el tiempo pasaban por allÃ­ mÃºsicos, productores, amigosâ€¦ En aquellas sesiones se grabÃ³ Life Lesson, que realmente no formaba parte de la narrativa del Ã¡lbum, por eso aparece al final. Y aunque no estÃ¡ integrada en el concepto, la canciÃ³n estÃ¡ hermanada con el resto del Ã¡lbum porque surgiÃ³ en las mismas sesionesâ€.
Otra colaboraciÃ³n sorprendente es la de la catalana Rita PayÃ©s; Â¿cÃ³mo llega su nombre, mucho menos popular que el del resto de colaboradores, hasta Batiste? â€œRita es una increÃ­ble cantante y trombonista. Yo no la conocÃ­a, pero mi productor ejecutivo, Ryan Lynn, me dijo que tenÃ­a que escucharla, y segÃºn lo hice lo tuve claro: Â¡era perfecta!â€.
SÃ­, no hay duda de que Batiste y su mÃºsica han evolucionado y, aunque el nuevo disco resultarÃ¡ demasiado disruptivo para algunos de sus seguidores, el mÃºsico tiene claro que se encuentra en el lugar en el que quiere estar, y por primera vez en toda su carrera profesional, despuÃ©s de dejar la televisiÃ³n el aÃ±o pasado, se estÃ¡ concentrando al 100% en su propia mÃºsica: â€œNunca he girado con mis proyectos propios, ni he grabado ninguno de mis Ã¡lbumes sin tener al mismo tiempo grandes obligaciones... hasta ahora. Los tres aÃ±os que pasaron desde que me graduÃ© hasta que empecÃ© a trabajar en televisiÃ³n estaba sin blanca, intentando mantener una banda a flote y conseguir algo de dinero en el metro de Nueva York para grabar un Ã¡lbum. Desde ahÃ­ pasÃ© a estar en televisiÃ³n durante siete aÃ±os seguidos, tocar mÃ¡s de 200 conciertos al aÃ±o, trabajar en bandas sonoras, y produciendo mis propios Ã¡lbumes al mismo tiempo. AsÃ­ que dejar la televisiÃ³n y concentrarme en mi obra es todo un cambio, y voy a aprovecharloâ€.
Toda la cultura que va contigo te espera aquÃ­. SuscrÃ­bete
Babelia Las novedades literarias analizadas por los mejores crÃ­ticos en nuestro boletÃ­n semanal RECÃBELO

title: Wenn du nicht einschlafen kannst, helfen dir diese Songs weiter
content:
Sanfte KlÃ¤nge kÃ¶nnen dabei helfen, ins Land der TrÃ¤ume abzudriften. Dank einer Studie weiss man nun auch, welche Lieder sich dafÃ¼r am besten eignen.
Adele & Pink Floyd : Schlafprobleme? Diese Songs lassen dich schnell einschlafen
Musik mit mÃ¶glichst vielen akustischen Anteilen kann beim Einschlummern helfen.
Schafe zÃ¤hlen, White Noise oder Akupressur-Klopftechniken: Tricks zum Einschlafen gibt es zahlreiche. Um dem nÃ¤chtlichen Gedankenkarussell eine Pause zu gÃ¶nnen, setzen viele auch auf ruhige Lieder. Das ergibt Sinn: Schliesslich wird diese Methode auch schon bei Kindern von Eltern auf der ganzen Welt in allen Varianten ausprobiert.
Damit du nun nicht auf Lieder wie Â«La Le LuÂ» zurÃ¼ckgreifen musst, haben Schlafexperten und -expertinnen der Firma Emma herausgefunden, welche Songs dich am schnellsten in das Gute-Nacht-Land katapultieren.
Brauchst du Musik zum Einschlafen? Ja, ich hÃ¶re jeden Abend ruhige Sounds. Ja, aber nicht immer. Nein, ich benutze aber andere Methoden. Nein, ich hab keine Probleme mit dem Einschlafen.
Gemeinsam mit Datenanalysten vom Musik-Streamingdienst Spotify wurden 150â€™000 Songs von mehr als 450 der beliebtesten KÃ¼nstlerinnen, KÃ¼nstler und Bands in den Genres Hip-Hop, Rock, Pop und Schlager auf ihre EinschlafqualitÃ¤ten untersucht. Dabei machte man sich wissenschaftliche Studien zunutze â€“ wie zum Beispiel eine Untersuchung der UniversitÃ¤t von Aarhus, die ausschlaggebende Audio-Merkmale in den Songstrukturen von Schlafmusik identifiziert hat.
Mehr als 450 Musiker, Musikerinnen und Bands wurden auf ihre EinschlafqualitÃ¤ten Ã¼berprÃ¼ft. Pexels/RFStudio
ZunÃ¤chst legten die Expertinnen und Experten mithilfe der dÃ¤nischen Studie eine Reihe von Merkmalen fest, die ein optimaler Song zum Einschlafen braucht, um im nÃ¤chsten Schritt eine Punktzahl fÃ¼r die untersuchten Lieder ermitteln zu kÃ¶nnen.
And The Winner Isâ€¦
Lana Del Rey! Das dÃ¼stere Schmachten, die rauchige Stimme und das ideale Soundprofil der US-amerikanischen KÃ¼nstlerin wirken bei Einschlafproblemen wahre Wunder. Zum besten Schlaflied wurde der Song Â«Norman Fucking RockwellÂ» auserkoren, die LP Â«Chemtrail Over The Country ClubÂ» zum besten Schlummer-Album. Insgesamt rÃ¤umt Del Rey im Ranking einen Score von 9,3 ab.
Zum Einschlafen sind auch die Pop-Songs Â«Everybody DiesÂ» von Billie Eilish, Â«NightÂ» von Frank Sinatra, Â«HeadspaceÂ» von Lewis Capaldi und Â«Make You Feel MeÂ» von Adele besonders gut geeignet.
Als beste Schlummer-Rockband rÃ¤umt Pink Floyd mit Â«Atom Heart Mother SuiteÂ» ab, der beste Schlagerhit ist laut Ranking Â«Erbarme dichÂ» von Reinhard Mey. Aber auch manche Hip-Hop-Artists haben ein ideales Soundprofil zum Einschlafen, zum Beispiel Pharrell Williams mit Â«Lost QueenÂ» und Post Malones Â«Waiting For A MiracleÂ».
Ã„hnliche Merkmale
Na, merkst du was? Richtig, die Lieder haben alle etwas gemeinsam. Zu dem Schluss kamen auch schon die Forschenden der Aarhus-UniversitÃ¤t in ihrer Studie. Musik, die zum Einschlafen geeignet ist, ist wenig energisch, kaum tanzbar, enthÃ¤lt mÃ¶glichst viele akustische Anteile und nur wenig oder leisen Gesang. Na dann, gute Nacht!

title: Lana Del Rey shows Taylor Swift-like fan connection at Outside Lands
content:
Lana Del Rey wowed fans on Day 2 of Outside Lands, performing a roughly 75-minute set that visibly connected with the huge crowd gathered to watch the pop star headline the festivalâ€™s Twin Peaks stage on Aug. 12.
Some fans appeared close to tears, so moved by the elegant and ethereal nature of the music as Del Rey moved through tracks from at least seven studio albums from her amazing catalog.
The most dramatic parts of her set â€” and there were plenty to choose from â€” came when the crowd pretty much took over on lead vocals, passionately belting out a number like â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ like it was the single most important song in the history of mankind.
Well, the single most important until Del Rey sang the next number, of course. She showed a near-Taylor Swift-like connection to her fans during her winning set.
Lana del Rey â€“ did you know that thereâ€™s a tunnel under ocean blvd #OutsideLands pic.twitter.com/6zCdRMNjUw â€” MORE (@mrmorevlogs) August 13, 2023
The multiplatinum-selling pop starâ€™s performance was a distinct highlight of a strong Day 2 of the festival, which also featured sets from Foo Fighters, Maggie Rogers, Alvvays, Conan Gray and more than two dozen other acts.
The festival â€” which is celebrating its 15th anniversary this year â€” kicked off Friday with hip-hop hero Kendrick Lamar, NBA legend Shaquille Oâ€™Neal (performing a DJ set under the stage name Diesel), funk-soul powerhouse Janelle Monae and others.
The 2023 Outside Lands was scheduled to continue on Sunday with a lineup that included Texas dream-pop outfit Cigarettes After Sex, Houston hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion and incredibly popular electronic music act Odesza.
The second best set I saw on Saturday came courtesy of Alvvays, the groovy Canadian indie-pop act that became a college radio favorite with the release of a self-titled debut album in 2014.
The quintet â€” consisting of vocalist-guitarist Molly Rankin, keyboardist Kerri MacLellan, guitarist Alec Oâ€™Hanley, bassist Abbey Blackwell and drummer Sheridan Riley â€” performed midway through the day on the big Lands End stage and spent much of its 14-song set promoting its most recent full-length, 2022â€™s great â€œBlue Rev.â€
Rankin proved to be a formidable frontwoman, commanding the crowdâ€™s attention with her alluring vocals and solid guitar work, and the rest of the band was also extremely on point.
Alvvaysâ€™ sound should appeal to fans of the â€™90s alt-rock outfit The Sundays â€” as well as to anyone who loves dreamy, yet driving indie-pop music.
The Foo Fighters were onstage at the same time as Lana Del Rey, drawing their own huge crowd over to the Lands End stage. It was the groupâ€™s first Bay Area show since the death of popular drummer Taylor Hawkins at the age of 50 in March 2022.
Led by the ever-energetic Dave Grohl, the Foos opened their headlining set with a powerful version of â€œAll My Lifeâ€ and then continued right into an equally strong â€œThe Pretender.â€ They seasoned â€œNo Son of Mineâ€ with some â€œEnter Sandman,â€ but one wishes that Grohl had played the whole thing, since it would have been great to hear the Metallica classic right in the Bay Area bandâ€™s own backyard.
Josh Freese, the bandâ€™s new drummer, did a great job on the kit. Freese may be new to the band, but heâ€™s certainly not new to the music business, having performed and recorded with everyone from Devo and the Nine Inch Nails to Sting and Michael Buble.
Speaking of Buble, for reasons as cloudy as the famed San Francisco fog that filled the festival grounds late in the day, the Canadian crooner actually showed up and performed a guest spot with the Foo Fighters.
Other acts that impressed fans on Day 2 included Niki, Maggie Rogers, Conan Gray, Zack Fox and Mariah the Scientist. DJ music fans, however, were disappointed that the festivalâ€™s popular SOMA dance tent was shut down for the second day in a row on Saturday due to flooring issues, a spokesman told media outlets.

title: Lana Del Reyâ€™s dating history from Guns 'N Roses' Axl Rose to secret fiance
content:
Lana Del Rey tends to keep her dating life private, even though her albums are full of songs of love and heartbreak.
It's been rumoured that the Summertime Sadness singer has been engaged three times since 2011. It's even speculated that the singer is currently engaged to a man she's never publicly stated she's been dating.
She's been connected to famous musicians, an Italian director, and even a police officer from Oklahoma. Lana told Rolling Stone in 2014 that she has "an affinity for really good, strong, self-assured people".
READ MORE: Ireland weather: Temperatures to rocket as maps show week-long 25C blast returning in August
Here's a list of Lana's rumoured and confirmed paramours that might have inspired some of her best songs and lyrics.
Barrie-James O'Neill
Lana started dating the Scottish singer-songwriter in 2011 and started writing music together. They made their red carpet debut at the MTV Europe Music Awards the next year.
(Image: PA)
Then in 2013, the couple recorded a cover together of Summer Wine by Nancy Sinatra and Lee Hazlewood. The same year it was reported that Lana and Barrie-James were engaged. But by 2014, they called it off.
"We are currently not together," Lana said, "He is a wonderful person. But there are some things he has to deal with."
Axl Rose
It hasn't been confirmed that Lana dated the Guns N' Roses frontman, but rumours swirled when the two were caught leaving Chateau Marmont in West Hollywood in 2012. Lana was reportedly dating Barrie-James at the time, but the two singers seemed to be getting cosy.
(Image: AFP/Getty Images)
Axl's former bandmate, DJ Ashba, said that he didn't believe the two were dating and that "Axl is a really cool dude and he likes to hang out with cool people". But even with the small doubts from a former bandmate of Axl's, Lana fans still believe something happened between the two.
Francesco Carrozzini
Shortly after her split from Barrie-James in 2014, Lana was spotted with Italian photographer and director Francesco Carrozzini. The two had an on and off again relationship until November 2015.
(Image: Getty Images)
Throughout their time together, they've been spotted at a World Cup game, spending a holiday in St. Barts, hanging out in Malibu, and attending a wedding together in Italy. Lana has never spoken publicly about this relationship, but her fans think her song 13 Beaches is about the Italian.
Francisco has been married to Bee Shaffer, Anna Wintour's daughter, since 2018.
G-Eazy
Lana was first linked to the rapper in 2017 when they were spotted together at Coachella music festival. A few weeks later the two were photographed leaving a Hollywood nightclub together.
(Image: Matt Baron/BEI/Shutterstock)
There's not a lot known about the relationship, since it seemed to be a very short fling. But the rapper supposedly mentions that Lana tried to get back together with him in his song Moana. He raps: "I know a Keisha and I know Lana/ They try to get me back, but I'm like 'no, nah, nah'/ I'm sorry, I don't want no drama."
Sean Larkin
The police officer and singer were first seen walking together through Central Park in September 2019. Lana has joked in an interview that if she knew she would be photographed that day she "would've worn something different."
(Image: AFP via Getty Images)
The two supposedly "hit it off from day one," even though Lana got flak for dating a police officer. But Lana called him a "good cop" and even met his kids in his hometown of Tulsa, Oklahoma. They made their first appearance on a red carpet in January 2020.
Two months after their red carpet appearance, the couple broke up. "We're just friends," Sean said to the New York Times, blaming the break up on "busy schedules."
Clayton Johnson
Sources say Lana met the musician on a dating app in 2020. Clayton appeared on a number of Lana's Instagram posts, including a Halloween post where the two wore matching Wizard of Oz costumes. In the photo, Lana appeared to have a diamond engagement ring on her finger, which she wore again when she went on The Tonight Show.
Eventually, the two broke up, but in typical Lana fashion, she kept this relationship details under wraps, so it's unclear exactly when the relationship ended.
Jack Donoghue
Salem band member Jack Donoghue and Lana were first rumoured to be together in 2022 after he posted a now-deleted video on Instagram of the pair together. Later, the two were seen at Jack's birthday party together, and Lana posted photos of them on Instagram. These pictures were later deleted.
This relationship was never confirmed or denied, but in February 2023 Lana posted an Instagram story of a flower bouquet, writing: "It's a love-hate thing." She never said the post was about Jack, but some eagle-eyed fans spotted what looks like the same bouquet on his Instagram.
Evan Winiker
According to Billboard, Lana reportedly got engaged to Evan Winiker in March 2023. Evan works for Range Media as a managing partner, working with musicians like MAX, Daya, and Walk Off the Earth.
(Image: Instagram)
Lana hasn't even confirmed she was dating Evan, let alone engaged to him. But the singer did attend the 2023 Billboard Women In Music event, flashing a diamond ring on her left finger to the cameras.

title: Der prominente WochenrÃ¼ckblick : Mit Megan Fox, Lana del Rey und Jeff Bezos
content:
Dieser Tage ist es ist wirklich langweilig in Berlin, niemand benimmt sich daneben und keinen interessiert das. Sommerpause bei Politik und Prominenz heiÃŸt Durststrecke â€“ im wahrsten Sinne des Wortes. WÃ¤hrend sich der gemeine Star sonst vor sogenannten â€Free-Drinkâ€œ-Event-Einladungen nicht retten kann, sind die Sommerferien eine einzige Veranstaltungs-WÃ¼ste.
Weil aber ausgerechnet im Sommer die Zeit ist, sich mit den banalen Dingen des Lebens zu beschÃ¤ftigen â€“ wer kennt es nicht, am Strandband liegen und sich darÃ¼ber lustig machen, dass der Kanzler schrullige Wanderklamotten trÃ¤gt â€“ ist das natÃ¼rlich besonders frustrierend. Deshalb sprechen Experten bei diesem sommerlichen Dilemma auch von der unbefriedigten Nachfrage.
Die Wirtschaft macht es vor, in solchen Situationen muss man sich mit billigen Importen begnÃ¼gen und damit jene ehren, die sich auch im August die MÃ¼he geben, ihre PersÃ¶nlichkeit zu verÃ¤uÃŸern.
Schauspielerin Megan Fox versucht sich als Dichterin
Das war in der vergangene Woche unter anderem Megan Fox. Beziehungsweise in der vergangenen Woche wurde klar, dass sie das im November sein wird. Die US-Schauspielerin verkÃ¼ndete nÃ¤mlich, dass sie jetzt Lyrikerin ist und in drei Monaten ihren ersten Gedichtband verÃ¶ffentlicht. â€Pretty Boys Are Poisonousâ€œ, â€HÃ¼bsche Jungs sind giftigâ€œ, wird er heiÃŸen und fÃ¼hrt bereits jetzt die Bestsellerliste auf Amazon an. â€Diese Gedichte wurden geschrieben, um die Krankheit zu beseitigen, die sich aufgrund meines Schweigens in mir festgesetzt hatteâ€œ, schreibt Fox Ã¼ber ihr Erstlingswerk auf Instagram. Und weiter: â€Ich habe mein ganzes Leben damit verbracht, die Geheimnisse der MÃ¤nner zu bewahren, und mein KÃ¶rper schmerzt von der Last ihrer SÃ¼nden.â€œ
Lana del Rey auf TikTok
FÃ¼r soviel poetischen Abgrund â€“ Pardon: Tiefe â€“ ist eigentlich nur die SÃ¤ngerin Lana del Rey bekannt. Die surft momentan aber in ganz andern SphÃ¤ren: Ihr zehn Jahre alter, aber erst kÃ¼rzlich verÃ¶ffentlichter Song â€Say Yes to Heavenâ€œ ist in beschleunigter Form beliebt bei TikTok. Ob das der Grund war, warum sie den jetzt gleich viermal â€remixenâ€œ lieÃŸ, ist nicht bekannt. Jedenfalls ist unter den Neuinterpretationen auch eine Version des Wiener â€neue neue deutsche Welleâ€œ Duos â€Amandus99â€œ und â€Danzinger99â€œ dabei.
EinschlÃ¤fernde Musik und illustre Nachbarschaft
Es kÃ¶nnte auch sein, dass sich Mrs. Del Rey ihren Song elektronisch-tanzbar aufhÃ¼bschen lieÃŸ, weil sie Wind davon bekam, dass sie eine Gruppe Liedermacher anfÃ¼hrt, deren Musik besonders einschlÃ¤fernd ist. Eine von dÃ¤nischen Schlafexperten durchgefÃ¼hrte Studie will das herausgefunden haben. Neben Del Rey sollen sich auch Songs von Billie Eilish, Adele, Pharrell Williams und Post Malone zum Einschlafen eignen.
Katy Perry taucht in dieser Liste nicht auf, was insofern verwunderlich ist, wenn man bedenkt, dass sie und ihr Gatte Orlando Bloom Geschick im Umgang mit Weggetretenen beweisen. Die SÃ¤ngerin und der Schauspieler sollen sich aktuell im Rechtsstreit mit einem todkranken US-Veteranen befinden: 2021 hatten die beiden fÃ¼r rund 13 Millionen Dollar eine Villa von dem unter Schmerzmitteln stehenden und deshalb nicht zurechnungsfÃ¤higen Mann erworben. Der Fall geht Ende August vor Gericht.
Solche Probleme kennt Jeff Bezos nicht, was wahrscheinlich am Preissegment in Sachen Immobilien liegt, auf dem er sich bewegt. Vergangene Woche wurde bekannt, dass sich der Amazon-GrÃ¼nder fÃ¼r 68 Millionen Dollar ein Haus auf einer Insel vor Miami gekauft hat. Die Insel heiÃŸt â€Indian Creek Islandâ€œ, wurde von Menschenhand gebaut und wird im Volksmund â€Billonaire Bunkerâ€œ genannt. Bezos neue Nachbarn tragen unter anderem die klingenden Namen Tom Brady oder Invanka Trump. Letztere nutzt ihre Sommerpause Ã¼brigens sinnvoll und nimmt Helikopter-Flugstunden. Damit wÃ¤re auch das geklÃ¤rt und wir kÃ¶nnen uns wieder der hiesigen Prominenz widmen. Obwohl, fast wieder vergessen, die ist ja gerade untÃ¤tig. Umso besser!

title: Songs zum Einschlafen: Warum Musik nicht ins Schlafzimmer gehÃ¶rt
content:
Zwischenruf Nicht zum Einschlafen und nicht zum Sex: Musik gehÃ¶rt nicht ins Bett Eine neue Studie will die besten Songs zum Einschlafen erkoren haben. Auf den Spitzenpositionen: Lana Del Rey, Billie Eilish und Adele. Wer wirklich Musik mag, verbannt sie aber aus dem Schlafzimmer.
Unser Autor findet: Wenn Musik zum Einschlafen verwendet wird, ist sie vor allem eines: schlecht. Bild: Dani Serrano / Getty
Es gibt Â«die antreibendste Musik zum JoggenÂ», Â«den idealen Soundtrack fÃ¼r das PflanzenwachstumÂ», Â«erlesene Tracks fÃ¼r lange Stunden im StauÂ». Es gebe wohl sogar, wÃ¼rde man lange genug danach suchen, irgendeine Playlist mit Â«motivierenden Tunes fÃ¼r das AusfÃ¼llen der SteuererklÃ¤rungÂ».
Und es gibt sie auch: Â«Die besten Songs zum EinschlafenÂ». Eine Firma, die sich Â«Emma â€“ The Sleep CompanyÂ» nennt, hat nun mehrere Spotify-Playlisten zusammengestellt, die Â«die nachweislich besten Songs zum EinschlafenÂ» enthalten. Bevor wir jetzt gedanklich alle Â«Schlaf, Chindli schlafÂ» und Â«La-Le-LuÂ» trÃ¤llern: Es sind allesamt Songs aus dem Oeuvre von durchaus bekannten Pop-, Rap-, Rock- und SchlagerkÃ¼nstlerinnen und -kÃ¼nstlern.
Ein idealer Song, um wegzudÃ¶sen beinhalte folgende Faktoren: Er sei wenig energisch, kaum tanzbar, enthalte mÃ¶glichste viele akustische Anteile und nur wenig oder leisen Gesang. Es sind allesamt bahnbrechende Erkenntnisse. Bisher hatten wir ja stets vermutet, dass unsere Schlafprobleme alleine darauf grÃ¼nden, dass wir beim Zubettgehen keinen Trash-Metal mit ordentlich GebrÃ¼ll hÃ¶ren.
Aber zurÃ¼ck zu den erkorenen Einschlafsongs. Diese haben alle einen Â«Sleep ScoreÂ» erhalten. Also Punkte auf einer Skala von 1 bis 10. Wobei
1 fÃ¼r musikalisches Koffein steht und 10 fÃ¼r eine hoch dosierte Schlaftablette.
HÃ¶chster Sleep Score: Lana del Rey
Auch darum ist es Ã¤usserst fraglich, ob es tatsÃ¤chlich eine Auszeichnung ist, dass Lana Del Rey gesamthaft den hÃ¶chsten Â«Sleep ScoreÂ» erzielt. Im Normalfall mÃ¶chten KÃ¼nstlerinnen und KÃ¼nstler wohl eher Musik machen, bei der nicht gleich weggeschlummert wird. Lana Del Rey erreicht auf jeden Fall einen Wert von 8,2.
Ebenfalls auf den Spitzen-Schnarch-PlÃ¤tzen sind Billie Eilish, Lewis Capaldi und Adele gelandet. Solider Mainstream-Pop, der meist ohne Ecken und Kanten auskommt. Es ist erstaunlich, dass die HÃ¶rerinnen und HÃ¶rer durchschnittlicher Radiostationen nicht Ã¶fter in einen Sekundenschlaf fallen.
Ob die Musik insgesamt spannend ist oder nicht, scheint bei der Liste absolut keinen Einfluss zu haben. Apache 207 und Helene Fischer, deren Gesamtwerk zweifelsfrei zum Allerlangweiligsten zÃ¤hlt, was die deutsche Popkultur in den vergangenen Jahrzehnten hervorgebracht hat, erreichen nur einen Wert von rund 7 Punkten. Wohl auch darum, weil man sofort den Raum verlassen will, wenn diese Songs gespielt werden. Wer auf der Flucht ist, kann nicht schlafen. Â«AtemlosÂ» halt.
Songtexte sind egal
Ebenfalls nicht eingeflossen sind die Texte zu den Songs. Auf den angepriesenen Playlists wimmelt es von Wehklagen Ã¼ber verflossene Liebe, allerlei Weltschmerz und sonstiger TrÃ¤nentreiberei. GlÃ¼cklich schlÃ¤ft da keiner und keine ein. Und sogar das Â«SchlafliedÂ» von Die Ã„rzte hat es auf die Liste geschafft. Â«Dein kleines Bettchen vom Blut ganz rot/ Die Sonne geht auf und du bist totÂ», heisst es in diesem satirischen Wiegenliedchen. Die AlbtrÃ¤ume danach sind garantiert.
Aber vielleicht ist es am Ende ganz generell so, dass Musik sowieso nicht unbedingt ins und ans Bett gehÃ¶rt. Neben den Einschlaflisten gibt es dann auch noch zahlreiche Beischlaflisten. Diese wollen dann entweder mit smoothem R'n'B in eine Kuschelstimmung schunkeln oder per kecken Drum den Rhythmus vorgeben. Schrecklich. Etwas bÃ¶se gesagt: Wer selbst den Takt nicht findet, der sollte vielleicht sowieso besser schlafen.
Am besten ganz ohne Musik. Ganz unabhÃ¤ngig vom jeweiligen Â«Sleep ScoreÂ». Wenn Lieder derart egal werden, dass man dazu einschlafen mÃ¶chte, dann sind sie vor allem eines: schlecht. Und fÃ¼r schlechte Songs ist das Leben zu kurz. Sogar im Schlaf.
