title: Why everyone seems so excited about this year's lineup
content:
Allen Scott understands that some people have enjoyed some Outside Landsâ€™ lineups better than others. He knows that because, well, heâ€™s one of those people â€” and heâ€™s also one of the primary architects putting together the lineup each year.
â€œI have different feelings on the lineup every year,â€ says Scott, co-founder of Outside Lands and president of concerts and festivals at Another Planet Entertainment. â€œSometimes, I like the lineup more than others, certainly â€” like everybody. And I am like really, really fired up for this year.â€
That seems to the general consensus about the bill for the 2023 Outside Lands, which marks the 15th anniversary of the festival. Kendrick Lamar, Lana Del Rey, Odeza, Foo Fighters, Megan Thee Stallion, The 1975, Janelle Monae, Zedd, J.I.D and Maggie Rogers are among the well-known acts set to appear at the three-day event, which takes place Aug. 11-13 at Golden Gate Park in San Francisco. (See sfoutsidelands.com for details and read our guide to the festival.)
â€œEveryone seems to like it â€” like 98 percent positivity about the lineup, which is unheard of,â€ Scott says. â€œUsually like half the people donâ€™t like it and half the people do. But kind of everybodyâ€™s really excited about this.â€
One of the biggest selling points, Scott says, is the lineup just contains so many great concert acts.
â€œThe performances are going to be so good,â€ he says. â€œKendrick Lamar, Foo Fighters and Odesza â€” those three headliners are just powerhouse live acts.â€
Also, as they say, timing is everything. And Scott and company have booked a lineup that is full of currently hot acts.
â€œWe have a lot of artists kind of cresting at the right time â€” like a Noah Kahan or Lil Yachty,â€ Scott says. â€œLana Del Rey is in the top 10 most streamed artists this year. She couldâ€™ve headlined on the main stage. Sheâ€™s that big. But Twin Peaks (where Del Rey is set to perform) is like a headlining slot for us these days.â€
Del Rey is performing on Saturday at the same time as the Foo Fighters, who â€œare bigger, probably, than they have ever been in their career right now,â€ Scott says.
Kahan will take the stage on Sunday at the same time as Odesza, the electronic music act that filled Mountain Viewâ€™s Shoreline Amphitheatre to the brim twice in 2022. â€œThey sold out two nights â€” 44,000 tickets â€” last fall,â€ Scott says. â€œAnd they blew them out.â€
Those kinds of marquee lineup conflicts have caused quite a stir on social media, as music fans debate the hard decisions of what to leave in and what to leave out in this jam-packed lineup.
â€œItâ€™s going to be hard to pick where to go,â€ Scott says. â€œWhen you have a really positive lineup like that, you are going to have people disappointed about the set times. I think of that as a well-curated festival â€” when people are upset about the conflicts. That is one of the things about festivals â€” you have to choose your own adventure.â€

title: Electric Picnic: 15 acts that left a mark, from Fontaines DCâ€™s storming set to Lana Del Reyâ€™s tears
content:
Itâ€™s almost time to set the table for another Electric Picnic â€“ the 18th, to be exact. The Picnic, which began life as a charmingly esoteric â€œboutiqueâ€ festival at Stradbally Estate in Co Laois, in 2004, has grown into a huge mainstream event headlined by some of the worldâ€™s biggest acts. Hereâ€™s our pick of the most memorable moments from almost two decades of Picnicking.
15. For Those I Love bring the feels
Electric arena, 2022
David Balfeâ€™s spoken-word electronic project was a vehicle for articulating his grief over the death of a friend. Photograph: Debbie Hickey/Getty
David Balfeâ€™s spoken-word electronic project was a vehicle for articulating his grief over the death of his friend Paul Curran, the poet and musician. The duo had attended Electric Picnic together, which made this performance by For Those I Love all the more emotional. What a roller coaster it was, from joy to devastation, all illuminated by Balfeâ€™s memories of his hard-knock upbringing in the Dublin suburbs. â€œI can feel you in this room,â€ he said towards the end, talking both to the audience and to his dear friend.
14. The Cure play on and on
Main stage, 2012
In all, The Cure performed 39 tracks during the set. Photograph: Dave Meehan
The Cure werenâ€™t pandering to the lightweights among their fans when they pummelled through a three-hour set at Stradbally, chucking in the hits but playing lots of B-sides and obscurities too. It did go on and on â€“ to the point where you could nip off and enjoy a lean 40-minute performance by The Horrors in an adjoining tent and then return to The Cure without feeling that youâ€™d missed all that much. In all, they performed 39 tracks, starting with Plainsong, from Disintegration, and concluding â€“ a long time later â€“ with 10:15 Saturday Night and Killing an Arab.
[ Electric Picnic: Paolo Nutini to headline festival ]
13. Scary Ã‰ire say goodbye
Salty Dog Stage, 2019
A poignant 1am gig by the influential early-1990s Irish hip-hop crew became even more significant after the fact. They blitzed through a gangsta-influenced repertoire informed by their experiences of life on social welfare in that pre-Celtic Tiger purgatory when Ireland was poor and miserable. It would be a poignant Picnic farewell to remember, with founder member and MC Dada Sloosh (aka James Molloy) dying a few years later, in 2022. In the dark, in front of a devoted crowd, he and the rest of Scary Ã‰ire left us with something to remember.
READ MORE
12. Charli XCX is joined by Christine and the Queens
Electric arena, 2019
A rare Charli XCX performance in Ireland was elevated when HÃ©loÃ¯se Letissier, aka Christine and the Queens, appeared. Photograph: Dave Meehan
A rare Charli XCX performance in Ireland was elevated when her occasional collaborator HÃ©loÃ¯se Letissier, aka Christine and the Queens, guested on their single Gone. The only black mark is Charli continually saying, â€œHello, Dublin!â€ As Richard Ashcroft, late of The Verve, would declare from the main stage later that weekend, this was the time to be â€œunleashed in Laoisâ€. Still, it was a searing turn by Charli â€“ who also performed her Troye Sivan nostalgia juggernaut 1999 and even covered the Spice Girls.
[ â€˜There are always people complainingâ€™: Electric Picnic must ensure a feast for everyone in the audience ]
11. Fontaines DC storm the Body & Soul stage
2018
Fontaines DC were not yet on the radar when they played the arcadian Body & Soul stage. Photograph: Dave Meehan
Fontaines who? The Dublinersâ€™ early single Liberty Belle had come out just a year earlier and they were not yet on the radar when they played the arcadian Body & Soul stage. What a treat of a gig it was, with those in the know hearing early versions of Boys in the Better Land and Hurricane Laughter. Irelandâ€™s new stars had arrived. It was just that nobody knew it yet â€“ them least of all.
10. Julian Casablancas goes on a rant
Main stage, 2019
Julian Casablancas radiated a not-a-care-in-the-world energy. Photograph: Debbie Hickey/Getty
â€œHey, whatâ€™s with these fancy TVs?â€ the Strokes frontman said as the louche New Yorkers headlined Saturday night in 2019. He was referring to the new wraparound screens on either side of the Picnicâ€™s main stage. That wasnâ€™t important, however. What mattered was the not-a-care-in-the-world energy that Julian Casablancas radiated. On a nippy night, it warmed the cockles â€“ especially when he responded to chants of â€œOlÃ©, olÃ©, olÃ©â€ with a derisive, â€œWhat does it mean?â€
[ GardaÃ­ billed promoters more than â‚¬300,000 for policing Garth Brooks concerts and Electric Picnic ]
9. Sigridâ€™s secret gig
Other Voices stage, 2018
Sigrid was so overwhelmed that she started crying â€“ a moment that inspired the track Sight of You. Photograph: Dave Meehan
Sigrid, the Norwegian pop star, had fallen in love with rural Ireland when playing the Other Voices festival. The day she headlined the Electric arena she made her feelings plain with a secret performance at the Other Voices stage. Back at the arena, she was so overwhelmed that she started crying â€“ a moment that inspired the track Sight of You, on her second LP, How to Let Go.
8. King Kong Company close the Body & Soul stage
2019
Such was the interest in the final-ever gig at the Body & Soul arena that the gates had to be closed so the crowd stayed within capacity. Attendees were rewarded with a set of knockout electro-rock from the Waterford group.
7. Grace Jones turns up as the grim reaper
Main stage, 2015
Grace Jones said she was surprised it wasn't raining. Photograph: Dave Meehan
Taking to the stage to the strains of Nightclubbing, Grace Jones was dressed as the grim reaper until she tossed off her robes to reveal head-to-toe body paint. â€œI know my Jamaican accent sounds a bit Irish,â€ Jones says, followed by, â€œIâ€™m surprised itâ€™s not raining.â€
6. Beastie Boysâ€™ final Irish show
Electric arena, 2007
The Brooklyn rappers delivered a powerful performance at the Electric arena, concluding with the mosh-pit frenzy of Sabotage. Five years later, Adam Yauch, aka MCA, would die of cancer, aged 47. Beastie Boys disbanded and their Picnic set would take on a poignant note.
[ Lewis Capaldi cancels Electric Picnic gig, announcing break from touring â€˜for the foreseeable futureâ€™ ]
5. My Bloody Valentine stage a glorious return
Electric arena, 2008
Kevin Shields, the mercurial leader of the Irish-British shoegaze quartet, was spotted having a carvery lunch with his parents in Portlaoise the afternoon MBV headlined Electric Picnic. The dinner must have blown away the cobwebs as their concert was rafter-shaking and beautifully uncompromising. It was memorable for other reasons, too: 2008 was the last year of Electric Picnicâ€™s early incarnation as a collaboration between John Reynoldsâ€™ Pod group and Aiken Promotions.
4. Mark E Smith Discovers Mumford and Sons
Backstage, 2010
Mark E Smithâ€™s response to encountering Mumford and Sons backstage has gone down in the annals. Photograph: Niall Carson/PA
The Fallâ€™s 2010 set at the Picnic is not widely remembered. Mark E Smithâ€™s response to encountering Mumford and Sons backstage, however, has gone down in the annals. â€œThere was this other group warming up in the next sort of chalet and they were terrible,â€ he recalled. â€œI said, â€˜Shut them c**ts up,â€™ and they were still warming up so I threw a bottle at them. The band said, â€˜Thatâ€™s the Sons of Mumford or something. Theyâ€™re number five in charts!â€™ I just thought they were a load of retarded Irish folk singers.â€
3. Lana Del Rey cries
Main stage, 2016
The Video Games star has long had an intense relationship with Ireland, having been feted like royalty when she played Vicar Street in 2012. Four years later, headlining Sunday night at Electric Picnic, she became overwrought. Her tour had been long and she was growing ambivalent about stardom and its pressures. As the crowd sang back, the floodgates opened. â€œItâ€™s just heavy performing for people who really care about you and you donâ€™t really care that much about yourself sometimes. I thought it was sad. I thought my position was sad. I thought it was sad to be in Ireland singing for people who really cared when I wasnâ€™t sure if I did.â€
[ Plastic cups, disposable plates and a sea of abandoned tents: Can festivals ever be ecofriendly? ]
2. Arcade Fire knock the blocks off
Electric arena, 2005
Much like Billie Eilish in 2019, Arcade Fire had yet to fully cement their stardom when they played their first Irish show. They knocked the roof off the Electric arena in the early afternoon â€“ and later spoke of the show as transformative in their history. Their reputation has since been sullied because of reports about the behaviour of their singer, Win Butler. For 40 shining minutes 18 years ago, though, they were the most exciting band in the universe. And Electric Picnic discovered them first.
1. Billie Eilish draws a record crowd
Main stage, 2019
Billie Eilish drew a record main-stage crowd of more than 50,000 for her Friday-evening set. Photograph: Kieran Frost/Redferns
Billie Eilish wasnâ€™t even listed as a headliner when the festival line-up was first announced. She drew a record main-stage crowd of more than 50,000 for her Friday-evening set, though. It was emotional for Eilish â€“ whose real name is Billie Oâ€™Connell and is of Irish and Scottish heritage â€“ and even more so for the audience, including many teenagers and children who were overwrought as she high-kicked her way through her hits. â€œThat show was awesome,â€ Finneas, her brother and co-songwriter, would tell The Irish Times. Can they top it as they return to headline in 2023?

title: Paul Dalla Rosa: the 10 funniest things I have ever seen (on the internet)
content:
Last year, I went to write in a cabin in the middle of the New Hampshire woods. There were deer and bobcats and large, expressive racoons. I was excited to be off-grid. But even there, I still received data. My phone reception was better than ever. During the day, I placed my phone in a ziplock bag and stashed it in the unlit fireplace, then, late at night, abjectly clawed it back out. I understood why writers in the past cut modem lines and severed fibre optic cables, but I told myself it was OK to be on the internet as I was writing a novel about the internet, that semiotic deluge weâ€™re all immersed in, which is something so strange and beautiful and wondrous and terrifying.
These are some of the things I return to. Though, if Iâ€™m honest, the funniest things Iâ€™ve seen arenâ€™t always â€œha haâ€ funny. Itâ€™s more that Iâ€™m drawn to a weirdness, a certain energy. These are the things that make me laugh.
1. Bill Gates jumping over a chair
Itâ€™s a very exciting video. Bill Gates jumps over an office chair. Something about Connie Chung saying â€œYes!â€ makes me laugh. The quick cut to a slow-motion replay of the jump, like Bill Gates just executed a kickflip, makes me laugh even more.
2. Hi Octane Comedy Central â€“ Sofia Coppola and Zoe Cassavetes
In 1994, the same year Bill leapt over an office chair, Comedy Central had Sofia Coppola and Zoe Cassavetes host a TV show. Hi Octane has the energy of someone stealing a camcorder and seeing what happens, except who steals it happens to be Sofia Coppola and Zoe Cassavetes. It makes a difference. They drive around in a red 60s Pontiac, have guest stars such as Keanu Reeves, Thurston Moore and Gus Van Sant, and always speak in a laconic Valley girl drawl.
In the first episode, AndrÃ© Leon Talley relays a message for Sofia from Karl Lagerfeld: â€œKarl says, would you please enunciate a little betteeeer â€¦ sometimes he canâ€™t understand what youâ€™re sayiiiing, because you talk like this, whhaaaaat â€¦ Just like, pick it up, girl. Work it.â€
3. Bethenny Frankelâ€™s TikTok
Allow TikTok content? This article includes content provided by TikTok. We ask for your permission before anything is loaded, as they may be using cookies and other technologies. To view this content, click 'Allow and continue'. Allow and continue
I love Bethenny Frankel. I do. Whenever I watch her TikTok, I get the sense that Bethenny would talk just as much without the camera present. She talks wandering through TJ Maxx, sitting in her house in the Hamptons, as she cooks. Thereâ€™s a chaos to it thatâ€™s difficult to describe. Sheâ€™s funny and somehow always entrancing, like an Ottessa Moshfegh narrator. Hereâ€™s Frankel eating crawfish in an Atlanta hotel room.
4. New York Post headlines
On my way to work, I stand on the tram and scroll through the New York Postâ€™s X feed. I often tell myself this has a literary precedent. In Jay McInerneyâ€™s Bright Lights, Big City, the narrator reads the Post on the subway on his way to factcheck at a magazine alluded to be the New Yorker. In the novel, as in life, the Post headlines are a hallucinatory, sensationalist, almost phantasmagorical pleasure.
Theyâ€™re not always funny. Most of them arenâ€™t. Thereâ€™s tragedy, world events, but then you hit something abrupt and anecdotal: â€œDog escapes kennel mid-flight by chewing through cageâ€, â€œMom blasts school after daughters told they canâ€™t wear Vivienne Westwood shoesâ€, â€œEmojis can cost you thousands of dollars or land you in jailâ€” hereâ€™s whyâ€.
5. Alexis Neiersâ€™ voicemail to Nancy Jo Sales
Iâ€™m roughly the same age as Alexis, and the words â€œNancy Jo, this is Alexis Neiers callingâ€ are seared into my mind. If intoxicated, I might even act out the scene. If you know it, you know it.
6. Angelllboys London
Allow TikTok content? This article includes content provided by TikTok. We ask for your permission before anything is loaded, as they may be using cookies and other technologies. To view this content, click 'Allow and continue'. Allow and continue
I usually find influencers opening HermÃ¨s boxes to be grotesque, but I find these two very charming. The artifice cuts it like a chaser. TikTok Brideshead-cum-Birkin Revisited. I donâ€™t know how theyâ€™ll turn out. Evelyn Waughâ€™s novel is a tragedy, but the times have changed. This weekend, Iâ€™ll order â€œa restorative Americanoâ€ and experience â€œdecibels of tranquillityâ€ and hope for the best.
7. Lana Del Rey in the bathtub with her cats
I donâ€™t think Lana Del Rey is funny per se, but I think sheâ€™s more playful than people recognise. She appears in this video piece for Interview magazine. She sits by a typewriter and types. She sits, fully dressed, in a bubble bath, holding her two cats. Her lines are electric. Theyâ€™re very glamorous things to say. Theyâ€™re funny if you repeat them in everyday settings.
â€œItâ€™s different being extraordinary, itâ€™s hard being eccentric.â€
â€œCrazy? Me? No. I mean, look, weâ€™re at a magazine shoot.â€
8. Dial Dan
Dial Dan is New York City photographer Dan Allegrettoâ€™s podcast. Iâ€™m hoping it becomes a sleeper hit. In the past, heâ€™s had guests such as Naomi Fry, John Early, Alissa Bennett and Chris Crocker. I prefer his solo episodes. Not a lot happens. Theyâ€™re calming, like a certain kind of domestic Japanese novel. Topics for an episode include: beef tartare with too much cheese, bisexuality, low tire pressure warnings, a panic attack in a Loweâ€™s parking lot. If you try to explain the meaning of the word simpatico, youâ€™re describing Dan. Heâ€™s funny, charismatic and infectious. You can also find him on Cameo.
9. Val Kilmer
Allow TikTok content? This article includes content provided by TikTok. We ask for your permission before anything is loaded, as they may be using cookies and other technologies. To view this content, click 'Allow and continue'. Allow and continue
Iâ€™m not sure if I can link to the video for legal reasons, but itâ€™s Val Kilmerâ€™s DVD commentary to the David Mamet film, Spartan. Clips are online. In them he discusses Mamet. He says, â€œHe [Mamet] actually had to confess publicly that Iâ€™m funnier because everybody knew it.â€ During a shootout, Kilmer shares, â€œThatâ€™s Davidâ€™s rabbi. Iâ€™m not even kidding. It sounds like Iâ€™m kidding but that guy I just killed is his rabbi. See, thatâ€™s what I mean by â€˜sickâ€™. I wouldnâ€™t have him shoot my practitioner in my film. Whyâ€™d he make me shoot his rabbi?â€
Instead of that video, hereâ€™s a clip of Val Kilmer at the beach.
10. New York Times advice column
I remember once working at a magazine with an advice column and every time it went to print there was a scramble to fill it with questions weâ€™d invent. I can say this because I never signed an NDA and the magazine no longer exists. I sometimes wonder if the New York Times does the same. This is an incredible question. I saw it screenshot in a tweet with a caption that said something like, â€œMeanwhile, during the decadent decline of the west.â€

title: Lana Del Rey Wasnâ€™t Working at Waffle House for Clout
content:
She could definitely break up a fight. Photo: Joseph Okpako/WireImage
Lana Del Rey has broken her silence on the employment allegations. That is, in an interview with The Hollywood Reporter, she confirmed how she got the job at Americaâ€™s premier dining establishment, Waffle House, known for its employees who promptly serve tasty breakfast platters that have a high risk of giving customers IBS and stay ready to throw hands with rowdy customers in the clips that make it to Twitter. Apparently, she was a regular at the Florence, Alabama, location of the diner chain with her brother and sister before deciding to cosplay as an employee and take selfies with fans in the standard-issue uniform. â€œWe were on our third hour, and the servers asked, â€˜Do you guys want shirts?â€™ â€ Lana told the magazine. â€œHell yeah! We were thrilled.â€ To a person on the internet, it looked like Lana Del Rey truly started working at the joint, especially when she was given the opportunity to serve a customer. â€œThis guy, a regular, comes in every day and orders two things, so they were like, â€˜Just go get it for him!â€™ I brought him a Coke. No ice. And an empty cup,â€ she explained. â€œI didnâ€™t see anyone take a video of me.â€
Though she appeared amused by the experience in the interview, she still doesnâ€™t get why people cared about her impromptu Waffle House internship. â€œI wish my album had gone as viral,â€ she said. â€œI woke up to, like, 10,000 texts the next morning â€” some from folks I had not heard from for ten years. â€˜Saw your picture at the Waffle House!â€™ I was like, â€˜Did you hear the new album?â€™â€ Your mom called, and Lana told her to stream Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd.

title: Lana Del Rey Praises Billie Eilish & Olivia Rodrigo: See What She Said
content:
Billie Eilish and Olivia Rodrigo have been vocal about their love of Lana Del Rey, and shared on multiple occasions that she has carved a path for their respective stars to rise. And the love is mutual, Del Rey revealed in a new interview published in The Hollywood Reporter on Wednesday (Sept. 20).
â€œBillie and Olivia are such good people, itâ€™s fâ€“king awesome. I love them and their music. Itâ€™s not like you have to be nice to be good [in music]. But, if you happen to be nice and a great singer, it makes me happy for the culture,â€ the six-time Grammy nominee replied when asked how it feels knowing the girls credit her as inspiration.
She added, â€œI always had girls telling me [things like] that. Maybe not the critics or anybody else â€” but singers I knew, no matter how big or small, would write me letters. I always felt like the older sister to pretty much everyone I ever met.â€
Elsewhere in the feature, Rodrigo â€” who presented Del Rey with the Visionary Award at the 2023 Billboard Women in Music Awards in March â€” shared, â€œLanaâ€™s work taught me how effective sentimentality can be in songwriting â€¦ She defies any stereotypes of what a woman writing pop songs should or shouldnâ€™t be. Sheâ€™s constantly pushing boundaries and making work that is fresh, adventurous and unabashedly feminine.â€
Del Rey also briefly addressed going viral for working at Waffle House in Alabama, and how she wanted her recent album, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, to receive even a fraction of the attention. â€œI wish my album had gone as viral,â€ she stated, adding that she received â€œ10,000 textsâ€ after the photos and videos of her working hit the internet.

title: Lana Del Rey Explains Working a Shift at an Alabama Waffle House
content:
Lana Del Reyâ€˜s fans are fascinated with pretty much everything the â€œA&Wâ€ singer does, especially when they get a rare chance to interact with her offstage, in the wild. Thatâ€™s why when she popped into a Waffle House in Florence, Alabama in July and worked a shift pouring coffee and chatting the patrons up â€” she even had an official â€œLanaâ€ name tag â€” it briefly broke the internet.
â€œI wish my album had gone as viral. I woke up to, like, 10,000 texts the next morning â€” some from folks I had not heard from for 10 years,â€ Del Rey said of the intense interest in her unexpected food service foray. â€œâ€™Saw your picture at the Waffle House!â€™â€ I was like, â€˜Did you hear the new album?'â€
At the time, neither Del Rey nor her team would give any explanation for the odd shift work, though sleuths did note that she name-checked the Alabama city on the song â€œParis, Texasâ€ on her most recent album, this yearâ€™s Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd.
Now, in a feature interview with The Hollywood Reporter, writer Mikey Oâ€™Connell reveals that Del Rey actually never meant to work that shift. â€œBut after seven days of seeing the same faces during a visit to Florence, Alabama, and a July morningâ€™s worth of shooting the sâ€“t with her brother and sister in the same plastic booth, the singer-songwriter found herself wearing the Southern chainâ€™s familiar uniform: a polycotton, working-class blue button-up garnished with a name tag bearing the crudely stickered letters L-A-N-A,â€ he wrote.
â€œWe were on our third hour, and the servers asked, â€˜Do you guys want shirts?â€™ â€ Del Rey explained. â€œHell yeah! We were thrilled.â€ Though the video of the superstar breakfast blitz was only 10 seconds long, it blew up after the restaurantâ€™s manager posted it to Facebook and some selfies Del Rey took with patrons made their way to social media. Was it some kind of elaborate, mysterious promo for her album, or a peek at some weird fast-food fetish?
As it turns out, Oâ€™connell said, is that Del Rey simply has family ties in the small town (pop. 40,000), is good at making fast friends and just loves hanging at diners. â€œThis guy, a regular, comes in every day and orders two things, so they were like, â€˜Just go get it for him!â€™ I brought him a Coke. No ice. And an empty cup,â€ she said, miming that the second cup was for the manâ€™s tobacco spit juice.
In the wide-ranging interview, Del Rey also touched on why she has refused to publish her lyrics, whether sheâ€™d ever perform on Saturday Nigh Live (or any other TV shows) again and how she feels like an â€œolder sisterâ€ to younger singers such as Billie Eilish and Olivia Rodrigo.

title: Lana Del Rey reveals the story behind the viral Waffle House photos
content:
CNN â€”
Lana Del Rey has revealed why she spent some time pouring Coca-Cola and coffee at a Waffle House over the summer.
Del Rey explained in an interview with The Hollywood Reporter that she was simply visiting friends in Florence, Alabama, where she hung out at the same Waffle House for several days in July with her brother and sister.
â€œWe were on our third hour [that day], and the servers asked, â€˜Do you guys want shirts?â€™â€ she said. â€œHell yeah! We were thrilled.â€
Staff also made her a name tag.
Del Rey was encouraged to pitch in and recalled serving one customer in particular.
â€œThis guy, a regular, comes in every day and orders two things, so they were like, â€˜Just go get it for him!â€™ I brought him a Coke. No ice. And an empty cup.â€
â€œFor dip,â€ she added, meaning chewing tobacco.
Video and social media posts of Del Rey in uniform behind the counter sparked speculation the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ singer was moonlighting as a waitress.
â€œI wish my album had gone as viral,â€ Del Rey joked. â€œI woke up to, like, 10,000 texts the next morning â€” some from folks I had not heard from for 10 years. â€˜Saw your picture at the Waffle House!â€™ [Laughing.] I was like, â€˜Did you hear the new album?â€™â€

title: Neue Platten fÃ¼rs Wochenende: Mitski, Diddy (Ex-Puff-Daddy), Anjimile
content:
Mitski: â€The Land Is Inhospitable and So Are Weâ€œ (Dead Oceans/Cargo)
Diese Frau hat wohl so ziemlich die unwahrscheinlichste Pop-Karriere der letzten Jahre gewoben! Mitski, 2o16 mit ihrer damals schon vierten Platte â€Puberty 2â€œ eindeutig noch dem gehobenen Schrammel-Indie-Genre auf billigen Gitarrenakkorden zuzurechnen, hat dann 2018 auf â€Be The Cowboyâ€œ ihre Klangpalette unter anderem um funkelnde Synthesizer bereichert, um dann 2022 mit ihrem â€Laurell Hellâ€œ sogleich das Ende all ihrer Musik zu verkÃ¼nden. Zum GlÃ¼ck ist Mitski wankelmÃ¼tig (wie die saufende Frau im Video zur Vorab-Single).
Vielleicht auch, weil Mitski mit â€The Only Heartbreakerâ€œ einen richtigen, sogar von Obama gefeierten Hit hatte. Oder weil ihre Songs derweil zum TikTok-Wunder-Soundtrack mutierten. Auf jeden Fall ist Mitskis neue Platte â€The Land Is Inhospitable and So Are Weâ€œ (zu Deutsch: â€Das Land ist ungastlich und wir sind es auchâ€œ) ein wunderbar poetisch verdichtetes Country-Folk-Album, das sich nicht scheut, auch Hundekacke beim Namen zu nennen. Mitski konzentriert sich auf die ihren (bei aller ZurÃ¼ckhaltung doch so eindringlichen) Gesang begleitende akustische Gitarre, hat aber zudem ein schÃ¶nes Saloon-Orchester im RÃ¼cken, das besser wÃ¤rmt als Whiskey. GlamourÃ¶se Tristesse, von der sich selbst Lana Del Rey noch was ablauschen kÃ¶nnte.
Anzeige | Zum Weiterlesen scrollen
Diddy: â€The Love Album: Off The Gridâ€œ (Love Records)
Spontan gar nicht so leicht zu sagen, welche Anzahl hÃ¶her ist: die von Puff Daddys, Ã¤h, P. Diddys, Ã¤h, Diddys Ex-KÃ¼nstlernamen oder doch die Zahl der KÃ¼nstlergÃ¤steliste auf dem neuen Album, seinem ersten seit mehr als zehn Jahren. Es sind nahezu drei Dutzend GÃ¤ste mit drauf. Um mal nur ein paar der prominentesten zu nennen: The Weeknd. Busty Rhymes. Mary J. Blige. Justin Bieber. Swae Lee (von Rae Sremmurds). Burna Boy. John Legend. Es geht noch ewig weiter!
KÃ¼ndet solch eine Party auf der Platte eigentlich mehr von GrÃ¶ÃŸenwahn oder doch eher von kÃ¼nstlerischen Selbstzweifeln? Stimmlich ist Diddy (als einer der einflussreichsten Rapper aller Zeiten) Ã¼berraschend wenig prÃ¤sent auf der neuen Platte. Er scheint das Mikro lieber weiterzureichen an seine Promi-Crew. Aber es dÃ¼rfte dennoch seiner Produktion zu verdanken sein, dass das â€Love Albumâ€œ so warmherzig klingt, nicht bloÃŸ R&B und HipHop fusionierend (gerÃ¼hrt, nicht geschÃ¼ttelt!), sondern auch mit Vintage-Soul auffahrend. Tolles melancholisches Mixtape, wie gemacht fÃ¼r die bittersÃ¼ÃŸe SpÃ¤tsommersonne.
Anjimile: â€The Kingâ€œ (4AD/Beggars)
Dass es solche Platten noch gibt! Anjimile, Jahrgang 1993, singt mit der FeinfÃ¼hligkeit von Sufjan Stevens, den Avantgarde-Ambitionen eines Perfume Genius und mitunter auch mit Tracy-Chapman-Wucht. Inmitten von viel betÃ¤ubendem Einheitsbrei, der zurzeit so erscheint, ist dieses Album ein Kronjuwel, passend zum kÃ¶niglichen Titel â€The Kingâ€œ.
Wobei, Obacht: Anjimile, schwarz, queer und trans, besingt oft in bester Protestmusiktradition harte Themen, auch rassistische Polizeigewalt. Also nicht von den Philip-Glass-Arpeggios einlullen lassen! So viel Prognose sei gewagt: â€The Kingâ€œ mit seiner ergreifenden KlangfÃ¼lle ist ein heiÃŸer Kandidat fÃ¼r die Jahresbestenlisten. Muss man nicht mal nur mit Bleistift notieren, sondern kann beherzt zu Hammer und MeiÃŸel greifen!

title: Madison Beer Talks 'Silence Between Songs, Lana Del Rey and 2024 Tour
content:
Madison Beer had already handed her sophomore album to her label when she frantically called her producer, New Zealand-born producer Leroy Clampitt, to tell him that she wanted to turn the whole project around. That was nearly a year ago, long before â€œSilence Between Songsâ€ became the 14-song collection of psychedelic rock-inspired dream pop released today on Epic Records.
Beer and Clampitt had just individually received the first test pressings of the set and after playing the album in full Beer went to bed. â€œThen, I woke up in the middle of the night and realized: â€˜This is not good enough,'â€ Beer tells Variety, recalling the â€œfull-blown meltdownâ€ that ultimately led her to return to the studio.
Before he picked up Beerâ€™s call, Clampitt had spent the night at a concert with the test pressings hidden away in his bag.
â€œI felt really weird carrying around like a bunch of vinyl, but I got home and I took a photo and sent it to her like â€˜Yo, look what I just got!â€™ and thatâ€™s when she told me she needed to talk,â€ he remembers. â€œShe felt so strongly about it and I trusted her; if she doesnâ€™t think itâ€™s right then we go back to the drawing board. We regained the idea together â€” went through what a new version might look like, what was working and what wasnâ€™t working.â€
Beer is grateful for the visceral feeling that drove her to rearrange the roots of her album, despite the fact that there is no distinctive method that can be used to decipher intuition from insecurity. But after years of producing music alongside a rotating list of label-picked songwriters and producers as a budding teenage pop star, Beerâ€™s desire for a long-time creative partner like Clampitt â€” who aside from producing, is also a songwriter and instrumentalist with a killer knack for guitar â€” was much needed.
The pair first met when Clampitt went by his former alias, Big Taste Double XL, which stunned Beer when she finally met the artist in person and realized he resembled more a ball of sunshine than a Double XL. Clampitt has been consistently working with Beer ever since 2018â€™s â€œHome With Youâ€ (her first charting single), and shares co-production credits with the pop star on â€œSilence,â€ as well as her 2021 album â€œLife Support.â€
Shortly after completing â€œLife Support,â€ Beer and Clampitt took a short journey out to Palm Springs to get away from the resurgence of the COVID virus and wrote the title track for â€œSilence,â€ which would go on to inspire much of the stripped-back lyricism found on the rest of the record. Around the same time, they had both begun obsessively listening to and absorbing the slow, sweet melodies found on the Beach Boysâ€™ 1966 record â€œPet Soundsâ€ and some of the Beatlesâ€™ psychedelic rock-leaning singles.
Take the acoustic guitar-oriented â€œRyder,â€ named after Beerâ€™s younger brother, which centers on their sibling dynamic and how her career impacted his life: â€œOur youth down the drain, and Iâ€™ll take all the blame,â€ she sings. She also touches on the estranged relationship she shares with her father for â€œKing of Everything,â€ which tackles touchy themes of resentment with metaphors like â€œBuilding castles in the sand / That crumble in your handsâ€¦ But no one gives a damn / When the rain comes pouring down / To wash away your crown.â€
â€œI had no idea what [the album] was going to turn into but when I make music, itâ€™s an ever-changing process,â€ adds Beer. â€œEven now, there are a few things that I would change but thatâ€™s just the kind of artist I amâ€¦ Iâ€™m never satisfied. However, Iâ€™m so proud of it and Iâ€™m going to ideally release another album within a year.â€
Madison Beer
Pictured above: Madison Beer in studio, strategizing the reconstruction of her album â€œSilence Between Songs.â€œ
After the restructuring, Beer ended up adding six new songs and scrapping an undisclosed number of songs that werenâ€™t originally on the first prints (among the new additions: â€œI Wonder,â€ â€œSweer Relief,â€ â€œNothing Matters But You,â€ â€œHome to Another One,â€ and â€œRyderâ€).
â€œI wanted people to be able to put headphones in and close their eyes and they could see everything,â€ says Beer, who has already released visual counterparts to â€œSpinninâ€ and â€œHome to Another One,â€ both of which build on feelings of otherworldly escapism. â€œWhen I listen to those songs, I can see movies â€” the colors and aesthetics and the videos perfectly capture the essence of my lyrics, the instrumentals â€” it all comes together then.â€
With a new tracklist in hand, Beer turned in her album once more and began sharing the music with her industry peers. Since jump-starting her career at 12 years old, thanks to a co-sign from Justin Bieber, Beerâ€™s circle of friends and mentors has only gotten bigger. She most recently linked up with Lana Del Rey, who told Beer what a big fan she was when they serendipitously ran into each other at a coffee shop.
â€œTo have someone like her say like, â€˜I think your album is beautiful,â€™ means the world to me,â€ says Beer who adds that Reyâ€™s favorite tracks were â€œRyderâ€ and â€œSpinnin.â€ â€œShe also taught me to not put so much pressure on myself when it comes to releasing music. I tend to overthink the timeline of my releases and sheâ€™s much more casual about it. I love making music and I want to release more, as I please. Iâ€™m excited for whatâ€™s in store.â€
Having dealt with a fair share of online criticism (when Bieber reposted videos of a beautiful, talented young Beer on his social media, much of his fanbase turned to attack her out of jealousy) and industry fall-outs (she was formerly managed by Bieberâ€™s longtime manager Scooter Braun), support from an established female figure like Rey means more than Beer can put into words â€” but she attempts to.
She praises fresh faces like Billie Eilish, Olivia Rodrigo, Melanie Martinez and Sabrina Carpenter for their artistry and success but at the same time, reminds herself to not get caught up in comparisons. â€œItâ€™s been a huge learning curve and what Iâ€™ve learned is that comparison is the thief of joy in every sense,â€ she says.
â€œFor a long time, I was someone who would compare myself: for example, when Billie first caught fire â€” it felt as though she had quickly popped off and was already 100,000 times more successful than me. I was jealous or upset by it but now, I couldnâ€™t be more proud of the work that I have out. Lanaâ€™s [co-sign] was definitely a breath of fresh air for me and I try to be the same with young artists coming up now â€“ a supporter or a voice of reason where I can be.â€
Beer is more eager than ever for the world to finally hear her in â€œSilence Between Songs,â€ and sheâ€™s even more pumped to take the record on the road at the beginning of 2024.

title: Sofia Coppola Hoped to Get Lana Del Rey for â€˜Priscillaâ€™ Soundtrack
content:
Lana Del Rey is not involved with the new film Priscilla, but director Sofia Coppola was open to the idea.
The Hollywood Reporter says the director first became aware of fans associating Elvis and Priscilla Presley with Del Rey â€” who has embodied Priscillaâ€™s â€™60s-style big hair and thick eyeliner throughout her career as an artist â€” while filming Priscilla.
â€œIâ€™m learning that people really connect Lana Del Rey and Priscilla and I didnâ€™t realize that, but I got a lot of requests with, â€˜How is she gonna be a part of the movie?â€™â€ Coppola said in a recent interview with E! News.
â€œWe were hoping she could do a song for it, but it didnâ€™t work out with the timing,â€ she explained.
Besides embodying Priscillaâ€™s style, Del Rey, known as a longtime fan of the Presleys, has referenced Elvis in her lyrics. She had a demo titled â€œElvisâ€ featured in Eugene Jareckiâ€™s Elvis documentary, The King, in 2017.
Coppola invited Del Rey to the Priscilla premiere, but the singer-songwriter couldnâ€™t attend. She says she is â€œexcited for her to see it.â€
The film is based on Priscillaâ€™s memoir, Elvis and Me, and follows the romance between Elvis and Priscilla, told from her perspective. It doesnâ€™t feature Elvisâ€™ actual music because Authentic Brands Group, the majority owner of Elvis Presley Enterprises, didnâ€™t accept Coppolaâ€™s offer for the rights.
â€œThey donâ€™t like projects that they havenâ€™t originated, and theyâ€™re protective of their brand,â€ Coppola told THR earlier this year. â€œBut that made us be more creative.â€
Although the late Lisa Marie Presley, who was the only child of Elvis and Priscilla, seemingly did not approve of the way her dad was depicted in Coppolaâ€™s script, Priscilla was moved by the project.
At the movieâ€™s Venice Film Festival showing, Priscilla embraced Coppola and wiped away tears during a standing ovation. â€œWe havenâ€™t talked specifically about the music, but she said, â€˜You did your homework,â€™ â€ Coppola told Billboard. â€œShe felt it was authentic, which was so important to me.â€
Priscilla, starring Cailee Spaeny and Jacob Elordi, is now playing in theaters.

title: Sofia Coppola reveals why Elvis Presley fan Lana Del Rey not featured in â€˜Priscillaâ€™
content:
Sofia Coppola reveals why Elvis Presley fan Lana Del Rey not featured in â€˜Priscillaâ€™
Filmmaker Sofia Coppola was hoping to rope in Elvis Presley fan, Lana Del Rey, to do a song for her newly-released film, Priscilla, but was unable to do so.
In an interview with E! News, Coppola shared how the Summertime Sadness songstress, 38, was nearly featured on the soundtrack.
â€œWe were hoping she could do a song for it, but it didnâ€™t work out with the timing,â€ the writer/director, 52, told the outlet in an on-camera interview.
Del Rey is known for her â€™70s-inspired bouffant hairstyle and cat eye eyeliner and her music also resonates with the era. Moreover, she famously sang â€œElvis is my daddyâ€ on her 2012 song Body Electric.
Coppola shared that many people pointed out how the Grammy-nominated singer has connection to the King of Rock and Roll.
â€œIâ€™m learning that people really connect Lana Del Rey and Priscilla and I didnâ€™t realise that, but I got a lot of requests with, â€˜How is she gonna be a part of the movie?â€™â€
Coppola added that she even â€œinvited her to the premiere,â€ even though she couldnâ€™t make it. She said, â€œIâ€™m excited for her to see it.â€
Priscilla, based on Priscillaâ€™s memoir Elvis and Me, stars Cailee Spaeny and Jacob Elordi, but notably doesnâ€™t feature music from the rock â€˜nâ€™ roll legend, as its usage was denied by his estate.

title: Lana Del Rey costume wearer runs into the real Lana Del Rey at a Halloween party
content:
(CNN) â€” It was wild when Lana Del Rey ran into Lana Del Rey.
Makeup artist Sandy Ganzer posted on Instagram Monday that she had dressed as the singer for a Halloween party, when, just like the most magical of Hollywood stories, the real Lana Del Rey showed up.
Ganzer went to the event as Del Reyâ€™s viral moment when she played at waitressing at an Alabama Waffle House over the summer.
â€œWaffle House employee shirt purchased on Ebay : $28.60. Pepsi bottle and fun little straw purchased last minute at CVS: $9. Waffle House â€œLanaâ€ name tag sticker: $5.59, Ganzer wrote in the caption, showing photos of her and Del Rey. â€œAttending a halloween party dressed as â€˜Lana Del Rey kickingâ€™ it at Waffle Houseâ€™ and sheâ€™s there in real life: Priceless.â€
She also thanked Del Rey for â€œhaving a sense of humor about it,â€ calling her a â€œqueenâ€ and noted that the Grammy-winning singer took the first two pictures Ganzer posted.
Del Rey explained in an interview last month how the photos of her at Waffle House came to be. She had been in Alabama visiting friends and had been to the restaurant several days in a row with her siblings,
â€œWe were on our third hour [that day], and the servers asked, â€˜Do you guys want shirts?â€™â€ she told The Hollywood Reporter. â€œHell yeah! We were thrilled.â€
She was also given a name tag and urged to wait on a regular, so she did. The resulting photos shared on social media exploded.
â€œI wish my album had gone as viral,â€ Del Rey said, jokingly. â€œI woke up to, like, 10,000 texts the next morning â€” some from folks I had not heard from for 10 years. â€˜Saw your picture at the Waffle House!â€™ [Laughing.] I was like, â€˜Did you hear the new album?â€™â€
This story was first published on CNN.com, "Lana Del Rey costume wearer runs into the real Lana Del Rey at a Halloween party"

title: Concertgoers Use iPhone 15 Zoom For 'Front Row Feeling' Amid High Ticket Prices
content:
Concertgoers are using the iPhone 15 zoom features for the â€œfront row experienceâ€ in viral TikTok videos.
The price of attending blockbuster concerts has reached astronomical heights, but Americans are still buying tickets even for worse seats. However, the iPhone 15 zoom is allowing concertgoers to work around this and get the close-up view they want.
TikTokers have been sharing how they were able to get a front row view with the iPhone 15 zoom at Lana Del Rey, Coldplay, Travis Scott, and Tate Mcrae concerts â€” despite having nosebleed seats.
In a TikTok video, with over 55.3 million views, TikToker Anthony Xavier films a Coldplay concert at the Rose Bowl stadium in Pasadena, California. He centers in on the band as they perform their hit song Paradise on stage.
The viewer is led to believe that Xavier has secured concert seats close to the stage and is filming Coldplay as she sees the band from his seating.
However, Xavier then dramatically and unexpectedly zooms out of his shot of Coldplay to reveal just how far away he is from the stage.
â€˜This Should Be an Ad For The iPhone 15â€™
In another video, that has over 2.6 million views, TikToker Jack films a Lana Del Rey concert at the MidFlorida Credit Union Amphitheatre in Tampa, Florida.
He sits a considerable distance away from the stage and is barely able to see Del Rey as she sings Chemtrails Over the Country Club.
However, the TikToker then reveals how he can achieve the â€œfront row feelingâ€ with his iPhone 15 Pro Max â€” as he smoothly zooms in with the smartphone camera to get a perfect close-up view of Del Rey.
Viewers insisted that Jackâ€™s footage â€œshould be an adâ€ for Appleâ€™s new smartphone.
In a similar TikTok video, Fitzroy Powell Jr. showed off his front row view with his iPhone 15 zoom at a Travis Scott concert in Spectrum Center Arena in North Carolina â€” despite being miles away from the stage.
â€˜Apple Users Donâ€™t Care About Samsungâ€™s Space Zoomâ€™
Likewise, in a TikTok video, that has racked up 2.4 million views, influencer Raina Baig said her iPhone 15 zoom â€œcame in clutchâ€ at a Tate Mcrae concert in Houston. Baig shows her impressive close-up view of the Greedy singer â€” even though she was far away.
Some viewers pointed out that â€œSamsung has been doing this for yearsâ€ â€” with its 100x Space Zoom. However, other TikTokers argued that â€œApple users donâ€™t care about Androidsâ€ and the iPhone 15â€™s new zoom capabilities were a â€œhuge dealâ€ for them.
In September, Apple introduced the iPhone 15 family of smartphones â€” with the iPhone 15 Pro Max featuring a tetraprism lens capable of 5x optical zoom.
The 5x optical zoom is an upgrade over the 3x zoom thatâ€™s available in the iPhone 15 Pro and the prior-generation iPhone 14. According to Apple, when the 5x optical zoom is enabled, users can also enable up to 25x digital zoom by pinching the viewfinder.
According to Billboard, concert tickets have reached sky-high prices as more shows increasingly implement dynamic pricing â€” which is a method of adjusting ticket costs based on demand. Dynamic pricing has been used by airlines and hotels for years and now live entertainment is getting in on the model, which can shoot up the cost of a ticket.
Image credits: Header photo sourced via TikTok/@anthony.xavier; via TikTok/@likeamrish ; TikTok/@rainabaig.

title: Pat McGrath talks Taylor Swift and her top makeup must-haves
content:
Page Six may be compensated and/or receive an affiliate commission if you buy through our links.
Whether sheâ€™s glamming up supermodels and stars or making an on-screen cameo in Taylor Swiftâ€™s â€œBejeweledâ€ video, Pat McGrath has long reigned as beauty-industry royalty.
In addition to creating looks for some of the most-Googled people on the planet, the makeup mastermind recently partnered with Google on augmented reality try-on tech, making it easier to seamlessly select Pat McGrath Labs shades while shopping online.
â€œThey were able to show me 10 different eyeshadows [on myself] in two seconds,â€ she tells Page Six Style. â€œThatâ€™s amazing. Can you imagine trying on 10 eyeshadows at home? That would take you forever.â€
Together, the beauty guru and Google created a New York City pop-up, â€œThe ARt of Beauty,â€ where shoppers can try out the tech from Oct. 20 to 22. (The experience is currently sold out, but limited walk-in space is available.)
A peek inside the Pat McGrath Labs x Google Beauty pop-up in NYC. Lester Ali
â€œYou can play without caution, have fun and try on shadows that you probably wouldnâ€™t try,â€ she tells us.
And when it comes to playing with products, â€œMotherâ€ (as McGrathâ€™s affectionately nicknamed in the industry) knows best; she tells us she gets â€œnonstop celebrity [product requests] all day, from all of our gorgeous fans.â€
Taylor Swift wore Pat McGrath Labs makeup in her â€œBejeweledâ€ video, which featured a cameo from the glam pro herself. Taylor Swift/VEVO
â€œTaylor [Swift] has a full kit of Pat McGrath Labs at home and she can do her own makeup beautifully,â€ adds the expert, who also worked with Lana Del Rey on her â€œwhole tour.â€
Hoping to make your own at-home makeup kit? McGrathâ€™s got you covered. While she famously travels with tons of products in tow â€” â€œas a woman who does 87 suitcases, I want to pick 20 [must-haves],â€ she quips â€” shop a selection of six of her absolute essentials below.
Courtesy of Pat McGrath
For those eyeing red carpet looks from the likes of Taylor Swift and Cardi B, this cult-classic palette is truly the mothership; it combines six of McGrathâ€™s most coveted shades, from statement-making sparkles to silky matte hues.
â€œObviously, No. 1 is shadows; everybody wants palettes,â€ McGrath tells us of the product famous folks request the most.
Courtesy of Pat McGrath
Want to shimmer like stars â€” or should we say, â€œStarshipsâ€? McGrathâ€™s must-haves also include this two-in-one glow go-to, which sheâ€™s previously used on celebrities like Nicki Minaj.
The â€œSuper Bassâ€ singer is a longtime devotee of the brand, as McGrath tells us, â€œWe just collaborated on her new album cover.â€
Courtesy of Pat McGrath
Also among McGrathâ€™s spotlight-ready essentials? This illuminating concealer, made to blur fine lines and provide an incandescent finish.
Pat McGrath Labs
While time is of the essence for busy multi-hyphenates, theyâ€™re not skipping skincare. â€œA lot [of stars are] asking for the Essence,â€ the makeup pro tells us of this lightweight emulsion, formulated to nourish, hydrate, and soften skin texture.
Pat McGrath Labs
The beauty legendâ€™s hero products also include this glossy cream blush stick that can also do double duty as lip color.
Pat McGrath Labs
Top off any beauty look in sparkling style with McGrathâ€™s go-to gloss, designed for â€œstained glass windowâ€- level shine.

title: What Brian Jordan Alvarez, the Guy Behind That Viral â€œSittingâ€ Song, Is Listening To
content:
Brian Jordan Alvarez is experiencing the craziest moment of his career thanks to a brief, improvised, and utterly silly song he recently sang into his phone about, well, sitting. â€œSitting is the opposite of standing,â€ starts the actor, who appeared in the Trump-era reboot of Will & Grace and the murder-doll film M3GAN, his unique vocal inflection morphing the titular word into something closer to â€œsittim.â€ â€œSittim is the opposite of runnim around.â€ The track shares the familiar sing-song melody of the Pocahontas classic â€œColors of the Wind,â€ and its lyrics are about as true as the sound of a wolf crying to a blue corn moon. â€œYou deserve to sit,â€ he sings at the songâ€™s conclusion. Itâ€™s a mantra for the ages.
TikTok content This content can also be viewed on the site it originates from.
He uploaded the video on September 10, and it has gone on to collect more than 3.5 million views across Instagram and TikTok. But the magic of the song and the intensity of its popularity are best illustrated by the countless fan versions that have popped up over the past month. An early dance remix created by producer Josh Mac has racked up nearly 450,000 streams on Spotify and was played on Australian radio. A video illustrating the actions described in the songâ€“sitting, running around, hanging from a barbellâ€“blew up too. And it is most definitely the only song in human history to be covered by Gen Z pop artist Remi Wolf, a Dutch singer who could be a Disney princess, and an AI version of the Talking Heads.
â€œSomething spiritual has happened with â€˜Sitting,â€™â€ Alvarez tells me. â€œThe whole experience with this song has been so communal. It requires that people get on board with something that appeals to a very particular sense of humor, and when you discover other people share that sense of humor, itâ€™s a special kind of connection. Itâ€™s like that Whitney Houston video, where she says people are singing her song at funerals. Thatâ€™s â€˜Sitting.â€™â€
To clarify, â€œSittingâ€ is the artistic creation of a character Alvarez invented named TJ Mack. (â€œThe artist performing as the artist,â€ he explains.) TJ Mack is an alternate-reality pop star whose face appears to be very Jaws-like thanks to a video filter. â€œTJ Mack is so cute,â€ Alvarez says. â€œI watch and enjoy all his videos as a fan because I kind of donâ€™t realize what Iâ€™m doing when I make them.â€ The oddball guise is one of many that Alvarez has dreamed up and posted to social media since 2020. His characters have made waves before: a grad student with an irresistible speech impediment, sometimes referred to as the Studempt, had a moment earlier this year. And thanks to the freakishly accurate Australian accent of muscle-bound buddies Rick and Vardy, Alvarez has been a favorite down under since 2021. But nothing has approached the popularity of â€œSitting.â€

title: Lana Del Rey Slams Hater for Accusing Her of Witchcraft: â€˜Gremlinâ€™
content:
Image Credit: Casey Flanigan/imageSPACE/Shutterstock
Lana Del Rey, 38, made sure to defend herself after an online hater accused her of witchcraft via Instagram, as reported by Stereogum on October 9. The â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ songstress took to the comments section via her Honeymoon Instagram account to clap back at a â€œChristianâ€ influencerâ€™s September 4 video. â€œB**** I know the Bible verse for verse better than you do,â€ Lana quipped. â€œPS youâ€™re giving off super gremlin energy. Not in a good way.â€
In the now-viral clip, the influencer named Traci Coston alleged that the 38-year-old practiced â€œwitchcraftâ€ during her recent tour. â€œLana Del Rey has been open about practicing witchcraft,â€ Traci claimed in the video. â€œWhatever witchcraft Del Rey is doing the spell sheâ€™s putting on her music to make it attractive those demons are being invited into the crowd and into you when you attend.â€ In addition, Traci added a video from one of Lanaâ€™s concerts this summer where a crowd fell due to a chain reaction. â€œThis is not normal,â€ she said.
Lana Del Rey claps back at woman accusing her of â€œdemonic energyâ€: â€œB!tch I know the Bible verse for verse better than you do. PS youâ€™re giving off super gremlin energy. Not in a good way.â€ pic.twitter.com/ScBL2UWmGw â€” Pop Crave (@PopCrave) October 9, 2023
More so, Traci then alleged that the â€œdemonsâ€ will â€œdestroy your life.â€ She claimed that her followers come to her for â€œdeliveranceâ€ to â€œget ridâ€ of the â€œdemonsâ€ that they â€œget through stuff like this.â€ She concluded the video by asking her followers to â€œgiveâ€ their â€œlifeâ€ to â€œJesusâ€ and to stop attending concerts like Lanaâ€™s.
Soon after the clip and Lanaâ€™s comments landed on social media, many of the musicianâ€˜s fans took to the comments to react. â€œLanaâ€™s Christian???â€ one admirer wrote in regards to Lanaâ€™s public churchgoing practices. â€œLana goes to church every Sunday !!â€ another fan clapped back, while a third added, â€œLanaâ€™s comeback game strong!â€
The Grammy-nominated artist has included spiritual and religious lyrics in her music over the years, including a quote from her pastor on â€œThe Grants.â€ The lyric opens her 2023 album, Did You Know that thereâ€™s a tunnel under Ocean Blvd, which was released in March. â€œMy pastor told me when you leave, all you take is your memories,â€ she belted out on the song.
Aside from the online drama, Lana recently opened up about her album during an interview with with The Hollywood Reporter. â€œI wish my album had gone as viral,â€ she said in reference to her viral Waffle House photos from the summer. â€œI woke up to, like, 10,000 texts the next morning â€” some from folks I had not heard from for 10 years. â€˜Saw your picture at the Waffle House!â€™ (Laughing.) I was like, â€˜Did you hear the new album?â€™â€

title: Lana Del Rey slams 'super gremlin' who accused her of having 'demonic energy'
content:
Click to email a link to a friend (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
Lana Del Rey clapped back at an internet troll after being accused of â€œpracticing witchcraftâ€ at one of her recent concerts.
The â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ singer defended herself on Instagram after a woman claimed she used her â€œdemonic energyâ€ to knock over a crowd of people during her show.
â€œWhatever witchcraft Lana Del Rey is doing, the spells she is putting on her music to make it attractive, those demons are being invited into the crowd and into you when you attend,â€ the woman alleged.
â€œThese demons will destroy your life.â€
The troll then tied her argument to the Bible, telling her followers to â€œstay awayâ€ from the Grammy winner.
4 The woman accused the singer of â€œpracticing witchcraftâ€ at a recent concert.
4 She claimed Del Rey was to blame for a group of concertgoers falling at the same time.
The social media user also included footage of concertgoers seemingly falling at the same time during Del Reyâ€™s set at a recent music festival.
While itâ€™s unclear what led the group to tumble, the songstress didnâ€™t seem to notice the incident and continued performing onstage.
For more Page Six you love â€¦
However, the 38-year-old singer â€” whose real name is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant â€” quick to shoot down the accusations after catching wind of the video.
â€œB!tch I know the Bible verse for verse better than you do,â€ Del Rey replied. â€œPS youâ€™re giving off super gremlin energy. Not in a good way.â€
4 In response, the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ songstress slammed the woman for giving off â€œsuper gremlin energy.â€ Peter Cruz / SplashNews.com
Although the woman disabled her comments after Del Reyâ€™s clapback, fans of the musician applauded the diss on Twitter.
â€œI hope she writes that into a song,â€ one user wrote, while another added, â€œQUEEN DIDNT HAVE TO END HER LIKE THAT.â€
â€œyeah they accused her because its not humanly possible to have a voice that sweet ğŸ’¯,â€ joked a third.
While Del Rey has denied casting spells on her fans, the songstress once jokingly tried to cast a spell on Donald Trump to end his presidency.
4 â€œB!tch I know the Bible verse for verse better than you do,â€ Del Rey clapped back. ZUMAPRESS.com
Meanwhile, the â€œYoung and Beautifulâ€ singer recently wrapped a 10-date mini tour to celebrate her latest album, â€œDid You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd.â€
She did not disappoint when she returned to the stage in May for her first full concert in nearly four years.
Del Rey shocked the audience when she came out in a short, curly blonde wig â€” channeling her inner Marilyn Monroe. She took inspiration from the Hollywood icon again that month for her â€œCandy Necklaceâ€ music video.

title: Les studios Rue Boyer, une audacieuse montÃ©e en gammes
content:
ReportageLana Del Rey, Pharrell Williams, Kid Cudiâ€¦ A Paris, les studios Rue Boyer ne sont ouverts que depuis janvier, mais de grands noms de la musique sâ€™y succÃ¨dent dÃ©jÃ . ConÃ§u par Maxime Le Guil et Victor LÃ©vy-Lasne dans un esprit Ã  la fois seventies et moderne, lâ€™endroit dispose dâ€™un matÃ©riel dâ€™enregistrement et dâ€™une acoustique hors pair.
Un matin de dÃ©cembre 2022, rue Boyer, dans le 20áµ‰ arrondissement de Paris. Dans cette rue qui accueille les salles de concerts La Bellevilloise et La Maroquinerie, RosalÃ­a attend devant une porte blanche. A quelques jours dâ€™un concert Ã  lâ€™Accor Arena de Bercy, la chanteuse espagnole sâ€™affaire dans ce bÃ¢timent, un studio de musique, dont la dÃ©coration oscille entre lâ€™hÃ´tel de luxe et lâ€™appartement ornÃ© de piÃ¨ces chinÃ©es. Elle y restera deux jours dâ€™affilÃ©e, notamment pour enregistrer le tube Beso.
Un mois plus tard, les studios Rue Boyer ouvrent officiellement. Ce bÃ¢timent de 500 mÃ¨tres carrÃ©s, invisible depuis la rue, a accueilli depuis les artistes amÃ©ricains Kid Cudi, Pusha T ou encore Pharrell Williams. Et mÃªme, en un sens, BeyoncÃ©, puisque Stuart White, son arrangeur sonore, y a effectuÃ© le mixage pour sa derniÃ¨re tournÃ©e mondiale, le Renaissance World Tour. Ceci en moins dâ€™un an et demi : Â« On ne sâ€™attendait pas Ã  une telle effervescence, dâ€™autant plus que la dÃ©co du studio nâ€™Ã©tait mÃªme pas terminÃ©e Â», sâ€™Ã©tonne Victor LÃ©vy-Lasne, lâ€™un des deux crÃ©ateurs.
Lâ€™inspiration est celle des studios emblÃ©matiques, Ã  la maniÃ¨re du Miraval, dans le Var. Lâ€™atmosphÃ¨re est boisÃ©e. Les couleurs sont chaudes. Quant aux meubles, on croit trouver des influences des annÃ©es 1970. Un lieu chaleureux qui est devenu un passage obligÃ© pour les musiciens en escale dans la capitale. Et ce, dans un contexte oÃ¹ les studios de musique ferment tour Ã  tour Ã  Paris.
Rien ne se passe comme prÃ©vu
IngÃ©nieurs de formation, Victor LÃ©vy-Lasne et Maxime Le Guil, tous deux Ã¢gÃ©s de 35 ans, se rencontrent en 2006, durant leurs Ã©tudes supÃ©rieures Ã  lâ€™Ecole centrale de Lyon. Ils forment Mix with the Masters quatre ans plus tard, programme de master class et de sÃ©minaires musicaux qui rÃ©unit le plus grand nombre de professionnels du secteur, allant des ingÃ©nieurs aux producteurs.
Ils se constituent ainsi un rÃ©seau au-delÃ  des frontiÃ¨res et dÃ©veloppent leur passion pour le son, lâ€™Ã©nergique Maxime Le Guil Ã©tant dÃ©jÃ  mixeur et rÃ©alisateur dâ€™albums. Â« On a toujours Ã©tÃ© passionnÃ©s par le travail du son. Un bon matos, le moindre cÃ¢ble, est aujourdâ€™hui important : cela permet de contrÃ´ler les dÃ©tails dâ€™une production. On a donc voulu crÃ©er un lieu Ã  Paris, Ã  partir de tout ce quâ€™on a appris, Ã  la pointe de la technique en matiÃ¨re dâ€™enregistrement sonore Â», se souvient ce dernier.
Les deux crÃ©ateurs des Studios Rue Boyer, Maxime Le Guil (Ã  gauche) et Victor LÃ©vy-Lasne, Ã  Paris, le 20 novembre 2023. STÃ©PHANE RUCHAUD POUR M LE MAGAZINE DU MONDE
En 2016, leur vient lâ€™idÃ©e de centraliser leurs activitÃ©s autour dâ€™un studio. Ils se mettent Ã  la recherche dâ€™un fonds de commerce, avec plusieurs caractÃ©ristiques : intra muros, mal isolÃ©, en mauvais Ã©tat. Â« On a aussi des compÃ©tences en ingÃ©nierie du bÃ¢timent quâ€™on voulait mettre en Å“uvre. On cherchait un endroit oÃ¹ tout Ã©tait Ã  refaire Â», raconte de son cÃ´tÃ© Victor LÃ©vy-Lasne. Ils trouvent cet ancien atelier dÃ©saffectÃ©, mais rien ne se passe comme prÃ©vu. Entre les entrepreneurs peu scrupuleux et les travaux qui prennent plus de temps que prÃ©vu, quatre ans passent.

title: Lana Del Rey Covers John Denverâ€™s Classic â€œTake Me Home, Country Roadsâ€: Listen
content:
Lana Del Rey has just shared a surprise one-off cover of the John Denver standard â€œTake Me Home, Country Roads.â€ Give it a listen below.
This fall, Del Rey went on a U.S. tour focusing on the South and Appalachia. The run ended in West Virginiaâ€™s capitol, Charleston. She recently covered another American classic: â€œUnchained Melody.â€ She performed it at Graceland for a televised holiday special.
In 2024, she could pick up her first Grammy win. Sheâ€™s up for Album of the Year, Song of the Year, Best Alternative Music Performance, Best Pop Duo/Group Performance, and Best Alternative Music Album. The nominations are largely for Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd and the single â€œA&W.â€

content:

Todas las columnas de opiniÃ³n de personas ajenas a la RedacciÃ³n de EL PAÃS llevarÃ¡n, tras la Ãºltima lÃ­nea, un pie de autor â€”por conocido que Ã©ste seaâ€” donde se indique el cargo, tÃ­tulo, militancia polÃ­tica (en su caso) u ocupaciÃ³n principal, o la que estÃ© o estuvo relacionada con el tema abordado
Mâ€™agradaria parlar amb la meva Ã via sobre Lana del Rey. No mâ€™haguÃ©s estat difÃ­cil aconseguir que pugÃ©s al tren de lâ€™adoraciÃ³. Del Rey reuneix molts dels atributs que segons el seu criteri feien que un artista fos digne dâ€™interÃ¨s. Ã‰s viva (no com lâ€™execrable Picasso); nord-americana (sempre un element a favor); i tÃ© un Ã¨xit monumental fent en tot moment el que li rota. Escoltar-la amb intenciÃ³ Ã©s una experiÃ¨ncia forÃ§a similar a la missa, la pregÃ ria o la meditaciÃ³ zen, tot dâ€™experiÃ¨ncies que duen el seu segell dâ€™aprovaciÃ³.
No em cal mirar lâ€™Spotify wrapped per saber que la meva canÃ§Ã³ mÃ©s escoltada dels Ãºltims temps ha estat The Grants. Grant Ã©s el cognom familiar real de Del Rey, i la canÃ§Ã³ Ã©s un gospel a la familia, la mort i la memÃ²ria. Les veus a capella del principi podrien ser el cor dâ€™una esglÃ©sia evangelista. â€œEl meu pastor em va dir/Que quan marxem lâ€™Ãºnic que ens enduem/SÃ³n els nostres records/I jo mâ€™endurÃ© els teus (o els vostres) amb miâ€. TambÃ© es podria llegir com lâ€™intent de preservar a la memÃ²ria un amor perdut â€”que el you sigui alhora plural i singular facilita lâ€™ambigÃ¼itatâ€” perÃ² la distinciÃ³ no Ã©s massa rellevant. Del Rey parla de lâ€™amor com un absolut, i vol preservar el record dels qui estima fins i tot desprÃ©s de la mort.
A Did you know that thereâ€™s a tunnel under Ocean Blvd, la canÃ§Ã³ que dÃ³na nom al disc, la preocupaciÃ³ personal per lâ€™oblit i la permanÃ¨ncia ressona per la histÃ²ria dels Estats Units. Del Rey evoca un tÃºnel abandonat amb â€œsostres de mosaic i rajoles pintades a terraâ€, una relÃ­quia dels anys vint ara tapiada que travessava lâ€™Ocean Boulevard i desembocava a la platja. Es pregunta quan arribarÃ  el seu torn de caure en lâ€™oblit. El donâ€™t forget me (â€œno mâ€™oblidisâ€) que ressona amb intensitat creixent contÃ© el terror lÃºcid de saber-se transitÃ²ria com el tÃºnel: prega al seu pÃºblic (al seu amant?) que no la deixi enrere com ho ha fet amb aquell tros del passat de Los Ãngeles.
Potser per temperament, comparteixo lâ€™obsessiÃ³ de Del Rey per lâ€™oblit, i per aixÃ² la malaltia mÃ©s terrorÃ­fica sempre mâ€™ha semblat lâ€™Alzheimer. Especialment des que vaig comenÃ§ar a veure com prenia els records a la meva Ã via, ens convertia als seus familiars en desconeguts, i lâ€™abocava a una decadÃ¨ncia lenta. Una terapeuta em va arribar a dir que la neurosi sentimental que mâ€™ocupava en aquell moment era nomÃ©s un mecanisme dâ€™evasiÃ³ per no haver-me dâ€™enfrontar al seu rÃ pid declivi; de la mateixa manera que en els seus Ãºltims dies de vida mâ€™he distret escrivint un article.
A The Grants, els records que planeja endur-se Del Rey inclouen â€œla primera filla de la meva germanaâ€ i â€œlâ€™Ãºltim somriure de la meva Ã viaâ€. El fil que conecta la besÃ via amb la neboda Ã©s la lÃ­nea de vida a la qual sâ€™aferra com una liana cap al mÃ©s enllÃ . Si hi fos a temps, li diria a la meva Ã via que la veig cada dia als ulls de la meva filla; que el fil continua, com en lâ€™himne de Lana del Rey, que tant bÃ© li haguÃ©s caigut.

title: AbgehÃ¶rt 2023: Das ist die beste Musik des Jahres
content: Dass Kunst aus Schmerz geboren wird, ist ein Klischee, aber im Falle des walisischen Rappers und Musikers Ren Gill trifft es zu: Mehr als zehn Jahre lang lag die kÃ¼nstlerische Arbeit des heute 33-JÃ¤hrigen brach, weil er sich mit den Folgen einer Borreliose-Infektion plagte, kÃ¶rperliche Qualen, Depressionen und Fatigue-Syndrom inklusive. Seine Erlebnisse mit Psychose und Pein, aber auch den ignoranten Umgang der Gesellschaft damit, verarbeitete er nun so virtuos und mitreiÃŸend selbstironisch, dass es ihm im Oktober ohne UnterstÃ¼tzung eines groÃŸen Labels gelang, den Spitzenplatz der britischen Charts zu erobern. Ren rappt auch kapitalismuskritische Epen wie Â»Money Game Pt. 3Â« so rasant und geschliffen, dass sein Flow an Eminem erinnert. Die Bandbreite seiner Musik, zum groÃŸen Teil selbst eingespielt und produziert, reicht von Folklore Ã¼ber Elektropunk und Ragga bis zu Ed-Sheeran-artigem Pop (Â»Suic*deÂ«). Das Genre Hip-Hop scheint schon jetzt zu eng fÃ¼r ein Talent, das sich nun ungehemmt Bahn brechen kann. Dieser Â»Sick BoiÂ« ist die Entdeckung des Jahres.
