title: â€˜Criticism doesnâ€™t keep me up at nightâ€™: superproducer Jack Antonoff on his haters - and Taylor Swiftâ€™s greatness
content:
Jack Antonoff is fewer than 24 hours into his flying visit to London from New York to talk about his new album as Bleachers, but trying to hold his attention as we eat in the celeb hotspot and luxury hotel Chiltern Firehouse is like trying to handle a dodgem. He becomes preoccupied by an abandoned baseball cap, my beer and the transmission risk of the packed dining room. â€œDo people still get Covid?â€ he asks. â€œShall we go outside?â€ (It is freezing.) He frets about â€œambient noiseâ€ affecting my recorder, looking at the couple next to us and the empty table a little further away. â€œDo you want to tell them to go over there? I couldnâ€™t, but you could,â€ he says, laughing.
He is certainly jetlagged, but otherwise itâ€™s hard to identify the source of his twitchiness. It could be down to the playful neuroticism that Antonoff wears on his sleeve in his music with the Springsteen-inspired, selfâ€‘mythologising Bleachers; maybe itâ€™s selfâ€‘consciousness about his celebrity status as a pop superproducer who works with Taylor Swift, Lana Del Rey, Lorde, St Vincent, the 1975 and more. At one point, we find ourselves playing a therapy-style word-association game, which is also how Antonoff approaches his songwriting. â€œMother,â€ I say. â€œWant!â€ Antonoff says, instantly. We are both horrified. â€œPaging Dr Freud!â€ says Antonoff.
For all his hair-trigger attention and frequent digressions, Antonoff is great company, lending weight to the online theory â€“ one of many put forward to explain his popularity with popâ€™s leading ladies â€“ that he â€œmust be an incredibly good hangâ€. A New Jersey muso who crept up through the 00s in the little-known indie-rock band Steel Train, in 2008 he joined Fun, who became one-hit wonders with the Queen-aping We Are Young in 2011. His production career started a year later with the Canadian pop stars Carly Rae Jepsen and Tegan and Sara.
Modern Girl, the first single from the new album.
He began to grace the tabloids thanks to what would become a five-year relationship with the Girls auteur Lena Dunham; meanwhile, Swift invited him to collaborate on her 2014 pop breakthrough, 1989, minting his credentials. Antonoff later produced half of the 2017 follow-up, Reputation. â€œSome people didnâ€™t get it and, at the time, I remember thinking: â€˜If you donâ€™t get this, then I donâ€™t know how to help you,â€™â€ he says. â€œâ€˜Because this is sick.â€™â€
In conversation, Antonoff generates so much energy that I am reminded of the scene from Swiftâ€™s 2020 documentary Miss Americana in which she and Antonoff conjure Reputationâ€™s Getaway Car out of thin air in minutes. As a record of creative chemistry, itâ€™s on par with the Beatles landing on Get Back in Peter Jacksonâ€™s film.
But despite Antonoffâ€™s success in shaping the sound of the past decade, he is a polarising figure. While prized by his peers, he has been held responsible for what fans of those artists perceive as underwhelming records â€“ Lordeâ€™s low-key 2021 album Solar Power, say â€“ as well as similarities between their sounds. This is despite his wide-ranging credits â€“ Florence + the Machine, the Chicks, Grimes, Pink, Troye Sivan, Diana Ross and Spoon â€“ and the obvious differences between Del Reyâ€™s smouldering modern standards and St Vincentâ€™s S&M disco.
Critics have derided the tastefulness of his production. A viral essay in July coined it â€œAntonofficationâ€, referring to the â€œhollow, cinematic bignessâ€ in which Antonoffâ€™s work is supposedly steeped. Max Martin and Rick Rubin have influenced pop to the same degree, if not more, but itâ€™s hard to think of any producer, past or present, who provokes such strong opinions as Antonoff. Bleachers, meanwhile, have received a middling critical response. The tenor of the coverage of his career, as the New Yorker put it, is: â€œWhy him?â€
On stage in New Jersey with Taylor Swift on her Eras tour. Photograph: Kevin Mazur/TAS23/Getty Images for TAS Rights Management
Antonoff is all too conscious of these conversations. â€œBecause I do a few things, it becomes hard â€“ rightfully â€“ for people to understand it,â€ he says. He describes the coverage as â€œtrying to put the whole thing together â€¦ an endless labyrinth of how Iâ€™m doing it. The work is the work; thatâ€™s not really for me to define.â€
But he is impatient with the criticism that his work sounds alike. â€œDoes anyone think thatâ€™s true?â€ The same critics â€œalways put my work on their best-of listsâ€, he says. Even the assertion that he is suddenly everywhere obscures the fact that he rarely produces an album in full. â€œSometimes, Iâ€™ll even start to believe the reflection of me,â€ he says. â€œYou get to a point where you start to connect the red yarn and you realise: thereâ€™s no there there,â€ he says, gesticulating like a conspiracist joining the dots. Regarding the criticism, he says: â€œI do think that thereâ€™s a remarkable amount of regurgitated ideas.â€ But he has become accustomed to being misunderstood: â€œIt doesnâ€™t keep me up at night.â€
While Antonoff can ignore the criticsâ€™ view, the new Bleachers album â€“ his first for the 1975â€™s label, Dirty Hit â€“ finds him reckoning with what he has spent a lifetime perceiving in the mirror. To date, the Bleachers project has been about Antonoffâ€™s conception of himself as a bereaved person. His younger sister, Sarah, died from brain cancer at 13 in 2001. Then came 9/11 and the Iraq war, in which Antonoffâ€™s cousin was killed. Antonoff, then 18 and already making headway in the music industry, was profoundly changed by it all.
Iâ€™ve been so hesitant about cleaning up certain parts of my life because it would affect the work
Now 39, Antonoff says he wanted to explore how to make room in his life for more than his defining losses. His starting point for the album, entitled Bleachers, was his notion of â€œtribute livingâ€, a term he coined to describe living for a late loved one. â€œIt was about a character â€“ myself, when I was sort of stuck â€“ who wants to find something outside of this living-in-tribute, where every move in oneâ€™s life is for the person who canâ€™t be here.â€ But what he actually wrote were â€œsongs that were extremely present. I started to see my writing not beyond, but in addition to, the lens of grief.â€
Bleachersâ€™ past three albums hurtled forward on the steam of carpe diem, replete with shotguns, rollercoasters, heart attacks and open highways â€“ the cinematic potential of love and loss. The titles speak for themselves: Donâ€™t Take the Money, Letâ€™s Get Married, I Wanna Get Better, Hate That You Know Me, How Dare You Want More. In Bleachersâ€™ world, there is no declaration that isnâ€™t best screamed outside someoneâ€™s bedroom window, no disagreement that canâ€™t be litigated in the pouring rain.
The new album paints a more peaceful and, by Antonoffâ€™s own admission, mature picture of love. In August, he married Margaret Qualley, the Maid actor (and daughter of Andie MacDowell). (Swift reportedly gave a â€œraucousâ€ 15-minute speech at the wedding.) On Jesus Is Dead, Antonoff sings of retreating into domestic bliss, watching Phantom Thread while the world outside wobbles on its axis. Me Before You is a soft, Streets-of-Philadelphia-style song about the personal growth needed to begin a meaningful relationship, contrasting Antonoffâ€™s historical emotional drama with his contentment at Qualley asking him when he will be home for dinner. Itâ€™s a quieter and more spacious album, with less of Bleachersâ€™ trademark thundering drums and 80s reverb. Antonoff even sings in a lower register, his trademark battle-cry choruses reduced to a faraway shout.
With his wife, the actor Margaret Qualley, at the Grammys in 2022. Photograph: Emma McIntyre/Getty Images for The Recording Academy
His past view of love wasnâ€™t just emotionally immature, Antonoff says, with the pop-eyed horror of someone confronting his former self: â€œIt was emotionally fucked. When I was 20 years old, my brain was on fire. I was really messy, emotionally. What I know now is this: if something in your gut says no, then itâ€™s no. But I didnâ€™t see anyone that was giving me all yesses.â€ He was led astray by cultural scripts characterising fighting as passion, or ambivalence as the best outcome. He channelled that into tortured artistry, attaching â€œromanticismâ€ to working all-nighters â€“ culminating in him being hospitalised with life-threatening pneumonia when he was 26. â€œIâ€™ve been so hesitant about cleaning up certain parts of my life because it would affect the work,â€ he says.
He has only recently unpicked the impact of his upbringing on his approach to relationships and his parentsâ€™ â€œcomplexâ€ marriage. His grief over Sarahâ€™s death had become a catch-all justification for his dissatisfaction. Meeting Qualley, and making this album, showed him that he didnâ€™t need to sacrifice contentment for creativity. â€œThe most inspiring thing is when you meet someone and you truly just want for them to be so happy,â€ says Antonoff. â€œItâ€™s not simple â€“ itâ€™s huge, itâ€™s controversial and itâ€™s wild â€“ but itâ€™s simple in how easy it is.â€
The shift is captured in a line in Bleachersâ€™ new single with Del Rey, Alma Mater, in which the pair â€œjoke about blowing town tonightâ€. In the past, I suggest, he would have had the car packed and ready to go. â€œItâ€™s so true,â€ Antonoff says. â€œLike, weâ€™re blowing town, weâ€™ve got a picture of your mother in the backseat and she was fucking awful to you â€“ but, nonetheless, there she is!â€ (The song represents what it feels like to collaborate with Del Rey, says Antonoff: â€œYou can hear paper noise, a bit of us talking, breathing â€“ it just feels like the room.â€)
He returns to my characterisation of his intensity, what he calls â€œthe rheumatoid arthritis grip, trying to capture a moment, the heaviness of all of itâ€. He hadnâ€™t thought about it that way before, he says. â€œThe truth is, when you make records, youâ€™re not thinking about it at all â€“ because if you are, you know what it is and itâ€™s not interesting. All of the songs that Iâ€™ve ever written, they feel like something that scares me and is really deep, and Iâ€™m figuring out as Iâ€™m doing it.â€
The new album is more conversational, outward-looking and even funny. Modern Girl evokes We Didnâ€™t Start the Fire with its rapid-fire dissection of modern life, freewheeling around a joyful saxophone riff. Antonoff takes umbrage at my Billy Joel comparison (â€œYou could easily have said End of the World As We Know It, which would have been preferableâ€), but agrees that this record feels like a step in the direction he wants to travel. â€œAre you calling it an arrival? Do you dare?â€ he jokes. â€œIt feels like an arrival to me.â€ Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s self-titled, he says, with evident pride.
â€˜Sincerity is something that we try to beat out of people to see if theyâ€™re real.â€™ Photograph: Alex Lockett
But if Antonoff feels as if he has changed, it remains to be seen whether the popular view of him will adapt in turn. Swifties have already seized upon the track list for the new album, reading Hey Joe as a paean to Swiftâ€™s recent ex, the British actor Joe Alwyn. â€œThereâ€™s a community of people that will be preeetty disappointed when they find out itâ€™s a meditation on my father and his friends walking the Ho Chi Minh trail in their 60s,â€ he says, smiling.
Antonoffâ€™s disdain is reserved for this kind of superficial misinterpretation and the platforms fuelling it. He cites streaming services bringing back live broadcasts and weekly episodes. â€œMost disruption is to break something to remake it exactly as it was,â€ he says. â€œGive us better food, find a way so that plastic isnâ€™t in everything we eat. Find a way to correct all the horrible injustice in our world. Please donâ€™t offer me 7,000 more ways to release an album or watch a movie. I am all for every machination of expression of art, as long as itâ€™s coming from an artist.â€
Modern Girl riffs on these contradictions and absurdities. A â€œbig culture roastâ€, it was inspired by the contrast he saw between the sober narration of these times, online and in the media, and what he observed around him. â€œI walk around New York City and I just see people fucking and fighting, basically.â€
All of the songs that Iâ€™ve ever written, they feel like something that scares me
It could sound condescending, but Antonoff says itâ€™s the pandering to which he objects â€“ the absence of â€œjust the least bit of wonderâ€. I get a sense of the instincts and acuity that have made him a sought-after producer; coupled with an idealist streak, maybe itâ€™s this that has made him a target of cynicism and even suspicion. The common threads through his work, I suggest, are sincerity, earnestness and emotion â€“ three things with which we have an uncomfortable relationship. â€œYeah â€“ Iâ€™m not kidding,â€ says Antonoff, through a mouthful of fried chicken. â€œPeople think I am, but not about the work.â€ He agrees that we have almost no tolerance for sincerity. â€œWe do crazy cultural due diligence to make sure itâ€™s real. Thatâ€™s why context is everything. I do feel like sincerity is something that we try to beat out of people as a means to see if theyâ€™re real.â€
Antonoff addresses this impulse on new song Self Respect. Based on a line written by Florence Welch, it expresses his weariness at the demands on him to be coherent and consistent. Itâ€™s knowing, he says. â€œIâ€™m tired of having self-respect in the way that anyone else defines it but me. I just want to get messy. I want to be happy and healthy and aware and here â€“ but I also want to live my life, and I donâ€™t want to spend my time a) denying myself things or b) expressing my moral superiority.â€
He is adamant that he has no specific ambitions, nor fears of his superproducer era coming to an end, calling it â€œan interesting conversation for someone else to haveâ€. Antonoffâ€™s only concern is â€œjust to beâ€, he says â€“ to focus on what he can control in his work and what really matters outside it. â€œIâ€™m just looking for that feeling â€“ I spend most of my days carving shit away to get to that.â€

title: Liam Gallagher, Fred Again and Lana Del Rey confirmed to headline Leeds and Reading Festival 2024
content:
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Invalid email Something went wrong, please try again later.
Subscribe to our daily What's On newsletter to keep up with what's happening around Greater Manchester
Something went wrong, please try again later.
Subscribe to our daily What's On newsletter to keep up with what's happening around Greater Manchester
Liam Gallagher, Fred Again and Lana Del Rey are among the artists set to headline Reading and Leeds Festivals 2024, it has been announced.
At the sister festivals, Britpop star Liam, 51, will mark the 30th anniversary of Oasisâ€™ debut album Definitely Maybe by performing the record in full. Indie rock band Catfish And The Bottlemen, American pop-punk outfit Blink-182 and Scottish singer Gerry Cinnamon will also top the bill for 2024.
Among the other acts announced on Thursday (November 23) are Mercury Prize nominee Raye, American DJ Skrillex, band Spiritbox and rapper Digga D. Mercury Prize nominee producer and DJ Fred Again said this will be â€œthe only UK festival Iâ€™m playing next year and is the first festival I ever went toâ€. He headlined Parklife Festival at Heaton Park in June this year.
READ MORE: Girls Aloud tell fans 'buckle up' as they reveal how long they kept tour under wraps and share fresh details
READ MORE: The Lottery Winners forced to postpone upcoming tour shows after 'tragic news'
Lana, who will headline for the first time, and Blink-182, who are returning to the festivals for the first time in a decade, will also not play any other UK festivals next year. Meanwhile Liam's headline set will see him return to the music festivals following performances in 2017 and headline sets in 2021.
Speaking about the announcement, Liam, who will perform his solo work alongside Oasisâ€™ greatest hits, said: â€œIâ€™m gonna be playing Reading & Leeds, the most RnR (Rock nâ€™ Roll) festivals we have left in the UK. Be there or be square LGxâ€.
(Image: Joseph Okpako/WireImage)
Also making a return are bands including Catfish And The Bottlemen, who last performed in 2021. The band and frontman Van McCann have not released any new music since 2019, with rumours of a comeback circulating online only months ago.
Melvin Benn, managing director of promoter Festival Republic, said: â€œWe are thrilled to announce the first wave of artists for Reading and Leeds 2024. I am very proud that the biggest artists in the world choose to play Reading and Leeds and to have three incredible UK festival exclusives â€“ the electrifying Fred again, a true generational talent Lana Del Ray and the legendary Blink-182.
â€œThe iconic Liam Gallagher will return to play an all-time classic album Definitely Maybe which will be a special moment indeed. We pride ourselves on nurturing artists from the early stages in their career, so to see acts like Catfish And The Bottlemen rising through the festival to headline for the second time is very rewarding.
Join our WhatsApp Top Stories and Breaking News group by clicking this link
â€œ2023 was a hugely successful year for attendance and sensational audience feedback, and we are eager to build upon this success even further at the UKâ€™s biggest and best music festival.â€
Tickets for the three-day event, taking place between August 21 and 25, will go on general sale next Thursday (November 30). Tickets for existing Barclaycard and Three customers will go on pre-sale at 8.30am on Tuesday November 28, and weekend and day tickets go on general sale at 8.30am on Thursday November 30 on the respective Reading and Leeds ticketing websites.

title: My ex had a 'little bubble ego'
content:

Sheâ€™s no Sad Girl.
Lana Del Rey has revealed that sheâ€™s single again â€” just months after her engagement to music manager and musician Evan Winiker came to light.
In the December cover story for Harperâ€™s Bazaar, the â€œRideâ€ hitmaker, 38, said that one of her exes had an ego problem that caused the demise of their relationship.
Specifically, Del Rey said the simplicity of her house became an â€œaccidentalâ€ litmus test for her significant others.
â€œWe had some fights over this house, a couple people,â€ the â€œCandy Necklaceâ€ singer told the outlet. â€œThey didnâ€™t get it.â€
Del Rey, whose real name is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, said a recent boyfriend of hers â€œdidnâ€™t getâ€ her home.
â€œI feel like even the most chill guy doesnâ€™t really want to chill here,â€ she told the publication. â€œSadly, part of you knows â€¦ that ainâ€™t it. â€¦ That one shocked me.â€
â€œI wonâ€™t name names and whatever, but that one really shocked me, that person. That was actually the end of a relationship.â€

The â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ hitmaker said her ex liked the â€œidea of herâ€ â€” but not who she actually is.
â€œThatâ€™s a tough nut to swallow,â€ she said. â€œIn that personâ€™s case, there was something going on with them, like a little bubble ego. See, I donâ€™t get to have one anymore. Itâ€™s been smashed to â€¦ what do you call it? Smithereens. Iâ€™m sure itâ€™s somewhere in my toe. Thatâ€™s it. Iâ€™d love to grow one.â€
â€œIâ€™m learning how. Iâ€™m learning. I know what I want,â€ she added.

The â€œFishtailâ€ singer sparked engagement rumors in March after she was seen wearing a huge diamond sparkler at the Billboard Women in Music event.
Prior to her ill-fated romance with Winiker, the singer, whose latest album â€œDid You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvdâ€ was released in March, was romantically linked to musician Jack Donaghue.
Del Rey was rumored to be dating the Salem frontman for a few months in early 2022, although the exact timeline of their relationship remains unclear.
Prior to that, she was in a relationship with country singer Clayton Johnson after they met on a dating app in 2020.

They were rumored to be engaged later that year, but ultimately called it quits and did not address the breakup.

She then dated Italian photographer Francesco Carrozzini from 2014 until 2015 before enjoying a brief romance with rapper G-Eazy in 2017.
She also dated cop Sean â€œSticksâ€ Larkin and even hit the 2020 Grammys red carpet with him. However, it was not to last, and they broke up just months later.

title: Lana Del Rey Was â€˜All Overâ€™ Taylor Swiftâ€™s Snow on the Beach
content:
Photo-Illustration: Vulture ; Photos: Getty Images
By now, the world doesnâ€™t need any more proof that Lana Del Rey is a musical genius. Have you heard â€œA&Wâ€? So we never should have doubted that there was actually a reason why Del Reyâ€™s vocals were so quiet for her feature on Taylor Swiftâ€™s â€œSnow on the Beach,â€ as Del Rey explained to Harperâ€™s Bazaar. â€œIf I think somebodyâ€™s song is perfect, I will act as a producer in it,â€ she said. â€œI can mimic almost anyone. So I am all over the first version of â€˜Snow on the Beach,â€™ but I layer and match her vocals perfectly, so you would never even know that I was completely all over that first song. She wanted me to sing the whole thing, but if it ainâ€™t broke, donâ€™t fix it!â€ There you have it: Del Rey is just so good that we couldnâ€™t even distinguish her voice from Swiftâ€™s. (You could say she was singing unbeknownst to us.) And it sounds like she didnâ€™t even think she needed to come back for the â€œMore Lanaâ€ version. Next time, just let the master do her thing!

title: Lana Del Rey Talks â€˜Notâ€™ Being â€˜In Loveâ€™ 8 Months After Engagement
content:
Image Credit: Collier Schorr
Eight months after news broke that Lana Del Rey, 38, reportedly got engaged to Evan Winiker, the pop music sensation revealed that she is no longer â€œin loveâ€ during an interview for Harperâ€™s BAZAARâ€˜s Art Issue. Although the Grammy-nominated songstress refused to â€œname names,â€ Lana did drop a few bombshells about her love life during the November 21 interview. â€œIâ€™m definitely not in love right now. No,â€ she explained. â€œAbsolutely not in love. Have been, but no.â€
The â€œCinnamon Girlâ€ hitmaker went on to admit that she hasnâ€™t thought about love since July. â€œWell, Iâ€™ll tell you. It hasnâ€™t crossed my mind in the last five months on the road or here yet,â€ Lana shared. â€œBut give it a week. My history, sure, itâ€™s coming for me at some point. Yeah.â€ She even said that â€œit would be interestingâ€ if the thought â€œdidnâ€™tâ€ cross her mind soon. When asked if she could imagine a life â€œwithout commitment to romantic love,â€ Lana explained what needs to happen before she can commit.
â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ she said. â€œI think I would have to get my orientation toward where I want to be geographically stronger in my solar plexus, like a knowingness there, before I could tune into a stronger desire romantically. Because if you donâ€™t feel a connection necessarily to the pavement youâ€™re walking on, the love thing stays over there.â€ Earlier in the candid conversation, the brunette beauty revealed that a recent split â€œshockedâ€ her.
â€œI feel like even the most chill guy doesnâ€™t really want to chill here,â€ she said of her house. â€œSadly, part of you knows â€¦ that ainâ€™t it. â€¦ That one shocked me. I wonâ€™t name names and whatever, but that one really shocked me, that person. That was actually the end of a relationship.â€ She went on to call the incident with her â€œrecentâ€ ex a â€œtough nut to swallow.â€ Earlier this year, in March, sources close to Lana told Billboard that she was reportedly engaged to Evan. Despite her recent comments, itâ€™s unclear if theyâ€™re still together or if the engagement was ever truly on.
During a separate video interview with the fashion mag, Lana gave Swifties an inside scoop on her prior collaboration with Taylor Swift. Lana is featured on â€œSnow On The Beach,â€ a track off of Taylorâ€™s 2022 album, Midnights. â€œThat was actually the song that Taylor wanted me to sing on,â€ she explained. â€œIf I think somebodyâ€™s song is perfect I will act as a producer in it.â€ Lana added that she can â€œmimic almost anyoneâ€ and is, in fact, â€œall overâ€ the initial version of the song. Lana revealed that Taylor wanted her to â€œsing the whole thing,â€ but she believed â€œif it ainâ€™t broke donâ€™t fix it.â€

title: PJ Harvey, Pulp, Lana del Rey y Vampire Weekend encabezan el Primavera Sound 2024
content:
No andaba demasiado errando quien lanzÃ³ hace unos dÃ­as el ya tradicional y prenavideÃ±o cartel 'fake' del Primavera Sound y colocÃ³ en lugares mÃ¡s o menos estratÃ©gicos a cabezas de cartel formidablemente previsibles como Pulp, The National, PJ Harvey y SZA, nombres que, efectivamente, estarÃ¡n en Barcelona entre el 29 de mayo y el 2 de junio de 2024 coronando la XXII ediciÃ³n del festival barcelonÃ©s.
Misterio casi resuelto y vuelta a la normalidad para un certamen que, tras la ediciÃ³n del doblete primero y la del accidentado aterrizaje en Madrid despuÃ©s (este aÃ±o, recuerden, la capital se queda en barbecho), aparca cuestiones logÃ­sticas y geogrÃ¡ficas para centrarse en la chicha de los nombres propios, anunciada este martes a travÃ©s de una aturullada retransmisiÃ³n vÃ­a Twitch.
Â¿En titulares? La rapera estadounidense SZA, la Lauryn Hill del siglo XXI, debutarÃ¡ en EspaÃ±a en el que probablemente sea su mejor momento comercial y artÃ­stico; Lana del Rey regresarÃ¡ a Barcelona tras pasar por el Sant Jordi en 2018 y caerse (como todos los demÃ¡s) del cartel pandÃ©mico de 2020; PJ Harvey sumarÃ¡ su cuarto Primavera Sound con el poco o nada festivalero 'I Inside the Old Year Dying'; Pulp volverÃ¡n de entre los muertos por segunda vez tras casi una dÃ©cada de parÃ³n; y Vampire Weekend, favoritos del indie ilustrado, actuarÃ¡n en el festival por primera vez desde 2008.
Noticia Relacionada Inverfest, una dÃ©cada dando la nota en Madrid Nacho Serrano El festival de invierno celebra sus 10 aÃ±os de vida con 120 conciertos en 13 recintos y salas
Â«Cualquier generaciÃ³n de fans de la mÃºsica va a encontrar mucho a lo que hincarle el dienteÂ», defienden desde un festival que sigue creciendo por la base gracias a fichajes com los de Charli XCX, Fka Twigs, Mitski y, sorpresa, o quizÃ¡ no tanto, Stella Maris, prolongaciÃ³n musical de ese fenÃ³meno televisivo que ha sido 'La MesÃ­as' de los Javis y tras la que se esconde la hÃ¡bil mano pop de Hidrogenesse. En el apartado de fichajes mÃ¡s o menos sorprendentes destacan tambiÃ©n los numetaleros Deftones, el pop desacomplejadamente comercial de Troye Sivan, la electrÃ³nica romÃ¡ntica del napolitano Liberato, el rapeoro mallorquÃ­n Rels B, los Dogstar de Keanu Reeves y el black metal de Wiegedood.
En el otro extremo, el de los sospechosos habituales y el rock dejÃ¡ vÃ¹, viejos conocidos como Yo La Tengo, Lambchop, The National, Phoenix y Arab Strap, nombres con los que el festival quiere reivindicar el amor por su propia historia y en encanto algo ajado de las primeras veces. Se trata, dicen, de celebrar la esencia del festival sin renunciar a todo el terreno conquistado, asÃ­ que por ahÃ­ andan tambiÃ©n, algo menos vistas o incluso inÃ©ditas, figuras de culto como Bikini Kill y Beth Gibbons, estilistas de estreno como The Lemon Twigs y nuevas reinas del pop contemporÃ¡neo como Romy y RÃ³isÃ­n Murphy.
A partir de ahÃ­, el festival sigue jugando a buscarle las cosquillas a tendencias aparentemente inconexas mezclando a La Zowi con LisabÃ¶, a Dj Playero con Mujeres y a Ã‰l MatÃ³ a un PolicÃ­a Motorizado con Channel One. En total, mÃ¡s de 150 artistas confirmados y una paridad tan ajustada que ni el Gobierno de SÃ¡nchez o una votaciÃ³n de la CUP: un 42â€™36% de mujeres, un 42â€™36% de hombres y un 15â€™28% de proyectos mixtos.

title: Primavera Sound 2024 anuncia su cartel completo: Lana del Rey, SZA, PJ Harvey o Pulp
content:
SerÃ¡ un Primavera Sound muy femenino, con cabezas de cartel como Lana del Rey, SZA, PJ Harvey, Charli XCX o Mitski. El festival vuelve en cierta forma a sus inicios, con una ediciÃ³n solo en Barcelona tras el chasco del aÃ±o pasado en Madrid y con un cartel musiquero con mucha chicha, pero sin centelleantes nombres como los del aÃ±o pasado, que trajo a RosalÃ­a, Depeche Mode o Blur. La cita se celebra del 29 de mayo al 2 de junio en Barcelona.
Se trata del cartel definitivo del Primavera Sound 2024 en su parte central, la que se celebra en el Parc del FÃ²rum. Falta por anunciarse el siempre interesante Primavera a la Ciutat, las actuaciones en salas. La veterana cita sigue apostando por la paridad y esta ediciÃ³n serÃ¡ escrupulosa en ese sentido: un 42â€²36% de mujeres, un 42â€²36% de hombres y un 15â€²28% de proyectos mixtos. Unos 150 nombres con un claro perfil musical.
Asoman como grandes nombres Lana del Rey, ya consolidada como una estrella desde hace aÃ±os; la estadounidense SZA, una de las triunfadoras de los Ãºltimos meses con el disco SOS, mÃºsica negra vanguardista; diosas del indie como Beth Gibbons (Portishead) o PJ Harvey, que este aÃ±o ha editado su disco mÃ¡s minimalista I Inside the Old Year Dying, aunque se espera que tambiÃ©n repase en Barcelona sus clÃ¡sicos. TambiÃ©n la neoyorquina Mitski, una de las sensaciones de la temporada con su sensacional The Land Is Inhospitable and So Are We, o la siempre efervescente Charli XCX.
Otro de los nombres fuertes es Pulp, grupo clave en el brit-pop ochentero y noventero. La banda de Jarvis Cocker cumplirÃ¡ la funciÃ³n de Blur en la anterior ediciÃ³n. Su clÃ¡sico Common People serÃ¡ uno de los himnos del festival. Vampire Weekend regresa al festival 16 aÃ±os despuÃ©s. Como siempre la intenciÃ³n de Primavera Sound es apostar por la variedad: tocarÃ¡n bandas duras, como Deftones o Shellac; tambiÃ©n propuestas del gÃ©nero urbano, como Milo J o La Zowi.
Otras bandas relevantes entre el maremÃ¡gnum de grupos son: The National, FKA twigs, Bikini Kill, Justice, Troye Sivan, The Lemon Twigs, RÃ³isÃ­n Murphy, Disclosure, Mujeres o El MatÃ³ a un PolicÃ­a Motorizado. Phoenix actuarÃ¡n en la jornada gratuita del miÃ©rcoles 29 de mayo y la fiesta Brunch Electronik pondrÃ¡ el broche final el domingo 2 de junio.
Hasta el 22 de noviembre estarÃ¡ disponible en la pÃ¡gina web de Primavera Sound un formulario de registro: el abono general tendrÃ¡ un precio de 265â‚¬ (mÃ¡s gastos de distribuciÃ³n) y el abono VIP un precio de 495â‚¬ (mÃ¡s gastos de distribuciÃ³n) hasta agotar existencias.El 23 de noviembre, los usuarios registrados recibirÃ¡n por email las instrucciones para acceder a la fan sale, que estarÃ¡ activa en DICE a partir de las 11h. durante 24 horas o hasta agotar existencias.
La venta general de entradas se abrirÃ¡ el 24 de noviembre a las 11 h. en DICE.
Toda la cultura que va contigo te espera aquÃ­. SuscrÃ­bete

title: How Lana Del Rey's 'West Coast' Reuses Part of The Beatles' 'And I Love Her'
content:
The prechorus of Lana Del Rey's "West Coast" features a bit of The Beatles' "And I Love Her." This might be blasphemy, but the former song might sound better.
Listen to the prechorus of Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€œWest Coastâ€ and youâ€™ll hear a bit of The Beatlesâ€˜ â€œAnd I Love Her.â€ It might be blasphemy to say this, but Del Reyâ€™s redux of â€œAnd I Love Herâ€ might sound better. Fascinatingly, Paul McCartney said â€œAnd I Love Herâ€ was his first impressive ballad.
Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜West Coastâ€™ reuses a riff from The Beatlesâ€™ â€˜And I Love Herâ€™
According to Grantland, â€œWest Coastâ€ interpolates the riff from The Beatlesâ€™ â€œAnd I Love Her.â€ Listening to both tunes side-by-side, itâ€™s impossible not to notice the similarity. Of course, the main difference between the two songs is the tone.
â€œAnd I Love Herâ€ is a straightforward, pretty piece of lounge music. â€œWest Coast,â€ on the other hand, changes tempo in a way thatâ€™s both beautiful and jarring. The eerie psychedelic undertones of the track make its lovelorn lyrics seem a touch sinister. Even the quoted riff from â€œAnd I Love Herâ€ feels more otherworldly in Del Reyâ€™s hands.
Itâ€™s odd that Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜West Coastâ€™ samples a British tune
1960s nostalgia is a big part of Del Reyâ€™s work, so itâ€™s no wonder sheâ€™d take cues from the Fab Four in â€œWest Coast.â€ But the interpolation of â€œAnd I Love Herâ€ feels a little strange in a song called â€œWest Coast.â€ Instead of recalling four lads from Liverpool couldnâ€™t she have interpolated a song by a West Coast band, such as The Beach Boys or The Doors? Sampling The Monkees would have made sense for that matter.
â€œWest Coastâ€ wouldnâ€™t be the last time Del Rey referenced The Beatles. She collaborated with Sean Ono Lennon on her track â€œTomorrow Never Came.â€ â€œSay Yes to Heavenâ€ quotes â€œGive Peace a Chance,â€ while â€œCaliforniaâ€ twists a line from â€œHappy Xmas (War Is Over)â€ on its head.
What Paul McCartney thought about The Beatles â€˜And I Love Herâ€™
In the 1997 book Paul McCartney; Many Years From Now, Paul had some high praise for â€œAnd I Love Her.â€ â€œIt was the first ballad I impressed myself with,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s got nice chords in it, â€˜Bright are the stars that shine, dark is the sky.â€™ I like the imagery of the stars and the sky. It was a love song really.
â€œThe â€˜Andâ€™ in the title was an important thing, â€˜And I Love Her,â€™ it came right out of left field, you were right up to speed the minute you heard it,â€ Paul added. â€œThe title comes in the second verse and it doesnâ€™t repeat. You would often go to town on the title, but this was almost an aside, â€˜Oh â€¦ and I love you.â€™ It still holds up and George played really good guitar on it. It worked very well.â€
Paul disputed John Lennonâ€™s claim to have penned the songâ€™s middle eight (bridge). â€œIâ€™m not sure if John worked on that at all,â€ he said. â€œThe middle eight is mine. I would say that John probably helped with the middle eight, but he canâ€™t say â€˜Itâ€™s mine.'â€
Paul impressed himself with â€œAnd I Love Herâ€ and the tune seems to have impressed Del Rey as well.

title: Jack Antonoff Producing The New Look TV Soundtrack Featuring Lana Del Rey, Matty Healy, Nick Cave, More
content:
The New Look is a new Apple TV+ historical drama series from Todd A. Kessler. It stars Ben Mendelsohn as Christian Dior and Juliette Binoche as Coco Chanel in a show that focuses on how the designers of their era revolutionized fashion during the Nazi occupation of Paris. Jack Antonoff is producing the original soundtrack, which will feature covers of period appropriate music performed by Lana Del Rey, Matty Healy, Nick Cave, Perfume Genius, Florence Welch, Bleachers, Beabadoobee, and more.
The series also stars Maisie Williams, John Malkovich, Emily Mortimer, and Claes Bang. The show debuts February 14 with the first three episodes. New episodes will air weekly on Wednesdays. Bleachersâ€™ new self-titled album is out March 8 via Dirty Hit.

title: Alanis Morissette & Lana Del Rey To Perform On NBCâ€™s â€˜Christmas at Gracelandâ€™
content:
NBC is heading to Memphis for its latest holiday special.
A slew of pop stars including Alanis Morissette, John Legend, Kacey Musgraves, Kane Brown, Lainey Wilson, Lana Del Rey, Post Malone, and The War And Treaty will perform as part of its Christmas at Graceland special.
The event will air on November 29 at 10pm.
It marks the first ever concert broadcast live from Elvis Presleyâ€™s iconic home and comes as Sofia Coppolaâ€™s Priscilla is currently in theaters. It will also feature never before broadcast footage of Presley.
The musicians will pay tribute to The King and his granddaughter Riley Keough, star of Amazonâ€™s Daisy Jones & the Six will make a special appearance.
Keough will also exec produce the special alongside her Felix Culpa partner Gina Gammell.
Done + Dusted and Authentic Studios will produce alongside Felix Culpa with Raj Kapoor, Katy Mullan and Ian Stewart exec producing for Done + Dusted and Colin Smeeton, Matthew Gross and Marc Rosen exec producing for Authentic. Gracelandâ€™s Joel Weinshanker will also exec produce.

title: Bleachers and Jack Antonoff Detail Album, Share New Song â€œAlma Materâ€: Listen
content:
Jack Antonoffâ€™s band, Bleachers, has returned with another new song, â€œAlma Mater.â€ Itâ€™s the second single from the groupâ€™s just-announced new album, Bleachers, which is out March 8 via Dirty Hit. Listen to the track, featuring vocals from longtime Antonoff collaborator Lana Del Rey, below.
Bleachers released the first Bleachers offering, â€œModern Girl,â€ last month. They also played the song on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon. The new album will follow 2021â€™s Take the Sadness Out of Saturday Night.
Once again, Antonoff is in the running for Producer of the Year, Non-Classical, at the upcoming Grammy Awards. Heâ€™s gotten nominated for the award at the 2020, 2021, 2022, and 2023 Grammy Awards, taking home the trophy at the latter two ceremonies.

title: Lana Del Rey & Phoebe Bridgers Competing Against Themselves at Grammys
content:
In addition to being Grammy-nominated for album of the year for her own album Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, Lana Del Rey is featured on two albums that are competing with her album in that category â€“ Taylor Swiftâ€™s Midnights and Jon Batisteâ€™s World Music Radio.
Likewise, in addition to being nominated as a member of boygenius for the record, Phoebe Bridgers is featured on SZAâ€™s SOS.
In all but a few years since 2006, this would have meant that Del Rey and Bridgers would have multiple album of the year nods this year. But this year, the Recording Academy added a baseline for receiving an album of the year nomination. Participants must contribute to 20% of an albumâ€™s playing time. This applies to featured artists as well as songwriters, producers, engineers, mixers and mastering engineers.
Six of this yearâ€™s eight album of the year nominees have featured artists, but none of the featured artists met that 20% requirement. So, these featured artists wonâ€™t be in line to win a Grammy even if the album wins, but they will get a certificate and might get a shout-out in the winnerâ€™s acceptance speech.
(Nigerian musician Sean Kuti, the youngest son of Afrobeat pioneer Fela Kuti, is featured on two of the 14 tracks on Janelle MonÃ¡eâ€™s The Age of Pleasure, but that didnâ€™t quite meet the standard.)
This yearâ€™s two other two album of the year nominees â€“ boygeniusâ€™ The Record and Olivia Rodrigoâ€™s Guts â€“ had no featured artists.
Hereâ€™s how the Grammy rules in this category have changed over the years. From 2006-16, all credited featured artists on the winning album won Grammys. From 2017-20, the baseline requirement was 33% of an albumâ€™s playing time, which some thought was too restrictive. From 2021-22, all featured artists were again eligible to win. This year, a baseline was re-added, but one that was more liberal than the previous one â€“ 20%.
During the years when there was no baseline requirement, the featured artists on Herbie Hancockâ€™s River: The Joni Letters, Swiftâ€™s Fearless, Daft Punkâ€™s Random Access Memories and Batisteâ€™s We Are all won Grammys.
Here are the featured artists on this yearâ€™s six album of the year nominees that had featured artists.

title: 2024 Grammys: Arctic Monkeys, Lana Del Rey, Boygenius, and More Nominated for Best Alternative Music Album
content:
The 2024 Grammy Award nominations are here, and that means five acts are vying for Best Alternative Music Album. The nominees are Arctic Monkeys, Boygenius, Gorillaz, Lana Del Rey, and PJ Harvey. See all of the 2024 Grammy nominations here.
Arctic Monkeys are recognized for their seventh studio album, The Car. The band is also up for Best Alternative Music Performance (for â€œBody Paintâ€) and Best Rock Performance (for â€œSculptures of Anything Goesâ€). Last year, Arctic Monkeys were nominated for Best Alternative Music Performance for The Carâ€™s lead single, â€œThereâ€™d Better Be a Mirrorball,â€ but the Grammy went to Wet Leg for â€œChaise Lounge.â€ Arctic Monkeys are now nine-time Grammy nominees, but they have yet to win an award.
Boygenius are among the most-nominated acts at the 2024 Grammy Awards. For their debut album, The Record, Boygenius got nominations for Best Alternative Music Album and Album of the Year. The group also got nominated for Record of the Year, Best Rock Performance, and Best Rock Song for â€œNot Strong Enoughâ€ and Best Alternative Music Performance for â€œCool About It.â€ In addition, the engineers behind The Record (including Illuminati Hottiesâ€™ Sarah Tudzin) are up for Best Engineered Album, Non-Classical. Boygeniusâ€™ Phoebe Bridgers has one more nomination than her bandmates, scoring a nod for Best Pop Duo/Group Performance for the SZA collaboration â€œGhost in the Machine.â€
Gorillazâ€™s 2024 Best Alternative Music Album nomination is for Cracker Island. Itâ€™s the first time since the 2018 Grammys that Gorillaz have been nominated. Gorillaz have won just one Grammy, Best Pop Collaboration With Vocals for â€œFeel Good Inc.â€ in 2006. While Gorillaz are not the official nominees, Dom Dollaâ€™s remix of the bandâ€™s â€œNew Goldâ€ is up for Best Remixed Recording.
Lana Del Reyâ€™s Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd is up for Best Alternative Music Album and Album of the Year. The recordâ€™s â€œCandy Necklace,â€ featuring Jon Batiste, is up for Best Pop Duo/Group Performance, and standout â€œA&Wâ€ got nods for Song of the Year and Best Alternative Music Performance. Del Rey collaborator Jack Antonoff is nominated for Producer of the Year, Non-Classical, and his work on Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd helped him score the nod.
Best Alternative Music Album is the lone category in which PJ Harvey is nominated at the 2024 Grammy Awards, and the nod comes for I Inside the Old Year Dying. Harvey was nominated for seven previous Grammys, most recently for The Hope Six Demolition Project at the 2017 Grammys.
The 2023 Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album went to Wet Leg for Wet Leg. Follow along with all of Pitchforkâ€™s coverage of the 2024 Grammy Awards.
Best Alternative Music Album
Arctic Monkeys - The Car
Boygenius - The Record
Gorillaz - Cracker Island
Lana Del Rey - Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd
PJ Harvey - I Inside The Old Year Dying

title: Lana Del Rey Couldnâ€™t Fit Priscilla in Her Schedule
content:
Photo: Kristy Sparow/Getty Images
Did you know that Lana Del Rey released an album this year called Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd? Maybe thatâ€™s why she didnâ€™t have time to be on the Priscilla soundtrack. (She only worked one shift at Waffle House, so that canâ€™t be it.) Sofia Coppola recently told E! News that Lana couldâ€™ve been part of the Priscilla Presley biopic. You know, the one that Jacob Elordi says he prepared for by eating about a pound of bacon every day. â€œWe were hoping she could do a song for it, but it didnâ€™t work out with the timing,â€ Coppola explained. The director added that Lana was also invited to the premiere, but apparently wasnâ€™t able to make it. This news will probably come as a blow to Lana stans. From her hair to her eyeliner to her lyrics like â€œElvis is my daddy,â€ Lana has long been associated with Elvisâ€™s ex-wife. In fact, Coppola said she received multiple requests specifically asking that the singer be involved in the film. But hey, Lanaâ€™s busy schedule doesnâ€™t appear to have led to any love lost with the titular characterâ€™s real-life counterpart. Priscilla Presley recently confirmed that she likes Lana â€œvery much.â€ In an alternate universe, theyâ€™d have gotten to walk the red carpet together.
Priscilla Presley says sheâ€™s a Lana Del Rey fan. pic.twitter.com/VDPI2gfVem â€” Pop Crave (@PopCrave) November 5, 2023

title: Taylor Swift, SZA, Phish, Lauren Daigle and more
content:
Live music was firing on all cylinders in 2023.
Taylor Swift, Beyonce, Ed Sheeran, Karol G, Dead & Company and other megastars filled massive stadiums. The arena and amphitheater circuit thrived thanks to high-profile tours from Pink, Kane Brown, Doja Cat, Offspring and other top performers.
And the smaller venues continued to draw sizable crowds to see the Dandy Warhols, ABC, Cowboy Junkies and other longtime favorites as well as newer acts like Morgan Wade, Palo Altoâ€™s Molly Tuttle, J.I.D and Smino.
In other words, 2023 was an absolute blast for fans living in the Bay Area. Not only did we have the opportunity to experience all that was mentioned above, but we also got to enjoy some of the best music festivals in the world.
We loved so much of what we saw and heard in 2023. Yet, itâ€™s now time for us to play favorites and look back at the very best from the past 12 months. Here are our picks for the Top 10 Bay Area Concerts of 2023.
1. SZA
When & Where: March 14, Oakland Arena
Watching SZA wow a capacity crowd with one wonderfully soulful song after another, during a concert that just kept growing better and more meaningful as it progressed, it was easy to wonder if any other show in 2023 would be able to top what we were witnessing in Oakland on this magic night in mid-March? A little more than nine months later, weâ€™d know that the answer would be, well, no. Indeed, with the exception of the one that comes in at No. 2 on our list, no other Bay Area concert really came close to reaching the heights of SZAâ€™s roadshow in support of â€œSOS,â€ the singerâ€™s sophomore full-length that came out in late 2022 and remained a huge seller throughout 2023. The stage production itself was visually and thematically stunning, powerfully resonating with the crowd from start to finish. It was matched step for step by SZAâ€™s towering vocal work and stage presence, as well as the feeling that we were watching, in real time, an artist power her career to an even higher level.
Read the full SZA concert review here.
2. Taylor Swift
When & Where: July 28, Leviâ€™s Stadium, Santa Clara
It was Taylorâ€™s year, in a fashion that few other superstars have ever experienced. Think back to Prince in 1984 or U2 in 1987. And then multiple it probably tenfold. Yet, Swift was still able rise up from the endless sea of soundbites, social media chatter and nonstop hype to deliver a stadium tour that somehow not only lived up to expectations â€” it surpassed them. The concert on July 28 (the first of two sold-out shows at the venue) was nothing short of an epic, as the biggest star in the pop music universe â€” with seemingly nothing left to prove â€” went above and beyond the call of duty and delivered a curfew-shattering 3Â½-hour performance that featured nearly four dozen songs. Fans who missed seeing the action in person, or simply need another dose of Taylor, should check out the great â€œTaylor Swift: The Eras Tourâ€ concert film.
Read the full Taylor Swift concert review here.
3. Phish
When & Where: April 17, UC Greek Theatre, Berkeley
The first set wouldâ€™ve been a career highlight for most groups, yet it was only a pedestrian offering by Phishâ€™s own lofty standards. Then the second set arrived and the Vermont quartet showed why it owns the title of the worldâ€™s greatest jam band. Starting out with a fairly concise version of Clifton Chenierâ€™s â€œMy Soul,â€ Phish then took its own â€œTweezerâ€ into deep space, twisting and turning the song in a myriad of directions for some 44 awe-inspiring minutes. The foursome then followed up with a 20-minute version of â€œSimpleâ€ that kept the party chugging along in high gear. After playing just three songs in roughly 70 minutes, Phish closed the second set in triumphant fashion with its rip-roaring take on the Velvet Undergroundâ€™s â€œRock & Roll.â€
Read the full Phish concert review here.
4. Christone â€œKingfishâ€ Ingram
When & Where: May 27, BottleRock Napa Valley
In a lineup filled with such multiplatinum-selling mega-acts as Red Hot Chili Peppers, Post Malone, Lizzo, Sheryl Crow and Duran Duran, it turned out to be a relatively still-unknown 20-something from Clarksdale, Mississippi who stole the show at the 2023 BottleRock Napa Valley. Yeah, Ingram is just that good â€” a blues guitarist of the highest order, whose admirers range from old-school blues aficionados to newcomers who (unfortunately) donâ€™t yet know their Freddie King from their B.B. King. Ingramâ€™s head-turning BottleRock set was filled with one lengthy electric guitar part after another, yet every single note mattered. The buzz quickly spread throughout the festival grounds, as people shared the news that they had just seen a guitarist for the ages.
Read the full Christone â€œKingfishâ€ Ingram BottleRock concert review here.
5. Lauren Daigle, Victory Boyd
When & Where: Nov. 14, Golden 1 Center, Sacramento
Daigle was the headliner and definitely lived up to the job description as she delighted 10,000 fans with joyous new songs from her self-titled fourth full-length studio outing as well as longtime fan favorites from 2015â€™s â€œHow Can It Beâ€ and 2018â€™s â€œLook Up Child.â€ Yet, Boyd was just as impressive in the opening act role, commanding our attention with a glorious set of gospel, folk, country blues and spoken word from the new album â€œGlory Hour.â€ Both â€œLauren Daigleâ€ and â€œGlory Hourâ€ rank among the best albums of 2023 â€” and their authors are two of the finest singers in the entire entire pop music industry â€” so itâ€™s really no wonder that this show ended up being so enjoyable.
Read the full Lauren Daigle, Victory Boyd concert review here.
6. First Aid Kit
When & Where: May 15, Fox Theater, Oakland
The Swedish country-folk-rock-pop duo, consisting of Johanna and Klara SÃ¶derberg, kicked off its 2023 North American tour in awe-inspiring fashion in front of a sold-out crowd of some 2,800 fans at the ornate downtown Oakland venue. The two sisters mesmerized listeners with their glorious harmonies as they highlighted their fifth â€” and, quite possibly, best â€” studio album, â€œPalomino,â€ which was released in late 2022. Yet, the eveningâ€™s most memorable moment â€” of many â€” came when the SÃ¶derbergs blended their voices in tribute to the late Christine McVie, who died in 2019 at the age of 79, with a gorgeous version of the Fleetwood Mac classic â€œSongbird.â€
Read the full First Aid Kit concert review here.
7. Lana Del Rey
When & Where: Aug. 12, Outside Lands, San Francisco
Outside Lands delivered so much great music in its most recent three-day run, including fantastic sets by Canadian indie-rock outfit Alvvays and Texas dream-pop act Cigarettes After Sex. Yet, the single most memorable offering came courtesy of Del Rey, who delivered an absolutely intoxicating 80-minute headlining set on the Twin Peaks stage during Day 2 of the festival in Golden Gate Park. The stellar vocalist delivered one gem after another, as she touched upon at least seven of her studio offerings with a 16-song performance that resonated in such powerful fashion with the crowd. The amazing bond that Del Rey has formed with her fans â€” who approach Swift-ian heights â€” was on full display throughout.
Read the full Lana Del Rey concert review here.
8. REO Speedwagon
When & Where: Jan. 18, San Jose Civic
More than a half century into is multiplatinum-selling career, this Champaign, Illinois,-born band still acts like it has to prove itself each and every time it takes the stage. â€œWeâ€™re going to give you everything weâ€™ve got,â€ vocalist Kevin Cronin promised fans, for what we can only guess must be about the 486,233rd time of his career. Yet â€” wow! â€” did Cronin and company ever deliver on that promise, running through â€œTake It On the Run,â€ â€œCanâ€™t Fight This Feeling,â€ â€œDonâ€™t Let Him Goâ€ and other fan favorites during a 90-minute set that only furthered strengthened the view that REO Speedwagon deserves to be the in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
Read the full REO Speedwagon concert review here.
9. The Offspring
When & Where: Aug. 5, Shoreline Amphitheatre, Mountain View
It was the best pop-punk party of 2023 in the Bay Area, as 18,000 very exuberant fans showed up to bounce around and sing along with one of the genreâ€™s all-time best. It turned out to be an 80-minute joyride for both the fans and the band, as the two sides found such mighty synergy in the midst of such adrenaline-rich rockers as â€œSelf Esteem,â€ â€œWhy Donâ€™t You Get a Job?â€ and â€œPretty Fly (for a White Guy).â€ â€œI canâ€™t believe this,â€ vocalist Dexter Holland remarked of the response from the audience. â€œItâ€™s volcanic!â€ Yet, the response was certainly fitting, given the equally explosive performance that the band put on.
Read the full Offspring concert review here.
10. TLC, En Vogue
When & Where: July 9, Toyota Pavilion, Concord
TLC was the main attraction and wowed fans with â€œCreep,â€ â€œDigginâ€™ on You,â€ â€œNo Scrubsâ€ and â€” what may well be the best pop song of â€™90s â€” â€œWaterfalls.â€ Tionne â€œT-Bozâ€ Watkins and Rozonda â€œChilliâ€ Thomas, the â€œTâ€ and â€œCâ€ in TLC, respectively, both sounded terrific, while recorded vocals of the late Lisa â€œLeft Eyeâ€ Lopes (the â€œLâ€ in the band name) were nicely woven into the mix. Oaklandâ€™s En Vogue also did not disappoint, impressing its hometown East Bay crowd with such favorites as â€œHold On,â€ â€œWhatta Manâ€ and â€œFree Your Mind.â€ TLC and En Vogue were the best reason for attending this Hot Summer Nights show, which (far less memorably) also featured â€œBeautiful Girlsâ€ singer Sean Kingston and Grammy-winning reggae-pop act Shaggy.
Read the full TLC, En Vogue concert review here.

title: The albums of the year 2023: from Olivia Rodrigo and Boygenius to Victoria MonÃ©t and Lana Del Rey
content: On 2018â€™s Bloom, Troye Sivan â€“ who rose to fame with sweeping, dreamy tales of life in suburbia, and his desperate longing to escape it â€“ showed early hints of cheekiness; the title track is a surprisingly emotive bottoming anthem, for crying out loud! Back then, it was all begging to be pushed so much further, with broodingly dramatic slow-burners still ruling the roost. Enter Something to Give Each Other, which embraces house music, queer clubbing culture, and a general sense of rampant horniness. From the relentless house beat and campy football chants of Rush (a song named after a brand of poppers, no less) to the truly ridiculous Bag Raiders sample on Got Me Started, it bursts with fun and personality.

content:
