title: Metallica, Lana Del Rey, Peso Pluma among picks
content:
It was a fascinating year for new music.
There was just so much to enjoy from so many different genres in 2023 â€” from Latin and country to mainstream pop and indie rock.
The mix was bountiful, often breathtaking, and, at times, even dizzying. But it was certainly never boring.
Related Articles Music | Top 11 video games of 2023: RPGs reigned supreme in a stacked year
Top 11 video games of 2023: RPGs reigned supreme in a stacked year Music | Barack Obama shares his favorite music of 2023, and itâ€™s an eclectic mix
Barack Obama shares his favorite music of 2023, and itâ€™s an eclectic mix Music | Elon Musk and these other 9 bosses had a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad 2023
Elon Musk and these other 9 bosses had a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad 2023 Music | 8 of 2023â€™s worst destinations for overtourism. Hereâ€™s how to avoid the crowds next year
8 of 2023â€™s worst destinations for overtourism. Hereâ€™s how to avoid the crowds next year Music | Bay Area theater scene bounced back in 2023 â€” here were 10 top shows The depth and breadth of the musical riches was underscored once again as we put together our picks for the Top 10 Albums of 2023, knowing full well that we werenâ€™t going to come anywhere close to being able to fit all that was worthwhile and deserving on the list.
Yet, we pushed ahead anyway and the result is one that we believe nicely represents the year in music.
Well, at least in terms of music that was actually released in 2023.
We feel it necessary to point out that the new album we listened to the most in 2023 was SZAâ€™s â€œSOS.â€ But that one came out at the tail end of 2022 and, thus, wasnâ€™t technically eligible for this list. Sorry, SZA. We still think youâ€™re great.
With that caveat out of the way, letâ€™s drop the needle on the top albums of 2023.
1. â€œLucky,â€ Megan Moroney
The Georgia native caught our attention in late 2022 with the single â€œTennessee Orangeâ€ â€” a wonderfully clever and endearing love song framed through the lens of college football loyalties â€” and then followed up with a full-length debut that contained a dozen more equally outstanding tunes. The result was not only the finest country music outing of the last 12 months, but also the best new album we heard from any genre in 2023. The songwriting simply sparkles, updating country traditions with a decidedly 21st-century edge, and Moroneyâ€™s voice is about as engaging as it gets. We simply canâ€™t wait to see where this major talent goes from here.
2. â€œGÃ©nesis,â€ Peso Pluma
The massive breakthrough album from this 24-year-old Mexican artist more than lives up to the hype, standing tall in a year in which Latin music continued to dominate so much of the pop universe. Of course, one doesnâ€™t have to understand Spanish to enjoy Pesoâ€™s modern brand of regional Mexican music â€” dubbed corridos tumbados â€“ where he takes the traditional corridor ballad form and then joyfully and fluidly spices it up with hip-hop, reggaeton and other styles. Yet, his lyrics certainly are a big selling point as well, bursting with swagger and style as he takes listeners on one memorable ride after another. The vibe and sound remain equally powerful and addictive throughout the 17 tracks, resulting in an album that was almost too easy to push repeat on, over and over again, in 2023.
3. â€œGlory Hour,â€ Victory
The wonderfully talented singer-songwriter-musician from Detroit, who won a Grammy for her contributions to Kanye Westâ€™s â€œJesus Is Kingâ€ album in 2021, avoids the sophomore slump in triumphant fashion with â€œGlory Hour.â€ The record is a stunning showcase for the singer â€” who also goes by Victory Boyd â€” mixing gospel, folk, country blues and spoken word in ways that just feel so entirely authentic and natural. Her voice, which has long drawn comparisons to that of the great Nina Simone, is sensational throughout, filling hearts with both joy and hope as she rejoices in the Lord.
4. â€œSuch Ferocious Beauty,â€ Cowboy Junkies
Itâ€™s the perfect title for a Cowboy Junkies album, underscoring the spellbinding tension that has always existed between songwriter-guitarist Michael Timminsâ€™ intensely emotional lyrics and sister Margoâ€™s gorgeous delivery of those oft-anguished words. This offering â€” the groupâ€™s first full-length album of new original material since 2018â€™s brilliant â€œAll That Reckoningâ€ â€” is particularly raw and emotional, as the Timmins family (including drummer Peter) process the loss of their parents and deliver a batch of songs that are indeed brimming with â€œSuch Ferocious Beauty.â€
5. â€œ72 Seasons,â€ Metallica
Forty years after breaking onto the scene with the 1983 debut â€œKill â€˜Em All,â€ Metallica served notice that itâ€™s still the band to beat in hard rock/metal with the release of its terrific 11th full-length studio offering. The album finds the best-selling Bay Area band of all time doing anything but resting on its mighty laurels, but rather pushing the pedal to the â€” um, well â€” metal for basically the entire 77-minute runtime. James Hetfieldâ€™s lyrics and vocal delivery are topnotch, while guitarist Kirk Hammett and bassist Robert Trujillo thunder along in equally impressive fashion. Lars Ulrich is the machine that makes the whole thing go, showing once again that he might be the most underrated drummer in rock history.
6. â€œDid You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd,â€ Lana Del Rey
Del Rey just keeps right on turning out great albums, with this wordy title being the eighth worthy effort sheâ€™s delivered since signing a major label deal in the early 2010s. While not every track on the record is stellar, the highs to be found here are truly towering â€” notably, the luxuriously gorgeous title track and the intensely moving and artsy â€œA&W.â€ Overall, the album stands as further proof that Del Rey ranks as one of the greatest artists of the 21st century.
7. â€œLauren Daigle,â€ Lauren Daigle
The Louisiana native nicely showcases her powerhouse vocals throughout her long-awaited fourth album, which follows the platinum-selling crossover smash â€œLook Up Childâ€ of 2018. Much has been made about this being the first mainstream pop record for Daigle â€” who has experienced her greatest success in the contemporary Christian music realm â€” yet thatâ€™s probably just marketing noise, given that the singerâ€™s faith is still at front and center of basically everything to be found here. And thatâ€™s a good thing, in part because no other topic propels Daigle to greater musical heights.
8. â€œEverything Is Alive,â€ Slowdive
The British shoegaze outfit returns with a work of shining beauty and vast intrigue, further cementing its position among the best indie-pop bands of the last 30 or so years. The music shimmers and soothes, playing down the always sturdy melodies in a mix of hushed lyrics, evocative sonic landscapes and just the right amount of tension to hold the whole thing together. The result â€” spanning eight songs over nearly 42 minutes â€” is the best chill-out record of 2023.
9. â€œPsychopath,â€ Morgan Wade
â€œReckless,â€ Wadeâ€™s remarkable major label debut from 2021, set the bar mighty high. While the follow-up effort doesnâ€™t quite clear that mark, it does come close enough for us to remain convinced that Wade should be one of country musicâ€™s best singer-songwriters for many years to come. Itâ€™s more finely polished than the earlier effort, at least in terms of the production work, which serves as an intriguing counterbalance to Wadeâ€™s gritty, hardscrabble lines. And her greatest strength remains the ability to make you believe every single word that she utters.
10. â€œThe Great Escape,â€ Larry June and The Alchemist
Prolific San Francisco rapper June, who has released something like a dozen albums/mixtapes/EPs in the 2020s alone, is at the top of his game on this outing with hip-hop producer Alchemist. The latter also does a great job as he shows off his Grammy-winning skills while building complex, yet fluid sheets of music from kooky cool samples and sounds. The synergy is tangible, with Juneâ€™s smooth flow finding a comfortable home amid Alchemistâ€™s easy grooves.

title: Top 5 songs of 2023 include hits by Lana Del Rey, Olivia Rodrigo, Troye Sivan, Pink Pantheress, Dua Lipa
content:
2023 was a year of incredible music defined by pop tunes that became impossible to get out of your head, thought-provoking ballads and thumping rock songs that forced you out of your seat.
This meant narrowing down the worldâ€™s best five tunes of the past year was no easy task.
But, thereâ€™s no denying there were a handful of songs that stood out from the pack, not just on the charts but in the impact they were able to deliver.
So, in no particular order, hereâ€™s our take on the best songs of 2023.
A&W by Lana Del Ray
Camera Icon Lana Del Rey Credit: BANG - Entertainment News
The sultry songstressâ€™s ditty, co-written with musician and Bleachers lead Jack Antonoff, was praised for its soulful storytelling as well as its contradictions in its messaging against the packaging.
It was declared song of the year by American music bible Pitchfork in the publicationâ€™s annual top 100 songs of 2023 and itâ€™s hard to disagree.
Pitchforkâ€™s Anna Gaca wrote: â€œLana seeks the source of her ill humours and speaks of lost youth, a distant mother, predation, addiction, and desperate, toxic validationâ€.
The letters A and W in the song title refers to â€œAmerican wh...eâ€. The song was released on Del Reyâ€™s ninth album.
Pitchfork wasnâ€™t the only one to label it tune of the year with British rival NME also naming it top of its 50 best songs of 2023 list. NME said the song, â€œplumbed the loss of innocence and youth, while also speaking to societal expectations of what womanhood should look likeâ€.
The 38-year-old, whose real name is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, is known for producing cinematic quality songs and exploration of tragic romance and melancholia.
Boys A Liar, Pt 2 by Pink Pantheress ft. Ice Spice
Camera Icon PinkPantheress and Ice Spice Credit: Instagram
If you spent any time on TikTok this year, you wouldâ€™ve seen how loved this song was and still is.
The viral bop is a sequel to PinkPantheressâ€™ 2022 original song, Boyâ€™s a Liar, which has similar lyrics and melody but without Ice Spiceâ€™s rap verse.
The 22-year-old released her second version of the song after being asked to remix it with cult rapper Ice Spice.
The song is about a boy who lies to his girlfriend and cheats on her with another girl. The girlfriend expresses her frustration and disappointment with him while also admitting that she still misses him and wants him back.
The collaboration went viral before its release in February when a fan recorded the duo filming the music video in New York City, which was seen by more than 20 million people and liked five million times on TikTok.
The UK artist is known for producing short songs ideal for TikToks and rose to fame because of it on the social media app.
Rush by Troye Sivan
Camera Icon Troye Sivan. Credit: AAP
Our very own Perth pop star sums up endless evenings in this song that could easily soundtrack the greatest night of your life.
If there was one song that perfectly intertwines love and partying, this is it.
Dropped in July, Rush is the lead single from Something To Give Each Other, the Aussieâ€™s first album in five years.
In a statement accompanying the track, Sivan said the song evoked â€œthe feeling of kissing a sweaty stranger on a dancefloor, a two-hour date that turned into a weekend, a crush, a winter, a summerâ€.
The song was released alongside a music video which sent the internet into a spin but didnâ€™t come without some controversy.
The 28-year-old copped abuse online for not showcasing enough diversity in terms of body types. Speaking about the criticism, Sivan said that he and his creative director Gordon von Steiner never thought it would be an issue.
â€œI definitely hear the critique,â€ Sivan told Billboard.
â€œTo be honest, it just wasnâ€™t a thought we had â€” we obviously werenâ€™t saying, â€˜We want to have one specific type of person in the video.â€™ We just made the video, and there wasnâ€™t a ton of thought put behind that.â€
get him back! by Olivia Rodrigo
Camera Icon Olivia Rodrigo Credit: BANG - Entertainment News
Itâ€™s the pop-rock, regretful track that describes the 20-year-oldâ€™s desperation to get back with her ex - while also wanting revenge.
Pitchfork described it â€œas messy, flawed, and ultimately freeing as a breakup feelsâ€.
While Rodrigo hasnâ€™t revealed who the song was about, fans speculate its message is at least in part aimed at her producer ex Adam Faze. For example, she sings, â€œI met a guy in the summer and I left him in the spring,â€ which follows the timeline of her relationship with Faze.
Off her hyped second album Guts, she fearlessly admits to a hopeless love life, mental health and body issues through an absorbing confessional, proving her global smash Sour at the age of just 17 was no fluke.
Only hours after it hit streaming services, critics were raving.
The London Evening Standard handed out four stars after being convinced she is â€the biggest new pop star since Billie Eilishâ€ for her new efforts.
Dance The Night by Dua Lipa
Camera Icon Dua Lipa Credit: BANG - Entertainment News
Itâ€™s the tune that was stuck in everybodyâ€™s minds after the box office smash Barbie.
The single was produced and co-written by Mark Ronson and has enough pop and disco to dance us into the new year.
Created during a break from Lipaâ€™s year-long Future Nostalgia tour, the pair spent days not just writing the song but also watching the dance party scene from the film in which the song was going to feature.
The pair were desperate to find lyrics that would perfectly match the scene.
â€œWe rewrote â€˜Dance the Nightâ€™ so many times to match the picture,â€ Ronson told Variety.
â€œLike, Dua was literally coming up with lyrics â€” â€˜When Margot does that come-hither thing with her fingers [in the scene], thatâ€™s when I want to sing â€˜Come along for the ride,â€™ We actually engineered that song almost like a score.â€
Lipa, who also appeared in the movie as Mermaid Barbie, said: â€œBarbie completely took over our lives â€” we were completely Barb-ified.â€
â€œWe were putting post-it notes everywhere, trying to brainstorm what â€˜Dance the Nightâ€™ was going to be.â€

title: Music: Kitty Empireâ€™s 10 best albums of 2023
content:
1. Billy Woods and Kenny Segal: Maps
Backwoodz Studioz; May
Leftfield New York rapper Billy Woods released a pair of superb collaborative albums this year: Maps, with producer Kenny Segal, and We Buy Diabetic Test Strips, as half of Armand Hammer. Of two very different records, both anchored by this caustic sophisticateâ€™s free associating, Maps edges it for its sly, deadpan take on a dissociative life in motion.
2. CMAT: Crazymad, for Me
AWAL; October
CMAT, AKA Ciara Mary-Alice Thompson. Photograph: Sarah Doyle
A bittersweet concept album about a misspent relationship in Irish singer-songwriter Ciara Mary-Alice Thompsonâ€™s youth, Crazymad, for Me was like a night of espresso martinis with your most voluble friend, channelling the self-actualising energy of Self Esteem with added country brio and a dash of Fleetwood Mac.
3. 100 Gecs: 10,000 Gecs
Dogshow/Atlantic; March
Now based in LA, hyper-pop-punk aesthetes Dylan Brady and Laura Les once again transformed seemingly obnoxious base metals into surreal and surprisingly emotional gold. Defiantly stupid, and spectacularly sharp at the same time, 100 Gecs pondered corn snacks, worried about bills and dumped losers while setting off musical fireworks indoors.
4. Billy Nomates: Cacti
Invada; January
Appallingly better known for taking abusive Glastonbury commentators to task than for her arresting songs, Billy Nomates is â€“ or possibly, was â€“ the pseudonym of indie auteur Tor Maries (she may have retired it). But if you were a person who needed to hear her acerbic, 80s-leaning earworms about self-care and vertigo, they hit home like a spiked mallet.
5. Janelle MonÃ¡e: The Age of Pleasure
Wondaland/Atlantic; June
Pleasure principleâ€¦ Janelle MonÃ¡e, pictured on stage in New Orleans in June. Getty Images
What now seems like aeons ago, the multi-hyphenate artist Janelle MonÃ¡e once rapped in riddles and resisted the male gaze. The Age of Pleasure, her fourth album, prioritised pleasure, the logical conclusion of a series of increasingly sex-positive releases that could only end in this joyously sapphic pool party.
6. Mitski: The Land Is Inhospitable and So Are We
Dead Oceans; September
Having threatened retirement, Mitski returned with another lacerating album whose existential concerns were sublimated into different strains of Americana: plangent pedal steel, churning indie rock, orchestral oompah jazz. Her songs of snow, frost and stars only cemented her status as an all-American talent for the ages.
7. Jpegmafia x Danny Brown: Scaring the Hoes
Peggy; March
Another rapper who dropped two essential albums in 2023, maverick Danny Brown here combined with fellow margin-walker Jpegmafia to challenge 100 Gecs for the tinnitus crown. This avant-rap double-header allied attention-deficit soundscapes to Danny and Peggyâ€™s furious, funny observations. Ironically, perhaps, the results were catchy as hell.
8. The Tubs: Dead Meat
Trouble in Mind; January
Indie rock periodically receives a stylistic shot in the arm (see Mitski, circa 2018). This yearâ€™s B12 jab came from former members of London-based Welsh band Joanna Gruesome in their sublime new incarnation, the Tubs. Not only did singing guitarist Owen Williams sound like Richard Thompson fronting Sugar, the Tubsâ€™ riveting songs dealt trenchantly with manic episodes and bad rashes.
9. Jaimie Branch: Fly Or Die Fly Or Die Fly Or Die ((world war))
International Anthem; August
A posthumous release from a prodigious trumpeter, Fly Or Dieâ€¦ ((world war)) was the third in a series of Branch records that expanded what contemporary jazz could be: politically progressive, mellifluously Latinate. Part protest record, part polyrhythmic workout, Fly Or Die also made room for an Americana-hued Meat Puppets cover.
10. Lana Del Rey: Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd
Polydor; March
Lana Del Rey. Photograph: Neil Krug
Gospel singers, ministering pastors and startling musical about-faces dot this ambitious record, one of the most compelling in a strong canon. There are, as expected, glossy Del Rey surfaces, but there are also songs of death and loss.

title: Jack Antonoff on the Best of Taylor Swift, Lana & Bleachers
content:
Superlatives A Vulture series in which artists judge the best and worst of their own careers. Photo-Illustration: Vulture; Photo: Tim Mosenfelder/Getty Images
Even though theyâ€™ve recorded three albums together, Jack Antonoff doesnâ€™t ever remember officially booking a studio session with Lana Del Rey. â€œWeâ€™ll just text and be like, â€˜Where are you?â€™ â€˜Okay, come over,â€™â€ he says. â€œI was with her the other day and we just went to the studio and started messing around. Itâ€™s very loose.â€ That casualness sets the tone for the whole recording process, no matter what kind of song theyâ€™re working on. â€œThe music can be so incredibly serious, and we just end up trolling each other and being funny the whole time.â€
Antonoff is feeling reflective as he whirls around his New York apartment, making coffee and getting ready to go out with his sister, Rachel Antonoff, and wife, Margaret Qualley. When he thinks back on the past year and change, heâ€™s grateful to have close collaborators like Del Rey, along with his friend Taylor Swift and his band Bleachers. Those bonds paid off when Antonoff was nominated for six Grammys earlier this year â€” including what could be his third Producer of the Year in a row â€” largely thanks to his production work on Swiftâ€™s Midnights and Del Reyâ€™s Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd. â€œA lot of creative industries, especially nowadays, are so obsessed with these harsh pivots, so itâ€™s not common to have really long-term collaborators,â€ he says over video call. Heâ€™s also produced multiple albums for Lorde and St. Vincent and recently added the 1975 to his cadre. While some fans accuse him of adding too much of his â€™80s pop style or dulling their favorite musiciansâ€™ best qualities, the artists themselves keep coming back â€” none more than Swift, whom heâ€™s worked with since her 2014 album, 1989. â€œWe will continue working together till 2089,â€ she said, joking, as she accepted an award at this yearâ€™s VMAs.
Safe to say Antonoff feels the same way about Bleachers, the group he started in 2014 as his own E Street Band. Heâ€™d spent the bulk of his performing career jumping between bands, from his grade-school punk band Outline to the jaunty rock outfit Steel Train to the indie-pop supergroup fun. Now, as heâ€™s preparing to release Bleachersâ€™ self-titled fourth album next March, heâ€™s writing in new styles and breaking down the barriers between the band and his solo production. But throughout our conversation, he canâ€™t stop coming back to Del Reyâ€™s â€œA&W,â€ which was nominated for Song of the Year this year. â€œWe didnâ€™t say this in the room, but itâ€™s the kind of song where you would be like, Well, itâ€™s definitely not getting nominated for a Grammy!â€ he says of the seven-minute, two-part opus. â€œBut, you know what, Lana and Taylor and this year Iâ€™ve had, I think the through-line is keep finding things that fucking thrill you. To do anything but push and find new ground is a bastardization of the job.â€
Song you and Taylor Swift couldnâ€™t have made until Midnights
Maybe â€œMastermind.â€ We made the bulk of that album in my apartment. Thereâ€™s a little studio in there, which is the same place that weâ€™ve worked for many years. It feels like we have such a bedrock beneath us of things that we know that we can do that it makes it really feel possible to stretch. And I remember when we were making â€œMastermind,â€ we were laughing at each other about going this way and that way. Itâ€™s a strange little song, and it just reminded me of the kind of thing that you can do with really close friends, whereas if it was a new relationship, you might not be able to dare to suck. Like, just try some weird shit. Because every once in a while, when you really throw yourself out there, you actually get the stuff thatâ€™s the most brilliant.
Most surprising Swift era
Oh, every one. Iâ€™ve never been in a room with her and felt like we were doing anything but treading new ground that weâ€™ve let last for even ten seconds. If weâ€™re not feeling it, weâ€™ll move right the hell along. What I think is fascinating about songwriting is you canâ€™t fake it. Thereâ€™s no shortcut; it comes or it doesnâ€™t. But the one thing that the years can do for you is at least recognize when itâ€™s not happening and get off quicker. When I was 19, I might go down a rabbit hole of some weird shit because I would care about the amount of time or the resources I put into it, and the more I do it, the more I realize that thatâ€™s a foolâ€™s errand. You show up, you hope to grab it, and you do or you donâ€™t. When Iâ€™m with my collaborators, the further we go down the road, the more weâ€™re only vibrating on the really special stuff.
Weâ€™ve been at this point for many years. I mean, we started working together on â€™89, we did a ton of work on Reputation, which was so wonderful and intense, and then Lover, we started to do some more strange things. When we did Folklore, that was obviously a really different angle, and some of the earlier songs, like â€œAugustâ€ and â€œMirrorball,â€ are some of my favorite things weâ€™ve ever done. You know, writing a song and collaborating with somebody, once you do it, youâ€™re like, Well, who knows if thatâ€™ll ever happen again, â€™cause itâ€™s just magic. With her, Iâ€™m constantly taken aback. Iâ€™ll joke with her sometimes when we get something crazy, like, â€œOkay, I guess we still fucking got it!â€ Thereâ€™s really nothing for her and I left to do if weâ€™re not completely stretching ourselves out there into the darkness. And that was the whole story with Midnights â€” we did so many things that we had never done before.
Hardest part of re-recording his own songs for 1989 (Taylorâ€™s Version)
I donâ€™t work with any soft synths, so everything is a sound thatâ€™s made in the room. The funny thing is you canâ€™t recall the sounds. So all the Bleachers guys helped a ton on that stuff. It became a really fun project for me and the band. It was like, â€œAll right, Mikey, here are the Juno tracks, do your best.â€ â€œSean, hereâ€™s the drum stuff, see what you can do.â€ And then Iâ€™ll have X amount of tracks that are just sound from the room. The internet was really interested in what sounded like a seagull sound in â€œIs It Over Now?â€ It was really fun, because it was all these analog instruments that we know and love: Moog model Ds, Juno-6s.
I would liken it to finding an old diary. There are so many things on so many of those sessions that I was like, Oh, you little freak. Little layering I would do then, â€™cause you go through phases, and it made me feel really sweet. That younger version of me that was just piling shit on, I mean, â€œOut of the Woodsâ€ is just like kitchen sink. Thatâ€™s the glory of it: As someone who didnâ€™t really have any success as a producer, there was no reason for me to pile all that shit on other than it was just giving me a lot of joy. And it made this weird, messy symphony and I love it to this day.
Most California song on Ocean Blvd
Definitely â€œPeppers.â€ Or â€œTaco Truck.â€ But Lanaâ€™s from Lake Placid and Iâ€™m from New Jersey. Sheâ€™s lived in California for a long time, so she really lives the life, but I do feel like both of us have this dream of California from growing up on the East Coast. Very often, someoneâ€™s idea of what a thing is can be a funnier, weirder version of what the thing is.
I actually think the most California song weâ€™ve ever made is â€œVenice Bitch,â€ and not for the obvious Venice line. I was thinking a lot about the space between Dick Dale and John Frusciante on the guitars; the drums, when I was playing them, I wanted them to feel like the early 2000s shoegaze scene that was happening out there. So Iâ€™m not saying itâ€™s a California thing â€” itâ€™s a New Jersey personâ€™s impression of California.
She and I will write a lot, and then the framework of the albums will come together. For example, â€œJimmy,â€ which ended up on â€œA&W,â€ was written during the Norman Fucking Rockwell sessions. So, the â€œVenice Bitchâ€ at the end of â€œTaco Truckâ€ is the original version of â€œVenice Bitch.â€ When we were doing Norman Rockwell, we had this whole idea of being up in Laurel Canyon and driving the truck down to the club. We moved on from that concept, so I had this original â€œVenice Bitch.â€ After we did â€œA&W,â€ where you have a song like â€œJimmyâ€ from that time period melding into it, I thought, This whole album is so sprawling and freaky. I just started putting things in weird places. This is another example of like, when you work with someone for a long time, you can start really getting weird. That was the theme of that album: Letâ€™s get fucking weird.
Most surprising the 1975 lyric
Iâ€™m not easily shocked, but the stuff that shocks or surprises me is often the most beautifully written stuff. A lot of his funnier, snarkier stuff thatâ€™s maybe more designed to shock, thatâ€™s one corner, but the stuff that really knocks me off my feet is when someone says something that just feels like a gut punch. The first song, Matty had that line, â€œIâ€™m sorry if youâ€™re living and youâ€™re 17,â€ which cuts me so much that I pushed it to become a repetitive thing. Itâ€™s not even about speaking to people that age â€” â€œIâ€™m sorry if youâ€™re living and youâ€™re 17â€ just feels so much like the experience of this moment. The one thing everyone agrees on is this grand failure of generations to come. When we were making that album, it was a pretty polarizing time in general, and that line just felt like a relief of a fact.
But yeah, the stuff that shocks me the most is someoneâ€™s vulnerability in a song. The end of â€œYouâ€™re on Your Own, Kidâ€ is one of those moments for me. I remember, she wrote that right in front of me and then we put it down, and I was completely punched in the gut. Beautiful.
Most Bleachers song on Bleachers
Thereâ€™s a song called â€œTiny Moves,â€ which no oneâ€™s heard yet. The real story there is I started writing music when I was 14 or 15, and my younger sister was sick then. She died when I was 18, so all my formative experiences with writing music were writing about this massive, heavy, big loss and grief. Then, obviously, that grief grows and changes. Itâ€™s such a fertile place to write from, and Iâ€™d felt a little bit resigned, not in a comfortable way, just like, Okay, my place in life as a writer is to write about loss through the lens of age. And donâ€™t get me wrong, thereâ€™s tons of that on this album. But I met my now-wife, and it feels like a lot of the mythology and armor that I wore â€” we all say, like, â€œI canâ€™t get relationships right,â€ â€œI donâ€™t do this,â€ â€œIâ€™m bad at this.â€ And when you have a big shift like that, which was really meeting my person, itâ€™s brilliant and amazing, but itâ€™s also destabilizing â€™cause you have to deal with all of the past, where you lived by this code that was bullshit. And within that, I found myself writing more conversationally, very deep and very intense. How do you have such a great loss and then also explore other parts of life? I wasnâ€™t able to do that in the past, because I felt like it was not honoring my loss to write about anything else. So, this is the first album where I explore other things, and thereâ€™s presence to it that I havenâ€™t had.
Best Bleachers saxophone part
â€‹â€‹Either â€œEverybody Lost Somebodyâ€ or â€œModern Girl.â€ Both those parts were written by Evan Smith, whoâ€™s one of our saxophone players. â€œModern Girlâ€ felt like a big, Knock down the front door, weâ€™re back! Itâ€™s giving me something that I felt like has been missing for a long time, which is, thereâ€™s so much weight in my music and thereâ€™s so much intensity, and thereâ€™s so much fucking weight in the world, and I just wanted music to be fucking fun and irreverent again. I wrote this whole song that basically roasts culture, roasts myself, has every inside joke about the band. Itâ€™s kind of a love letter to the fans, itâ€™s kind of a fuck-you to the things that bother me out there in the world, and most importantly, weâ€™re having a fucking blast playing it. Then also, you just donâ€™t hear saxophone out there, so I thought, Letâ€™s have the first thing people hear from the next album be this sax played like its head is on fire, and anyone whoâ€™s not feeling it is not who weâ€™re looking for.
Most influential Steel Train song to Bleachers
One thing Iâ€™m not sure that everyone fully understands: fun. was sort of this, like, left pivot. Iâ€™ve always written my own lyrics to my own songs, so it really went Outline, Steel Train, Bleachers, with production peppered through all of that. You know, fun. was this side project I started, with three friends, but it just had this funny hit, so it felt so front and center. But the ladder is Steel Train into Bleachers. I mean, the time between writing â€œBulletâ€ and â€œRollercoasterâ€ wasnâ€™t very far off.
Thereâ€™s a song called â€œS.O.G Burning in Hell,â€ which I feel like has a Bleachers-ness to it. It feels like trying to break through to that controlled chaos thing. Thatâ€™s a huge thing that Iâ€™m always after, that feeling of like, Is this thing gonna stay on the track? Like, I always want the audience to feel both safe and terrified all at once. I think with Bleachers, it really crystallized.
Hardest project youâ€™ve produced
Itâ€™s pretty rare that something is impossible to write or arrange. Itâ€™s more like, I can get very obsessive on making the sound be what I hear in my head. I feel like the process is like either you capture this crazy lightning in a bottle and then you spend your time protecting it, or you have this crazy idea of what you want something to be. Did you ever hear that Lorde song â€œHard Feelingsâ€? The end of that, production-wise, I was so obsessed with wanting it to be these crazy Transformers fighting sounds, but also really warm. I went really crazy on that. Melodrama was a really intense process. We were just tearing stuff apart. Weâ€™d do one thing one day, zero it out, try a whole other thing.
The end of â€œAugust,â€ the strings and twangy guitar â€” that was one where it was really in my head, production-wise, for a long time. The end has to be so euphoric. Sheâ€™s talking about, like, â€œMeet me behind the mallâ€ and â€œBack when we were living for the hope of it all.â€ I kept attaching to all of her lyrics and being like, This crescendo at the end has to feel like all of that, on fire.
The second Bleachers album, Gone Now, almost killed me, because I felt so fucking obsessive about what I had to say after being given the success I had off the first album. Like, This is the moment, I have to get this right. That second-album anxiety is pretty fucking heavy and with good reason. Youâ€™re given an opportunity, and youâ€™re just standing there remembering all the things that you thought your whole life that you had that opportunity.
Song you produced that you want to steal for Bleachers
You know, thereâ€™s not really one. Like, stuff on Bleachers albums, itâ€™s so separate. Iâ€™ve written songs with Lana that have been on Bleachers albums, obviously â€œAlma Mater.â€ When I was exiting fun. and trying to get everyone to focus on Bleachers, but also wanting people to understand what I did as a producer, I feel like I created a lot of separation. Like, This is when Iâ€™m in the studio for Bleachers. This is when Iâ€™m in the studio producing an album. But it wasnâ€™t very true, to be honest. Itâ€™s a pretty connected group of friends and weâ€™re bouncing around a lot, playing on each otherâ€™s records, writing records with each other. I donâ€™t regret creating that narrative, but itâ€™s not the most truthful one. I care less about that now, because I feel like I can recognize a community around it.
This interview has been edited for clarity.

content:

title: The 50 best albums of 2023, No 6 - Lana Del Rey: Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd
content:
Intoxicating love, triumphant self-destruction, abject abandonment, simmering-to-roiling melancholia: this is the tonal palette Lana Del Rey has spent the past 12 years fashioning into a heady sonic calling card. Pop is still thrilled by reinvention, but for the musician born Elizabeth Grant consistency is crucial: her inner darkness is always rendered in languid, sumptuously beautiful ballads littered with strange, specific detail and steeped in the musty beauty of golden age Hollywood, as well as the gritty romance of everyday Americana. Songs are occasionally jolted into the 21st century by sharply flickering trap beats and always by her voice, a puffy sonic pout with a slight slur â€“ in the past she has christened the cumulative style â€œnarco swing.â€
On her lovely and perturbing ninth album, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, Del Rey continues to map out this turbulent, symbol-strewn emotional landscape with disturbing ferocity: if the wretched creature here doesnâ€™t line up with your mental image of a superstar singer-songwriter, you havenâ€™t been consuming enough celebrity misery memoirs. On the hauntingly gorgeous title track â€“ which takes pains to pinpoint her favourite moment of Harry Nilssonâ€™s 1974 single Donâ€™t Forget Me â€“ she identifies hard with the eponymous tunnel, which has been boarded up for decades. Del Rey is tired of being closed off and terrified of being forgotten: she needs to be walked through. â€œOpen me up, tell me you like it / Fuck me to death, love me until I love myself,â€ she croons elegiacally.
That craving for ego-obliterating affection is her lodestar; a pop trope she gave a cleverly contemporary spin on her 2011 breakthrough single Video Games. That song was a celebration of all-consuming romance, however wilfully delusional â€“ yet on this albumâ€™s staggering standout track A&W she has been robbed even of that. â€œItâ€™s not about having someone to love me any more / This is the experience of being an American whore,â€ she mutters over scratchy acoustic guitar and warbling keys. Gradually, synths drone louder, a hypnotic trap beat appears, and things get blurry, feedback-drenched and faintly industrial. We hear about Jimmy, who only loves her â€œwhen he wanna get highâ€, while Del Rey herself multiplies into a drugged-up choir destined for â€œthe clubâ€. It feels like a desperate cry from a pained soul, but also something more abstract and conceptual; a twisted anthem for an opioid-ravaged America, even.
Lana Del Rey: Candy Necklace ft Jon Batiste â€“ video
Ocean Blvd does not begin with one of these poetic studies in disturbing dysfunctionality: gospel choir-backed opener The Grants is uncharacteristically wholesome, if characteristically morbid, as Del Rey counts the treasured memories â€“ her niece, her grandmotherâ€™s final smile â€“ that her pastor says are the only things she can transport into the afterlife. A few tracks later, she murmurs and chuckles along with an extensive recording of the controversial megachurch preacher Judah Smith, who has expressed anti-abortion and homophobic views. Critics were confused â€“ was this an endorsement, or a satirical takedown?
On Ocean Blvd, Del Reyâ€™s inbuilt ambiguity seeps deep into the music too. Instead of the smattering of pop songs â€“ strangely unsettling, always, but catchy as well â€“ that made her name in the 2010s, she now deals almost exclusively in impressionistic material which doesnâ€™t instantly hit the pleasure centre. These tracks reward repeated listening, such as Candy Necklace â€“ a Jon Batiste collaboration dense with Del Rey tropes (idealistic love, obsessive love, soul-sucking love) that is meandering at first, later potent and indelible. It pays dividends to invest in her world, an articulation of American darkness, of female pain, of the quest for temporary transcendence. Del Reyâ€™s music has always been partly about cheap, empty thrills, but this richly imagistic, captivatingly cryptic album is never one itself.

title: Karol G Reveals Tour Secrets: Workouts, Lana Del Rey & More
content:
When Karol G decided to go on a stadium tour, she recalls, someone asked her how prepared she was. â€œâ€˜BeyoncÃ© is doing stadiums. Taylor Swift is doing stadiums. Are you ready?â€™ And I answered, â€˜No, today Iâ€™m not. But I will be ready, because it depends on me.â€™â€
Explore Explore Karol G See latest videos, charts and news See latest videos, charts and news
Six months later, Karol G, the subject of this weekâ€™s Billboard cover story, was onstage in a phenomenally quick turnaround, and, most importantly, an astoundingly successful one. By year-end, she was the highest grossing Latin artist of 2023 according to Billboard Boxscore.
But planning to perform in stadiums and actually performing are two very different things. For Karol, it starts with the basic love of performance. â€œThe stage is my happiest place,â€ she tells Billboard. â€œItâ€™s not like Iâ€™m always happy and perfect when I go onstage. But when I go out, thereâ€™s nothing the energy in that place canâ€™t cure.â€
When it came time to plan her MaÃ±ana SerÃ¡ Bonito Tour, the singer says that she and her team knew it was time to take on bigger audiences. â€œIt was something we discussed a lot internally,â€ she says. â€œI came from doing the â€˜Bichotaâ€™ tour, then $trip Love tour. Everyone said, â€˜You have to let people breathe. A lot of artists are touring.â€™ Then, I released MaÃ±ana serÃ¡ bonito. This album, I feel, got into peopleâ€™s bodies, their veins, and it touched something in them. I had never felt as much love from my fans as with this album.â€
Playing MaÃ±ana live became a mission. The first step in preparing, says Karol, was â€œproving to myself that I was ready to do it. We had the pressure of knowing BeyoncÃ© and Taylor Swift would be touring at the same time, so it couldnâ€™t look like Karol G was the one who had no business doing a stadium tour. It was a huge personal challenge from how I looked to how I thought.â€
Among the challenges was getting physically fit â€” between changing her diet and exercise routine and getting mentally prepared for the show, Karol says the physical preparation for her show brought out a major change in her.
â€œItâ€™s spending two hours and 45 minutes in a place thatâ€™s five or six times bigger than what youâ€™re used to, singing and dancing, so there was a big physical challenge,â€ she says. â€œI had worked out my entire life, my muscles were used to it, so I began to see changes. And the more change I saw, the more I wanted to do!â€
However, she says, the hardest challenge was having MaÃ±ana serÃ¡ bonito, and MaÃ±ana serÃ¡ bonito: Bichota season â€“ two very different albums â€” coexist in the same show.
â€œItâ€™s two completely different worlds,â€ she says. â€œSo, I wrote a mini book [a concept that opens the show] where I explained everything, and I gave it to [the tour designers], and said: â€˜This is my story. This is Carolinaâ€™s story, and I want her to be a siren.â€™ And they found the way to make it work.â€
Going to a Karol G show is a bit like a religious experience â€” multiple generations gather together in a collective exercise of letting go that begins hours, even days before a show, when fans decide what to wear, what wig to buy, what signs to take to catch Karolâ€™s attention; sheâ€™s known for constantly engaging with fans from the stage, sometimes dropping out of a choreography mid-song for a picture, a kiss, a hello.
â€œItâ€™s an energy,â€ Karol says. â€œAfter a show, I put on Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€˜Summertime Sadnessâ€™ and I lie in bed crying thinking how amazing shows are. If you could turn off the light and just see the energy, it would be blinding. The most beautiful thing about my shows is people arrive with the intention to heal. Their intentions are so beautiful that when I go onstage, and all that energy is directed toward me, I feel like a battery thatâ€™s recharging, and filling up and sometimes I cry a lot in my shows. I try not to, but my heart feels like itâ€™s going to burst.â€
Read the full cover story here.

title: Lana Del Rey annuncia un album country intitolato Lasso: ecco tutto quello che c'Ã¨ da sapere
content:
La cantautrice, poetessa e modella statunitense ha dato la notizia ufficiale di una nuova fatica discografica in arrivo. Ha annunciato ai Billboard x NMPA Songwriter Awards che il suo prossimo lavoro uscirÃ  a settembre, con una virata verso un genere differente da quel pop e indie a cui ci aveva abituato. L'annuncio risale a mercoledÃ¬ 31 gennaio 2024, in occasione della premiazione ai cantautori tenutasi a Los Angeles
Lana Del Rey ha annunciato l'arrivo di un nuovo album, che uscirÃ  nel settembre 2024 per stupire il pubblico della cantautrice, poetessa e modella statunitense con una virata verso un genere differente da quel pop e indie a cui ci aveva abituato. Il nuovo disco, infatti, sarÃ  country, con un titolo che Ã¨ stato giÃ  annunciato nelle scorse ore: Lasso.
Questo sarÃ  il suo quarto album in soli tre anni e mezzo, e cinque anni dal fortunato incontro che ebbe con Jack Antonoff, produttore che si cela ancora una volta dietro a questa sua nuova fatica discografica.
Ricordiamo che, oltre ai dischi veri e propri, Lana Del Rey ha anche prodotto l'audiolibro Violet Bent Backwards over the Grass del 2020. Del Ray vanta nove apparizioni nella top 10 della classifica Billboard 200, incluso due primi posti, con Ultraviolence del 2014 e Lust for Life del 2017.
La star ha fatto lâ€™annuncio del suo prossimo disco Lasso ai Billboard x NMPA Songwriter Awards mercoledÃ¬ 31 gennaio 2024, in occasione della premiazione dei cantautori piÃ¹ meritevoli tenutasi a Los Angeles. Mentre rendeva omaggio dal palco a Jack Antonoff - in corsa per diventare il secondo creativo a vincere il Grammy come produttore dell'anno per tre anni consecutivi, unendosi cosÃ¬ a Babyface - Del Rey ha svelato i dettagli del suo prossimo progetto.
Lana Del Rey: â€œLâ€™industria musicale sta diventando countryâ€ "Se non ve ne siete giÃ  accorti dai nostri vincitori e dai nostri interpreti, l'industria musicale sta diventando countryâ€, ha dichiarato Lana Del Rey sul palco dei Billboard x NMPA Songwriter Awards. â€œCi stiamo dirigendo verso il country. Sta succedendo. Ecco perchÃ© Jack Antonoff mi ha seguito a Muscle Shoals, Nashville, Mississippi, negli ultimi quattro anniâ€, ha aggiunto. Il risultato di questo viaggio musicale Ã¨ un nuovo album in uscita a settembre, intitolato Lasso. Si tratta del suo decimo album in studio, che segue Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd del 2023, che ha raggiunto la posizione n. 3 nella classifica Billboard 200.
approfondimento Lana Del Rey, in Italia nel 2024 sul palco degli I-Days di Milano
Jack Antonoff, il produttore che sta dietro al nuovo album country di Lana Del Rey Antonoff Ã¨ uno dei produttori piÃ¹ premiati, celebri e ricercati delle sette note mondiali. Ha giÃ  vinto ben otto Grammy Awards e ha sei opportunitÃ  in piÃ¹ di aggiungere a quella collezione nuovi premi alla 66Âª edizione dei Grammy annuali, in programma per questa domenica, 4 febbraio, a Los Angeles, dove Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd di Lana Del Rey e Midnights di Taylor Swift (entrambi dischi che si avvalgono del suo lavoro) sono in lizza per diversi riconoscimenti. Essere nominato produttore dell'anno per cinque anni consecutivi, sottolinea Lana Del Rey, Ã¨ "tutto tranne che fortuna". La cantautrice ha proseguito dicendo che Antonoff Ã¨ nato sotto una di quelle stelle musicali talentuose e fortunate e, come produttore e creativo, puÃ² praticamente fare tutto.
approfondimento Incidente concerto di Lana del Rey in Messico, pubblico cade a terra
La cantautrice ha raccontato il suo primo incontro con Antonoff Del Rey ha raccontato il suo primo incontro con Antonoff. Ãˆ avvenuto a una delle leggendarie feste pre-Grammy di Clive Davis. Era il 2018, una notte particolarmente "interessante", spiega, avendo appena rotto con un fidanzato, proprio pochi giorni prima della piÃ¹ grande notte dell'industria discografica, a cui partecipava per la seconda volta nella sua vita. La star ha spiegato sul palco dei Billboard x NMPA Songwriter Awards che con Jack Antonoff si Ã¨ creata un'amicizia istantanea, sottolineando che lui Ã¨ "amico di tutti". Questa amicizia ha portato poi a una collaborazione in studio, dove sono state create cinque canzoni in un solo giorno. Lana Del Rey ha proseguito dicendo che le progressioni di accordi di Antonoff sono "senza tempo, istantaneamente classiche". E i suoi "istinti sono unici. E apparentemente vincenti di premi". Aggiunge che un uomo della musica del genere Ã¨ una cosa davvero rara, "uno su un milione". Del resto la cantautrice americana deve molto al suo amico e produttore, dato che proprio la collaborazione musicale con Antonoff le sta dando grandi soddisfazioni, sia lato riconoscimenti sia sul piano dei guadagni. approfondimento Lana Del Rey, arrestato un uomo per minacce di morte contro di lei

title: Entenda briga que fez Universal tirar mÃºsicas do TikTok
content:
The New York Times
Os usuÃ¡rios do TikTok acordaram na quinta-feira e descobriram que muitos vÃ­deos usando mÃºsicas de estrelas como Taylor Swift, Lana Del Rey, Drake e Ariana Grande ficaram silenciosos, apÃ³s uma briga pÃºblica entre o TikTok e a Universal Music Group, a maior empresa de mÃºsica do mundo.
A cantora Taylor Swift se apresenta no Brasil - Adriano Vizoni/Folhapress
Foi uma reviravolta surpreendente para os criadores e usuÃ¡rios do aplicativo, bem como para a indÃºstria da mÃºsica, onde negociaÃ§Ãµes acaloradas sobre permissÃµes de direitos autorais e termos de royalties Ã s vezes transbordam para a visÃ£o pÃºblica, mas raramente chegam ao que uma publicaÃ§Ã£o do setor chamou de "opÃ§Ã£o nuclear" â€”a remoÃ§Ã£o em larga escala de conteÃºdo de um dos maiores e mais influentes pontos de venda online da mÃºsica.
Aqui estÃ¡ uma visÃ£o do que aconteceu e por quÃª, e algumas reflexÃµes sobre o que pode acontecer a seguir.
Por que a Universal Music saiu do TikTok?
Na terÃ§a-feira, a Universal Music, a gigante global que lanÃ§a mÃºsicas de centenas de artistas importantes, publicou uma carta aberta contundente ao TikTok quando o fim de seu contrato com a plataforma de mÃ­dia social se aproximava.
A Universal afirmou que o TikTok, que Ã© de propriedade da empresa chinesa ByteDance, nÃ£o havia abordado adequadamente as preocupaÃ§Ãµes da Universal sobre mÃºsica gerada por inteligÃªncia artificial na plataforma e que nÃ£o concordaria com o que a Universal considerava uma taxa de royalties satisfatÃ³ria.
"No final das contas, o TikTok estÃ¡ tentando construir um negÃ³cio baseado em mÃºsica", disse o selo, "sem pagar um valor justo pela mÃºsica".
A Universal observou que seu acordo existente com o TikTok estava programado para expirar na quarta-feira e o selo disse que revogaria suas licenÃ§as â€”as permissÃµes legais para usar sua mÃºsicasâ€” e um acordo nÃ£o fosse alcanÃ§ado. O prazo passou, e o TikTok confirmou na quinta-feira que havia comeÃ§ado a remover o acesso ao vasto catÃ¡logo de mÃºsicas da Universal.
O que Ã© a Universal Music?
A Universal Ã© a maior das trÃªs principais conglomerados de mÃºsica â€”os outros sÃ£o Sony e Warnerâ€” que tÃªm acordos com milhares de estrelas da mÃºsica para lanÃ§ar suas mÃºsicas. AlÃ©m de Swift e Drake, os maiores nomes de suas gravadoras incluem Olivia Rodrigo, Morgan Wallen, Nicki Minaj, Billie Eilish, Noah Kahan, Post Malone e Lorde, e ela tem acordos com gigantes do K-pop como Stray Kids e NewJeans.
As gravadoras da empresa incluem Interscope, Geffen, Island, Def Jam, Capitol, Motown, Blue Note e Republic, e ela tambÃ©m possui uma extensa divisÃ£o de publicaÃ§Ã£o de mÃºsica para compositores.
O CEO da Universal, Lucian Grainge, Ã© um experiente caÃ§ador de talentos que, hÃ¡ mais de uma dÃ©cada, tem sido um dos lÃ­deres corporativos dominantes da indÃºstria. Na maioria dos anos, ele tende a ficar em primeiro lugar na lista anual "Power 100" da Billboard. Este ano, ele estÃ¡ em segundo lugar â€”atrÃ¡s de Swift, com quem Grainge Ã© dito ter um relacionamento de trabalho prÃ³ximo.
A Universal tem sido agressiva na defesa dos direitos de seus artistas e na busca dos melhores acordos que pode obter; no ano passado, a empresa processou o Triller, outro aplicativo de mÃ­dia social, alegando que nÃ£o havia pago taxas de licenciamento. Recentemente, Grainge tem sido enfÃ¡tico sobre a necessidade de controles e padrÃµes da indÃºstria em relaÃ§Ã£o ao uso de inteligÃªncia artificial na mÃºsica.
Como funcionarÃ£o as remoÃ§Ãµes?
Quando a indÃºstria da mÃºsica teve problemas no passado com plataformas de streaming como o Spotify, ela teve a capacidade â€”teoricamente, de qualquer maneira; sempre Ã© complicadoâ€” de simplesmente retirar seu conteÃºdo. Foi o que aconteceu quando a Warner Music brigou com o YouTube por nove meses em 2008 e 2009.
Mas o TikTok Ã© diferente. No aplicativo, os usuÃ¡rios carregam seus prÃ³prios videoclipes e podem usar uma biblioteca de Ã¡udio â€”grande parte fornecida por gravadoras como a Universalâ€” para adicionar sons de fundo. Artistas e gravadoras tambÃ©m adicionam seu prÃ³prio conteÃºdo.
Para cumprir as retiradas da Universal, o TikTok removeu as mÃºsicas da empresa de sua biblioteca de mÃºsica, o que tornou essas mÃºsicas indisponÃ­veis para novos clipes.
Para vÃ­deos antigos que jÃ¡ tinham mÃºsica da Universal, o TikTok comeÃ§ou a "silenciar" os clipes na quinta-feira â€”excluindo completamente o Ã¡udio, deixando vÃ­deos silenciosos. Isso aconteceu com vÃ­deos de celebridades como Kylie Jenner e Dwayne Johnson (tambÃ©m conhecido como The Rock), bem como em inÃºmeros outros; muitos incluÃ­am notas explicativas como "Este som nÃ£o estÃ¡ disponÃ­vel".
Nas pÃ¡ginas de perfil oficial de artistas como Swift, as seÃ§Ãµes que normalmente continham dezenas de mÃºsicas para os usuÃ¡rios apresentarem ficaram em grande parte vazias. (Em alguns casos, trechos breves ou mixagens geradas pelo usuÃ¡rio permaneceram.)
Espera-se que o processo completo de remoÃ§Ã£o leve pelo menos vÃ¡rios dias. Um representante do TikTok nÃ£o informou na quinta-feira quantos vÃ­deos seriam afetados pela retirada da Universal, mas poderia ser concebivelmente milhÃµes.
Por que isso estÃ¡ acontecendo?
De certa forma, este Ã© um exemplo de um conflito que se repetiu vÃ¡rias vezes no setor de mÃ­dia ao longo das Ãºltimas dÃ©cadas, no qual as inovaÃ§Ãµes das empresas de tecnologia â€”e, Ã s vezes, a criatividade dos usuÃ¡rios que burlam as regras se chocam com as demandas da indÃºstria musical por controle e compensaÃ§Ã£o justa.
Essa tensÃ£o tem sido uma forÃ§a motriz na indÃºstria musical, desde o Napster e o YouTube atÃ© o Pandora e, agora, o TikTok.
As preocupaÃ§Ãµes da Universal sÃ£o reais e refletem alguns dos desafios mais urgentes no negÃ³cio da mÃºsica hoje: a necessidade dos artistas de ganhar a vida decentemente, os parÃ¢metros dos contratos de licenciamento modernos, o papel da inteligÃªncia artificial.
E nos Ãºltimos anos, as empresas de mÃºsica comeÃ§aram a se adaptar Ã  realidade de que a atenÃ§Ã£o dos fÃ£s de mÃºsica nÃ£o estÃ¡ apenas focada em plataformas de streaming tipo jukebox, como o Spotify ou o Apple Music, mas tambÃ©m em uma variedade de plataformas sociais, como o TikTok, onde a mÃºsica pode ser apenas uma atraÃ§Ã£o.
Para o TikTok, assim como qualquer empresa de mÃ­dia social, a questÃ£o pode envolver atÃ© que ponto estÃ¡ disposto a ceder a qualquer parceiro de conteÃºdo. Por mais importante que a mÃºsica seja no TikTok â€”a empresa jÃ¡ disse no passado que "a mÃºsica estÃ¡ no coraÃ§Ã£o da experiÃªncia do TikTok" - ela nÃ£o representa a totalidade da experiÃªncia no aplicativo; como qualquer usuÃ¡rio do TikTok sabe, uma mÃºsica pode ser apenas o plano de fundo sonoro de um tutorial de maquiagem ou um guia de encanamento.
Como isso pode afetar os mÃºsicos?
Isso Ã© uma consideraÃ§Ã£o importante para a Universal, que diz estar buscando um acordo melhor para seus artistas. Ao mesmo tempo, quanto mais a disputa se arrasta, mais pode prejudicar os artistas, pelo menos a curto prazo. O TikTok Ã© uma plataforma de promoÃ§Ã£o vital, e uma geraÃ§Ã£o de fÃ£s jovens agora depende do aplicativo para descobrir mÃºsicas, antigas e novas.
Alguns dos momentos mais importantes da mÃºsica nos Ãºltimos anos aconteceram no TikTok, desde o sucesso de "Old Town Road" de Lil Nas X e "Drivers License" de Olivia Rodrigo atÃ© a volta de "Dreams" do Fleetwood Mac. Para muitos artistas hoje, estar ausente do TikTok seria como Madonna ter um vÃ­deo desaparecido da MTV nos anos 1980.
Ao mesmo tempo, porÃ©m, os artistas estÃ£o cientes da necessidade de obter acordos melhores para sua mÃºsica e das baixas taxas que enfrentam em todo o cenÃ¡rio de streaming. Fale com um artista por dois minutos sobre o negÃ³cio e ele lhe dirÃ¡ que deveria ganhar mais dinheiro com streaming. Eles simplesmente nÃ£o querem sacrificar a promoÃ§Ã£o ou a conexÃ£o com os fÃ£s no processo.
O que acontece agora?
Aguardamos para ver quem cede primeiro.
O elenco de estrelas da Universal lhe dÃ¡ vantagem, e perder o acesso a uma biblioteca de milhares das mÃºsicas mais populares do mundo nÃ£o Ã© bom para o TikTok. Aplicativos com componente musical dependem de seus acordos de licenciamento com empresas de entretenimento, e os usuÃ¡rios esperam ter uma ampla seleÃ§Ã£o.
Por outro lado, o TikTok tem acordos de licenciamento com muitas outras empresas de mÃºsica, e os usuÃ¡rios logo podem perceber que, se perderem o acesso a uma mÃºsica da Lady Gaga, podem escolher uma da Dua Lipa (uma artista da Warner), por exemplo.
No entanto, o maior poder pode residir nos artistas da Universal, especialmente aqueles que tÃªm mÃºsicas novas para promover; se eles sentirem que o conflito estÃ¡ comeÃ§ando a prejudicÃ¡-los mais do que um novo acordo poderia ajudar, eles farÃ£o isso saber.

title: Taylor Swift weit vorne: DiesjÃ¤hrige Grammys von Frauen dominiert
content:
Am Sonntag werden in Los Angeles die Grammy verliehen. In diesem Jahr sind deutlich mehr KÃ¼nstlerinnen nominiert als in der Vergangenheit. Neben Lana Del Rey, Billie Eilish und Olivia Rodrigo ist natÃ¼rlich auch Taylor Swift dabei. Sie kÃ¶nnte mit Frank Sinatra und Stevie Wonder gleichziehen.
Wer die Liste der grÃ¶ÃŸten Grammy-Hoffnungen durchgeht, merkt sofort, dass dieses Jahr Frauen die Nominierungen fÃ¼r den wohl wichtigsten Musikpreis der Welt dominieren. Taylor Swift, SZA, Olivia Rodrigo, Billie Eilish, Victoria MonÃ©t, Miley Cyrus, Lana Del Rey, Dua Lipa und die weibliche Supergroup Boygenius mit Phoebe Bridgers dÃ¼rfen sich bei der Preisverleihung am Sonntagabend (Ortszeit) Chancen ausrechnen. MÃ¤nner dÃ¼rften bei der Grammofon-Vergabe in Los Angeles zumindest in den prestigetrÃ¤chtigsten Kategorien leer ausgehen. Dabei kÃ¶nnte sogar eine Frau abrÃ¤umen, die nicht einmal Musik macht.
Dreimal gewann der wohl grÃ¶ÃŸte Musikstar der Gegenwart bereits einen Grammy in der Kategorie "Bestes Album" - nun kÃ¶nnte Taylor Swift nach "Fearless", "1989" und "Folklore" den vierten Coup folgen lassen: Mit ihrem Album "Midnights" ist sie heiÃŸe AnwÃ¤rterin auf den Sieg. Swift wÃ¼rde dann gleichziehen mit Paul Simon, Frank Sinatra und Stevie Wonder, die ebenfalls viermal in dieser Kategorie ausgezeichnet wurden. Die 34-JÃ¤hrige, die mit ihrer "Eras-Tour" Millionen Fans anzieht und Rekordsummen einnimmt, muss fÃ¼r den Abend aber auf die Begleitung ihres neuen Freundes Travis Kelce verzichten. Der Footballspieler der Kansas City Chiefs bereitet sich mit seinem Team auf den Super Bowl vor.
Konkurrenz ist groÃŸ
Swifts Sieg ist alles andere als ausgemacht, denn die Konkurrenz ist riesig: Die amerikanische Singer-Songwriterin SZA, mit bÃ¼rgerlichem Namen SolÃ¡na Rowe, tritt mit ihrem Album "SOS" an und ist mit insgesamt neun Nominierungen die chancenreichste KÃ¼nstlerin am Sonntag. Chancen auf den Preis fÃ¼rs beste Album haben auch die SÃ¤ngerinnen Olivia Rodrigo ("Guts"), Lana Del Rey ("Did You Know That There's a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd"), Miley Cyrus ("Endless Summer Vacation") und Boygenius ("The Record").
Ã„hnlich hochkarÃ¤tig sieht es in den beiden anderen Hauptkategorien "Aufnahme des Jahres" und "Song des Jahres" aus, wo auch ein Mann allein gegen die weiblichen Stars antritt: Der eklektische KÃ¼nstler Jon Batiste ("World Music Radio") ist fÃ¼r die Songs "Worship" und "Butterfly" nominiert. R&B-SÃ¤ngerin Victoria MonÃ©t darf sich derweil Hoffnung in sieben Disziplinen machen - bei Swift, Rodrigo, Eilish, Cyrus und Boygenius sind es deren sechs. Auch der berÃ¼hmte Produzent Jack Antonoff hat mehrere Chancen auf die begehrte Statue.
Die Grammys werden in diesem Jahr zum 66. Mal verliehen. Rund 13.000 Mitglieder der Recording Academy entscheiden Ã¼ber die PreistrÃ¤ger der goldenen Grammofone, die zu den begehrtesten Musikpreisen der Welt zÃ¤hlen und in 94 Kategorien vergeben werden.
Barbie... Barbie?
Und ja, auch Barbie sollte eine Rolle spielen. Selbst bei den Grammys ist die Plastikpuppe, die sich in den Augen einiger 2023 zu einer feministischen Kino-Ikone aufschwang, eine TrophÃ¤en-Asprirantin. Denn das Album zum "Barbie Movie" geht in mehreren Kategorien fÃ¼r ein Grammofon an den Start: Allen voran Billie Eilishs "What Was I Made For?", nominiert fÃ¼r die Aufnahme und den Song des Jahres.
Vereiteln kÃ¶nnten das Rodrigos "Vampire", SZAs "Kill Bill" oder Swifts "Anti-Hero". Auftreten werden die drei Superstars an dem Abend auch - neben einigen bekannten Gesichtern wie Joni Mitchell und Billy Joel sowie der irischen Band U2. Comedian Trevor Noah wird die Grammys zum vierten Mal in Folge moderieren.

title: Taylor Swift y Lana del Rey compartirÃ¡n mesa en los Grammys: asÃ­ reaccionan las redes
content:
El prÃ³ximo domingo se celebrarÃ¡ la 66Âª ediciÃ³n de los Premios Grammy en el estadio Crypto.com Arena de Los Ãngeles y la expectativa es muy grande entre los fanÃ¡ticos. Precisamente, en las Ãºltimas horas se revelÃ³ que Taylor Swift, una de las artistas del momento, compartirÃ¡ mesa con Lana del Rey. La noticia se origina en medio de la noticia que la mÃºsica de ambas desaparecerÃ¡ de TikTok, tras el anuncio de Universal Music Group.
Una de las artistas que el mundo espera ver en la 66Âª ediciÃ³n de los Premios Grammy es Taylor Swift, la cantante de 34 aÃ±os que en los prÃ³ximos dÃ­as retomarÃ¡ su The Eras Tour. Pese a que sus fanÃ¡ticos esperaban que su novio Travis Kelce le acompaÃ±e en el evento, el jugador de los Chiefs confirmÃ³ que no serÃ¡ posible.
Sin embargo, Taylor Swift compartirÃ¡ mesa con su amiga y compatriota, Lana del Rey. AsÃ­ lo revelÃ³ el medio CBS, a travÃ©s de un video compartido en su cuenta de Instagram.
La amistada de Taylor Swift y Lana del Rey
La amistad de Taylor Swift y Lana del Rey se remonta hacia el aÃ±o 2012, durante los MTV European Music Awards (EMA), que se realizÃ³ en en el Festhalle de Frankfurt am Main, Alemania. Lana del Rey, quien era la presentadora, le entregÃ³ el premio a la Mejor Mujer.
AdemÃ¡s, las estadounidenses son representadas por Universal Music Group, editora musical lÃ­der en el mundo que hace poco anunciÃ³ la no renovaciÃ³n con TikTok.

title: Grammys 2024 Predictions: Who Will Win and Who Should Win?
content:
The Grammy Awards are back on Sunday night, and isnâ€™t that great? SZA leads the field with nine nominations. Victoria MonÃ©t and Boygenius arenâ€™t far behind. For the past couple of years, each of the Big Four categories had 10 nominees. This year, when voting for Album of the Year, Record of the Year, Song of the Year, or Best New Artist, the Recording Academyâ€™s members had to choose between only eight contenders apiece. In theory, that should mean less vote-splitting and solid, meaningful victories. In practice, weâ€™ll just have to wait and see.
The Grammys will be there againâ€”live from Los Angelesâ€™ Crypto.com Arenaâ€”to delight, maybe disappoint, and, at the very least, add to the discourse at 8 p.m. Eastern on CBS and Paramount+ With Showtime. Hereâ€™s our breakdown of who will win and who should win in key categories weâ€™re watching.
Album of the Year
Boygenius - The Record
Janelle MonÃ¡e - The Age of Pleasure
Jon Batiste - World Music Radio
Lana Del Rey - Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd
Miley Cyrus - Endless Summer Vacation
Olivia Rodrigo - Guts
SZA - SOS
Taylor Swift - Midnights
Should win: SZA - SOS
Will win: Olivia Rodrigo - Guts
Taylor Swift may look like the easy choice, as a Grammy Award for Album of the Year in 2024 would be her fourth win in this categoryâ€”the most by any primary artist, ever, breaking Swiftâ€™s current tie with music legends Stevie Wonder, Frank Sinatra, and Paul Simon. Still, Olivia Rodrigo is also a Grammy darling, with three statuettes to her name, including Best New Artist in 2022. Importantly, Rodrigoâ€™s beloved sophomore album, Guts, rocks out with an alt-pop energy and razor-sharp wit that could feel like the future to the academy voters.
Boygenius, Lana Del Rey, and Janelle MonÃ¡e would be welcome winners, but itâ€™s SZA who deserves this trophy for SOS, her soul-baring, genre-hopping tour de force. Strangely, what might be holding her back is that the artist with the most Grammy nominations in a given year often leaves without best-album honors (just ask Kendrick Lamar and â€‹â€‹BeyoncÃ©). Between two rising stars with angry hit songs about exes, Rodrigo seems the more likely to land on the Grammy stage accepting this award. Bad idea, right? Nah, seriously, itâ€™s fine. â€“Marc Hogan
Record of the Year

title: Lana Del Rey Teases New Country Album Lasso
content:
Last night, at a Billboard event, Lana Del Rey revealed the title, release month, and genre of her next album: Lasso, a country album, is out in September. â€œIf you canâ€™t already tell by our award winners and our performers, the music business is going country. Weâ€™re going country. Itâ€™s happening,â€ Del Rey said, according to Billboard. â€œThatâ€™s why [producer] Jack [Antonoff] has followed me to Muscle Shoals, Nashville, Mississippi, over the last four years.â€
When reached by Pitchfork, Lana Del Rey and Jack Antonoffâ€™s respective representatives had no further comment or information to share on Lasso.
Lana Del Rey has been known to tease albums that donâ€™t come out exactly the way she plannedâ€”or donâ€™t necessarily come out at all. For instance, immediately following the release of Chemtrails Over the Country Club, she said that a follow-up called Rock Candy Sweet would arrive June 1, 2021. Instead, Blue Banisters came out October 22.
As far as albums that havenâ€™t materialized, Del Rey said in November 2020 that sheâ€™d release â€œa digital record of American standards and classics for Christmas.â€ Instead, she shared only a cover of â€œYouâ€™ll Never Walk Alone.â€
Del Rey also told Mojo about an in-progress country covers album. â€œI went back and listened to â€˜Rideâ€™ and â€˜Video Gamesâ€™ and thought, you know theyâ€™re kind of country,â€ Del Rey said. â€œMaybe the way â€˜Video Gamesâ€™ got remastered, theyâ€™re popâ€”but thereâ€™s something Americana about it for sure.â€
As far as her more recent forays into country music, Del Rey, in December, shared her cover of the John Denver staple â€œTake Me Home, Country Roads.â€ The cover arrived after her U.S. tour that focused on the South and Appalachia. In addition, the singer was among the performers in NBCâ€™s Christmas at Graceland, filmed at Elvis Presleyâ€™s iconic Memphis estate. For the special, she sang â€œUnchained Melody.â€
Lasso will follow Lana Del Reyâ€™s Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, which you can read about at No. 11 in Pitchforkâ€™s â€œThe 50 Best Albums of 2023.â€

title: Lana Del Rey to release new country album â€˜Lassoâ€™ in September 2024
content:
Lana Del Rey is branching out into country music with her upcoming album â€˜Lassoâ€™
Lana Del Rey is going country.
Speaking to the audience at Billboardâ€™s pre-Grammy event on Wednesday, the Summertime Sadness hitmaker announced that she is releasing a new album entitled Lasso in September this year.
The 38-year-old songstress reflected that there is a huge shift happening in the music industry, and sheâ€™s hopping on board.
â€œIf you canâ€™t already tell by our award winners and our performers, the music business is going country. Weâ€™re going country. Itâ€™s happening,â€ she said.
Lasso will be Lanaâ€™s 10th studio album following her Grammy-nominated Did You Know That Thereâ€™s A Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd last year.
The Young and Beautiful singer further revealed that she will work alongside her regular collaborator Jack Antonoff and country musician Luke Laird for the upcoming project.
â€œThatâ€™s why Jack has followed me to Muscle Shoals, Nashville, Mississippi, over the last four years,â€ she added.
The announcement followed Lanaâ€™s admission that she will eventually be ready to venture into motherhood â€“ following her split from Evan Winiker.
But before she gets there, the chart-topping musician declared that she has â€œmore to exploreâ€ in the world.

title: Florence and the Machine Cover â€œWhite Cliffs of Doverâ€ for Jack Antonoffâ€™s New Look Soundtrack: Listen
content:
Florence and the Machine have released a cover of composer Walter Kent and lyricist Nat Burtonâ€™s â€œ(Thereâ€™ll Be Bluebirds Over) The White Cliffs of Dover.â€ Florence Welch recorded the song with producer Jack Antonoff for his soundtrack to the new Apple TV+ show The New Look. Listen to the cover below.
The New Look is a historical drama starring Ben Mendelsohn as Christian Dior and Juliette Binoche as Coco Chanel. The series focus on how the designers of their era revolutionized fashion during the Nazi occupation of Paris. The Antonoff-helmed soundtrack features period-appropriate cover songs performed by Lana Del Rey, the 1975, Nick Cave, Perfume Genius, Bleachers, Beabadoobee, Bartees Strange, and more. See the New Look tracklist below.
The New Lookâ€™s soundtrack is being released via Antonoffâ€™s new Dirty Hit imprint, Shadow of the City. Antonoff and his band, Bleachers, will release a new album via Dirty Hit on March 8.
