title: Drop Nineteens Announce Delaware Reissue, Share New Cover of Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€œWhite Dressâ€: Listen
content:
Drop Nineteens are reissuing their classic debut, Delaware, on June 21 via Wharf Cat. The album was remastered by Carl Saff, and the new vinyl edition features a new cover photo. The original Delaware artwork featured a photo of a girl with a gun in her left hand. Now, the girl is holding a small bouquet of flowers. A portion of proceeds from the reissue will go to Artists for Action to Prevent Gun Violence.
â€œWe decided to change the cover image, not so much to self-cancel, but because we simply will not put the image of a young person with a gun in their hand out in the world in todayâ€™s climate,â€ the shoegaze band explained in a press statement. â€œTo be fair, the concept was probably overstated even in 1992. We love the new cover design, and we are proud to be donating a portion of the proceeds from the sale of this Delaware reissue to the charity Artist for Action to Prevent Gun Violence.â€
Along with the reissue, Drop Nineteens have shared two new songs: â€œNestâ€ and a cover of Lana Del Reyâ€™s â€œWhite Dress.â€ Listen to the tracks below.
â€œâ€˜Nestâ€™ was originally intended to either open or close our album Hard Light,â€ Drop Nineteensâ€™ lead singer and songwriter, Greg Ackell, said. â€œWhen we realized we had a better opener and closer, we were unable to find the right place for it on the album. Itâ€™s an apt closer as B-side to â€˜White Dress,â€™ because itâ€™s the the last song Drop Nineteens will be releasing for a while, or perhaps ever, because you know, you never knowâ€¦. The ruminative lyrics make it well suited for this position.â€
Regarding â€œWhite Dress,â€ Ackell added:

title: Lana Del Rey Shows Love to Camila Cabello's New Song
content:
Lana Del Rey appears to be a fan of Camila Cabelloâ€˜s new music.
On Saturday (March 23), the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ songstress took to Instagram to show some love to Cabelloâ€™s recently teased song.
â€œi luv it,â€ Del Rey captioned two black-and-white photos of the â€œSenoritaâ€ singer.
In one snapshot, the newly blonde artist is seen with a lollipop in her mouth and the â€œParental Advisoryâ€ warning on the bottom right. The other image finds Cabello donning an off-the-shoulder white top while flipping off the camera and flashing a subtle smirk.
The former Fifth Harmony member took to the comments section of Del Reyâ€™s post, leaving a series of crown emojis. She also shared the post in her Instagram Story on Saturday.
In early March, Cabello shared a 30-second teaser of what appears to be her upcoming untitled single, accompanied by the caption â€œcoming soon(er than you think).â€ In the brief clip, sheâ€™s riding in the passenger seat of a car, her blonde tresses whipped by the wind, as she sings an exuberant, summery pop ditty.
Trending on Billboard
â€œIâ€™m seeing stars/ Oh my God/ I love it, I love it, I love it, I love it, I love it, I love it,â€ Cabello joyfully exhales in her breathy voice, adding, â€œI love it, I love it, I love it, I love it, I love it, I love it,â€ while making a hand heart in the song that features a sample of Gucci Maneâ€™s 2009 single â€œLemonade.â€
Cabelloâ€™s last album was 2022â€™s Familia, which featured her No. 21-charting Billboard Hot 100 hit â€œBam Bam.â€
During an early March episode on the Call Her Daddy podcast, the musician said the making of her upcoming album has been â€œsuch a journey.â€
â€œIt started off with me really having that intention of going back to how it started with me,â€ she told host Alex Cooper. â€œSitting with myself, and really getting back to that first passion of songwriting.â€
Del Rey, meanwhile, announced in February that her next album, Lasso, will arrive in September. The announcement arrived while she paid tribute to Jack Antonoff at the Billboard and NMPA Songwriter Awards in Los Angeles on Jan. 31.
â€If you canâ€™t already tell by our award winners and our performers, the music business is going country. Weâ€™re going country. Itâ€™s happening,â€ she told the crowd. â€œThatâ€™s why Jack has followed me to Muscle Shoals, Nashville, Mississippi, over the last four years.â€
Del Reyâ€™s forthcoming release is the follow-up to 2023â€™s Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, which peaked at No. 3 on the Billboard 200 chart.
See Del Reyâ€™s post about Cabelloâ€™s new music on Instagram here.

title: Everything Camila Cabello Says Her Album Is Giving
content:
Photo: Karwai Tang/WireImage
Itâ€™s giving Cher Charli. Itâ€™s giving Lana Del Rey. Itâ€™s giving Flo Milli x Rilke? Wait â€¦ Camila Cabello is in her bleached-blonde, lo-fi, post-SOPHIE era, and it comes with a whole new POV with some surprising references. The pop star is going edgy. The album began with â€œthe intention of going back to how it started for me, which is sitting with myself,â€ she tells Call Her Daddy, â€œnerding out over references and artists and poetry.â€ People (namely Charli XCX) have already noticed that one of those artists is Charli XCX, but thatâ€™s just the tip of the iceberg here. Below, ahead of the release of her new single â€œI Luv It,â€ the eclectic, eccentric, and occasionally confusing moodboard Camila Cabello and her collaborators say inspired CC4. Ahem.
- A â€œlove letter to Miamiâ€ as a â€œmelting pot of music and culture,â€ where you hear â€œAfrobeat, and reggaeton, and hip-hop and popâ€
- Her old music not being â€œweird enoughâ€
- A â€œhyperfemmeâ€ â€œpersona that I was tapping intoâ€
- â€œLip gloss and nails and whateverâ€
- Lana Del Rey
- Working with Stromae on â€œMon Amourâ€
- Gucci Maneâ€™s â€œLemonadeâ€
- Flo Milli
- My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy
- Combining rap with â€œbeautiful music and pretty chords and lush guitarâ€
- Rainer Maria Rilkeâ€™s Letters to a Young Poet
- Grunge
- Y2K
- Dover Street Market and its â€œweird out-of-the-States fashion brands.â€

title: Country-Boom: 5 Beispiele, wie Pop den Country erobert
content:
Â«Crazy In LoveÂ» sang BeyoncÃ© schon vor 20 Jahren. Und verknallt scheint sie auch heute wieder zu sein: in die Country Musik. Mit ihrer Liebe ist sie aber nicht alleine. Immer mehr genrefremde Popstars nehmen sich dem Country an.
Country im Wandel
BeyoncÃ© gilt als KÃ¶nigin des RnBs. Doch zurzeit schreibt sie Geschichte in einem anderen Genre. Aus der Queen wurde quasi ein Cowgirl. Ihre Single Â«Texas Hold 'EmÂ» fÃ¼hrt in der dritten Woche in Folge die amerikanischen Countrycharts an.
Die Streamingzahlen sind in keinem anderen Genre so explodiert.
Sie ist die erste schwarze SÃ¤ngerin, die Platz 1 in diesen Charts erreichte.
Der Fakt, dass ihr das als erste schwarze SÃ¤ngerin gelang, war eine positive Ãœberraschung fÃ¼r Beobachter der nach wie vor weiss geprÃ¤gten Country-Szene.
Das ein Countrysong in der breiten BevÃ¶lkerung so gut ankommt Ã¼berrascht aber weniger.
Â«The music business is going countryÂ»
Diverse Popstars nehmen sich zurzeit diesem Stil an. Ed Sheeran hat vergangenen Herbst seinen Song Â«Life Goes OnÂ» als Duett mit Country-Star Luke Combs verÃ¶ffentlicht.
Ein weiteres Beispiel ist Rapper Post Malone. Der US-Amerikaner hat seine Wurzeln im Hip-Hop. Vergangenes Jahr stand er mit verschiedenen Country-Stars auf der BÃ¼hne bei den Â«Country Music Association AwardsÂ» und kÃ¼ndigte ein Country-Album an.
Und auch die New Yorker SÃ¤ngerin Lana Del Rey bewegt sich aktuell auf Country-Pfaden. Im Herbst erscheint ihr Album Â«LassoÂ». Die erste Single ist ein Cover des John Denver Klassikers Â«Take Me Home, Country RoadsÂ».
In einem Interview vor den Grammy-Awards zeigte sie sich Ã¼berzeugt: Â«The music business is going countryÂ». Das MusikgeschÃ¤ft bewege sich aktuell in Richtung Country.
FÃ¼r Country Special Redaktorin Christa Helbling ist es nicht Ã¼berraschend, dass viele Popmusikerinnen und -Musiker mit dem Genre liebÃ¤ugeln: Â«Country ist gerade sehr im TrendÂ». Mit angestossen habe diesen sicherlich auch Rapper Lil Nas X.
Bereits vor fÃ¼nf Jahren landete er im Duett mit der Country-Legende Billy Ray Cyrus den grossen Hit Â«Old Town Road.Â» Gleichzeitig habe der afroamerikanische Musiker damit eine grosse Debatte Ã¼ber die fehlende DiversitÃ¤t in der Country-Szene ausgelÃ¶st, erinnert sich Helbling.
Aber warum Country Musik?
Â«Die Streamingzahlen sind im letzten Jahr in den USA in keinem anderen Genre so explodiert, wie bei CountryÂ», weiss Helbling. AushÃ¤ngeschilder wie Luke Combs, Zach Bryan oder Morgan Wallen gehÃ¶ren in den Staaten zu den erfolgreichsten Musikern Ã¼berhaupt.
Diese Stars aus der Branche wiederum setzten ihrerseits auch genrefremde Elemente ein. Morgan Wallen zum Beispiel integriere Hip-Hop in seinen Countrysongs.
Durch das Mixen der Genres kÃ¶nnten Musikschaffende Â«beider SeitenÂ» ein grÃ¶sseres und auch jÃ¼ngeres Publikum erreichen. Dies ist eine ErklÃ¤rung fÃ¼r den aktuellen Boom. Eine zweite sei eher politisch, so Helbling: Â«Alles wirkt vor den PrÃ¤sidentschaftswahlen unsicher und chaotisch. Country hingegen ist etwas, das in den USA tief verwurzelt ist. Es ist ein Anker fÃ¼r die BevÃ¶lkerung, und wie es aussieht, nicht nur fÃ¼r die konservativen Republikaner, sondern auch fÃ¼r demokratische Kreise. Im besten Fall schaffen es also Songs wie â€¹Texas Hold 'Emâ€º, GrÃ¤ben zu Ã¼berwinden.Â»

title: Bleachers: Bleachers review - uninspiring shades of Springsteen with Jack Antonoff and co
content:
You may have been unaware of it, but you will almost certainly have heard Bleachersâ€™ music already. Theyâ€™ve secretly been the backing band on recent albums by Taylor Swift, Lana Del Rey and St Vincent, in large part because frontman Jack Antonoffâ€™s day job is being the most in-demand producer in the world, responsible for many of the defining pop records of this decade â€“ itâ€™s not for nothing that he recently won the producer of the year Grammy for the third time in a row.
His fourth album with Bleachers begins in the much the same vein as its three predecessors, with strong echoes of fellow New Jerseyite Bruce Springsteen, most notably on Modern Girl, and to a lesser extent the National on motorik opener I Am Right on Time. Elsewhere, Del Rey guests on the atmospheric but unspectacular Alma Mater. Then, midway through, the so-so Boss-isms give way to so-so ballads. As youâ€™d expect, given Antonoffâ€™s production chops, these are all tastefully realised, but thereâ€™s precious little excitement to be found in the likes of the Auto-Tuned ambient of The Waiter or the Needles and Pins-lite of Woke Up Today. While Bleachers is far from being a bad album, itâ€™s even further from being an exciting one.

title: Giada Biaggi: "Mi sento vittima di blonde-shaming e sÃ¬, lo ammetto, la mia vita non Ã¨ stata piÃ¹ la stessa dopo quel videoclip di Lana Del Rey..."
content:
Comunismo a Times Square apre con una delle scene di seduzione piÃ¹ originali che io abbia letto negli ultimi anni. Agata, attrice e Walther, drammaturgo egoico e carismatico, si incontrano per caso nella sala di unâ€™universitÃ  e si ritrovano a parlare dei dettagli del suicidio della drammaturga Sarah Kane. Vivisezionano lâ€™accaduto, valutano la plausibilitÃ  dello strumento usato (i lacci delle scarpe) e allo stesso tempo si sfiorano, si annusano, entrano in unâ€™intimitÃ  fisica. â€œSai morire?â€ le chiede poi Walther. Scopriamo dopo poco che si riferisce alla morte sul palco, ma lâ€™effetto Ã¨ comunque forte.
Questo ballo attorno alla morte li attrae e li respinge anche eroticamente. I limiti del loro rapporto vengono dichiarati da subito. â€œSono sposato da due anni,â€ ammette Walther, una frase che ad Agata fa pensare a Ironic, di Alanis Morissette: â€œItâ€™s meeting the man of my dreams, and then meeting his beautiful wife / Isnâ€™t it ironic donâ€™t you think?â€. Nel nuovo romanzo di Giada Biaggi (edito da Feltrinelli) Agata poi abbandona il suo sogno e si ritrova a fare la hostess di Emirates. In aereo incontra John, affascinante regista e pubblicitario newyorkese, ma rimane, struggentemente nostalgica per il suo primo amore â€“ sia quello creativo che quello sentimentale. Ogni membro di questo triangolo possiede una cosa che gli altri non hanno, abbagliati da miraggi diversi. Cavalcano illusioni e chimere in maniera sfrontata e disordinata. Procedono a tentoni. Insieme formano un trio tragicomico che cerca di interrogarsi su quello che significa essere sognatori ed artisti durante lâ€™era delle grandi recessioni, del crollo dellâ€™occidente e lâ€™incombente crisi climatica. Un romanzo postmoderno, postcapitalista, forse anche post apocalittico ma non per questo disilluso. Il romanticismo câ€™Ã¨, solo che respira per vie traverse: fantasticare sul suicidio di una famosa drammaturga inglese, Ã¨ una di queste.
Sei una fuoriclasse dei sentimenti malripostiâ€¦
Â«La vita vera Ã¨ spesso noiosa; soprattutto se sei una scrittrice, penso che puoi capirmi. La cosa che amo della letteratura Ã¨ far succedere le cose nel modo esatto in cui vorresti accadessero sia nel bene che nel male. Ogni personaggio di questo libro Ã¨ in un dialogo non scritto con il collasso dellâ€™Occidente. Sono molto anarchica e rifuggo anche con la fantasia ogni retorica dellâ€™innamoramento stereotipato; e cosÃ¬ nel mio libro Agata e Walther iniziano ad appartenersi tutta la vita mentre lui le insegna a fingere la morte scenica. La domanda: â€œSai morire?â€ che lui le fa qualche istante dopo che si sono conosciuti Ã¨ la domanda che ho sempre sognato mi venisse rivolta da un mio potenziale partnerÂ».
I personaggi del tuo libro sembrano vivere al di fuori dei loro corpi. Quando pensa troppo, Agata ha bisogno di ricordarsi di avere il sangue che le circola dentro. In una scena di sesso sbagliato percepisce le sue tette come â€œdue ammassi lipidici disincarnati dal corpo.â€
Â«Sono un poâ€™ nauseata alla Sartre dalla retorica dei corpi da memoir che sta impazzando in questi anni, dove il corpo Ã¨ vissuto come condanna o chiave di volta di ogni emancipazione. Mi piace lâ€™approccio letterario che hanno autori come Pennac o Vian. Vian in particolare lo tratta come un pittore surrealista dipinge la realtÃ . Penso a La schiuma dei giorni in cui il tumore ai polmoni assume la forma di una ninfea. Sono molto visiva e penso che sia piÃ¹ umano e poetico approciare il corpo con un materialismo-surrealista piuttosto che con il vittimismo astratto che va per la maggioreÂ».
Seguo il tuo stand-up e adoro la tua sentenza caustica contro la body positivity e il tuo amore per Kate Moss e la sua mitica frase, ripresa anche nel libro: â€œNothing tastes as good as feeling skinny doesâ€.
Â«Mi piace avere una taglia 40; sono una bimba del heroin-chic e câ€™Ã¨ una parte di me che vorrÃ  sempre essere Kate Moss! Da comica italiana mi trovo in uno scenario ahimÃ¨ anni luce distante dal Saturday Night Live o dalla Bbc in cui ci piace che a fare ridere siano donne classicamente non piacenti; infatti ironizzo sul fatto di subire blonde-shaming!Â».
Si scopa pensando ad altro, si viene mentendo: la vita interiore dei personaggi Ã¨ vivissima in questo romanzo, forse piÃ¹ di quella esterna. Che ruolo ha il mondo invisibile nella tua vita e nella tua scrittura?
Â«SÃ¬, questo Ã¨ stato programmatico nella stesura del libro. Volevo scrivere un romanzo molto â€œsally-rooneyanoâ€ a tratti; fortemente introspettivo e senza amori iper-idilliaci, ma â€œsinghiozzi di relazioniâ€. Forse inconsciamente tutti abbiamo introiettato un rapporto cattolico di condanna nei confronti della menzogna. Se ci pensiamo solo gli esseri umani sanno mentire, Ã¨ una delle grandi differenze tra noi e gli animaliÂ».
I tuoi personaggi vivono le emozioni piÃ¹ grandi in movimento: guardando i palazzi brutti davanti alla spiaggia di Coney Island, sui voli degli Emirates, ascoltando messaggi che arrivano dallâ€™altra parte degli oceani. La mobilitÃ  continua ti agita o ti fa sentire a casa?
Â«La mobilitÃ  Ã¨ molto contemporanea, oggi viaggiare costa di meno; con lâ€™avvento di Internet nessuno Ã¨ mai in un solo posto anche quando non si sta spostando. Ho in programma di trasferirmi a breve; vorrei vivere a Parigi per qualche anno pur continuando a lavorare in Italia. Nel nostro Paese mi terrorizza il clima politico, culturale e questa forte aggressivitÃ  degli uomini anche quando non sfocia in violenza fisica; direi che la mobilitÃ  Ã¨ un rescue kit per la mia sopravvivenza emotivaÂ».
Amo il passato recente in cui si muovono i protagonisti di questo libro. Ci sono i Blackberry, câ€™Ã¨ Tumblr, Bad Romance, il suicidio di Alexander McQueen, gli shorts di spugna American Apparel. Incredibile sentirsi nostalgici per unâ€™era cosÃ¬ recente eppure cosÃ¬ lontana?
Â«Secondo me aveva una grande valenza parlare di quegli anni in questo tragico momento storico perchÃ© sono stati gli ultimi nei quali lâ€™Occidente si Ã¨ immaginato il futuro; nei quali Ã¨ come se avesse avuto un approccio letterario su se stesso. Il libro infatti abbraccia il periodo che va dallâ€™ascesa di Obama e si chiude con Occupy Wall Street. Lato costume sono stati anni molto punk in cui la morte e il sesso sono entrati nella cultura di massa; i nostri idoli morivano sotto i nostri occhi, American Apparel anticipava lâ€™estetica adolescenziale pseudo pornografica che abbiamo poi ritrovato nei balletti di TikTokÂ».
La cantate Lana Del Rey Ã¨ davvero responsabile della relazione tra morte e costume?
Â«Con lei e McQueen la morte Ã¨ rientrata nel pop dopo la new wave e la cultura punk. Questa donna di ventâ€™anni piena di botox che cantava di morte vestita come una sacerdotessa in un castello francese mi ha cambiato; va bene lo ammetto la mia vita non Ã¨ stata piÃ¹ la stessa dopo il videoclip di Born to Die!Â».
La cosa piÃ¹ bella che Agata dice a Walther Ã¨ che lâ€™interpretazione del femminismo degli uomini in ambito culturale non porterÃ  mai da nessuna parte. â€œÃˆ un genocidio di estrogeniâ€. Lâ€™uomo maschilista Ã¨ in crisi quanto quello femminista? Entrambi, perÃ², non riconoscono i finti orgasmi...
Â«Quello femminista Ã¨ peggio perchÃ© Ã¨ ipocrita. Nel mio primo romanzo al proposito avevo coniato lâ€™espressione â€œpatriarcato negazionistaâ€. Pensiamo al mio mondo: la maggioranza dei comici italiani che magari condivide un post di sensibilizzazione quando accade qualche femminicidio non Ã¨ mai andato a sentire uno spettacolo di stand-up comedian donna. Supportano pubblicamente una donna solo quando Ã¨ famosissimaÂ».
Una playlist con le canzoni top five da dedicare a questo libro?
Â«Hey There Delilah, Father and Son, NYC, Born to Die, Rocket ManÂ».
In questo romanzo câ€™Ã¨ musica, storia, filosofia, politica, la morte psicogenetica... Ma anche qualche cristallo di quarzo di Sedona. I tarocchi li tieni anche tu sotto al cuscino?
Â«(Ride) Allora, io sono una persona super razionale, in questo non sono molto Lana Del Rey o Natalia Ginzburg, entrambe matte per i tarocchi. Ho comprato quelli di Jodorowsky, ma solo perchÃ© mi piace esporli in casa come cimelio hipster! Scherzi a parte, penso che tutto il cosmo si regga in termini di algoritmi e sulla terra domini il materialismo storico. Le cose piÃ¹ esoteriche nella mia vita credo siano: la psicoanalisi lacaniana, i fiori di Bach che do al mio cane, le mie conversazioni con Sartre al cimitero di Parigi e le candele profumate dellâ€™Ikea che accendo sempre prima di mettermi a scrivere!Â».

title: Taylor Swift producer Jack Antonoff: â€˜I thought Shane MacGowan would last forever... Heâ€™s the ultimate artistâ€™
content:
A few months ago, the superstar producer Jack Antonoff opened his laptop and clicked on a live-stream from a church in the middle of Ireland. â€œI sat home alone on my computer, watching Shane MacGowanâ€™s funeral,â€ says Antonoff, the mild-mannered co-writer of such juggernauts as Taylor Swiftâ€™s Cruel Summer, Lordeâ€™s Solar Power and Lana Del Reyâ€™s Grammy-bagging A&W.
He talks passionately about MacGowan and Nick Cave, who honoured his late friend by singing Rainy Night in Soho from the altar at Mary of the Rosary Church in Nenagh. â€œNick Cave is one of my favourite artists of all time, and then Shaneâ€™s music is some of my favourite of all time. You put that together: that was one of the important musical moments in my lifetime â€“ and I was just f**king watching that on my laptop.â€
Antonoff is not an obvious Shane MacGowan disciple. MacGowanâ€™s music, if often eloquent and fuelled by a doomed romanticism, could be anarchic and messy, too. Antonoffâ€™s work with his band Bleachers and as a producer of Swift, Lorde, Del Rey, St Vincent and others is measured and pristine â€“ as you can hear on Bleachersâ€™ self-titled new LP. Nonetheless, MacGowan really did mean something to Antonoff, whose voice cracks as he discusses the Pogues singer and his death, last November, at the age of 65.
â€œI didnâ€™t think he would ever die. When Shane MacGowan was 25 he looked unwell. I thought he would last forever. I figured he had something inside of him that would keep him alive.â€
READ MORE
After the funeral, Antonoff went down a YouTube rabbit hole and discovered a 1995 joint interview with MacGowan and SinÃ©ad Oâ€™Connor on Pat Kennyâ€™s Kenny Live chat show. â€œShane MacGowan reminded me so much about what I love about music. His literal physical formâ€¦ heâ€™s so rough and intense-looking. And his voice is so rough and intense. But his melodies are so tender and beautiful. And then, when you read the lyrics, theyâ€™re so vulnerable. Heâ€™s the ultimate artist. Not even in song but just by living his life, he represents both sides of the human experience. I never met him. But I used to stare at pictures of him forever.â€
MacGowanâ€™s life in music was a story of early success followed by a leisurely amble into the twilight. Antonoffâ€™s trajectory is the opposite: at 39, he is only getting started. This much is clear from that new Bleachers record. Itâ€™s his best solo work to date, brimming with the same empathy, vulnerability and tunefulness that have marked his work with Swift and Del Rey.
One way of understanding Bleachers is to see the songs as an extension of Antonoffâ€™s personality: they are understated and playful, but confident and sometimes a little goofy and brash, too. Itâ€™s also about where he comes from. Antonoff grew up in New Milford, New Jersey, and his new album is steeped in the music of his home state. There are references to the introverted indie pop of the local touchstones The Feelies and Yo La Tengo, but thereâ€™s some strut and brio as well: his recent single Modern Girl is outfitted with saxophones that recall another pre-eminent New Jersey native, his friend and confidant Bruce Springsteen.
Ever since I was first started writing and touring, I had a â€˜This is the last day on earthâ€™ feeling about every song. Itâ€™s the only way I know how to do it â€” Jack Antonoff, music producer
Bleachersâ€™ early records were coloured with sadness and trauma, of which Antonoff has experienced plenty. In 2001, when he was 18, his younger sister, Sarah, died of brain cancer. A cousin was later killed fighting in Iraq. For years he experienced depression and anxiety â€“ emotions he filtered through Bleachers.
Jack Antonoff pictured at his home studio in New York in 2017. Photograph: Tawni Bannister/The New York Times
The new LP is different: heâ€™s in a better place following his marriage to the actor Margaret Qualley (Andie MacDowellâ€™s daughter, who plays one of Charles Mansonâ€™s disciples in the Quentin Tarantino film Once Upon a Time in Hollywood). There is still plenty of intensity, though â€“ despite suggestions to the contrary in some early coverage of the album, this is not Antonoffâ€™s feelgood record.
Jack Antonoff performing with Taylor Swift during Swift's Eras Tour at MetLife Stadium in May 2023 in East Rutherford, New Jersey. Photograph: Kevin Mazur/TAS23/Getty
â€œI was joking with a friend about how jealous I feel â€“ how nice it would be to sit at a piano, write some songs, go do a show. But ever since I was first started writing and touring, I had a â€˜This is the last day on earthâ€™ feeling about every song. Itâ€™s the only way I know how to do it. It can be exhausting.â€
[ Music Jack Antonoff: Fun guy on a serious pop mission ]
The biggest surprise is that Antonoff has time for Bleachers in the first place. In the past three years he has written Anti-Hero with Swift, worked on her Taylorâ€™s Version revisiting of 1989, written A&W with Del Rey and collaborated with Lorde, Clairo and The 1975. Next month heâ€™s back over the top with Swift again on her album The Tortured Poets Department. There is also another Del Rey LP, a country record called Lasso.
Lana Del Rey, Taylor Swift and Jack Antonoff at the 66th Grammy Awards last month in Los Angeles, California. Photograph: Johnny Nunez/Getty
Why do so many stars clamour to work with Antonoff? Talent is obviously part of the answer. He also makes for easy-going company, and so stands in refreshing contrast to the stereotype of the producer as a control freak or passive-aggressive knob-twiddler.
â€œHeâ€™s an absolute joy,â€ Swift said of Antonoff in 2017. Their friendship is one of the defining relationships of his career: Swift was a guest at his marriage to Qualley last year, on Long Beach Island, in New Jersey; the singerâ€™s appearance attracted a swarm of Swifties and forced police to temporarily close a street.
Jack Antonoff with his wife Margaret Qualley at AMC Lincoln Square 13 in New York City last month. Photograph: Nina Westervelt/Variety/Getty
Theirs is a rare musical chemistry. In the 2020 Swift documentary Miss Americana, we see them essentially conjure the song Getaway Car, from the LP Reputation, out of thin air. One moment itâ€™s just a fragment of an idea; the next theyâ€™re finishing each otherâ€™s sentences and coming up with the chorus. Their partnership also yielded Cruel Summer (which they wrote with St Vincentâ€™s Annie Clark) â€“ a long-time Swiftie favourite that became a surprise hit in 2023, four years after its release.
â€œItâ€™s really cool,â€ says Antonoff of Cruel Summerâ€™s surprise comeback. â€œThe big takeaway is that if you follow your heart and soul with what you love to make, then a lot of strange and surprising things happen. Whether itâ€™s Cruel Summer or A&W [winning song of the year at the Grammys] or Bleachersâ€™ touring becoming so crazyâ€¦ I feel â€“ Okay, got it. Message received â€“ Just do you.â€
[ Lana Del Rey: Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd â€“ Long, maudlin and one of her best albums yet ]
Given his output, you might imagine Antonoff to be a workaholic or possessing superhuman powers of organisation. The secret of his success is more straightforward, he explains. â€œI try to spend my days doing whatever I feel. If Iâ€™m working with someone for too many days in a row I can get a little anxious, because I like to be free with my time,â€ he says.
â€œMostly Iâ€™m working on whatever I feel. You kind of wait to be called. I felt called to make this Bleachers album. And then, other moments, I feel compelled to do other things. It might sound like pandering or bullshit because of what I do, but I donâ€™t try to structure my day too much, other than being in the studio. And what I do kind of moves from there.â€
Thereâ€™s a huge discourse about, How do you do this? How do you do all this? And I donâ€™t know â€” Jack Antonoff
With great success comes the inevitable backlash. Or, as a noted philosopher once put it, â€œHaters gonna hate, hate, hate, hate, hateâ€. Antonoff has experienced his share of snark â€“ shade on social media, and also the direct salvo of an essay in New York magazine the Drift â€“ â€œthe intellectual arm of the leftist resurgenceâ€ â€“ which labelled him pop musicâ€™s blandest prophet. â€œThere is something about Antonoffâ€™s production that is at once instantaneously identifiable and frustratingly anonymous,â€ the magazine claimed. â€œVapour does not photograph especially well.â€
Antonoff is nothing if not self-aware. He understands how things work â€“ that cycle from fame to resentment.
â€œWhen people have a lot of opinions, sometimes they forget that thereâ€™s a person there who actually knows the truth about it all. However people feel about the work is how people feel about the work â€“ itâ€™s designed for people to feel very different things. But the amount of discourse about how these records are being made... I find that people have such a hard time imagining that Iâ€™m really doing what Iâ€™m doing. That part is a little funny to me, because itâ€™s likeâ€¦ Iâ€™m not very shy about what happens. I go into a room every day and sometimes Iâ€™m alone and sometime Iâ€™m with people. And thereâ€™s the music that comes out of it.â€
A hint of frustration creeps into his voice.
[ Jack Antonoff: â€˜Irish music has had a huge influence on me â€“ itâ€™s steeped in celebration and sadnessâ€™ ]
â€œThe need to try to understand how I do that is funny to me. Because I donâ€™t even understand how I do it. Sometimes I feel positive or negative. Thereâ€™s a huge discourse about, How do you do this? How do you do all this? And I donâ€™t know. I go into the studio or I go into a room and I write songs or produce songs and here they are. And then some people are, like, â€˜Yeah I understand that â€“ but how?â€™ And I donâ€™t know. Thatâ€™s also the culture we live in. We live in this masterclass culture where everyone can describe everything they do. Maybe someone else can â€“ songwriting and producing is not a very describable craft. Itâ€™s one of catching magic.â€
Bleachers are not a million-selling act yet. But Antonoff has been involved in some of the biggest records of the past decade. What does he think of the argument that the music business has never been so stratified, with the top 1 per cent earning 90 per cent of streaming revenue and making millions from touring, while other musicians struggle?
Itâ€™s a very strange industry that has historically forced you to go to the edge of oneâ€™s capacity to get recognised â€” Jack Antonoff
Itâ€™s a tricky one, he says. He wonders whether the industry has changed much from when he started, 20 years ago, with his band Steel Train (followed by the group Fun, for whom he co-wrote the hit We Are Young).
â€œItâ€™s tough, because Iâ€™ve had experiences on both sides. So on one hand I understand that [critique]. On the other hand Iâ€™ve lived in so many sides of the music industry that sometimes, as time goes on, I donâ€™t see things changing as much as it gets written about. Sometimes Iâ€™m sort of, like, â€˜Oh, itâ€™s same bullsh*t as always.â€™ The music business is always so f**king hard to break into. You have got to grind it out until you find your window. Because a lot of the things that people discuss about the current music business sound very similar to the music business I grew up in, I think a lot about it. I think about my circle. How I came up. My friends and how theyâ€™re coming up. Itâ€™s a very strange industry that has historically forced you to go to the edge of oneâ€™s capacity to get recognised.â€
The release of Bleachersâ€™s new album coincides with a significant anniversary for Antonoff. Itâ€™s 10 years since he started Bleachers â€“ and 10 years since the release of 1989, his first collaboration with Swift. Antonoff co-wrote Out of the Woods and has production credits on two tracks on the LP proper. It was the start of a blockbuster relationship, the first step on Antonoffâ€™s ascent to the very summit of the music industry,
â€œAll that was happening at the same time,â€ he says. â€œIt was a special time in my life â€“ when I was starting Bleachers, working on 1989 â€“ the beginning of a lot of important things. I could feel it with the music. And then, as it started to come out, I could feel people were hearing what I was hearing.â€
Bleachers, by Bleachers, is released by Dirty Hit

title: Nach Hits fÃ¼r Taylor und Lana: Neues Album von Jack Antonoff
content:
Nach Hits fÃ¼r Taylor und Lana: Neues Album von Jack Antonoff
Drucken Teilen
Frontmann Jack Antonoff (2.v.r.) mit seiner Band Bleachers. Â© Alex Lockett/Dirty Hit/dpa
Er gilt als Songwriter der ganz GroÃŸen: Jack Antonoff schreibt unter anderem fÃ¼r Lana Del Rey, Taylor Swift und Lorde. Im neuen Album seiner eigenen Band Bleachers lÃ¤sst er nun tief blicken.
New York/Berlin - Die Stimme von Jack Antonoff strahlt trotz eines Alltags, der stressig sein muss, Gelassenheit aus. â€Ich bin Optimist. Aus welchem verdammten Grund auch immerâ€œ, witzelt der 39-JÃ¤hrige am Telefon. Er steht kurz vor der VerÃ¶ffentlichung der neuen Platte â€Bleachersâ€œ - seiner gleichnamigen Band.
Es ist das vierte Album der Indie-Pop-Kombi, aber fÃ¼r Antonoff eines von sehr, sehr vielen Platten, denn der 39-JÃ¤hrige ist schon seit Jahren fÃ¼r diverse PopgrÃ¶ÃŸen tÃ¤tig: Taylor Swift, Lana Del Rey, Florence and the Machine, Clairo, Lorde und einige mehr vertrauen auf sein KÃ¶nnen als Co-Songwriter und Produzent. Das brachte ihm bereits zehn Grammys ein, kÃ¼rzlich erst den als Produzent des Jahres.
Geld ersetzt keinen kÃ¼nstlerischen Prozess
Bei all dem Erfolg bleibt der Musiker gelassen. â€Ich bin sehr dankbar, aber ich verbringe nicht viel Zeit damit, darÃ¼ber nachzudenken. Ich denke eher Ã¼ber das nach, was ich macheâ€œ, sagt Antonoff. Und das sei in erster Linie Musik. Nicht nur fÃ¼r die ganz GroÃŸen, auch fÃ¼r seine eigene Band, die - zumindest im kommerziellen Vergleich - noch etwas hinter seinen anderen Erfolgen hinkt.
â€Diese Erfolgsmarker sind komplett unterschiedlich zu dem kÃ¼nstlerischen Erfolg, jeden Tag daran zu arbeitenâ€œ, sinniert er. â€Kein Geld kann dir die Arbeit im Studio abnehmen. Entweder du steigst da in eine wichtige Sache ein, oder du lÃ¤sst es.â€œ
Mit Songs wie â€Modern Girlâ€œ oder â€Tiny Movesâ€œ auf dem neuen Album gelingen immer wieder tanzbare und mitreiÃŸende Momente. Meist sind es Lieder, die Antonoff Ã¼ber seine kÃ¼rzlich geheiratete Ehefrau geschrieben hat, die Schauspielern Margaret Qualley. Sie spielt auch in den Musikvideos mit. Ihren Einfluss auf die Platte beschreibt er als â€endlosâ€œ und freut sich, die Songs als Momentaufnahme auch in ein paar Jahren noch mal selbst zu hÃ¶ren. â€Ich schreie auf dem Album eigentlich nur heraus, wie es sich gerade anfÃ¼hlt, ich zu sein.â€œ
Auch der Track â€Isimoâ€œ handelt von Qualley. Songs wie dieser geben dem Album die nÃ¶tige Tiefe, die Ã¼ber eine romantisierte Melancholie hinausgeht. â€Das ist mein Lieblingstext von einem lyrischen Blickwinkel ausâ€œ, sagt Antonoff. Es geht um emotionalen Ballast und wie beide Partner ihn zusammen tragen kÃ¶nnen. Doch dabei geht es nicht um Beziehungsprobleme, sondern um eigene PÃ¤ckchen. Wie etwa den Verlust seiner jÃ¼ngeren Schwester Sarah, die an einem Gehirntumor starb, als er 18 Jahre alt war.
Radikale Akzeptanz als Erfolgsgeheimnis
Deswegen geht es in Songs wie â€Woke Up Todayâ€œ - wie auch schon auf frÃ¼heren Bleachers-Alben - um den Schmerz dieses Verlustes, den Antonoff seither spÃ¼rt. Aber auch die aufgeladene weltpolitische Situation und den einhergehenden Weltschmerz thematisiert er parallel in â€Hey Joeâ€œ oder â€Self Respectâ€œ. â€Ich glaube, das Einzige, warum Menschen sich wirklich grauenvoll fÃ¼hlen, ist, wenn sie ihre GefÃ¼hle verweigern.â€œ Es gehe vor allem darum, zu akzeptieren, wie man sich fÃ¼hlt. Das sei auch das Geheimnis zu einem guten Song.
â€Der einzige Ratschlag, den ich habe, ist, dass man seine Vision unverfÃ¤lscht lassen sollte, denn das ist das Einzige, was man wirklich hatâ€œ, rÃ¤t er. Das Wichtigste als Songwriter und KÃ¼nstler sei, Dinge in die Welt zu entlassen, die man wirklich liebt und von denen man denkt, dass die Welt sie braucht.
Typisch fÃ¼r Antonoffs Songwriting ist die Bereitschaft zu Spielerischem, die eine Leichtigkeit verleiht. So entstand auch das Feature mit Lana Del Rey in â€Alma Materâ€œ, das dem Album nach dem ersten Viertel die nÃ¶tige Abwechslung und Kantigkeit gibt. Jack Antonoff ist der beste Beweis dafÃ¼r, dass es keine Tiktok-Optimierung mit hohlen Phrasen und verkÃ¼rzten Hooks braucht, um sich GehÃ¶r zu verschaffen.
Sein Leben zu leben und zu genieÃŸen, fÃ¼r seine Schwester, die es nicht mehr kann. Die emotionale Offenheit, die er durch seine Frau neu gelernt hat. Und auch die vielen Freunde und KÃ¼nstler, die seinen Alltag ausmachen und die am Album mitgearbeitet haben: Matty Healy von The 1975 spielt Klavier, St. Vincent, Florence Welch, Clairo und Lana Del Rey steuern Gesang bei. All das vereint Antonoff im aktuellen Album. â€Wenn man das GlÃ¼ck hat, seine Leute zu finden, macht man einfach mit. Vielleicht bin ich deshalb so optimistisch.â€œ dpa

title: Why Are Pop Stars Going Country?
content:
Bolstered by acts like Morgan Wallen, Zach Bryan and Luke Combs, country music in 2023 experienced its biggest growth spurt in more than 30 years â€” way back when Garth Brooks soared to superstardom. Already, this year seems on track to continue that explosion, as country stars and pop icons alike are capitalizing on the genreâ€™s recent boom.
In February, BeyoncÃ© became the first Black woman to top Billboardâ€™s Hot Country Songs chart with her galloping hit, â€œTexas Hold â€™Em,â€ from her upcoming Act II, expected to be a full-on country album, out March 29. Post Malone has teased a duet with Combs on social media and written with other genre stars including Wallen and HARDY for his upcoming country album. And Lana Del Rey â€” who declared that her fall album, Lasso, will be a country set â€” recently posted a snippet of a song that she worked on with noted Nashville songwriter-producer Luke Laird.
CMT senior vp of music strategy and talent Leslie Fram views the influx as a sign of â€œoverwhelming respect for the storytelling and the songwriting in Nashville,â€ but predicts that noncountry artists taking up slots at terrestrial country radio â€œis going to be a major topic of conversation â€¦ If [a core country artist] has spent 30 to 50 weeks trying to climb up a chart and, all of a sudden, theyâ€™re replaced by someone who is not in the genre, I do believe there will be concerns.â€
Trending on Billboard
However, Simon Tikhman, co-founder of The Core Entertainment, which manages Nickelback and country upstarts Bailey Zimmerman and Nate Smith, sees the possible radio displacement as a good sign overall. â€œWe were on a call with Nateâ€™s Sony team talking about adds at radio, and No. 1 was BeyoncÃ© and No. 2 was Nate,â€ he says, adding that The Core Entertainment co-founder Kevin â€œChiefâ€ Zaruk â€œand I were like, â€˜This is amazing that she sees whatâ€™s going on over here.â€™ Sheâ€™s as brilliant as a performer gets, and she wants to be part of this. It just goes to show how powerful the genre is right now.â€
As Alan Jackson famously sang in his 1994 hit, â€œGone Country,â€ for decades, any artist who released such music but who hadnâ€™t moved to Nashville or put in the time building a country audience and courting country radio was considered a carpetbagger. But now, many insiders see it as a sign that borders between genres have fallen and that countryâ€™s recent surge in popularity has made it extremely appealing to artists who have fallen in love with the music, too.
And unlike in the past, when artists might explore country only as their pop career dwindled, todayâ€™s infiltration and interest are coming from names at the peak of their pop prowess. â€œIt isnâ€™t like the heritage artists before that wanted to do a country record. These are artists at the top of their game,â€ Fram says. Olivia Rodrigo attended Megan Moroneyâ€™s Los Angeles show last year and posted photos backstage together. And in November, Post Malone made his debut performance at the Country Music Association Awards.
Plus, fandom aside, itâ€™s smart business. â€œThe pop labels are seeing the success of a Morgan Wallen,â€ Sony Nashville chairman/CEO Randy Goodman says of the country superstar, whose smash â€œLast Nightâ€ and album One Thing at a Time logged the most weeks of any song or album on the Billboard Hot 100 and Billboard 200 last year, respectively. He adds: â€œThe biggest female artist in the world is Taylor [Swift], who started in country. I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s lost on any of the labels.â€
Related A New Crop of Pop Stars Are Going Country in 2024
Range Media Partners co-founder Matt Graham, whose company manages Jack Harlow, Midland and Saweetie, believes the pop transplants could help expand countryâ€™s global audience. â€œItâ€™s good for making the genre international,â€ he says, noting that acts like Wallen and Combs have already helped country grow worldwide. â€œThis has the potential to blow that wide open.â€ He predicts streaming numbers for country artists, which were already up nearly 24% year over year in 2023 domestically, according to Luminate, will â€œdrasticallyâ€ increase this year and beyond.
And the genre-flipping isnâ€™t just flowing one way: Country artists are finding success in other formats, too. Combs had a massive crossover hit with his cover of Tracy Chapmanâ€™s â€œFast Car,â€ and Wallen topped Billboardâ€™s year-end Streaming Songs Artists chart, the first time a country act had achieved the feat. Meanwhile, Jelly Roll and HARDY â€” both of whom are considered primarily country artists â€” reached No. 1 on the Mainstream Rock and Hard Rock charts, respectively.
Like 21-year-old Rodrigo, younger music listeners donâ€™t â€œput music in a box,â€ Zaruk says, noting Zimmermanâ€™s November duet with the Jonas Brothers. â€œFor years, country fans didnâ€™t really listen to hip-hop and rap and rap fans were not listening to country,â€ he continues. â€œWeâ€™re genreless now.â€
This story will appear in the March 9, 2024, issue of Billboard.

title: Ice Spice Says She's 'Obsessed' With Lana Del Rey
content:
Ahead of her 2024 Billboard Women in Music Hitmaker ceremony on Wednesday (March 6), â€œMunchâ€ hitmaker Ice Spice talked about some of her biggest musical inspirations, one of which might surprise you.
In a recent chat with Billboard, Spice was asked to name some of her favorite hit-makers of all time. After shouting out past Hitmakers honorees including Charli XCX and Dolly Parton (â€œtheyâ€™re iconic, each in their own wayâ€), Spice specifically called out Lana Del Rey as her musical north star.
â€œIâ€™m obsessed with her, and I feel like all of her songs are hits, even the ones that arenâ€™t as big as the others,â€ Ice Spice, 24, said of the sad-eyed singer who joined her and Taylor Swift in a skybox in February for Super Bowl LVIII to root on champs the Kansas City Chiefs. The unlikely Spice/Del Rey duo got to hang at a pre-Grammys gala honoring Jon Platt last month at the Beverley Hilton and Spice told Complex last year that at the time the only album she wanted to listen to was Del Reyâ€™s 2014 album Ultraviolence.
Trending on Billboard
â€œRihanna, too. I have both [her and Del Reyâ€™s] vinyls. Taylor Swift. Of course, Nicki Minaj. Drake. The list is long!â€ Spice added in her Billboard chat.
Itâ€™s been a wild year for the Bronx MC, who has stormed the charts with a series of Jersey-club infected songs created with her longtime collaborator, RIOTUSA. Starting with her first solo Hot 100 entry with â€œIn Ha Moodâ€ last February, Ice Spice ended 2023 with four Hot 100 top 10s, a high point that tied her with Nicki Minaj (2012) and Cardi B (2018) for the most by a female rapper in a calendar year.

title: Coquette: Cresce interesse pelo estilo no Brasil
content:

Sabrina Carpenter durante o Jingle Ball 2023 da iHeartRadio z100 no Madison Square Garden - Dia Dipasupil / Getty Images via AFP
Dados do Google Trends mostram que nos Ãºltimos 12 meses o interesse pelo termo atingiu o pico em janeiro de 2024 no Brasil, e as buscas por "coquette" dobraram em 2023 em relaÃ§Ã£o ao ano anterior.
No TikTok, a hashtag #coquette tem 1,8 milhÃµes de publicaÃ§Ãµes, enquanto no Pinterest, rede social para inspiraÃ§Ãµes e tendÃªncias, as buscas por "coquette aesthetic" e "laÃ§o coquette" aumentaram 10.000% em marÃ§o de 2024 em comparaÃ§Ã£o com marÃ§o do ano passado.
"As estampas florais, tecido acetinado, peÃ§as com decote, o corset e muitos laÃ§os, seja no cabelo, na roupa ou na meia. A junÃ§Ã£o desses elementos Ã© o principal do 'coquette'", diz Gabriela Donato, consultora de estilo e stylist.
Para ela, o estilo Ã© o queridinho da geraÃ§Ã£o Z, influenciada pela cantora pop Sabrina Carpenter e a modelo Hailey Bieber. AlÃ©m da sÃ©rie "Bridgerton", que resgatou o estilo vitoriano com vestidos com babados, decotes quadrados e estampas florais.
Sabrina estrelou uma coleÃ§Ã£o de roupa Ã­ntima da Skims, da socialite Kim Kardashian, com lingerie de renda, laÃ§os e cores pastÃ©is nos tons rosa e verde.
Outra queridinha dos jovens pelas canÃ§Ãµes melodramÃ¡ticas Ã© a cantora Lana Del Rey, que protagonizou uma campanha da marca em janeiro. A coleÃ§Ã£o trazia referÃªncias ao estilo, como lingerie acetinada, renda e laÃ§os.
RelatÃ³rio do Pinterest com tendÃªncias de festivais e do Coachella 2024 confirmou essa tendÃªncia impulsionada pela cantora. A pesquisa indica que as pessoas acessam a rede para se inspirar nos artistas do Coachella e encontrar o melhor estilo para o look.
Neste ano, as buscas por "Lana Del Rey core" subiram 300%. "Minivestido de corset", "corset vintage" e "penteado com laÃ§o" sÃ£o algumas das pesquisas na plataforma relacionadas a essa estÃ©tica que tiveram aumento, com destaque para "joias com formato de laÃ§o", que teve um crescimento de 1.764%.
Os dados abrangem as buscas globais de dezembro de 2022 a janeiro de 2023, em comparaÃ§Ã£o com dezembro de 2023 a janeiro de 2024.
Lucius Vilar, estilista e professor do curso de moda da Faculdade Santa Marcelina, diz que uma das expoentes do "coquette" Ã© a designer de moda irlandesa Simone Rocha, que jÃ¡ trabalha com essa ideia de roupa super delicada, com renda e conectada a essa estÃ©tica vitoriana.
Look da grife Simone Rocha - DivulgaÃ§Ã£o
"Se juntar o estilo romÃ¢ntico com a era vitoriana e com o visual rococÃ³, pensando no filme Maria Antonieta, essas influÃªncias bebem muito disso. E 'Bridgerton' tem um figurino muito interessante que influencia tambÃ©m essas pessoas que seguem tendÃªncias", diz Vilar.
A criadora de conteÃºdo no TikTok, Bruna Monteiro, 26, produz vÃ­deos inspirados nesse estilo o que a levou a montar uma loja, a Coquettie com produÃ§Ã£o de roupas e acessÃ³rios como laÃ§os, scrunchies, casaquinhos e saias.
Bruna diz que foi influenciada a aderir ao "coquette" por conta do balÃ©, que tambÃ©m leva o nome de "balletcore", estÃ©tica que remete ao estilo de bailarina como as sapatilhas e a saia de tule.
A jovem Giullia Marchetti, 24, tambÃ©m tem sua prÃ³pria marca de roupa, a Leoni per me que abusa de looks com scrunchies, vestidos e tops com laÃ§os.
"Seguimos nesse estilo romÃ¢ntico, mas, ao mesmo tempo, conseguimos mesclar com outros estilos diferentes. As adeptas do street style tambÃ©m conseguem incorporar peÃ§as da Leone", diz Giullia.
Looks da loja Leoni per me, (Ã  esq.), a modelo usa um top de algodÃ£o branco com detalhes de fitas pretas na parte frontal, manga bufante e detalhes de nervura na cintura e (Ã  dir.), a modelo usa top reto com alÃ§as em cetim - DivulgaÃ§Ã£o
"Apostar em tons pastÃ©is, rosados e nude. As sapatilhas sÃ£o Ã³timas, porque trazem o romÃ¢ntico a qualquer look, e os sapatos Mary Jane", diz Bruna, que tambÃ©m indica acessÃ³rios de pÃ©rolas e fitas de cetim.
"As fitas de cetim podem ser usadas como colar, basta amarrar no pescoÃ§o. Se vocÃª as coloca no cabelo, podem servir como uma faixa ou um acessÃ³rio para o coque", diz Bruna.
Para Giullia, as meias tambÃ©m podem compor esse estilo. "Sejam elas curtas, trÃªs quartos ou atÃ© mesmo meia-calÃ§a, acredito que adicionam um toque extra ao visual", diz Giullia.

title: Lana Del Rey & Paul Cauthen Sing 'Unchained Melody'
content:
California got a little bit more of Lana Del Rey this weekend, with her making an unannounced appearance at Stagecoach following two weekends of headlining Coachella. Paul Cauthen welcomed the Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd songstress to the stage for a stirring rendition of â€œUnchained Melodyâ€ on Friday (April 27).
Del Rey and Cauthen crooned the classic that became a hit recording for the Righteous Brothers in 1965 â€” and was also famously performed by Elvis Presley in 1977, just two months before his death â€” during Cauthenâ€™s set at the first night of the Indio, California, festival.
Trending on Billboard
Related Diddy Files Motion to Dismiss Some Claims in a Sexual Assault Lawsuit
â€œHe decided he wanted me to do a nice slow one to finish it off,â€ Del Rey, who joined Cauthen at the end of his set, said to the crowd.
Stagecoach shared the video below of the pairâ€™s performance Friday night.
And on Saturday, Del Rey uploaded a short video of their duet.
â€œJust lovin life with @paulcauthen,â€ she captioned the post. She also uploaded photos from their day.
Cauthen posted pictures and a clip from their performance on Instagram as well, writing, â€œThank you @stagecoach! Yâ€™all were electric this year. Thank you @honeymoon for sharing the stage with me for this special moment. Thank you to my team for your support through this whole process. Yâ€™all, we are just getting started!â€
Del Rey, who has a country album called Lasso in the works, sang â€œUnchained Melodyâ€ last year for Christmas at Graceland, NBCâ€™s holiday special celebrating the legacy of Elvis Presley. Cauthen previously covered the classic with Orville Peck, with the pair performing as their act The Unrighteous Brothers.
See Lana hitting a heavenly note on the Stagecoach stage with Cauthen.

title: Lana Del Reys Coachella-Auftritt verursacht dickes BuÃŸgeld!
content:
Den Veranstaltern des Coachella-Festivals droht eine Geldstrafe in HÃ¶he von mehr als 26.000 Euro â€“ und das wegen nur 13 lÃ¤ppischen Minuten. Denn: Lana Del Rey (38) Ã¼berzog ihr Set. Ein Vertreter der Stadt Indio, wo das berÃ¼hmte Musikfestival stattfindet, berichtet, dass die Show der SÃ¤ngerin am Freitagabend eine knappe Viertelstunde lÃ¤nger ging als geplant. FÃ¼r den VerstoÃŸ gegen die Sperrstundenregelung wird nun zur Kasse gebeten, berichtet TMZ. Dennoch dÃ¼rfte allein die Summe schon ein Grund zur Freude fÃ¼r die Veranstalter sein. Im vergangenen Jahr fiel das BuÃŸgeld mit rund 110.000 Euro nÃ¤mlich noch deutlich Ã¼ppiger aus.
Lanas Set am zweiten Wochenende umfasste insgesamt 19 Songs und dÃ¼rfte die Fans voll auf ihre Kosten gebracht haben â€“ BuÃŸgeld hin oder her. Besonders begeisterte die Zuschauer der Ãœberraschungsauftritt von Camila Cabello (27), die ihre neue Single performte. "Camila ist mein MÃ¤dchen, ich habe so viel SpaÃŸ mit ihr. Ich liebe diesen Song und danke dir so sehr, Engel, dass du gekommen bist und mit mir gesungen hast", schwÃ¤rmte die Headlinerin des Festivals laut Daily Mail am Ende des gemeinsamen Auftritts. Auch am ersten Coachella-Wochenende stand die Musikerin nicht allein auf der BÃ¼hne. Am 12. April unterstÃ¼tzte Billie Eilish (22) Lana bei ihrer megaerfolgreichen Ballade "Video Games" und trÃ¤llerte gleich noch ihren eigenen Hit "Ocean Eyes" hinterher.
Abgesehen vom Ã¤rgerlichen BuÃŸgeld war Coachella in diesem Jahr anscheinend das Festival der Liebe â€“ zahlreiche Promis zeigten sich kÃ¼ssend und kuschelnd der Welt. Taylor Swift (34) und Travis Kelce (34) feierten ausgelassen mitten in der Crowd. Auch die frisch gebackenen Eltern Suki Waterhouse (32) und Robert Pattinson (37) genossen ein wenig Zweisamkeit nach dem Auftritt der "Good Looking"-Interpretin. Und wÃ¤hrend Heidi Klum (50) die Musik mit all ihren Kindern genoss, nabelte sich die Ã„lteste Leni (19) von ihrer Familie ab und knutschte lieber mit ihrem Freund Aris Rachevsky.

title: Lana Del Rey brings Camila Cabello on stage during Coachella 2024
content:
Lana Del Rey and Camila Cabello performed a duet of the latter's new song, 'I Luv It'
Lana Del Rey took the Coachella 2024 stage by storm, but her performance took an unexpected turn when she brought Camila Cabello on stage to collaborate on the latter's new song, I Luv It.
The surprise duet delighted fans as Lana joined Camila in singing the catchy chorus, showcasing their dynamic chemistry.
Transitioning from her balcony perch to the stage floor, Lana seamlessly blended her vocals with Camila's rendition of the song, even taking on the parts originally performed by Playboy Carti.
As the performance concluded, Lana expressed her gratitude to Camila, declaring, â€œ[Camilla] is my girl, I have so much fun with her. I love this song and thank you so much angel, for coming and singing with me.â€
In response, Camila expressed her admiration for Lana, calling her one of her favorite artists and expressing her gratitude for the opportunity to perform alongside her. Later, Camila shared snippets of Lana's performance on her Instagram Stories, showcasing her admiration for the talented singer.
This collaboration follows Lana's previous duet with Billie Eilish during weekend one of Coachella, where they mesmerised audiences with renditions of Ocean Eyes and Video Games.

title: Lana Del Rey Joined by Camila Cabello at Coachella 2024 Weekend Two
content:
Lana Del Rey was joined by surprise guest Camila Cabello during her weekend two performance at Coachella 2024.
During her headlining set on Friday night (April 19), the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ songstress welcomed Cabello to the stage to sing her new track â€œI Luv It.â€
After Del Rey temporarily left the stage following a performance of â€œBartender,â€ Cabello emerged with backup dancers for a lively delivery of her hyper-pop collab with Playboi Carti (who didnâ€™t make an appearance at the Indio. Calif., festival).
Del Rey mostly watched with admiration, but joined in on some of the verses and at one point placed her hands on Cabelloâ€™s waist and playfully spun her around.
â€œI luv it, I luv it, I luv it, I luv it,â€ Del Rey sang to Fifth Harmony alum after she closed the song. â€œThis is my girl. I have so much fun with her. I love this song to death. Thank you so much, angel, for coming to sing with me.â€
Trending on Billboard
Cabello replied, â€This is an honor me, youâ€™re one of my favorite artists of all time. Thank you so much.â€
In late March, prior to the release of â€œI Luv It,â€ Del Rey showed some love for the energetic single on social media. â€œi luv it,â€ the singer-songwriter captioned black-and-white photos of the â€œSenoritaâ€ singer on Instagram. Cabello took to the comments section of the post, leaving a series of crown emojis.
Del Reyâ€™s weekend two performance at Coachella follows her guest-filled set at the popular music festâ€™s opening day on April 12. During the performance, she welcomed Jon Batiste for â€œCandy Necklace,â€ Jack Antonoff for â€œHope Is a Dangerous Thing,â€ and duetted with Billie Eilish on â€œOcean Eyesâ€ and â€œVideo Games.â€
Del Reyâ€™s roughly 90-minute Coachella set last weekend also boasted some truly stunning set design, a bizarrely alluring hologram moment, her trademark sultry vocals, a generous helping of faded glamour and even some stripper pole twirling by the singer herself for good measure.
Check out a video of Del Rey and Cabello singing â€œI Luv Itâ€ at Coachella 2024 via TMZ.

title: Camila Cabello and Lana Del Rey Sing 'I Luv It' at Coachella
content:
Camila Cabello was the surprise guest artist for Lana Del Reyâ€˜s headlining Coachella set on Friday night.
Del Rey temporarily left the stage after singing her song â€œBartenderâ€ as Cabello launched into a surprise performance of her new single â€œI Luv Itâ€ from her forthcoming fourth studio album. Lana joined Cabello through some verses but mostly watched and danced from the balcony of her palace-like stage.
Cabello was backed by a crew of dancers who recreated the robotic choreography seen in the singleâ€™s matching music video which also features collaborator, Playboi Carti (Carti was not present on stage). Del Rey joined Cabello on the floor of the stage during Cartiâ€™s verse and placed her hands around Cabelloâ€™s waist as the two shared a playful spin.
â€œI luv it, I luv it, I luv it, I luv it,â€ Del Rey sang back to Cabello as the pop singer closed the song. She continued, â€œ[Camila] is my girl, I have so much fun with her. I love this song and thank you so much angel, for coming and singing with me.â€
Popular on Variety
Cabello responded, â€œThis is an honor for me, youâ€™re one of my favorite artists of all time. I love you so much.â€
Del Reyâ€™s week one Coachella performance welcomed recent collaborators Jack Antonoff and Jon Batiste, who again joined Del Rey again on Friday night. Both Antonoff and Batiste are also performing their own sets (Antonoff as the lead singer of the band Bleachers) at the festival. Billie Eilish also joined Del Rey who turned up for a surprise pair of duets of Eilishâ€™s â€œOcean Eyes,â€ and Del Reyâ€™s â€œVideo Games.â€

title: Camila Cabello makes surprise appearance during Lana Del Reyâ€™s Coachella set
content:
Camila Cabello made a surprise appearance during Lana Del Reyâ€™s headline slot at Coachella festival to perform her new single I Luv It featuring Playboi Carti.
Cabello, 27, who rose to prominence as a member of the girl group Fifth Harmony, graced the stage on Friday night during week two of the California-based event.
Advertisement
During her performance, the singer, who wore a white glittery T-shirt with the words â€œpepsi colaâ€ emblazoned on it, boot-cut blue jeans and a sparkly choker, told the crowd to â€œmake some motherf****** noise if you love Lana Del Rey.â€
When the song came to an end the Summertime Sadness singer thanked Cabello for performing with her and said: â€œThis my girl, I have so much fun with her, I love this song to death, thank you so much angel for coming and singing with me.â€
Advertisement
Lana Del Rey headlined Coachella (Danny Lawson/PA)
Advertisement
Cabello responded: â€œThis is an honour for me, youâ€™re one of my artists of all time, I love you so much.â€
Last week Del Rey, 38, welcomed Billie Eilish to the stage during week one of the festival, to perform her 2016 track Ocean Eyes, before they duetted on Del Reyâ€™s 2012 hit song Video Games.
She also performed alongside Grammy winner Jon Batiste, who played the piano on her hit Candy Necklace.
Del Rey, whose last appearance at the festival was her debut in 2014, was scheduled to feature in the 2020 Coachella line-up which was cancelled amid the Covid pandemic.
Advertisement
The singer, whose real name is Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, hit headlines last year for delayed performances at Glastonbury and BST Hyde Park festival.

title: Jeffrey Dahmer actor Evan Peters spotted â€˜dry humpingâ€™ new New York City influencer girlfriend at Coachella
content:
Actor Evan Peters has been spotted â€˜dry humpingâ€™ his new lover at Coachella, putting on their own spicy show during Lana Del Reyâ€™s set.
The 37-year-old star, most known for his roles in American Horror Story and Dahmer â€” Monster: The Jeffrey Dahmer Story, was captured in photos with a woman in which the two displayed their affection for one another.
Petersâ€™ new flame, reportedly a social media star from New York City, was seen dancing on the actor before he picked her up and passionately kissed her.
TheNightly Get in front of tomorrow's news for FREE Journalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion. READ NOW
The womanâ€™s dress appeared to ride up, but the loved-up couple were too smitten with each other to notice â€” or care.
A post on Facebook called out the pair for â€œdamn near dry humpingâ€.
â€œActor #EvanPeters was spotted making out with and damn near dry humping his new girlfriend during #LanaDelReyâ€™s set at #Coachella,â€ the post said.
â€œThe streets are saying that the girlâ€™s name is Natalie Engel, and sheâ€™s an influencer in New York City.
â€œYou know what, I be feeling the same way when Lana Del Rey is playing around me too.â€
People flooded the comments section with stunned reactions.
Camera Icon Evan Peters as Jeffrey Dahmer. Credit: BANG - Entertainment News
â€œOh, to be her,â€ one fan said.
Another said: â€œLucky gal.â€
â€œThis is not surprising behaviour during a Lana Del Rey set, lol,â€ a third said.
Another fan said: â€œIâ€™ve never been so jealous.â€
Peters made his acting debut in the 2004 drama film Clipping Adam and starred in the ABC science fiction series Invasion from 2005 to 2006.
He was last in a relationship with well-known actress and AHS co-star Emma Roberts.

title: Billie Eilish Says Lana Del Rey Is the Reason 'Ocean Eyes' Exists
content:
When Billie Eilish called Lana Del Rey â€œthe reason for half of you bâ€”-es existence, including mineâ€ during her surprise appearance at the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ singerâ€™s Coachella set over the weekend, she wasnâ€™t kidding.
While reflecting on the festivalâ€™s opening weekend on Instagram Stories Thursday (April 18), the 22-year-old pop star revealed that her debut single â€œOcean Eyesâ€ never wouldâ€™ve materialized if not for the influences of the 38-year-old alt-pop crusader. â€œThis song wouldnâ€™t even exist without her,â€ Eilish wrote, sharing a video of her singing the track on Friday (April 12) with Del Rey for thousands of festival-goers.
â€œLiterally a hallucination,â€ the two-time Oscar winner added of the experience.
Trending on Billboard
The post comes nearly a week after Eilish took the main stage at Coachella to sing â€œOcean Eyesâ€ as a duet with Lana â€” as well as help the headliner perform her own Born to Die single â€œVideo Games.â€ At the time, Del Rey told the crowd that the dreamy, Finneas-produced track was her favorite song of Eilishâ€™s and called the Swarm star the â€œvoice of our generation.â€
Eilish replied at the time, â€œ[She] is the reason for half you bâ€”-es existence, including mine.â€
The â€œWhat Was I Made For?â€ artist has previously praised Lanaâ€™s impact, telling Dua Lipa in August that Born to Die â€œchanged music.â€ â€œ[The album] especially changed music for girls and the potential of what is possible,â€ she added on the â€œLevitatingâ€ singerâ€™s At Your Service podcast.
In the eight years since she kickstarted her career with â€œOcean Eyes,â€ Eilish has released two Billboard 200-topping LPs, won nine Grammys and built a fanbase that includes well over 100 million followers on Instagram. Her third studio album, Hit Me Hard and Soft, arrives May 17, as announced earlier this month.
â€œfinneas and i truly could not be more proud of this album and we absolutely canâ€™t wait for you to hear it,â€ she wrote at the time. â€œlove you love you love you.â€

title: Lana Del Rey sufriÃ³ de laringitis antes de su show en Coachella 2024
content:

El pasado fin de semana, Lana Del Rey encabezÃ³ el emblemÃ¡tico festival de mÃºsica Coachella ofreciendo una memorable presentaciÃ³n a una dÃ©cada de debutar en dicho escenario. El show se realizÃ³ en medio la gira por su Ã¡lbum Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, y aunque logrÃ³ culminar con gran Ã©xito, sufriÃ³ una serie de contratiempos durante su preparaciÃ³n, desde laringitis hasta la renuncia de su manager.
En una publicaciÃ³n de Instagram, la cantante expresÃ³ su gratitud hacia quienes hicieron posible su actuaciÃ³n, desde su banda y bailarines hasta su equipo de producciÃ³n y escenario, pasando por sus invitados especiales Billie Eilish, Jack Antonoff y Jon Batiste. Sin embargo, aprovechÃ³ para mencionar la sorpresiva renuncia de su mÃ¡nager de gira, Peter â€˜Peteâ€™ Abbott, a solo un mes de la presentaciÃ³n.

â€œSe fue sin ninguna razÃ³n despuÃ©s de 15 aÃ±osâ€. Â¿La razÃ³n? Aparentemente, su salida se debiÃ³ a que se sintiÃ³ â€œdolidoâ€ porque le regalaron 10 motobicicletas gratis [que usÃ³ en su performance], hecho que disgustÃ³ a Pete. â€œDecidiÃ³ al azar que era mÃ¡s un escenÃ³grafo que un tour managerâ€, agregÃ³.
En medio de la salida de Pete, la interpretÃ© encontrÃ³ en Emily, su sustituta, la fortaleza y el apoyo necesarios para llevar a cabo el show. La artista no dudÃ³ en elogiarla por su excelente trabajo bajo presiÃ³n, subrayando que â€œlo hizo de p*** madreâ€.
Con la supuesta ayuda de su clarividente, Lana del Rey superÃ³ una inoportuna laringitis. (CrÃ©ditos: Joe Camporeale-USA TODAY Sports)
AdemÃ¡s, la preparaciÃ³n para el espectÃ¡culo de Del Rey estuvo lejos de ser tranquila. La artista revelÃ³ que su banda pasÃ³ â€œmesesâ€ ensayando en un almacÃ©n de Los Ãngeles, un lugar que se enfriÃ³ tanto que contrajo laringitis. Pero, al parecer, logrÃ³ recuperarse solo unos minutos antes de su presentaciÃ³n gracias a su clarividente y sanadora Tessa DiPietro, quien â€œpasÃ³ dos horas levantando esa tos a distancia [videollamada] a travÃ©s de sus habilidades intuitivas corporalesâ€.
En nombre de DiPietro sus habilidades curativas ya habÃ­an sido mencionadas por la cantante en un poema incluido en su libro Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, ademÃ¡s expresÃ³ su admiraciÃ³n por la chamana en una publicaciÃ³n de Facebook en 2020 y a final de 2023 le dijo a la revista Harperâ€™s Bazaar que mantiene sesiones con ella todos los jueves.
Luego de diez aÃ±os, Lana del Rey volviÃ³ al festival de Coachella montada en una motocicleta. (CrÃ©ditos: Coachella Live/YouTube)
Un Ã©xito en Coachella 2024
Lana Del Rey cerrÃ³ el primer dÃ­a de Coachella 2024 con una actuaciÃ³n impactante que deslumbrÃ³ al pÃºblico gracias a sus colaboraciones. Ella compartiÃ³ escenario con Billie Eilish para entonar una emotiva versiÃ³n de â€œVideo Gamesâ€ y â€œOcean Eyesâ€.
Durante su dueto expresaron su admiraciÃ³n mutua. â€œEsa es la voz de nuestra generaciÃ³n, la voz de tu generaciÃ³n, y estoy tan jodidamente agradecida que ella estÃ© de pie a mi lado en este momento cantando mi canciÃ³n favoritaâ€, declarÃ³ la cantautora. Por su parte, Eilish sostuvo visiblemente emocionada que Del Rey es una influencia fundamental en su vida: â€œÂ¡Esta es la razÃ³n de la existencia de la mitad de ustedes, incluida la mÃ­a!â€, exclamÃ³.
La colaboraciÃ³n de Lana Del Rey con Billie Eilish marcÃ³ uno de los momentos mÃ¡s destacados del festival. (CrÃ©ditos: REUTERS)
Jon Batiste tambiÃ©n subiÃ³ para cantar â€œCandy Necklaceâ€, canciÃ³n nominada a la mejor actuaciÃ³n de dÃºo/grupo pop en los Grammys 2024. Finalmente, Jack Antonoff la acompaÃ±Ã³ al piano en el tema â€œHope Is a Dangerous Thing for a Woman Like Me to Have - But I Have Itâ€.
