AdemÃ¡s, la estrella identificada por su pop barroco con letras melancÃ³licas, tiene previsto otro show en Estados Unidos, en el Hangout Fest de Alabama en mayo. TambiÃ©n se encuentra preparando su prÃ³ximo proyecto musical, Lasso, un Ã¡lbum de country que sus seguidores esperan con ansias para septiembre.
â€œSi aÃºn no lo sabes por nuestros ganadores de premios y nuestros artistas, el negocio de la mÃºsica se estÃ¡ volviendo country. Nos vamos al campo. EstÃ¡ sucediendoâ€, dijo durante el anuncio del disco en los Premios Grammy 2024.

title: Lana Del Rey Says Tour Manager Quit Month Before Coachella
content:
Lana Del Rey reigned as the Queen of Indio, Calif., when she headlined Coachella last weekend (April 13), but one particular exit from her kingdom left the â€œVideo Gamesâ€ singer especially peeved.
In an Instagram post reflecting on her performance shared to her Instagram account, Del Rey revealed that her tour manager, Peter Abbott, quit just over a month before she took the stage.
After thanking all the key players that made her set possible â€” including her fans, her band, Wally Crowder (who helped choreograph her motorcycle entrance) and special guests Billie Eilish, Jon Batiste and Jack Antonoff â€” Del Rey revealed that a team member had to step up as tour manager on short notice.
â€œ[Thank you] Emily for stepping up as tour manager when Pete quit for no reason after 15 years,â€ Del Rey wrote, referencing Emily Holt before continuing about Abbott. â€œHe was butt hurt that I got 10 comped bikes for free from Wally and randomly decided he was more of a stage designer than a tour managerâ€¦ Never got a phone call probably never will. Still grateful for the 15 years though.â€
Trending on Billboard
Billboard has made attempts to reach Abbott for his response.
Del Reyâ€™s appearance at this yearâ€™s Coachella comes a decade after she last performed at the festival. The â€œA&Wâ€ singer was originally scheduled for a prime Coachella spot back in 2020, but that year was canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. From her lyrics to her imagery, Del Rey has long been synonymous with Coachella and its aesthetic. She even played on that synergy with billboards leading into Indio that read â€œHas anyone else died for you?â€ â€” a reference to how Del Rey was effectively crucified by the media after her infamous 2012 Saturday Night Live performance.
â€œNo worries â€“ 37 days was more than enough time to put together an entire headlining set all by ourselves. Not stressful at all,â€ Del Reyâ€™s Instagram post continued. â€œWay to go Emily you fâ€”ing killed it with grace. Thank you to my managers Ben and Ed for making me laugh the entire way through everything for my whole freaking life even though none of it ever makes any sense. PS please send me an email If you decide to quit this year- 15 years is a long time for us too.â€
The rest of Del Reyâ€™s statement continued with her thanks to various collaborators, making for a deeply personal caption for a carousel of photographs from her performance. Among those photos are rehearsal footage, flicks of her background singers and dancers, and an adorable backstage picture of Del Rey, Batiste and Antonoff.
Last year, the â€œSummertime Sadnessâ€ singer notched her ninth top 10 entry on the Billboard 200 with Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, which earned five Grammy nominations, including for album of the year. Del Rey is set to return to the stage Friday (April 19) for round 2 of her headlining stint.
Read the starâ€™s full statement below.

title: Coachella Streaming Gains for Lana Del Rey, No Doubt, Sublime & More
content:
Welcome to Billboard Proâ€™s Trending Up column, where we take a closer look at the songs, artists, curiosities and trends that have caught the music industryâ€™s attention. Some have come out of nowhere, others have taken months to catch on, and all of them could become ubiquitous in the blink of a TikTok clip.
This week: The first weekend of Coachella spurs gains for a lot of the biggest and most ascendant names involved, while songs that soundtracked the biggest moments of Wrestlemania XL also see big bumps, a Cowboy Carter collaborator has his first solo breakout hit and more.
New Peaks in the Coachella Valley: Streaming Bumps for Lana Del Rey, No Doubt, Sabrina Carpenter & More Weekend One Performers
Coachella Season was once again upon us this past weekend, as hundreds of thousands of music fans flocked to the desert in Indio, Calif. to see many of the best and brightest performers in pop, rock, dance, hip-hop and more. While this yearâ€™s festival saw a little less hype (and was reported to have slower ticket sales) than some past incarnations, many of the key artists involved still saw big bumps in streaming consumption following their buzzed-about performances.
Trending on Billboard
Friday (Apr. 12) headliner Lana Del Rey saw a 36% rise in official on-demand U.S. streams over the following Saturday to Monday compared to that period from the previous week, climbing from 19.4 million streams to 26.4 million, according to Luminate. Breakthrough hit â€œVideo Gamesâ€ was one of her biggest beneficiaries, rising 70% to nearly 1.2 million streams, thanks to Del Rey bringing out fellow alt-pop superstar Billie Eilish for her Coachella performance of it â€” then returning the favor by dueting with Eilish on her own breakout single, â€œOcean Eyesâ€ (up 21% to 1.5 million). Saturday headliner Tyler, the Creator also saw a Sunday-to-Monday bump from the prior week, with his catalog increasing 20% to 13.5 million streams. (Sunday headliner Doja Cat was down overall in streams, due to her having released her Scarlet 2: Claude deluxe edition the week before.)
In addition to those headliner bumps, a number of the reunited â€™90s rock acts on the undercard for Saturday also saw major gains. Of those, No Doubt easily saw the biggest, with their overall catalog leaping 85% (from 1.4 million to 2.6 million) over Sunday and Monday from the previous week â€” with their â€œBathwater,â€ performed with a special cameo from pop-rock superstar Olivia Rodrigo, seeing a particularly notable spike (up 450% to 113,000 streams). No Doubtâ€™s â€™90s ska-punk peers Sublime, who assembled on Saturday with late original lead singer Bradley Nowellâ€™s son Jakob taking vocal duties for the first time, also saw a more modest bump for their catalog over that period (up 19% to 4.6 million streams), as did Britpop greats Blur (up 27% to 770,000).
It wasnâ€™t just the established veterans seeing the catalog spikes for the weekend, though. Still-rising pop star Sabrina Carpenter had one of the best-received sets on Friday, not only helping her just-released single â€œEspressoâ€ score her best numbers for a new song to date (9.9 million streams between Apr. 12-15), but also offering a major bump for the rest of her catalog â€” which was up 41% from the previous week to 10.4 million streams over the three days following her set, not counting the â€œEspressoâ€ numbers. Meanwhile, Chappell Roanâ€˜s breakout spring just kept rolling, with her catalog streams rising 52% to 14.6 million over Saturday to Monday from the previous week, following her Friday performance. And ReneÃ© Rappâ€˜s headline-capturing Sunday set also resulted in a 33% bump from the prior week for her catalogue that Monday, climbing to 1.4 million streams. â€“ ANDREW UNTERBERGER
WrestleMania XL Lights Up Tracks from The Weeknd and Nothing More
As wrestling fans continue to bask in the glow of WrestleMania XL (April 6-7), so do songs featured prominently at the blockbuster event. Both The Weekndâ€™s â€œGasolineâ€ and Nothing Moreâ€™s â€œIf It Doesnâ€™t Hurtâ€ posted impressive streaming gains during WrestleMania week.
â€œGasoline,â€ a single from the pop superstarâ€™s 2022 Dawn FM album that peaked at No. 29 on the Billboard Hot 100, pulled over 560,000 official on-demand U.S. streams during the period of April 5-11, according to Luminate. That marks a 72% increase from just over 320,000 streams during March 29-April 4. â€œGasolineâ€ marks the fifth consecutive Weeknd song to be selected as the WrestleMania theme. Past Weeknd selections include â€œLess Than Zeroâ€ (2023), â€œSacrificeâ€ (2022), â€œSave Your Tearsâ€ (2021) and â€œBlinding Lightsâ€ (2020).
At the top of the year (Jan. 19), Grammy-nominated hard rockers Nothing More launched â€œIf It Doesnâ€™t Hurtâ€ as a standalone single. During the week of WrestleMania (April 5-11), where â€œHurtâ€ was used in a hype package video for the much-anticipated Rhea Ripley vs. Becky Lynch match, the song collected over 580,000 official on-demand U.S. streams, posting a whopping 132% gain from around 253,000 streams the week prior.
According to Deadline, WrestleMania XL was Peacockâ€™s most-streamed entertainment event ever, garnering jaw-dropping 1.3 billion live minutes across April 6 and 7. Clearly, some of those viewers made their way to favorite music streaming platforms after hearing those theme songs for two action-packed nights in a row. â€“ KYLE DENIS
Shaboozeyâ€™s Boozy New Single Is Already a Breakout Hit
Along with the multiple country legends who swung by or got shouted out on Cowboy Carter, BeyoncÃ©â€™s latest blockbuster also featured a handful of rising artists as collaborators, receiving the most coveted type of co-sign by popping up on a Queen Bey track list. Shaboozey arguably received the biggest showcase of any of the guest artists by appearing on two songs from the Billboard 200-topping set, as the rising country singer-songwriter swung by â€œSpaghettiiâ€ and â€œSweet / Honey / Buckiinâ€™â€ and quickly expanded his profile one decade into his recording career.
Not wanting to sacrifice any of the Cowboy Carter momentum, Shaboozey returned last Friday (Apr. 12) with â€œA Bar Song (Tipsy),â€ a clap-along country anthem designed for bleary-eyed TouchTunes plays. The BeyoncÃ© Bump helped the single score seven-figure streaming totals in its first four days of release, debuting with 1.63 million U.S. on-demand streams on Friday (according to Luminate), and racking up 5.66 million streams through Monday â€” along with nearly 6,000 in digital song sales, a tremendous number for a song by a newer artist over just for days.
Meanwhile, â€œTipsyâ€ â€” J-Kwonâ€™s eternal 2004 hip-hop smash, which reached No. 2 on the Hot 100 â€” was revived in â€œA Bar Song (Tipsy)â€ via interpolation, and is enjoying a slight streaming bump of its own following the Shaboozey single release. â€œTipsyâ€ earned 413,000 streams from Apr. 12-15, up 8% from the same four-day period during the previous week (383,000 streams from Apr. 5-8), as listeners likely played it one time, then ran it back from the two to the three to the four times. â€“ JASON LIPSHUTZ
GloRilla Guns for Third Concurrent Hit With Fast-Rising Big Boogie Collab â€œBopâ€
Between â€œYeah Glo!â€ and the Megan Thee Stallion-assisted â€œWanna Be,â€ GloRilla has the first half of the year on lock. Now, with her catchy Big Boogie collaboration â€œBop,â€ sheâ€™s looking to add another 2024 hit to her arsenal.
During the period of April 12-15, â€œBopâ€ earned slightly over one million official on-demand U.S. streams, ballooning 43% from just under 730,000 streams during April 5-8. The songâ€™s growth has been spurred by a dance trend created by TikTok user @curvejso. The infectious choreography is set to the very end of GloRillaâ€™s guest verse and the entirety of her hook.
Although the sound that played in the video that kickstarted the trend is no longer available, several â€œBopâ€ sounds have found traction on TikTok. A fan-uploaded snippet of the sound boasts over 16,000 posts on the platform, and another user-uploaded snippet (which soundtracks a different dance trend) plays in over 4,000 posts. Should the dance trend continue to turn into streaming gains, Big Boogie could be in for his very first Hot 100 entry with â€œBop.â€ â€” KD

title: Whatâ€™s 15 Years Working for Lana Del Rey Worth?
content:
Lana Del Reyâ€™s Coachella prep sure sounds like a ride. In true Del Rey fashion, she turned what was ostensibly a thank-you post after her headlining set into an airing of grievances â€” beginning with her 15-year tour manager, who quit 37 days before the set. â€œEmily for stepping up as tour manager when Pete quit for no reason after 15 years because he was butt hurt that I got 10 comped bikes for free from Wally and randomly decided he was more of a stage designer than a tour manager â€¦,â€ Del Rey wrote. â€œNever got a phone call probably never will. Still grateful for the 15 years though.â€ Sheâ€™s talking about the motorcycles that rode out during the set, gifted to her by stuntman Wally Crowder, who got his own thank-you â€œfor my bad as bikes.â€ Sorry to Pete, but come on â€” ever heard of a two weeksâ€™ notice?
â€œNo worries â€” 37 days was more than enough time to put together an entire headlining set by ourselves,â€ Del Rey continued. â€œNot stressful at all.â€ The biggest stressor, it sounds like, was Del Rey catching laryngitis after â€œspending months in Sylmar in a 40Â° warehouse.â€ Thus, one of Del Reyâ€™s biggest (honest) thank-yous goes to her friend Tessa DiPietro, whom she previously named a poem after on her collection Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass. â€œTessa DiPietro spent two hours lifting that cough remotely through her body intuitive skills just minutes before showtime,â€ she wrote. So it really was a resurrection.

title: Courtney Love attacca Taylor Swift: â€œNon Ã¨ interessanteâ€
content:
Courtney Love contro tutti. Lâ€™ex leader degli Hole e vedova di Kurt Cobain ha mostrato scarso apprezzamento per ben tre colleghe celebri nel corso di unâ€™intervista rilasciata a The Standard per promuovere la nuova serie BBC intitolata Courtney Loveâ€™s Women, ideata per celebrare le donne nella musica.
Nonostante le intenzioni del suo programma, Love ha criticato piuttosto duramente Taylor Swift, Lana Del Rey e Madonna. La prima a finire sotto accusa Ã¨ stata Swift, lâ€™artista dei record: â€œTaylor non Ã¨ importante â€“ ha dichiarato Love - Potrebbe essere uno spazio sicuro per le ragazze, e probabilmente Ã¨ la Madonna di oggi, ma non Ã¨ interessante come artistaâ€.
Poi Ã¨ toccato a Lana Del Rey. Nonostante avesse precedentemente affermato che il suo defunto marito Kurt Cobain e Lana Del Rey erano gli unici "veri geni musicali" che avesse mai conosciuto, la cantante ha ora affermato di essersi stancata anche della sua collega affermando di aver smesso di seguirla nel dicembre dello scorso anno.
"Non mi piace Lana da quando ha fatto la cover di una canzone di John Denver, e penso che dovrebbe davvero prendersi sette anni di pausa", ha detto Love. â€œFino a Take Me Home, Country Roads pensavo che fosse fantastica. Mentre stavo registrando il mio nuovo album, ho dovuto smettere di ascoltarla perchÃ© mi stava influenzando troppoâ€.
Courtney Love ha poi parlato di Madonna, con la quale ha un rapporto difficile da decenni. Nel 2007, Love mise in dubbio la validitÃ  di Madonna come artista, scrivendo sul suo blog dell'epoca: â€œMadonna Ã¨ una grande donna d'affari ma andiamo, Ã¨ debole come artista e lo sappiamo tutti. Mi piace, ma come musicista importante Ã¨ uno scherzoâ€. Poi ha aggiunto: â€œNon mi piace e io non piaccio a lei. Ho adorato Cercasi Susan disperatamente, non solo per lei ma per come era raccontata New Yorkâ€.
In un altro momento dellâ€™intervista, Love ha parlato di BeyoncÃ© e del nuovo, discusso album Cowboy Carter: â€œMi piace lâ€™idea che BeyoncÃ© faccia un disco country perchÃ© riguarda le donne nere che entrano in spazi dove prima erano ammesse solo le donne bianche. Come concetto, lo adoro. Semplicemente non mi piace la sua musicaâ€.

title: Taylor Swift & Travis Kelce, Courtney Love Disses BeyoncÃ©
content:
Itâ€™s Tuesday, April 16th and Courtney Love is dissing Taylor Swift, BeyoncÃ©, Lana Del Rey, and more big artists. The Kid LAROI officially confirms his relationship status with Tate McRae, Coi Leray wants to change her stage name and the Department of Justice is putting Live Nation & Ticketmaster in the hot seat. Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce are about to be busy with Taylor releasing â€˜The Tortured Poets Departmentâ€™ this week, sheâ€™s giving her fans all the clues prior to its release. Travis Kelce is officially named the host of â€˜Are You Smarter Than a Celebrity?,â€™ what canâ€™t this power duo do? Richy Jackson spills into what itâ€™s like working with Lady Gaga & JoJo Siwa, Dua Lipa explains her creativity behind â€˜Illusionâ€™ and more!
Katie Cao 3:11 PM
Rania Aniftos:
Courtney Love isnâ€™t here for Beyonce, Taylor or Lana. Travis and Taylor are booked and busy Tate and LAROI are official, Coi wants to lose Leray and the DOJ is going after Live Nation. Choreographer Richy Jackson stops by our studio and Dua Lipa gives us all the details on her new single. Welcome back to another episode of Billboard News. Iâ€™m Rania Aniftos, itâ€™s Tuesday, April 16 and we got to kick off the show with Courtney Love getting real about some of your faves. Courtney Love did not hold back when she talked about BeyoncÃ©, Taylor Swift, Lana Del Rey and more. Letâ€™s break it down. Courtney Love does not shy away from sharing her opinions while promoting her eight part audio series on the BBC, Courtney Loveâ€™s Women, The whole front woman actually admitted to not liking some womenâ€™s music. She told the Atlantic she likes the idea of Beyonce doing a country album because sheâ€™s a black woman in a commonly white space, but she doesnâ€™t like her music. BeyoncÃ© and Taylor Swift are the biggest women in music at the moment, but Courtney doesnâ€™t think Taylorâ€™s important. Love said â€œshe might be a safe space for girls and sheâ€™s probably the Madonna of now, but sheâ€™s not interesting as an artist.â€ Speaking on Madonna Courtney simply said â€œI donâ€™t like Madonna and she doesnâ€™t like me.â€ She also talked about Lana Del Rey.
Watch to learn more!

title: The Country Boom Is Happening Outside Nashville
content:
Photo-Illustration: Vulture; Photos: Getty
Thereâ€™s always been something twangy in Jewelâ€™s music. The singer-songwriterâ€™s voice has a yodel-like warble, and a banjo or steel guitar could fit right into her folkier hits like â€œYou Were Meant for Me.â€ But selling tens of millions of records couldnâ€™t help her achieve one of her longtime goals: getting played on country radio. Jewel was signed to Atlantic, a pop label that didnâ€™t have the resources to promote songs to country stations, which tend to prioritize artists on Nashville-based labels. So when her contract was up, she moved to Valory Music Co., an imprint of Nashvilleâ€™s Big Machine Records, and worked with John Rich of Big & Rich to produce Perfectly Clear, an album marketed as her country pivot. Not only did it go No. 1 on Billboardâ€™s country chart, but its lead single, â€œStronger Woman,â€ worked its way into radio rotation.
For years, established artists have listened to Dolly Parton, who sang in 1973 that Music Row was â€œwhere you have to goâ€ if you want to make country music. Yet the city has always been wary of so-called carpetbaggers like Bret Michaels and Steven Tyler, who arrived in Nashville around the same time as Jewel, but whose contrived country songs failed to revive their lagging solo careers. As â€˜90s powerhouse Clay Walker put it in 2015, â€œWe have great singers, great musicians. Thereâ€™s no reason we have to dilute it by letting people in the format that donâ€™t have any business being in the format.â€ Though Walker didnâ€™t name names, his specific mention of â€œoutdated rock-and-rollersâ€ made it pretty clear who he was talking about.
But not everyone interested in the genre sees a need to engage with its restrictive systems. Today, a new crop of outsiders are trying their hands at country without ever setting foot in Tennessee. By avoiding the industry entirely, theyâ€™re circumventing the usual gatekeepers and writing more progressive songs than the middle-of-the-road fare they wouldâ€™ve found on Music Row. BeyoncÃ© headlines the group with Cowboy Carter, a survey of Americana with one eye to the past and one to the future. Alongside her are pop musicians Lana Del Rey and Maggie Rogers, who are finding fresh inspiration in country sounds. At the same time, indie rockers Waxahatchee, Angel Olsen, and Big Thief are foregrounding the twangy influences that have long lurked in their music.
Unlike Michaels and Tyler, these artists arenâ€™t turning to the genre to juice their own careers. Theyâ€™re doing it for the same reason as Nashvilleâ€™s greats: Thereâ€™s something in the music they canâ€™t find elsewhere. While shunning the system means giving up their chance at radio spins or a No. 1, theyâ€™re freeing themselves from the industryâ€™s notions of what its music ought to be, laying the groundwork for a future where Nashville isnâ€™t countryâ€™s only player.
The current non-Nashville boom has roots in 2016, when a handful of pop acts began incorporating the genre into their music. Lady Gaga channeled her love of country on Joanne, while Justin Timberlake and BeyoncÃ© honored their southern roots with detours like â€œDrink You Awayâ€ and â€œDaddy Lessons.â€ These tradition-steeped songs became hits and fan favorites, proving that the pop-listening public had an appetite for country if it was packaged right.
Kacey Musgraves went further. Though she came up within the country system, she was far from an insider â€” as a woman with progressive politics that often bled into her music, Musgraves struggled in the conservative world of country radio, which rarely prioritizes female singers. But in 2018, she re-envisioned what country could be on Golden Hour, introducing synthesizers and other pop touches without conceding the banjos or twang that first established her career. Country continued to move into pop in 2019, when Lil Nas X turned a banjo loop into a massive pop-rap hit in â€œOld Town Road.â€ It hardly mattered that everyone in Nashville (besides Billie Ray Cyrus) shunned the song, because a bigger audience had already claimed it.
As the 2020s began, a group of indie-rock musicians began tapping into their latent country roots. Katie Crutchfield grew up in Birmingham, Alabama, where she listened to Shania Twain, Lucinda Williams, and Gillian Welch. When she started performing, though, it was in punk-rock bands, and her solo career as Waxahatchee snaked from lo-fi folk to noisy rock before she finally returned to country music for 2020â€™s Saint Cloud. Newly sober, she found clarity in the unadorned sound â€” so she kept following it. (It also helped that sheâ€™d never lost her Alabama accent.) Crutchfieldâ€™s latest album, Tigers Blood, sees her settling in and stretching out in the genre.
Other artists made their way back too: Big Thief, Angel Olsen, and Wilco all released self-described country music after previously avoiding those roots in favor of more respected folk or rock. Unbound by Nashville gatekeepers, these artists could see country the way they wanted it to be. Big Thief accompanied hoedowns like â€œSpud Infinityâ€ and â€œRed Moonâ€ with glitchy electronic tracks like â€œBlurred View.â€ Olsen and Plains, the duo of Crutchfield and Jess Williamson, chased sounds that had long been out of fashion, like crisp â€˜70s countrypolitan and plucky turn-of-the-century Americana. Wilco, on their double album Cruel Country, used country and all its baggage as a form to exorcize American history and politics. None of these projects sounded like pivots, but rather, natural progressions of their work.
So does Donâ€™t Forget Me, the third album by Maggie Rogers. In the same Greenwich Village studio where Ian Fitchuk co-produced Musgravesâ€™s folky return Deeper Well, he helped bring a rawer element out of Rogersâ€™s songwriting, who stressed that the vibe of Donâ€™t Forget Me is â€œvintage, but not overly Americana.â€ â€œMy friends keep saying it sounds like the version of me that they know,â€ Rogers wrote to fans. As cheesy as the adage about â€œthree chords and the truthâ€ is, sometimes itâ€™s just true.
As artists found space for country music outside the industry, some in Nashville were becoming skeptical of its racist, sexist tendencies. In 2019, the fiddler and singer Amanda Shires formed the Highwomen with Maren Morris, Natalie Hemby, and Brandi Carlile to sing from Black, queer, and feminist perspectives, with little concern for radio or charts. The folk musician and scholar Rhiannon Giddens was working toward a similar goal when she founded Our Native Daughters, a quartet of Black female folk singers and banjo players, the same year.
It was a stark contrast to the mainstream, where Morgan Wallenâ€™s Dangerous was still topping charts even after he said a racial slur on video. Watching Wallen experience little consequence, Black country musicians and fans became more interested in building their own community â€” like the Black Opry, founded by Holly G in 2021. Generations of Black musicians before had struggled to find a place for themselves in the Nashville system, and now, their followers decided it was no longer a worthwhile goal. BeyoncÃ© would later turn to some of those same artists â€” Giddens, Tanner Adell, Willie Jones, Robert Randolph â€” on Cowboy Carter.
The flow of country music coming from outside Nashville is only set to continue. Lana Del Rey is approaching her new country album, Lasso, less as a fan than as a student of the American songbook. She teased the project last year by covering Tammy Wynetteâ€™s â€œStand by Your Man,â€ and later by performing â€œTake Me Home, Country Roads,â€ by John Denver, a man who never lived in Nashville or fit too well into the scene. Del Rey said she recorded some music in Nashville, but also in Mississippi and Muscle Shoals, Alabama â€” all integral sites to the genreâ€™s history. Maybe sheâ€™s a tourist, but at least she knows sheâ€™s chasing something that canâ€™t just be found on Music Row.
Zach Bryan has been doing that for years now. In 2022, he made his major-label debut with the triple album American Heartbreak, which bridges country, folk, and rock â€” and has topped all three corresponding Billboard charts. Music Row had little to do with the album, which he recorded in New York and released on Warner Recordsâ€™ main label. â€œAt the risk of sounding pretentious; I donâ€™t want a genre, I donâ€™t want a scene, I donâ€™t want a title, I just want to make music,â€ he wrote in the recordâ€™s liner notes.
Listeners gravitated toward something simple and old-fashioned in Bryanâ€™s music: the cutting emotion of the lyrics and the organic arrangements of the songs. So they found more of it. Tyler Childers, a country classicist who has been releasing music out of Kentucky for years, reached a new peak in 2023 when his song â€œIn Your Loveâ€ became an unlikely TikTok hit. By then, the Vermont singer-songwriter Noah Kahan had developed a massive following off his folky anthems of northeastern angst like â€œStick Season.â€ Kahan has never claimed much influence from country music, and thereâ€™s a pop sensibility to his soaring choruses. But without Nashville drawing the lines, fans were queuing up his songs right after Bryanâ€™s.
The successes of these artists are setting country up for one of its biggest years on record. But what does it mean when the genreâ€™s best music is being made away from its capital? The castle isnâ€™t quite crumbling, but the cracks are still there. With Nashville labels no longer releasing the coolest and most acclaimed new music, rising artists might start to wonder what value the cityâ€™s services have. When artists like Bryan and BeyoncÃ© decry the industry as backward, their words reach thousands of budding country fans, who are already finding what they want outside the system. Now itâ€™s on Nashville to regain their trust. The good news is that the solution is simple: Start listening everywhere else.

title: Courtney Love Calls Out Taylor Swift, Beyonce, Lana Del Rey, and More
content:
Courtney Love did not hold back when sharing her thoughts on the current crop of the biggest popstars in the world. The alt-rock icon, 59, didnâ€™t mince words in letting people know where she stands in terms of the music of Taylor Swift, Lana Del Rey, Madonna, and BeyoncÃ©. Sheâ€™s simply not a fan. The singer, who was married to Kurt Cobain, took shots at each singer while speaking to The Standard in an interview, published on Saturday, April 13.
Seeing as Courtneyâ€™s new BBC show is titled Courtney Loveâ€™s women, she discussed some of the most famous women in the music business. In terms of 2024, itâ€™s hard to be bigger than Taylor Swift, and despite many people singing the â€œAll Too Wellâ€ singerâ€™s praises, Courtneyâ€™s definitely not a Swiftie. â€œTaylor is not important. She might be a safe space for girls, and sheâ€™s probably the Madonna of now, but sheâ€™s not interesting as an artist,â€ she told The Standard.
Another woman that cannot be left out of the conversation when discussing the biggest popstars in the world is BeyoncÃ©. While Courtney supports the idea of Cowboy Carter, she also made it clear that she doesnâ€™t vibe with the music. â€ like the idea of BeyoncÃ© doing a country record because itâ€™s about Black women going into spaces where previously only white women have been allowed, not that I like it much. As a concept, I love it. I just donâ€™t like her music,â€ she said.
Speaking of popstars doing country songs, Courtney also called out Lana Del Rey for covering a country classic, advising her to take some time away. â€œI havenâ€™t liked Lana since she covered a John Denver song, and I think she should really take seven years off. Up until â€˜Take Me Home Country Roadsâ€™ I thought she was great,â€ she said, before admitting that she was a fan of her earlier work. â€œWhen I was recording my new album, I had to stop listening to her as she was influencing me too much.â€
To go back to Madonna, Courtney made it known that sheâ€™s definitely not a fan, and even made a jab at one of Madgeâ€™s most popular movies. â€œI donâ€™t like her and she doesnâ€™t like me. I loved Desperately Seeking Susan, but for the city of New York as much as her,â€ she said.
When it comes to female artists that Courtney is a fan of, she named punk icon Patti Smith, Nine Simone, alt-rock singer-songwriter PJ Harvey, jazz singer Julie London, and Joni Mitchell, as well as Debbie Harry and Blondie.

title: A Courtney Love no le interesa Taylor Swift, le aburre Lana Del Rey y no le gusta Madonna
content:
A estas alturas de la pelÃ­cula, nadie deberÃ­a sorprenderse por un titular polÃ©mico salido de la boca de Courtney Love (San Francisco, EE UU, 59 aÃ±os). La estrella del rock, piedra angular del movimiento grunge, fundadora y vocalista de Hole y pareja de Kurt Cobain, a menudo se ha convertido en protagonista de la historia mÃ¡s por sus frases que por todos sus mÃ©ritos. Recapitulemos: Love admitiÃ³ haber consumido heroÃ­na durante su embarazo y haber recibido el consejo mÃ©dico de abortar (eso sÃ­, la cantante no sabÃ­a que estaba embarazada mientras consumÃ­a, y dejÃ³ las drogas al momento de enterarse). Tras la muerte en 1994 de Cobain, locutÃ³ la nota de suicidio del lÃ­der de Nirvana en una grabaciÃ³n para todos los seguidores que se congregaron a las puertas de la casa de la pareja. Le lanzÃ³ un objeto no identificado (Â¿un pintalabios? Â¿Una mÃ¡scara de pestaÃ±as?) a Madonna durante una entrevista en la MTV en 1995, y entrÃ³ como un elefante en una cacharrerÃ­a en medio de la grabaciÃ³n. Cuando le quitaron durante 18 meses la custodia de su hija, Frances Bean Cobain, debido al abuso de sustancias, dijo en el juicio: â€œEs horrible, pero me lo merezcoâ€. En 2005, cuando una reportera le preguntÃ³ sobre una alfombra roja quÃ© consejo le darÃ­a a una aspirante a actriz, respondiÃ³: â€œMe van a demandar por difamaciÃ³n como diga esto, peroâ€¦ Si Harvey Weinstein te invita a una fiesta privada en el Four Seasons, no vayasâ€. A Love se le atribuyen perlas como: â€œSolo la gente imbÃ©cil es felizâ€, â€œSer una estrella del rock es como ser el lÃ­der de una secta, tienes tu propia religiÃ³nâ€ o â€œÂ¿Sabes lo que le da mÃ¡s dinero a esta industria? Los rockeros muertosâ€.
Recientemente ha concedido una entrevista al medio britÃ¡nico The Standard con motivo del estreno de su programa de radio Courtney Loveâ€™s Women (que se traducirÃ­a como Las mujeres de Courtney Love, pero fonÃ©ticamente tambiÃ©n suena a Courtney ama a las mujeres), que se ha estrenado este mes en BBC Radio 6 Music y BBC Sounds, donde la cantante comparte la banda sonora que la ha acompaÃ±ado en su vida, mientras reflexiona sobre las mujeres a las que admira en la industria y ofrece una crÃ³nica personal sobre su propia trayectoria y vida personal. Y algunas de sus nuevas declaraciones han resultado sorprendentes y virales, ya que no ha dudado en ser tan honesta como suele ser, y ha conseguido cabrear a todas las swifties del mundo. Â¿La razÃ³n? Taylor Swift no le resulta interesante: â€œTaylor no es importante. Puede que sea un espacio seguro para las chicas y probablemente sea la Madonna de ahora, pero no es interesante como artistaâ€. Tampoco le gusta Lana Del Rey: â€œNo me gusta Lana desde que hizo un cover de una canciÃ³n de John Denver, y creo que deberÃ­a tomarse siete aÃ±os de descansoâ€. Aunque, matiza, sÃ­ que le gustaba antes: â€œHasta Take Me Home, Country Roads pensÃ© que era genial. Cuando estaba grabando mi nuevo Ã¡lbum, tuve que dejar de escucharla porque me estaba influyendo demasiadoâ€. Y, por supuesto, no le gusta Madonna: â€œNo me gusta y a ella no le gusto. Me encantÃ³ Buscando a Susan desesperadamente, pero mÃ¡s por Nueva York que por ellaâ€.
La artista cuenta muchas mÃ¡s cosas en esa entrevista. Como, por ejemplo, que vive desde hace cinco aÃ±os en Londres, desde 2019, cuando se mudÃ³ para huir de Los Ãngeles junto a sus perritos pomerania, y donde se codea con personalidades de la talla de Kate Moss. Reconoce que es feliz en la capital britÃ¡nica: â€œSoy una anglÃ³fila. Amo Londres, es mi ciudad favorita y es el mejor lugar en el que he vivido. AquÃ­ hay leyes que me protegen cuando hablo con franqueza y me gustan los amigos que he hecho aquÃ­â€, reconoce Love.
Aunque lo interesante, sin duda, son sus opiniones. â€œLa gente solÃ­a decir que yo era muy difÃ­cil. Dijeron que era desagradable. SÃ­, soy completamente desagradable y nunca me disculparÃ© por eso. Siempre he querido que me conocieran por ser una cabrona. Ser querida nunca fue lo mÃ­o. Kurt querÃ­a agradar, pero yo no. Pudo esconderse detrÃ¡s de mÃ­, pero luego me odiaron. Entonces Kurt muriÃ³ y el odio hacia mÃ­ alcanzÃ³ un nivel completamente nuevo. No planeÃ© eso. Estoy totalmente a favor de sacarse el rabo en el escenario, como hizo Jim Morrison. Si tuviera rabo y estuviera lo suficientemente borracha, me lo hubiese sacado, igual que Jim. TenÃ­a alma de perra y estaba conforme con que no me quisieran. Vi a Bob Dylan en Donâ€™t Look Back y me di cuenta de que Ã©l no buscaba agradar y yo pensÃ©: â€˜Quiero ser asÃ­â€.
La cantante Courtney Love en el 'backstage' de los premios MTV de 1995, poco antes le habÃ­a lanzado un objeto no identificado a Madonna. Catherine McGann (Getty Images)
SegÃºn adelantan en The Standard, su podcast serializado es tambiÃ©n un recorrido sobre su vida, donde no esconde los detalles mÃ¡s escabrosos: habla de su paso por un centro de menores y de su lucha contra la adicciÃ³n, pero tambiÃ©n de cÃ³mo descubriÃ³ la mÃºsica disco, del dÃ­a que recitÃ³ un poema de Sylvia Plath en una audiciÃ³n para presentar el Mickey Mouse Club y, sobre todo, habla de mÃºsica. De Nina Simone y Billie Holiday, de Stevie Nicks y Debbie Harry y, sÃ­, tambiÃ©n de Kurt Cobain.
En cuanto a la mÃºsica de hoy en dÃ­a y las figuras mÃ¡s relevantes, Love lo tiene claro: â€œEs maravilloso ver a tantas mujeres teniendo Ã©xito en la industria de la mÃºsica, pero muchas de ellas se han vuelto un clichÃ©. Ahora, cada mujer exitosa es clonada, asÃ­ que hay un montÃ³n de mÃºsica y toda la mÃºsica es igual. Si te pones cualquier cosa en Spotify, inmediatamente despuÃ©s serÃ¡s bombardeado por un montÃ³n de cosas idÃ©nticas. No sÃ©, me gusta la idea de BeyoncÃ© haciendo un disco de country porque se trata de una mujer negra reclamando un espacio en el que antes solo se les permitÃ­a la entrada a las mujeres blancas, y eso me encanta. Como concepto me encanta. Pero no me gusta su mÃºsicaâ€.
Que nadie se atreva a llamar a Courtney Love mala feminista, en todo caso, y como ha demostrado en otras ocasiones, la cantante es opinativa y un tanto bocachancla, pero su programa trata de poner a las mujeres en el lugar que merecen: â€œCon mi programa intento redimir a algunas de las mujeres que han sido tan maltratadas por la industria discogrÃ¡fica. Eso es todo. DespuÃ©s de ver el Ã©xito de [la banda de chicas] The Runaways a mediados de la dÃ©cada de 1970, tuve la idea de que Hollywood estaba dirigido por chicas en bandas, o al menos, por chicas que querÃ­an follar con chicos en bandas. Vaya, me equivoquÃ©. Hollywood era como el resto de la industria musical: dirigida por hombres. Entonces no lo aceptÃ©. Dije. â€˜Y una mierdaâ€™. Productores, crÃ­ticos, mÃºsicos, todos hombres. Y las mujeres todavÃ­a estÃ¡n marginadas en esta industria, aunque tienen mÃ¡s Ã©xitoâ€, reconoce.

title: Del Eras Tour a Coachella: las botas de Louboutin que no se quitan Lana del Rey y Taylor Swift
content:
Hay unas botas que te convierten automÃ¡ticamente en diva del pop empoderada y exitosa. Son altas, tienen un tacÃ³n ancho, son brillantes y tienen la suela roja mÃ¡s aspiracional del universo del calzado: la que diferencia a su creador Christian Louboutin de otros diseÃ±adores. Y lo mÃ¡s importante: son las botas que han acompaÃ±ado a Taylor Swift durante toda su gira mundial.
Hasta el momento, eran una seÃ±a de identidad mÃ¡s del Eras Tour, el proyecto que ha convertido a Swift en milmilloraria. Pero hace unos dÃ­as fueron tambiÃ©n protagonistas del Festival de Coachella, donde Lana del Rey, gran amiga de Swift, tambiÃ©n las luciÃ³ sobre el escenario. Â¿QuÃ© tienen estas botas que no se quitan las artistas mÃ¡s importantes del mundo? Â¿Por quÃ© BeyoncÃ© y Ariana Grande tambiÃ©n han confiado en el creador de calzado francÃ©s para el diseÃ±o para sus tours?
Todo parece indicar que la comodidad y seguridad que experimentan las cantantes para moverse y bailar por escenarios gigantes es una de las claves del Ã©xito de Louboutin en el mundo de la mÃºsica. No hay que olvidar que el francÃ©s comenzÃ³ su carrera diseÃ±ando los zapatos para el music-hall parisino. Tras comprobar que sus creaciones soportaban las carreras constantes y a las exigentes coreografÃ­as de las bailarinas, por fin abriÃ³ su primera tienda en ParÃ­s.
Taylor Swift en su concierto de Glendale (Arizona), con las botas de Louboutin. Kevin Mazur (Getty Images for TAS Rights Mana)
SegÃºn explican desde la firma, todo el calzado que luce Taylor Swift en su gira fue creado especialmente para ella e inspirado en las diferentes eras de su carrera. â€œNuestra maison produjo una gama de siluetas, tanto personalizadas como ya existentes, de diversas formas y alturas de tacÃ³n, con intrincados bordados de cristal aplicados a mano uno a uno y con diferentes combinaciones de colores. Para abrir el espectÃ¡culo, miles de brillantes cristales de strass adornan la bota Eleonora, un modelo clÃ¡sico hasta la rodilla con un escultural tacÃ³n y la caracterÃ­stica suela roja, creando un espectacular juego de luces. Igual de luminosa es la bota Cate con la que Taylor baila Fearlessâ€, detallan.
Encima del escenario, Swift combina el calzado de Louboutin con diferentes bodys tambiÃ©n de cristales firmados por Cavalli y Versace y vestidos de Oscar de la Renta.
AdemÃ¡s de la comodidad, las botas de Louboutin confieren a las artistas que las lucen un halo de diosas inalcanzables. Uno de los modelos de bota mÃ¡s sencillos de la firma supera los 1.700 euros en la tienda online. Uno de estos diseÃ±os hechos a medida con cristales bordados a mano, tiene un precio incalculable. Algo solo al alcance de las mÃ¡s poderosas estrellas de la mÃºsica.

title: Courtney Love Rips Taylor Swift, BeyoncÃ©, Madonna & Lana Del Rey
content:
With a new BBC radio series now launched, Courtney Love is once again proving the power of the adage â€œgo large or go home.â€
In a wide ranging interview with the UKâ€™s Standard today, the former Hole front woman puts forth her take on some of the biggest names in the music industry. Letâ€™s just say, Love bites in deep in the newspaper, to quote from her 1998 tune â€œCelebrity Skin,â€ to get her pound of flesh from Taylor Swift, BeyoncÃ©, Madonna and recent Coachella headliner Lana Del Rey.
â€œTaylor is not important,â€ the People vs. Larry Flint star says of the superstar.
â€œShe might be a safe space for girls, and sheâ€™s probably the Madonna of now, but sheâ€™s not interesting as an artist,â€ Love added.
The contrarian opinion on Swift is a big shift from where Love was on the Folklore singer just over two years ago. Back in a Facebook post on December 22, 2021, Love wished Swift a â€œhappy birthdayâ€ and called her an â€œaspirational huge role model for many young women.â€ The post also features a photo of Love and her â€œoccasional hair twin/neighbor.â€
No word on why the Swift love from Love has eroded, but itâ€™s worth noting that in 2021, she didnâ€™t have an eight-part BBC Radio 6 series on Woman in music to promote.
Speaking of Madonna, the touring Material Girl is not favorite of Loveâ€™s either â€“ and the feeling is evidently mutual. â€œI donâ€™t like her and she doesnâ€™t like me,â€ the RuPaulâ€™s Drag Race guest judge stated. â€œI loved Desperately Seeking Susan, but for the city of New York as much as her,â€ she went on to say in a stinging back-handed compliment.
Never shy to share her opinions over the years, Love in 2005 warned actresses to stay away from Harvey Weinstein. Repeating this remarks in late 2017 as the New York Times dropped its explosive expose on the now incarcerated producer, Love said her comments from 12 years beforehand had earned her CAAâ€˜s wrath. Over the decades, Love has also had sharp words for the likes of her deceased husband Kurt Cobainâ€™s bandmate Dave Grohl, No Doubtâ€™s and The Voiceâ€™s Gwen Stefani, Olivia Rodrigo, her almost Fight Club co-star Brad Pitt, and former Nine Inch Nails leader and soundtrack composer Trent Reznor, among many others.
(L-R) Gwen Stefani of No Doubt and Olivia Rodrigo perform at the 2024 Coachella Stage John Shearer/Getty Images for No Doubt
Today, BeyoncÃ© and Lana Del Rey were added to the list.
â€œI havenâ€™t liked Lana since she covered a John Denver song, and I think she should really take seven years off,â€ Love told the Dylan Jones-led Standard. About a year or so ago, Love called Del Rey a â€œmusical geniusâ€ and compared her to Nirvanaâ€™s Cobain.
As for the chart-topping Cowboy Carter performer, Love asserted: I like the idea of BeyoncÃ© doing a country record because itâ€™s about Black women going into spaces where previously only white women have been allowed, not that I like it much. As a concept, I love it. I just donâ€™t like her music.â€
If you wonder, if there is anyone Love does like. There is. Patti Smith, Blondieâ€™s Debbie Harry, Nina Simone, and Billie Holiday, plus early albums by PJ Harvey and Joni Mitchell, get a thumbs up from the past Golden Globe nominee and grunge icon, at least for now.
Absent Loveâ€™s love, coming off blockbuster tours last year, Swift and BeyoncÃ© both took over the big screen with their box office topping Taylor Swift | The Eras Tour and Renaissance: A Film by BeyoncÃ© releases. BeyoncÃ©â€™s March 29 dropped Cowboy Carter was her eighth consecutive number #1 album on the Billboard Top 200, and the first album by a Black woman to soar to the top of the Country charts. Swiftâ€™s new album The Tortured Poet Department comes out on April 19 and is expected to debut at number #1.

title: Courtney Love says Taylor Swift is â€˜not interestingâ€™ or â€˜important'
content:
Click to email a link to a friend (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
Courtney Love didnâ€™t hold back when asked how she felt about several popular female artists â€” including Taylor Swift.
According to an interview published by the Standard Monday, the 59-year-old â€œpositively hates the ideaâ€ of Swift.
â€œTaylor is not important,â€ Love said of the 14-time Grammy winner. â€œShe might be a safe space for girls, and sheâ€™s probably the Madonna of now, but sheâ€™s not interesting as an artist.â€
10 â€œTaylor is not important,â€ she told the Standard in an interview published Monday. Facebook/Courtney Love
10 â€œShe might be a safe space for girls, and sheâ€™s probably the Madonna of now, but sheâ€™s not interesting as an artist,â€ she continued. Getty Images for TAS Rights Management
Love made the shocking statement while promoting her new series, â€œCourtney Loveâ€™s Women,â€ in which she reflects on the various women in music who have shaped her career.
However, her comments didnâ€™t sit right with Swifites and many pointed out that Love seemingly liked Swift enough to wish the â€œCruel Summerâ€ singer a happy birthday on Facebook just a few years ago.
For more Page Six you loveâ€¦
â€œHappy belated birthday @taylorswift, aspirational huge role model for many young women & occasional hair twin / neighbour,â€ Love wrote in December 2021 alongside a photo of the two.
After slamming the â€œAnti-Heroâ€ singer, Love didnâ€™t mince words when mentioning Lana Del Rey, who she said â€œshould really take seven years off.â€
10 Loveâ€™s comments quickly made her a few enemies amongst the Grammy winnerâ€™s fans. SplashNews.com
10 Several pointed out that she wished the â€œCruel Summerâ€ songstress a happy birthday a few years ago on Facebook. Getty Images for MTV
â€œI havenâ€™t liked Lana since she covered a John Denver song,â€ she said of the â€œYoung & Beautifulâ€ singer. â€œUp until â€˜Take Me Home Country Roadsâ€™ I thought she was great.â€
Despite not liking Del Reyâ€™s music, Love admitted that she had to stop listening to the Coachella headliner while recording her new album because it was â€œinfluencing [her] too much.â€
Love â€” who also said she doesnâ€™t â€œlikeâ€ Madonna â€” then took one final shot at BeyoncÃ©, who recently became the first black woman to lead the Top Country Albums Chart following the release of â€œCowboy Carter.â€
10 â€œHappy belated birthday @taylorswift, aspirational huge role model for many young women & occasional hair twin / neighbour,â€ Love wrote in December 2021. Kevin Mazur Archive 1/WireImage.
10 During the interview, Love also took a jab at Swiftâ€™s bestie Lana Del Rey. REUTERS
â€œI mean, I like the idea of BeyoncÃ© doing a country record because itâ€™s about Black women going into spaces where previously only white women have been allowed, not that I like it much,â€ she said.
â€œAs a concept, I love it. I just donâ€™t like her music.â€
Following her comments, fans from several different corners of the internet took to X to blast the â€œMonoâ€ singer for â€œpublicly putting down fellow female artistsâ€ while promoting a series that is supposed to be about the importance of women in music.
â€œShe is jealous, I donâ€™t even know her,â€ one fan wrote. â€œTaylor is a world-class artist.â€
10 â€œI havenâ€™t liked Lana since she covered a John Denver song,â€ she added. AFP via Getty Images
10 Several people took to social media to slam the â€œMonoâ€ singer. Dave Benett/Getty Images for National Portrait Gallery
â€œCourtney love always coming for women younger and prettier than her, like go find something to do granny,â€ another wrote.
â€œ100 years from now, the name Courtney Love will mean nothing,â€ a third fan added. â€œNot a single person will know who she is. But when Taylor Swift is mentioned, people will remember how she was able to connect with millions of people thru [sic] her music, cherished her fans, and fought for artistsâ€™ rights.â€
â€œIâ€™m laughing at people being shocked that Courtney Love is hating on other female artists,â€ a fourth joked. â€œWelcome to 1992!!! Homegirl has been a hater since the 90s.â€
10 â€œShe is jealous, I donâ€™t even know her,â€ one person wrote. Kevin Mazur Archive 1/WireImage.
10 â€œCourtney love always coming for women younger and prettier than her, like go find something to do granny,â€ another chimed in. WireImage for New York Post
However, Love seems to agree.
In her interview, the musician admitted that she is â€œcompletely disagreeableâ€ and said she is â€œnever going to [apologize] for that.â€
â€œI always wanted to be known as a bitch,â€ she added. â€œBeing liked was never my thing.â€

title: Courtney Love disses fellow singers Taylor Swift, Madonna, BeyoncÃ©: â€˜Not importantâ€™
content:
Courtney Love disses fellow singers Taylor Swift, Madonna, BeyoncÃ©
Courtney Love disrespectfully takes dig at fellow singers including Taylor Swift, BeyoncÃ©, Lana Del Rey and Madonna over her talent and life choices.
The singer started to question Taylor Swift first in her recent interview with The Standard. â€œTaylor is not important. She might be a safe space for girls, and sheâ€™s probably the Madonna of now, but sheâ€™s not interesting as an artist.â€
Not only this, Love didnâ€™t spare Madonna either showing hatred towards her: â€œI donâ€™t like her and she doesnâ€™t like me.â€
Elsewhere in the interview, Love also mentioned how much she dislikes BeyoncÃ©â€™s new country hit, Cowboy Carter, despite appreciating the albumâ€™s symbolism being â€œabout Black women going into spaces where previously only white women have been allowed.â€
â€œAs a concept, I love it,â€ Love said. â€œI just donâ€™t like her music.â€
Love went on to express her hatred adding another name, Lana Del Rey. â€œI think she should really take seven years off,â€ she said, noting she hasnâ€™t enjoyed Lanaâ€™s music â€œsince she covered a John Denver song.â€
â€œUp until â€˜Take Me Home Country Roadsâ€™ I thought she was great,â€ Love continued. â€œWhen I was recording my new album, I had to stop listening to her as she was influencing me too much.â€
The singer didnâ€™t stop here. She further criticised female musicians for converging in style.
â€œItâ€™s great that there are so many successful women in the music industry, but lots of them are becoming a clichÃ©,â€ she said. â€œNow, every successful woman is cloned, so there is just too much music. Theyâ€™re all the same. If you play something on Spotify, you get bombarded with a lot of stuff thatâ€™s exactly the same.â€

content:

En matiÃ¨re de surprise, c'est Shakira qui a dÃ©boulÃ© sur la scÃ¨ne du dÃ©sert californien pour Ã©lectriser un peu plus le set de son acolyte, le producteur et DJ argentin Bizarrap. Cette annÃ©e, c'est Peso Pluma â€“ cinquiÃ¨me artiste le plus Ã©coutÃ© dans le monde sur Spotify en 2023 â€“ qui a attirÃ© une immense foule avec son style unique, fusion des musiques rÃ©gionales mexicaines traditionnelles, de rap latino et de reggaeton. title: Billie Eilish: "Stimmen der Generation" verzaubern Coachella-Festival
content:
Indio/Kalifornien (USA) - Das Coachella-Festival gilt seit jeher als Mekka der Festival-Kultur. In diesem Jahr begeistern unter anderem Headliner Lana Del Rey (38) und US-Rapperin Doja Cat (28) die Massen.
Lana Del Rey (38) stÃ¼rmte unter anderem im Jahr 2012 mit "Summertime Sandes" die Charts. Â© Evan Agostini/Invision/AP/dpa

title: Lana Del Rey welcomes Billie Eilish as her Coachella duet guest
content:
Lana Del Rey had a couple of heavily favored cameos during her Coachella performance Friday, welcoming recent collaborators Jack Antonoff and Jon Batiste, both of whom will be fronting their own sets later in the weekend â€” but also one far less easily guessed guest, in the form of Billie Eilish, who turned up for a surprise pair of duets.
Taking to a terrace overlooking the massive stage, the duo first joined forces on Eilishâ€™s â€œOcean Eyes,â€ then turned their voices to â€œVideo Games.â€ Both songs represent the first real breakout hits in these artistsâ€™ respective careers.
The two traded fangirl notes as their joint appearance came to a close. Enthused Del Rey about her singing partner: â€œThatâ€™s the voice of our generation, the voice of your generation, and iâ€™m so f---ing grateful sheâ€™s standing next to me right now singing my favorite song.â€
Eilish retorted, â€œGet the f--- out of my face,â€ as they both fell into laughter.
â€œThis is the reason for half you b-----sâ€™ existence â€” including mine!â€ Eilish further told the crowd. â€œLana Del Rey, you guys, come on!â€
The emergence of Eilish onto the stage followed a lengthy turn by Batiste as he and Del Rey recreated â€œCandy Necklace,â€ a song they worked up together for Del Reyâ€™s most recent album, 2023â€™s â€œDid You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd.â€ The song was nominated for best pop duoâ€™group performance at the 2024 Grammys. For most of the tune, Batiste played piano while she kneeled atop the instrument, but after she stepped down toward the end, they began spontaneously trading vocal lines.
â€œSometimes you need somebody elseâ€™s spirit to move with you, and thatâ€™s always going to be Jon Batiste,â€ said the headliner.
Following Eilishâ€™s appearance, Del Rey was joined by her co-producer and co-writer of late, Antonoff, for a reading of â€œHope Is a Dangerous Thing for a Woman Like Me â€” but I Have It.â€ Or at least some version of her was joined by Antonoff: He was playing piano very definitely in the flesh, but she appeared as an oversized hologram, just for that one number. The track dates back to her â€œNormal F---ing Rockwellâ€ album from 2019.Her setlist included some live rarities, including opening with â€œWithout You,â€ which fans say she has not performed since 2014, and her cover of Sublimeâ€™s â€œDoinâ€™ Time,â€ which she hasnâ€™t done since 2019 â€” possibly a nod to the fact that a contemporary iteration of Sublime is also booked for Coachella.
Del Rey didnâ€™t need any of her guests to make an impression, most viewers on-site or watching via the YouTube livestream would agree. She had certainly one of the more memorable entrances and exits in Coachella history, riding in and out through the audience, via walled off sections splitting up the crowd, on the back of a motorcycle, sometimes standing and/or blowing kisses as she passed by. Her six dancers trailed her, also holding onto motorcycle drivers, in motorcades that lasted minutes.

title: Lana Del Rey + Billie Eilish Duet at Coachella Resurrection
content:
Photo: YouTube/Coachella
Lana Del Rey promised a resurrection for her headlining spot at Coachella this weekendâ€” on her billboard posted on the way to the festival referenced her â€œdeathâ€ after being crucified for her Saturday Night Live performance in 2012. However, she said nothing about bringing out her disciple Billie Eilish to sing â€œocean eyesâ€ and â€œVideo Games.â€ And how could she? By the time they finished harmonizing their whispers, they were stunned by each otherâ€™s presence. â€œGet the fuck out of my face,â€ joked Eilish after the performance. The two continued to gush over each other, with Del Rey raising up her protege. She praised, â€œYep, thatâ€™s the voice of your generation, the voice of our generation. Iâ€m so fucking grateful sheâ€™s standing next to me right now singing my favorite song of hers.â€ Eilish replied by giving the flower (crowns) back to the woman who influenced her, â€œThis is the reason for half you bitches existence, including mine.â€ Sheâ€™s not wrong; thou shalt be saved listening to Lana Del Rey.

title: Lana Del Rey at Coachella review - a disappointingly lifeless start to the festival
content:
The cliche image of Lana Del Rey â€“ flower crown, heart-shaped sunglasses, Lolita pout â€“ matches the cliche of a Coachella girl. Both Del Rey and the festival saw a peak in the mid-2010s, during the early years of influencer culture excess. So it makes sense that Coachellaâ€™s golden girl would headline â€¦ even though, in 2024, Del Rey doing so feels about a decade too late.
Indeed, Del Rey first played Coachella exactly 10 years to the day before Fridayâ€™s opening night performance, as she proudly told the crowd. This time, she rode in on a biker motorcade, clad in a baby blue sequin dress, smiling and waving like the beauty queens sheâ€™s prone to singing about. It was ambitious, lively crowd work â€“ literal momentum to started the show off right. But then she opened her mouth.
Del Rey has become an icon for the dour and terminally online, in no small part to her well-known shtick: being too cool and half there. Unfortunately, her signature laconic delivery just didnâ€™t work for such a big stage, and came off as unprepared rather than unbothered.
Ongoing mic problems plagued her set the whole way through, causing awkward stops, starts and moments where she just motioned for the singing crowd to pick up the slack for her.
Her pitchy, faltering vocals were reminiscent of her disastrous 2012 Saturday Night Live performance, sometimes dubbed the worst in the showâ€™s history. (Whether or not that dubious distinction is fair or not is an argument for another day.) Back then, critics tore her vacant, yet somehow also trying-too-hard, turn to shreds. Del Rey has redeemed herself in the years since via some very good music, and enough time has passed that she can joke about the fiasco.
While driving into town, I noticed that Del Rey poked fun at the SNL mishap on a billboard that referenced its airdate. I assume it was supposed to be a joke intended to show how far sheâ€™s come. Instead, I fear it served as an omen.
Was this a headline act, or a hostage-proof-of-life video? A woman standing next to me and I burst out laughing at Del Reyâ€™s lifeless delivery of the Summertime Sadness opening line â€œIâ€™m feeling electric tonightâ€ because, well, clearly she was not. Background dancers gave their all behind her, landing balletic, lyrical moves. At one point, when she attempted to artfully drape herself over one, it looked as if she might fall asleep right there.
Del Rey maintained her capacity to surprise, though. Just when it felt as if she hit peak indifference watching, stalking around the stage and mumbling lyrics as if she had nothing better to do with her time, she transitioned into a segment where she lay on the stage and sang, straight up bed-rotting her way though Coachella.

We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. after newsletter promotion
Itâ€™s bad luck Del Rey had so many issues with her mic. But she canâ€™t blame the lackluster scene on technical difficulties alone. When she brought out guest stars Jon Batiste and Billie Eilish, or even duetted with her background singers, their voices sounded rich and full, while hers sounded like what you hear at sorority karaoke night. The audience stayed polite, and diehard fans were going to have a good time anyway. About 20 minutes into the show, however, attendees started to leave early, and this stream of quitters did not end.
Much of the audience hemorrhaged by the time that Eilish, Del Reyâ€™s rumored and hotly anticipated main special guest, came out. Thatâ€™s a shame, because their performance of Video Games proved to be the highlight. Del Rey gushed over Eilish, calling her â€œthe voice of a generationâ€. And Eilish gave us the line of the day when she pointed to Del Rey, the OG flower crown influencer, and said: â€œThis is the reason for half of you bitchesâ€™ existence.â€

title: Peso Pluma, Lana & Billie, ATEEZ
content:
The first day of this yearâ€™s Coachella was loaded with memorable moments, from the genesis of a new hashtag to a bevy of special guest stars to Lana Del Reyâ€˜s profound â€” and profoundly weird â€” headlining performance. Among the established acts playing on Friday were recently-minted superstar Peso Pluma, Lil Uzi Vert and Justice, while rising artists like Chappell Roan, ChlÃ¶e and ATEEZ also got a chance to shine on some of the festivalâ€™s smaller stages.
Del Reyâ€™s performance proved to be a showstopper from the very beginning, when the singer-songwriter rode the back of a motorcycle in a caravan to the main stage. The noteworthy moments continued with the appearance of special guest stars Jon Batiste, Jack Antonoff and Billie Eilish â€” the latter of whom performed a pair of gorgeous duets with Del Rey: â€œOcean Eyesâ€ and Del Reyâ€™s breakthrough hit â€œVideo Games.â€ The roughly 90-minute performance also boasted some truly stunning set design, a bizarrely alluring hologram moment, Del Reyâ€™s trademark sultry vocals, a generous helping of faded glamour and even some stripper pole twirling by the singer herself for good measure.
This was just the first day of the three-day festivalâ€™s first weekend, which continues tomorrow with a headlining performance by Tyler, the Creator as well as a special reunion appearance by No Doubt. On Sunday, the festival continues with a headlining set by Doja Cat.
Below, you can find all the highlights from Coachella day one, with additional recaps to follow on Saturday and Sunday.

title: Lana Del Rey's Headlining Set
content:
Not only did Lana Del Rey start her Coachella headlining set early, but her entry was epic.
On Friday, April 12, at 11:16 p.m. the festival main stage screens showed an aerial view of Del Rey and her entourage rapidly approaching. As she neared, it became clear her crew was not rolling up on the expected golf carts that often shuttle stars around the Indio, Calif. fest, but rather motorcycles. And as a snippet of her never-to-be-officially-released song â€œJealous Girlâ€ played â€“ with the lyric â€œBaby, Iâ€™m a gangster tooâ€ on loop â€“ Del Reyâ€™s motorcade took a lap through the crowd as she smiled and waved to the thousands of fans gathered for this very moment.
â€œWhatâ€™s up, Coachella,â€ she asked casually, after making her way to center stage and offering a small smile before performing â€œWithout Youâ€ into a fusion of Sublimeâ€™s â€œDoinâ€™ Timeâ€ with â€œSummertime Sadness.â€ â€œIâ€™m so happy to be here,â€ she added with another faint, and even briefer, smile. But keep in mind, this is Lana Del Rey â€“ sad girl pop president and eternally committed to the bit, whether sheâ€™s headlining Coachella or not.
Explore Explore Lana Del Rey See latest videos, charts and news See latest videos, charts and news
As such, her demeanor matched the elaborate set design that looked much like a dilapidated version of the Gatsby Mansion long after it had thrown its last party. Making it, of course, the perfect imaginary scene for Del Rey to host a late-night shindig of her own complete with a swing band and roaring 20s-inspired backup dancers.
Trending on Billboard
Early into the set, Del Rey noted that she last played Coachella â€œexactly 10 years ago to the dayâ€ (during which she debuted single â€œWest Coastâ€), before softly speak-singing, â€œWeâ€™re still doing it.â€ Yet, itâ€™s not the fact that she is still here a decade in thatâ€™s impressive, but more so that she is still entirely and unapologetically herself after so many years â€“ or at least, that the persona of Lana Del Rey is still so intact. In fact, across her nine studio albums, Del Rey has seemingly become even more herself, taking bigger experimental swings and offering longer, more eyebrow-raising track titles along the way.
And tonight, her headlining set seemed to be a quiet celebration of such, during which Del Rey sauntered across the stage performing career-spanning hits that, in a festival setting like Coachella, felt almost like underground gems that she was carefully unearthing. Even the expected â€œheadliner stuntsâ€ were delivered with a delicate touch: She performed â€œRideâ€ while slowly spinning from within a circular, leaf-covered swing; delivered a gorgeous a cappella rendition of â€œThe Grantsâ€ alongside her trio of backup singers; and, most notably of all, sang â€œHope Is a Dangerous Thing for a Woman Like Me to Have â€“ but I Have Itâ€ via hologram accompanied by collaborator and close friend Jack Antonoff on piano, who co-produced the track. (Earlier in the night, she was joined by Jon Batiste on piano for an extended version of â€œCandy Necklace.â€)
The hologram â€“ though a bit morbid, especially considering the lyric, â€œHello, itâ€™s the most famous woman you know on the iPad/Calling from beyond the graveâ€ â€“ perfectly punctuated the spirit of the set. As evidenced by her closing song selection of â€œYoung and Beautifulâ€ (which was prominently used in The Great Gatsby), it became increasingly clear that Del Rey had come to make a statement.
As she sings on â€œYoung and Beautiful: â€œIâ€™ve seen the world, done it all, had my cake now. Iâ€™ve seen the world, lit it up as my stage now.â€ All the while, the songâ€™s primary question loomed: â€œWill you still love me when Iâ€™m no longer young and beautiful?â€
Earlier in the night, Billie Eilish delivered an affirmative answer.
Following online rumors that the superstar would be making a guest appearance during Del Reyâ€™s set (an artist Eilish has long been a fan of), she appeared toward its end atop the arched trellis to duet on â€œOcean Eyesâ€ and â€œVideo Gamesâ€ with Del Rey. After the two were done, they sat a moment longer, seeming genuinely stunned by one anotherâ€™s presence. â€œGet the fâ€“k out of my face,â€ laughed Eilish, speaking to her hero.
â€œYep, thatâ€™s the voice of your generation, the voice of our generation,â€ replied Del Rey. â€œIâ€m so fâ€”ing grateful sheâ€™s standing next to me right now.â€ To which Eilish replied: â€œThis is the reason for half you bâ€”-es existence, including mine.â€
That simple sentence cut to the core of the evening. Sure, the set was spotty at parts â€“ with moments of darkness and silence in between many songs and a handful of issues with mic volume, all of which Del Rey audibly called out. And yes, Del Reyâ€™s soft-spoken tendencies on and off stage may have not made her the most obvious headlining act to kick-off Coachella. But itâ€™s her impact that remains undeniable.
But donâ€™t take my word for it, take it from â€œthe voice of our generation.â€ The artist who we may not have had it not been for an artist like Lana Del Rey doing what she has and will always do best: being Lana Del Rey.
As she delivered the final note of â€œYoung and Beautiful,â€ the band picked up steam and her dancers reappeared with champagne bottles in hand as fireworks exploded into the night sky â€“ all the makings of a signature Gatsby blowout. And as Del Rey rode off on motorcycle, just as she came in, the party on stage continued long after she was gone. And thatâ€™s the point.
Her undeniable impact is also unforgettable â€“ and exactly what makes Lana Del Rey the icon she is. And one well worth the celebration.

title: Lana Del Rey Welcomes Billie Eilish as Coachella Guest for Two Duets
content:
Lana Del Rey had a couple of heavily favored cameos during her Coachella performance, welcoming recent collaborators Jack Antonoff and Jon Batiste, both of whom will be fronting their own sets later in the weekend â€” but also one far less easily guessed guest, in the form of Billie Eilish, who turned up for a surprise pair of duets.
Taking to a terrace overlooking the massive stage, the duo first joined forces on Eilishâ€™s â€œOcean Eyes,â€ then turned their voices to â€œVideo Games.â€ Both songs represent the first real breakout hits in these artistsâ€™ respective careers.
The two traded fangirl notes as their joint appearance came to a close. Enthused Del Rey about her singing partner: â€œThatâ€™s the voice of our generation, the voice of your generation, and iâ€™m so fucking grateful sheâ€™s standing next to me right now singing my favorite song.â€
Eilish retorted, â€œGet the fuck out of my face,â€ as they both fell into laughter.
Popular on Variety
â€œThis is the reason for half you bitchesâ€™ existence â€” including mine!â€ Eilish further told the crowd. â€œLana Del Rey, you guys, come on!â€
Lana Del Rey and Billie Eilish at Coachella
The emergence of Eilish onto the stage followed a lengthy turn by Batiste as he and Del Rey recreated â€œCandy Necklaces,â€ a song they worked up together for Del Reyâ€™s most recent album, 2023â€™s â€œDid You Know Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd.â€ The song was nominated for best pop duoâ€™group performance at the 2024 Grammys. For most of the tune, Batiste played piano while she kneeled atop the instrument, but after she stepped down toward the end, they began spontaneously trading vocal lines.
â€œSometimes you need somebody elseâ€™s spirit to move with you, and thatâ€™s always going to be Jon Batiste,â€ said the headliner.
Following Eilishâ€™s appearance, Del Rey was joined by her co-producer and co-writer of late, Antonoff, for a reading of â€œHope Is a Dangerous Thing for a Woman Like Me â€” but I Have It.â€ Or at least some version of her was joined by Antonoff: He was playing piano very definitely in the flesh, but she appeared as an oversized hologram, just for that one number. The track dates back to her â€œNormal Fucking Rockwellâ€ album from 2019.
Her setlist included some live rarities, including opening with â€œWithout You,â€ which fans say she has not performed since 2014, and her cover of Sublimeâ€™s â€œDoinâ€™ Time,â€ which she hasnâ€™t done since 2019 â€” possibly a nod to the fact that a contemporary iteration of Sublime is also booked for Coachella.
Del Rey didnâ€™t need any of her guests to make an impression, most viewers on-site or watching via the YouTube livestream would agree. She had certainly one of the more memorable entrances and exits in Coachella history, riding in and out through the audience, via walled off sections splitting up the crowd, on the back of a motorcycle, sometimes standing and/or blowing kisses as she passed by. Her six dancers trailed her, also holding onto motorcycle drivers, in motorcades that lasted minutes.
The hour-and-a-half set was well received by the massive crowd, either in spite of or because of offering such different moods and musical fare than what had preceded it during the day. The live singing and instrumentation was just one obvious point of demarcation from some other Coachella artists seen throughout the day. Low on the highly aggro qualities emphasized by some other performers, the Del Rey show was all about gentle, if determined, feminine energy, with Del Rey and her female dancers and backup singers wearing dresses and singing softly or beauteously, while, of course, putting this low-key energy to use on the bold themes sheâ€™s famous for.
From the very first drone (or Steadicam) shots of her motorcades, on through to what almost counted as delicate pole dancing, to a succession of piano ballads in the second half of the set, her show was characterized by what might have been described a late-night vibe, even if it hadnâ€™t started (on schedule) at 11:20 p.m. and lasted nearly till 1. That easygoing sense of summertime sadness is no easy thing to pull off in a climactic slot: Perhaps only Del Rey could turn in a headlining festival set this laid-back, or even sweet, and still utterly reassert herself as an alpha in the process.

title: Lana Del Rey Headlines First Night of Coachella 2024
content:
Lana Del Rey was the Friday headliner at the 2024 Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. She performed at the Indio, California, festival for the first time since her 2014 debut. Watch a replay of her performance below.
Del Rey began her Coachella performance with the Born to Die bonus song â€œWithout You.â€ She went on to perform songs from Ultraviolence, Norman Fucking Rockwell!, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, and more.
Eventually, Del Rey brought out Jon Batiste for â€œCandy Necklace,â€ Billie Eilish for â€œOcean Eyesâ€ and â€œVideo Games,â€ and Jack Antonoff for â€œHope Is a Dangerous Thing for a Woman Like Me to Have - But I Have It.â€
Del Rey attended at least one other Coachellaâ€”as an audience memberâ€”in 2017, which became the subject of her single â€œCoachella - Woodstock in My Mind.â€ The track alludes to Father John Mistyâ€™s set that year, which she filmed from the crowd.
Lana Del Rey released her most recent full-length, Did You Know That Thereâ€™s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd, last year. The LP netted her multiple Grammy nominationsâ€”for Album of the Year and Best Alternative Music Album. The single â€œA&Wâ€ also earned a nod for Song of the Year. Despite her multiple nominations, Del Rey has still not been recognized with a Grammy win.
Del Rey has continued to hint at more new music: She teased a song called â€œHenry, Come Onâ€ earlier this year, and sheâ€™s promised a new country album titled Lasso. In addition, on Valentineâ€™s Day, the singer-songwriter shared a cover of Irving Berlinâ€™s 1920s classic â€œBlue Skies.â€
Follow along with all of Pitchforkâ€™s coverage of Coachella 2024.
